Jerry, the son of a shoe manufacturer and businessman, had been married once before in his late twenties after attending the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School and becoming a consultant in Boston. His former wife had retained her maiden name. When Connie married Jerry, she did as well. A few years later, they moved from Chicago back to their hometown of St. Louis.

杰瑞从事房地产和物业管理行业，曾担任圣路易斯开发商罗伯茨公司的首席法律顾问兼副总裁。杰瑞善于与人打交道。他热衷于经济适用房，并参与了多个旨在促进社区发展、振兴圣路易斯的商业和住宅项目。萨姆后来重复了父亲教给他的最重要的一课：“你总是帮助别人——即使你认为自己没有时间，你也会想办法解决。”

Jerry went into real estate and property management, for a time serving as chief counsel and vice president of the Roberts Companies, a St. Louis developer. Jerry was a people person. He had a passion for affordable housing and worked on several commercial and residential projects that sought to foster community and revitalize St. Louis. Sam would later repeat one of the biggest lessons his father taught him: “You always help people—even if you don’t think you have time, you figure it out.”

康妮和杰瑞接连生了三个儿子：萨姆之后是马克斯，然后是杰克。五年后——萨姆出生九年后——康妮生下了安妮，她终于有了一个女儿，欣喜若狂。康妮自称无神论者，但文化上属于犹太教；杰瑞则更加虔诚。他会参加逾越节等犹太重要节日的礼拜，并坚持四个孩子都要举行犹太成年礼和成人礼。康妮的理性和自律，以及杰瑞的……他们的灵性和对服务的关注会以不同的方式体现在他们的孩子身上。

Connie and Jerry had three boys in rapid succession: After Sam, there was Max, then Jack. Five years later—nine years after Sam—Connie gave birth to Annie, delighted to finally have a daughter. Connie referred to herself as an atheist but culturally Jewish; Jerry was more religious. He attended services during Jewish high holidays like Passover and insisted on all four children having bat and bar mitzvahs, Jewish coming-of-age ceremonies. Connie’s rationality and discipline and Jerry’s spirituality and focus on service would each manifest in their children in various ways.

—

—

山姆从小就充满动力和好奇心。两岁时，他学会了操作家里的录像机；三岁时，他就开始修理录像机了。五年后，父母送给他一台Mac电脑，他很快就学会了如何编程和拆卸电脑。他很好地适应了哥哥的角色，有时对弟弟妹妹们颐指气使，有时又充当他们的看护人。他极具竞争力，总是坚持要赢棋盘游戏。

From a young age, Sam was driven and intensely curious. At two, he learned how to operate the family VCR; by three, he was fixing it. When his parents gifted him a Mac computer five years later, he quickly learned how to program and disassemble it. He settled well into the role of oldest brother, at times bossing around his younger siblings, at times playing their caretaker. He was extremely competitive, always insistent on winning board games.

尽管萨姆是个输不起的人，但他也渴望胜利。当祖母给每个孙辈送股票时，他选了苹果公司，杰克选了苹果蜂公司。这成了家里一个流传已久的笑话。二十多年来，杰克的股票几乎没有增长，而萨姆的却一路飙升。“你的苹果公司涨了——我都不想去想，”杰克后来回忆起这件事时说，“涨了几百倍。”

As much as Sam was a sore loser, he also had a zest for victory. When his grandmother gifted each of her grandchildren some stock, he picked Apple; Jack picked Applebee’s. It became a running joke in the family. Over twenty years, Jack’s stock barely grew; Sam’s shot up. “Your Apple has gone up—I don’t even want to think about it,” Jack later said, recounting the story, “hundreds and hundreds of times.”

“是的，很多，”萨姆得意地说道。

“Yes, it’s been a lot,” Sam said smugly.

随着萨姆长大，康妮给了他一个她愿意给所有孩子的选择：是否转学到当地一所私立学校——约翰·伯勒斯学校。这所学校以其严谨的学术和令人印象深刻的校友名录而闻名。萨姆转学了，马克斯转学但没有留下，杰克拒绝了，安妮则跟随她的大哥。在伯勒斯学校，萨姆茁壮成长。他外向的性格和诙谐幽默，在学业和社交方面都表现出色。他不仅对STEM（科学、技术、工程和数学）感兴趣，还对写作和各种课外活动感兴趣。他担任年鉴负责人、水球队队长，并参加了模拟联合国活动——这是一个将学生聚集在世界各地，模拟联合国并讨论公共政策的项目。我记得我当时想——说实话，这么说可能有点尴尬——‘我希望他别搞科技。他很有创造力，文笔也很好，’”他的英语老师、后来成为巴勒斯学校校长的安迪·阿伯特回忆道。“我希望他能成为一名作家之类的。”

As Sam got older, Connie gave him a choice that she would give to all of her children: whether or not to transfer to a local private school, John Burroughs, known for its rigorous academics and impressive roster of famed alumni. Sam made the switch, Max switched but didn’t stay, Jack declined, and Annie followed her oldest brother. At Burroughs, Sam thrived. He excelled academically and socially with his extroverted personality and goofy humor. He was drawn not just to STEM but to writing and a variety of extracurriculars. He was head of the yearbook, captain of the water polo team, and did Model UN, a program that brings students together in events around the world to simulate the United Nations and debate public policy. “I remember thinking—and this is an embarrassing confession—‘I hope he doesn’t go into technology. He’s so creative and such a good writer,’ ” Andy Abbott, his English teacher who would become the head of Burroughs, would recall. “I hoped he would be an author or something like that.”

即使在那时，奥特曼就极具魅力，是一位天生的领导者。他喜欢突破政治上可接受的界限，他在一个保守的学校里，曾因在年度动员会上带领水球队跳脱衣舞（只穿泳裤）而惹上麻烦。正是在那几年里，他向父母和同学公开了自己的同性恋身份。虽然这让他母亲感到惊讶，但她和其他家人一样接受了。学校里一群基督教学生却不承认。在全国出柜日那天，他们抵制了他主持的一场关于性取向的集会。17岁的奥特曼决定在学生会上发表演讲，直面他们，他的大学辅导员认为这次演讲开启了学校的文化。你要么容忍开放社区，要么不容忍，你没有选择的权利，”他后来回忆起自己的最后一句话时说道。

Even then, Altman was charismatic and a natural leader. He loved to push the boundaries of what was politically acceptable at his more conservative school, once getting in trouble for leading his water polo team in a striptease down to their Speedos at an annual pep rally. It was during those years that he came out to his parents and classmates as gay. While it surprised his mother, she accepted it, as did the rest of the family. A group of Christian students at his school did not. On National Coming Out Day, they boycotted an assembly that he led about sexuality. Altman, seventeen, decided to confront them in a speech to the student body that his college counselor would credit for opening up the school’s culture. “Either you have tolerance to open community or you don’t, and you don’t get to pick and choose,” he later said, recalling his last line.

自信的外表背后，萨姆其实很敏感。他很在意别人对他的看法。他经常焦虑不安，这种性格一直延续到成年。随着他在硅谷的声名鹊起，他有时会因为头痛而给妈妈打电话，因为他确信自己实际上患有脑膜炎或淋巴瘤。有一次，他在谈判过程中惊慌失措，不得不躺在地上，赤裸上身，张开双臂，才能让自己平静下来。

Behind the confident facade, Sam was also sensitive. He worried about what people thought of him. He often grappled with anxiety, a trait that would carry over into his adult life. As his star rose in Silicon Valley, he’d sometimes call his mom with a headache, having convinced himself that he actually had meningitis or lymphoma. He would grow so panicked once while negotiating a deal that he’d have to lie down on the ground, bare chested, arms splayed, to calm himself.

正是他的这两个部分——他的雄心和他的敏感性——决定了他的职业生涯的走向。2016年， 《纽约客》的泰德·弗兰德（Tad Friend）在与奥特曼进行了大量访谈后，注意到了这种双重性：在任何问题上，奥特曼似乎都既被一种永不放弃的进取心所驱使，又兼顾着谨慎行事。他的目标是尽快实现通用人工智能（AGI）；还有：不要毁灭人类。

It was these two parts of him—his ambition and his sensitivity—that would come to mark the shape of his career. After spending many hours with Altman to profile him in 2016, The New Yorker’s Tad Friend would note this duality: On any given issue, Altman seemed as driven by a relentless desire to push ahead as he was attuned to the countervailing need for caution. Reach AGI as fast as possible; also: Don’t destroy humanity.

—

—

2003年从伯勒斯学院毕业后，Altman离开美国中西部，前往斯坦福大学，因为他被斯坦福大学靠近科技行业的地理位置所吸引。然而，他并没有立即决定进入科技行业。正如他的老师Andy Abbott所希望的那样，他确实考虑过成为一名作家。他也曾短暂地考虑过成为一名投资银行家。最终，他最终还是投身于自己对编程和计算机的痴迷之中。“我意识到这个世界并不需要，也不重视第700万本小说，”他后来说，“那不是我能做出最大贡献的地方，而且在这种情况下，通常也更难赚到很多钱，甚至赚到足够的钱。”

Upon graduating from Burroughs in 2003, Altman left the Midwest for Stanford University, drawn in by its proximity to the tech industry. He didn’t settle on getting into tech immediately, however. As his teacher Andy Abbott had hoped, he did in fact consider being a writer. He also ever so briefly entertained the idea of being an investment banker. In the end, he leaned into his fascination with programming and computers. “I realized that the world does not need or value the seven-millionth novel,” he later said. “That was not where I could make the best contribution, and, in cases like that, it also is generally harder to make a lot of money or even enough money.”

奥特曼主修计算机科学，对人工智能和安全特别感兴趣。他深入钻研作业。一位同学回忆说，他曾经彻底研究过一个他本该用来做作业的软件，只留下了底层代码，结果在作业里发现了一个bug。大二的时候，他对移动技术产生了兴趣。在得知手机即将配备GPS后，他参加了一场校园创业活动，并拿着翻盖手机走上舞台。他公开招募人们加入他，共同开发一款利用位置追踪功能的产品。

Altman majored in computer science and took a particular interest in AI and security. He dug deep into assignments, once disemboweling a piece of software he was supposed to use for his homework to its low-level code, a classmate remembered, and finding a bug in the assignment itself. As a sophomore, he became interested in mobile technology. After learning that phones would soon all be equipped with GPS, he went to a campus entrepreneur event and stepped onstage holding a flip phone. He made an open call for people to join him in building something that took advantage of the location-tracking feature.

大约在那个时候，他遇到了保罗·格雷厄姆 (Paul Graham)，一位企业家兼颇具影响力的科技博主，当时他正与女友杰西卡·利文斯顿 (Jessica Livingston) 创办一家名为 Y Combinator 的初创企业孵化器。2005 年，阿尔特曼以新创公司 Loopt 的创始人身份加入了 YC 的首批孵化企业，并在该孵化器最初启动的地方——马萨诸塞州剑桥市度过了那个夏天。Loopt 是一个社交网络，它利用位置追踪技术，在用户靠近朋友时通知他们，或推荐附近的餐厅。那个夏天，他工作非常卖力，吃了太多方便面，以至于患上了坏血病。

Around that time, he met Paul Graham, an entrepreneur and influential tech blogger who was beginning a new startup incubator called Y Combinator with his girlfriend Jessica Livingston. Altman joined YC’s first batch of companies in 2005 as the founder of his new startup, Loopt, and spent the summer in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where the incubator initially started. Loopt was a social network that used location tracking to notify users when they were close to friends or to recommend nearby restaurants. He worked so hard that summer and ate so much instant ramen, he gave himself scurvy.

他并不后悔。”“职业生涯初期要非常努力，”他后来对年轻的创业者说，“就像复利一样，回报丰厚。” 奥特曼再也没有回到斯坦福。2005年底，他和联合创始人已开始与风险投资公司New Enterprise Associates和Sequoia洽谈，希望获得500万美元的融资。Altman抓住了机会，从大学退学了。

He didn’t regret it. “Work really hard in the beginning of your career,” he would later say to young founders. “It pays off like compound interest.” Altman never returned to Stanford. By late 2005, he and his cofounders were already in talks with VC firms New Enterprise Associates and Sequoia to give them $5 million in funding. Altman took his chances and dropped out of college.

—

—

Loopt 不会取得巨大的成功。经过七年的运营，奥特曼于 2012 年以 4,340 万美元的价格将其出售，这与他的投资者投入的价格大致相同。但如果你听过他当时的采访和他的支持者的话，他的初创公司听起来就像是即将迎来一场伟大的转型。

Loopt wouldn’t become a great success. After a seven-year run, Altman would sell it in 2012 for $43.4 million, around what his investors put in. But if you had listened to his interviews and his backers at the time, his startup would have sounded like it was on the precipice of ushering in a great transformation.

在早期的采访中，我们更容易理解奥特曼成功的根源，当时他向你推销的是远没有人工智能那么诱人的东西：也就是 Foursquare 早期的竞争对手，而且没有成功。

It’s easier to understand the seeds of Altman’s success in those early interviews, when he’s selling you something far less alluring than artificial intelligence: namely, an earlier competitor to Foursquare, and one that didn’t work out.

奥特曼崛起的两大支柱——媒体敏锐度和交易撮合——都源于他非凡的叙事能力。奥特曼在这方面可谓天赋异禀。即使你明知他的公司最终会失败，你也禁不住被他所讲述的故事所吸引。他轻松地谈论着公司独特的定位。他的初创公司是科技发展宏伟而不可阻挡的一部分。消费者和广告商都对这项服务趋之若鹜。别跟他赌——他的成功是必然的。

Both his media savvy and dealmaking, two pillars of his rise, rest on his remarkable ability to tell a good story. In this Altman is a natural. Even knowing as you watch him that his company would ultimately fail, you can’t help but be compelled by what he’s saying. He speaks with a casual ease about the singular positioning of his company. His startup is part of the grand, unstoppable trajectory of technology. Consumers and advertisers are clamoring for the service. Don’t bet against him—his success is inevitable.

““反响非常热烈，”2010年6月，他在接受科技博主罗伯特·斯科布尔（Robert Scoble）采访时谈到公司的新应用Loopt Star时说道。该应用允许广告商根据用户位置向他们推送优惠信息，例如餐厅优惠券或零售商团购折扣。“我们已经跨越了这个临界点，现在人们认为分享位置信息的价值超过了隐私方面的担忧，”他补充道。“再过几年，分享位置信息将成为常态，不分享位置信息反而会显得很奇怪。”

“The response has been tremendous,” he said to tech blogger Robert Scoble in June 2010 about his company’s new app, Loopt Star, for advertisers to push deals, such as coupons for restaurants or group discounts for retailers, to users based on their location. “We’ve crossed over this point where now the value perceived of sharing my location outweighs the privacy concerns of doing so,” he added. “In another few years, it’ll be the norm to share your location and it’ll be weird when you don’t.”

““这真是荒谬的区分，”几个月后，奥特曼在接受CNN商业频道采访时谈到网络生活和现实生活的区别时说道；这两者正通过移动设备上的位置追踪融合在一起。“全世界都在走向移动化，全世界都将实现无论你身在何处都能访问你的数据和服务，”他说。

“It’s a ridiculous distinction,” Altman said a few months later to CNN Business, about the difference between life online and in person; the two were fusing together with location tracking on mobile devices. “The whole world is going mobile and the whole world is going universal access to your data and your services no matter where you are,” he said.

对 Altman 来说，即使讨论这些陷阱，也算是一个强调其宣传策略的机会。2008 年，The Information创始人、当时担任《华尔街日报》记者的Jessica Lessin告诉 Altman，她想写一篇关于位置追踪隐私问题的报道，Altman 主动提出帮忙。他给她发了一份 Loopt 已经识别出的风险清单，以及相应的解决方案。这暗示着：世界将会如此运转，所以你最好做好准备。“他不只是想创办一家初创公司，”莱辛在谈到这段经历时写道，“他想制定规则。”

For Altman, even discussing the pitfalls was an opportunity to underscore the pitch. When The Information founder Jessica Lessin, then a Wall Street Journal reporter, told Altman in 2008 she would write a story about the privacy concerns of location tracking, he offered to help. He sent her a long list of risks that Loopt had already identified and its proposals for how to solve them. The implicit message: This is how the world will work, so you might as well prepare for it. “He didn’t just want to build a startup,” Lessin wrote about the experience. “He wanted to write the rules.”

在 Loopt 的帮助下，Altman 建立了人脉网络，磨练了日后成为他最宝贵资产的技能。作为 21 世纪初到 20 世纪初在湾区创立的一家初创公司，他置身于快速增长、新兴企业蓬勃发展的时代。他经常与其他永不停歇的创业者交流，建立了至关重要的联系。无论他转向哪里。Loopt 刚起步时，办公室就在刚刚起步的初创公司 YouTube 的楼下。Altman 的 YC 同学（YC 指的是 YC 的同班创业者）中，有 Steve Huffman 和 Chris Slowe，他们分别是 Reddit 的联合创始人和创始工程师。2014年，Altman 成为 Reddit 董事会成员，最终持有的公司股份超过了 Huffman。另一位 YC 的同学是 Twitch 的联合创始人 Emmett Shear，近二十年后，Altman 下台后，他接任了 OpenAI 的临时 CEO。

With Loopt, Altman built the networks and sharpened the skills that would become his greatest assets. As a startup founder through the mid aughts and early teens in the Bay Area, he placed himself in the thick of an era of rapid growth and buzzy new ventures. He regularly rubbed shoulders with other restless entrepreneurs, making crucial connections wherever he turned. Right as Loopt was getting started, its office was down the hall from the fledgling startup YouTube. Among Altman’s YC batchmates—the term for fellow founders in a YC cohort—were Steve Huffman and Chris Slowe, the respective cofounder and founding engineer of Reddit. Altman would become a Reddit board member in 2014, eventually amassing a larger share of the company than Huffman. Another YC batchmate was Emmett Shear, the cofounder of Twitch, who would step in as OpenAI’s interim CEO during Altman’s ouster almost two decades later.

奥特曼还学会了如何将信息包装给媒体，以及如何最稳妥地达成非凡交易。即便只是一家名不见经传的初创公司的首席执行官，他也成功地与美国主要移动电话运营商达成了企业合作协议。人们说，他成功秘诀的关键在于他卓越的倾听技巧、乐于助人的性格，以及能够根据客户的具体需求，精准地规划他所能提供的一切。（如今，作为硅谷超级富豪的关键人物，他能提供很多帮助也并非坏事。）人们称他为“倾听界的迈克尔·乔丹”。他是““筹款界的尤塞恩·博尔特，”在奥特曼之后接手 YC 运营的杰夫·拉尔斯顿 (Geoff Ralston) 说。

Altman also learned the best way to package things to the media and the surest way to strike extraordinary deals. Even as the CEO of a little-known startup, he successfully negotiated enterprise partnerships with the major US mobile phone carriers. Key to his formula, people say, is the combination of his remarkable listening skills, his willingness to help, and his ability to frame whatever he has to offer in terms of exactly what you want. (These days, as an ultrawealthy Silicon Valley linchpin, it doesn’t hurt that he can offer a lot.) He is the “Michael Jordan of listening,” people have said. He is the “Usain Bolt of fundraising,” says Geoff Ralston, who took over running YC after Altman.

“从根本上讲，当你从某人那里融资时，你实际上是在讲述一个关于你的项目未来的故事，这个故事涉及到这个项目，以及这家公司如何取得非凡的成功，”拉尔斯顿说。“萨姆能讲出一个你想参与的故事，这个故事引人入胜，而且看起来很真实，甚至很有可能实现。”

“Fundamentally when you raise money from someone, what you’re doing is telling a story about the future of whatever your project is, which involves that project, that company becoming an extraordinary success,” Ralston says. “Sam can tell a tale that you want to be part of, that is compelling, and that seems real, that seems even likely.”

拉尔斯顿将其比作史蒂夫·乔布斯的现实扭曲力场。“史蒂夫可以讲述一个故事，压倒你现实中的任何其他部分，”他说，“无论现实是被扭曲的，还是变成了现实。因为记住，史蒂夫的真正之处在于，他确实创造了一些能够改变你现实的东西。这不仅仅是扭曲。这是真实的。”

Ralston likens it to Steve Jobs’s reality distortion field. “Steve could tell a story that overwhelmed any other part of your reality,” he says, “whether there was a distortion of reality or it became a reality. Because remember, the thing about Steve is he actually built stuff that did change your reality. It wasn’t just distortion. It was real.

“显然，萨姆也是如此。”

“And obviously, Sam has too.”

但事情也有另一面。“萨姆记得你的所有细节。他非常细心。但另一方面，他也会利用这一点来想办法用不同的方式影响你，”一位曾与他共事多年的人说道。“他非常善于根据你的言辞调整，而且你真的感觉自己和他在一起正在取得进步。但随着时间的推移，你意识到你实际上只是在原地踏步。

But there’s a flip side to the story. “Sam remembers all these details about you. He’s so attentive. But then part of it is he uses that to figure out how to influence you in different ways,” says one person who worked several years with him. “He’s so good at adjusting to what you say, and you really feel like you’re making progress with him. And then you realize over time that you’re actually just running in place.”

据《华尔街日报》报道，在 Altman 执掌 Loopt 期间，这家初创公司的高层领导曾两次与董事会接触，敦促其解雇 Altman，并提出两项指控，这两项指控一直伴随他直到他被 OpenAI 短暂解雇。一项指控是他倾向于为个人利益而不是公司利益行事，有时甚至以牺牲公司利益为代价。另一项指控是他似乎有歪曲事实的冲动。后者更难确定：他有时会在微不足道的细节上撒谎，很难说这种不诚实有什么大不了的。但随着时间的推移，这些微小的“纸上谈兵”，正如有人所说，导致公司普遍存在不信任和混乱的气氛。

Twice during his time running Loopt, senior leaders at the startup approached its board and urged it to fire Altman, according to The Wall Street Journal, leveling two accusations that would follow him all the way through to his brief ouster at OpenAI. One was his tendency to operate for his own gain rather than the company’s, and at times even at the expense of the company. The other was his seeming compulsion to distort the truth. The latter was harder to pin down: He sometimes lied about details so insignificant that it was hard to say why the dishonesty mattered at all. But over time, those tiny “paper cuts,” as one person called them, led to an atmosphere of pervasive distrust and chaos at the company.

奥特曼最终以决定其职业生涯余下部分的方式摆脱了危机。卢普特董事会站在了奥特曼一边。

In a manner that would come to define the rest of his career, Altman emerged from the crisis with the upper hand. Loopt’s board sided with Altman.

尽管Loopt的业绩平平，但Altman从Loopt离开后也比当初好得多。他利用这家初创公司，一步步跻身硅谷最有权势的人脉网络，并随后利用这些关系为公司成功退出，最终致富。26岁时，他从Loopt的出售中净赚了500万美元。Altman对此感到失望——乔布斯25岁时身价就已达2.56亿美元——但他很快积累了更多财富。这些财富慢慢改变了他的生活方式。最终，他不再去杂货店，而是乘坐私人飞机出行。他收藏豪华跑车，包括迈凯伦和一辆价值500万美元的极其罕见的科尼赛克，并培养了对赛车的热爱。有一段时间，他参加了一年一度的为期一周、充满迷幻和性爱的沙漠艺术节“火人节”。和许多硅谷大佬一样，他偶尔也会服用氯胺酮，这是一种可以合法用于缓解抑郁症的派对药物。

Despite its middling record, Altman would also emerge from Loopt much better off than he’d started. He used the startup to springboard himself higher and higher into the most powerful networks in Silicon Valley and subsequently used those connections to orchestrate an exit for his company that made himself rich. At twenty-six, he netted $5 million from Loopt’s sale. Altman considered this a disappointment—Jobs had been worth $256 million by age twenty-five—but he would soon accumulate far more money. That wealth would slowly change his lifestyle. Eventually, he’d stop going to the grocery store. He’d travel by private jet. He’d collect luxury sports cars, including McLarens and an ultrarare $5 million Koenigsegg, and cultivate a love for racing them. For a time he attended the annual weeklong psychedelic and sex-fueled desert art festival Burning Man. He became, like many Silicon Valley bigwigs, a casual user of ketamine, a party drug that can be legally prescribed to relieve depression.

奥特曼的成功让兄弟们也加入了进来。2012年，他和弟弟杰克创办了名为“肼资本”的个人投资基金。杰克曾在普林斯顿大学学习经济学，杰克尝试投资银行业务。杰克随后转向科技领域，创办了一家名为Lattice的初创公司，在萨姆成为孵化器总裁后，该公司获得了YC的资助。马克斯曾在杜克大学学习计算机科学，并在成为交易员之前曾在微软短暂工作过。2014年，他转投YC的另一家公司Zenefits。两年后，他加入了萨姆和杰克在Hydrazine Capital的团队。在此期间，两个弟弟搬来和萨姆一起住，但这只是暂时的安排。最终，他们三人生活在一起，兄弟情深，事业上也保持着密切的联系，并一起度过了许多年。

With his success, Altman brought his brothers along with him. In 2012, he started a personal investment fund called Hydrazine Capital with his brother Jack, who had studied economics at Princeton and was trying his hand at investment banking. Jack subsequently switched to tech and founded a startup, Lattice, that would get funded by YC after Sam became the incubator’s president. Max, who had studied computer science at Duke and worked briefly at Microsoft before becoming a trader, switched to working at another YC company, Zenefits, in 2014. Two years later, he would join Sam and Jack at Hydrazine Capital. During that time, both younger brothers moved in with Sam for what was meant to be a temporary arrangement. The three ended up living together—a tight knot of brotherly love and business relationships—for many years to come.

—

—

对于奥特曼的职业生涯来说，尤为重要的是他与他的两位最重要的导师保罗·格雷厄姆和彼得·泰尔的关系。

Of particular importance to the shape of Altman’s career was his relationship with his two biggest mentors, Paul Graham and Peter Thiel.

绰号 PG 的 Graham 最初是作为初创公司 Viaweb 的联合创始人成名的，该公司于 1998 年被雅虎以 4900 万美元收购，之后他成为一名博主，发表有关初创公司、创业精神和风险投资的热门文章。创办 YC 后，他将自己的观点灌输给每一代 YC 创始人。每一家成功的 YC 公司都赢得了孵化器，Graham 也因此声望日渐提升。到 Altman 出售 Loopt 时，该孵化器已经孵化了几家初创公司，这些公司已经或即将成长为价值 10 亿美元的公司，包括 Dropbox 和 Airbnb。YC 成为硅谷最精英的俱乐部。如果你加入，你会立即获得声望和更多资源，包括老 YC 公司的内置客户群、更渴望为你提供资金的投资者以及更高的估值。如果你退出，就没有那么幸运了。

Known as PG, Graham had made his name first as the cofounder of a startup, Viaweb, which Yahoo acquired in 1998 for $49 million, and then as a blogger who published popular essays on startups, entrepreneurship, and venture capital. After starting YC, he impressed his views onto each generation of YC founders. Every YC company that succeeded gained the incubator, and Graham, increasing prestige. By the time Altman sold Loopt, the incubator had already seeded several startups that had grown or would soon grow into billion-dollar companies, including Dropbox and Airbnb. YC became the most elite club in the Valley. If you were in, you gained instant cachet and access to more resources, including a built-in customer base among old YC companies, investors more eager to fund you, and higher valuations. If you were out, no such luck.

Graham 成为了硅谷初创企业和初创企业文化的重要引领者。“这个领域、这个生态系统中的许多人，都以他关于如何成为一名优秀创始人和成功企业家的基本准则为生，”Ralston 说。“我们中的许多人在很多事情上都向 Graham 寻求指导。” Graham 也成为了众矢之的。他倡导科技行业精英管理的理念，同时将 YC 设计成一个封闭的兄弟会。他为 YC 女性创始人数量偏少辩护，称大多数女性并没有从小就做好成为成功的科技企业家的准备。在分析了 YC 申请者的表现后在面试中，他确定了三四十个因素，包括“浓重的外国口音”，当候选人同时表现出其中几个因素时，这些因素就预示着失败。他说，这不是 YC 评估体系的缺陷，而是一个重要的数据驱动信号。

Graham became an essential tastemaker for startups and startup culture in Silicon Valley. “Many folks in the space, in the ecosystem, came to live by and to take his fundamental precepts for what it meant to be a good founder and a successful entrepreneur,” says Ralston. “Many of us looked to PG for guidance on a lot of things.” Graham also became a lightning rod for criticism. He championed the idea of the tech industry as a meritocracy, while designing YC to be an insular fraternity. He defended YC for not having many female founders by saying that most women had not been prepared from an early age to succeed as tech entrepreneurs. After analyzing the performance of applicants in YC interviews, he identified thirty or forty factors, including “a strong foreign accent,” that were predictors of failure when candidates exhibited several of them together. This was not a flaw of YC’s evaluation system but rather an important data-driven signal, he said.

格雷厄姆很早就对奥特曼给予了强有力的支持。在2006年的一篇博客文章中，格雷厄姆回忆了大学二年级时与奥特曼的相遇。“Loopt 可能是我们迄今为止资助的所有初创公司中最有前途的，”格雷厄姆写道。“但萨姆·奥特曼是个非常不寻常的人。我记得我和他见面不到三分钟，就心想：‘啊，原来比尔·盖茨 19 岁时是这样的。’”

Graham’s support for Altman was strong and early. In a 2006 blog post, Graham recounted meeting Altman as a college sophomore. “Loopt is probably the most promising of all the startups we’ve funded so far,” Graham wrote. “But Sam Altman is a very unusual guy. Within about three minutes of meeting him, I remember thinking ‘Ah, so this is what Bill Gates must have been like when he was 19.’ ”

Altman 很快启发了 Graham 去寻找更多像 Altman 这样的人。他问这位年轻的创始人，YC 应该在申请材料中问些什么，才能发现更多像他这样的人。Altman 建议增加一个问题，Graham 很快将其视为最重要的问题之一：“请告诉我们，你最成功入侵某个（非计算机）系统并为自己谋利的经历。” 这个问题最终概括并鼓励了一代又一代初创企业追求的一种精神：为了称霸市场，他们不惜扭曲、绕过甚至打破规则。

Altman quickly inspired Graham to search for more Altmans. He asked the young founder what YC should ask on its application to discover more people like him. Altman suggested adding a question that Graham would soon describe as one of the most important: “Please tell us about the time you most successfully hacked some (non-computer) system to your advantage.” It would come to encapsulate and encourage a certain ethos among generations of startups to bend, bypass, and break the rules to domination.

当奥特曼二十三岁时，格雷厄姆开始将他与乔布斯进行比较。”“萨姆和史蒂夫·乔布斯一样，是我在为初创公司提供咨询时最常提及的创始人，”他写道。“谈到设计问题，我会问：‘史蒂夫会怎么做？’但谈到战略或抱负，我会问：‘萨玛会怎么做？’”——他用的是奥特曼的昵称，也是他的X代号。

By the time Altman was twenty-three, Graham was comparing him to Jobs. “Sam is, along with Steve Jobs, the founder I refer to most when I’m advising startups,” he wrote. “On questions of design, I ask, ‘What would Steve do?’ But on questions of strategy or ambition I ask ‘What would Sama do?’ ”—referring to Altman by his nickname, which is also his X handle.

正是 Graham 对 Altman 的独特信任，让他在 2014 年，也就是出售 Loopt 两年后，以 28 岁的年纪，一跃成为 YC 主席。当格雷厄姆在厨房里问奥特曼是否想成为他的继任者时，奥特曼忍不住笑了。“YC 在某种程度上掌控着科技的进程，”奥特曼后来说道。“我认为他的目标是创造整个未来，”格雷厄姆这样评价奥特曼。这个继任故事被反复提及，以至于成为了硅谷的传奇。“如果萨姆笑了，那一定是经过深思熟虑的，”一位前 YC 创始人说道。“萨姆只有一次忍不住笑了，那就是当格雷厄姆告诉他接管 YC 的时候。”格雷厄姆的选择让很多人感到惊讶，但他对此坚信不疑。“当时并没有一份名单，上面写着谁应该管理 YC，以及谁应该让 Sam 担任最高领导，”Livingston 回忆道，“就只有 Sam 一个人。”

It was Graham’s singular belief in Altman that would catapult him to the YC presidency in 2014 at age twenty-eight, two years after selling Loopt. When Graham asked in his kitchen if Altman wanted to be his successor, Altman smiled uncontrollably. “YC somewhat gets to direct the course of technology,” Altman would later say. “I think his goal is to make the whole future,” Graham said of Altman. The succession story would get repeated so often that it would turn into Silicon Valley lore. “If Sam smiles, it’s super deliberate,” a former YC founder says. “Sam has smiled uncontrollably only once, when PG told him to take over YC.” Graham’s choice surprised many others, but he held strong convictions. “There wasn’t a list of who should run YC and Sam at the top,” Livingston would recall. “It was just: Sam.”

彼得·泰尔（Peter Thiel）成为奥特曼的第二位导师。泰尔是科技行业的另一位关键人物，他通过创立支付公司PayPal和数据挖掘公司Palantir，并成为Facebook的早期投资者，最终成为亿万富翁。与格雷厄姆一样，泰尔也饱受争议，包括在2016年大选期间，在科技界同行中罕见地公开支持特朗普，以及秘密资助一场导致Gawker Media倒闭的诉讼，以报复该网站近十年前曝光他的同性恋身份。

Peter Thiel became Altman’s second mentor. Another linchpin in the tech industry, Thiel became a billionaire by founding payments company PayPal and data-mining firm Palantir, and being an early investor in Facebook. Like Graham, Thiel would attract his own fair share of controversies, including being a rare vocal Trump backer among his tech peers during the 2016 election and secretly funding a lawsuit that would lead to the demise of Gawker Media, in retaliation for the site outing him as gay nearly a decade earlier.

Loopt 出售后，Altman 与一位联合创始人以及交往九年的男友分手。伤心欲绝、事业也陷入低谷的 Altman 休息了一年，创办了 Hydrazine，并筹集了 2100 万美元。比 Altman 大近二十岁的 Thiel 参与了大部分融资。Altman 成为 YC 合伙人后，他利用 Hydrazine 投资加速器旗下的公司，同时帮助 Thiel 的风险投资公司 Founders Fund 寻找高回报的投资机会。Thiel 的净资产翻了数倍。两人的关系也变得异常亲密。他们之间的关系曾被描述为只有一个相似之处：蒂尔与 Facebook 联合创始人马克·扎克伯格的导师关系。)

After the sale of Loopt, Altman suffered a breakup with one of his cofounders as well as boyfriend of nine years. Heartbroken and professionally adrift, Altman took a year off, started Hydrazine, and raised $21 million. Thiel, almost twenty years Altman’s senior, pitched in a majority of the funding. When Altman became a YC partner, he used Hydrazine to bet on the accelerator’s portfolio companies while also helping Thiel’s venture firm, Founders Fund, to identify high-return investments. Thiel’s net worth multiplied several times over. The two men grew extremely close. (Their bond was once described as having only one parallel: Thiel’s mentor relationship with Facebook cofounder Mark Zuckerberg.)

格雷厄姆和蒂尔深深地影响了奥特曼的世界观、他打造高效企业的方法，以及他作为政治家的智慧。两位导师让奥特曼深刻认识到规模化的重要性，以及资本主义相对于政府的效率。

Graham and Thiel heavily influenced Altman’s worldview, his approach to building effective businesses, and his savvy as a political operator. The two mentors impressed on Altman the imperative for scale and the efficiencies of capitalism over government.

““我听到的第一条创业箴言是‘提高销售额能解决所有问题’，”奥特曼在2013年一篇题为“增长与政府”的博客文章中写道，感谢格雷厄姆和蒂尔对他思想的塑造。“这其实是保罗·格雷厄姆“增长至关重要”观点的另一种表述方式。”对于初创公司而言，更高的销售额意味着更多的资本，意味着更优秀的人才和更少的内部矛盾。对于国家而言，更快的增长意味着更多的技术创新，意味着更高的生活质量。奥特曼补充道，美国政府的失职正在威胁着这一增长周期。“要么你发展，要么你慢慢走向衰亡，”美国政府正在走向衰亡。“没有经济增长，民主就无法发挥作用，因为选民参与的是零和博弈，”他说。

“The first piece of startup wisdom I heard was ‘increasing your sales will fix all problems,’ ” Altman wrote in a 2013 blog post titled “Growth and Government” that thanked Graham and Thiel for shaping his ideas. “This turns out to be another way of phrasing Paul Graham’s point that growth is critical.” For startups, more sales meant more capital meant better talent and fewer internal tensions. For countries, more growth meant more technological innovation meant a higher quality of life. The dysfunction in the US government was threatening this growth cycle, Altman added. “Either you’re growing, or you’re slowly dying,” and the US government was dying. “Without economic growth, democracy doesn’t work because voters occupy a zero-sum system,” he said.

这个想法后来演变成推动奥特曼职业生涯和投资的核心论点。”“私营部门人士能为国家重回正轨做出的最大贡献就是恢复经济增长，”他在2017年说道。“美国经历了两百年无与伦比的经济增长。我们经历了一百年的领土扩张；我们经历了一百年的新技术真正发挥作用，”他补充道，对血腥的殖民历史以及不受约束的工业化带来的复杂的劳工和环境记录避而不谈。“人们大多都很幸福。而现在，我们却不幸福了。”

This idea would evolve into a core thesis driving Altman’s career and investments. “The thing that people in the private sector can do the most to help get the country back on track is to get economic growth back,” he’d say in 2017. “In the US we had two hundred years of unrivaled economic growth. We had one hundred years of territorial expansion; we had one hundred years of new technology really working,” he added, glossing over a bloody colonial history and the complicated labor and environmental record of unfettered industrialization. “And people were mostly pretty happy. And now we don’t.”

“可持续的经济增长几乎总是一种道德上的好事，”他在 2019 年补充道。“促使我致力于 Y Combinator 和 OpenAI 的部分原因就是回归这一点，回归可持续的经济增长，回归一个大多数人的生活每年都在变得更好、我们都能感受到共同的成功精神的世界。”

“Sustainable economic growth is almost always a moral good,” he’d add in 2019. “Part of what motivates me to work on Y Combinator and OpenAI is getting back to that, getting back to sustainable economic growth, getting back to a world where most people’s lives get better every year and that we feel the shared spirit of success.”

在创办公司的过程中，奥特曼经常引用蒂尔的“垄断”战略，即所有创始人都应该“以垄断为目标”才能打造成功的企业。2014年，奥特曼回到母校斯坦福大学，教授一门名为“如何创办一家初创企业”的课程。他邀请蒂尔在题为“竞争是失败者的”的讲座中进一步阐述他的标志性理念。

On building companies, Altman frequently channeled Thiel’s “monopoly” strategy, the belief that all founders should “aim for monopoly” to create a successful business. In 2014, Altman returned to his alma mater, Stanford, to teach a class called How to Start a Startup. He invited Thiel to expand upon his signature philosophy in a lecture called “Competition Is for Losers.”

泰尔说，垄断是好事，因为“它们更加稳定，是长期业务，你拥有更多资本，而且……这标志着你创造了真正有价值的东西。” 建立垄断依赖于某种专有技术、网络效应、规模经济和良好的品牌效应。所有这些要素都需要经久不衰。拥有专有技术，保持领先地位至关重要。“你不想被别人取代，”泰尔说。“在所有这些创新领域，都存在着巨大的创新，但却没有人从中获利。”

Monopolies are good, Thiel said, because “they are much more stable, longer-term businesses, you have more capital, and…it’s symptomatic of having created something really valuable.” Building one relied on having some kind of proprietary technology, network effects, economies of scale, and good branding. Each of these elements needed to endure over time. With proprietary technology, it was critical to stay in the leading position. “You don’t want to be superseded by somebody else,” Thiel said. “There are all these areas of innovation where there was tremendous innovation but no one made any money.”

他以 20 世纪 80 年代的磁盘驱动器制造业为例，该行业每两年就会出现一次进步，但由不同的公司进行。他说：“这给消费者带来了巨大的好处，但实际上并没有帮助到这些公司的创始人。”公司不仅需要在初期取得“重大突破”来确立主导地位，还需要确保拥有“最后的突破”来维持这种优势，例如“以足够快的速度进行改进，让任何人都无法赶上”。

He gave the example of disc drive manufacturing in the 1980s, which saw repeated advancements every two years, but by different companies. “It had great benefit to consumers, but it didn’t actually help the people who started these companies,” he said. Companies needed not only to have “a huge breakthrough” at the beginning to establish their dominance but also to ensure they had the “last breakthrough” to maintain it, such as by “improving on it at a quick enough pace that no one can ever catch up.

“如果你的未来架构充满了创新，其他人会在你正在做的事情上提出新的东西，”他总结道，“这对社会来说是好事。但实际上，这对你的企业来说却不是那么好。”

“If you have a structure of the future where there’s a lot of innovation and other people will come up with new things in the thing you’re working on,” he concluded, “that’s great for society. It’s actually not that good for your business.”

—

—

从这两位男士身上，奥特曼还了解到建立关系和创造“网络效应”对个人的重要性。

From both men, Altman also learned the importance of building relationships and creating “network effects” as an individual.

““我听过很多关于如何完成任务的不同理论，”他在2013年博客中写道。“最好的理论是：专注力与人脉的结合。查理·罗斯把这句话告诉了保罗·格雷厄姆，保罗又转述给了我。” 奥特曼后来又补充了第三个要素：自信。“对于初创企业来说，我认为增加这一点非常重要，”他说，“你必须相信自己能够做到。”

“I’ve heard a lot of different theories about how things get done,” he wrote on his blog in 2013. “Here’s the best one: a combination of focus and personal connections. Charlie Rose said this to Paul Graham, who told it to me.” Altman would later add a third ingredient: self-belief. “For startups I think it’s really important to add this,” he said. “You actually have to believe you might do it.”

奥特曼开始虔诚地践行这句箴言。他以严谨的态度培养人际关系，首先是奉献时间和策略建议，随着他掌控的资本越来越多，他也会奉献金钱。泰尔在这方面堪称典范：他的导师长期以来一直利用建议和金钱来建立人脉，并利用人脉积累更多人脉和财富。对于年轻的创业者以及其他他想带入自己圈子的人，泰尔会提供指导和少量资金，以及进入自己圈子的途径。奥特曼也以同样的方式学会了战略性地运用自己的财务和社会资源。随着地位和财富的增长，他以不懈的效率不断扩展这种方法。

Altman began to live by this mantra religiously. He cultivated relationships with intensity and discipline, first by giving his time and tactical advice and then, as he came to control increasing amounts of capital, his money. Thiel was a role model in this regard: His mentor had long used advice and money to build his network, and used his network to amass more connections and money. To young entrepreneurs and other people he wanted to bring into his orbit, Thiel provided mentorship and small amounts of capital, as well as access to that orbit. In much the same way, Altman learned to use his financial and social resources strategically. As his stature and wealth grew, he scaled the approach with relentless efficiency.

他经常在家里为形形色色、相互联系的人们举办晚宴和聚会——这些人与 YC 或他的公司有联系，与他有着共同投资兴趣，还有活跃且日益壮大的同性恋创业者群体。他通过以下方式提供建议：简洁的短信和电话——最短只有两分钟——可以让他安排更多时间。他通过电子邮件用一个词（“meet”）或一个标点符号（“？”）——这是亚马逊创始人杰夫·贝佐斯的著名习惯——将人们联系起来，开启一段对话。奥特曼很少用他的钱进行大额投资，而是主要进行小额、大额的投资。根据 2024 年 6 月《华尔街日报》的评估，随着时间的推移，他通过 YC、Hydrazine 和他的其他基金与四百多家公司建立了财务联系。

He became a frequent host of dinners and gatherings at his house for different, interlocking groups of people—people connected to YC or his companies, people who share his interests in investing, the active and growing gay entrepreneur community. He imparted advice through concise texts and calls—as short as two minutes—to pack more into his schedule. He connected people to one another over email with a single word (“meet”) or a single punctuation mark (“?”)—a famous habit of Amazon’s Jeff Bezos—to get a conversation started. With his money, Altman made very few large bets, going mostly instead for small ones at high volume. Over time he accumulated financial ties with more than four hundred companies through YC, Hydrazine, and his other funds, according to a June 2024 Wall Street Journal assessment.

在 Altman 的核心圈子里，很难找到与他没有某种经济关系的人。他第二次也是最成功的一次创业投资是 YC 支持的支付技术公司 Stripe，Greg Brockman 是该公司的第一任首席技术官。Altman 早期投资了 YC 支持的 Airbnb，该公司的联合创始人兼首席执行官 Brian Chesky 是 Altman 最亲密的知己之一。他为前男友兼朋友 Matt Krisiloff 的生物技术公司 Conception 提供资金支持。他与另一位前男友、著名的个人风险投资家 Lachy Groom 共同投资。对那些人来说，这是 Altman 慷慨的证明。他经常提供资源，无论是开放他的房子供人们居住还是提供经济支持。据一位人士回忆，他甚至会不遗余力地帮助完全陌生的人，曾经给一位埃塞俄比亚男子寄钱，那人给他发电子邮件寻求他的帮助购买一台笔记本电脑。克里斯洛夫回忆说，在 2023 年硅谷银行危机期间，当硅谷一家对初创企业至关重要的金融机构遭遇挤兑，导致自 2008 年以来最大的银行倒闭时，他向这些公司直接发放了无需任何文书的资金，以防止它们倒闭或裁员。““这是一种极其罕见的品质，”格鲁姆说道，“这种品质对我影响很大——慷慨。我对此心怀感激。”

It’s hard to find people within Altman’s inner circle who don’t have some kind of financial relationship with him. His second-ever and most successful startup investment was in the YC-backed payments technology company Stripe, for which Greg Brockman was its first chief technology officer. Altman invested early in YC-backed Airbnb, the cofounder and CEO of which, Brian Chesky, is one of his closest confidants. He pitched into his ex-boyfriend and friend Matt Krisiloff’s biotechnology firm Conception. He coinvests in deals with another ex-boyfriend, Lachy Groom, a prominent solo venture capitalist. To those people, it’s a testament to Altman’s generosity. He regularly offers his resources, whether opening up his houses for people to stay in or supporting them financially. He has gone out of his way to support even complete strangers, once sending funds to a man in Ethiopia who emailed him seeking his help to buy a laptop, one person recalls. During the 2023 Silicon Valley Bank crisis, when a run on a critical financial institution for Valley startups led to the largest bank failure since 2008, he sent money without any paperwork to companies to save them from shutting down or laying off people, remembers Krisiloff. “It’s an extremely rare trait,” Groom says, “and that trait has really rubbed off on me—the generosity. I feel very grateful for that.”

奥特曼对政客也采取了同样的策略，这又一次借鉴了蒂尔的做法。不过，蒂尔利用自己的财富支持共和党候选人，为他们的竞选活动投入数千万美元，而奥特曼则反其道而行之，越来越多地参与政治活动，举办筹款活动，并为民主党人开支票。有一段时间，蒂尔和奥特曼之间的政治分歧导致他们关系紧张关系。2017年，奥特曼利用两人之间的分歧，像蒂尔的另一位弟子扎克伯格一样，在美国进行了一轮巡回演讲，并与一百名特朗普的支持者进行了交谈。奥特曼还考虑过自己从政，竞选加州州长，他认为这将使他能够执掌世界第五大经济体，这将是修复他所认为的政治体系功能失调的坚实基石。他发表了一份名为《联合名单》的宣言，其中包含三大原则：（1）科技带来的繁荣；（2）经济公平；（3）个人自由。他组织了焦点小组来测试自己的候选人资格。他的亲信开玩笑说，他应该竞选美国总统。

Altman developed the same approach with politicians, taking another page out of Thiel’s book. But where Thiel asserted his wealth to back Republican candidates, pumping tens of millions into their campaigns, Altman grew increasingly involved in politics in the opposite direction, hosting fundraisers and writing checks for Democrats. For a time, the political differences between Thiel and Altman strained their relationship. In 2017, Altman leaned into their disagreements and went on a tour of America, much like Thiel’s other mentee Zuckerberg, and spoke to one hundred Trump supporters. Altman also entertained the idea of going into politics himself with a run for California governor, reasoning that it would place him in charge of the world’s fifth largest economy, a strong stepping stone for fixing what he saw as dysfunction in the political system. He published a manifesto called “The United Slate,” with three principles: (1) prosperity from technology; (2) economic fairness; and (3) personal liberty. He organized focus groups to test out his candidacy. People close to him joked that he should shoot for US president.

最终，Altman 从未成为一名政客——焦点小组认为他显得太年轻——但他的行为举止却开始像个政客。在运营 YC 的最初几年里，他依然稚嫩的脸颊，只有一件西装外套，坐在椅子上时，腿会翘起来，或者像鸟儿一样栖息。他有时会轻率地说话，随意夸张，句子中夹杂着脏话。他更轻松地提到一些挑衅性的个人细节，比如他收藏的枪支。他更容易发怒，对效率低下的人也更容易表现出不耐烦，他曾编写过一个软件程序，根据 YC 创始人的邮件回复时间来评估他们。

In the end, Altman never became a politician—the focus groups thought he came off as too young—but he began to act like one. In his first few years of running YC, he still had boyish cheeks, owned one suit jacket, and sat with a leg popped up or perched like a bird atop his chair. He sometimes spoke flippantly and in casual hyperboles, punctuating his sentences with profanity. He was breezier with his references to provocative personal details, like his collection of guns. He was faster to anger and to show his impatience for ineffective people, at one point coding up a software program to size up YC founders based on their email response times.

几年过去了，他的形象也变得精致起来，不再那么棱角分明。他不再穿T恤和工装短裤，而是穿上了合身的亨利衫和牛仔裤。一年之内，他增重了18磅（约7公斤），让原本瘦小的身躯更加丰满。他学会了少说话，多提问，总是皱着眉头，展现出一种深思熟虑的谦逊。在私人场合和亲密朋友面前，他仍然会流露出愤怒和沮丧。但在公共场合和熟人面前，他则是一个好人。他乐于称赞别人，发短信时全部用小写字母，表情丰富，总是带着笑脸和皱眉。他把自己的电话号码留给员工，鼓励他们随时联系他，并以令人印象深刻的专注度回复他们的反馈。他避免表达负面情绪，避免冲突，避免对人说“不”。有一次，OpenAI解雇了一名员工，他亲自伸出援手，提供氯胺酮和酒精来安慰他。“我觉得，无论你愿不愿意，Sam的所有感情最终都以好的方式结束。”这位员工说道。

A few years in, he had refined his appearance and ironed out the edges. He’d traded in T-shirts and cargo shorts for fitted Henleys and jeans. He’d built eighteen pounds of muscle in a single year to flesh out his small frame. He learned to talk less, ask more questions, and project a thoughtful modesty with furrowed brow. In private settings and with close friends, he still showed flashes of anger and frustration. In public ones and with acquaintances, he embodied the nice guy. He readily gave people credit for things and texted in all lowercase with lots of smiley and frowny faces. He gave employees his personal number, encouraging them to reach out at any time and responding to their feedback with impressive attentiveness. He avoided expressing negative emotions, avoided confrontation, avoided saying no to people. Once when OpenAI fired an employee, he reached out personally to offer ketamine and booze as consolation. “I think all of Sam’s relationships end in a good way whether you want it to or not,” the employee says.

Altman 成为了他自己的机构。YC 是他的平台和催化剂。他将 YC 的力量转化为自己的力量，将其人脉转化为自己的人脉。这些人际关系和公众声誉成为了他最大的财富。他定期与政策制定者会面，而这些政策制定者将他视为通往硅谷的门户。2016 年，奥巴马的国防部长阿什顿·卡特 (Ashton Carter) 向奥特曼寻求建议，以了解国防部如何挖掘年轻科技人才。三年后，也就是2019年3月，Altman从YC卸任的那天，卸任的是查克·舒默。时任美国参议院少数党领袖的舒默带着他的特勤局特工秘密访问了OpenAI。“你们正在做一项重要的工作，”舒默在办公室里对员工们说。他和Altman并排坐在扶手椅上，面前是一台放映着熊熊烈火的电视。“我们并不完全理解它，但它很重要，”舒默补充道。“而且我了解萨姆。你会得到很好的照顾。”

Altman became his own institution. YC was his platform and accelerant. He converted its power into his own power, its network into his own network. Those personal connections and his public reputation became his greatest currency. He met regularly with policymakers, who viewed him as a gateway to Silicon Valley. In 2016, it was Ashton Carter, Obama’s secretary of defense, who sought Altman’s advice on how his agency could tap into the well of young tech talent. Three years later, on the day Altman stepped down from YC in March 2019, it was Chuck Schumer. At the time the US Senate minority leader, Schumer paid a clandestine visit to OpenAI with his Secret Service detail. “You’re doing important work,” Schumer told employees in the office as he sat side by side with Altman in armchairs in front of a TV projecting a roaring fire. “We don’t fully understand it, but it’s important,” Schumer added. “And I know Sam. You’re in good hands.”

—

—

Altman 的崛起也伴随着日益增长的代价，因为他积累了越来越多的批评者和彻头彻尾的敌人，这些人与 Loopt 的高级副手们的指控如出一辙：他自私地追求权力，并且强迫性地不诚实。虽然许多人受益于 Altman 的建议、财富和人脉，成为了他的忠实拥护者，但也有人开始认为他极其擅长操纵局势，为己所用。对一些人来说，包括他在 YC 的合伙人和其他权力掮客，这可能是一种烦恼。对员工和那些影响力远不如他的人来说，这可能是一种恐惧。而对那些强烈反对他的世界观的人来说，他是一个巨大的威胁。

Altman’s ascendancy would also come at a mounting cost as he accumulated more and more detractors and outright enemies who would echo the accusations of his senior lieutenants at Loopt: that of his self-serving pursuit of power and his compulsive dishonesty. While many people who benefited from Altman’s advice, wealth, and networks became stalwart loyalists, others began to view him as devilishly capable of bending situations to his advantage. For some, including his partners at YC and other power brokers, this could be an annoyance. For employees and people with far less leverage, it could be a source of fear. To still others, who disagreed vehemently with his worldview, he was a massive threat.

阿尔特曼的攀升也让他痛苦不堪，继而愤怒不已，最终导致他与姐姐的关系破裂。从孩提时代到二十多岁，萨姆和安妮一直很亲密。她是最小的；他是最大的，是她的保护者。她热爱科学，又充满艺术气息，而且最善于表达情感。有时，他喜欢听取她对自己伴侣的看法，向她倾诉内心的担忧和情绪。但随着他在硅谷越来越根深蒂固，安妮看着他在自己最敏感的一面筑起越来越厚的墙。她记得，他会告诉她自己学到的新心理战术，比如在电子邮件中使用更少的词语，以显示自己作为商业领袖的强大力量。

Altman’s climb would also, to his agony and then ire, unravel his relationship with his sister. As kids and well into his twenties, Sam and Annie were close. She, the youngest; he, the oldest, her protector. She was science minded and the artsy one, the most emotionally expressive. At times he liked to get her opinions about his romantic partners, to confide in her about his inner worries and emotions. But as he grew more ingrained in Silicon Valley, Annie watched him build thicker and thicker walls around the part of him that was the most sensitive. He would tell her about new psychological tactics he’d learned, she remembers, like using fewer words in an email, to appear more powerful as a business leader.

起初，她感到难过，后来又感到害怕，担心那敏感的一面是否还在。“有一段时间，我确实还能瞥见它，所以我一直和他保持着密切的联系，”她说。“然后，我开始成为被他伤害的那个人。”

At first it made her sad, and then scared, about whether that sensitive part was even still there. “I definitely still got glimpses of it for a while, which was why I stayed close,” she says. “And then I started being the one to be harmed by him.”

她说，萨姆刚发家致富时，当时的男友定了一条规矩：萨姆每买一件高价商品，就得捐出等额的钱给慈善事业。这一度抑制了萨姆生活方式的快速增长。但随着他赚钱的速度超过花钱的速度，她觉得他与金钱的关系变得更加复杂。在她看来，他开始囤积金钱，是因为他越来越疏远那些需要帮助的人。据她与我分享的大量信件记载，从2019年底到2020年上半年，他和其他家人曾多次拒绝或不愿向安妮提供她认为是紧急经济援助的资金，以帮助她支付房租和医疗费用。当时，她的医疗和治疗记录显示，她面临着严重的身心健康问题，而父亲的突然去世更是加剧了她的病情。这使她陷入了住房不稳定的困境；为了维持生计，她开始从事性工作来赚钱。 2020 年夏天，当 OpenAI 在 Sam 的领导下开始获得第一波公众关注时，安妮切断了与家人的联系。

When Sam first came into wealth, she says, his then boyfriend created a rule: for every big-ticket item that Sam purchased, he needed to donate the same amount to a good cause. For a time, it created a check on the rapid creep of Sam’s lifestyle. But as he earned money faster than he could spend it, she felt his relationship with that money grow more complicated. In her view, he began to hoard it as he grew more and more out of touch with people in need. Through the end of 2019 and the first half of 2020, several times he and the rest of the family declined or were reluctant to provide Annie access to what she saw as emergency financial support to help front her rent and medical expenses, according to extensive correspondence she shared with me. At the time, she faced acute physical and mental health challenges, her medical and therapy records show, exacerbated by the sudden death of their father. It left her struggling with unstable housing; out of desperation to make ends meet, she turned to sex work for money. In the summer of 2020, as OpenAI began to gain its first major wave of public attention under Sam’s leadership, Annie would cut off contact with her family.

有证据表明，萨姆和他的兄弟们效仿了他们和安妮的母亲，试图推动安妮走向经济独立。这是一个复杂而痛苦的家庭故事，仅凭部分信息很难判断。2025 年 1 月，萨姆、他的母亲和两个兄弟在一份公开声明中表达了对安妮的爱和关心，并否认了她的所有指控，称其“完全不属实”。在回应我的采访请求和详细的评论请求时，康妮·吉布斯汀 (Connie Gibstine) 提供了一份类似声明的简短版本，并拒绝进一步阐述；萨姆 (Sam) 通过 OpenAI 的通讯团队和他的兄弟们没有做出回应。

There is a case to be made that Sam, as well as his brothers, were following the lead of their and Annie’s mother in an attempt to push Annie toward financial independence. It’s a complicated and painful family story, difficult to judge based on partial information. In a public statement in January 2025, Sam, his mom, and his two brothers expressed their love and concern for Annie and denied all of her allegations as “utterly untrue.” In response to my requests for interviews and detailed asks for comment, Connie Gibstine provided a shorter version of a similar statement and declined further elaboration; Sam, via OpenAI’s communications team, and his brothers did not respond.

尽管如此，安妮的经历与这些文章探讨了许多主题：在所谓的进步进程中，受益者和被抛在后面的人之间日益扩大的鸿沟；被剥夺权利的人面对日益扩大的鸿沟而失去了自主权和发言权；将如此大的权力不仅交给公司，也交给管理公司的个人，而没有相应的制衡框架，这种做法的局限性。安妮的行动也使她的故事成为理解 OpenAI 的发展轨迹及其对人工智能发展的影响不可或缺的一部分：2021 年，她决定公开对萨姆提出严重指控，声称他在她小时候对她实施了性虐待——她的家人称这是她“不实”指控中“最严重的”——而且他和家里的其他成员在她最脆弱的时候抛弃了她。随后，她于2025年1月6日，也就是她31岁生日的前两天，对萨姆提起了此类虐待指控的诉讼，以符合密苏里州此类案件的诉讼时效。安妮坚持不懈地提出指控，并讲述自己的故事，这不仅影响了萨姆，也影响了OpenAI的其他高管，因为他们正在应对萨姆和公司日益增长的全球影响力和声望。

Nevertheless, Annie’s experience contains striking parallels to the many themes explored within these pages: the ever-widening gulf between those who benefit and those left behind in the supposed march for progress; the loss of agency and voice among the disenfranchised confronted by that accelerating chasm; the limits of ceding so much power not just to companies but to the individuals who run them without the scaffolding to provide commensurate checks and balances. Annie’s actions would also make her story an inescapable part of understanding OpenAI’s trajectory and its impact on AI development: In 2021, she would make the decision to go public with serious allegations about Sam, claiming that he sexually abused her as a child—which her family has called “the worst” of her “untrue” accusations—and also that he and the rest of the family abandoned her when she was at her most vulnerable. She would subsequently file a lawsuit against Sam for such alleged abuse on January 6, 2025, two days before her thirty-first birthday, to meet the statute of limitations for such cases in Missouri. Annie’s persistent efforts to voice her allegations and tell her side of the story would affect Sam and influence OpenAI’s other executives as they contended with his and the company’s surge to global impact and prominence.

这些谜题的碎片——萨姆的崛起、他的性格和人际关系、他身后留下的分裂、金钱和权力的流向——都揭示了他突然而短暂的下台之路。在短暂的一瞬间，世界其他地方得以一窥最高层为决定人工智能的未来而展开的斗争。这将揭示，对这项技术——它已经重构了社会，改变了我们的地球——的主导地位的追求，最终在多大程度上取决于少数易犯错误之人的两极价值观、冲突的自我和混乱的人性。

Each of these puzzle pieces—Sam’s ascendence, his character and relationships, the divisiveness he left in his wake, the flows of money and power—speaks to the path that led to his sudden and fleeting ouster. For a brief moment, the rest of the world caught a glimpse into the struggles happening at the highest levels to dictate the future of artificial intelligence. It would reveal just how much the quest for dominance of that technology—already restructuring society and terraforming our earth—ultimately rests on the polarized values, clashing egos, and messy humanity of a small handful of fallible people.

第二章

Chapter 2

文明使命

A Civilizing Mission

格雷格·布罗克曼 (reg Brockman) 成为第一个致力于创建 OpenAI 的人。奥特曼亲自挑选了当时在谷歌担任人工智能研究员的伊利亚·苏茨克弗 (Ilya Sutskever) 来担任布罗克曼的联合创始人。奥特曼曾通过电子邮件邀请苏茨克弗参加 2015 年夏天的 Rosewood 晚宴；当得知马斯克将出席晚宴时，苏茨克弗欣然接受了邀请。

Greg Brockman became the first to commit to building OpenAI. To be Brockman’s cofounder, Altman handpicked Ilya Sutskever, then an AI researcher at Google whom Altman cold-emailed to come to the Rosewood dinner in the summer of 2015; Sutskever enthusiastically accepted upon learning that Musk would be in attendance.

布罗克曼和萨茨克弗是一对有趣的搭档。布罗克曼身材高大结实，举止和蔼可亲，他既是工程师，又像奥特曼一样热衷于创业。他在北达科他州的一个业余农场长大。在挤牛奶的间隙，他爱上了数学，后来又爱上了科学。2008 年，他进入哈佛大学学习，两年后转学到麻省理工学院。又读了一个学期后，他干脆退学了，因为他可以到现实世界去开发产品，所以无法再继续上学。他搬到了湾区，加入了 Stripe，当时这家初创公司只有另外三个人；他的编程天赋给创始人留下了深刻的印象，于是他成为了首席技术官。在五年的时间里，他为 Stripe 的许多早期产品制作了原型，帮助它成长为一家强大的金融科技公司，为亚马逊和 Shopify 等公司提供数字支付基础设施。这段经历让他积累了巨额财富，并因参与打造了这家价值数十亿美元的公司而获得了硅谷的稀有地位。

Brockman and Sutskever made an interesting duo. Tall and stocky, with an amiable demeanor, Brockman was an engineer and a startup guy like Altman. He had grown up on a hobby farm in North Dakota. In between milking cows, he fell in love with math and then science. In 2008, he enrolled in Harvard and transferred to MIT two years later. After another semester, he dropped out of college entirely, unable to swallow any more school when he could be out in the real world building products. He moved to the Bay Area and joined Stripe as a budding startup with only three other people; he impressed the founders so much with his coding genius that he became chief technology officer. Over five years, he prototyped many of Stripe’s early products, helping it grow into a powerhouse fintech company that provides digital payments infrastructure to the likes of Amazon and Shopify. The run left him with significant wealth and the rarefied Valley status of having helped build a multibillion-dollar company.

苏茨克维尔是一位科学家。他身材精瘦，出生于苏联，在以色列长大，并在那里成长为一名数学神童。由于难以找到能跟上他进步步伐的老师，他的父母在他八年级时送他进入以色列开放大学学习。十六岁时，他搬到多伦多，只上了一个月的高中，就于 2003 年被多伦多大学录取，成为三年级本科生。正是在那里，苏茨克维尔遇到了杰弗里·辛顿，一位在人工智能研究方面做出开创性贡献的英裔加拿大教授。辛顿成为苏茨克维尔唯一称之为导师的人，并且对他的工作和生活产生了深远的影响。2012 年，他与辛顿的另一名研究生亚历克斯·克里热夫斯基一起，在 ImageNet 学术竞赛中大获全胜，开发了用于自动识别照片中物体的软件，震惊了人工智能界。当其他团队都在努力将软件的错误率降至25%以下时，Hinton、Sutskever和Krizhevsky却将他们的软件错误率降至15%。次年年初，谷歌宣布以4400万美元的价格收购了他们新成立的公司DNNresearch。这一举动让这些学者成为了千万富翁，并掀起了人工智能商业化的第一次浪潮。我们以为自己是在拍电影，”欣顿说。

Sutskever was the scientist. Lean and wiry, he was born in the Soviet Union and raised in Israel, where he blossomed as a math prodigy. After struggling to find teachers who could keep up with his advancement, his parents enrolled him as an eighth grader in courses at the Open University of Israel. At sixteen, he moved to Toronto and attended high school for just a month before being admitted to the University of Toronto in 2003 as a third-year undergraduate student. It was there that Sutskever met Geoffrey Hinton, a British Canadian professor who had done seminal work in AI research. Hinton became the only person whom Sutskever would call a mentor and who’d subsequently have a profound influence on his work and life. In 2012, together with another one of Hinton’s grad students, Alex Krizhevsky, they shocked the AI world by sweeping the floor at an academic contest called ImageNet to build software for automatically identifying objects in photos. Where every other team struggled to get their software’s error rate below 25 percent, Hinton, Sutskever, and Krizhevsky drove theirs down to 15 percent. Early the following year, Google announced that it had acquired their newly formed company, DNNresearch, in a heated auction for $44 million. The move minted the academics into multimillionaires and unleashed the first major rush to commercialize artificial intelligence. “We thought we were in a movie,” Hinton says.

布罗克曼和萨茨克弗在玫瑰园晚宴上首次见面。和他们一样，房间里的其他人也都是企业家或科学家。讨论来回穿梭，既有关于人工智能研究不同方法的学术探讨，也有马斯克特别关注的——他们相信，是否还有时间击败DeepMind和谷歌，这对于纠正人工智能发展的进程至关重要。所有人都一致认为，关键的瓶颈在于人才：大多数顶尖的人工智能研究人员，比如萨茨克弗，如果不是受雇于谷歌，就是受雇于其他科技巨头，享受着丰厚的薪水、福利和工作保障。

Brockman and Sutskever met for the first time during the Rosewood dinner. Much like themselves, the others in the room were either entrepreneurs or scientists. The discussion ping-ponged back and forth between academic deliberations about different approaches to AI research and, Musk’s particular fixation, whether there was still time to beat out DeepMind and Google, essential, they believed, to correcting the course of AI development. The critical bottleneck, everyone agreed, was talent: Most of the top AI researchers were employed, like Sutskever, if not by Google, then by other tech giants, enjoying extravagant salaries, benefits, and job security.

AGI 也是讨论的焦点，这在当时非常罕见。大多数严肃的科学家认为，用数字技术复制真正的人类智能的想法只是科幻小说，或者至少是科幻小说。距离实现还有几十年甚至更久。大胆宣称目前投资即可实现，这在很大程度上被视为伪科学和江湖骗术。但哈萨比斯却欣然接受了这个词来描述DeepMind的雄心壮志，尽管他自己的研究人员认为这是一种令人反感的、无耻的营销手段。Rosewood团队同样认为，如果他们打算组建一个竞争对手，与哈萨比斯的组织展开竞争，那么通用人工智能（AGI）这个目标最能体现他们的愿景。

AGI was also central to the discussion, which at the time was highly unusual. Most serious scientists considered the idea of digitally replicating true human-level intelligence to be science fiction, or at the very least decades or more away from attainability. Bold declarations that it was within reach enough to invest in it presently was viewed largely as pseudoscience and quackery. But Hassabis had embraced that term to describe the ambitions of DeepMind, despite a belief among his own research staff that this was distasteful, shameless marketing. The Rosewood group equally felt that the same goal, AGI, would best describe their own aspirations if they intended to form a competitor to go toe to toe with Hassabis’s organization.

即使对于 Sutskever 来说，这种厚颜无耻的言论一开始也让他有些不安。Sutskever 暗自相信 AGI 是可能的，并且会全力支持一些关于其创造速度的最激进的预测。他担心，如果其他研究人员发现他在公开讨论追求这一目标，他将面临失去在科学界信誉的风险。这些担忧并没有阻止 Brockman，他是该领域的门外汉，真诚地相信，只要付出足够的努力和专注，AGI 指日可待。Sutskever 和其他研究人员愿意至少私下考虑建立新实验室的可行性，这只会增强 Brockman 的信心。那天晚上，Altman 开车送他从酒店回旧金山时，Brockman 告诉他，他已经准备好全身心投入到这个项目中。

Even to Sutskever, who secretly believed AGI was possible and would come to full-throatedly endorse some of the most aggressive predictions about the speed of its creation, the brazen talk at first made him a little squeamish. If other researchers found out that he was openly discussing the pursuit of this objective, he worried, he risked losing his credibility within the scientific community. Those concerns did not hold back Brockman, an outsider to the field and sincere in his belief that AGI, with enough effort and focus, could be just around the corner. That Sutskever and the other researchers were willing to at least privately entertain the feasibility of a new lab could have only strengthened Brockman’s confidence. As Altman drove him back from the hotel to San Francisco that night, Brockman told him that he was ready to commit himself to the project.

—

—

在硅谷，有句俗话：成为联合创始人就像步入婚姻殿堂。正如任何忠诚的伴侣关系一样，在Altman委婉地告诉Brockman，他需要一位了解AI研究的人作为搭档后，Brockman和Sutskever开始互相追求。在Rosewood的晚宴几周后，两人又在山景城单独吃了一顿饭。这真是天作之合。“虽然我们才刚认识，但我知道这一定会成功……我和伊利亚的交流非常活跃，”布罗克曼后来在博客上写道。“我们的想法互相促进，相得益彰。”

In Silicon Valley, there is a common saying: Becoming cofounders is like entering a marriage. As with any committed partnership, Brockman and Sutskever courted each other after Altman had diplomatically told Brockman he needed to be paired with someone who understood AI research. A few weeks after the Rosewood dinner, the two grabbed another meal alone in Mountain View. It was a perfect match. “I knew it was going to work though we’d just met…. Ilya and I had an extremely high-bandwidth interaction,” Brockman later wrote on his blog. “Our ideas enhanced and complemented one another.”

在接下来的几个月里，当苏茨克弗仔细思考这个提案时，布罗克曼承担起了说服其他人加入这项新“登月计划”的任务。他打电话给该领域的领军人物，征求他们推荐一份顶尖人工智能人才名单。他与教授们共进晚餐大学会询问他们最优秀的学生。为了更有说服力地招募他们，他在每次面试前都会对每位候选人进行深入研究。奥特曼后来在一篇博客文章中赞扬了这些早期的努力，文章标题很简单，就叫“格雷格”。“很多人问我，理想的联合创始人是什么样的，”奥特曼写道。“现在我有答案了：格雷格·布罗克曼。”

Over the next few months, as Sutskever thought through the proposal, Brockman took on the task of convincing others to join the new moonshot venture. He called leading figures in the field to get their recommendations for a list of top AI talent. He dined with professors at universities to ask about their best students. He heavily researched each candidate before any conversation to more persuasively recruit them. Altman would later extol those early efforts in a blog post simply titled “Greg.” “A lot of people ask me what the ideal cofounder looks like,” Altman wrote. “I now have an answer: Greg Brockman.”

奥特曼和马斯克也进行了相当多的招聘谈话，慢慢地放松了那些抵制 AGI 想法的研究人员的警惕。“通用人工智能或许遥不可及，但万一它真的来了呢？”加州大学伯克利分校教授皮特·阿比尔（Pieter Abbeel）记得马斯克曾这样鼓励他。“就算未来五到十年内，哪怕只有 1% 或 0.1% 的概率实现，我们难道不应该认真考虑一下吗？”阿比尔后来加入 OpenAI 担任研究顾问，后来又全职指导他的几名博士生。

Altman and Musk also had their fair share of recruiting conversations, slowly loosening up researchers resistant to the idea of AGI. “AGI might be far away, but what if it’s not?” Pieter Abbeel, a professor at the University of California, Berkeley, remembers Musk urging him. “What if it’s even just a 1 percent or 0.1 percent chance that it’s happening in the next five to ten years? Shouldn’t we think about it very carefully?” Abbeel would join OpenAI as a research adviser and later full time with several of his PhD students.

起初，布罗克曼接触的许多人都表示，只有其他人也愿意签约，他们才愿意签约。他毫不气馁，邀请了十位最想招募的工程师和研究人员，在纳帕谷一边品酒，一边讨论他们的犹豫和兴奋之情。他雇了一辆巴士接送所有人往返，这样他就可以继续在单程一个多小时的车程中向他们推销。三周后，也就是布罗克曼设定的截止日期，几乎所有人都接受了他的邀请。

At first, many of the people Brockman approached were willing to sign on only if others were as well. Undeterred, he invited his ten most-wanted engineers and researchers to discuss their hesitations and rally their excitement over wine in Napa Valley. He hired a bus to drive everyone there and back so he could continue pitching them on the more than hourlong ride each way. Three weeks later, by Brockman’s deadline, nearly all had accepted his offer.

当马斯克、奥特曼和布罗克曼讨论如何在OpenAI发布时为其设定最佳定位时，他们都敏锐地意识到公众认知的重要性。他们赞同奥特曼的建议，将OpenAI打造为非营利组织，并强调其名称所体现的开放性。OpenAI，作为谷歌的反面教材，将面向所有人开展研究，将科学成果开源，并成为透明度的典范。

As Musk, Altman, and Brockman discussed how best to position OpenAI at launch, all were keenly aware of the importance of its public perception. They agreed with Altman’s proposal to make it a nonprofit and to play up the openness for which it was named. OpenAI, the anti-Google, would conduct its research for everyone, open source the science, and be the paragon of transparency.

“我希望我们能以中立的姿态进入该领域，寻求广泛合作，并将对话转向人类的胜利，而不是任何特定的团体或公司，”布罗克曼在 2015 年 11 月写给马斯克和奥特曼的信中写道。“（我认为这是让我们成为领先研究机构的最佳途径。）”

“I hope for us to enter the field as a neutral group, looking to collaborate widely and shift the dialog towards being about humanity winning rather than any particular group or company,” Brockman wrote to Musk and Altman in November 2015. “(I think that’s the best way to bootstrap ourselves into being a leading research institution.)”

“公众的支持对我们的成功意义重大，”马斯克当月晚些时候回复道，并建议重写 OpenAI 成立公告，以使其更具吸引力。“我们需要“我们会给出比 1 亿美元大得多的数字，以免听起来与谷歌或 Facebook 的支出相比毫无希望，”他补充道。“我认为我们应该说，我们一开始就承诺提供 10 亿美元的资金。这是真的。其他人没有提供的，我会承担。”

“There is a lot of value to having the public root for us to succeed,” Musk replied later that month, with a suggestion to rewrite the announcement of OpenAI’s formation to have broader appeal. “We need to go with a much bigger number than $100M to avoid sounding hopeless relative to what Google or Facebook are spending,” he added. “I think we should say that we are starting with a $1B funding commitment. This is real. I will cover whatever anyone else doesn’t provide.”

在后来的通信中，该团队承认，一旦叙事达到目的，并且出现需要，例如为了避免不法分子窃取技术，他们可以撤回对开放的承诺。“随着我们越来越接近构建人工智能，开始降低开放程度是有意义的，”Sutskever 在 2016 年 1 月 OpenAI 成立后不久向三人提出。“openAI 中的开放意味着每个人都应该从人工智能建成后的成果中受益，但不分享科学成果也完全没问题。” “是的，”马斯克回应道。

In later correspondence, the group acknowledged that they could walk back their commitments to openness once the narrative had served its purpose and as the need arose, such as to avoid bad actors getting their hands on the technology. “As we get closer to building AI, it will make sense to start being less open,” Sutskever raised to the trio in January 2016, shortly after OpenAI launched. “The Open in openAI means that everyone should benefit from the fruits of AI after its [sic] built, but it’s totally OK to not share the science.” “Yup,” Musk responded.

2015年12月，OpenAI公告于一个周五晚发布，恰逢规模最大的年度人工智能研究会议——神经信息处理系统大会（Neural Information Processing Systems）。三年前，Hinton和Sutskever在此拍卖了DNNresearch。这篇题为“OpenAI简介”的博客文章列出了九位创始成员，包括将担任首席技术官的Brockman和将指导研究的Sutskever。马斯克和Altman将担任联合主席。Altman和Brockman也与马斯克一起承诺，要确保OpenAI获得10亿美元的资金。Jessica Livingston、Peter Thiel和LinkedIn联合创始人Reid Hoffman也做出了同样的承诺。Hoffman曾在PayPal与马斯克和Thiel共事，并经常与他们一起投资初创公司，被称为“PayPal帮”。该博文在谈到这笔资金时表示：“我们预计未来几年只会动用其中的一小部分。”

In December 2015, the announcement went out on a Friday night, to coincide with Neural Information Processing Systems, the largest annual AI research conference, where Hinton and Sutskever had auctioned off DNNresearch three years earlier. The blog post, “Introducing OpenAI,” listed each of the nine founding members, including Brockman, who would serve as CTO, and Sutskever, who would direct research. Musk and Altman would be cochairs. Altman and Brockman had also joined Musk in his pledge to see that the lab would have $1 billion in funding. So had Jessica Livingston, Peter Thiel, and LinkedIn cofounder Reid Hoffman. Hoffman had worked with Musk and Thiel at PayPal and often invested with them in startups as the “PayPal mafia.” “We expect to only spend a tiny fraction of this in the next few years,” the post said of the funding.

在宣布这一决定前的最后倒计时中，苏茨克弗几乎留在了谷歌。对于所有其他创始成员，OpenAI 提供了 175,000 美元的基本工资以及 YC 或 SpaceX 股票。对于苏茨克维尔来说，该实验室却向他提供了近 200 万美元，对于一家非营利组织来说，这是一笔巨款。即便如此，谷歌还是向他提供了更高的薪水，一次又一次，达到了两到三倍的薪水，以期留住他。马斯克和奥特曼一再推迟公司公告的发布，而苏茨克弗则苦苦挣扎，他给父母打电话，并回应了马斯克和布罗克曼的恳求。最终，谷歌令人眼花缭乱的提议让苏茨克弗更加明白了为什么像 OpenAI 这样的非营利组织是必要的。

In the final countdown before the announcement, Sutskever had almost stayed at Google. To all of the other founding members, OpenAI had offered a base salary of $175,000 and YC or SpaceX stock. To Sutskever, the lab had instead offered him nearly $2 million, a whopping sum for a nonprofit. Even then, Google had offered him more, and then more again, reaching two or three times that amount, in a bid to keep him. Musk and Altman delayed the company announcement repeatedly as Sutskever agonized over the decision, calling his parents and fielding pleas from Musk and Brockman. In the end, Google’s dizzying offer underscored to Sutskever why a nonprofit like OpenAI was needed.

那天，马斯克给创始团队发了一封电子邮件，郑重承诺将致力于带领OpenAI走向胜利。“我们最重要的考虑是招募最优秀的人才，”他写道，并承诺将全力支持这方面的工作，以及他能提供的任何帮助。“你们所熟知的组织在人员和武器方面都远远落后于我们，”他补充道，“但我们拥有优势，这对我们来说至关重要。我喜欢这种胜算。”为了防止其他反报价挖走创始团队成员，OpenAI 立即将每个人的基本工资再提高 10 万美元。

That day Musk marked the occasion with an email to the founding team solemnly pledging his commitment to making OpenAI victorious. “Our most important consideration is recruitment of the best people,” he wrote, which he promised to support, along with whatever else for which he could be helpful. “We are outmanned and outgunned by a ridiculous margin by organizations you know well,” he added, “but we have right on our side and that counts for a lot. I like the odds.” To preempt any other counteroffers from luring away members of their founding team, OpenAI immediately increased everyone’s base salary by another $100,000.

马斯克后来回忆起自己因亲自挖走萨茨克弗而遭到拉里·佩奇的怒斥。两人此后很少交谈，因为他们在人工智能发展方面的观点持续冲突。但 OpenAI 的招聘突然变得更容易了。在硅谷，登月计划和与亿万富翁的合作极具吸引力。几个月内，员工人数翻了一番。

Musk would later recount facing the fury of Larry Page for personally poaching Sutskever. The two didn’t speak much again as their views continued to clash on AI development. But OpenAI’s recruiting suddenly became easier. Moonshots and associations with billionaires were a powerful draw in the Valley. Within a few months, the number of employees doubled.

—

—

缺乏透明度、巨额支票以及对亿万富翁的崇拜，让硅谷的权力达到了顶峰。但 OpenAI 的定位非常巧妙：它巧妙地游走于技术沙文主义的硅谷与正在兴起的更具良知的硅谷之间。接下来的一年，唐纳德·特朗普在 2016 年美国总统大选中的惊人崛起和胜利，震惊了科技行业的左翼人士，促使他们进行反思。随着 Meta 和谷歌等公司发生剧变，以及“科技抵制”情绪席卷公众，人工智能研究人员也开始质疑，该领域是否发展过快，以至于将其技术与企业利润捆绑在一起。

The lack of clarity, the big check, and the billionaire worship were Silicon Valley at the heady peak of its unchecked power. But OpenAI had been clever with its positioning: It straddled the border between the techno-chauvinist version of Silicon Valley and a more conscientious strand that was emerging. Over the following year, Donald Trump’s spectacular rise and win in the 2016 US presidential election would shock the left-leaning workforce of the tech industry into self-reflection. As upheaval ripped through companies like Meta and Google and techlash sentiment gripped the public, AI researchers, too, began to question whether the field had moved too quickly to yoke its technologies to corporate bottom lines.

对人工智能研究商业化的社会影响的核算得出了令人不安的结论：出售给警察、抵押贷款经纪人和信贷机构的自动化软件正在加剧种族、性别和阶级歧视。Facebook 的新闻推送和 YouTube 的推荐系统运行的算法很可能加剧了公众的两极分化，助长了虚假信息和极端主义，使干预选举，以及最令人震惊的 Facebook 事件，引发了缅甸的种族清洗。

An accounting of the societal impacts of commercializing AI research returned an unsettling scorecard: Automated software being sold to the police, mortgage brokers, and credit lenders were entrenching racial, gender, and class discrimination. Algorithms running Facebook’s News Feed and YouTube’s recommendation systems had likely polarized the public, fueled misinformation and extremism, enabled election interference, and, most horrifying in the case of Facebook, precipitated ethnic cleansing in Myanmar.

但主要的融资替代方案——从政府获取资金——本身就存在道德风险。2018年，数千名谷歌员工抗议该公司与五角大楼签订的一项秘密合同，该合同旨在开发名为“Maven”的人工智能侦察无人机项目。员工们表示，这些能力可能为自主武器奠定基础；五角大楼表示，这并非其本意，乌克兰战争爆发后，五角大楼将放弃这一立场。

But the main funding alternative, taking money from the government, had its own ethical land mines. In 2018, thousands of Google employees would protest a secret company contract with the Pentagon for its program known as Project Maven to develop AI-powered surveillance drones. The capabilities, employees said, could lay the groundwork for autonomous weapons; the Pentagon, which said this had not been its intention, would move away from that position with the Ukraine war.

这在人工智能研究人员中成了一句玩世不恭的口头禅：要么向科技巨头或军工联合体出卖，要么退出人工智能研究。在这两个极端之间，OpenAI 似乎是第三条道路，既不受利润的侵蚀，也不受国家权力的腐蚀。它是一座希望的灯塔，”在场边观察的机器学习工程师兼热门科技博主 Chip Huyen 说道。

It became a cynical refrain among AI researchers: sell out to Big Tech or to the military industrial complex, or leave AI research. Between these binary extremes, OpenAI seemed like a third way, corrupted by neither profit nor state power. “It was a beacon of hope,” said Chip Huyen, a machine learning engineer and popular tech blogger observing from the sidelines.

但并非所有人都对此印象深刻。2015年12月OpenAI发布会当晚，曾质疑马斯克为何将人工智能威胁置于气候变化之上的人工智能研究员蒂姆尼特·格布鲁（Timnit Gebru）对OpenAI的声明感到难以置信。

Not everyone was impressed. On the night of OpenAI’s launch in December 2015, Timnit Gebru, the AI researcher who’d questioned Musk about prioritizing the threats of AI over climate change, couldn’t believe the announcement.

这位斯坦福大学的研究生，出生于埃塞俄比亚，是厄立特里亚难民，十几岁时移居美国。整整一周，她都在反思身处白人男性主导的环境中，作为一名黑人女性的代价有多高昂。这是她第一次参加为期一周的“神经信息处理系统”（NIPS，当时名为NIPS，后更名为NeurIPS）人工智能研究人员大会。她是现场仅有的黑人之一。第二年，在2016年的会议上，她进行了一次真正的统计：在8500名参会者中，只有另外6名黑人研究人员。在斯坦福，她开玩笑说校园里缺乏黑人研究人员，说她可以成立一个“人工智能黑人”小组，单独开会。她想象着创建一个YouTube频道来讽刺这种情况，改变发型，扮演不同的角色，以戏剧化的方式展现她与自己的对话。尽管她努力淡化自己的孤立感，但2015年的这场会议提醒她，事情可能很快就会变得充满敌意。在一个晚上的派对上，她她正在喝水，突然一群穿着谷歌研究T恤的醉汉盯上了她，并决定拿她开玩笑。他们把她团团围住。一个男人强行抱住她；另一个男人在她脸颊上亲了一下，还拍了一张羞辱她的照片。在同一次会议上，她的一个朋友还被一位教授骚扰了。

All week the Stanford University graduate student, an Ethiopia-born Eritrean refugee who moved to the US as a teen, had been reminded of the high cost of being a Black woman in an environment dominated by white men. It was her first time joining the throngs of AI researchers at the weeklong Neural Information Processing Systems, then called NIPS and later rebranded to NeurIPS for short. She was one of the only Black people there. The following year at the 2016 conference, she would put an actual tally to it, counting only six other Black researchers among the 8,500 attendees. At Stanford, she joked about the lack of Black researchers on campus by saying she could found a Black in AI group and have meetings alone. She imagined starting a YouTube channel to lampoon the situation, changing her hairstyle and acting out different personalities to dramatize her speaking with herself. But as much as she tried to make light of her isolation, this conference in 2015 was reminding her how quickly things could turn hostile. At a party one night, she was getting some water when a group of drunk guys wearing Google Research T-shirts locked eyes on her and decided to make her the object of their fun. They surrounded her. One man forced her into a hug; another foisted a kiss on her cheek as he snapped a humiliating photo. At the same conference, a friend of hers was harassed by a professor.

现在有一群人——其中十一人中有九人是白人——被给予了前所未闻的巨额金钱，谈论着邪恶超级智能统治世界的理论前景，并提议通过建立更好的超级智能来抵消它。

Now here was a group of people—nine out of eleven of whom were white men—being showered in previously unheard-of amounts of money, speaking about the theoretical prospect of a bad superintelligence taking over the world, and proposing to counteract it by building a better superintelligence.

当晚，格布鲁起草了一份措辞严厉的批评信，批评她在一封匿名公开信中观察到的情况：人工智能的奇观、对明星的狂热推崇，以及最重要的，构建和塑造如此重大技术的人员的压倒性同质化。这种同质化的文化不仅排挤了优秀的研究人员，还导致了对人工智能以及谁能从这项技术中受益的危险狭隘认识。

That night, Gebru drafted a scathing critique of what she’d observed in an anonymous open letter: the spectacle, the cultlike exaltation of AI celebrities, and, most of all, the overwhelming homogeneity of the people building and shaping such a consequential technology. This homogeneous culture was not only pushing away talented researchers but also leading to a dangerously narrow conception of AI and of who could benefit from the technology.

“我们无需预测未来就能看到人工智能的潜在负面影响，”格布鲁写道。“它已经发生了。”

“We don’t have to project into the future to see AI’s potential adverse effects,” Gebru wrote. “It is already happening.”

在从会议返回的航班上，她犹豫了很久，决定匿名发布这封信。最终，她用自己在Facebook上的名字，发布了一篇更简短、更清晰的批评文章。

On her flight back home from the conference, she thought twice about posting the letter anonymously. Instead she posted a shorter, more sanitized version of her critique, using her name on Facebook.

几周后，她写了一封电子邮件，主题是“来自 Timnit 的问候。”

Several weeks later, she typed up an email with the subject line “Hello from Timnit.”

“我去参加计算机视觉会议的时候，经常是那里唯一的黑人，”她写道。“但现在我已经看到你们五个人了:)，我觉得如果我们能成立一个人工智能黑人小组，或者至少互相认识一下，那一定很酷。”

“When I go to computer vision conferences, I am often the only black person there,” she wrote. “But now I have seen 5 of you:) and thought that it would be cool if we started a black in AI group or at least know of each other.”

她逐一添加了研究人员的电子邮件地址，然后按下了发送键。

One by one she added the researchers’ emails. And then she pressed send.

—

—

在 OpenAI 成立初期，Altman 和 Musk 几乎不担任联合主席。两人忙于其他事务，于是离开了布罗克曼和苏茨克弗共同组建了这家组织。苏茨克弗召集研究人员，向他提供最好的想法，而布罗克曼则全身心投入到构建合适的组织文化的工作中。

In the early days of OpenAI, Altman and Musk were barely around as cochairmen. Busy with their full plate of other endeavors, the two left Brockman and Sutskever to build up the organization. As Sutskever rallied researchers to give him their best ideas, Brockman threw himself into the work of developing the right organizational culture.

几年后，布罗克曼向我讲述了他的想法。为了做好准备，他阅读了所有能找到的关于美国历史上雄心勃勃的科技事业的书籍：横贯大陆的铁路、托马斯·爱迪生的电灯泡，以及奠定现代互联网基础的早期计算机网络。他像研读宗教经文一样吸收这些书籍，寻找如何设计自己事业的线索和指导。

Some years later, Brockman would recount to me his thinking. To prepare, he read every book he could find on ambitious science and technology undertakings in US history: the transcontinental railroad, Thomas Edison’s light bulb, the early network of computers that would lay the groundwork for the modern Web. He absorbed them like religious texts, searching for hints and guidance on how to design his own endeavor.

他珍藏的一个故事，是约翰·F·肯尼迪在NASA航天中心走近一位手持扫帚的看门人，这故事或许是杜撰的。“肯尼迪问他，‘先生，您在做什么？’他回答说，‘哦，我在帮助人类登上月球。’”布罗克曼回忆道，显然很高兴。“每个人都有这种使命感和目标感——我认为这真的很棒，而且在我看来，在如今普遍发生的事情中，这种感觉已经很少见了。”

One story he held dear was the likely apocryphal tale of John F. Kennedy approaching a janitor holding a broom at the NASA space center. “Kennedy asks him, ‘Sir, what are you doing?’ And he says, ‘Oh, I’m helping put a man on the moon,’ ” Brockman recounted, clearly delighted. “Everyone having this sense of mission and purpose—I think that’s something really amazing and something I don’t see as reflected in what happens generally today.”

他随后补充道：“我真的觉得我们美国人已经不再敢于梦想了。”

He later added: “I really feel like we as Americans have stopped daring to dream.”

他认为，要想成功，OpenAI 需要同样的团结一致；公司各个层级的每个人都需要像那位清洁工一样。他向我指出，事实上，在 OpenAI 成立的最初几个月里，当大家都在他的公寓里办公时，他确实体现了这种精神，花了很多时间清洁大家的玻璃器皿。他制定了一项公司政策，要求所有员工在旧金山办公室办公，OpenAI 一直坚持这项政策，直到疫情结束。当然，这也带来了一些代价；他承认，并非所有人都想住在湾区。我后来通过其他采访了解到，对于像格布鲁这样的女性和有色人种来说，这种情况尤其如此，他们感到被主流科技行业的白人和男性文化所疏远。但对布罗克曼来说，凝聚力更为重要，而身临其境的交流有助于偶然的思想交流。

To succeed, he believed, OpenAI needed that same level of alignment; every person at every level of the company needed to be like that janitor. He pointed out to me that, in fact, during the first few months of OpenAI, when everyone worked out of his apartment, he embodied that spirit literally and spent a lot of time cleaning people’s glassware. He created a company policy requiring all employees to work out of the San Francisco office, a policy that OpenAI would hold onto until the pandemic. This, of course, came with some trade-offs; not everyone wanted to live in the Bay Area, he acknowledged. I would learn through my other interviews that this was particularly true for women and people of color who, like Gebru, felt alienated by the white and male culture of the dominant tech industry. But to Brockman cohesion was more important, and being physically together helped with the serendipitous exchange of ideas.

布罗克曼也决定将所有 OpenAI 员工称为“技术人员”，这是受到施乐帕克研究中心 (Xerox PARC) 的启发。帕洛阿尔托研发实验室也这样做，效仿新泽西州同样著名的贝尔实验室的传统，以创造更加民主的工作环境。

Brockman decided, too, that he would call all OpenAI employees “members of technical staff,” inspired by Xerox PARC, the storied research and development lab in Palo Alto, which had done so, after a tradition at the equally famed Bell Labs in New Jersey, to create a more democratic work environment.

当谈到OpenAI追求通用人工智能（AGI）所面临的批评时，他将其与爱迪生发明的电灯泡进行了类比。“一个由杰出专家组成的委员会说‘这永远行不通’，但一年后，他就成功了，”布罗克曼说。怎么可能呢？ ”正如科普作家阿瑟·克拉克在《未来概况》一书中所说，“想象力的失败。”

When considering the criticisms leveled at OpenAI for its pursuit of AGI, he drew parallels with Edison’s light bulb. “A committee of distinguished experts said ‘It’s never going to work,’ and one year later he shipped,” Brockman said. “How could that be?” It was, as science writer Arthur C. Clarke in the book Profiles of the Future called it, “a failure of imagination.”

—

—

达里奥·阿莫迪（Dario Amodei）也出席了Rosewood晚宴。阿莫迪是一位计算神经科学家，后来成为人工智能研究员，此前曾在中国公司百度位于硅谷的人工智能实验室工作，之后又在谷歌短暂工作过一段时间。他的妹妹丹妮拉·阿莫迪（Daniela Amodei）曾与布罗克曼在Stripe共事，布罗克曼最初开始认真从事人工智能开发时，曾向达里奥寻求学习资源。达里奥并没有立即加入OpenAI，但他对OpenAI的理念很感兴趣。在马斯克的影响下，OpenAI似乎在其他人工智能实验室中脱颖而出，成为最愿意专注于所谓人工智能安全的机构。

Among the attendees at the Rosewood dinner had been Dario Amodei. Amodei, a computational neuroscientist turned AI researcher, was then working in the Silicon Valley–based AI lab of Chinese company Baidu before doing a brief stint at Google. His sister Daniela Amodei had worked with Brockman at Stripe, and when Brockman first started to engage seriously in AI developments, he had turned to Dario for learning resources. Dario didn’t join OpenAI immediately but was intrigued by the premise. OpenAI, under Musk’s influence, seemed to stand out from other AI labs as the most willing to focus on so-called AI safety.

2016 年，仍在谷歌任职的 Amodei 与他人合作撰写了一篇该学科的基础论文，阐明了人工智能安全的一个核心问题是解决“机器学习系统中的意外问题，定义为现实世界人工智能系统设计不良可能导致的意外且有害的行为。他和他的合著者写道，这与其他人工智能相关的挑战截然不同，包括隐私、安全、公平和经济影响。换句话说，在这个框架下，人工智能的“安全”是为了防止流氓的、失调的人工智能——正如尼克·博斯特罗姆所描述的，超级智能可能成为生存威胁的根源。

In 2016, while still at Google, Amodei cowrote a foundational paper to the discipline, articulating a central problem in AI safety as addressing “the problem of accidents in machine learning systems, defined as unintended and harmful behavior that may emerge from poor design of real-world AI systems.” This was distinct from other AI-related challenges, he and his coauthors wrote, including privacy, security, fairness, and economic impact. AI “safety” in this framework, in other words, was about preventing rogue, misaligned AI—the root from which, as described by Nick Bostrom, superintelligence could become an existential threat.

对阿莫迪来说，没有什么比阻止超人类人工智能造成灾难性后果，甚至人类灭绝更重要的事情了。阿莫迪兄妹都对有效利他主义（EA）运动表示同情。这种颇具争议的意识形态是在博斯特罗姆所在的牛津大学哲学家中兴起的。在硅谷扎根。随着时间的推移，这场运动宣扬致力于用极端理性和反直觉逻辑指导决策，为世界带来最大福祉。在很大程度上，由于博斯特罗姆的影响，这场运动将流氓人工智能的生存威胁视为其追随者们关注的首要议题。两年前，丹妮拉的丈夫霍尔登·卡诺夫斯基创立了一个名为“开放慈善”（Open Philanthropy）的非营利组织，部分基于“开放慈善”原则进行捐赠。这个名为“开放慈善”的组织很快成为灾难性及生存性人工智能安全研究的主要资助者。到 2024 年 11 月，它已颁发了三百多项与人工智能安全相关的拨款，价值 4.4 亿美元。）

To Amodei, there was no matter more important to work on: the prevention of superhuman AI causing catastrophic outcomes, even human extinction. Both Amodei siblings were sympathetic to the effective altruism, or EA, movement, a controversial ideology that had been spawned among philosophers at Oxford University, where Bostrom was based, and taken hold in Silicon Valley. Over time the movement, which preaches dedicating oneself to doing maximal good in the world by using extreme rationality and counterintuitive logic to guide decisions, had, in no small part due to Bostrom’s influence, identified the existential threat of rogue AI as a leading issue area for its adherents to pursue. Two years earlier, Daniela’s husband, Holden Karnofsky, had founded a nonprofit called Open Philanthropy to donate money in part based on EA principles. Open Phil, as it was called, would fast become the primary funder of catastrophic and existentially related AI safety research. (By November 2024, it had awarded more than three hundred AI-safety-related grants worth $440 million.)

但是，随着人工智能研究界逐渐意识到人工智能在现实世界中不那么可怕且直接的危害，这种建立在哲学思想实验基础上的人工智能安全存在主义很快就会受到抨击。就在阿莫迪发表论文的同时，ProPublica发表了一项名为“机器偏见”的开创性调查，揭露了美国刑事司法系统正在使用算法预测未来的犯罪行为，这些算法被错误地归类为比犯罪记录更丰富的白人更高的犯罪风险。这篇文章，以及2016年后人们对大型科技公司因社交媒体危害而普遍感到不满，引发了新一轮研究浪潮，旨在反思人工智能对社会的有害影响。

But this existential brand of AI safety, built on philosophical thought experiments, would soon come under fire as the AI research community awakened to the less apocalyptic and immediate real-world harms of AI.
