Around the same time Amodei published his paper, ProPublica published a groundbreaking investigation called “Machine Bias” that revealed algorithms were being used across the US criminal justice system in misguided attempts to predict future criminals, and those algorithms were classifying Black people as higher risk than white ones who had more extensive criminal records. The piece, and an overall souring on Big Tech post-2016 over the harms of social media, sparked a new wave of research reckoning with the harmful societal impacts of AI.

加州大学伯克利分校的人工智能问责研究员黛博拉·拉吉（Deborah Raji）倡导重新审视人工智能安全研究的过度关注点，即理论上的流氓人工智能及其可能存在的、损害其他真实存在、基于证据的问题的生存风险，并因此降低了其他问题的优先级。她于2020年与他人合著了一篇论文，回应了阿莫迪（Amodei）的观点。她认为，真正“安全”的人工智能系统不可能通过孤立技术系统本身的行为来构建，而必须将其置于其对隐私、公平和经济等问题（Amodei 所区分的）影响的全面背景下。阿莫迪提出了人工智能在不懈追求目标的过程中会产生“负面影响”的观点，她举了一个类似于回形针思维实验的例子：清洁机器人会撞倒花瓶或损坏墙壁。拉吉指出，人工智能行业正在走向“整理”之路，而这已经在发生。在对商业产品和通用人工智能（AGI）的不懈追求中，人工智能行业已经产生了广泛的负面影响，包括为训练面部识别技术而大规模侵犯隐私，以及支持该技术发展所需的数据中心不断上升的环境成本。

Deborah Raji, an AI accountability researcher at the University of California, Berkeley, would come to champion the reexamination of the overwhelming focus of AI safety research on theoretical rogue AI and its possible existential risks to the detriment and de-prioritization of other real, evidence-based problems, coauthoring a 2020 paper in response to Amodei’s. She argued that truly “safe” AI systems could not be built by isolating the behaviors of the technical systems themselves without placing them in full context of their impacts on the very things—privacy, fairness, and economics—that Amodei had set apart. Where Amodei had raised the idea of AI creating “negative side effects” as it relentlessly pursued an objective, using an example akin to the paper clip thought experiment of a cleaning robot knocking over a vase or damaging the walls on its path to tidying up, Raji pointed out that this was already happening. In its relentless pursuit of commercial products and AGI, the AI industry had produced expansive negative side effects, including the wide-scale infringement of privacy to train facial recognition and the spiraling environmental costs of the data centers required to support the technology’s development.

“不仅仅是人工智能代理的行为会产生副作用，”她和她的合著者写道。“在现实生活中，模型创建和部署过程中涉及的基本设计选择也会产生远远超出单个模型决策所能产生的影响的后果。实际上，即使是人工智能系统的构建，也往往存在着隐性的人力成本。”

“It is not just the actions of an AI agent that can produce side effects,” she and her coauthor wrote. “In real life, basic design choices involved in model creation and deployment processes also have consequences that reach far beyond the impact that a single model’s decision can have. In reality, for AI systems to even be built, there is very often a hidden human cost.”

在OpenAI内部，各种各样的研究人员，其中一些是公司少数有色人种女性，会敦促高管扩大“人工智能安全”的定义，并将深度学习模型的歧视性影响等领域的研究纳入其中。但高管们对此不屑一顾。“这不是我们的职责，”其中一位高管说道。

Within OpenAI, various researchers, some of them among the small handful of women of color at the company, would press executives to expand their “AI safety” definition and include research on areas such as the discriminatory impacts of deep learning models. Executives were dismissive. “That’s not our role,” one said.

2016年5月，仍在谷歌工作的阿莫迪来到OpenAI的办公室，了解情况。OpenAI刚刚从布罗克曼的公寓搬出，搬到了旧金山米慎区一家巧克力工厂楼上的一个地方。米慎区是旧金山最古老的街区，也是拉丁裔聚居区。研究人员们穿着袜子四处走动。

In May 2016, Amodei, still at Google, stopped by OpenAI’s office to see how things were going. OpenAI had just moved out of Brockman’s apartment to a space above a chocolate factory in San Francisco’s Mission District, the city’s oldest neighborhood and a Latino stronghold. Researchers padded around in socks.

“据《纽约客》报道，阿莫迪告诉阿尔特曼和布罗克曼，“这个领域有二三十个人，包括尼克·博斯特罗姆和维基百科文章，都说 OpenAI 的目标是构建一个友好的人工智能，然后向世界发布它的源代码。”

“There are twenty to thirty people in the field, including Nick Bostrom and the Wikipedia article, who are saying that the goal of OpenAI is to build a friendly AI and then release its source code into the world,” Amodei told Altman and Brockman, according to an account in The New Yorker.

“我们不打算发布所有源代码，”奥特曼说。“但请不要试图纠正这一点。这通常只会让情况变得更糟。”

“We don’t plan to release all of our source code,” Altman said. “But let’s please not try to correct that. That usually only makes it worse.”

“但是目标是什么？”阿莫迪问道。

“But what is the goal?” Amodei asked.

“我们现在的目标……是尽力而为，”布罗克曼回答道，“具体目标有点模糊。”

“Our goal right now…is to do the best thing there is to do,” Brockman replied. “It’s a little vague.”

两个月后，Amodei 加入并领导人工智能安全研究。此后，Open Phil 将向 OpenAI 捐赠 3000 万美元，以确保三年的霍尔顿·卡诺夫斯基（Holden Karnofsky）的董事会席位。2018年，应布罗克曼的邀请，曾担任Stripe首任招聘人员的丹妮拉（Daniela）也加入了OpenAI，担任工程经理和人事副总裁，以组建团队。“我们认识很久了，彼此都很甜蜜，”一年后，丹妮拉跟我开玩笑说起她和布罗克曼。“没错，”布罗克曼笑着说。“我们创办 OpenAI 的时候，我刚开始在这里招募员工，我就想，‘真希望我也有丹妮拉。’”

Amodei joined two months later to lead AI safety research. Thereafter, Open Phil would donate $30 million to OpenAI to secure a three-year board seat for Holden Karnofsky. In 2018, at Brockman’s invitation, Daniela, who had been the first recruiter at Stripe, would also move over to OpenAI to build up its team as an engineering manager and its VP of people. “We have a long, cute history of knowing each other,” Daniela would joke to me of her and Brockman a year later. “That’s right,” Brockman would say, chuckling. “When we started OpenAI, and I started doing the initial recruiting here, I was like, ‘I really wish I had Daniela.’ ”

到2020年底，Amodei兄妹对Altman和OpenAI背离其初衷的行为深感不安，于是他们决定分头成立另一个人工智能实验室Anthropic，带走关键员工，并由此引发竞争，最终在ChatGPT的疯狂发布中发挥了关键作用。Karnofsky在任期结束后，由于新的利益冲突而辞去OpenAI董事会职务。在他提名的继任者候选人名单中，包括他的一位前雇员：Helen Toner。

By the end of 2020, the Amodei siblings would become so disturbed by what they viewed as Altman’s and OpenAI’s break from its original premise that they would cleave off to form another AI lab, Anthropic, taking critical staff with them and creating a rivalry that would play a pivotal role in the frenzied release of ChatGPT. Karnofsky would step down from OpenAI’s board, having served his term and due to the new conflict of interest. On the list of candidates he nominated for his replacement, he would include one of his former employees: Helen Toner.

—

—

问题在于，OpenAI 根本不知道自己在做什么。一年来，在行业激烈的人才争夺战中，它通过挖角、恳求和借调，组建了一支顶尖团队，仅凭顶尖人才的密度就维持了内部的活力。然而，它却难以找到一个连贯的战略。而它之前的势头和光芒也开始消退。

The problem was that OpenAI had no idea what it was doing. A year in, it had poached, begged, and borrowed its way to a stellar team in the aggressive fight for talent within the industry, keeping up the excitement internally just from the sheer density of top people. Still, it struggled to find a coherent strategy. And the momentum and shine were beginning to wear off.

它的项目清单五花八门，简直就是这个领域一言难尽的缩影。它利用机器人、电子游戏和模拟虚拟世界来训练代理——所有这些都是为了尝试实现更高级的人工智能能力。但几乎没有什么成果是真正有效的，即使有成果，也感觉像是别人已经做过的东西的翻版。无论通用人工智能 (AGI) 是什么，它都不是。“他们做的那些大型项目，看起来都不像是在做什么超级创新的事情，”2017 年在 OpenAI 实习的人工智能研究员尼基尔·米什拉 (Nikhil Mishra) 说。

Its list of projects sprawled every which way in a kitchen-sink reflection of the field. It was using robots and video games and simulated virtual worlds for training agents—all as ways of trying to reach more advanced AI capabilities. Little was working, and what did work felt derivative of something someone else had already done. Whatever AGI was, it wasn’t that. “The bigger projects that they had, it didn’t seem like they were doing anything super innovative,” says Nikhil Mishra, an AI researcher who interned at OpenAI in 2017.

布罗克曼和萨茨克弗的领导能力也受到了极大的挑战。布罗克曼大部分时间都在写代码，而萨茨克弗则在办公室里踱来踱去，反复询问每位研究员：“你的下一个大项目是什么？” 这使得团队上下无定所，压力巨大。环境。没有真正的管理架构，也没有明确的工作重点。有时有人会在周末被解雇，而团队的其他成员直到下周一才发现他们被解雇了，因为他们根本没来上班。实验室还在烧钱，大部分都用来压低刚组建的团队的工资。2016 年，OpenAI 在 1100 万美元的支出中，有 700 多万美元用于薪酬和福利。

Brockman’s and Sutskever’s leadership abilities were also being pushed to their limits. While Brockman spent most of his days coding, Sutskever stalked around the office repeatedly asking each researcher, “What’s your next big thing?” It made for a rudderless, high-stress environment. There was no real management structure or clear set of priorities. Sometimes people would get fired on the weekends, and the rest of the team would only find out the following Monday when they didn’t show up. And the lab was burning cash, most of it to hold down the salaries of the team it had assembled. In 2016, OpenAI spent more than $7 million out of its $11 million in expenses on compensation and benefits.

马斯克开始失去耐心。DeepMind 突然赢得了全世界的赞誉，但这并没有起到什么帮助作用。2016 年 3 月，它的程序 AlphaGo 击败了世界顶尖的人类围棋选手之一李世石。（“DeepMind 让我精神压力极大，”马斯克在五局比赛前不久写信给 OpenAI 领导层。“如果他们赢了，那对他们一心一意统治世界的理念来说可就糟了。”）比赛在韩国进行了直播，吸引了超过两亿观众。一年后，Netflix 发布了一部关于该公司发展历程的轰动性纪录片。

Musk was getting impatient. It didn’t help that DeepMind was suddenly garnering worldwide adulation. In March 2016, its program AlphaGo beat Lee Sedol, one of the world’s best human players in the ancient Chinese game of Go. (“Deepmind is causing me extreme mental stress,” Musk wrote to OpenAI leadership shortly before the five-game match. “If they win, it will be really bad news with their one mind to rule the world philosophy.”) The games were live streamed from South Korea to over two hundred million viewers. A year later Netflix released a blockbuster documentary about the company’s journey.

马斯克会定期到办公室来要求取得更多进展，有时会设定完全不切实际的截止日期，这正是他管理理念的典型特征。许多员工对这些期望感到不满，认为这些期望与研究的曲折性和不可预测性格格不入。在一次全体会议上，曾是创始团队成员的机器人技术负责人沃伊切赫·扎伦巴 (Wojciech Zaremba) 介绍了他希望团队追求的机器人技术进步计划。马斯克只有一个问题：“什么时候？你们什么时候打算做这些事？”

Musk came into the office periodically to demand more progress, at times setting completely unrealistic deadlines that were characteristic of his management philosophy. Many employees chafed at the expectations, believing they made no sense for the winding, unpredictable nature of research. During one all-hands meeting, Wojciech Zaremba, the robotics lead who had been part of the founding group, presented his plans for the kinds of robotics advancements he wanted his team to pursue. Musk had only one question: “When? When are you going to do those things?”

“我不知道，”扎伦巴说。

“I don’t know,” Zaremba said.

马斯克反驳道：“那你其实没什么计划。”

Musk pushed back. “Well, then you don’t really have a plan.”

因此，在2017年3月，布罗克曼和苏茨克弗开始认真制定更具针对性的研究路线图。他们的核心问题是：OpenAI要实现通用人工智能（AGI），并成为第一个实现这一目标的公司，究竟需要什么？

So in March 2017, Brockman and Sutskever began in earnest to develop a more focused research road map. Their central question: What would it really take for OpenAI to reach AGI—and be the first to do so?

Sutskever 直觉地认为，这首先与一个关键维度有关：OpenAI 需要的“计算量”（指计算资源），才能在 AI 能力上取得重大突破。他参与的 ImageNet 竞赛及其后续进展都与计算资源的大幅提升有关。用于训练人工智能模型的计算量。这些进步还涉及其他方面：显著增加的数据和更复杂的算法。但 Sutskever 认为，计算才是王道。他相信，如果计算规模能够达到足以训练人脑规模的人工智能模型的程度，那么必将出现一些颠覆性的东西：通用人工智能 (AGI)。

Sutskever intuitively believed it would have to do with one key dimension above all else: the amount of “compute,” a term of art for computational resources, that OpenAI would need to achieve major breakthroughs in AI capabilities. The ImageNet competition and subsequent advancements that he had been a part of had all involved a material increase in the amount of compute that had been used to train an AI model. The advancements had involved other things, too: significantly more data and more sophisticated algorithms. But compute, Sutskever felt, was king. And if it were possible to scale compute enough to train an AI model at human brain scale, he believed, something radical would surely happen: AGI.

计算量取决于三个因素：单个计算机芯片的处理能力，即每秒可以进行的计算次数；可用的计算机芯片总数；以及它们需要运行多长时间才能完成计算。第一个因素由计算机芯片制造行业决定，几十年来，该行业通过深入的研究和开发，每两年将单个芯片的马力翻一番。这种进步速度被称为摩尔定律，它基于英特尔传奇创始人戈登·摩尔在 20 世纪 60 年代首次提出的关于其行业创新速度的预测，十年后对其进行了修订。摩尔定律变成了一个自我实现的预言。它成为芯片制造公司认为需要多快创新才能跟上竞争并保持相关性的目标。

The amount of compute is based on three things: the processing power of an individual computer chip, or how many calculations it can crunch per second; the total number of computer chips available; and how long they are left running to perform their calculations. The first is dictated by the computer chipmaking industry, which has for decades doubled the horsepower of a single chip every two years through intensive research and development. This rate of progress is known as Moore’s Law, based on a prediction that legendary Intel cofounder Gordon Moore first made in the 1960s, then revised a decade later, about how quickly his industry could innovate. Moore’s Law turned into a self-fulfilling prophecy. It became the target for how quickly chipmaking firms believed they needed to innovate in order to keep up with competition and stay relevant.

布罗克曼和萨茨克弗进行了一个简单的计算：按照摩尔定律的速度，OpenAI 需要多长时间才能达到脑级人工智能所需的计算水平？答案是坏消息：这将需要太长时间。

Brockman and Sutskever performed a simple calculation: Based on the pace of Moore’s Law, how long would it take to reach the level of compute OpenAI needed for brain-scale AI? The answer was bad news: It would take far too long.

大约在同一时间，Amodei 和另一位研究员 Danny Hernandez 开始从不同的角度研究同一个想法。他们在一张简单的图表上，以时间为横轴，绘制了自 2012 年以来，人工智能研究中每一项重大突破实际使用的计算量，从 Sutskever 在研究生院取得的突破，也就是人工智能革命的开始，一直到现在。他们发现，计算使用量的增长速度实际上比摩尔定律更快，快得多。在过去的六年里，它每3.4 个月就翻一番，或者换句话说，增长了3000 万个百分点。

Around the same time, Amodei and another researcher, Danny Hernandez, had begun to look at the same idea from a different direction. On a simple chart, with time as the x-axis, they plotted the amount of compute that every major breakthrough in AI research had actually used since 2012, beginning with Sutskever’s grad school breakthrough, the start of the AI revolution. They discovered that compute use was in fact growing faster than Moore’s Law. Much faster. In the last six years, it had doubled every 3.4 months, or, put another way, increased 30 million percent.

布罗克曼开始将这条新的倍增曲线称为 OpenAI 定律。他和其他领导层认为，OpenAI 不仅需要大量计算才能实现最终目标，还需要扩大其规模。计算速度至少要与这条新定律相匹配。芯片制造公司曾以生存的热情将摩尔定律强加于他们的公司；现在，领导层也以同样的眼光看待 OpenAI 定律。

Brockman began to call this new doubling curve OpenAI’s Law. Not only did OpenAI need massively more amounts of compute to reach its end goal, he and the other leadership believed it also needed to scale its compute at a pace that at the very least matched this new law. Chipmaking firms had imposed Moore’s Law on their companies with existential fervor; the leadership now saw OpenAI’s Law in the same light.

如果他们等不到摩尔定律，他们就需要以另一种方式来提高他们的计算能力：他们需要大量的芯片。

If they couldn’t wait for Moore’s Law, they needed to grow their compute the other way: They needed a whole hell of a lot more chips.

—

—

OpenAI 所需的芯片价格不菲。它们被称为图形处理单元（GPU），最初的设计目的是在计算机上快速渲染图形，例如为视频游戏提供低延迟、高光的画面效果。但同样的尺寸在训练 OpenAI 想要开发的 AI 模型方面表现出色，因为它们与图形渲染有着共同的需求：需要并行处理大量数据。

The kinds of chips that OpenAI needed were expensive. Known as graphics processing units, or GPUs, they had originally been designed to quickly render graphics on computers, such as for giving video games a low-latency, glossy finish. But the same form factor excelled at training the AI models OpenAI wanted to develop, since they shared with graphics-rendering a common requirement: the need for crunching massive amounts of numbers in parallel.

业内绝大多数企业只从一家公司购买 GPU：总部位于圣克拉拉的芯片制造商英伟达 (Nvidia)。英伟达不仅制造了世界上最好的 GPU，还开发了一个名为 CUDA（计算统一设备架构的缩写）的配套软件平台，该平台对 AI 开发者有着强大的吸引力。

The vast majority of the industry bought these GPUs from only one company: the Santa Clara–headquartered chipmaker Nvidia. Nvidia not only made the best GPUs in the world but also had developed a companion software platform called CUDA, short for Compute Unified Device Architecture, that had a powerful grip on AI developers.

2017年，一台配备八块英伟达顶级GPU的定制服务器售价15万美元——到2023年，随着通货膨胀，这一价格将大致上涨至近19.5万美元。OpenAI定律预测，在未来几年，OpenAI将需要数千甚至数万块GPU来训练一个模型。用于支持这种训练的电力成本也将激增。OpenAI需要更多资金——不仅仅是10亿美元，而是数十亿美元来维持未来几年的运营。

In 2017, a custom Nvidia server with eight of their best GPUs cost $150,000—a price that would rise roughly with inflation to nearly $195,000 by 2023. In the coming years, OpenAI’s Law was projecting that OpenAI would need thousands, if not tens of thousands, of GPUs to train just a single model. The cost of electricity to power that training would also explode. OpenAI needed more money—not just $1 billion, but billions of dollars to sustain itself in the coming years.

这种认识将导致该组织失去财务基础。对布罗克曼和萨茨克弗来说，这挑战了OpenAI架构的根本前提。一个非营利组织如何能够每年筹集如此多的资金，以保持领先地位所需的速度？他们曾短暂考虑与一家芯片初创公司合并，但在2017年夏天，他们开始与Altman和Musk认真讨论OpenAI是否需要转型为营利性公司。这是他们吸引投资者并创造财务回报机会的最大希望。经过数周的谈判，讨论突然终止，没有达成任何结果。如果OpenAI 将成为一家营利性公司，奥特曼希望成为该公司的首席执行官，当时他正在考虑竞选加州州长，但在焦点小组中反响平平。马斯克也是如此；他希望完全控制实验室并拥有多数股权。

The realization would lead the organization to lose its financial footing. To Brockman and Sutskever, it challenged the very premise of OpenAI’s structure. How could a nonprofit raise that much annually to keep up with the pace required to stay number one? They briefly considered merging with a chip startup, but, in the summer of 2017, they began serious discussions with Altman and Musk about whether OpenAI needed to transform into a for-profit. That was their best hope to entice investors with a chance at generating a financial return. After several weeks of negotiations, the deliberations ended abruptly without resolution. If OpenAI were to become a for-profit, Altman, who was in the middle of considering his run for California governor and getting a lackluster reception in focus groups, wanted to be the company’s chief executive. So did Musk; he wanted full control of the lab and to have majority equity.

萨茨克弗和布罗克曼左右为难，几乎选择了后者。两人都更倾向于马斯克的领导。但阿尔特曼直接向布罗克曼表达了他们之间的私人关系以及对马斯克不可靠的担忧。马斯克面临诸多外部压力，行为反复无常，反复无常。如果OpenAI成功，将通用人工智能完全交给马斯克控制岂不是危险？布罗克曼深信不疑，于是向萨茨克弗求助，但萨茨克弗仍然犹豫不决。2017年9月，他代表自己和布罗克曼给马斯克和阿尔特曼发了一封电子邮件，试图做最后的努力来化解局面。

Caught in the middle, Sutskever and Brockman nearly went with the latter. The two preferred Musk’s leadership. But Altman appealed to Brockman directly with their personal relationship and concerns about Musk’s unreliability. Musk faced many external pressures and was prone to erratic and unstable behavior. Should OpenAI succeed, wouldn’t it be dangerous to give Musk full control of AGI? Convinced, Brockman appealed to Sutskever, who remained uncertain. In September 2017, he emailed Musk and Altman, on behalf of him and Brockman, in a last-ditch attempt to resolve the situation.

“埃隆：我们真的想和你合作，”苏茨克弗写道。“我们相信，如果我们联手，我们完成任务的几率最大。”但他表示，马斯克对完全控制的渴望与 OpenAI 的初衷背道而驰。“你担心德米斯会建立一个通用人工智能独裁政权。我们也是。所以，建立一个让你自己选择成为独裁者的体制是个坏主意。”

“Elon: We really want to work with you,” Sutskever wrote. “We believe that if we join forces, our chance of success in the mission is the greatest.” But Musk’s desire for total control felt antithetical to OpenAI’s original spirit, he said. “You are concerned that Demis could create an AGI dictatorship. So [are] we. So it is a bad idea to create a structure where you could become a dictator if you chose to.

“萨姆：每当格雷格和我陷入困境时，你总能给出深刻而正确的答案，”萨茨克弗继续说道。话虽如此，奥特曼的行为常常让两人对他的真实信念和意图感到困惑。“我们不明白为什么CEO这个头衔对你如此重要，”他写道。“你陈述的理由已经改变了，很难真正理解是什么在驱动着你。AGI真的是你的主要动机吗？它与你的政治目标有什么关联？你的思维方式是如何随着时间而改变的？”

“Sam: When Greg and I are stuck, you’ve always had an answer that turned out to be deep and correct,” Sutskever continued. That said, Altman’s behaviors had often left the two confused about his true beliefs and intentions. “We don’t understand why the CEO title is so important to you,” he wrote. “Your stated reasons have changed, and it’s hard to really understand what’s driving it. Is AGI truly your primary motivation? How does it connect to your political goals? How has your thought process changed over time?

“我们面临的问题已经够多了，我们认为见面谈谈非常重要，”他在邮件中总结道。“如果我们都说实话，解决问题，我们创建的公司就更有可能承受住即将经历的强大压力。”

“There’s enough baggage here that we think it’s very important for us to meet and talk it out,” his email concluded. “If all of us say the truth, and resolve the issues, the company that we’ll create will be much more likely to withstand the very strong forces it’ll experience.”

不到十分钟，马斯克就回复了。“伙计们，我受够了。这是最后一根稻草，”他写道。如果Sutskever和Brockman仍然想要追求营利性，他们就必须独立发展。否则，OpenAI 将继续以非营利组织的形式存在。“除非你坚定地承诺留下来，否则我不会再资助 OpenAI，否则我就是个傻瓜，基本上是在免费资助一家初创公司，”马斯克说道。五十分钟后，他又补充道：“需要明确的是，这不是接受之前讨论内容的最后通牒。现在不再讨论这些内容了。”

Within ten minutes, Musk had responded. “Guys, I’ve had enough. This is the final straw,” he wrote. If Sutskever and Brockman still wanted to pursue a for-profit, they would need to strike out on their own. Otherwise, OpenAI would continue as a nonprofit. “I will no longer fund OpenAI until you have made a firm commitment to stay or I’m just being a fool who is essentially providing free funding to a startup,” Musk said. Fifty minutes later, he followed up again. “To be clear, this is not an ultimatum to accept what was discussed before. That is no longer on the table.”

第二天早上，奥尔特曼在帖子中插话说：“我仍然对非营利结构充满热情！”他通过马斯克最信任的副手之一希冯·齐利斯（Shivon Zilis）向马斯克传达了进一步的保证。希冯·齐利斯曾在特斯拉和马斯克的脑机接口公司 Neuralink 工作。“很高兴能保持非营利性并继续支持它，”齐利斯在给马斯克的信中记录了奥尔特曼告诉她的话。“他承认，在这个过程中，他失去了格雷格和伊利亚很大的信任。感觉他们传达的信息不一致，有时还显得幼稚。”奥尔特曼还对格雷格和伊利亚在整个谈判过程中不断与 OpenAI 其他成员分享信息感到困扰。“感觉这分散了团队的注意力，”齐利斯说。

Altman piped up in the thread the following morning: “i remain enthusiastic about the non-profit structure!” He sent further assurance to Musk via one of Musk’s trusted deputies, Shivon Zilis, who worked at Tesla and Neuralink, his brain-machine interface company. “Great with keeping non-profit and continuing to support it,” Zilis wrote to Musk with notes of what Altman told her. “Admitted that he lost a lot of trust with Greg and Ilya through this process. Felt their messaging was inconsistent and felt childish at times.” Altman had also been bothered by how much Greg and Ilya kept sharing with the rest of OpenAI throughout the negotiations. “Felt like it distracted the team,” Zilis said.

—

—

但现实是，保持 OpenAI 的非营利性并不能解决其资金问题。布罗克曼和苏茨克弗继续与潜在的非营利投资者会面，但他们难以获得他们认为 OpenAI 所需的资金。马斯克在资金承诺上的反复无常也威胁着 OpenAI 陷入危机。在幕后，奥特曼开始寻找其他融资途径，并试图摆脱 OpenAI 对马斯克的依赖。他打电话给雷德霍夫曼 (Reid Hoffman)，后者愿意介入并控制员工工资和运营成本。他考虑推出一种新的加密货币。他调查了一系列不同的公司结构，包括公益公司。马斯克一直热衷于公益公司，认为它能让OpenAI转型为营利性公司，同时又能使其在法律上履行使命。

But the reality was that keeping OpenAI a nonprofit wouldn’t solve its money problem. As Brockman and Sutskever continued to meet with potential nonprofit investors, they struggled to get anywhere near the kind of capital that they believed OpenAI would need. Musk’s capricious wavering on his funding commitment also threatened to throw OpenAI into a state of crisis. Behind the scenes, Altman began searching for funding alternatives and to wean off OpenAI’s dependency on Musk. He called Reid Hoffman, who offered to step in and hold down employee salaries and operational costs. He considered launching a new cryptocurrency. He investigated an array of different corporate structures, including a public benefit corporation, which Musk had been keen on and would allow OpenAI to become a for-profit while still legally binding it to its mission.

加剧紧迫性的是，人们始终担心 OpenAI 随时可能失去其最优秀的研究人员。此前，在马斯克的强力支持下，OpenAI 曾大幅提高其非营利部门的薪酬，以抵御反制措施。如今，人才争夺战愈演愈烈。这场争论愈演愈烈，马斯克本人也在2017年6月挖走了OpenAI的关键创始科学家之一安德烈·卡帕西（Andrej Karpathy），让他来领导特斯拉的AI部门。在薪酬方面，OpenAI有一个很大的劣势：它无法提供公司股权，而许多湾区科技工作者认为，股权是支付高昂生活成本的必要条件。

Compounding the urgency was an ever-present worry that OpenAI could lose its best researchers at any moment. Previously, with Musk’s firm backing, OpenAI had aggressively cranked up its nonprofit salaries to ward off counteroffers. Now the talent war had only grown more heated, and Musk himself had poached away one of OpenAI’s key founding scientists, Andrej Karpathy, in June 2017, to direct Tesla’s AI division. On compensation, OpenAI had a major disadvantage: It couldn’t offer equity into the organization, which many Bay Area tech workers viewed as necessary to afford the steep cost of living.

马斯克很快就找到了解决 OpenAI 资金问题的方案。2018 年 1 月，安德烈·卡帕西 (Andrej Karpathy) 给马斯克发送了一封电子邮件，其中包含谷歌在顶级人工智能研究出版物中的主导地位的新数据。卡帕西写道：“不幸的是，在人工智能前沿领域工作成本高昂。在我看来，OpenAI 如今正在烧钱，而且其融资模式无法达到与谷歌（一家 8000 亿美元的公司）真正竞争的规模。”虽然将 OpenAI 转变为自己的营利性机构可以帮助筹集资金，但这需要实验室从头开始开发人工智能产品，这会严重分散其对基础人工智能研究的注意力。卡帕西说：“正如我之前提到的，我能想到的最有希望的选择是让 OpenAI 依附于特斯拉作为它的摇钱树。”他继续说道，特斯拉已经完成了开发人工智能产品的大部分繁重工作，即其自动驾驶功能 Autopilot。如果 OpenAI 能够帮助特斯拉加快将 Autopilot 发展成为成熟的自动驾驶解决方案的努力，那么仅此一项就可能足以提高特斯拉的收入，以支付 OpenAI 昂贵的计算费用。

Musk soon arrived at his own conclusion for how to solve OpenAI’s money problem. In January 2018, Andrej Karpathy emailed Musk with new data showing how much Google was dominating top AI research publications. “Working at the cutting edge of AI is unfortunately expensive,” Karpathy wrote. “It seems to me that OpenAI today is burning cash and that the funding model cannot reach the scale to seriously compete with Google (an 800B company).” While turning OpenAI into its own for-profit could help raise capital, it would require the lab to develop an AI product from scratch, a significant distraction from its fundamental AI research. “The most promising option I can think of, as I mentioned earlier, would be for OpenAI to attach to Tesla as its cash cow,” Karpathy said. Tesla had already done most of the heavy lifting to develop an AI product—namely, its self-driving function, Autopilot, he continued. If OpenAI could help speed up Tesla’s efforts to mature Autopilot into a full-fledged self-driving solution, that alone could possibly boost Tesla’s revenue enough to foot OpenAI’s costly compute bill.

马斯克将卡帕西的邮件转发给了布罗克曼和苏茨克弗。“安德烈说得完全正确，”马斯克写道。“特斯拉是唯一一条有望与谷歌抗衡的道路。即便如此，它成为谷歌制衡力量的可能性也很小。当然，可能性不为零。”

Musk forwarded Karpathy’s email to Brockman and Sutskever. “Andrej is exactly right,” Musk wrote. “Tesla is the only path that could even hope to hold a candle to Google. Even then, the probability of being a counterweight to Google is small. It just isn’t zero.”

但那时，奥特曼已经放弃了他的政治计划，并成功说服布罗克曼，并通过布罗克曼说服了萨茨克弗，让他相信自己才是更优秀的领导者。鉴于该组织的决定，马斯克不再希望公开与该组织有任何关联。“我不会让自己的影响力和时间与现实不符，”他之前写道。几周后，马斯克辞去了OpenAI联合主席一职。奥特曼成为该非营利组织的总裁。

But by then, Altman had abandoned his political plans and succeeded in his efforts to persuade Brockman, and, through Brockman, Sutskever, that he would be the better leader. With the group’s decision, Musk no longer wanted to be publicly affiliated with the organization. “I will not be in a situation where the perception of my influence and time doesn’t match the reality,” he’d previously written. A few weeks later, Musk stepped down as OpenAI cochair. Altman became president of the nonprofit.

OpenAI 向公众解释称，马斯克的离职是因为利益冲突，并对其新的财务现实保持沉默：在10亿美元的承诺中，最终只收到了约1.3亿美元的资金，其中不到4500万美元来自马斯克。OpenAI的未来现在取决于奥特曼能否凭借其独特的融资能力弥补这些损失，并继续满足其日益增长的资金需求。

To the public, OpenAI framed the departure as Musk having a conflict of interest and stayed mum about its new financial reality: Of the $1 billion commitment, it ultimately received only around $130 million, less than $45 million of which had come from Musk. OpenAI’s future now rested on Altman’s singular fundraising abilities to recover those losses and continue to fulfill its accelerating need for even more capital.

马斯克在OpenAI全体会议上亲自宣布了离职决定。对于许多不了解领导层内幕的员工来说，马斯克的离职不仅减轻了压力，也给公司的未来带来了巨大的不确定性。此前，马斯克一直是OpenAI公众形象的重要推动者。在会议上，他直言不讳：首先要开发安全的通用人工智能（AGI）至关重要，现在很明显，OpenAI作为非营利组织无法做到这一点；他将在特斯拉追求同样的目标，特斯拉是一家资源雄厚的公司，拥有雄厚的资金，成功的可能性要大得多。

Musk announced his decision to leave in person at an OpenAI all-hands meeting. To many employees, unaware of any of the drama at the leadership level, Musk’s departure brought a release of pressure but also significant uncertainty about the future of the organization. Until then, Musk had been a big driver of the lab’s public profile. During the meeting, he didn’t hold back: The need to make safe AGI first was imperative, and it was clear now that OpenAI would fail to do this as a nonprofit, he told employees; he would instead pursue the same goal at Tesla, which had far higher chances of succeeding with the deep coffers of a well-resourced company.

一位实习生质疑马斯克的意图。这真的是最好的解决方案吗？马斯克真的用尽了所有替代方案吗？在特斯拉推进OpenAI的竞争对手似乎只会加剧营利性竞争，并可能危及通用人工智能（AGI）的安全发展。“这难道不是又回到了你之前说过不想做的事情吗？”这位实习生问道。

An intern questioned Musk’s intentions. Was this really the best solution? Had Musk really exhausted all alternatives? Advancing an OpenAI competitor at Tesla seemed like it would only serve to create for-profit race dynamics and could risk undermining safe AGI development. “Isn’t this going back to what you said you didn’t want to do?” the intern asked.

马斯克勃然大怒。“你真是个混蛋！我考虑了好久，什么办法都试过了。你简直无法想象我花了多少时间思考这个问题，”他说。“我真的很害怕这个问题。”

Musk blew up. “You’re a jackass! I’ve thought about this so much. I’ve tried everything. You can’t imagine how much time I’ve spent thinking about this,” he said. “I’m truly scared about this issue.”

后来，为了纪念这名实习生的英勇行为，人们给他颁发了一座“蠢驴”奖杯。

The intern was later commemorated for his heroism with a “jackass” trophy.

那年圣诞节的第二天，马斯克再次写信给奥特曼、布罗克曼和萨茨克弗：

The day after Christmas that year, Musk wrote again to Altman, Brockman, and Sutskever:

主题：我觉得我应该重申。

Subject line: I feel I should reiterate.

我估计，如果执行力和资源没有发生显著变化，OpenAI 与 DeepMind/Google 合并的可能性是 0%。而不是 1%。我希望情况并非如此。

My probability assessment of OpenAI being relevant to DeepMind/Google without a dramatic change in execution and resources is 0%. Not 1%. I wish it were otherwise.

即使筹集几亿美元也不够。这需要每年立即投入数十亿美元，否则就算了。

Even raising several hundred million won’t be enough. This needs billions per year immediately or forget it.

奥特曼需要尽快筹集资金。

Altman needed to fundraise, fast.

—

—

OpenAI 加大了宣传力度，专注于一些能够向普通观众展示其能力的演示项目。它特别关注一个项目：打造一个能够在复杂的战斗策略电子游戏Dota 2中击败世界顶级人类玩家的 AI 代理。OpenAI 已经创建了一个能够一对一击败顶级人类玩家的代理。现在，它将尝试组建一支由五名代理组成的团队，与世界顶级的五人团队对决。

OpenAI cranked up its publicity, focusing on demonstration projects that could highlight the lab’s capabilities to a lay audience. It leaned into one project in particular: an effort to build an AI agent that could beat the world’s best human players at the complex battle strategy video game Dota 2. OpenAI had already created an agent that could beat the best human player one on one. Now it would try to build a team of five agents to face off against the world’s best team of five human players.

不管有意无意，这都像是 DeepMind 的翻版。Dota 2曾举办过一场全球锦标赛，并进行现场直播，以清晰且充满戏剧性的输赢方式聚焦 OpenAI 的研究。DeepMind 当时已经开展了一个类似的项目，试图在战略游戏《星际争霸 II》中击败人类顶尖玩家，这可以在 OpenAI 的潜在投资者之间引发一种随意而又自然的比较。Dota 2项目也需要大量计算，这是测试和展示实验室长期扩展战略的好方法。领导Dota 2项目初始阶段的 Brockman扩大了团队并开始工作。

Consciously or not, it was a page out of DeepMind’s book. Dota 2 had a worldwide championship that would be live streamed and spotlight OpenAI’s research in clear and dramatic win-or-lose terms. DeepMind had moved on to a similar project attempting to beat top human players in the strategy game StarCraft II, which could create an arbitrary yet natural comparison among potential OpenAI investors. The Dota 2 project was also compute heavy, a good way to test out and showcase the lab’s long-term scaling strategy. Brockman, who led the initial phase of the Dota 2 project, expanded his team and got to work.

现在唯一缺少的就是一部纪录片。

Now all that was missing was a documentary.

这项任务落到了OpenAI机器人团队的一名成员身上。他购买了昂贵的摄像设备，开始在办公室里跟踪Dota团队。他自己编写了脚本，并将素材粗剪成一部长达三个小时的长篇故事。尽管他付出了巨大的努力，但OpenAI内部审阅了初稿的人一致认为，这部作品糟糕透顶。他们雇佣了专业人士，布罗克曼开始用自己的部分资金为他们提供资金。

That task fell to a member of OpenAI’s robotics team. He bought expensive camera equipment and began following the Dota team around in the office. He wrote his own script and rough cut the footage into a three-hour-long saga. For all his efforts, people at OpenAI who reviewed the draft agreed that it was terrible. Professionals were hired, and Brockman began bankrolling them in part with his own money.

与此同时，Altman 也在完善融资计划。在考虑了各种营利性结构后，他最终提出了一个不同寻常的方案，以平衡资金需求和对 OpenAI 使命的持续投入。虽然公益性公司本身就具备维持这种平衡的机制，但也附带了太多其他规则。Altman 决定创建一个有限合伙企业（LP），作为其作为……OpenAI 的盈利部门负责接收投资并将技术商业化。该部门将对投资者的回报设定上限，并由 OpenAI 的非营利组织管理。其优势在于，有限合伙人 (LP) 的运营协议可以根据创始人的意愿制定。OpenAI 可以明确规定使命优先于投资者。LP 还限制了股东的权力，使其无法获得多数控制权。

All the while, Altman fleshed out the plan for raising money. After considering a variety of for-profit structures, he landed on an unusual proposal to balance the need for capital with a continued commitment to OpenAI’s mission. While benefit corporations had a built-in mechanism for maintaining this balance, they also came with too many other rules. Instead, Altman would create a limited partnership, or LP, to act as a for-profit arm for receiving investment and commercializing OpenAI’s technologies. That arm would place a ceiling on investors’ returns and be governed by OpenAI’s nonprofit. The advantage was that the operating agreement for LPs could be written based on whatever the creator wanted. OpenAI could specify that the mission took precedence over investors. LPs also limited the power shareholders could exercise so they never gained majority control.

奥特曼向员工们谨慎地阐述了这项提议：OpenAI 最初承诺避免盈利动机，是为了防止实验室在其使命上妥协。但考虑到实验室的成功需要非营利组织无法筹集的资金，坚持原有的架构现在面临着更大的危及使命的风险。最终，尽管有些人不情愿，但大多数人都同意有限合伙制才是最佳的前进方向。

Altman framed the proposal to employees carefully: OpenAI’s initial commitment to avoid profit motives was made in the spirit of preventing the lab from compromising on its mission. But given that the lab’s success required capital the nonprofit couldn’t raise, clinging onto the original structure now held a greater risk of endangering the mission. In the end, most people agreed, though some reluctantly, that the LP was the best way forward.

2018年4月，OpenAI发布了一份章程，为过渡铺平道路。该文件没有公开透露任何即将发生的变化，但重申了实验室的宗旨，并采用了新的措辞：“OpenAI的使命是确保通用人工智能（AGI）……造福全人类。” 该文件补充说，要实现这一使命，OpenAI需要“处于人工智能能力的前沿”，并需要“大量资源”；这可能意味着出于“安全保障”的考虑，OpenAI将不得不放弃发布实验室研究成果的承诺。OpenAI还首次阐明了其对AGI的定义：“在最具经济价值的工作中超越人类的高度自主系统。”

In April 2018, OpenAI released a charter to pave the way for the transition. Without publicly revealing anything about the change to come, the document reiterated the lab’s purpose, now with new wording: “OpenAI’s mission is to ensure that artificial general intelligence (AGI)…benefits all of humanity.” Such a mission, the document added, would need OpenAI to be “on the cutting edge of AI capabilities” and require “substantial resources”; it could mean walking back the commitment to release the lab’s research due to “safety and security concerns.” For the first time, OpenAI also spelled out its AGI definition: “highly autonomous systems that outperform humans at most economically valuable work.”

那年夏天，Dota战队开始赢得业余比赛，并在科技媒体上大肆宣扬战绩（其中一条标题称赞道：“OpenAI的Dota 2 AI连续两次击败世界冠军电子竞技战队”），Altman在爱达荷州太阳谷举行的Allen & Company大会上偶遇了微软首席执行官萨蒂亚·纳德拉。这场被称为“亿万富翁夏令营”的年度盛会曾是许多重大企业交易的举办地。Altman也准备好了，开启属于自己的交易之旅。

That summer, as the Dota team began winning amateur matches and trumpeting its results across tech media (“OpenAI’s Dota 2 AI Steamrolls World Champion E-sports Team with Back-to-Back Victories,” lauded one headline), Altman bumped into Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella at the Allen & Company conference in Sun Valley, Idaho. The annual event, known as the “summer camp for billionaires,” had been the backdrop for many a major corporate deal. Altman was ready to strike his own.

他向纳德拉推荐了对 OpenAI 的投资，这足以激起这位首席执行官的兴趣。但纳德拉质疑，既然公司本身已经有长期的合作关系，是否应该投资外部机构？微软研究院的人工智能研究部门。回到微软后，他向高级顾问提出了这个问题。

He pitched Nadella on an OpenAI investment, enough to pique the chief executive’s interest. But Nadella questioned whether he should invest in an external organization when his company had its own long-standing AI research division within Microsoft Research. When he returned to Microsoft, he posed the question to his senior advisers.

““微软研究院和 OpenAI 都是在不断推进前沿技术的组织，”时任 Azure AI 首席技术官的黄学东说道。“为什么不同时投资两者呢？”

“Microsoft Research and OpenAI are both organizations pushing the frontier,” Xuedong Huang, then the chief technology officer of Azure AI, reasoned. Why not invest in both?

—

—

不到半年，OpenAI 和微软就开始认真商讨交易事宜。Altman 奠定了法律基础，迅速成立了有限合伙公司，并任命自己为首席执行官。在内部，该项目的代号为“俄勒冈之路”。为了防止交易被窥探，这家营利性实体还以“SummerSafe LP”的别名注册成立。这个名字来源于动画片《瑞克和莫蒂》中的一集，剧中主角——疯狂科学家瑞克和他的孙子莫蒂——抛下莫蒂的姐姐萨默，前往另一个宇宙，并指示他们的汽车“保护萨默的安全”。这辆汽车认真对待这个目标，采取了极端且有害的防御机制，包括谋杀、麻痹和折磨接近车辆的人。这暗示了人工智能的潜在风险。

Within half a year, OpenAI and Microsoft were discussing a deal in earnest. Altman laid the legal groundwork, hurrying along the creation of the limited partnership and appointing himself as its CEO. Internally, the project was code-named Oregon Trail. To keep the deal secret from prying eyes, the for-profit entity was also incorporated under the alias SummerSafe LP. The name was a reference to an episode of the cartoon show Rick and Morty where the titular characters, mad scientist Rick and his grandson Morty, leave behind Morty’s older sister Summer for another universe and instruct their car to “keep Summer safe.” The car takes the objective seriously, resorting to extreme and harmful mechanisms of defense, including murdering, paralyzing, and torturing people who approach the vehicle. It was a nod to the potential pitfalls of AI.

2019年初，微软高层领导开始来OpenAI办公室。首先是这家科技巨头的首席技术官凯文·斯科特（Kevin Scott），他一直关注OpenAI，并对这家初创公司情有独钟；然后是克雷格·蒙迪（Craig Mundie），他是纳德拉的高级顾问，曾在微软领导层任职二十多年，包括担任首席研究和战略官。比尔·盖茨也来到了OpenAI办公室，他一如既往地保持沉默，观看了一系列演示。大多数员工对微软的参与一无所知。奥特曼告诉负责这笔交易的小团队，要对可能的投资保密。

In early 2019, senior Microsoft leadership began coming through the OpenAI office. First came Kevin Scott, the tech giant’s excitable chief technology officer, who had followed OpenAI and grown particularly fond of the startup; then came Craig Mundie, a senior adviser to Nadella who had served on Microsoft leadership, including as its chief research and strategy officer, for over twenty years. Bill Gates also turned up, reserved and tight-lipped as usual, as he watched a series of demos. Most employees were left in the dark about Microsoft’s engagement. Altman told the small team working on the deal to keep knowledge of a possible investment limited.

大约在同一时期，Altman 在 YC 开始遇到麻烦。在担任该组织负责人五年后，人们对 Altman 的不满达到了极点，原因与 Loopt 出现的问题惊人地相似：他似乎将自己的项目和愿景置于组织的利益之上——有时甚至以牺牲组织利益为代价。他花了大量时间在 OpenAI 谈判上，而没有为 YC 提供建议。初创企业并没有起到什么作用。一些人认为，Altman 获得了巨大的个人利益，他用自己的私人基金 Hydrazine 投资 YC 公司，却只做了有限的工作，却获得了巨额回报。据《华盛顿邮报》报道，得知 Altman 缺席后，忧心忡忡的 Jessica Livingston 敦促 Altman 辞去 YC 主席一职。Altman 同意了。2019 年初，Paul Graham 从退休的英国飞往旧金山，最终敲定了这一决定。

Around the same time, Altman began to face trouble at YC. After five years as head of the organization, frustration with Altman had reached critical levels over an issue strikingly similar to one that had arisen at Loopt: his seeming prioritization of his own projects and aspirations over the organization’s—sometimes even at its expense. The amount of time he was spending on OpenAI negotiations and away from advising YC startups wasn’t helping. Some saw Altman as reaping significant personal benefit, gaining massive returns by investing in YC companies with his own personal fund Hydrazine, while doing limited work. Upon learning of his absenteeism, a concerned Jessica Livingston urged Altman to step down from the YC presidency, according to The Washington Post. Altman agreed. In early 2019, Paul Graham flew from the UK, where he had retired, to San Francisco to finalize the decision.

Altman 试图在公开场合淡化这一变化。2019 年 3 月 8 日，也就是他接待舒默参议员的当天，他在 YC 网站上发表了一篇博文，宣布他将从 YC 总裁转任董事长，以便为 OpenAI 腾出更多时间。几天后，也就是 3 月 11 日，Brockman 和 Sutskever 公开宣布成立 OpenAI LP，Altman 也透露了他担任首席执行官的职位。时机把握得非常巧妙。媒体广泛报道 Altman 的这一举动是他职业生涯中精心策划的一步，也是他担任 YC 董事长的新角色。只是，他实际上并没有这个头衔。据《华尔街日报》报道，他曾向 YC 的合伙人提出这个想法，但随后却在未经他们同意的情况下，将其公之于众，仿佛这已成定局。这篇博文后来被编辑，完全删除了对奥特曼的提及。

Altman tried to smooth over the change publicly. On March 8, 2019, the day he hosted Senator Schumer, he published a blog post on YC’s website announcing that he would transition from YC president to chairman to make more time for OpenAI. Days later, on March 11, Brockman and Sutskever publicly unveiled OpenAI LP, and Altman revealed his role as its chief executive. The timing was artful. The media widely reported Altman’s move as a well-choreographed step in his career and his new role as YC chairman. Except that he didn’t actually hold the title. He had proposed the idea to YC’s partnership but then publicized it as if it were a foregone conclusion, without their agreement, The Wall Street Journal reported. The blog post was later edited to remove mention of Altman completely.

在 OpenAI，奥特曼的新头衔只是正式确立了他自马斯克离职以来所扮演的角色。奥特曼接任后，许多员工都松了一口气。与马斯克的紧张和不可预测的情绪波动相比，他冷静沉着的举止令人欣慰。奥特曼还帮助缓解了人们对布罗克曼和萨茨克弗管理层日益增长的不满。他聘请了一位高管教练，并为管理人员提供培训。他安插了更多高级领导，包括聘请 YC 投资者布拉德·莱特卡普 (Brad Lightcap) 担任首席财务官；将曾在泰尔创立的 Palantir 领导工程和产品管理的鲍勃·麦格鲁 (Bob McGrew) 从机器人团队提拔为研究副总裁；并聘请曾在虚拟现实初创公司 Leap Motion 和特斯拉 Model X 领导产品和工程的米拉·穆拉蒂 (Mira Murati) 来监督硬件战略和核心研究路线。

At OpenAI, Altman’s new title merely formalized the role he had been playing since Musk’s departure. When Altman took the reins, many employees were relieved. His calm and collected demeanor was a welcome alternative to Musk’s intensity and unpredictable mood swings. Altman also helped alleviate mounting gripes with Brockman’s and Sutskever’s management. He brought in an executive coach and provided training to the managers. He installed more senior leaders, bringing in Brad Lightcap, an investor at YC, to be chief financial officer; promoting Bob McGrew, who had formerly led engineering and product management at the Thiel-founded Palantir, from the robotics team to a VP of research; and hiring Mira Murati, who had led product and engineering at the virtual reality startup Leap Motion and for Tesla’s Model X, to oversee hardware strategy and a core line of research.

随着 OpenAI LP 的成立，大多数员工从这家非营利组织辞职，并签署了新的合同，这些合同现在包含在营利性组织名下，并附带股权。（例外情况包括持有与……相关的签证的国际员工）非营利组织。薪酬结构不仅将薪酬与“工程专业知识”和“研究方向”挂钩，还与章程的一致性挂钩。三级员工需要“理解并内化OpenAI章程”。五级员工需要“确保你和你的团队成员参与的所有项目都符合章程”。七级员工“负责维护和改进章程，并督促组织内其他人也这样做”。高管们还撰写了一份常见问题解答文档，以应对大家的担忧。其中一个问题是：“我能信任 OpenAI 吗？”答案是“可以”。

With the formation of OpenAI LP, most employees resigned from the nonprofit and signed new contracts, now with equity, under the for-profit. (The exceptions included international employees on visas tied to the nonprofit.) A payband structure tied compensation not just to “engineering expertise” and “research direction,” but also to charter alignment. Level three employees needed to “understand and internalize the OpenAI charter.” Level fives needed to “ensure all projects you and your team-mates work on are consistent with the charter.” Level sevens were “responsible for upholding and improving the charter, and holding others in the organization accountable for doing the same.” Executives also wrote up an FAQ doc to manage residual nerves. “Can I trust OpenAI?” one question asked. The answer began with “Yes.”

在更广泛的科技界，OpenAI 的转型引发了一波指责，称该实验室违背了最初的承诺。有限合伙制的初始条款规定，首轮投资者的回报上限为其投入的 100 倍。OpenAI 将这种新结构称为“利润上限”公司。在 YC 运营的热门新闻聚合网站 Hacker News 上，一位用户在帖子中质问，这个上限究竟有何意义。所以，投资 1000 万美元的人，他们的投资额度就被“限制”在 10 亿美元。哈哈。除非公司市值达到 FAANG 那样的规模，否则基本上是无限的，”他们写道。FAANG 指的是 Facebook、Apple、Amazon、Netflix 和 Google 的首字母缩写。

In the broader tech world, OpenAI’s transition set off a wave of accusations that the lab was walking back its original promise. The initial terms of the limited partnership stated that the first round of investors would have their returns capped at 100x of what they put in. OpenAI termed the invented structure a “capped-profit” company. In a post on Hacker News, a popular news aggregation website run by YC, a user asked how this cap was at all meaningful. “So someone who invests $10 million has their investment ‘capped’ at $1 billion. Lol. Basically unlimited unless the company grew to a FAANG-scale market value,” they wrote, using the acronym for Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix, and Google.

布罗克曼以他的用户名 gdb 回复道：“我们相信，如果我们真的创造了 AGI，我们将创造比任何现有公司都要大几个数量级的价值。”

Brockman responded under his username, gdb: “We believe that if we do create AGI, we’ll create orders of magnitude more value than any existing company.”

另一位用户接着写道：“谷歌的早期投资者获得了大约20倍的资本回报。谷歌目前的估值为7500亿美元。你的赌注是，你将拥有一个比谷歌回报率高出几个数量级的公司结构……但你不想‘过度集中权力’？”他引用了章程中的一段话。“如果不是资源的集中，权力究竟是什么？”

Another user followed up. “Early investors in Google have received a roughly 20x return on their capital. Google is currently valued at $750 billion. Your bet is that you’ll have a corporate structure which returns orders of magnitude more than Google…but you don’t want to ‘unduly concentrate power’?” they wrote, quoting from the charter. “What exactly is power, if not the concentration of resources?”

—

—

初始投资涌入该 LP，其中包括来自 OpenAI 非营利组织的 6000 多万美元、来自 YC 的 1000 万美元以及来自 Khosla Ventures 和霍夫曼慈善基金会各 5000 万美元。霍夫曼后来回忆说，当 OpenAI 没有产品或市场计划时，他最初不愿意加大投资。但他最终同意在奥特曼告诉他这将有助于证明 OpenAI 发展盈利业务的认真态度后，他共同领导了这轮融资。

Initial investments poured in to the LP, including more than $60 million rolled over from OpenAI’s nonprofit, $10 million from YC, and $50 million each from Khosla Ventures and Hoffman’s charitable foundation. Hoffman was initially reluctant to invest more in OpenAI when it had no product or market plan, he later recounted. But he ultimately agreed to colead the round after Altman told him it would help legitimize the seriousness of OpenAI’s intention to develop a profitable business.

与此同时，微软仍在深思熟虑。纳德拉、斯科特和其他微软高管已经同意了初步投资。唯一的例外是比尔·盖茨。

Microsoft, meanwhile, continued to deliberate. Nadella, Scott, and other Microsoft executives were already on board with an initial investment. The one holdout was Bill Gates.

对盖茨来说，Dota 2并没有那么令人兴奋。机器人技术也让他很不感兴趣。机器人团队制作了一个机器手的演示，它通过自己的反复试验学会了如何解开魔方，并获得了普遍的好评。但盖茨觉得它没什么用。他想要一个能够消化书籍、掌握科学概念并根据材料回答问题的人工智能模型——作为开展研究的助手。

For Gates, Dota 2 wasn’t all that exciting. Nor was he moved by robotics. The robotics team had created a demo of a robotic hand that had learned to solve a Rubik’s Cube through its own trial and error, which had received universally favorable coverage. Gates didn’t find it useful. He wanted an AI model that could digest books, grasp scientific concepts, and answer questions based on the material—to be an assistant for conducting research.

OpenAI 只有一个项目接近符合要求：一个名为 GPT-2 的大型语言模型，它能够生成与人类书写极其相似的文本段落。同年 2 月，OpenAI 采取了不同寻常的举措，向媒体宣称，该模型一旦进一步发展，就可能成为一项极其危险的技术。专制政府或恐怖组织可能会利用该模型武器化，大规模制造虚假信息。用户可能会用大量垃圾内容淹没互联网，以至于难以找到高质量的信息。OpenAI 表示，将采取道德立场，不提供该模型的完整版本。该模型包含 15 亿个参数（或称变量），这大致反映了模型的大小和复杂性。相反，为了让公众体验到社会需要做好准备的能力，OpenAI 只会发布一个精简版本，其大小不到原模型的十分之一，该版本只能有限地生成几个句子，但容易出现不连贯和重复的情况。

OpenAI had only one project that approached fitting the bill: a large language model called GPT-2 that was capable of generating passages of text that closely resembled human writing. In February that year, OpenAI had taken the unusual step of proclaiming to the press that this model, once advanced a little further, could become an exceedingly dangerous technology. Authoritarian governments or terrorist organizations could weaponize the model to mass-produce disinformation. Users could overwhelm the internet with so much trash content that it would be difficult to find high-quality information. OpenAI would take the ethical high road, it said, and withhold the full version of the model, which had 1.5 billion parameters, or variables, an approximate measure of a model’s size and complexity. Instead, to give the public just a taste of the kind of capabilities that society needed to prepare for, it would publish only a diminished version, less than one-tenth of the size, that had a limited ability to generate a few sentences at a time but was prone to non sequiturs and repetition.

GPT-2 甚至还无法掌握科学概念，但该模型可以对文档进行一些基本的总结，并回答一些问题。OpenAI 的一些研究人员或许在思考，如果他们用更多数据训练一个更大的模型，并让它执行至少看起来更符合盖茨意图的任务，或许就能让他从批评者转变为至少保持中立。2019 年 4 月，一小群这些研究人员飞往西雅图，进行了所谓的“盖茨演示”，演示了增强版 GPT-2。到最后，盖茨确实被说服了，这笔交易得以通过。

GPT-2 wasn’t even close to grasping scientific concepts, but the model could do some basic summarization of documents and sort of answer questions. Perhaps, some of OpenAI’s researchers wondered, if they trained a larger model on more data and to perform tasks that at least looked more like what Gates wanted, they could sway him from being a detractor to being, at minimum, neutral. In April 2019, a small group of those researchers flew to Seattle to give what they called the Gates Demo of a souped-up GPT-2. By the end of it, Gates was indeed swayed just enough for the deal to go through.

在随后的全体会议上，Altman 宣布了这一消息，并称赞微软是合适的投资者和合作伙伴。这家科技巨头拥有 OpenAI 所需的资金和计算能力，其领导层的价值理念与确保通用人工智能 (AGI) 效益的使命高度契合。OpenAI 对于向微软交付哪些商业化成果做出了非常宽松的承诺。Altman 表示，实验室几乎不需要在任何事情上做出妥协。这是一笔非常划算的交易。

In a subsequent all-hands, Altman delivered the news, championing Microsoft as the right investor and partner. The tech giant had the money and the compute that OpenAI needed, and its leadership was deeply value aligned with the mission to ensure beneficial AGI. OpenAI had also made very loose commitments around what to deliver to Microsoft for commercialization. The lab hadn’t needed to compromise on much of anything, Altman said. It was a very good deal.

在微软内部，这项投资是经过深思熟虑的。OpenAI 是否能达到 AGI 水平并非他们真正关心的问题。但 OpenAI 显然处于领先地位，早期投资最终可能使微软成为 AI 领域的领导者——无论是在软件还是硬件领域——与谷歌比肩。斯科特在六月中旬写给纳德拉和盖茨的信中提到谷歌的人工智能研究部门时表示：“Open AI、Deep Mind 和 Google Brain 所做的事情最有趣之处在于他们的雄心壮志，以及这种雄心如何推动着从数据中心设计到计算芯片、从网络和分布式系统架构、到数值优化器、编译器、编程框架以及模型开发人员可以使用的高级抽象等各个方面。” 他表示，微软在多个方面都远远落后：它一直在努力复制谷歌最好的语言模型，其 Azure 云计算平台与谷歌的同等基础设施相比存在巨大差距。微软可能需要数年时间才能独自迎头赶上。他“非常非常担心”。

Within Microsoft, the investment was framed practically. Whether OpenAI did or didn’t reach AGI wasn’t really their concern. But OpenAI was clearly on the cutting edge, and investing early could finally turn Microsoft into an AI leader—both in software and in hardware—on par with Google. “The thing that’s interesting about what Open AI and Deep Mind and Google Brain are doing is the scale of their ambition,” wrote Scott to Nadella and Gates in mid-June, referring to Google’s AI research division, “and how that ambition is driving everything from datacenter design to compute silicon to networks and distributed systems architectures to numerical optimizers, compiler, programming frameworks, and the high level abstractions that model developers have at their disposal.” Microsoft was desperately behind on multiple fronts, he said: It had struggled to replicate Google’s best language models, and its Azure cloud-computing platform had large gaps compared with Google’s equivalent infrastructure. It could take years for Microsoft to catch up by itself. He was “very, very worried.”

纳德拉当天就做出了回应，撤掉了盖茨的职位，并任命了微软首席财务官艾米·胡德。“这封邮件非常好，解释了我为什么要这么做……以及为什么我们会确保我们的基础设施部门人员能够执行，”他说道，胡德用的是“基础设施”的缩写。

Nadella responded the same day, removing Gates and adding Microsoft’s CFO Amy Hood. “Very good email that explains, why I want us to do this…and also why we will then ensure our infra folks execute,” he said, using the abbreviation for infrastructure.

一个月后，即2019年7月22日，微软宣布投资10亿美元。根据交易条款，其回报率上限为20倍。

A month later, on July 22, 2019, Microsoft announced its $1 billion investment. Under the terms of the deal, its returns would be capped at 20x.

第三章

Chapter 3

神经中枢

Nerve Center

我两周后，即 2019 年 8 月 7 日，他们抵达了 OpenAI 的办公室。那时，实验室已经搬到了旧金山第十八街和福尔瑟姆街交汇处一栋独立的建筑里，离巧克力工厂不远。建筑灰色的外墙在其拐角处涂上字母，标志着这里是一座历史地标：先锋大楼，曾经是先锋皮箱工厂的所在地。三年前，马斯克通过他的一家公司租用了这栋建筑，从 Stripe 以前的主要办公空间继承了翻新的内部空间。OpenAI 搬进了马斯克的另一家创业公司——脑机接口公司 Neuralink。

Iarrived at OpenAI’s offices two weeks later, on August 7, 2019. By then the lab had moved to a stand-alone building, not far from the chocolate factory, at Eighteenth and Folsom Streets in San Francisco. Its gray exterior was marked by the lettering painted around its corner to announce the presence of a historic landmark: the pioneer building, once home to the Pioneer Trunk Factory. Three years earlier, Musk had leased the building through one of his companies, inheriting the refurbished interior from a shared office space primarily occupied by Stripe. OpenAI moved in with another one of Musk’s ventures, Neuralink, the brain-machine interface company.

我一路蜿蜒穿过教会区，一路上汗流浃背，路过那些正被新潮咖啡馆慢慢取代的招牌墨西哥卷饼店，穿梭于日益扩张的无家可归人群之中。走进门，一股凉风迎面扑来。穿过保安柜台，门厅展现出一片开放式休息区。阳光透过窗户倾泻而入，洒满裸露的木梁天花板和舒适的沙发。右边是一家自助餐厅，为员工提供餐食；棋盘游戏和书籍摇摇晃晃地摆放在墙边的书架上。

I had worked up a sheen of sweat as I’d wound my way through the Mission District, passing beloved taquerias slowly being uprooted by trendy new cafés and navigating around the growing sprawl of the unhoused population. A burst of cool air greeted me as I walked through the door. Past the security desk, the foyer unfurled into an open lounge area. Sunlight streamed in through the windows, bathing exposed wood beam ceilings and inviting couches. To the right, a cafeteria catered meals for employees; board games and books teetered on shelves along the walls.

在硅谷，办公室设计是一种货币，是对公司财务未来信心的象征，也是在争夺顶级人才的竞争中获得微弱优势的一种方式。2021年，OpenAI 将接管几个街区外的另一栋连体建筑，并在两年内斥资1000万美元翻新超过三万平方英尺（约合3000平方米）的办公空间。员工们将第一栋办公室称为“先锋大厦”（Pioneer Building），而第二栋办公室（前身是一家蛋黄酱工厂）则被昵称为“梅奥”（Mayo）。奥特曼将负责监督梅奥诊所的办公室设计，将先锋大厦的工业金属框架楼梯升级为波浪形的木材和石材中心装饰；将网上售价约 2,000 美元的皮革扶手椅升级为售价超过 10,000 美元的巴西设计师休闲椅。他将在梅奥诊所增建一座图书馆，馆内设有木质书架和波斯地毯，其设计灵感来源于他最喜欢的巴黎书店和他母校斯坦福大学最大的图书馆的学习空间的结合。他告诉公司设计师，他想要“一个水景”。设计师提议在办公室中央建造一个气势恢宏的漂浮瀑布，一个支撑自然的人工结构，象征着人与机器的共生。最终，Altman 选择了不同的方向。他安装了汩汩作响的石头喷泉，周围环绕着茂密的植物，喷泉环绕着沙发，悬挂在天花板上，沿着墙壁倾泻而下。

In Silicon Valley, office design is a kind of currency, a symbol of confidence in the company’s financial future and a way to gain a slim advantage in the competition for top-tier talent. In 2021, OpenAI would take over another pair of conjoined buildings a few blocks away, spending $10 million over two years to renovate more than thirty thousand square feet. Where employees called the first office the Pioneer Building, the second, a former mayonnaise factory, would be nicknamed Mayo. Altman would oversee Mayo’s office design, upgrading from the industrial metal frame staircase of the Pioneer Building to an undulating wood and stone centerpiece; from leather armchairs that can go for around $2,000 online to Brazilian designer lounge chairs that can go for more than $10,000. He would add a library to Mayo with wooden shelves and a Persian carpet, modeled after a cross between his favorite Parisian bookstore and a study space in the largest library of his alma mater, Stanford University. He wanted “a water feature,” he would tell his company’s designer, who proposed a magnificent floating waterfall in the middle of the office, an artificial structure supporting nature to represent a symbiosis between human and machine. In the end, Altman would go a different direction. He installed bubbling stone fountains surrounded by a profusion of plants, nestled around the couches, hanging from the ceiling, cascading down the walls.

在这两家办公室之外，同样的两年时间里，疫情将进一步摧毁这片早已成为科技行业绅士化中心的区域。历史悠久的拉丁裔企业将倒闭。暴力犯罪将激增。随着无家可归者人数达到危机水平，先锋大厦附近将出现一排帐篷和丢弃的垃圾。

Outside both offices, the same two-year period would see the pandemic further ravage what had already become the epicenter of the tech industry’s gentrification. Long-standing Latino businesses would shutter. Violent crime would jump. A line of tents and discarded trash would spring up steps away from the Pioneer Building as homelessness reached crisis levels.

但在这里，沐浴在欢快的灯光下，杂志散落在桌子上，很容易让人感受到一种更温和的现实。一位员工后来告诉我，这正是她在这家公司工作的那段时光的象征。加入这家公司就像踏入了另一个宇宙。直到离开后，她才重新回归现实。

But here, ensconced in the cheery glow, magazines strewn across the tables, it was easy to live in a gentler reality. An employee would later tell me that this was emblematic of her time at the company. Joining it was like stepping into an alternate universe. Only after she left did she snap back down to the earth.

当时 31 岁的布罗克曼是 OpenAI 的首席技术官，即将成为公司总裁。他走下楼梯来迎接我。他他试探性地笑了笑，和我握手。“我们以前从未给予过任何人如此多的访问权限，”他说。

Brockman, then thirty-one, OpenAI’s chief technology officer and soon-to-be company president, came down the staircase to greet me. He shook my hand with a tentative smile. “We’ve never given someone so much access before,” he said.

—

—

当时，在封闭的人工智能研究领域之外，很少有人知道OpenAI。但作为《麻省理工科技评论》的记者，我一直密切关注着人工智能领域不断拓展的领域，关注着它的动态。

At the time, few people beyond the insular world of AI research knew about OpenAI. But as a reporter at MIT Technology Review covering the ever-expanding boundaries of artificial intelligence, I had been following its movements closely.

在那一年之前，OpenAI 在人工智能研究领域一直处于劣势。它有一个荒诞的前提，认为通用人工智能 (AGI) 可以在十年内实现，而大多数非 OpenAI 专家却对此表示怀疑。对许多业内人士来说，OpenAI 虽然缺乏方向，却拥有巨额资金，并将过多的资金投入到营销那些经常被其他研究人员视为非原创研究的成果上。对某些人来说，OpenAI 也成了羡慕的对象。作为一家非营利组织，OpenAI 曾表示无意追求商业化。它是一个难得的、没有附加条件的智力游乐场，一个边缘思想的避风港。

Until that year, OpenAI had been something of a stepchild in AI research. It had an outlandish premise that AGI could be attained within a decade, when most non-OpenAI experts doubted it could be attained at all. To much of the field, it had an obscene amount of funding despite little direction and spent too much of the money on marketing what other researchers frequently snubbed as unoriginal research. It was, for some, also an object of envy. As a nonprofit, it had said that it had no intention to chase commercialization. It was a rare intellectual playground without strings attached, a haven for fringe ideas.

但在我访问OpenAI之前的六个月里，OpenAI的一系列快速变化预示着其发展轨迹的重大转变。首先是它令人困惑的决定，即暂停GPT-2并大肆吹嘘。然后，它宣布神秘地离开YC影响力巨大的职位的Altman将接任OpenAI的首席执行官，并创建了新的“利润上限”架构。我已经安排好了参观办公室的时间，OpenAI随后公布了与微软的交易，该交易赋予这家科技巨头优先商业化OpenAI技术的权利，并锁定了其独家使用微软云计算平台Azure的权利。

But in the six months leading up to my visit, the rapid slew of changes at OpenAI signaled a major shift in its trajectory. First was its confusing decision to withhold GPT-2 and brag about it. Then its announcement that Altman, who had mysteriously departed his influential perch at YC, would step in as OpenAI’s CEO with the creation of its new “capped-profit” structure. I had already made my arrangements to visit the office when it subsequently revealed its deal with Microsoft, which gave the tech giant priority for commercializing OpenAI’s technologies and locked it into exclusively using Azure, Microsoft’s cloud-computing platform.

每一次新的声明都引发新的争议、激烈的猜测和日益增长的关注，并开始超越科技行业的界限。当我和同事们报道这家公司的发展时，很难完全理解正在发生的事情。显而易见的是，OpenAI 开始对人工智能研究以及政策制定者理解这项技术的方式产生有意义的影响。该实验室决定转型为一家部分营利性企业，这将对其在工业界和政府领域的影响力产生连锁反应。

Each new announcement garnered fresh controversy, intense speculation, and growing attention, beginning to reach beyond the confines of the tech industry. As my colleagues and I covered the company’s progression, it was hard to grasp the full weight of what was happening. What was clear was that OpenAI was beginning to exert meaningful sway over AI research and the way policymakers were learning to understand the technology. The lab’s decision to revamp itself into a partially for-profit business would have ripple effects across its spheres of influence in industry and government.

于是，一天深夜，在编辑的催促下，我匆匆给 OpenAI 的政策总监杰克·克拉克（Jack Clark）写了一封电子邮件，我之前和他聊过：我会在城里待两周，感觉这是 OpenAI 历史上最合适的时机。我能不能让他们对我的简介感兴趣？克拉克把我介绍给了公关主管，后者回复了我。OpenAI 确实准备好重新向公众介绍自己了。我将有三天时间采访领导层并深入公司内部。

So late one night, with the urging of my editor, I dashed off an email to Jack Clark, OpenAI’s policy director, whom I had spoken with before: I would be in town for two weeks, and it felt like the right moment in OpenAI’s history. Could I interest them in a profile? Clark passed me onto the communications head, who came back with an answer. OpenAI was indeed ready to reintroduce itself to the public. I would have three days to interview leadership and embed inside the company.

—

—

我和布罗克曼与萨茨克弗一起在一间玻璃会议室里坐下。他们并肩坐在一张长长的会议桌旁，各司其职。身为程序员兼实干家的布罗克曼身子前倾，略显紧张，准备给人留下好印象；而身为研究员兼哲学家的萨茨克弗则靠在椅子上，显得轻松而冷漠。

Brockman and I settled into a glass meeting room with Sutskever. Sitting side by side at a long conference table, they each played their part. Brockman, the coder and doer, leaned forward, a little on edge, ready to make a good impression; Sutskever, the researcher and philosopher, settled back into his chair, relaxed and aloof.

我打开笔记本电脑，浏览着我的问题。OpenAI 的使命是确保通用人工智能 (AGI) 的效益，我开口问道。为什么要在这个问题上投入数十亿美元，而不是其他问题呢？

I opened my laptop and scrolled through my questions. OpenAI’s mission is to ensure beneficial AGI, I began. Why spend billions of dollars on this problem and not something else?

布罗克曼用力地点了点头。他习惯于捍卫OpenAI的立场。“我们之所以如此关注AGI，并认为构建它很重要，是因为我们认为它能够帮助解决人类无法触及的复杂问题，”他说。

Brockman nodded vigorously. He was used to defending OpenAI’s position. “The reason that we care so much about AGI and that we think it’s important to build is because we think it can help solve complex problems that are just out of reach of humans,” he said.

他举了两个在通用人工智能信徒中已成为信条的例子。气候变化。“这是一个超级复杂的问题。你到底该如何解决它？”还有医学。“看看如今医疗保健在美国作为一个政治议题的重要性。我们如何才能以更低的成本为人们提供更好的治疗？”

He offered two examples that had become dogma among AGI believers. Climate change. “It’s a super-complex problem. How are you even supposed to solve it?” And medicine. “Look at how important health care is in the US as a political issue these days. How do we actually get better treatment for people at lower cost?”

关于后者，他开始讲述一位朋友的故事。这位朋友患有一种罕见疾病，最近为了找到问题所在，辗转于不同的专家之间，经历了令人精疲力竭的繁琐程序。AGI 将整合所有这些专业。像他朋友这样的人将不再需要花费那么多精力和精力去寻找答案。

On the latter, he began to recount the story of a friend who had a rare disorder and had recently gone through the exhausting rigmarole of bouncing between different specialists to figure out his problem. AGI would bring together all of these specialties. People like his friend would no longer spend so much energy and frustration on getting an answer.

我问道：“为什么我们需要通用人工智能（AGI）而不是人工智能（AI）来做这件事？”

Why did we need AGI to do that instead of AI? I asked.

这是一个重要的区别。“AGI”这个术语曾经在科技词典中被归类为不受欢迎的类别，直到最近才开始获得更多主流使用——这很大程度上要归功于OpenAI。OpenAI 将其定义为人工智能研究的理论巅峰：一种软件，其复杂程度、敏捷性和创造力与人类思维不相上下，能够在大多数（具有经济价值的）任务上匹敌甚至超越人类思维。关键词是“理论”。自几十年前开始认真研究人工智能以来，人们一直在激烈争论：用二进制 1 和 0 编码的硅芯片能否模拟大脑和其他生物过程，从而产生我们所说的智能。目前还没有确凿的证据表明这是可能的，甚至还没有触及关于人们是否应该发展智能的规范性讨论。

This was an important distinction. The term AGI, once relegated to an unpopular section of the technology dictionary, had only recently begun to gain more mainstream usage—in large part because of OpenAI. And as OpenAI defined it, AGI referred to a theoretical pinnacle of AI research: a piece of software that had just as much sophistication, agility, and creativity as the human mind to match or exceed its performance on most (economically valuable) tasks. The operative word was theoretical. Since the beginning of earnest research into AI several decades earlier, debates had raged about whether silicon chips encoding everything in their binary ones and zeros could ever simulate brains and the other biological processes that give rise to what we consider intelligence. There had yet to be definitive evidence that this was possible, which didn’t even touch on the normative discussion of whether people should develop it.

另一方面，“人工智能”一词既指当前可用的技术版本，也指研究人员通过改进现有能力在不久的将来能够合理实现的技术版本。这些能力——植根于强大的模式匹配，即机器学习——已经在缓解气候变化和医疗保健领域展现出激动人心的应用。

AI, on the other hand, was the term du jour for both the version of the technology currently available and the version that researchers could reasonably attain in the near future through refining existing capabilities. Those capabilities—rooted in powerful pattern matching known as machine learning—had already demonstrated exciting applications in climate change mitigation and health care.

就在那个夏天，一群由该领域一些最杰出科学家支持的研究人员成立了一个名为“气候变化人工智能”的新组织，旨在推动能够有效应对气候相关挑战的人工智能技术和模型的应用。该组织在一份白皮书中详细列出了十类特别适合现有机器学习能力的挑战，包括提高建筑能效、优化电网负荷分配以整合更多可再生能源，以及发现用于能源生产和储存的新材料或更碳高效的水泥和钢铁。

Just that summer, a group of researchers backed by some of the field’s most prominent scientists had formed a new organization called Climate Change AI, to spur the application of AI techniques and models that could meaningfully make a difference to climate-related challenges. In a white paper, the organization detailed ten categories of those challenges particularly well suited to existing machine learning capabilities, including making buildings more efficient, optimizing the load distribution of power grids to integrate more renewable energy, and discovering new materials for energy generation and storage or more carbon-efficient cement and steel.

12月，气候变化人工智能 (Climate Change AI) 在年度人工智能研究大会 NeurIPS 上举办了一场座无虚席的聚会。而就在前一天，另一个小组在大厅另一头一个足球场大小的房间里举办了一场人头攒动的研讨会，主题是机器学习在医疗保健研究中的应用。研讨会上的演讲和墙上的海报展示了大量的应用，包括利用计算机视觉在医学图像扫描中检测阿尔茨海默病等疾病的早期、几乎难以察觉的阶段，以及如何利用语音识别帮助有声音障碍的患者更轻松地沟通。这个定期举办的研讨会强调与健康专家和临床医生的合作，两年后，该研讨会发展成为一个独立的组织，名为“健康机器学习”。

In December, Climate Change AI would host a packed gathering at NeurIPS, the yearly AI research conference, a day after another group held a different well-attended workshop down the hall in a room the size of a football field about machine learning for health care research. The talks and the posters lining the walls showcased a plethora of applications, including the use of computer vision to detect the early, near-imperceptible stages of diseases like Alzheimer’s in medical image scans, and the use of speech recognition to help patients with vocal impediments to communicate more easily. The recurring workshop, which emphasized collaboration with health experts and clinicians, would evolve into its own organization, Machine Learning for Health, two years later.

这两个机构的研究人员告诉我，在这些领域工作的主要挑战并非技术限制，而是恰恰相反：说服才华横溢的科学家专注于那些需要相当简单的机器学习解决方案的问题，而不是那些满足他们雄心壮志、在研究履历上更上一层楼的最新尖端技术。此外，还在于找到在全球范围内部署这些解决方案的政治意愿。“应对气候变化的技术已经问世多年，但在很大程度上尚未被社会大规模采用，”气候变化人工智能研究人员在白皮书中写道。虽然他们希望人工智能“能够有助于降低气候行动的相关成本，但人类也必须决定采取行动。”

Researchers from both organizations would tell me that the main challenge of working in these areas was not technical limitations. It was quite the opposite: persuading talented scientists to focus on problems that necessitated rather simple machine learning solutions, instead of the latest cutting-edge techniques that satisfied their ambitions and looked better on a research résumé. It was also finding the political will to deploy those solutions globally. “Technologies that would address climate change have been available for years, but have largely not been adopted at scale by society,” wrote the Climate Change AI researchers in their white paper. While they hoped that AI would “be useful in reducing the costs associated with climate action, humanity also must decide to act.”

回到会议室，萨茨克弗插嘴道。在解决复杂的全球挑战方面，“根本的瓶颈在于你拥有大量的人类，他们沟通不够快，工作不够快，而且有很多激励问题。” 他说，通用人工智能会有所不同。“想象一下，这是一个由智能计算机组成的大型计算机网络——它们都在进行医学诊断；它们之间都能以极快的速度传递结果。”

Back in the conference room, Sutskever chimed in. When it comes to solving complex global challenges, “fundamentally the bottleneck is that you have a large number of humans and they don’t communicate as fast, they don’t work as fast, they have a lot of incentive problems.” AGI would be different, he said. “Imagine it’s a large computer network of intelligent computers—they’re all doing their medical diagnostics; they all communicate results between them extremely fast.”

在我看来，这似乎是在用另一种方式说AGI的目标是取代人类。Sutskever 是这个意思吗？几个小时后，当只剩下我们两个人时，我问了 Brockman。

This seemed to me like another way of saying that the goal of AGI was to replace humans. Is that what Sutskever meant? I asked Brockman a few hours later, once it was just the two of us.

“不，”布罗克曼迅速回答。“这是一件非常重要的事情。技术的目的是什么？它为什么存在？我们为什么要创造它？我们已经开发技术几千年了，对吧？我们这样做是因为它们服务于人类。AGI 不会有什么不同——不会像我们设想的那样，不会像我们想要的那样，不会像我们想象的那样，不会像我们认为它应该发挥的那样。”

“No,” Brockman replied quickly. “This is one thing that’s really important. What is the purpose of technology? Why is it here? Why do we build it? We’ve been building technologies for thousands of years now, right? We do it because they serve people. AGI is not going to be different—not the way that we envision it, not the way we want to build it, not the way we think it should play out.”

尽管如此，几分钟后他承认，技术总是会摧毁一些工作，也会创造其他工作。OpenAI 的挑战将打造通用人工智能，赋予每个人“经济自由”，同时让他们能够在新的现实中继续“过上有意义的生活”。如果成功，它将使工作需求与生存需求脱钩。

That said, he acknowledged a few minutes later, technology had always destroyed some jobs and created others. OpenAI’s challenge would be to build AGI that gave everyone “economic freedom” while allowing them to continue to “live meaningful lives” in that new reality. If it succeeded, it would decouple the need to work from survival.

“我真的认为这是一件非常美好的事情，”他说。

“I actually think that’s a very beautiful thing,” he said.

在与萨茨克弗的会面中，布罗克曼提醒我要看清全局。“我们认为自己的角色实际上并非决定通用人工智能能否实现，”他说。这在硅谷是一个热门话题——必然性牌。如果我们不做，别人也会做。 “轨迹已经存在，”他强调，“但我们能影响的是它诞生的初始条件。”

In our meeting with Sutskever, Brockman reminded me of the bigger picture. “What we view our role as is not actually being a determiner of whether AGI gets built,” he said. This was a favorite argument in Silicon Valley—the inevitability card. If we don’t do it, somebody else will. “The trajectory is already there,” he emphasized, “but the thing we can influence is the initial conditions under which it’s born.

“OpenAI 是什么？”他继续说道。“我们的目标是什么？我们真正想做什么？我们的使命是确保 AGI 造福全人类。而我们想要实现这一目标的方式是：构建 AGI 并分配其经济效益。”

“What is OpenAI?” he continued. “What is our purpose? What are we really trying to do? Our mission is to ensure that AGI benefits all of humanity. And the way we want to do that is: Build AGI and distribute its economic benefits.”

他的语气平静而决绝，仿佛已经解答了我的疑问。然而，不知何故，我们又回到了原点。

His tone was matter-of-fact and final, as if he’d put my questions to rest. And yet we had somehow just arrived back to exactly where we’d started.

—

—

我和布罗克曼、萨茨克弗的对话一直兜圈子，直到四十五分钟后时间耗尽。我试图了解他们究竟想做什么——他们解释说，他们不可能知道——以及为什么，如果他们不知道，却如此确信这会有益——但收效甚微。

My conversation with Brockman and Sutskever continued on in circles until we ran out the clock after forty-five minutes. I tried with little success to get more concrete details on what exactly they were trying to build—which by nature, they explained, they couldn’t know—and why then, if they couldn’t know, they were so confident it would be beneficial.

有一次，我尝试了另一种方法，让他们举例说明这项技术的缺点。这正是 OpenAI 创始理念的支柱之一：实验室必须先开发出优秀的通用人工智能 (AGI)，才能防止别人开发出糟糕的通用人工智能。

At one point, I tried a different approach, asking them instead to give examples of the downsides of the technology. This was a pillar of OpenAI’s founding mythology: The lab had to build good AGI before someone else built a bad one.

布罗克曼尝试给出答案：深度伪造。“目前还不清楚它的应用是否能让世界变得更好，”他说。

Brockman attempted an answer: deepfakes. “It’s not clear the world is better through its applications,” he said.

我举了自己的例子：说到气候变化，那么人工智能本身对环境的影响又如何呢？马萨诸塞大学阿默斯特分校最近的一项研究表明，训练越来越大的人工智能模型会产生巨大且不断增长的碳排放量，这令人担忧。

I offered my own example: Speaking of climate change, what about the environmental impact of AI itself? A recent study from the University of Massachusetts Amherst had placed alarming numbers on the huge and growing carbon emissions of training larger and larger AI models.

萨茨克维尔表示，这一点“无可否认”，但其回报是值得的，因为AGI“除其他外，还能具体抵消环境成本”。但他没有举例说明。

That was “undeniable,” Sutskever said, but the payoff was worth it because AGI would, “among other things, counteract the environmental cost specifically.” He stopped short of offering examples.

他补充道：“毫无疑问，数据中心尽可能的环保是人们非常希望看到的。”

“It is unquestioningly very highly desirable that data centers be as green as possible,” he added.

“毫无疑问，”布罗克曼打趣道。

“No question,” Brockman quipped.

“数据中心是最大的能源和电力消耗者，”苏茨克弗继续说道，他似乎有意证明自己意识到并关心这个问题。

“Data centers are the biggest consumer of energy, of electricity,” Sutskever continued, seeming intent now on proving that he was aware of and cared about this issue.

“全球是 2%”，我说道。

“It’s 2 percent globally,” I offered.

“比特币不是只有 1% 吗？”布罗克曼说。

“Isn’t Bitcoin like 1 percent?” Brockman said.

“哇！ ”萨茨克维尔突然激动地说道，此时距离谈话已经过去了四十分钟，他感觉自己的情绪有些夸张了。

“Wow!” Sutskever said, in a sudden burst of emotion that felt, at this point, forty minutes into the conversation, somewhat performative.

后来，萨茨克弗与《纽约时报》记者凯德·梅茨（Cade Metz）坐在一起，谈论他的新书《天才制造者》（Genius Makers ），该书讲述了人工智能发展的叙事历史，萨茨克弗毫不讽刺地说道，“我认为，用不了多久，整个地球表面就将被数据中心和发电站覆盖。届时将会出现“一场计算海啸……几乎就像一种自然现象”。通用人工智能——以及支持通用人工智能所需的数据中心——将“非常有用，以至于不能不存在”。

Sutskever would later sit down with New York Times reporter Cade Metz for his book Genius Makers, which recounts a narrative history of AI development, and say without a hint of satire, “I think that it’s fairly likely that it will not take too long of a time for the entire surface of the Earth to become covered with data centers and power stations.” There would be “a tsunami of computing…almost like a natural phenomenon.” AGI—and thus the data centers needed to support them—would be “too useful to not exist.”

我再次尝试追问更多细节。“你的意思是，OpenAI 正在做一场豪赌，赌你能成功实现有益的通用人工智能，从而在加剧全球变暖之前抵消其影响。”

I tried again to press for more details. “What you’re saying is OpenAI is making a huge gamble that you will successfully reach beneficial AGI to counteract global warming before the act of doing so might exacerbate it.”

“我不会在这个问题上钻得太深，”布罗克曼急忙打断道。“我们的想法是这样的：我们正处于人工智能进步的上升期。这比OpenAI更大，对吧？这是一个领域。而且我认为社会实际上正在从中受益。”

“I wouldn’t go too far down that rabbit hole,” Brockman hastily cut in. “The way we think about it is the following: We’re on a ramp of AI progress. This is bigger than OpenAI, right? It’s the field. And I think society is actually getting benefit from it.”

“我们宣布这笔交易的那天，”他指的是微软新获得的10亿美元投资，“微软的市值就上涨了100亿美元。人们相信，即使只是短期技术投资，也能带来积极的投资回报。”

“The day we announced the deal,” he said, referring to Microsoft’s new $1 billion investment, “Microsoft’s market cap went up by $10 billion. People believe there is a positive ROI even just on short-term technology.”

因此，OpenAI 的策略非常简单，他解释道：跟上带着这样的进步。“这才是我们真正应该坚持的标准。我们应该继续取得这样的进步。这样我们才知道我们走在正确的轨道上。”

OpenAI’s strategy was thus quite simple, he explained: to keep up with that progress. “That’s the standard we should really hold ourselves to. We should continue to make that progress. That’s how we know we’re on track.”

当天晚些时候，布罗克曼重申，在 OpenAI 工作的核心挑战在于没有人真正知道 AGI 会是什么样子。但作为研究人员和工程师，他们的任务是不断推进，一步步探索这项技术的雏形。

Later that day, Brockman reiterated that the central challenge of working at OpenAI was that no one really knew what AGI would look like. But as researchers and engineers, their task was to keep pushing forward, to unearth the shape of the technology step by step.

他说话就像米开朗基罗一样，仿佛AGI早已存在于他正在雕刻的大理石之中。他只需一点点凿刻，直到它显露出来。

He spoke like Michelangelo, as though AGI already existed within the marble he was carving. All he had to do was chip away until it revealed itself.

—

—

计划有变。我原本计划和员工们在自助餐厅一起吃午饭，但现在有事需要我到办公室外面去。布罗克曼会陪我。我们走了二十几步，穿过马路，来到一家露天咖啡馆，那里已经成为员工们最爱去的地方。

There had been a change of plans. I had been scheduled to eat lunch with employees in the cafeteria, but something now required me to be outside the office. Brockman would be my chaperone. We headed two dozen steps across the street to an open-air café that had become a favorite haunt for employees.

在我访问期间，这种情况反复出现：我看不到楼层，无法参加会议，研究人员每隔几句话就会偷偷瞥一眼通讯主管，确认他们没有违反某些信息披露政策。后来我才知道，在我访问之后，杰克·克拉克会向 Slack 上的员工发出异常严厉的警告，除了经过批准的对话外，不要与我交谈。保安会收到一张我的照片，上面指示如果我未经批准出现在场地内，就要提高警惕。这种行为本身就很奇怪，而 OpenAI 对透明度的承诺则让这种行为更加奇怪。我开始怀疑，如果所有这一切都是有益的研究，最终都会向公众公开，那么他们到底在隐藏什么呢？

This would become a recurring theme throughout my visit: floors I couldn’t see, meetings I couldn’t attend, researchers stealing furtive glances at the communications head every few sentences to check that they hadn’t violated some disclosure policy. I would later learn that after my visit, Jack Clark would issue an unusually stern warning to employees on Slack not to speak with me beyond sanctioned conversations. The security guard would receive a photo of me with instructions to be on the lookout if I appeared unapproved on the premises. It was odd behavior in general, made odder by OpenAI’s commitment to transparency. What, I began to wonder, were they hiding, if everything was supposed to be beneficial research eventually made available to the public?

午餐时以及接下来的几天里，我深入探究了布罗克曼为何会成为 OpenAI 的联合创始人。十几岁时，他第一次痴迷于重塑人类智能的可能性。正是英国数学家艾伦·图灵的一篇著名论文激发了他的兴趣。该论文第一部分名为《模仿游戏》，2014年好莱坞改编的图灵生平电影的片名也源于此。影片开头的引人深思的问题是：“机器能否思考？”这篇论文进一步定义了后来被称为图灵测试的内容：一种衡量机器智能进步的指标，其依据是机器能否与人类对话而不暴露自己是机器。这在人工智能领域人士中是一个经典的起源故事。布罗克曼对此着迷不已，编写了一个图灵测试游戏并将其上传到网上，获得了约1500次点击。这让他感觉棒极了。“我突然意识到，这就是我想要追求的东西，”他说。

At lunch and through the following days, I probed deeper into why Brockman had cofounded OpenAI. He was a teen when he first grew obsessed with the idea that it could be possible to re-create human intelligence. It was a famous paper from British mathematician Alan Turing that sparked his fascination. The name of its first section, “The Imitation Game,” which inspired the title of the 2014 Hollywood dramatization of Turing’s life, begins with the opening provocation, “Can machines think?” The paper goes on to define what would become known as the Turing test: a measure of the progression of machine intelligence based on whether a machine can talk to a human without giving away that it is a machine. It was a classic origin story among people working in AI. Enchanted, Brockman coded up a Turing test game and put it online, garnering some 1,500 hits. It made him feel amazing. “I just realized that was the kind of thing I wanted to pursue,” he said.

但当时，他的顿悟为时过早；人工智能尚未成熟，而他也不是那种把自己关在实验室里做研究的人。于是，他加入了Stripe，同样对创建公司和开发可以交付给真实用户的产品的前景感到兴奋。在Stripe，Brockman以传奇般的编码效率而闻名。他是一位“10倍工程师”，这是硅谷的行话，指的是能够以比普通程序员快十倍的速度解决编码问题的程序员。他不太擅长与人打交道。在担任首席技术官期间，他更喜欢编码而不是管理。在尝试了一段时间他所谓的“人际交往路线”后，他想方设法减轻管理责任，将大部分时间用于编程。虽然他非常关心如何与同事相处，但他也会犯一些让同事感到尴尬的社交失态行为。一位前同事回忆道，有一次，他邀请了另一位Stripe员工约会，并立即通过电子邮件向全公司通报此事，以确保完全透明。 “我认为他是好意，但这很奇怪，”这位同事说。

But at the time, his revelation was too early; AI wasn’t ready for prime time, and he wasn’t one to sequester himself in a lab to do research. He joined Stripe instead, equally thrilled by the prospect of building a company and building products that he could place in the hands of real users. At Stripe, Brockman developed a reputation for a legendary coding productivity. He was a “10x engineer,” Valley lingo for a coder who could punch through coding problems ten times faster than the average coder. He was less adept with people. In his role as CTO, he much preferred coding to managing. After trying “the people route” for a while, as he called it, he sought ways to off-load executive responsibilities and spend the majority of his time programming. While he cared deeply about doing right by colleagues, he could also commit social gaffes that made them cringe. Once he asked another Stripe employee out on a date and immediately emailed the entire company about it for full transparency, a former colleague remembers. “I think he meant well, but it was very strange,” the colleague says.

2015年，人工智能飞速发展之际，布罗克曼与Stripe分道扬镳，他说，他意识到是时候回归最初的抱负了。这对初创公司来说也是一件好事：随着Stripe的成熟，他不愿管理或遵循公司标准流程的性格也变得越来越难以改变。他在笔记中写道，只要AGI能够实现，他愿意做任何事情，哪怕去做一名清洁工。四年后，他结婚了，在OpenAI的办公室举行了一场民事婚礼，婚礼由苏茨克维尔主持，婚礼现场是一面定制的花墙，上面装饰着实验室六边形的标志。他们用于研究的机械手站在过道上，手上戴着戒指，就像来自世界末日未来的哨兵。

In 2015, as AI saw great leaps of advancement, Brockman parted ways with Stripe, realizing, he says, that it was time to return to his original ambition. It was just as well for the startup: His unwillingness to manage or to follow standard company processes grew more challenging with Stripe’s maturation. He wrote down in his notes that he would do anything to bring AGI to fruition, even if it meant being a janitor. When he got married four years later, he held a civil ceremony at OpenAI’s office in front of a custom flower wall emblazoned with the shape of the lab’s hexagonal logo. Sutskever officiated. The robotic hand they used for research stood in the aisle bearing the rings, like a sentinel from a postapocalyptic future.

“从根本上来说，我想用我的余生致力于 AGI 的研究，”布罗克曼告诉我。

“Fundamentally, I want to work on AGI for the rest of my life,” Brockman told me.

他对待每件事都充满热情。他亲力亲为，注重细节。他长时间熬夜，专注于眼前的任务。工作之余，他仍在努力提升自己。他阅读有关公开演讲和谈判的书籍，他相信这些技能将有助于他完成OpenAI的使命。他羞于承认，自己也读书是为了娱乐——比如中国作家刘慈欣的《三体》三部曲和艾萨克·阿西莫夫的《基地》系列等科幻巨著。

He approached everything with this kind of intensity. He was hands on and detail oriented. He pulled long hours and all-nighters, consumed by the tasks in front of him. When he wasn’t working, he was still working to better himself. He read books about public speaking and negotiation, skills he believed would help him serve OpenAI’s mission. He was sheepish to admit that he also read books for fun—science fiction epics like The Three-Body Problem trilogy by Chinese writer Liu Cixin and Isaac Asimov’s Foundation series.

对员工来说，他坚持不懈的专注既是福也是祸。任何细节都值得他关注。如果一个团队遇到瓶颈，他可以一坐就是几个小时，一口气解决所有编程难题。他是推动团队不断进步的引擎，愿意日夜操劳，只为更快达成目标。与此同时，员工们常常认为他过于注重细节，只见树木不见森林。他可能会陷入狭隘的思维，夜以继日地处理一个问题，却不去评估环境是否发生了变化，以及这个问题是否仍然需要解决。如果他觉得编程进度不够快，他会进行微观管理，并迅速接替其他员工。和他一起工作的人都难以跟上他的节奏，许多人因此精疲力竭。

For employees, his relentless focus was a blessing and a curse. No detail was too small for him to obsess over. If a team got stuck, he could sit down for hours without getting up to knock down all of their coding obstacles. He was the engine of relentless progress, willing to work all hours of the day and night to hit milestones faster. At the same time, employees often thought he was too detail oriented, missing the forest for the trees. He could get tunnel vision, working on a problem around the clock without taking stock of whether the context had changed and the problem was still the right one to solve. He could micromanage and quickly take over from other employees if he felt coding wasn’t going fast enough. People who worked with him struggled to keep up. Many burned out.

一位曾与布罗克曼密切合作的前工程师表示，如果没有他，OpenAI 不可能取得如今的成就。但如果完全依靠他，事情就会变得非常糟糕。“格雷格没有远见卓识。他不是萨姆·奥特曼那样的远见卓识者。他只是想解决一个很酷的难题，并证明自己比任何人都聪明 10 倍。”

OpenAI couldn’t have gotten to where it was without him, a former engineer who worked closely with Brockman says. But if left totally up to him, things would go very wrong. “Greg doesn’t have a vision. He’s not the Sam Altman visionary.
