He just wants a cool hard problem to solve and to prove out that he’s 10x smarter than anyone else.”

是什么激励了他？我问布罗克曼。

What motivated him? I asked Brockman.

他反驳道：“在你的一生中，变革性技术出现的可能性有多大？”

What are the chances that a transformative technology could arrive in your lifetime? he countered.

他坚信，他和他组建的团队拥有独一无二的优势，能够引领这一变革。“我真正关注的是，如果我不参与，那些问题就不会以同样的方式发展，”他说。

He was confident that he—and the team he assembled—was uniquely positioned to usher in that transformation. “What I’m really drawn to are problems that will not play out in the same way if I don’t participate,” he said.

事实上，布罗克曼并不想只当一名看门人。他想领导通用人工智能。他身上充满了渴望获得历史性认可的焦虑。他希望有一天，人们能带着敬畏和钦佩讲述他的故事，就像他讲述前辈伟大创新者的故事一样。

Brockman did not in fact just want to be a janitor. He wanted to lead AGI. And he bristled with the anxious energy of someone who wanted history-defining recognition. He wanted people to one day tell his story with the same mixture of awe and admiration that he used to recount the ones of the great innovators who came before him.

在我们交谈一年前，他在太浩湖的一次私人度假胜地告诉一群年轻的科技创业者，首席技术官（CTO）从来都不是众所周知的。他向众人发起挑战：“说出一位著名的CTO吧。”众人费了好大劲才说出答案。他用行动证明了自己的观点。

A year before we spoke, he had told a group of young tech entrepreneurs at an exclusive retreat in Lake Tahoe with a twinge of self-pity that chief technology officers were never known. Name a famous CTO, he challenged the crowd. They struggled to do so. He had proved his point.

2022年，他成为OpenAI总裁。

In 2022, he became OpenAI’s president.

—

—

在我们交谈的过程中，布罗克曼向我坚称，OpenAI 的结构性变化并不代表其核心使命的转变。事实上，有限合伙人和新一批投资者强化了这一使命。“我们成功吸引了这些与使命一致的投资者，他们愿意将使命置于回报之上。这真是太不可思议了，”他说。

During our conversations, Brockman insisted to me that none of OpenAI’s structural changes signaled a shift in its core mission. In fact, the LP and the new crop of funders enhanced it. “We managed to get these mission-aligned investors who are willing to prioritize mission over returns. That’s a crazy thing,” he said.

OpenAI 现在拥有了遵循 OpenAI 法则所需的长期资源。Brockman 强调，这一点至关重要。未能紧跟潮流才是真正威胁 OpenAI 使命的因素。如果实验室落后，它就不是最好的。如果它不是最好的，它就不可能扭转历史的潮流，朝着有益的通用人工智能 (AGI) 愿景迈进。

OpenAI now had the long-term resources it needed to follow OpenAI’s Law. And this was imperative, Brockman stressed. Failing to stay on the curve was the real threat that could undermine OpenAI’s mission. If the lab fell behind, it wouldn’t be the best. If it weren’t the best, it had no hope of bending the arc of history toward its vision of beneficial AGI.

直到后来我才意识到这一断言的全部含义。正是这一根本假设——要么领先，要么灭亡——推动了 OpenAI 的所有行动及其深远的影响。它为 OpenAI 的每一项研究进展设定了一个滴答作响的时钟，并非基于精心策划的时间表，而是基于领先于其他人冲过终点线所需的不懈速度。它证明了 OpenAI 消耗大量资源的合理性：既包括计算资源，无论其对环境的影响如何；也包括数据资源，其积累速度无法通过获得同意或遵守法规来减缓。

Only later would I realize the full implications of this assertion. It was this fundamental assumption—the need to be first or perish—that set in motion all of OpenAI’s actions and their far-reaching consequences. It put a ticking clock on each of OpenAI’s research advancements, based not on the timescale of careful deliberation but on the relentless pace required to cross the finish line before anyone else. It justified OpenAI’s consumption of an unfathomable amount of resources: both compute, regardless of its impact on the environment; and data, the amassing of which couldn’t be slowed by getting consent or abiding by regulations.

布罗克曼再次指出微软市值跃升100亿美元。“这实际上反映出人工智能正在为当今现实世界带来真正的价值，”他说道。他承认，这些价值目前集中在一家已经非常富有的公司手中，这就是为什么OpenAI 的使命的第二部分是：将 AGI 的好处重新分配给每个人。

Brockman pointed once again to the $10 billion jump in Microsoft’s market cap. “What that really reflects is AI is delivering real value to the real world today,” he said. That value was currently being concentrated in an already wealthy corporation, he acknowledged, which was why OpenAI had the second part of its mission: to redistribute the benefits of AGI to everyone.

我问道：“历史上有没有成功分配技术利益的例子？”

Was there a historical example of a technology’s benefits that had been successfully distributed? I asked.

“嗯，我其实觉得——即使以互联网为例，也挺有意思的，”他支支吾吾地说，最后终于确定了答案。“问题也存在，对吧？”他提醒道。“任何时候，当你拥有一件极具变革性的事情时，要弄清楚如何最大限度地发挥其积极作用，最大限度地减少其消极作用，都不是一件容易的事。”

“Well, I actually think that—it’s actually interesting to look even at the internet as an example,” he said, fumbling a bit before settling on his answer. “There’s problems, too, right?” he said as a caveat. “Anytime you have something super transformative, it’s not going to be easy to figure out how to maximize positive, minimize negative.

“火灾是另一个例子，”他补充道。“它也有一些真正的弊端。所以我们必须想办法控制它，并制定共同的标准。”

“Fire is another example,” he added. “It’s also got some real drawbacks to it. So we have to figure out how to keep it under control and have shared standards.

“汽车就是一个很好的例子，”他接着说道。“很多人拥有汽车，造福了很多人。但它们也有一些缺点。它们有一些外部效应，不一定对世界有利，”他犹豫地总结道。

“Cars are a good example,” he followed. “Lots of people have cars, benefit a lot of people. They have some drawbacks to them as well. They have some externalities that are not necessarily good for the world,” he finished hesitantly.

“我想我只是认为——我们想要的通用人工智能与互联网、汽车、火的积极方面并没有什么不同。然而，实现方式却截然不同，因为它是一种截然不同的技术。”

“I guess I just view—the thing we want for AGI is not that different from the positive sides of the internet, positive sides of cars, positive sides of fire. The implementation is very different, though, because it’s a very different type of technology.”

他突然想到一个新主意，眼睛一亮。“看看公用事业公司。电力公司，也就是电力公司，都是非常集中的实体，提供低成本、高质量的产品，切实改善人们的生活。”

His eyes lit up with a new idea. “Just look at utilities. Power companies, electric companies are very centralized entities that provide low-cost, high-quality things that meaningfully improve people’s lives.”

这比喻很贴切。但布罗克曼似乎再次不清楚OpenAI将如何将自己打造成一家公用事业公司。他自言自语道，或许可以通过分配全民基本收入，或许可以通过其他方式。

It was a nice analogy. But Brockman seemed once again unclear about how OpenAI would turn itself into a utility. Perhaps through distributing universal basic income, he wondered aloud, perhaps through something else.

他又回到了他确信无疑的一件事。OpenAI 致力于重新分配通用人工智能的利益，赋予每个人经济自由。“我们确实是认真的，”他说。

He returned to the one thing he knew for certain. OpenAI was committed to redistributing AGI’s benefits and giving everyone economic freedom. “We actually really mean that,” he said.

“我们的想法是：迄今为止，技术确实能提升所有事物，但它也具有真正的集中效应，”他说。“通用人工智能可能会更加极端。如果所有价值都被锁定在一个地方会怎样？这就是我们社会的发展轨迹。我们从未我见过那种极端的情况。我觉得那不是一个好世界。那不是我想要的世界。那也不是我想要参与建设的世界。

“The way that we think about it is: Technology so far has been something that does rise all the boats, but it has this real concentrating effect,” he said. “AGI could be more extreme. What if all value gets locked up in one place? That is the trajectory we’re on as a society. And we’ve never seen that extreme of it. I don’t think that’s a good world. That’s not a world that I want to sign up for. That’s not a world that I want to help build.”

—

—

2020年2月，我为《麻省理工科技评论》发表了一篇个人简介，内容涵盖了我在公司任职期间的观察、近30次采访以及一些内部文件。我写道：“这家公司公开宣称的理念与幕后运作方式存在偏差。随着时间的推移，激烈的竞争和日益增长的融资压力侵蚀了其透明、开放和协作的创始理念。”

In February 2020, I published my profile for MIT Technology Review, drawing on my observations from my time in the office, nearly three dozen interviews, and a handful of internal documents. “There is a misalignment between what the company publicly espouses and how it operates behind closed doors,” I wrote. “Over time, it has allowed a fierce competitiveness and mounting pressure for ever more funding to erode its founding ideals of transparency, openness, and collaboration.”

几个小时后，马斯克连续发了三条推文回复了该报道：

Hours later, Musk replied to the story with three tweets in rapid succession:

“我认为 OpenAI 应该更加开放”

“OpenAI should be more open imo”

我对 OpenAI 没有任何控制权，了解也非常有限。我对 Dario 的安全性没有信心。

“I have no control & only very limited insight into OpenAI. Confidence in Dario for safety is not high.”

“所有开发先进人工智能的组织都应该受到监管，包括特斯拉”

“All orgs developing advanced AI should be regulated, including Tesla”

随后，奥特曼给 OpenAI 员工发了一封电子邮件。

Afterward, Altman sent OpenAI employees an email.

“我想分享一些关于《科技评论》文章的想法，”他写道。“虽然肯定不是灾难性的，但显然很糟糕。”

“I wanted to share some thoughts about the Tech Review article,” he wrote. “While definitely not catastrophic, it was clearly bad.”

他说，这篇文章指出了人们对 OpenAI 的认知与现实之间的脱节，这“是合理的批评”。这个问题可以通过调整 OpenAI 的公开信息而非改变其内部实践来解决。“这很好，也不错，我们已经找到了灵活适应的方法，”他说，包括重组组织结构和加强保密性，“以便在我们了解更多信息的同时实现我们的使命。”OpenAI 应该暂时忽略我的文章，并在几周后开始强调其在新的转型下将继续坚持其最初的原则。“这或许也是一个探讨 API 作为开放和利益共享策略的好机会，”他补充道。

It was “a fair criticism,” he said, that the piece had identified a disconnect between the perception of OpenAI and its reality. This could be smoothed over not with changes to its internal practices but some tuning of OpenAI’s public messaging. “It’s good, not bad, that we have figured out how to be flexible and adapt,” he said, including restructuring the organization and heightening confidentiality, “in order to achieve our mission as we learn more.” OpenAI should ignore my article for now and, in a few weeks’ time, start underscoring its continued commitment to its original principles under the new transformation. “This may also be a good opportunity to talk about the API as a strategy for openness and benefit sharing,” he added.

“对我来说，最严重的问题是，”他继续说道，“有人泄露了我们的内部文件。”他们已经开设了一个调查并将随时向公司通报最新情况。他还建议阿莫迪和马斯克会面，讨论马斯克的批评。马斯克的批评“相对于他之前说过的其他话来说，力度比较小”，但仍然“不妥”。他写道，为了避免任何疑问，阿莫迪的工作和人工智能安全对这项任务至关重要。“我认为我们应该在未来的某个时候找到一种方式公开捍卫我们的团队（但不要像媒体现在喜欢的那样公开辩论）。”

“The most serious issue of all, to me,” he continued, “is that someone leaked our internal documents.” They had already opened an investigation and would keep the company updated. He would also suggest that Amodei and Musk meet to work out Musk’s criticism, which was “mild relative to other things he’s said” but still “a bad thing to do.” For the avoidance of any doubt, Amodei’s work and AI safety were critical to the mission, he wrote. “I think we should at some point in the future find a way to publicly defend our team (but not give the press the public fight they’d love right now).”

OpenAI 三年都没有再和我说话。

OpenAI wouldn’t speak to me again for three years.

第四章

Chapter 4

现代之梦

Dreams of Modernity

我麻省理工学院经济学家、诺贝尔奖获得者达隆·阿西莫格鲁和西蒙·约翰逊在其著作《权力与进步》中指出，每一次技术革命都必须始于一个团结一致的雄心壮志。正是技术惠及所有人的承诺，才推动了漫长的征程，汇聚了足够的人才和资源，最终将其变为现实。在分析了一千年的技术历史之后，作者得出结论：技术并非必然。推动技术进步的能力源于一种集体信念，即技术值得推进。讽刺的是，正因如此，新技术很少会默认带来广泛的繁荣，作者继续说道。那些成功为一项技术的创造团结起来的人，是那些拥有力量和资源来团结起来的人。当他们将自己的想法变成现实时，他们所强加的愿景——关于技术是什么以及它能造福谁——因此只是一小撮精英的愿景，充满了他们所有的盲点和自私自利的哲学。只有通过社会的剧变或强大的有组织的抵抗，一项技术才能从让少数人致富转变为造福大多数人。

In their book Power and Progress, MIT economists and Nobel laureates Daron Acemoglu and Simon Johnson argue that every technology revolution must begin with a rallying ambition. It is the promise of a technology benefiting everyone that puts in motion the long journey of amassing enough talent and resources to turn it into a reality. After analyzing one thousand years of technology history, the authors conclude that technologies are not inevitable. The ability to advance them is driven by a collective belief that they are worth advancing. The irony is that for this very reason, new technologies rarely default to bringing widespread prosperity, the authors continue. Those who successfully rally for a technology’s creation are those who have the power and resources to do the rallying. As they turn their ideas into reality, the vision they impose—of what the technology is and whom it can benefit—is thus the vision of a narrow elite, imbued with all their blind spots and self-serving philosophies. Only through cataclysmic shifts in society or powerful organized resistance can a technology transform from enriching the few to lifting the many.

作者以18世纪90年代新型轧棉机的发明为例。这台机器使美国南部成为全球最大的棉花出口地，并提振了该国的经济增长。棉花产量激增，为许多土地所有者和棉花相关企业带来了暴利。但它却加剧了奴隶制及其可怕的非人化和劳动剥削制度，直到七十年后才被废除。随着棉花产量的激增，被奴役的黑人被迫工作更长时间，并遭受更残酷的体罚，榨干他们每一分劳动成果。与此同时，那些从轧棉机中获利的人却把这项发明描绘成让奴隶更幸福的发明。“我大胆地说，地球上没有比轧棉机更幸福、更满足的种族了，”一位南卡罗来纳州的国会议员说道。

The authors point to the invention of a new cotton gin in the 1790s as an example. The machine turned the American South into the largest global exporter of cotton, boosted the country’s top-line economic growth, and generated windfall returns for many landowners and cotton-related businesses. But it only served to intensify slavery and its horrific system of dehumanization and labor exploitation until its abolition seven decades later. With the surge in cotton production, enslaved Black people were forced to work longer hours and physically coerced by even harsher means to squeeze out every ounce of their labor. All the while, those who profited from the cotton gin painted the invention as one that made the enslaved happier. “I say it boldly, there is not a happier, more contented race upon the face of the earth,” said one South Carolina congressman.

技术革命的两大特征——承诺带来进步，却又倾向于逆转弱势群体，尤其是最弱势群体的进步——或许在人工智能时代比以往任何时候都更加真实。自诞生以来，人工智能的开发和应用一直受到诱人的现代化梦想的推动，并由少数拥有金钱和影响力的精英阶层塑造，以推动他们对这项技术的构想。正是这种构想导致了当今世界各地社会、劳动力和环境成本的激增，尤其是在许多发展中国家，正如我们将看到的，这些国家仍然受到历史上帝国掠夺的影响，经济发展迟缓，政治制度薄弱。然而，就像那位南卡罗来纳州的国会议员一样，硅谷却将那些被技术剥削和伤害的人描绘成因技术而更加幸福的人。

These two features of technology revolutions—their promise to deliver progress and their tendency instead to reverse it for people out of power, especially the most vulnerable—are perhaps truer than ever for the moment we now find ourselves in with artificial intelligence. Since its conception, the development and use of AI has been propelled by tantalizing dreams of modernity and shaped by a narrow elite with the money and influence to bring forth their conception of the technology. That conception is what has led to the exploding social, labor, and environmental costs that are playing out around the world today, particularly, as we’ll see, in many Global South countries, for which the consequences of their dispossession by historical empires still linger in delayed economic development and weaker political institutions. And yet, just like the South Carolina congressman, Silicon Valley has painted the experiences of those being exploited and harmed by the technology as happier because of it.

—

—

推动人工智能发展的前景已蕴含在该技术的名称之中。1956年，图灵论文以“机器能思考吗？”开头六年后，二十位科学家齐聚达特茅斯学院，全是白人，旨在创立一门研究这一问题的新学科。他们来自数学、密码学和认知科学等领域，需要一个新名称来统一这些学科。召集这次研讨会的达特茅斯教授约翰·麦卡锡最初使用“自动机研究”一词来描述对能够自动完成任务的机器的追求。行为。当这项研究没有引起太多关注时，他开始寻找一个更能引起共鸣的词语。他最终选择了“人工智能”这个术语。

The promise propelling AI development is encoded in the technology’s very name. In 1956, six years after Turing’s paper began with the line “Can machines think?” twenty scientists, all white men, gathered at Dartmouth College to form a new discipline in the study of this question. They came from fields such as mathematics, cryptography, and cognitive science and needed a new name to unify them. John McCarthy, the Dartmouth professor who convened the workshop, initially used the term automata studies to describe the pursuit of machines capable of automatic behavior. When the research didn’t attract much attention, he cast about for a more evocative phrase. He settled on the term artificial intelligence.

因此， “人工智能”这个名称从一开始就是一种营销手段，蕴含着这项技术所能带来的美好前景。“智能”听起来天生就很好，令人向往，复杂精妙，令人印象深刻；社会必然渴望更多；应该造福全人类。更名成功了。这两个词立刻吸引了更多人的兴趣——不仅来自资助者，也来自渴望加入这个雄心勃勃的新兴领域的科学家。

The name artificial intelligence was thus a marketing tool from the very beginning, the promise of what the technology could bring embedded within it. Intelligence sounds inherently good and desirable, sophisticated and impressive; something that society would certainly want more of; something that should deliver universal benefit. The name change did the trick. The two words immediately garnered more interest—not just from funders but also scientists, eager to be part of a budding field with such colossal ambitions.

长期从事人工智能研究的凯德·梅茨（Cade Metz）将这种重塑称为该领域的原罪：如今围绕这项技术的诸多炒作和风险，都源于麦卡锡做出的那个致命决定：他将其与“智能”这个诱人却又难以捉摸的概念联系起来。“智能”一词本身就容易让人随意地将其拟人化，并夸大其词地描述这项技术的能力。1958年，即该领域创立两年后，康奈尔大学教授弗兰克·罗森布拉特（Frank Rosenblatt）展示了感知器（Perceptron）。该系统可以执行基本的模式匹配，根据卡片左侧或右侧是否印有小方块来区分卡片。罗森布拉特不顾主要合作者的反对，宣称他的系统类似于人脑。他甚至大胆宣称，该系统有朝一日将能够繁殖并开始拥有感知能力。第二天早上，《纽约时报》宣布感知器未来将“能够行走、说话、看、写、自我复制并意识到自己的存在”。

Cade Metz, a longtime chronicler of AI, calls this rebranding the original sin of the field: So much of the hype and peril that now surround the technology flow from McCarthy’s fateful decision to hitch it to this alluring yet elusive concept of “intelligence.” The term lends itself to casual anthropomorphizing and breathless exaggerations about the technology’s capabilities. In 1958, two years after the field’s founding, Frank Rosenblatt, a Cornell University professor, demonstrated the Perceptron, a system that could perform basic pattern matching to tell apart cards based on whether they had a small square printed on their left or their right. Over his main collaborator’s objections, Rosenblatt advertised his system as something akin to the human brain. He even ventured to say that it would one day be able to reproduce and begin to have sentience. The next morning, The New York Times announced that the Perceptron would in the future “be able to walk, talk, see, write, reproduce itself and be conscious of its existence.”

这种拟人化的传统一直延续至今，好莱坞电影将“人工智能”的概念与人类创造物突然苏醒的古老描述相结合，进一步助长了这种趋势。人工智能开发者经常谈论他们的软件如何像人类一样“学习”、“阅读”或“创造”。这不仅助长了人们认为当前的人工智能技术远超其实际能力的观念，也成为了企业逃避法律责任的修辞工具。一些艺术家和作家起诉人工智能开发者，称其未经同意且未支付报酬就使用他们的创作成果来训练人工智能，违反了版权法。系统。开发者认为，这种做法符合合理使用，因为这与人类受他人作品“启发”并无二致。无处不在的人工智能与人类的类比也加剧了这样一种感觉：这类软件的能力可能超越我们，甚至威胁到我们的生存。对超级智能的恐惧源于这样一种观点：人工智能可能会以某种方式超越我们，凭借其特殊特质，人类在数万年的时间里一直是地球上的优等物种。

That tradition of anthropomorphizing continues to this day, aided by Hollywood tales combining the idea of “AI” with age-old depictions of human-made creations suddenly waking up. AI developers speak often about how their software “learns,” “reads,” or “creates” just like humans. Not only has this fed into a sense that current AI technologies are far more capable than they are, it has become a rhetorical tool for companies to avoid legal responsibility. Several artists and writers have sued AI developers for violating copyright laws by using their creative work—without their consent and without compensating them—to train AI systems. Developers have argued that doing so falls under fair use because it is no different from a human being “inspired” by others’ work. The omnipresent AI-to-human analogies have also fueled the sense that such software could become so capable that it surpasses us and comes to threaten our very existence. The fear of superintelligence is predicated on the idea that AI could somehow rise above us in the special quality that has made humans the planet’s superior species for tens of thousands of years.

“人工智能”这个名称也塑造了该领域对其实际用途的理解。此前，科学家们仅仅致力于构建机器来实现计算自动化，这与《模仿游戏》中图灵在二战期间破解纳粹恩尼格玛密码时制造的庞大装置并无二致。而如今，科学家们正在重新创造智能——这一理念定义了该领域进步的衡量标准，并在几十年后催生了OpenAI自身的雄心壮志。

Artificial intelligence as a name also forged the field’s own conceptions about what it was actually doing. Before, scientists were merely building machines to automate calculations, not unlike the large hulking apparatus, as portrayed in The Imitation Game, that Turing made to crack the Nazi Enigma code during World War II. Now, scientists were re-creating intelligence—an idea that would define the field’s measures of progress and would decades later birth OpenAI’s own ambitions.

但核心问题在于，目前尚无科学界公认的智力定义。纵观历史，神经科学家、生物学家和心理学家都对智力的定义以及人类为何比其他物种拥有更高的智力提出了不同的解释。或许是因为我们大脑的大小，我们推理复杂问题的能力，或是我们对他人信念建立心智模型的能力。几个世纪以来，人们开发了无数测试来根据这些定义来衡量智力，但其中许多测试后来因其不光彩的历史而被推翻，并逐渐失宠。19世纪初，美国颅相学家塞缪尔·莫顿（Samuel Morton）为了证明种族主义观点的合理性，曾对人类头骨的尺寸进行了精确测量。他发现，白人的头骨平均尺寸较大，因此他们的智力优于黑人。后来的科学家发现，莫顿捏造了数据以迎合他先入为主的观念，他的数据显示不同种族之间并没有显著差异。同样，智商测试最初是为了剔除社会中的“弱智”群体，并通过科学的“客观性”来为优生政策的合理性辩护。而较近的标准化考试，例如SAT，则对考生的社会经济背景表现出高度敏感性，这表明他们可能衡量获取资源和教育的机会，而不是某些固有的能力。

But the central problem is that there is no scientifically agreed-upon definition of intelligence. Throughout history, neuroscientists, biologists, and psychologists have all come up with varying explanations for what it is and why it seems that humans have more of it than any other species. Perhaps it’s the size of our human brains, our ability to reason through complex problems, or our capacity to create a mental model of other people’s beliefs. Myriad tests have been developed over the centuries to measure intelligence against these definitions, many of which have subsequently been debunked and fallen out of favor due to their unsavory histories. In the early 1800s, American craniologist Samuel Morton quite literally measured the size of human skulls in an attempt to justify the racist belief that white people, whose skulls he found were on average larger, had superior intelligence to Black people. Later generations of scientists found that Morton had fudged his numbers to fit his preconceived beliefs, and his data showed no significant differences between races. IQ tests similarly began as a means to weed out the “feebleminded” in society and to justify eugenics policies through scientific “objectivity.” More recent standardized tests, such as the SAT, have shown high sensitivity to a test taker’s socioeconomic background, suggesting that they may measure access to resources and education rather than some inherent ability.

在 2004 年首次发表的题为“什么是人工智能？”的文件中，麦卡锡承认，对于试图重建自然智能的领域来说，缺乏对自然智能的共识本质上是令人困惑的。2007年，他的文章进行了修订，其中包含一段冗长而曲折的问答，旨在解答普通读者的一些基本问题。文章开头写道：

In a document first published in 2004 titled “What Is Artificial Intelligence?,” McCarthy admitted that the lack of consensus around natural intelligence was inherently confusing for a field trying to re-create it. A 2007 revision of his write-up presents a long and winding Q&A, meant to address basic questions for a lay audience. It begins:

问：什么是人工智能？

Q. What is artificial intelligence?

答：它是制造智能机器，尤其是智能计算机程序的科学和工程……

A. It is the science and engineering of making intelligent machines, especially intelligent computer programs….

问：是的，但是什么是智力？

Q. Yes, but what is intelligence?

答：智能是实现现实目标的能力的计算部分。人类、许多动物以及一些机器都拥有不同种类和程度的智能。

A. Intelligence is the computational part of the ability to achieve goals in the world. Varying kinds and degrees of intelligence occur in people, many animals and some machines.

问：难道没有一个不依赖于与人类智能关联的确切的智能定义吗？

Q. Isn’t there a solid definition of intelligence that doesn’t depend on relating it to human intelligence?

答：还没有。问题在于，我们还无法概括地描述哪些类型的计算过程可以被称为智能。

A. Not yet. The problem is that we cannot yet characterize in general what kinds of computational procedures we want to call intelligent.

因此，人工智能领域倾向于以人类能力来衡量其进步。人类的技能和天赋已成为组织研究的蓝图。计算机视觉旨在重塑我们的视觉；自然语言处理和生成，即我们的阅读和写作能力；语音识别和合成，即我们的听和说能力；图像和视频生成，即我们的创造力和想象力。随着这些能力的软件不断进步，研究人员随后试图将它们组合成所谓的多模式系统——能够“看”、“说”、“听”和“读”的系统。这项技术如今正威胁着大量人类工作者的就业，这并非偶然，而是经过精心设计。

As a result, the field of AI has gravitated toward measuring its progress against human capabilities. Human skills and aptitudes have become the blueprint for organizing research. Computer vision seeks to re-create our sight; natural language processing and generation, our ability to read and write; speech recognition and synthesis, our ability to hear and speak; and image and video generation, our creativity and imagination. As software for each of these capabilities has advanced, researchers have subsequently sought to combine them into so-called multimodal systems—systems that can “see” and “speak,” “hear” and “read.” That the technology is now threatening to replace large swaths of human workers is not by accident but by design.

然而，对人工智能的探索依然漫无目的。人工智能研究的每一个新里程碑都引发了激烈的争论，关于它是代表着对真正智能的再创造还是苍白的模仿。为了区分两者，“通用人工智能”已成为指代真正智能的新术语。这一最新的名称更名并没有改变这样一个事实：目前尚无明确的方法来衡量进展或确定该领域何时取得成功。研究人员普遍认为，今天被认为是人工智能的东西，明天就不再是人工智能了。图灵测试作为人工智能的指标，很快就被迅速超越，科学家们认为他们实际上并没有解决他们的目标。科学家们也曾一度认为，计算机在国际象棋或围棋中击败人类将是衡量成功的最终标准。如今，DeepMind 的 AlphaGo 被视为软件能力的有力证明，但这再次表明，该领域的雄心壮志尚未最终实现。经过数十年的研究，随着基准的演变、重写和废弃，人工智能的定义也发生了变化。人工智能发展的目标永远在变化，正如数据与社会研究主管詹娜·伯雷尔（Jenna Burrell）曾经描述的那样，“未来的地平线永远在后退”。这项技术的进步正朝着一个未知的目标前进，看不到任何可预见的终点。

Still, the quest for artificial intelligence remains unmoored. With every new milestone in AI research, fierce debates follow about whether it represents the re-creation of true intelligence or a pale imitation. To distinguish between the two, artificial general intelligence has become the new term of art to refer to the real deal. This latest rebranding hasn’t changed the fact that there is not yet a clear way to mark progress or determine when the field will have succeeded. It’s a common saying among researchers that what is considered AI today will no longer be AI tomorrow. The Turing test didn’t last long as an indicator of AI after it was quickly surpassed, and scientists felt they hadn’t actually solved their objective. There was also a time when scientists believed that a computer beating humans in chess or Go would be a conclusive measure of success. Now DeepMind’s AlphaGo is seen as a compelling demonstration of what software can be made to do but once again not yet a conclusion to the field’s ambitions. Through decades of research, the definition of AI has changed as benchmarks have evolved, been rewritten, and been discarded. The goalposts for AI development are forever shifting and, as the research director at Data & Society Jenna Burrell once described it, an “ever-receding horizon of the future.” The technology’s advancement is headed toward an unknown objective, with no foreseeable end in sight.

为了证明追求人工智能雄心壮志所耗费的时间和成本的不断攀升是合理的，我们被告知的关于人工智能的承诺比以往任何时候都更加宏大：人工智能曾经只是一门科学，是一项具有潜在商业价值的技术。如今，人工智能是第四次工业革命的先兆，是现代超级大国的基石。通用人工智能（AGI）一旦实现，将解决气候变化问题，实现可负担的医疗保健，提供公平的教育。OpenAI 就是这种思路的典范。它无法预知这项技术将如何兑现这些承诺——只能说，社会为其正在开发的东西付出的巨额代价终有一天会值得。

To justify the elongating timeline and the ever-expanding costs of pursuing the ambition for AI, the promises we’re told about it have grown more grandiose than ever before: AI was once a scientific fascination, a technology with some potential commercial utility. Now, AI is the harbinger of the fourth industrial revolution. The keystone of the modern superpower. AGI, if ever reached, will solve climate change, enable affordable health care, provide equitable education. OpenAI is the poster child for this line of thought. It cannot say how the technology will deliver on these promises—only that the staggering price society needs to pay for what it is developing will someday be worth it.

未明说的是，在缺乏一致认可的含义的情况下，“人工智能”或“通用人工智能”可以是 OpenAI 想要的任何名称。

What’s left unsaid is that in a vacuum of agreed-upon meaning, “artificial intelligence” or “artificial general intelligence” can be whatever OpenAI wants.

—

—

人工智能的历史表明，人工智能的发展始终由强大的精英阶层主导。如今，人工智能已成为庞大且耗费资源的模型的代名词，只有极少数公司有能力开发这些模型，并希望我们将其产品打造成一切的基础，这并非巧合。即使在早期，在商业利益尚未使人工智能革命的政治影响更加清晰可见之前，该领域的科学探索就已经在资金和影响力的激烈冲突中摇摆不定。

The history of AI shows us that AI development has always been shaped by a powerful elite. It’s not a coincidence that AI today has become synonymous with colossal, resource-hungry models that only a tiny handful of companies are equipped to develop, and that desire us to make their products into the foundations for everything. Even in the early days, before commercial interests made the politics of the AI revolution far more visible, the field’s scientific explorations lurched and swerved amid heated clashes over funding and influence.

达特茅斯会议之后，出现了两大阵营，各自提出了关于如何推动该领域发展的相互竞争的理论。第一阵营被称为符号学派，他们认为智能源于认知。人类比动物拥有更多知识，并能运用这些知识理解世界、影响世界。因此，要实现人工智能，就必须将世界知识的符号表征编码到机器中，从而创建所谓的专家系统。第二阵营被称为联结学派，他们认为智能源于学习。人类比动物拥有更强的学习能力，并能利用这种能力获得和提升不同的技能。人工智能的发展应该专注于创建所谓的机器学习系统，例如模仿我们大脑处理信号和信息的方式。这一假设最终导致了神经网络的普及，这种数据处理软件的设计大致是为了模拟大脑的相互关联的连接，如今已成为现代人工智能（包括所有生成式人工智能系统）的基础。

Following the Dartmouth gathering, two camps emerged with competing theories about how to advance the field. The first camp, known as the symbolists, believed that intelligence comes from knowing. Humans know more than animals and can use that knowledge to understand and act on the world. Achieving AI must then involve encoding symbolic representations of the world’s knowledge into machines, creating so-called expert systems. The second camp, called the connectionists, believed that intelligence comes from learning. Humans have a greater capacity to learn than animals and can use that ability to acquire and advance different skills. Developing AI should focus instead on creating so-called machine learning systems, such as by mimicking the ways our brains process signals and information. This hypothesis would eventually lead to the popularity of neural networks, data-processing software loosely designed to mirror the brain’s interlocking connections, now the basis of modern AI, including all generative AI systems.

在接下来的几十年里，两大阵营争夺着有限的资金，并控制着大众对人工智能未来的想象。当时，这些争斗主要发生在大学和学术期刊上，科学家们为争夺政府和基金会的资金而争吵不休；有时，他们的争论会在媒体报道中爆发，影响着公众对他们研究方向的理解。联结学派的领袖是罗森布拉特和他的感知器，它是人工智能概念的早期证明。一个机器学习系统。罗森布拉特从未给过这个系统明确的指令，而是让它在观察大量例子后，自行计算出区分不同卡片的规则。符号学派的掌舵人是罗森布拉特的宿敌——麻省理工学院教授马文·明斯基。作为达特茅斯研讨会的联合组织者，明斯基本人也曾涉猎过联结主义思想，但最终却对这个想法感到失望。他并没有悄悄地改变立场。他经常找机会作秀和嘲讽那些与他竞争相同经费的联结主义同事，甚至连职业生涯早期的研究人员也不放过。1969 年，他与人合著了一本名为《感知器》的书，书中对联结主义进行了猛烈批判，人们认为，随着神经网络的中等进步，联结主义几乎扼杀了该领域研究 15 年多来的所有资金。

Over subsequent decades the two camps vied for a limited pool of funding and control over the popular imagination of what AI could be. At the time, those fights played out in universities and academic journals among scientists squabbling over government and foundation money; on occasion, their debates would burst forth in media coverage, shaping the public’s understanding of their pursuits. At the helm of the connectionists was Rosenblatt and his Perceptron, an early proof of concept for a machine learning system. Rosenblatt never gave the system explicit instructions, designing it instead to compute its own rules for how to tell different cards apart after seeing numerous examples. At the helm of the symbolists was Rosenblatt’s nemesis, MIT professor Marvin Minsky. A co-organizer of the Dartmouth workshop, Minsky had himself dabbled in connectionist thinking before souring on the idea. He did not switch his loyalties quietly. He found frequent opportunities to grandstand and ridicule his connectionist colleagues who competed with him for the same grants, sparing not even early-career researchers. In 1969, he coauthored a book, called Perceptrons, so critical of connectionism that it is credited, along with the middling progress of neural networks, for killing off nearly all funding to that vein of research for more than fifteen years.

在争夺影响力的斗争中，明斯基遇到了一位意想不到的盟友：他在麻省理工学院的同事约瑟夫·魏森鲍姆。1958年，也就是罗森布拉特的感知器引起《纽约时报》轰动的同一年，魏森鲍姆发明了一个名为ELIZA的人工智能系统，同样也登上了新闻头条。在ChatGPT诞生的六十多年前，ELIZA是一个聊天机器人，你可以通过连接到一台占据整个房间的庞大主机上的电动打字机与之交谈。然而，在 ChatGPT 摆脱联结主义传统的同时，ELIZA 却是一个符号系统，它使用简单的规则来表现出对用户的关注和响应。

In their battle for influence, Minsky had an unlikely ally: his MIT colleague Joseph Weizenbaum. In 1958, the same year that Rosenblatt’s Perceptron captivated The New York Times, Weizenbaum invented an AI system called ELIZA that similarly drew headlines. More than six decades before ChatGPT, ELIZA was a chatbot that you could converse with through an electric typewriter hooked up to a hulking mainframe that spanned an entire room. Under the hood, though, where ChatGPT would emerge from connectionist tradition, ELIZA was a symbolic system, using simple rules to seem attentive and responsive to a user.

ELIZA 最受欢迎的实例之一是仿照谈话疗法而设计的，该方法通过回顾患者所说的内容并温和地询问更多信息来探究患者。在魏泽鲍姆后来发表的一篇关于 ELIZA 内部工作原理的论文中，他提供了以下对话作为示例：

One of the most popular instantiations of ELIZA was designed after a method of talk therapy that probed a patient by reflecting back what they said and gently asking for more information. In a paper Weizenbaum later published on the inner workings of ELIZA, he provided the following dialogue as an example:

网友：男人都一样。

User: Men are all alike.

伊丽莎：以什么方式

ELIZA: IN WHAT WAY

用户：他们总是以这样或那样的事情来烦扰我们。

User: They’re always bugging us about something or other.

伊丽莎：你能举一个具体的例子吗

ELIZA: CAN YOU THINK OF A SPECIFIC EXAMPLE

用户：嗯，我男朋友让我来这里。

User: Well, my boyfriend made me come here.

伊丽莎：你的男朋友让你来这里

ELIZA: YOUR BOYFRIEND MADE YOU COME HERE

用户：他说我大部分时间都很沮丧。

User: He says I’m depressed much of the time.

伊丽莎：我很遗憾听到你心情低落

ELIZA: I AM SORRY TO HEAR YOU ARE DEPRESSED

用户：是啊，我不开心。

User: It’s true. I am unhappy.

伊丽莎：你觉得来这里能让你不再不快乐吗

ELIZA: DO YOU THINK COMING HERE WILL HELP YOU NOT TO BE UNHAPPY

魏森鲍姆设计这套系统是为了进行一项实验，看看人类究竟有多容易被所谓的“智力幻觉”所蒙蔽。ELIZA 的名字来源于伊莉莎·杜利特尔 (Eliza Doolittle)，她是奥黛丽·赫本在 1956 年的电影《窈窕淑女》中饰演的虚构工人阶级卖花女。在一位富豪教她如何改变自己的言谈举止后，她学会了如何冒充上流社会的公爵夫人。ELIZA 随后成功欺骗人们，使其相信自己拥有智能，这让魏森鲍姆感到震惊。事实上，这场演示让一些人感到信服，以至于精神病学家开始谈论自动化心理治疗即将到来。而在人工智能领域成立仅仅几年后，计算机科学家们就过早地得出结论，认为计算机的自然语言理解问题已经得到解决。（几十年后，这个问题是否已经得到解决至今仍是一个悬而未决的问题。）

Weizenbaum designed the system as an experiment to see how easily humans might fall for an illusion of intelligence. ELIZA’s namesake was Eliza Doolittle, a fictional working-class flower girl portrayed by Audrey Hepburn in the 1956 film My Fair Lady, who learns to pass as a duchess in high society after a wealthy man teaches her to change her diction and manners. ELIZA’s subsequent success in fooling people into believing it to be intelligent alarmed Weizenbaum. In fact, the demonstration felt so convincing to some that psychiatrists began to speak of automated psychotherapy as just around the corner, and merely a few years after the founding of the AI field, computer scientists were already prematurely concluding that natural language understanding in computers was a solved problem. (Decades later, whether or not it’s even been solved today is still an open debate.)

魏森鲍姆在其职业生涯的余下时间里，大部分时间都在努力淡化人们对其作品的炒作，并反对人工智能发展背后的根本假设。他写道，ELIZA 只不过是一个简单的程序，由他编写，用于识别用户输入中的关键词，并执行基本转换来构建响应。“我的男朋友”变成了“你的男朋友”；“我很沮丧”变成了“你很沮丧”。它真的没什么智能可言。在明斯基的感知器问世后的十年里，他出版了一本名为《计算机能力与人类理性》的巨著，认为人类和机器是不同的，而人工智能领域试图模糊这种区别这将导致深远的社会后果。例如，它将允许掌权者——无论是首席执行官还是政客——通过机器执行他们的意志，同时免除他们的道德责任。

Weizenbaum would spend much of the rest of his career attempting to deflate the hype of his creation and campaigning against the fundamental presumption behind the pursuit of AI. ELIZA, he wrote, was nothing but a simple procedural program, coded by him to identify keywords in a user’s input and perform basic transformations to construct responses. My boyfriend became your boyfriend; I’m depressed became you are depressed. There was really nothing much intelligent about it. He later published a tome called Computer Power and Human Reason in the decade following Minsky’s Perceptrons that argued that humans and machines are different and the AI field’s attempt to blur that distinction would lead to profound societal consequences. It would, for example, allow people in power—whether CEOs or politicians—to execute their will through machines while absolving themselves of moral responsibility.

尽管魏森鲍姆竭尽全力，ELIZA 对符号系统的精彩演示却无意中支持了明斯基提升符号主义而非联结主义的主张。在接下来的几十年里，直到九十年代，专家系统成为人工智能研究和商业化最热门的领域。这种主流思想催生了像 Cyc 这样的项目，该项目旨在通过编写一亿条关于日常生活的规则来开发一个常识系统。然而，在不同的发展阶段，符号人工智能系统的进展会遇到阻碍，因为扩展它们的努力会遭遇手动编码所有规则的挑战。如何才能编码英语中所有微妙之处，包括俚语、讽刺、修辞手法和语法例外？每当障碍增多，资助者就会失去兴趣，使该领域陷入生存危机，即所谓的“人工智能寒冬”。

Despite Weizenbaum’s best efforts, ELIZA’s arresting demonstration of a symbolic system inadvertently bolstered Minsky’s campaign to elevate symbolism over connectionism. Over the next few decades, through the nineties, expert systems became the hottest area of AI research and commercialization. The prevailing thinking spawned projects like Cyc, an effort to develop a common-sense system by programming it with one hundred million rules about daily life. But during various stretches, advancements in symbolic AI systems would sputter and slow as efforts to scale them hit up against the challenges of manually encoding all the rules. How does one encode all the subtleties of the English language with its slang, sarcasm, figures of speech, and grammar exceptions? Each time the roadblocks mounted, funders would lose interest, plunging the field into a state of existential crisis known as an “AI winter.”

—

—

故事发展到这一阶段，人工智能的历史常常被解读为科学价值战胜政治的胜利。明斯基或许利用自己的地位和平台压制了联结主义，但该思想本身的优势最终使其占据了主导地位，并成为现代人工智能革命的基石。在象征主义盛行的年代，一小群联结主义者坚定地追随罗森布拉特对机器学习系统的追求，并不断推进它的发展。他们之中包括苏茨克弗的博士生导师杰弗里·辛顿，他在20世纪80年代担任卡内基梅隆大学教授时，与加州大学圣地亚哥分校的同事一起对早期神经网络进行了关键性的改进。当时，联结主义者假设他们的神经网络失败是因为它们过于简单；它们只包含一层联网的“神经元”，即数据处理节点。为了更好地模拟人脑，软件可能需要多层堆叠和连接的神经网络来形成所谓的深度神经网络。 Hinton 和他的合著者们通过使用一种称为反向传播，它允许深度神经网络跨层交换和处理信息。在另一个品牌重塑的例子中，Hinton 后来巧妙地将这种多层处理命名为“深度学习” ，这是使用深度神经网络进行机器学习的简写。

At this point in the story, the history of AI is often told as the triumph of scientific merit over politics. Minsky may have used his stature and platform to quash connectionism, but the strengths of the idea itself eventually allowed it to rise to the top and take its rightful place as the bedrock of the modern AI revolution. During the years that symbolism reigned, a small band of connectionists held fast to Rosenblatt’s pursuit of machine learning systems and continued to advance it. They included Sutskever’s PhD adviser, Geoffrey Hinton, who, as a professor at Carnegie Mellon University in the 1980s, made a key improvement to early neural networks along with colleagues from the University of California, San Diego. By then, connectionists had hypothesized that their neural networks were failing because they were too simple; they contained only a single layer of networked “neurons,” or data-processing nodes. To better mimic the human brain, the software likely needed multiple stacked and connected layers to form a so-called deep neural network. Hinton and his coauthors made this change possible by using an algorithm known as backpropagation, which allows deep neural networks to exchange and process information across their layers. In another instance of rebranding, Hinton later cleverly gave this multilayer processing the name deep learning, a shorthand for using deep neural networks to perform machine learning.

但深度神经网络（如今简称为“神经网络”）的出现早了几十年。为了真正发挥其潜力，它们需要比 20 世纪 80 年代计算机更强大的处理能力，以及比从模拟世界中廉价编译的更多的示例或数据。神经网络的核心是统计计算器，它识别旧数据（文本、图片或视频）中的模式，并将其应用于新数据。如今，如果一位人工智能开发者想要构建一个用于检测图像中人物的人工智能模型，他们可能会向神经网络输入数十万张图片，每张图片都带有一个标签——1 表示“有人”，0 表示“没有人”。（当你通过点击所有带有停车标志的图片来破解谷歌的验证码时，你实际上是在训练该公司的神经网络。）然后，神经网络利用统计数据，梳理出图像中与是否有人相关的像素模式。这就是所谓的训练人工智能模型。模型训练完成后，开发人员可以在新数据上运行它（称为推理），以确定它是否符合模式。这张图片是 1 还是 0？上面有人吗？

But deep neural networks—today, simply called “neural networks”—came several decades too early. To really shine, they needed more processing power than computers in the 1980s had available, and more examples, or data, than could be cheaply compiled from the analog world. At their core, neural networks are calculators of statistics that identify patterns in old data—text, pictures, or videos—and apply them to new data. Today, if an AI developer wants to build an AI model for detecting people in images, they might feed a neural network hundreds of thousands of images, each with a label—1 for “has a person,” 0 for “does not have a person.” (When you’re solving Google’s captchas by clicking all the images with stop signs, you are in fact training the company’s neural networks.) Using statistics, the neural network then teases out the pixel patterns within the images that are associated with whether a person is present. This is what’s known as training an AI model. Once the model is done training, the developer can run it on new data—known as inferencing—to determine whether it fits the pattern. Is this image a 1 or a 0? Does it have a person or not?

一般来说，神经网络需要在一定阈值的高质量数据和一定阈值的计算能力上进行训练，才能计算出这些模式并生成高性能的人工智能模型。Hinton 和他的合著者们走在了时代的前列。但在本世纪末，随着计算机的发展和互联网的成熟，新的数字数据存储库应运而生，神经网络终于具备了蓬勃发展的条件。此后不久，谷歌收购了 Hinton 的 DNNresearch（深度神经网络的简称“DNN”），引发了一场深度学习商业化的新竞赛。

Generally speaking, neural networks need to be trained on a certain threshold of high-quality data with a certain threshold of compute to calculate these patterns and produce a performant AI model. Hinton and his coauthors were ahead of their time. But in the late aughts, once computers had advanced and the internet had matured, creating new repositories of digital data, neural networks finally had the right conditions to flourish. Shortly thereafter, Google acquired Hinton’s DNNresearch—“DNN” for deep neural networks—igniting a new race to commercialize deep learning.

在这个故事中，我们要吸取的教训是：科学是一个混乱的过程，但最终最好的想法将会出现，尽管最响亮的批评者。叙述中隐含着另一个信息：技术随着不可避免的进步而进步。

In this telling of the story, the lesson to be learned is this: Science is a messy process, but ultimately the best ideas will rise despite even the loudest detractors. Implicit within the narrative is another message: Technology advances with the inevitable march of progress.

但我们可以换一种角度来看待这段历史。联结主义之所以能够超越象征主义，不仅仅是因为它的科学价值。它还凭借其吸引商业利益的关键优势，赢得了财力雄厚的资助者的支持。

But there is a different way to view this history. Connectionism rose to overshadow symbolism not just for its scientific merit. It also won over the backing of deep-pocketed funders due to key advantages that appealed to those funders’ business interests.

符号人工智能的优势在于将信息及其关系显式编码到系统中，使其能够检索准确的答案并进行推理，而这正是人类智能的一个关键特征，被认为对其复制至关重要。想想IBM Watson，它是最著名的符号系统之一，在2011年的《危险边缘！》（Jeopardy!）节目中大放异彩。它能够快速给出游戏节目的致胜答案，这源于它能够搜索海量知识并准确复现。另一方面，符号系统的弱点也对其造成了损害：它的商业化进程一次又一次地被证明是缓慢、昂贵且难以预测的。在深夜电视节目中首次推出Watson后，IBM发现，要让该系统提供客户真正愿意付费的结果（例如回答医疗问题而非琐碎问题），可能需要多年的前期投资，而且公司何时才能获得回报也尚不明确。在烧掉超过40亿美元且看不到尽头之后，IBM宣布退出，并于2022年以当时金额的四分之一出售了Watson Health。

The strength of symbolic AI is in the explicit encoding of information and their relationships into the system, allowing it to retrieve accurate answers and perform reasoning, a feature of human intelligence seen as critical to its replication. Think of IBM Watson, one of the most famous symbolic systems, which would dazzle on Jeopardy! in 2011. Its speedy delivery of game show–winning answers was based in its ability to trawl through vast stores of knowledge and accurately reproduce them. The weakness of symbolism, on the other hand, has been to its detriment: Time and again its commercialization has proven slow, expensive, and unpredictable. After debuting Watson on late-night TV, IBM discovered that getting the system to produce the kinds of results that customers would actually pay for, such as answering medical rather than trivia questions, could take years of up-front investment without clarity on when the company would see returns. IBM called it quits after burning more than $4 billion with no end in sight and sold Watson Health for a quarter of that amount in 2022.

与此同时，神经网络则面临着不同的权衡。多年来，该领域一直在激烈争论这种联结主义软件能否做到符号软件所能做到的事情：存储信息和推理。无论答案如何，显而易见的是，即使它们能够做到，效率也很低下。只有在拥有海量数据和强大计算能力的情况下，神经网络才开始表现出可能暗示这两种特性出现的行为。话虽如此，深度学习模型真正闪耀的一个领域是其易于商业化。你不需要拥有具有推理能力的完美精确系统就能获得丰厚的利润。强大的统计模式匹配和预测能力在解决经济效益问题方面大有裨益。尽管前期投资同样昂贵，但获得回报的路径却短且可预测，非常适合企业规划周期和季度盈利节奏。更棒的是，此类模型无需专业领域知识即可应用于各种场景，这与科技巨头的扩张野心相契合。更不用说，深度学习能为拥有最多数据的玩家带来最大的竞争优势。

Neural networks, meanwhile, come with a different trade-off. For years the field has aggressively debated whether such connectionist software can do what the symbolic ones can: store information and reason. Regardless of the answer, it has become clear that if they can, they do so inefficiently. Only with extraordinary amounts of data and computational power have neural networks even begun to have the kinds of behaviors that may suggest the emergence of either property. That said, one area where deep learning models really shine is how easy it is to commercialize them. You do not need perfectly accurate systems with reasoning capabilities to turn a handsome profit. Strong statistical pattern-matching and prediction go a long way in solving financially lucrative problems. The path to reaping a return, despite similarly expensive upfront investment, is also short and predictable, well suited to corporate planning cycles and the pace of quarterly earnings. Even better that such models can be spun up for a range of contexts without specialized domain knowledge, fitting for a tech giant’s expansive ambitions. Not to mention that deep learning affords the greatest competitive advantage to players with the most data.

在DNNresearch被拍卖之前，科技巨头们已经看到了神经网络商业潜力的早期证据。2009年，Hinton的研究生们展示了这种软件在语音识别方面表现出色。IBM、微软和谷歌都加入了这股潮流，但谷歌是实现商业化速度最快的。2012年，谷歌将神经网络投入生产，极大地提升了安卓系统的语音识别能力。与此同时，Hinton的更多研究生，这次是Sutskever和Alex Krizhevsky，在ImageNet上取得了突破性的成果，证明了神经网络在图像识别方面也同样出色。安卓系统的成功部署促使谷歌愿意在这三位学者身上投入巨资，标志着科技行业开始全面拥抱深度学习。

Tech giants were already seeing early evidence of the commercial potential of neural networks before the auction of DNNresearch. In 2009, Hinton’s grad students showed that such software was decent at speech recognition. IBM, Microsoft, and Google all jumped on the trend, but Google was the fastest to reach commercialization. In 2012, Google put neural networks into production, greatly improving Android’s speech-recognition capabilities, just as more of Hinton’s grad students, this time Sutskever and Alex Krizhevsky, achieved their breakthrough results at ImageNet, demonstrating that neural networks were also very good at image recognition. The successful Android deployment primed Google’s willingness to spend big on the three academics, marking the start of the tech industry’s full embrace of deep learning.

随后，Hinton、Sutskever 和 Krizhevsky 继续在谷歌内部推广神经网络。他们从将软件应用于一系列其他商业相关的技术问题中获得了动力。他们同时开发深度学习模型，用于机器翻译，升级谷歌翻译；用于文本预测，为 Gmail 添加建议完成功能；以及开发名为 Waymo 的雄心勃勃的全新自动驾驶汽车项目。随着谷歌人工智能业务的持续增长，神经网络也为公司的摇钱树——搜索——带来了至关重要的改进。该软件可以更好地将用户查询与相关网页匹配，为用户提供更高质量的搜索结果，更重要的是，可以精准投放更相关的广告。谷歌的利润越高，投入深度学习的资金越多，其他行业也纷纷效仿。企业迅速超越政府和基金会，成为人工智能的最大资助者。研究，并很快制定了基于可能产生短期盈利能力的进步的研究议程。

Hinton, Sutskever, and Krizhevsky subsequently continued to evangelize neural networks within Google. They found momentum applying their software to a wide array of other commercially relevant technical problems. They worked in parallel to develop deep learning models for machine translation, upgrading Google Translate; for text prediction, adding the suggested completions feature to Gmail; and for an ambitious new self-driving-car project called Waymo. As Google’s AI operations continued to grow, neural networks also produced crucial improvements to the company’s cash cow, search. The software could better match user queries to relevant web pages, delivering users higher-quality search results and, importantly, targeting them with more relevant ads. The more Google profited and the more billions it poured into deep learning, the more the rest of the industry followed. Companies quickly came to dominate over governments and foundations as the biggest funders of AI research and were soon setting the research agenda based on advancements that could also produce short-term profitability.

—

—

深度学习与商业利益的交织，同时改变了科技行业和人工智能发展的面貌。在公众看来，随着 OpenAI 于 2022 年底推出 ChatGPT，生成式人工智能似乎会凭空而来。但从 2012 年到 2022 年，从 ImageNet 的突破开始，正是人工智能商业化第一个重要时代的这些转变，为当今生成式人工智能革命的诸多特征奠定了基础。

The entwining of deep learning with commercial interests simultaneously transformed the tech industry and the face of AI development. To the public, generative AI would erupt seemingly out of nowhere in late 2022 with OpenAI’s launch of ChatGPT. But from 2012 to 2022, beginning with the ImageNet breakthrough, it was these shifts during the first major era of AI commercialization that laid the groundwork for many characteristics of the generative AI revolution today.

对工业界而言，深度学习推动了新产品和新服务的改进和涌现，从更快的信息获取到更高效的电子商务，再到共享经济的兴起。对深度学习而言，工业界推动了神经网络和计算机芯片的新技术突破，从而推动了更大、更强大的人工智能模型的开发。

For industry, deep learning fueled the improvement and emergence of new products and services, from faster access to information to more efficient e-commerce to the rise of the sharing economy. For deep learning, industry drove new technical breakthroughs in neural networks and computer chips that enabled the development of larger and more powerful AI models.

但除了这些令人瞩目的进步之外，深度学习对硅谷的超级充电也将积极扩展其商业模式，哈佛大学教授肖莎娜·祖博夫在 2014 年创造了一个术语来形容这种模式：监控资本主义。工业资本主义从生产人们想要购买的物质商品中获得价值，而祖博夫认为，监控资本主义将其用户视为产品。掌握着海量用户数据的科技巨头可以轻松地将这些宝藏输入神经网络，以比以往更精确地分析用户，并从他们的参与度中榨取广告收入。为了在竞争中胜出，他们可以通过记录每个用户的点击、滚动和点赞的越来越详尽的日志来收集更多的数据，并鼓励他们提供越来越私人的数字物品，包括他们的每一次电子邮件交流、他们孩子的每一张照片以及他们对社会和政治问题的每一个想法。

But alongside these impressive advances, deep learning’s supercharging of Silicon Valley would also aggressively expand its business model, for which Harvard professor Shoshana Zuboff would coin a term in 2014: surveillance capitalism. Where industrial capitalism derived value from producing material goods that people wanted to buy, surveillance capitalism, Zuboff argued, treated its users as the product. Tech giants sitting atop vast amounts of user data could easily pump those troves into neural networks to more precisely profile users than ever before and milk their engagement for ad revenue. To outcompete one another, they could simply collect even more of that data by recording increasingly exhaustive logs of every user’s clicks, scrolls, and likes, and encouraging them to supply increasingly personal digital artifacts, including their every email exchange, every photo of their kids, and every thought they had about social and political issues.

与此同时，硅谷大力发展深度学习，以扩大和巩固全球垄断地位，这也在人工智能开发者中形成了一种文化，即将所有事物都视为数据，被他们的技术所捕获和消耗，以期让它们尽可能多地反映世界。2023年，一组人工智能研究人员，包括斯坦福大学的里亚·卡鲁里、华盛顿大学的威廉·阿格纽和Mozilla基金会的阿贝巴·伯尔哈内，将分析四万多篇计算机视觉论文和专利，并注意到抽象、不连贯的语言被广泛使用，以净化和规范该领域对大规模抓取和提取的依赖。社交媒体上人们思想和想法的详细数字轨迹仅仅是“文本”。图片中的人物和车辆仅仅是“物体”。监控仅仅是“检测”。

At the same time, Silicon Valley’s supercharging of deep learning in its quest to expand and entrench global-scale monopolies also codified a culture among AI developers to view anything and everything as data to be captured and consumed by their technologies in a noble attempt to make them reflect as much of the world as possible. In 2023, a group of AI researchers, including Ria Kalluri at Stanford University, William Agnew from the University of Washington, and Abeba Birhane from the Mozilla Foundation, would analyze more than forty thousand computer-vision papers and patents, and note the pervasive use of abstract, detached language to sanitize and normalize the field’s reliance upon mass scraping and extraction. Detailed digital trails of people’s thoughts and ideas on social media were merely “text.” People and vehicles in pictures were merely “objects.” Surveillance was merely “detection.”

这种文化如今正处于生成人工智能领域一场激烈争论的核心，争论的焦点是科技公司是否可以批量抓取书籍和艺术品来训练他们的人工智能系统。对于许多长期以这种思维方式运作的人工智能开发者来说，这个问题似乎有些古怪；认真对待它会直接阻碍追求更大进步的道德追求。即使他们中的一些人已经越来越意识到并担心他们的观点与许多持反对态度的作家和艺术家的观点之间的鸿沟，但这种思维方式仍然难以摆脱。2023 年 5 月，一群艺术家首次就几位生成人工智能开发者盗窃其作品一事提起诉讼后不久，我作为《华尔街日报》的记者参加了在卢旺达举行的一次人工智能研究会议。当我走在首都闪闪发光的圆顶会议中心的拱形大厅时，一位高级研究员拦住了我，问我名牌上的《华尔街日报》是一家新创业公司还是一家媒体出版物。当我澄清自己是记者，并且“华尔街日报”确实是“The Wall Street Journal”的缩写时，另一位高级研究员插嘴道：“我是通过WSJ数据集认出来的，”她指的是早期人工智能语音识别数据集，里面记录了人们朗读报纸摘录的内容。“我用过很多次了。”

That culture is now at the crux of a raging debate in generative AI over whether tech companies can scrape books and artwork wholesale to train their AI systems. To many AI developers who have long operated under this mindset, that question seems rather quaint; taking it seriously presents a direct obstacle to the moral pursuit of ever-more progress. Even as some of them have grown more aware of and concerned by the chasm between their perspective and the view of many authors and artists who stand in opposition, this way of thinking has been difficult to shake. In May 2023, shortly after a group of artists filed suit for the first time against several generative AI developers over the theft of their artwork, I went to an AI research conference in Rwanda as a reporter for The Wall Street Journal. As I walked the vaulted hall of the glistening dome-shaped convention center in the country’s capital, a senior researcher stopped me and asked me whether the WSJ on my name badge was a new startup or the media publication. When I clarified that I was a journalist and it indeed stood for The Wall Street Journal, another senior researcher chimed in. “I recognized it because of the WSJ dataset,” she said, referring to an early AI speech-recognition dataset of people reading excerpts from the newspaper. “I’ve worked with it many times.”

2018年我刚开始报道人工智能的时候，就发现自己也陷入了同样的思维模式。在学会了人工智能领域的专业术语，并与人工智能研究人员交流沟通后，我惊叹于研究人员挖掘和生成数据集的千差万别。我认为一个特别巧妙的例子是，研究人员使用了数千个YouTube视频2016 年病毒式传播的人体模型挑战赛，参赛者在摄像机在他们周围摇摄和变焦时，身体静止不动，以此训练人工智能模型来处理三维场景。

I found myself entrapped in this very same thinking when I first began covering AI in 2018. After internalizing the community’s lingo to speak and relate with AI researchers, I marveled at the myriad ways that researchers mined for and produced datasets. In one example I thought was particularly clever, researchers used thousands of YouTube videos of the viral 2016 Mannequin Challenge, where people froze in place as cameras panned and zoomed around them, to train up AI models for processing three-dimensional scenes.

2019年，奥利维亚·索伦（Olivia Solon）在NBC的一项调查彻底粉碎了我的乐观主义。索伦揭露，面部识别软件未经用户同意，就利用数百万用户的个人Flickr照片进行了训练。令我惊讶的并非调查结果——我早就知道Flickr是人工智能研究人员最喜爱的数据来源。让我惊讶的是，我竟然已经完全视其为常态。

In 2019, an NBC investigation from Olivia Solon knocked off my rose-colored glasses. Solon revealed that facial-recognition software had been trained on millions of people’s personal Flickr photos without their consent. What surprised me was not the findings—I had long known that Flickr was a favorite data source for AI researchers. What surprised me was how much I had come to view that as completely normal.

有了新的认识，我开始注意到积极收集更多训练数据是如何导致不仅在数字世界而且在物理世界中都出现普遍监控的。我还注意到，这种物理监控的目光似乎一再落在本已脆弱的群体身上，包括儿童或历史上被边缘化的群体，在发展中国家尤其如此。那一年，我偶然发现了一家位于马萨诸塞州、哈佛大学孵化的初创公司，该公司销售人工智能头带，声称可以测量学生的脑电波活动，从而告诉老师孩子是否集中注意力。这家初创公司正在哥伦比亚和中国的小学试点这种产品，以换取使用学生数据来推进公司技术的权利。

With new awareness, I began to notice how the aggressive push to collect more training data was leading to pervasive surveillance not just in the digital world but the physical one as well. I noticed, too, how the gaze of that physical surveillance seemed to repeatedly fall on already vulnerable populations, including children or historically marginalized groups, even more so in developing countries. That year, I stumbled across a Massachusetts-based, Harvard-incubated startup selling AI-powered headbands that said it could measure a student’s brain wave activity to tell a teacher whether or not the child was focused. The startup was piloting them in elementary schools in Colombia and China, in exchange for the rights to use their students’ data to advance the company’s technology.

““我们拥有先发优势，”该公司一位研究科学家在2017年的一次教育技术会议上表示。“我们将能够建立世界上最大的脑电波数据库之一。所有这些数据将帮助我们改进算法，从而改进我们的产品，从而提高进入门槛。”

“We have the first mover’s advantage,” a research scientist at the company had said at an education technology conference in 2017. “We’ll be able to build one of the largest brain wave databases in the world. All that data will help us improve our algorithms and therefore our products, creating a higher barrier to entry.”

在我接触这家初创公司几个月后，中国家长们对数据隐私的强烈抗议迫使该公司转向了其技术的其他应用领域。他们担心自己的孩子会被当作实验对象，这迫使该公司转向了其他应用领域。但这个故事让我感到不安，这种成功的反响只是个例，而该公司最初的做法——去那些渴望接受这项技术前景的国家寻找数据捐赠者和产品测试者——实际上是一种趋势。

A few months after I came across the startup, a data privacy outcry in China from parents horrified at their kids being turned into guinea pigs forced the company to pivot to a different application of its technology. But the story left me with an uneasy feeling that the successful backlash was an anomaly, and the company’s original approach—to go to countries eager to embrace the promise of technology for finding data donors and product testers—was in fact a trend.

当我向一位同事讲述我的担忧时，她向我介绍了一位已经为这一现象创造了一个短语：“数据殖民主义”。我发现了学者尼克·库尔德里 (Nick Couldry) 和尤利西斯·A·梅希亚斯 (Ulises A. Mejias) 的著作，他们同年出版的奠基性著作《连接的成本》 (The Costs of Connection)指出，硅谷对一切事物的普遍数据化正在导致令人不安的征服和掠夺主义历史模式的回归。[*] 第二年，DeepMind 的 Shakir Mohamed 和 William Isaac 与牛津大学的 Marie-Therese Png 共同发表了一篇名为“去殖民化人工智能”的论文，进一步证实了我已经开始产生的怀疑：人工智能行业在数据化的推动下，又反过来进一步加速了这种新的殖民主义。

As I recounted this worry to a colleague, she introduced me to a phrase that had already been coined for the phenomenon: “data colonialism.” I discovered the work of scholars Nick Couldry and Ulises A. Mejias, whose foundational text The Costs of Connection, published just that year, argued that Silicon Valley’s pervasive datafication of everything was leading to a return of disturbing historical patterns of conquest and extractivism.[*] The following year, a paper called “Decolonial AI” from Shakir Mohamed and William Isaac at DeepMind and Marie-Therese Png at the University of Oxford reinforced a suspicion I had begun to develop: The AI industry, in equal parts fueled by and fueling this datafication, was in turn accelerating that new colonialism further.

不久之后，到了2021年，我发现这家人工智能教育初创公司在南非也出现了同样的动态。世界各地的人脸识别公司争相在南非站稳脚跟，收集宝贵的人脸数据，尤其是在该行业因其产品无法准确识别深色皮肤人群而受到严厉批评之后。我遇到了一位当地活动家，塔米·恩科西 (Thami Nkosi)，他出生并成长于约翰内斯堡最贫穷的街区之一，那里曾经是采矿业的化学废料堆。他向我展示了遍布城市街道的数千台摄像头，并向我描述了这些摄像头如何限制黑人的行动。黑人早已饱受种族隔离遗留问题的压迫，仅仅因为身处白人社区，他们就害怕被定罪。

Not long after, in 2021, I found the same dynamics of the AI education startup playing out in South Africa. Facial recognition companies from all over the world were jostling to get a foothold in the country to collect valuable face data, especially after the industry had received significant criticism about their products’ failures to accurately detect darker-skinned individuals. I met a local activist, Thami Nkosi, who was born and raised in one of the poorest neighborhoods in Johannesburg, which used to be a chemical waste dump for the mining industry. He showed me the thousands of cameras dotting the city’s sprawling streets and described to me the ways it was restricting the movements of Black people, already squeezed by the racial legacies of apartheid and in fear of being criminalized, simply for being Black in a white neighborhood.

“他们本质上是将公共空间和公共生活货币化，”恩科西说。

“They’re essentially monetizing public spaces and public life,” Nkosi said.

随着我越来越清晰地认识到，这场充满希望的革命为每个人带来更美好的未来，却让社会边缘的人们重拾过去最黑暗的残余。

With increasing clarity, I realized that the very revolution promising to bring everyone a better future was instead, for people on the margins of society, reviving the darkest remnants of the past.

—

—

然而，即使硅谷的人工智能理念揭示了其挑战，人工智能商业化的第一个时代也扼杀了其他替代方案。随着企业向深度学习和联结主义投入前所未有的资金，盖过了所有其他资金来源，它们围绕自己的优先事项重塑了研究格局。

But even as Silicon Valley’s conception of AI revealed its challenges, the first era of AI commercialization also choked off alternatives. As companies pumped unprecedented sums into deep learning and connectionism, overshadowing all other sources of funding, they remade the landscape of research around their priorities.

根据斯坦福大学人工智能指数，从2013年到2022年，企业在人工智能领域的投资（例如并购）从146亿美元飙升至2350亿美元，并在2021年达到3374亿美元的峰值。这些数字甚至还不包括公司内部的研发支出。2021年，Alphabet和Meta分别支出316亿美元和247亿美元。相比之下，美国政府在2021年拨款15亿美元用于非国防人工智能发展。欧盟委员会同年拨款10亿欧元（12亿美元）。

From 2013 to 2022, corporate investments in AI, such as mergers and acquisitions, shot up from $14.6 billion to $235 billion, peaking at $337.4 billion in 2021, according to the Stanford University AI Index. Those numbers don’t even include in-house company spending on research and development. In 2021, Alphabet and Meta spent $31.6 billion and $24.7 billion, respectively. By contrast, the US government allocated $1.5 billion in 2021 to nondefense AI development. The European Commission allocated €1 billion ($1.2 billion) the same year.

金钱追随着人才。许多教授被神经网络的出色成果和更容易获得企业资助的优势所吸引，重新调整了他们的研究方向。许多大学生和研究生也纷纷效仿，原因是深度学习的工作稳定性以及其他方法中越来越少的职业发展道路。企业也制定了各种安排，加深与学术界的融合。2013 年，Hinton 加入谷歌，条件是同时保留他在多伦多大学的职位。第二年，Facebook 与 Hinton 的前博士后、纽约大学教授 Yann LeCun 达成了同样的协议。他们后来与蒙特利尔大学教授 Yoshua Bengio 共同获得了 2018 年图灵奖，该奖通常被称为“计算机界的诺贝尔奖”，以表彰他们在深度学习领域的奠基性工作。这项荣誉为这三人赢得了“人工智能教父”的称号。Hinton 还将与另一位科学家一起在 2024 年获得真正的诺贝尔奖。追随Hinton和LeCun的脚步，许多人工智能教授开始同时在公司和大学保持双重身份。这种做法规模化发展，开始侵蚀真正独立研究的界限。

Talent followed the money. Many professors re-formed their research around neural networks, drawn in by their strong results as well as greater access to corporate funding. Many college and graduate students did the same, guided by the job security of deep learning and the diminishing viable career paths in other methods. Companies also fostered various arrangements that deepened their integration with academia. In 2013, Hinton joined Google on the condition that he simultaneously keep his position at the University of Toronto. Facebook struck the same deal the following year with Yann LeCun, a former postdoc of Hinton’s and a professor at New York University. Both would later share the 2018 Turing Award, often called the “Nobel Prize of Computing,” with Yoshua Bengio, a professor at the Université de Montréal, for their foundational work in deep learning. The accolade would earn the trio the moniker “godfathers of AI.” Hinton would also go on to win an actual Nobel Prize in 2024 with another scientist. Following in Hinton’s and LeCun’s footsteps, many AI professors began to maintain dual affiliations with a company and university. At scale, the practice began to erode the boundaries of truly independent research.

越来越多的研究人员也离开了学术界。根据麻省理工学院研究人员 2023 年在《科学》杂志上发表的一项研究，从 2006 年到 2020 年，人工智能研究教师流向工业界的人数增加了 8 倍；从 2004 年到 2020 年，进入企业的人工智能博士毕业生比例从 21% 跃升至 70% 。许多人最初是被天文数字般的报酬吸引而来的，经验丰富的研究人员的报酬每年可达到 100 万美元。2015年，Uber在卡内基梅隆大学设立了分支机构，并向一些科学家提供了相当于其大学薪水两倍的薪酬，结果从该大学一个实验室挖走了100名人工智能研究人员中的40人。随着时间的推移，另一个原因导致了人员流失：深度学习研究成本的不断上升。大学再也无力承担在人工智能发展最热门领域开展工作所需的计算机芯片和电力。因此，同一项《2023年科学》研究发现，在短短三年内，从2017年到2020年，全球最佳人工智能模型中，与行业相关的模型所占比例从62%增长到惊人的91%。

Increasingly, more researchers also left academia altogether. From 2006 to 2020, the exodus to industry among AI research faculty increased eightfold; from 2004 to 2020, AI PhD graduates heading to corporations jumped from 21 percent to 70 percent, according to a 2023 study in Science from MIT researchers. Many were initially whisked away by the astronomical compensation, which for seasoned researchers could reach $1 million a year. In 2015, Uber infamously poached forty out of one hundred AI researchers from a single lab at Carnegie Mellon University after setting up shop in town and offering some scientists double their university salaries. Over time, another reason fed into the attrition: the growing costliness of deep learning research. Universities could no longer afford the computer chips or the electricity needed to work in the hottest areas of AI development. As such, the same 2023 Science study found that in just three years, from 2017 to 2020, industry-affiliated models grew from 62 percent to a whopping 91 percent of the world’s best-performing AI models.

在人工智能商业化的第一个十年中期，大多数顶级人工智能研究都在科技公司内部或与科技公司相关的学术实验室中进行。在另一项研究中，Kalluri、Agnew、Birhane 和其他同事发现，2018 年和 2019 年，55% 最具影响力的人工智能研究论文至少有一位行业合著者。而十年前这一比例仅为 24%。研究成果也高度集中在少数几家公司内部。同一时期，微软和谷歌等科技巨头在企业关联论文中所占份额增长了两倍多，达到 66%。讽刺的是，这正是马斯克和 Altman 想要创办 OpenAI 的原因。科技行业的利润驱动力已成为推动人工智能发展的压倒性力量。

Midway through the first decade of AI commercialization, most top-level AI research was now happening within or in academic labs connected to tech companies. In another study, Kalluri, Agnew, Birhane, and other colleagues found that 55 percent of the most influential AI research papers had at least one industry coauthor in 2018 and 2019. This was compared with 24 percent a decade earlier. The research had also consolidated heavily within just a few corporations. Over the same decade, tech giants such as Microsoft and Google more than tripled their share of corporate-affiliated papers, to 66 percent. Ironically, this was precisely the reason Musk and Altman said they wanted to start OpenAI. The tech industry’s profit motive had become the overwhelming force driving AI development.

—

—

第一个时代，资金和人才的整合显著缩小了人工智能研究领域的思想多样性。深度学习之所以继续占据主导地位，不仅是因为它的科学价值，还因为很少有人投入资金去探索和推进其他范式。事实上，尽管神经网络是非凡的发明，尽管它们有无数令人兴奋的用途，但它们的弱点——即它们存储准确信息和推理的方式备受争议且效率低下——随着公司将它们部署到越来越多的环境和应用程序中，它们仍然存在。

The impact of this consolidation of funding and talent in the first era significantly narrowed the diversity of ideas in AI research. Deep learning continued to reign supreme not just for its scientific merit but also because very little investment went into exploring and advancing other paradigms. Indeed, while neural networks are remarkable inventions with myriad exciting uses, their weaknesses—namely, their hotly contested and inefficient ways of storing accurate information and reasoning—have endured as companies have deployed them in an expanding list of contexts and applications.

例如，神经网络已被证明可能不可靠且难以预测。作为统计模式匹配器，它们有时会追踪到一些奇怪的特定模式，甚至完全错误的模式。深度学习模型可能仅通过人行横道识别行人，而无法识别乱穿马路的人。它可能会学会将停车标志与路边联系起来，而忽略校车侧面伸出的停车标志或被过街警卫拦住的标志。神经网络对训练数据的变化也非常敏感。给它们输入一组不同的行人图像或一组不同的停车标志图像，它们就会学会一整套新的关联。但这些变化是难以捉摸的。打开深度学习模型的外壳，里面只有高度抽象的数字链。这就是研究人员称深度学习为“黑匣子”的原因。他们无法准确解释模型的行为方式，尤其是在奇怪的边缘情况下，因为模型计算出的模式人类无法辨认。

Neural networks have shown, for example, that they can be unreliable and unpredictable. As statistical pattern matchers, they sometimes home in on oddly specific patterns or completely incorrect ones. A deep learning model might recognize pedestrians only by the crosswalks underneath them and fail to register a person who is jaywalking. It might learn to associate a stop sign with being on the side of the road and miss the same sign extended on the side of a school bus or being held by a crossing guard. Neural networks are also highly sensitive to changes in their training data. Feed them a different set of pedestrian images, or a different set of stop sign images, and they will learn a whole new set of associations. But those changes are inscrutable. Pop open the hood of a deep learning model and inside are only highly abstracted daisy chains of numbers. This is what researchers mean when they call deep learning “a black box.” They cannot explain exactly how the model will behave, especially in strange edge-case scenarios, because the patterns that the model has computed are not legible to humans.

这导致了危险的后果。2018年3月，一辆Uber自动驾驶汽车在亚利桑那州坦佩撞死了49岁的伊莱恩·赫茨伯格，这是有史以来首例自动驾驶汽车致行人死亡的事故。调查发现，该汽车的深度学习模型根本没有将赫茨伯格识别为人类。专家得出结论，这是因为她推着一辆装满购物袋的自行车穿过指定人行横道外的马路——这是教科书上对极端情况的定义。六年后，即 2024 年 4 月，美国国家公路交通安全管理局发现，特斯拉的自动驾驶仪发生了 200 多起车祸，造成 14 人死亡，原因是基于深度学习的系统未能感知周围环境并做出反应，而驾驶员未能及时接管并超越它。

This has led to dangerous outcomes. In March 2018, a self-driving Uber killed forty-nine-year-old Elaine Herzberg in Tempe, Arizona, in the first ever recorded incident of an autonomous vehicle causing a pedestrian fatality. Investigations found that the car’s deep learning model simply didn’t register Herzberg as a person. Experts concluded that it was because she was pushing a bicycle loaded with shopping bags across the road outside the designated crosswalk—the textbook definition of an edge-case scenario. Six years later, in April 2024, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration found that Tesla’s Autopilot had been involved in more than two hundred crashes, including fourteen fatalities, in which the deep learning–based system failed to register and react to its surroundings and the driver failed to take over in time to override it.

神经网络的易错且难以捉摸的统计模式也可能成为安全漏洞。2019 年，白帽黑客诱骗一辆处于自动驾驶模式的特斯拉汽车转向对面车道。他们所做的只是在道路上放置一系列小贴纸，以欺骗汽车的深度学习模型，使其失灵，将错误的车道识别为正确的车道。此类漏洞并不仅限于物理系统或计算机视觉模型。加州大学伯克利分校教授 Dawn Song 专门研究这一被称为“对抗性攻击”的研究领域，他的研究表明，向语言模型输入正确的信息会导致其吐出信用卡号等敏感数据。

The fallible and inscrutable statistical patterns of neural networks can also turn into a security vulnerability. In 2019, white hat hackers tricked a Tesla in self-driving mode into veering into an incoming lane of traffic. All they did was place a series of tiny stickers on the road to fool the car’s deep learning model into misfiring and registering the wrong lane as the right one. Such vulnerabilities aren’t limited to physical systems or computer-vision models. Dawn Song, a professor at the University of California, Berkeley, who specializes in this area of research, known as “adversarial attacks,” showed that prompting a language model with the right message caused it to spit out sensitive data such as credit card numbers.

出于同样的原因，深度学习模型也受到歧视模式的困扰，有时这些模式多年来一直未被注意到。2019 年，佐治亚理工学院的研究人员发现，用于检测行人的最佳模型在检测深色皮肤行人时的准确率要低 4% 到 10%。2024年，北京大学和伦敦大学学院等几所大学的研究人员发现，目前最新的模型对不同肤色的行人识别性能相对匹配，但在检测儿童方面的准确率比检测成年人的准确率低20%以上，因为儿童在模型的训练数据中的代表性很差。

For the same reasons, deep learning models have been plagued by discriminatory patterns that have sometimes stayed unnoticed for years. In 2019, researchers at the Georgia Institute of Technology found that the best models for detecting pedestrians were between 4 and 10 percent less accurate at detecting darker-skinned pedestrians. In 2024, researchers at Peking University and several other universities, including University College London, found that the most up-to-date models now had relatively matched performance for pedestrians with different skin colors but were more than 20 percent less accurate at detecting children than adults, because children had been poorly represented in the models’ training data.

事实上，深度学习模型天生就容易产生歧视性的影响，因为它们会拾取并放大海量训练数据中哪怕最微小的不平衡。这不仅在某个群体代表性不足时是个问题，在某个群体代表性过高时也同样是个问题。黛博拉·拉吉（Deborah Raji）是伯克利大学人工智能问责研究员，也是尼日利亚裔加拿大人。职业生涯早期，她在一家名为Clarifai的人工智能初创公司实习。该公司当时正在构建一个深度学习模型，用于检测“不适合工作场合”的图片。拉吉发现，该模型对有色人种的标记比例过高，因为该公司用来训练模型判断哪些图片存在问题的图片，比用来训练模型判断哪些图片可接受的图片库图片中，有色人种的占比更高。这一令人震惊的发现促使拉吉和蒂姆尼特·格布鲁一样，对人工智能发展的主导方向提出了严峻的质疑。

In fact, deep learning models are inherently prone to having discriminatory impacts because they pick up and amplify even the tiniest imbalances present in huge volumes of training data. It’s not just a problem when a demographic is poorly represented, but when it’s overrepresented as well. Early in her career, Deborah Raji, the Berkeley AI accountability researcher, who is Nigerian Canadian, interned at an AI startup called Clarifai that was building a deep learning model for detecting images that were “not safe for work.” The model disproportionately flagged people of color because, Raji discovered, they were more represented in the pornographic images that the company was using to teach the model what was problematic than the stock photos it was using to teach the model what was acceptable. It was a shocking realization that would push Raji, like Timnit Gebru, to severely question the dominant direction of AI development.

2010年代末到2020年代初，随着深度学习的挑战日益凸显，关于如何最好地克服这些挑战的激烈争论再次出现。如同符号学派和联结学派之间的冲突一样，不同阵营的研究者对于是否存在彻底摆脱神经网络局限性的方法，或者是否只能通过一些“创可贴”式的补救措施来缓解这些局限性，持有激烈的分歧。

In the late 2010s and early 2020s, as the challenges of deep learning grew more apparent, fierce debates reemerged over the best way to overcome them. Much like the clashes between symbolists and connectionists, different camps of researchers disagreed vehemently about whether there would ever be a way to rid neural networks of their limitations entirely, or whether there would only be Band-Aid fixes that merely mitigated them.

Hinton 和 Sutskever 继续坚定地支持深度学习。他们认为，深度学习的缺陷并非源于方法本身，而是由于神经网络设计不完善以及训练数据和计算能力有限所致。总有一天，当两者兼备，并被输入到更强大的神经网络中时，深度学习模型应该能够彻底摆脱上述问题。“人脑大约有 100 万亿个参数，或者说突触，”辛顿在 2020 年告诉我。“我们现在所说的真正大的模型，比如 GPT-3，有 1750 亿个。它比大脑小一千倍。

Hinton and Sutskever continued to staunchly champion deep learning. Its flaws, they argued, are not inherent to the approach itself. Rather they are the artifacts of imperfect neural-network design as well as limited training data and compute. Some day with enough of both, fed into even better neural networks, deep learning models should be able to completely shed the aforementioned problems. “The human brain has about 100 trillion parameters, or synapses,” Hinton told me in 2020. “What we now call a really big model, like GPT-3, has 175 billion. It’s a thousand times smaller than the brain.

他说：“深度学习将能够做一切事情。”

“Deep learning is going to be able to do everything,” he said.

他们当代的对手是纽约大学心理学和神经科学名誉教授加里·马库斯 (Gary Marcus)，他将于 2023 年 5 月与萨姆·奥尔特曼一起在国会作证。四年前，马库斯与人合著了一本名为《重启人工智能》的书，声称这些问题是深度学习所固有的。神经网络永远停留在相关性领域，无论有多少数据或计算，都无法理解因果关系 - 事物为什么会这样 - 从而进行因果推理。马库斯认为，人类认知的这一关键部分就是为什么人类只需要学习一个城市的交通规则，就能够在许多其他城市熟练驾驶的原因。相比之下，特斯拉的自动驾驶仪可以记录数十亿英里的驾驶数据，但在遇到不熟悉的场景时仍然会崩溃，或者被一些策略性放置的贴纸所欺骗。马库斯主张结合联结主义和符号主义，这是一种被称为神经符号人工智能的研究方向。专家系统可以通过编程理解因果关系并擅长推理，弥补了深度学习的不足。深度学习可以快速地用数据或代表那些难以用规则来编纂的东西，填补了专家系统的空白。”“我们实际上需要这两种方法，”马库斯告诉我。

Their modern-day nemesis was Gary Marcus, a professor emeritus of psychology and neural science at New York University, who would testify in Congress next to Sam Altman in May 2023. Four years earlier, Marcus coauthored a book called Rebooting AI, asserting that these issues were inherent to deep learning. Forever stuck in the realm of correlations, neural networks would never, with any amount of data or compute, be able to understand causal relationships—why things are the way they are—and thus perform causal reasoning. This critical part of human cognition is why humans need only learn the rules of the road in one city to be able to drive proficiently in many others, Marcus argued. Tesla’s Autopilot, by contrast, can log billions of miles of driving data and still crash when encountering unfamiliar scenarios or be fooled with a few strategically placed stickers. Marcus advocated instead for combining connectionism and symbolism, a strain of research known as neurosymbolic AI. Expert systems can be programmed to understand causal relationships and excel at reasoning, shoring up the shortcomings of deep learning. Deep learning can rapidly update the system with data or represent things that are difficult to codify in rules, plugging the gaps of expert systems. “We actually need both approaches,” Marcus told me.

然而，尽管科学界的争论愈演愈烈，人工智能开发的资金却几乎全部流向了纯粹的联结主义方向。马库斯对神经符号人工智能潜力的预测是否正确，这无关紧要；更大的根本问题是，用于积极探索这种可能性以及深度学习其他替代方案的科学环境正在逐渐萎缩和弱化。

Despite the heated scientific conflict, however, the funding for AI development has continued to accelerate almost exclusively in the pure connectionist direction. Whether or not Marcus is right about the potential of neurosymbolic AI is beside the point; the bigger root issue has been the whittling down and weakening of a scientific environment for robustly exploring that possibility and other alternatives to deep learning.

对于辛顿、萨茨克弗和马库斯来说，企业资金与人工智能开发之间的紧密关系也影响了他们自身的职业生涯。在谷歌全力支持辛顿和萨茨克弗后不久，马库斯于2014年与他人共同创立了自己的公司，名为Geometric Intelligence。两年后，这家初创公司被优步收购，用于组建人工智能实验室。但在2020年，优步IPO后，优步裁撤了该部门。Geometric Intelligence的几位创始成员随后加入了OpenAI，他们从神经符号学研究转向了深度学习。

For Hinton, Sutskever, and Marcus, the tight relationship between corporate funding and AI development also affected their own careers. Not long after Google put its full weight behind Hinton and Sutskever, Marcus cofounded his own company, called Geometric Intelligence, in 2014. The startup was acquired by Uber two years later to build out an AI lab, but in 2020, after the ride-hailing firm’s IPO, it axed the division. Several original members of Geometric Intelligence subsequently joined OpenAI, where they switched from working on neurosymbolic advancements to deep learning.

多年来，马库斯一直是 OpenAI 最大的批评者之一，他撰写了大量文章，驳斥 OpenAI 的研究，并在社交媒体上嘲笑其失误。员工们在公司 Slack 上创建了他的表情符号，以便在他谴责之后鼓舞士气，或者在其他时候用作笑料。2022 年 3 月，马库斯为Nautilus撰写了一篇题为《深度学习正在碰壁》的文章，重申了他的观点：OpenAI 全力投入深度学习的做法将导致其无法实现真正的人工智能进步。一个月后，OpenAI 发布了 DALL-E 2，引起了巨大反响，布罗克曼则在推特上调侃了一张 DALL-E 2 生成的图像，并配文“深度学习正在碰壁”。第二天，阿尔特曼又发了一条推文：“给我一个平庸的深度学习怀疑论者的信心……”许多 OpenAI 员工都很高兴终于有机会报复马库斯了。

Over the years, Marcus would become one of the biggest critics of OpenAI, writing detailed takedowns of its research and jeering its missteps on social media. Employees created an emoji of him on the company Slack to lift up morale after his denouncements and to otherwise use as a punch line. In March 2022, Marcus wrote a piece for Nautilus titled “Deep Learning Is Hitting a Wall,” repeating his argument that OpenAI’s all-in approach to deep learning would lead it to fall short of true AI advancements. A month later, OpenAI released DALL-E 2 to immense fanfare, and Brockman cheekily tweeted a DALL-E 2–generated image using the prompt “deep learning hitting a wall.” The following day, Altman followed with another tweet: “Give me the confidence of a mediocre deep learning skeptic…” Many OpenAI employees relished the chance to finally get back at Marcus.

—

—

生成式人工智能是 OpenAI 愿景的产物，如果没有人工智能商业化的初代发展，生成式人工智能就不可能出现。生成式人工智能模型是经过训练的深度学习模型，用于生成其数据的复本。输入。从旧文本中，它们学习合成新文本；从旧图像中，它们学习合成新图像。但为了达到足够高的保真度以变得像人类一样，OpenAI 认为这是其追求 AGI 的关键，它们接受了比以往任何时候都多的数据和计算训练。因此，生成式人工智能是深度学习的最大化形式。它由第一时代完善的尖端软件和硬件创新所实现。它以通过监控资本主义积累的爆炸式数据宝库为食。它受到人工智能研究文化的推动和教唆，这种文化将尽可能多地消费数据视为其道德责任。生成式人工智能现在也在进一步推动这些现象。

Generative AI, the product of OpenAI’s vision, could not have emerged without the first era of AI commercialization. Generative AI models are deep learning models trained to generate reproductions of their data inputs. From old text, they learn to synthesize new text; from old images, they learn to synthesize new images. But to do so at high-enough fidelity to become humanlike, which OpenAI says is key in its quest for AGI, they are trained on more data and compute than have ever been used before. Generative AI is thus the maximalist form of deep learning. It is enabled by the cutting-edge software and hardware innovations refined during the first era. It feeds on the exploding troves of data amassed through surveillance capitalism. It is fueled and abetted by the culture of AI research that views consuming as much data as possible as its moral responsibility. Generative AI is now also pushing each of these phenomena even further.

2022 年 11 月，ChatGPT 的发布令人瞩目，超越了以往任何技术，这得益于 OpenAI 的愿景：将深度学习推向前所未有的规模。凭借雄厚的资金和资源，OpenAI 积极推进这一愿景，大幅扩展其模型，甚至触及数据、计算和能源方面的极限。ChatGPT 在市场营销和包装方面也进行了创新。它与历史上另一个最引人注目的人工智能演示 ELIZA 共享一个类人聊天机器人的展示，这并非巧合。人类心理学自然而然地将智能，甚至意识，与任何看似与我们对话的事物联系起来。ELIZA 无意中主导了早期人工智能的流行概念，而 OpenAI 则在公众中煽动了 ChatGPT 与通用人工智能 (AGI) 之间的联系。2023 年 2 月，在 ChatGPT 炒作达到顶峰之际，该公司以 Altman 的名义发表了一篇博客文章，题为“规划 AGI 及未来”。其暗示 ChatGPT 已向通用人工智能迈出了大胆的一步。

What made ChatGPT in November 2022 appear as such a stunning leapfrog ahead of anything that had come before was OpenAI’s vision to push deep learning to this unprecedented scale. With its sheer money and resources, OpenAI executed that vision aggressively, exploding its models so much that it would begin to hit the limits—in data, compute, and energy—of what the world has available. ChatGPT was also an innovation in marketing and packaging. It is not a coincidence that it shares the same presentation as a humanlike chatbot with one of the other most compelling demonstrations of AI in history, ELIZA. Human psychology naturally leads us to associate intelligence, even consciousness, with anything that appears to speak to us. And where ELIZA inadvertently came to dominate the early popular conception of AI, OpenAI has fanned the public association now between ChatGPT and AGI. In February 2023, at the height of ChatGPT hype, the company published a blog post under Altman’s name titled “Planning for AGI and Beyond.” The implication by proximity was that ChatGPT had taken a bold step toward artificial general intelligence.

事实上，与智能的类比再次将这项技术拟人化，并夸大了其能力。尽管辛顿和其他深度学习绝对论者预测，神经网络与人类相比的不足之处会在足够规模的情况下消失，但事实上，这些挑战仍然存在，而且据许多人称，只会愈演愈烈。

In reality, the analogies to intelligence are once again anthropomorphizing and exaggerating the capabilities of the technology. While Hinton and other deep learning absolutists predicted that the shortfalls of neural networks compared with humans would go away at sufficient scale, the challenges have in fact persisted and, by many accounts, only gotten worse.

生成式人工智能模型仍然不可靠且难以预测。即使图像生成器已经变得更加逼真，它们仍可能以怪异的方式犯错，例如在手上添加额外的手指或生成动物杂交图像。虽然文本生成器变得更加健谈和自然，但它们在最基本的任务上也会出错，例如命名包含特定字母的单词，并且可能会得出意想不到的答案。当微软在必应上推出基于 OpenAI GPT-4 版本构建的新聊天功能时，《纽约时报》专栏作家 Kevin Roose 与该机器人聊了两个多小时。随着对话越来越怪异，机器人最终陷入了反复宣称“我爱上你”并敦促 Roose 与妻子分手的循环。许多其他用户报告称，该搜索引擎会生成侮辱性和情感操纵性的回复。在 Roose 发布他的对话后的第二天，微软将必应的每次会话回复限制为五条，称超过十五条用户提示的长时间聊天会话属于极端情况，会使模型的行为更难预测和控制。毕竟，这样的系统是在互联网上训练的，充斥着许多边缘亚文化和阴暗角落。你探索的时间越长，就越有可能发现它从训练数据中学习到的模式。

Generative AI models are still unreliable and unpredictable. Even as image generators have grown more photorealistic, they can make mistakes in eerie and strange ways, such as by adding extra fingers to hands or producing hybrids of animals. While text generators have grown chattier and more natural, they flub on the most elementary of tasks, such as naming words that contain specific letters, and can veer into unexpected answers. When Microsoft unveiled its new chat feature on Bing, built on a version of OpenAI’s GPT-4, New York Times columnist Kevin Roose chatted with the bot for more than two hours. As the conversation grew weirder and weirder, the bot finally entered a loop of repeatedly declaring “I’m in love with you” and urging Roose to break up with his wife. Many other users reported the search engine generating insulting and emotionally manipulative responses. The day after Roose published his exchange, Microsoft limited Bing to five replies per session, saying that long chat sessions with more than fifteen user prompts were edge-case scenarios that made the model’s behavior more difficult to anticipate and control. After all, such systems are trained on the internet, replete with its many fringe subcultures and dark corners. The longer you probe, the more likely you are to hit upon the patterns it learned from those parts of its training data.
