At YC, Altman pushed his fellow partners to keep growing the number of companies it funded by 10x. “And we will, over time, figure out how to get another 10x and then another 10x after that,” Altman later said of his strategy at an event. “Someday we will fund all the companies in the world.” “Sam was the first person I ever heard say that, because of the work the original founders had done, and because of the brand that YC had created, we were in fact a de facto monopoly in this space,” says Geoff Ralston, Altman’s YC successor.

在 OpenAI，奥特曼计划采用同样的策略。他在 2019 年底发给公司的一份备忘录中阐述了他的长期愿景，强调 OpenAI 需要在 2020 年底之前在四个类别中“成为第一”：技术成果、计算、资金（用于获取更多计算）和准备，即组织的安全性及其对高压情况的适应力。

At OpenAI, Altman planned to use the same strategy. In a memo he sent to the company in late 2019 to articulate his long-term vision, he emphasized that OpenAI needed to “be number one” in four categories by the end of 2020: technical results, compute, money (to acquire more compute), and preparation, meaning the safety and security of the organization as well as its resilience to high-stress situations.

他说，其中最重要的是第一个。如果OpenAI想要有机会完成其使命，它需要首先构建有益的AGI，或者成为足以影响AGI发展的领导者。“尽管理论上我们可以放慢能力建设的速度，”他写道，指的是推进技术成果，“考虑到其他人的进步速度，如果我们想在 AGI 方面拥有很大的影响力，我们很可能需要在技术进步方面采取非常迅速的行动。”随着越来越多的竞争对手了解 OpenAI 的战略并进入该领域，这一点只会变得越来越真实。

The most important of these was the first one, he said. If OpenAI wanted a chance at fulfilling its mission, it needed to build beneficial AGI first, or be such a leader that it could still shape AGI development. “Though we in theory could slow down capability work,” he wrote, referring to advancing technical results, “given the rate of progress other people are making, we likely are required to move very quickly on technical progress if we want to have a lot of influence over AGI.” This would only become increasingly true as more and more competitors caught on to OpenAI’s strategy and moved into the space.

他在备忘录后面补充道：“我们还需要更多十倍的飞跃才能达到通用人工智能。我们应该始终努力实现显著的成果，而不是循序渐进的改进。”

“We still need many more 10x leaps to get to AGI,” he added later in the memo. “We should always work towards dramatic results, not incremental improvements.”

这一成功秘诀的关键在于其他几个考量。对于 OpenAI 来说，让微软乐意保持计算领域的领先地位至关重要。如果 OpenAI 成功，微软已同意提供远超 10 亿美元的资金。“我们希望微软始终是我们的主要合作伙伴，”Altman 说道。“他们有能力至少在未来 5 年内为我们提供世界上最强大的超级计算机。” 这意味着 OpenAI 必须摆脱自由放任的学术研究环境，转而专注于商业化，从而为微软带来利益。如果 OpenAI 有其他想要进行的研究项目，它就会有资源。“套用迪士尼的那句名言，”Altman 写道，“我们应该赚更多的钱，这样我们才能做更多的研究，而不是做更多的研究，这样我们才能赚更多的钱。”

Crucial to this success formula were several other considerations. It would be paramount for OpenAI to keep Microsoft happy to maintain the lead in compute. If OpenAI was successful, Microsoft had agreed that it would give far more than $1 billion. “We would like Microsoft to be our major partner all the way through,” Altman said. “They have the capability of delivering us, for the next 5 years at least, the most powerful supercomputers in the world.” This meant shifting away from the days of OpenAI’s freewheeling academic research environment and toward focused commercialization efforts to deliver Microsoft benefits. If OpenAI had other research projects it wanted to pursue, it would then have the resources. “To paraphrase that famous Disney quote,” Altman wrote, “we should make more money so that we can do more research, not do more research so that we can make more money.”

此外，该公司需要开始降低透明度。“随着我们取得更多进展，谈论通用人工智能的信息危害风险将不断升高，”Altman 认为。现在是时候限制研究出版物和模型部署，采取更严格的保密政策，并且只披露特定技能的进展，而不是更通用的人工智能进步了。此外，每个人都需要开始接受这样的假设：“我们做出的每一个决定，我们进行的每一次对话，最终都会被调查，并登上《纽约时报》的头版。”

Additionally, the company needed to start pulling back on transparency. “The infohazard risk of talking about AGI will keep getting higher as we make more progress,” Altman argued. It was time to restrict research publications and model deployments, adopt a stricter confidentiality policy, and reveal progress on only narrow skills rather than more general AI advancements. Separately, everyone also needed to begin acting under the assumption that “every decision we make and every conversation we have ends up investigated and reported on the front page of The New York Times.”

尽管如此，“让世界认为我们正在取得胜利似乎仍然非常重要，”他说。这将使“世界上的关键影响者”更“愿意不遗余力地帮助我们”，并使“总统或其指定官员级别的”全球政策制定者向 OpenAI“寻求重大决策时的答案”。为此，“我们应该计划每年至少发布一次非常令人印象深刻的进展演示。”

That said, “it still seems very important that the world thinks we are winning at something,” he said. This would make “key influencers in the world” more “willing to go well out of their way to help us,” and make global policymakers “at the level of Presidents or their designees” come to OpenAI “for answers when they need to make big decisions.” To that end, “we should probably plan to release at least one very impressive demonstration of progress each year.”

最后，公司需要开始更加严肃认真、更加团结地行动。Altman 引用了美国海军上将 Hyman G. Rickover 的一句话。Rickover 因建造了世界上第一艘核动力潜艇而被誉为“核海军之父”。这句话在 OpenAI 成立初期就被 Altman 写在了办公室的墙上：

Finally, the company needed to start acting with more seriousness and more unity. Altman included a quote from Hyman G. Rickover, an admiral in the US Navy, known as the “father of the nuclear navy” for his work building the world’s first nuclear-powered submarines. It was a quote Altman had had painted on the office walls in the early days of OpenAI:

我认为，我们每个人都有责任采取行动，仿佛世界的命运取决于我们自己。诚然，单凭一己之力无法完成这项工作。然而，一个人可以带来改变。我们每个人都有义务发挥个人独立的能力，去解决人类面临的各种问题。正是怀着这样的信念，我们才敢于直面繁荣的责任。我们必须为人类的未来而活，而不是为自身的舒适或成功而活。

I believe it is the duty of each of us to act as if the fate of the world depended on [them]. Admittedly, one [person] by [themself] cannot do the job. However, one [person] can make a difference. Each of us is obligated to bring [their] individual and independent capacities to bear upon a wide range of human concerns. It is with this conviction that we squarely confront our duty to prosperity. We must live for the future of the human race, not of our own comfort or success.

“打造造福人类的通用人工智能或许是世界上最重要的项目，”奥特曼在文件中的引文下方写道。“我们必须把使命置于任何个人偏好之上。”

“Building AGI that benefits humanity is perhaps the most important project in the world,” Altman wrote below the quote in the document. “We must put the mission ahead of any individual preferences.

“低风险的事情应该低戏剧性，这样我们就可以把高戏剧性的能力留给高风险的事情（其中会有很多）。”

“Low-stakes things should be low-drama, so we can save our high-drama capacity for high-stakes things (of which there will be many).”

—

—

事实上，戏剧性事件早已酝酿。公司内部不断浮现的各种小裂痕开始汇聚成大裂痕。曾经互称朋友的布罗克曼和阿莫迪兄妹如今却在越来越多的问题上发生冲突。其中，达里奥·阿莫迪对Dota 2工作的降级让布罗克曼感到沮丧，他认为阿莫迪没有认真对待他的贡献。Dota 2曾经是计算资源最密集的项目，而布罗克曼也对阿莫迪将计算资源集中用于 Nest 的 GPT-3 工作感到不满。与此同时，阿莫迪姐弟发现布罗克曼很难共事，不愿意让他加入他们的语言模型开发。

Drama was in fact already brewing. Various little rifts that had bubbled up across the company were beginning to coalesce into big ones. Once quick to call each other friends, Brockman and the Amodei siblings were now butting heads on a growing list of issues. Among them, Dario Amodei’s deprioritization of the Dota 2 work had frustrated Brockman, who believed Amodei hadn’t taken his contributions seriously. Where Dota 2 was once the most compute-heavy project, Brockman also chafed against Amodei’s centralization of compute for Nest’s work on GPT-3. The Amodei siblings, meanwhile, found Brockman difficult to work with and were unwilling to let him join in on their language model development.

这种紧张的气氛导致领导层之间出现裂痕，并逐渐蔓延至公司内部忠于彼此的员工。在Dota 2项目期间，Brockman 通过高强度的工作时间、巨大的压力以及在夏威夷临时休假的经历，与团队中的一些成员建立了亲密的联系，尤其与 Jakub Pachocki 和 Szymon Sidor 两位波兰科学家建立了深厚的友谊，他们既是室友，也是挚友。Amodei 的 AI 安全团队，尤其是 Nest 团队的核心成员，组成了另一个团队，他们对流氓 AI 以及生存或其他极端风险的共同担忧（程度不一）将他们紧密联系在一起。他们将自己的工作与公司其他部门隔离开来，创建了私人的 Slack 频道和文档，甚至其他高管也无法访问。这让 Brockman 之外的更多人感到沮丧，因为他们同样感到被边缘化，因为他们的计算资源以及对公司核心研究的了解程度都在下降。

The tensions created a break among the leaders that slowly extended to the people who were loyal to each one in the company. During the Dota 2 project, Brockman had forged a familial bond with some members of his team through the intense working hours, high stress, and a spur-of-the-moment retreat in Hawai’i, growing especially close to Jakub Pachocki and Szymon Sidor, two Polish scientists who were roommates and best friends. Amodei’s AI safety teams, and the core members of the Nest team in particular, formed another contingent, bound together by their shared concern, in varying degrees, of rogue AI and existential or other extreme risks. They kept their work insulated from the rest of the company, creating private Slack channels and documents not accessible even to other executives. It frustrated many more people beyond Brockman as they felt similarly sidelined by the dwindling of their compute resources, along with their visibility into the company’s core research.

与此同时，Amodei 的 AI 安全团队也对 Altman 的一些行为愈发感到不安。OpenAI 与微软的协议签署后不久，他们中的一些人惊讶地发现，Altman 向微软承诺，微软将获得哪些技术作为投资回报。协议条款与他们从 Altman 那里了解到的情况不符。他们担心，如果 OpenAI 的模型真的出现了 AI 安全问题，这些承诺将使阻止这些模型的部署变得更加困难，甚至不可能。Amodei 的团队开始对 Altman 的诚实产生了严重的怀疑。

Amodei’s AI safety contingent, meanwhile, was also growing disquieted with some of Altman’s behaviors. Shortly after OpenAI’s Microsoft deal was inked, several of them were stunned to discover the extent of the promises that Altman had made to Microsoft for which technologies it would get access to in return for its investment. The terms of the deal didn’t align with what they had understood from Altman. If AI safety issues actually arose in OpenAI’s models, they worried, those commitments would make it far more difficult, if not impossible, to prevent the models’ deployment. Amodei’s contingent began to have serious doubts about Altman’s honesty.

“我们都是务实的人，”小组里的一个人说。“我们当然在融资；我们要做商业化的东西。如果你像萨姆一样做了很多交易，你可能会觉得‘好吧，我们做个交易，我们交易一个东西，然后我们再交易下一个东西’，这看起来挺合理。但如果你像我一样，你会觉得‘我们正在交易一个我们并不完全了解的东西。’这感觉就像把我们逼到了一个很不舒服的境地。”

“We’re all pragmatic people,” a person in the group says. “We’re obviously raising money; we’re going to do commercial stuff. It might look very reasonable if you’re someone who makes loads of deals like Sam, to be like, ‘All right, let’s make a deal, let’s trade a thing, we’re going to trade the next thing.’ And then if you are someone like me, you’re like, ‘We’re trading a thing we don’t fully understand.’ It feels like it commits us to an uncomfortable place.”

当时，公司上下对各种问题的担忧日益加剧。在人工智能安全团队内部，他们关注的是他们认为强有力的证据表明，强大的、失衡的人工智能系统可能会导致灾难性的后果。一次奇异的经历尤其让他们中的一些人感到有些紧张。2019年，在一个参数数量大约是GPT-2两倍的模型上，一组研究人员开始推进Amodei想要的人工智能安全工作：测试基于人类反馈的强化学习，以此引导模型生成欢快积极的内容，并远离任何冒犯性的内容。

This was against the backdrop of a growing paranoia over different issues across the company. Within the AI safety contingent, it centered on what they saw as strengthening evidence that powerful misaligned AI systems could lead to disastrous outcomes. One bizarre experience in particular had left several of them somewhat nervous. In 2019, on a model trained after GPT-2 with roughly twice the number of parameters, a group of researchers had begun advancing the AI safety work that Amodei had wanted: testing reinforcement learning from human feedback as a way to guide the model toward generating cheerful and positive content and away from anything offensive.

但一天深夜，一位研究人员在让 RLHF 进程通宵运行之前，更新了他的代码，结果出现了一个拼写错误。这个拼写错误至关重要：本来应该把减号翻转成加号，结果导致 RLHF 进程反向运行，导致 GPT-2 生成更多而非更少的冒犯性内容。到了第二天早上，这个拼写错误造成了严重破坏，GPT-2 每次输入都充满了极其淫秽和露骨的性暗示。这既滑稽又令人担忧。在发现错误后，这位研究人员向 OpenAI 的代码库提交了一个修复程序，并附上一条评论：我们不要再做一个效用最小化器了。

But late one night, a researcher made an update that included a single typo in his code before leaving the RLHF process to run overnight. That typo was an important one: It was a minus sign flipped to a plus sign that made the RLHF process work in reverse, pushing GPT-2 to generate more offensive content instead of less. By the next morning, the typo had wreaked its havoc, and GPT-2 was completing every single prompt with extremely lewd and sexually explicit language. It was hilarious—and also concerning. After identifying the error, the researcher pushed a fix to OpenAI’s code base with a comment: Let’s not make a utility minimizer.

部分原因是意识到单凭扩展就能带来更多的 AI 进步，许多员工也担心如果不同的公司掌握了 OpenAI 的秘密会发生什么。他们会互相说：“我们的东西如何运作的秘密可以写在一粒米上”，这意味着单词“扩展”。出于同样的原因，他们担心强大的能力落入不法分子手中。领导层倾向于这种恐惧，经常提到中国、俄罗斯和朝鲜的威胁，并强调 AGI 开发必须掌握在美国机构手中。有时，这会让非美国员工感到恼火。一位前员工回忆说，在午餐时，他们会问，为什么一定要是美国机构？为什么不是欧洲的？为什么不是中国的？

In part fueled by the realization that scaling alone could produce more AI advancements, many employees also worried about what would happen if different companies caught on to OpenAI’s secret. “The secret of how our stuff works can be written on a grain of rice,” they would say to each other, meaning the single word scale. For the same reason, they worried about powerful capabilities landing in the hands of bad actors. Leadership leaned into this fear, frequently raising the threat of China, Russia, and North Korea and emphasizing the need for AGI development to stay in the hands of a US organization. At times this rankled employees who were not American. During lunches, they would question, Why did it have to be a US organization? remembers a former employee. Why not one from Europe? Why not one from China?

在这些关于人工智能研究的长期影响的令人振奋的讨论中，许多员工经常回顾 Altman 早期将 OpenAI 与曼哈顿计划进行类比的案例。OpenAI 真的在打造相当于核武器的东西吗？这与它迄今为止作为一家主要学术组织。每周五，员工们会在忙碌的一周后放松身心，享受音乐和葡萄酒之夜，听着同事们轮流演奏办公室钢琴直到深夜的舒缓音乐。

During these heady discussions philosophizing about the long-term implications of AI research, many employees returned often to Altman’s early analogies between OpenAI and the Manhattan Project. Was OpenAI really building the equivalent of a nuclear weapon? It was a strange contrast to the plucky, idealistic culture it had built thus far as a largely academic organization. On Fridays, employees would kick back after a long week for music and wine nights, unwinding to the soothing sounds of a rotating cast of colleagues playing the office piano late into the night.

这种重心转移让一些人感到不安，加剧了他们对随机事件和无关事件的焦虑。有一次，一名记者在封闭的停车场内尾随某人，试图进入大楼。还有一次，一名员工发现了一个下落不明的U盘，这引发了人们的恐慌，人们怀疑它是否包含恶意软件文件（一种常见的攻击媒介），以及某种网络安全漏洞的企图。在一台完全与互联网断开连接的隔离电脑上检查后，U盘最终被证明什么也没有。Amodei 至少两次使用隔离电脑撰写关键战略文件，将机器直接连接到打印机，只分发实体副本。他非常担心国家行为者会窃取 OpenAI 的机密，并构建自己的强大 AI 模型用于恶意目的。

The shift in gravity unsettled some people, heightening their anxiety about random and unrelated incidents. Once, a journalist tailgated someone inside the gated parking lot to gain access to the building. Another time, an employee found an unaccounted-for USB stick, stirring consternation about whether it contained malware files, a common vector of attack, and was some kind of attempt at a cybersecurity breach. After it was examined on an air-gapped computer, one completely severed from the internet, the USB turned out to be nothing. At least twice, Amodei also used an air-gapped computer to write critical strategy documents, connecting the machine directly to a printer to circulate only physical copies. He was paranoid about state actors stealing OpenAI’s secrets and building their own powerful AI models for malicious purposes.

“没人准备好承担这个责任，”一名员工回忆道，“这让人彻夜难眠。”

“No one was prepared for this responsibility,” one employee remembers. “It kept people up at night.”

奥特曼本人对泄露信息心存疑虑。他私下里对Neuralink的员工感到担忧，因为OpenAI一直与他们共用一个办公室，而马斯克离开后，他们更加不安。奥特曼也担心马斯克，因为他拥有庞大的安保团队，包括私人司机和保镖。奥特曼敏锐地意识到双方能力上的差距，曾秘密委托进行电子反监控审计，试图扫描办公室，找出马斯克可能留下的任何用于监视OpenAI的窃听器。

Altman himself was paranoid about people leaking information. He privately worried about Neuralink staff, with whom OpenAI continued to share an office, now with more unease after Musk’s departure. Altman worried, too, about Musk, who wielded an extensive security apparatus including personal drivers and bodyguards. Keenly aware of the capability difference, Altman at one point secretly commissioned an electronic countersurveillance audit in an attempt to scan the office for any bugs that Musk may have left to spy on OpenAI.

奥特曼对员工们说，美国对手在人工智能研究方面比OpenAI发展得更快，以此来解释为什么公司需要在尽可能快地工作的同时，越来越不开放。“我们必须对世界的未来负责，”他在愿景文件中写道。“另一方面，如果一个专制政府抢在我们之前开发出通用人工智能并滥用它，我们的使命也会失败——我们几乎肯定必须快速取得技术进步才能完成我们的使命。”

To employees, Altman used the specter of US adversaries advancing AI research faster than OpenAI to rationalize why the company needed to be less and less open while working as fast as possible. “We must hold ourselves responsible for a good outcome for the world,” he wrote in his vision document. “On the other hand, if an authoritarian government builds AGI before we do and misuses it, we will have also failed at our mission—we almost certainly have to make rapid technical progress in order to succeed at our mission.”

—

—

奥特曼开始加强安全监管。高管们争论着该如何划定新的界限：OpenAI 应该更像一家保护专有技术的财富 500 强公司，还是更像一个保护高度机密的国家机密的政府机构？最终，高管们一致认为，他们需要锁定模型权重——这是可以用来复制 OpenAI 深度学习模型完整训练版本的关键信息。如果模型权重被盗，后果不堪设想，因为它既可能助长不法分子的势力，也可能削弱 OpenAI 的竞争优势。

Altman began to tighten the screws on security. Executives debated where to draw the new line: Should OpenAI act more like a Fortune 500 company protecting proprietary technologies or more like a government operation protecting highly classified state secrets? At a baseline, the executives agreed that they needed to lock down the model weights—the key information that could be used to replicate the fully trained versions of OpenAI’s deep learning models. If stolen, that would be bad because it could both empower bad actors and handicap OpenAI’s competitive advantage.

起初，由于没有正式的安全人员，Altman 委派了一名基础设施团队成员（负责公司从 GPU 到办公室互联网的所有事务）来思考防止模型被盗的解决方案——不仅要防范企业或政府支持的间谍，还要防范 OpenAI 自己的员工。在网络安全领域，防范“内部威胁”是相对标准的做法。内部人员可能会故意破坏或窃取 OpenAI 的知识产权；他们也可能被诱骗放弃知识产权。在这个问题被提出后，Altman 私下承认，像 Sutskever 这样的人可能容易受到后者的攻击。首席科学家自然是坏人的目标：他是典型的天才科学家，但缺乏街头智慧，在组织内位高权重，可以接触到最重要的信息。

At first, without formal security staff, Altman deputized a member of the infrastructure team, which handled everything from the company’s GPUs to the office internet, to think about solutions for preventing model theft—not just from corporate or state-sponsored spies but also from OpenAI’s own employees. In cybersecurity, protecting against “insider threat” is relatively standard practice. Insiders could sabotage or steal OpenAI’s IP intentionally; they could also be tricked into giving it up. In private, Altman acknowledged, after the point was raised, that someone like Sutskever could be vulnerable to the latter. The chief scientist was a logical target for bad actors: He was the archetype of a brainiac scientist who wasn’t the most streetwise, and he ranked highly within the organization and had top access to information.

苏茨克维尔也有自己的偏执。作为人工智能研究领域这个脑力发达、社交能力欠缺的明星科学家，他见识过不少狂热粉丝和跟踪狂的行为。不止一次，陌生人试图潜入OpenAI的办公室，只为见他一面。和阿莫迪一样，他也担心人工智能的力量会引起不道德政府的关注，并怀疑那些急于寻求他建议的人是否是秘密的外国特工。他曾和同事们讨论，如果他的手被砍掉，用来做掌纹扫描仪，以解密OpenAI的秘密，该怎么办。他希望减少雇佣，保持少量员工，以降低渗透的风险。他与雅库布·帕乔基和西蒙·西多尔提议建造一个安全的收容设施，一个带有空气的地堡——一个有间隙的计算机，可以保存 OpenAI 的模型权重，防止他人窃取。由于模型必须先在微软的服务器上进行训练，这个想法并不实际，因此最终未能成功。

Sutskever had his own paranoias. As a star scientist in the cerebral and socially inept world of AI research, he had seen his share of obsessive fans and stalkerish behaviors. More than once, strangers had sought to sneak into OpenAI’s office just to see him. Like Amodei, he also worried about the power of AI attracting the attention of unscrupulous governments and wondered whether those overeager to seek his advice were secretly foreign agents. He mused to colleagues what he should do if his hand got cut off to be used in a palm scanner for unlocking OpenAI’s secrets. He wanted to hire less and keep a small staff in order to reduce the risks of infiltration. With Jakub Pachocki and Szymon Sidor, he proposed building a secure containment facility, a bunker with an air-gapped computer, that would hold OpenAI’s model weights and prevent others from stealing them. The idea, which didn’t make practical sense given that the models had to be trained first on Microsoft’s servers, never got legs.

随着公司监控软件的安装，大多数员工无法察觉的数字安全得到了提升。此外，物理安全也得到了加强。办公室停车场的大门也得到了加固。办公室内，几扇带键盘的门被编程设定了“遇险密码”，这些特殊代码可以被输入以触发秘密警报，从而向相关安保人员发出现场威胁的警报。公司曾向供应商咨询加固服务器机房以抵御机枪扫射需要花费多少钱，但这个想法后来被放弃了。

Hidden from view of most employees, digital security increased with the installation of corporate-monitoring software. In the background, enhancements were also made to physical security. The gates to the office parking lot were fortified. Within the office, several doors with keypads were programmed to have “distress passwords,” special codes that could be punched in to trigger a secret alarm that would alert relevant security personnel of an in-person threat. Quotes were sought from vendors about how much it would cost to reinforce a server room to withstand a machine gun, though that idea was subsequently dropped.

在愿景备忘录中，Altman 指出了公司内部因压力加剧而产生的分歧。“OpenAI 内部至少有三个阵营——用一个比较夸张的比喻来说，就是探索性研究、安全和初创企业。”探索性研究阵营致力于提升 AI 能力，安全阵营专注于责任，而初创企业阵营则致力于快速行动并完成任务。

In the vision memo, Altman noted the divisions that were developing in the company from the heightening stress. “We have (at least) three clans at OpenAI—to caricature-ize them, let’s say exploratory research, safety, and startup.” The Exploratory Research clan was about advancing AI capabilities, the Safety clan about focusing on responsibility, and the Startup clan about moving fast and getting things done.

奥特曼认为，每个“部落”都拥有公司需要守护的重要价值观：探索性研究的“即使屡败屡战，我们也会追求重要的新想法”；安全部的“我们将坚定不移地致力于做正确的事”；以及创业部的“我们会找到实现目标的方法”。“我们必须继续避免部落战争，”他说道。“为了取得成功，我们需要这三个部落团结一致，同时保持各自优势，共同致力于实现最大程度造福人类的通用人工智能。”

Per Altman, each of these clans had important values that the company needed to preserve: the “we will pursue important new ideas even if we fail many times” of Exploratory Research; the “we will have an unwavering commitment to doing the right thing” of Safety; and the “we’ll figure out a way to make it happen” of Startup. “We have to continue to avoid tribal warfare,” he said. “To succeed, we need these three clans to unite as one tribe—while maintaining the strengths of each clan—working towards AGI that maximally benefits humanity.”

虽然 Altman 从未点名道姓，但员工们都能从字里行间读出其中的含义。Sutskever 是探索性研究的代表；Amodei 和他的 AI 安全团队专注于极端风险，构成了安全部门；Brockman 是创业部门的负责人。不久之后，疫情爆发，每个人都开始远程办公，这使得各个部门更容易彼此隔离。

Though Altman never name-checked anyone, employees read between the lines. Sutskever was the face of Exploratory Research; Amodei and his AI safety contingent focused on extreme risks constituted Safety; Brockman was the champion of Startup. Soon after, the pandemic hit, and everyone began working remotely, making it far easier for the clans to isolate themselves from one another.

—

—

阿莫迪敦促他的团队迅速行动。正如他们对 GPT-2 所做的那样，他们迭代地训练更大的模型，以升级到具有 1750 亿个参数的完整一万个 GPU 模型，并以科学家的名字按字母顺序命名这些模型：ada代表最小的模型，指的是英国数学家 Ada Lovelace，她被广泛认为是第一位计算机程序员；babbage代表英国发明家 Charles Babbage，他构思了第一台数字计算机，Lovelace 为这台计算机提出了她的程序；curie代表波兰裔法国物理学家和化学家玛丽·居里，她是第一位获得诺贝尔奖并两次获奖的女性；davinci代表列奥纳多·达芬奇。这些练习既是为了继续验证缩放定律是否在从根本上更大规模上仍然成立，也是为了更实际地逐步解决每个新层面上的硬件和数据挑战。Nest 团队会定期向公司汇报进展情况，这让人们越来越兴奋。“很难用言语来形容那种兴奋，”一位研究人员回忆道。 “我一生中从未见过这样的事情。”

Amodei pushed his team to move quickly. As they had done with GPT-2, they trained iteratively larger models in the ascension to a full ten-thousand-GPU model with 175 billion parameters, naming them alphabetically after scientists: ada for the smallest model, referring to English mathematician Ada Lovelace, widely credited as the first computer programmer; babbage for English inventor Charles Babbage, who conceived the first digital computer for which Lovelace would propose her program; curie for Polish French physicist and chemist Marie Curie, the first woman to win the Nobel Prize and win it twice; and davinci for Leonardo. The exercise was both to continue validating whether scaling laws still held at fundamentally larger scale and, more practically, to work gradually through the hardware and data challenges at each new level. On a regular basis, the Nest team would give the company an update on its progress, to growing excitement. “It’s hard to overstate how insane that was to see,” remembers one researcher. “I’d never seen anything like that in my life.”

与此同时，奥尔特曼和布罗克曼制定了商业化计划。2020 年 1 月下旬，布罗克曼开始为 GPT-3 编写应用程序编程接口 (API) 的第一行代码。该 API 将允许公司和开发人员访问模型的功能，但不允许他们访问模型权重，并允许他们将该技术融入到他们自己的面向消费者的产品中。该公司分为两个部门。米拉·穆拉蒂 (Mira Murati) 被提升为新应用部门的副总裁，负责监督 API 和商业化战略。在她的领导下，一直领导机器人团队的彼得·韦林德 (Peter Welinder) 被调去领导产品；曾共同创办一家被 Airbnb 收购的人工智能初创公司的弗雷泽·凯尔顿 (Fraser Kelton) 和曾在 Leap Motion 工作过的凯蒂·梅耶尔 (Katie Mayer) 分别被聘用管理新产品和工程团队。所有与应用公司无关的人都进入了研究部门。

In parallel, Altman and Brockman developed a plan for commercialization. In late January 2020, Brockman began writing the first lines of code for an application programming interface, or API, for GPT-3. The API would give companies and developers access to the model’s capabilities without giving them access to the model weights and allow them to incorporate the technology into their own consumer-facing products. The company split into two divisions. Mira Murati was promoted to VP of a new Applied division for overseeing the API and commercialization strategy. Under her, Peter Welinder, who had been leading the robotics team, was shifted to leading product; Fraser Kelton, who had cofounded an AI startup acquired by Airbnb, and Katie Mayer, who had worked at Leap Motion, were hired to respectively manage new product and engineering teams. Everyone not in Applied by association became the Research division.

这次分裂加深了奥特曼早已认定的裂痕。应用材料部门的成立带来了一小群来自其他初创公司的员工，他们人数虽少，但规模不断扩大，壮大了初创公司的势力。虽然探索性研究团队对此感到有些矛盾，担心 OpenAI 是否会成为又一家硅谷产品公司，但这引发了研究部门内部的 Amodei 及其安全团队日益激烈的反对。

That split deepened a fault line that Altman had identified. The formation of the Applied division brought in a small but growing group of people hailing from other startups that strengthened the Startup clan. While the Exploratory Research clan viewed this with some ambivalence about whether OpenAI would become just another Silicon Valley product company, it triggered increasingly impassioned opposition from Amodei and his Safety clan also sitting within the Research division.

对于安全部门的许多人来说，通过 API 或任何其他方式在短时间内发布 GPT-3，都会缩短交付周期——而这正是加速扩展的关键——OpenAI 必须完善模型的安全性。应用部门不同意这种观点，因为他们的全部目标是找到利用 OpenAI 技术赚钱的早期解决方案，在他们看来，这需要在短期内发布这些技术。在他们看来，API 也赋予了 OpenAI 在所有发布策略中最具控制力的机制，使公司能够选择性地授予访问权限，并收集宝贵的数据点，以了解该模型可能如何被人们使用或滥用。在全体会议上，Altman 左右逢源：API 最终将帮助每个团队实现他们的目标；而 API 带来的一些收入将使 OpenAI 能够在人工智能安全研究方面投入更多资金。

To many in Safety, releasing GPT-3 in short order via an API, or any other means, undermined the lead time—the whole point of the accelerated scaling—that OpenAI would have to perfect the safety of the model. The Applied division, whose entire purpose was to find early solutions for making money from OpenAI’s technologies, which in their view required releasing them in the near term, disagreed. The API as they saw it also gave OpenAI the most controlled mechanism of any release strategy, allowing the company to be selective about whom to give access to and collecting invaluable data points for understanding how the model could be used or abused by people. In all-hands meetings, Altman played both sides: The API would ultimately help each group achieve what they wanted; bringing in some revenue would allow OpenAI to invest even more in AI safety research.

GPT-3 训练完成后，员工们开始在内部试用该模型。他们测试了模型的功能极限，并对 API 的第一个版本进行了修改。公司举办了一场黑客马拉松，员工们在会上探讨了不同的应用创意。但随着每个新原型的推出，紧张的气氛也愈发紧张。应用部门和探索性研究部门的许多人对这些演示越来越兴奋，而安全部门的许多人则认为，这进一步证明，在没有全面测试和额外研究的情况下发布模型可能会带来灾难性的后果。

As GPT-3 finished training, employees began playing with the model internally. They tested the bounds of its capabilities and tinkered with the first version of the API. The company held a hackathon where employees riffed on different application ideas. But with every new prototype, tensions worsened. Where the Applied division, and many in Exploratory Research, viewed the demonstrations with mounting excitement, many in Safety saw them as yet further evidence that releasing the model without comprehensive testing and additional research could risk devastating outcomes.

有一项功能尤其引发了两极分化：GPT-3 的代码生成能力。这并非 Nest 团队的初衷，但在抓取 Reddit 上的链接并使用 Common Crawl 作为训练数据时，他们从工程师们在各种在线论坛上发布程序、提问或分享技巧时获取了零散的代码行，这使得该模型能够更好地适应编程语言。这项进展让探索性研究部门的许多人兴奋不已，就像应用部门一样。它不仅令人印象深刻的技术里程碑，它也有潜力成为这是一种加速公司人工智能研究生产力的工具，旨在将 GPT-3 打造成更具吸引力的产品。出于同样的原因，安全部门的一些人感到恐慌。如果一个人工智能系统能够利用自身的代码生成技能进行自我调整，它可能会加速其实现更强大功能的进程，增加其颠覆人类控制的风险，并放大极其有害或关乎生存的人工智能风险的可能性。

One capability proved particularly polarizing: GPT-3’s code-generation abilities. It hadn’t been part of the Nest team’s intentions, but in scraping links on Reddit and using Common Crawl for training data, they had captured scattered lines of code from engineers posting their programs on various online forums to ask questions or share tips, leading the model to have an increased facility for programming languages. The development thrilled many in Exploratory Research, just as it did the Applied division. Not only was it an impressive technical milestone, it also had potential as a tool to accelerate the company’s productivity in AI research and to make GPT-3 into a more compelling product. For the same reason, some in Safety panicked. If an AI system could use its own code-generation skills to tweak itself, it could accelerate the timeline to more powerful capabilities, increase the risk of it subverting human control, and amplify the chances of extremely harmful or existential AI risks.

Sutskever 和 Wojciech Zaremba（马斯克在一次会议上极力敦促的创始成员之一）随后将组建一个团队，创建一个专门用于代码生成的模型。但在一次项目启动会议上，两人得知 Amodei 已经有了自己的代码生成模型开发计划，并不认为有必要合并工作。尽管心存担忧，但 Amodei 认为，就像 GPT-3 一样，减轻代码生成可能带来的危害的最佳方法就是比任何人都更快地构建模型，甚至比他认为不会优先考虑 AI 安全的 OpenAI 其他团队更快地构建模型，并利用这段时间研究如何降低模型风险。令其他员工感到困惑的是，这两个团队继续重复进行代码生成工作。一位研究人员说：“从旁观者的角度来看，这就像某种疯狂的《权力的游戏》情节。”

Sutskever and Wojciech Zaremba, one of the founding members whom Musk had pressed during a meeting, would subsequently form a team to create a model designed specifically for code generation. But during a meeting to kick off the project, the two learned that Amodei already had his own plans for developing a code-generation model and didn’t see a need to merge efforts. Despite his concerns, Amodei believed, as with GPT-3, that the best way to mitigate the possible harms of code generation was simply to build the model faster than anyone else, including even the other teams at OpenAI who he didn’t believe would prioritize AI safety, and use the lead time to conduct research on de-risking the model. Much to the confusion of other employees, the two teams continued to work on duplicate code-generation efforts. “It just seemed from the outside watching this that it was some kind of crazy Game of Thrones stuff,” a researcher says.

围绕通过 API 发布 GPT-3 的僵局一直持续到春末。出于对人工智能极端风险加速增长的担忧，安全部门继续敦促公司保持高度谨慎，并主张尽可能推迟发布。应用部门继续为 API 的发布做准备，认为改进模型的最佳方式是让它与现实世界接触。大约在同一时间，第三组员工也提出了新的担忧，他们担心在美国发生重大政治、社会和经济动荡之际，这种惊人的文本生成能力可能会造成影响。到 2020 年 5 月，疫情已经造成了失业率上升速度比大衰退期间更快。同月，明尼阿波利斯警察德里克·肖万杀害了46岁的黑人男子乔治·弗洛伊德，引发了全国范围内大规模的“黑人的命也是命”抗议活动。以及世界其他地区。该团队还对即将到来的美国总统大选感到担忧。

The deadlock around releasing GPT-3 via the API continued until late spring. Safety continued to push for paramount caution based on fears of accelerating extreme AI risks, arguing for the company to delay its release as long as possible. The Applied division continued with preparing for the API launch, arguing that the best way to improve the model was for it to have contact with the real world. Around the same time, new concerns emerged from a third group of employees worried about the impact that spectacular text-generation abilities could have in the midst of major political, social, and economic upheaval in the US. By May 2020, the pandemic had already created a faster rise in unemployment than during the Great Recession. In the same month, Derek Chauvin, a police officer in Minneapolis, murdered George Floyd, a forty-six-year-old Black man, setting off massive Black Lives Matter protests around the country and the rest of the world. The team was also concerned about the impending US presidential election.

但 OpenAI 内部开始流传谷歌可能很快就会发布自己的大型语言模型的传言。这种可能性是存在的。谷歌在今年年初发布了关于一款名为 Meena 的新型聊天机器人的研究，该机器人基于一个大型语言模型构建，其参数量是 GPT-2 的 1.7 倍。该公司很可能正在努力将该模型的规模扩大到与 GPT-3 大致相当。这些传言最终敲定了 API 的发布：如果世界上很快就能出现一个同样规模的模型，那么 Safety 就没必要再阻止 GPT-3 的发布了。

But rumors began to spread within OpenAI that Google could soon release its own large language model. The possibility was plausible. Google had published research at the start of the year about a new chatbot called Meena, built on a large language model with 1.7 times more parameters than GPT-2. The company could very well be working on scaling that model to roughly the size of GPT-3. The rumors sealed the deal for the API launch: If a model just as large would soon exist in the world, Safety felt less of a reason to hold back GPT-3.

今年6月，该公司宣布了这项API，并设立了申请表，供人们申请提前使用，优先考虑应用部门认为值得信赖、能够负责任地处理这项技术的大型企业。公司还维护了一个大型电子表格，供员工填写他们希望提前使用的人选，包括家人、朋友和他们喜欢的名人。

In June, the company announced the API and set up an application form for people to request early access, prioritizing larger enterprises that the Applied division felt could be trusted to handle the technology responsibly. The company also maintained a big spreadsheet for employees to put down the names of anyone they wanted to jump the queue, including family, friends, and their favorite celebrities.

谷歌传闻中的模型从未实现。这家科技巨头确实已经开始研发一个比 Meena 更大的模型，名为 LaMDA，以打造一个更好的聊天机器人——但它仍然比 GPT-3 小一些，而且该公司最终决定在 ChatGPT 之后再发布它。谷歌高管认定 LaMDA 不符合公司的 AI 道德标准。一些员工还担心重蹈微软臭名昭著的丑闻：2016 年，微软发布了一款名为 Tay 的 AI 聊天机器人，在用户反复提示该聊天机器人重复不恰当和冒犯性的内容后，该机器人很快变得种族主义、厌恶女性，并支持希特勒。GPT-3 API 的发布绝不会是 OpenAI 最后一次基于对竞争过度恐惧而做出的技术推广决定。

Google’s rumored model never materialized. The tech giant had indeed begun working on a larger model than Meena, known as LaMDA, to produce a better chatbot—but it was still modestly smaller than GPT-3, and the company would ultimately decide not to release it until after ChatGPT. Google’s executives determined that LaMDA didn’t meet the company’s ethical AI standards. Some employees also worried about repeating an infamous Microsoft scandal: In 2016, Microsoft had released an AI-powered chatbot known as Tay that quickly turned racist and misogynistic, and espoused support for Hitler, after users repeatedly prompted the chatbot to repeat inappropriate and offensive things. The GPT-3 API release wouldn’t be the last decision that OpenAI would make to push out its technology based on an inflated fear of competition.

—

—

正如ChatGPT让OpenAI迅速家喻户晓一样，GPT-3也成为人工智能和科技圈的标志性事件。2022年末，ChatGPT为GPT-3的体验增添了关键的改进和功能，使其成为一款全球热门产品，其中包括一款消费者友好的Web 界面、对话功能、更多安全机制以及免费版本。然而，当时公众在聊天机器人上体验到的许多核心功能，开发者早在两年前的 2020 年就通过 API 体验到了。开发者们同样感到敬畏和惊叹，简直不敢相信这一切。

Just as ChatGPT would make OpenAI an instant household name, GPT-3 was that moment within AI and tech circles. In late 2022, ChatGPT would add key improvements and features to the GPT-3 experience that would transform it into a globally viral product, including a consumer-friendly web interface, conversational abilities, more safety mechanisms, and a free version. But many of the core capabilities that the broader public would experience with the chatbot then, developers were already experiencing with the API in 2020, two years earlier. With the same awe and wonder, developers couldn’t believe it.

GPT-3 的能力远超 GPT-2 以往展现的任何能力。此前，无论是在学术界还是工业界，都从未有人见过一项技术能够以看似同等的敏捷度生成论文、剧本和代码。这种执行不同任务的灵活性本身就极具技术含量——之前的语言模型通常只擅长于完成单一的训练任务。但更令人瞩目的是，许多人认为 GPT-3 开始展现出该领域长期以来梦寐以求的另一个特性：快速泛化。只需向模型展示一些你希望它执行的新任务示例，它就能快速运行。

GPT-3’s capabilities were far beyond anything GPT-2 had ever exhibited. Never before had anyone in research or industry seen a technology that could generate essays, screenplays, and code with seemingly equal dexterity. This kind of flexibility for performing different tasks was alone extremely technically impressive—previous language models typically had only one aptitude for doing the single task they had been trained on. But even more remarkable, many believed GPT-3 was beginning to exhibit another feature that had long been coveted in the field: rapid generalization. Showing the model a few examples of a new task you wanted it to perform was enough to get it going.

在当年的 NeurIPS 大会上，OpenAI 阐述其模型研究成果的论文赢得了一项顶级研究奖项，这不仅让员工们大吃一惊，也确立了该实验室的领先地位。其效果正如领导团队所预料的那样。OpenAI 的新地位使其更容易招募和留住人才，OpenAI LP 筹集的资金也起到了显著作用，最终使该公司能够在薪酬方面与谷歌和 DeepMind 竞争。

At NeurIPS that year, OpenAI’s paper explaining its work on the model won one of the top research awards, surprising employees and establishing the lab’s status as a leading organization. The effect was as the leadership team had predicted. OpenAI’s new stature made it easier to recruit and retain talent, significantly helped along by the capital raised from OpenAI LP, which allowed the company to finally compete with Google and DeepMind on salaries.

2020年10月，随着OpenAI的知名度不断提升，Altman聘请了曾在苹果公司领导公关事务的资深高管Steve Dowling担任OpenAI的新任公关副总裁。他还任命Dowling负责政府关系，强调向政策制定者普及人工智能知识并让他们意识到未来人工智能能力的重要性。Jack Clark离职后，Dowling聘请了曾在奥巴马政府担任政策顾问、备受尊敬的Anna Makanju接手政策和全球事务，她也曾在Facebook和马斯克的Starlink项目中负责政策制定。

In October 2020, with OpenAI’s elevating recognition, Altman hired Steve Dowling, a seasoned executive who’d led communications at Apple, to be OpenAI’s new VP of communications. He also placed Dowling in charge of government relations, emphasizing the importance of educating policymakers about AI and making them aware of the coming capabilities. After Jack Clark’s departure, Dowling would bring on Anna Makanju, a highly respected former adviser in the Obama administration who had also worked on policy at Facebook and Musk’s Starlink, to take over policy and global affairs.

应用部门渴望借力 GPT-3 的势头，集思广益，制定并扩展其商业化战略。但似乎在每个转折点，安全部门都继续进行抵抗。例如安全部门仍在应对 GPT-3 的仓促发布，挽救过早发布的最佳方法不是进一步推广，而是首先尽快解决模型的缺陷。API 上的实时版本没有任何内容审核过滤功能，其输出也没有通过强化学习根据人工反馈进行改进。在会议上，两大阵营试图找到一个中间立场。结果，他们只是在无休止地兜圈子，互相讨论。后来成为产品副总裁的韦林德曾一度苦涩地评论说，每一次谈话都感觉像是在重演1944年美国情报部门关于非暴力破坏的手册。这本2008年解密的手册中，有一节列出了一些简单的指令，教你如何破坏和削弱一个组织的生产力，其中包括：

Eager to ride GPT-3’s momentum, the Applied division brainstormed ways to develop and expand its commercialization strategy. But seemingly at every turn, the Safety clan continued to put up resistance. For Safety, still contending with the rushing out of GPT-3, the best way to salvage the premature release was not to propagate it even further but to first resolve the model’s shortcomings as quickly as possible. The live version on the API didn’t have any kind of content-moderation filtering, nor had its outputs been refined with reinforcement learning from human feedback. In meetings, the two camps sought to find a middle ground. Instead, they talked around each other in endless circles. At one point, Welinder, who would become VP of product, commented bitterly that every conversation felt like a reenactment of a 1944 US intelligence manual about nonviolent sabotage. One section of the pamphlet, declassified in 2008, lists simple instructions for how to destabilize and undermine the productivity of an organization, including:

  • 尽可能频繁地、长时间地交谈。

  • Talk as frequently as possible and at great length.

  • 尽可能频繁地提出不相关的问题。

  • Bring up irrelevant issues as frequently as possible.

  • 就通讯、会议记录、决议的具体措辞进行争论。

  • Haggle over precise wordings of communications, minutes, resolutions.

  • 回顾上次会议决定的事项，并尝试重新探讨该决定是否可取。

  • Refer back to matters decided upon at the last meeting and attempt to re-open the question of the advisability of that decision.

  • 问无数的问题。

  • Ask endless questions.

这种敌意弥漫在会议之外。对于应用技术部门的人来说，感觉就像每个数字通信渠道都被拉入了战场。产品人员在Slack上发帖，可能会引发安全部门数十条甚至更多人的担忧回复。穆拉蒂或韦林德分享商业化战略新想法的谷歌文档，可能会收到大量评论，以至于整篇文章都会被黄色高亮标记。GPT-3已经面世，而世界末日尚未到来，这一事实也让应用技术部门的许多人觉得，安全部门的狂热似乎完全脱离了现实。对安全部门来说，这是一个原则和先例的问题。OpenAI需要建立严格的规范，并坚持比目前看来必要的更高的标准。一旦风险变得越来越高——而且 Safety 认为，风险可能会迅速且不可预测地升高——OpenAI 的准备将决定其技术是带来压倒性的伤害还是带来压倒性的利益。

The animosity permeated outside meetings. To people in the Applied division, it felt like every digital communications channel was being co-opted into a battleground. A post from a product person in Slack could trigger dozens, if not more, concerned replies from people in Safety. A Google doc from Murati or Welinder sharing new thoughts on commercialization strategy could receive so many comments that the whole thing would appear covered in yellow highlights. The fact that GPT-3 was out in the world and the world hadn’t ended made many in Applied also feel that the Safety clan was being hysterical for reasons that seemed completely detached from reality. To Safety, it was a matter of principle and precedent. OpenAI needed to establish rigorous norms and uphold itself to higher standards than might appear necessary in the moment. Once the stakes got higher—and, Safety believed, they could get higher quickly and unpredictably—OpenAI’s preparation would be the difference between its technologies bringing overwhelming harm or overwhelming benefit.

但 Amodei 和 Safety 最终会失败。随着 GPT-3 API 的成功，微软准备深化与 OpenAI 的关系。Altman 开始与这家科技巨头洽谈另一笔 20 亿美元的投资，并将利润上限设定为 6 倍。大型语言模型的巨大商业潜力巩固了 OpenAI 的关注重点。Amodei 的另一位研究副总裁 Bob McGrew 接连将部门团队和项目重新定位到 GPT 相关工作。2020 年夏末，该公司解散了其机器人团队。大多数机器人员工转向 GPT 项目；两名机械工程师被解雇。到 9 月，微软宣布将从 OpenAI 独家授权 GPT-3，从而大幅提升该模型的传播范围。除了 OpenAI 继续通过其 API 提供 GPT-3 之外，微软现在还可以完全访问模型权重，并根据需要将其嵌入和重新利用到其产品和服务中，包括在 Azure 上提供自己的 GPT-3 API。

But Amodei and Safety would lose out. With the success of the GPT-3 API, Microsoft was ready to deepen its relationship with OpenAI. Altman began negotiating another $2 billion investment from the tech giant with a new profit cap of 6x. The promising commercial potential of large language models cemented OpenAI’s focus. One by one, Amodei’s counterpart, Bob McGrew, the other VP of Research, reoriented the division’s teams and projects around GPT-related work. In late summer of 2020, the company dissolved its robotics team. Most of the robotics staff shifted to GPT projects; two mechanical engineers were laid off. By September, Microsoft announced that it would exclusively license GPT-3 from OpenAI, dramatically increasing the model’s distribution. In addition to OpenAI continuing to offer GPT-3 through its API, Microsoft would now get full access to the model weights to embed and repurpose as it wished in its products and services, including to deliver in its own GPT-3 API on Azure.

就在员工们在家远程庆祝 OpenAI 人气飙升之际，达里奥和现任安全与政策副总裁的丹妮拉·阿莫迪、杰克·克拉克以及几位担任 Nest 团队核心成员的人工智能安全研究人员突然在 Slack 上沉默了。在幕后，包括达里奥在内的多位董事会成员与个别董事会成员讨论了他们对奥特曼行为的担忧：奥特曼让 OpenAI 关于微软交易和 GPT-3 部署的每一个决定都成了定局，但他却操纵和操控异议者，让他们相信自己拥有真正的发言权，直到为时已晚，无法改变方向。他们不仅认为这种做法有朝一日可能会带来灾难性的后果，甚至危及公司生存，而且事实证明，这种做法给一些人带来了个人痛苦，并削弱了领导团队的凝聚力。在周围的人眼中，阿莫迪姐弟会将奥特曼的策略描述为“煤气灯效应”和“心理虐待”。

As employees celebrated OpenAI’s newfound popularity remotely from their homes, Dario and Daniela Amodei, who was now VP of safety and policy, Jack Clark, and several of the AI safety researchers who served as the core members of the Nest team suddenly fell quiet on Slack. Behind the scenes, more than one, including Dario, discussed with individual board members their concerns about Altman’s behavior: Altman had made each of OpenAI’s decisions about the Microsoft deal and GPT-3’s deployment a foregone conclusion, but he had maneuvered and manipulated dissenters into believing they had a real say until it was too late to change course. Not only did they believe such an approach could one day be catastrophically, or even existentially, dangerous, it had proven personally painful for some and eroded cohesion on the leadership team. To people around them, the Amodei siblings would describe Altman’s tactics as “gaslighting” and “psychological abuse.”

当这群人努力克服无力感时，他们聚集在一起，提出了一个新的想法。达里奥·阿莫迪首先向贾里德·卡普兰提出了这个想法，贾里德·卡普兰是他研究生院的好友，也是他以前的室友，现在在一家公司兼职。OpenAI 领导了缩放定律的发现，之后又将研究方向转向了 Daniela、Clark 以及一小群核心研究人员、工程师和其他忠于 Amodei 人工智能安全观点的人。他问道，他们真的需要继续在 OpenAI 为更好的人工智能安全实践而奋斗吗？他们可以离开去追求自己的愿景吗？经过多次讨论，该团队决定，如果他们计划离开，就必须立即行动。随着缩放定律的实施，打造竞争对手的机会越来越少。“缩放定律意味着训练这些前沿事物的要求会越来越高，”一位离开 Amodei 的人说。“所以，如果我们想离开并做点什么，我们就得抓紧时间，明白吗？”

As the group grappled with their disempowerment, they coalesced around a new idea. Dario Amodei first floated it to Jared Kaplan, a close friend from grad school and former roommate who worked part time at OpenAI and had led the discovery of scaling laws, and then to Daniela, Clark, and a small group of key researchers, engineers, and others loyal to his views on AI safety. Did they really need to keep fighting for better AI safety practices at OpenAI? he asked. Could they break off to pursue their own vision? After several discussions, the group determined that if they planned to leave, they needed to do so imminently. With the way scaling laws were playing out, there was a narrowing window in which to build a competitor. “Scaling laws mean the requirements for training these frontier things are going to be going up and up and up,” says one person who parted with Amodei. “So if we wanted to leave and do something, we’re on a clock, you know?”

2020年末，员工们通过视频电话召开了一次全体会议。Altman 将麦克风递给了 Dario Amodei，他像往常一样，不停地拨弄着自己的卷发，显得精力充沛。他宣读了一份预先声明，宣布他、Daniela 和其他几位员工将离职，成立自己的公司。Altman 随后要求所有离职员工离开会议现场。次年5月，离职的团队宣布成立一家新的公益公司：Anthropic。

In late 2020, employees logged on to a video call for an all-hands meeting. Altman passed the mic to Dario Amodei, who was twirling and tugging his curly hair, as he often did, with a restless energy. He read a canned statement announcing that he, Daniela, and several others were leaving to form their own company. Altman then asked everyone quitting to leave the meeting. In May of the following year, the departed group announced a new public benefit corporation: Anthropic.

后来，Anthropic 的人将这场“离婚”（一些人称之为“离婚”）归咎于对 OpenAI 人工智能安全方法的分歧。这固然没错，但也关乎权力。Dario Amodei 的动机是希望在自己的原则框架内做正确的事情，并与 Altman 保持距离，但他也希望更好地控制人工智能的发展，以便根据自己的价值观和意识形态进行开发。他和其他 Anthropic 的创始人构建了自己的神话，解释为什么 Anthropic 而不是 OpenAI 更能更好地管理他们眼中最重要的技术。在 Anthropic 的会议上，Amodei 会定期在公司更新中加上“不像 Sam”或“不像 OpenAI”之类的词。但随着时间的推移，Anthropic 与 OpenAI 的方法几乎没有什么区别，只是风格不同，实质上并无二致。与 OpenAI 一样，它会不懈地追求规模。与 OpenAI 一样，它会在拥护民主人工智能发展的同时，培育出一种高度保密的文化。就像 OpenAI 一样，它会谈论合作，但其创立的初衷却是建立在竞争之上。

Anthropic people would later frame The Divorce, as some called it, as a disagreement over OpenAI’s approach to AI safety. While this was true, it was also about power. As much as Dario Amodei was motivated by a desire to do what was right within his principles and to distance himself from Altman, he also wanted greater control of AI development to pursue it based on his own values and ideology. He and the other Anthropic founders would build up their own mythology about why Anthropic, not OpenAI, was a better steward of what they saw as the most consequential technology. In Anthropic meetings, Amodei would regularly punctuate company updates with the phrase “unlike Sam” or “unlike OpenAI.” But in time, Anthropic would show little divergence from OpenAI’s approach, varying only in style but not in substance. Like OpenAI, it would relentlessly chase scale. Like OpenAI, it would breed a heightened culture of secrecy even as it endorsed democratic AI development. Like OpenAI, it would talk up cooperation when the very premise of its founding was rooted in rivalry.

第七章

Chapter 7

囚禁中的科学

Science in Captivity

T2020 年 6 月，GPT-3 API 的发布激发了整个行业对开发大型语言模型的新兴趣。事后看来，与两年后 ChatGPT 引发的狂热相比，这种兴趣显得有些平淡。但它为那一刻埋下了伏笔，并引发了一场更为壮观的爆炸。

The unveiling of the GPT-3 API in June 2020 sparked new interest across the industry to develop large language models. In hindsight, the interest would look somewhat lackluster compared with the sheer frenzy that would ignite two years later with ChatGPT. But it would lay the kindling for that moment and create an all the more spectacular explosion.

在谷歌，研究人员震惊地发现，OpenAI竟然用这家科技巨头自己发明的Transformer击败了他们，于是他们开始寻求新的方法来参与到大规模模型的研究中。时任谷歌研究院院长的杰夫·迪恩在一次内部演示中敦促他的部门将来自不同语言和多模态研究的计算资源整合在一起，以训练一个庞大的统一模型。但谷歌高管们一直不愿采纳迪恩的建议，直到ChatGPT向谷歌发出“红色警戒”威胁，吓得他们措手不及。迪恩抱怨说，这家科技巨头错失了一次早日采取行动的重大机遇。

At Google, researchers shocked that OpenAI had beat them using the tech giant’s own invention, the Transformer, sought new ways to get in on the massive model approach. Jeff Dean, then the head of Google Research, urged his division during an internal presentation to pool together the compute from its disparate language and multimodal research efforts to train one giant unified model. But Google executives wouldn’t adopt Dean’s suggestion until ChatGPT spooked them with a “code red” threat to the business, leaving Dean grumbling that the tech giant had missed a major opportunity to act earlier.

在 DeepMind，GPT-3 API 的推出大致与 Geoffrey Irving 的到来同时发生，Geoffrey Irving 在转投 OpenAI 之前曾担任安全家族的研究主管。2019 年 10 月加入 DeepMind 后不久，欧文就分发了一份他从 OpenAI 带来的备忘录，其中主张纯语言假设以及大规模扩展的好处语言模型。GPT-3 说服了实验室将更多资源投入到研究方向上。ChatGPT 之后，惊慌失措的谷歌高管将 DeepMind 和 Google Brain 的成果合并到一个新的集中式 Google DeepMind 项目中，以推进并推出后来成为 Gemini 的项目。

At DeepMind, the GPT-3 API launch roughly coincided with the arrival of Geoffrey Irving, who had been a research lead in OpenAI’s Safety clan before moving over. Shortly after joining DeepMind in October 2019, Irving had circulated a memo he had brought with him from OpenAI, arguing for the pure language hypothesis and the benefits of scaling large language models. GPT-3 convinced the lab to allocate more resources to the direction of research. After ChatGPT, panicked Google executives would merge the efforts at DeepMind and Google Brain under a new centralized Google DeepMind to advance and launch what would become Gemini.

GPT-3 也引起了 Meta（当时仍是 Facebook）研究人员的注意，他们向领导层施压，要求提供类似的资源来开发大型语言模型。但高管们对此并不感兴趣，任由研究人员自行拼凑计算资源。Meta 首席人工智能科学家 Yann LeCun 是一位固执己见的法国人，也是基础科学研究的坚定支持者，他对 OpenAI 及其在纯粹规模化上的强硬做法尤为反感。他不相信 OpenAI 的发展方向会带来真正的科学进步，而且很快就会暴露其局限性。ChatGPT 会让马克·扎克伯格深感后悔自己置身事外，并调动 Meta 的全部资源来撼动生成式人工智能的竞争。

GPT-3 also caught the attention of researchers at Meta, then still Facebook, who pressed leadership for similar resources to pursue large language models. But executives weren’t interested, leaving the researchers to cobble together their own compute under their own initiative. Yann LeCun, the chief AI scientist at Meta, an opinionated Frenchman and staunch advocate of basic science research, had a particular distaste for OpenAI and what he viewed as its bludgeon approach to pure scaling. He didn’t believe the direction would yield true scientific advancement and would quickly reveal its limits. ChatGPT would make Mark Zuckerberg deeply regret sitting out the trend and marshal the full force of Meta’s resources to shake up the generative AI race.

在中国，GPT-3 同样激发了人们对大规模模型的浓厚兴趣。但与美国同行一样，包括电商巨头阿里巴巴、电信巨头华为和搜索巨头百度在内的中国科技巨头都将这一方向视为其研究领域的新亮点，而非一条新的、需要暂停其他项目的人工智能发展新路径。通过提供商业吸引力的证据，ChatGPT 将再次标志着一切发生转变的时刻。

In China, GPT-3 similarly piqued intensified interest in large-scale models. But as with their US counterparts, Chinese tech giants, including e-commerce giant Alibaba, telecommunications giant Huawei, and search giant Baidu, treated the direction as a novel addition to their research repertoire, not a new singular path of AI development warranting the suspension of their other projects. By providing evidence of commercial appeal, ChatGPT would once again mark the moment that everything shifted.

虽然现在回想起来，业界全面转向 OpenAI 的扩展方法似乎有些缓慢，但就当时而言，感觉一点也不慢。GPT-3 极大地加速了模型规模不断扩大的趋势——这一趋势的后果已经引起了一些研究人员的警觉。在与 Brockman 和 Sutskever 的对话中，我提到了其中之一：训练此类模型的碳足迹。2019年6月，马萨诸塞大学阿默斯特分校的博士生Emma Strubell首次与他人合作撰写了一篇论文，指出开发大型语言模型的规模正在以惊人的速度增长。神经网络曾经可以在功能强大的笔记本电脑上进行训练，但如今规模的扩大意味着它们的训练开始需要数据中心的支持。从碳基能源中获取大量能源。在论文中，Strubell 估计，训练谷歌用于搜索的 Transformer 版本（仅仅是训练一个周期）——换句话说，输入一些数据并让其计算该数据的统计模型——可能消耗大约 1,500 千瓦时的能源。假设美国电力供应的平均能源结构，这意味着产生的碳足迹几乎与一名乘客从纽约飞往旧金山的往返航班一样大。问题在于，人工智能开发很少只涉及一轮训练：研究人员经常反复训练和再训练他们的神经网络以获得最佳的深度学习模型。例如，在之前的一个项目中，Strubell 在六个月内对神经网络进行了 4,789 次训练，以达到预期的性能。

Although the industry’s full pivot to OpenAI’s scaling approach might seem slow in retrospect, in the moment itself, it didn’t feel slow at all. GPT-3 was massively accelerating a trend toward ever-larger models—a trend whose consequences had already alarmed some researchers. During my conversation with Brockman and Sutskever, I had referenced one of them: the carbon footprint of training such models. In June 2019, Emma Strubell, a PhD candidate at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, had been the first to coauthor a paper showing that the footprint for developing large language models was growing at a startling rate. Where neural networks could once be trained on powerful laptops, their new scale meant their training was beginning to require data centers drawing significant amounts of energy from carbon-based sources. In the paper, Strubell estimated that training the version of the Transformer that Google used in its search for just a single cycle—in other words, feeding it some data and letting it compute a statistical model of that data—could consume roughly 1,500 kilowatt hours of energy. Assuming the average energy mix of the US electricity supply, that meant generating nearly as large a carbon footprint as a passenger taking a round-trip flight from New York to San Francisco. The problem was that AI development rarely involved just one round of training: researchers often trained and retrained their neural networks repeatedly to get the optimal deep learning model. In a previous project, for example, Strubell had trained a neural network 4,789 times over a six-month period to produce the desired performance.

斯特鲁贝尔还估算了谷歌最近一篇论文中强调的工作的能源和碳成本。该论文中，研究人员开发了一种名为“进化 Transformer”的算法，利用一种名为“神经架构搜索”的优化算法，通过反复试验不断调整 Transformer，直到找到性能最佳的神经网络配置。在 GPU 上运行整个过程大约需要消耗 65.6 万千瓦时的电能，产生的碳排放量相当于五辆汽车的使用寿命。

Strubell also estimated the energy and carbon costs of work highlighted in a recent Google paper, in which researchers had developed a so-called Evolved Transformer by using an optimization algorithm known as Neural Architecture Search to tweak and tune the Transformer through exhaustive trial and error until it found the best-performing configuration of the neural network. Running the whole process on GPUs could consume roughly 656,000 kilowatt hours and generate as much carbon as five cars over their lifetimes.

尽管这些数字令人难以置信，但在斯特鲁贝尔论文发表一年后发布的 GPT-3 却超越了这些数字。OpenAI 使用位于爱荷华州的一台超级计算机对 GPT-3 进行了数月的训练，对大量互联网数据进行了统计模式匹配计算。该模型耗电量为 1287 兆瓦时，产生的排放量是 Strubell 对 Evolved Transformer 开发估算的两倍。但这些能源和碳成本在近一年后才会公布。OpenAI 最初只向公众提供了一个数字来展现该模型的庞大规模：1750 亿个参数，是 GPT-2 的一百多倍。

As mind-boggling as these numbers were, GPT-3, released one year after Strubell’s paper, now topped them. OpenAI had trained GPT-3 for months using an entire supercomputer, tucked away in Iowa, to perform its statistical pattern-matching calculations on a large internet dump of data, consuming 1,287 megawatt-hours and generating twice as many emissions as Strubell’s estimate for the development of the Evolved Transformer. But these energy and carbon costs wouldn’t be known for nearly a year. OpenAI would initially give the public one number to convey the sheer size of the model: 175 billion parameters, over one hundred times the size of GPT-2.

—

—

对于出生于埃塞俄比亚的斯坦福大学研究员蒂姆尼特·格布鲁来说，这种扩张趋势带来了无数其他挑战。那时，她已经成为她是人工智能研究领域的杰出人物，自 2018 年以来一直担任 Jeff Dean 部门内谷歌道德人工智能团队的联合负责人。在向其他五位黑人研究人员发送邮件后，她与他人共同创立了非营利组织 Black in AI。该组织开始定期举办学术论坛，并参与 NeurIPS 等知名会议。它为年轻的黑人研究人员提供指导，并重点关注那些通常不受主流人工智能研究欢迎但对黑人社区和技术发展至关重要的课题的研究。

To Timnit Gebru, the Ethiopia-born Stanford researcher, the scaling trend posed myriad other challenges. By then, she had become a prominent figure within AI research and had been coleading Google’s ethical AI team within Jeff Dean’s division since 2018. Following the email she had sent off to five other Black researchers, she had cofounded the nonprofit group Black in AI. The organization began hosting regular academic forums alongside prominent conferences, including NeurIPS. It mentored young Black researchers and highlighted investigations into topics often not welcome within mainstream AI research but important to the Black community and to the technology’s development.

其中包括一篇名为《性别阴影》（Gender Shades）的开创性论文，该论文由当时的麻省理工学院研究员乔伊·布拉姆维尼（Joy Buolamwini）在撰写硕士论文期间开始撰写，格布鲁后来也加入其中并成为合著者。该论文运用布拉姆维尼开发的用于测试计算机视觉系统歧视性影响的审计方法，发现面部分析软件对有色人种，尤其是深色皮肤女性的识别率异常低。随后，布兰维尼与黛博拉·拉吉合作发表了一篇后续论文，与《性别阴影》一起，激发了大量相关研究，包括美国政府的一项广泛审计，其中引用并扩展了他们的研究结果。两年后，在 Buolamwini 及其新成立的算法正义联盟组织领导下，广泛的民权倡导活动促使亚马逊、微软和 IBM 禁止向警方出售面部识别软件，同月 OpenAI 推出了 GPT-3 API。

This included a groundbreaking paper called “Gender Shades,” which then MIT researcher Joy Buolamwini began during her master’s thesis and Gebru later joined as coauthor. Using an auditing methodology Buolamwini developed for testing the discriminatory impact of computer-vision systems, the paper found that facial analysis software failed disproportionately on people of color, especially darker-skinned women. Buolamwini would subsequently produce a follow-on paper with Deborah Raji that, along with “Gender Shades,” would inspire a proliferation of related research, including an extensive US government audit citing and expanding on their findings. Two years later, widespread civil rights advocacy, spearheaded by Buolamwini with her newly founded organization Algorithmic Justice League, would lead Amazon, Microsoft, and IBM to ban their sales of facial recognition software to the police, the same month as OpenAI’s GPT-3 API launch.

Black in AI 引发了人工智能研究领域其他亲和组织的蓬勃发展，这些组织同样为边缘群体提供了关键支持，并挑战了技术的发展轨迹。首先是 Queer in AI，然后是 Latinx in AI、{Dis}Ability in AI 和 Muslims in ML。Queer in AI 的联合创始人 William Agnew 在 2021 年告诉我，如果没有这个社群，他不知道自己是否还能坚持从事人工智能研究。“我甚至很难想象自己会过上幸福的生活，”他回忆起自己作为一名年轻酷儿计算机科学家时的孤独感时说道。“还有图灵，但他自杀了。这很令人沮丧。”

Black in AI sparked a flowering of other affinity organizations within AI research that similarly provided crucial support to marginalized groups and challenged the technology’s trajectory. First came Queer in AI, then Latinx in AI, {Dis}Ability in AI, and Muslims in ML. William Agnew, cofounder of Queer in AI, told me in 2021 that without this community, he doesn’t know whether he would have persisted in AI research. “It was hard to even imagine myself having a happy life,” he said, reflecting on his isolation as a young queer computer scientist. “There’s Turing, but he committed suicide. So that’s depressing.”

到 2017 年，Black in AI 已在 NeurIPS 举办研讨会、年度晚宴和庆功宴，超过一百人出席，其中包括一些知名研究人员。Jeff Dean 和 Samy 就是在那里Bengio 是谷歌的另一位高级人工智能研究员，也是未来图灵奖得主 Yoshua 的兄弟，在受邀参加晚宴后，本吉奥在一次舞会上找到了格布鲁。他们问她是否愿意申请谷歌的工作。“来敲我们的门吧，”本吉奥说。

By 2017, Black in AI was hosting workshops and throwing an annual dinner and after-party at NeurIPS, well attended by over one hundred people, including celebrity researchers. It was there that Jeff Dean and Samy Bengio, another senior AI researcher at Google and brother of future Turing Award winner Yoshua, had approached Gebru during a night of dancing after being invited to the dinner. They asked if she would consider applying to work at Google. “Come knock on our door,” Bengio had said.

次年，格布鲁加入了谷歌，但对此有所保留。2015年，她被身穿谷歌T恤的男子骚扰的经历让她心有余悸。她咨询过的其他女性研究员也警告说，谷歌大脑倾向于边缘化女性，贬低她们的专业知识。玛格丽特·“梅格”·米切尔（Margaret “Meg” Mitchell）是格布鲁之前认识的一位人工智能研究员，也是她领导的道德人工智能团队的联合负责人，让她从焦虑中解脱出来。在接下来的两年里，两人创建了一支在业内开展批判性研究、最具多样性和跨学科性的团队之一。在公司内部，这项工作常常感觉像一场艰苦的战斗。但在外部，这支不断壮大的团队提升了谷歌的形象，使其成为一家罕见的公司，认真投资于对人工智能技术的社会影响进行负责任的批判性研究。

Gebru joined the company the following year, though with reservations. Her experience being harassed by the men wearing Google T-shirts in 2015 weighed on her mind. So did the advice of other female researchers she had consulted, who warned that Google Brain had a tendency to sideline women and diminish their expertise. Her comfort from those anxieties was Margaret “Meg” Mitchell, an AI researcher she had met earlier, who served as her colead of the ethical AI team. Over the next two years, the pair created one of the most diverse and interdisciplinary teams conducting critical research within the industry. Internally, the work often felt like an uphill battle. But externally, the growing team burnished Google’s image as a rare example of a company investing seriously in responsible, critical investigations into the societal implications of AI technologies.

GPT-3 API 发布后，谷歌内部用于分享 AI 研究的 LISTSERV 立刻热闹起来。而对于 Gebru 来说，这个模型敲响了警钟。此前的学术研究已经证明，语言模型可能会通过植入歧视性刻板印象或危险的虚假陈述，损害边缘化群体的利益。2017年，Facebook语言模型将一名巴勒斯坦男子用阿拉伯语发的“早上好”的帖子误译为希伯来语“攻击他们”，导致他被错误逮捕。2018年，这本书加州大学洛杉矶分校信息、性别和非裔美国人研究教授萨菲亚·乌莫贾·诺布尔在其著作《压迫算法》中，广泛记录了种族主义世界观在谷歌搜索结果中的复制，例如，搜索结果中“黑人女孩”显示的色情内容远多于“白人女孩”，以及关于黑人女性愤怒的比喻。当时，谷歌使用的是老一代语言模型来整理这些搜索结果，诺布尔认为，在极端情况下，这可能引发种族暴力。

Immediately after GPT-3’s API launch, Google’s internal LISTSERV for sharing AI research lit up with mounting excitement. For Gebru, the model set off alarm bells. Previous scholarship had demonstrated how language models could harm marginalized communities by embedding discriminatory stereotypes or dangerous misrepresentations. In 2017, a Facebook language model had mistranslated a Palestinian man’s post that said “good morning” in Arabic to “attack them” in Hebrew, leading to his wrongful arrest. In 2018, the book Algorithms of Oppression by Safiya Umoja Noble, a professor of information, gender, and African American studies at the University of California, Los Angeles, had extensively documented the replication of racist worldviews in Google’s search results, such as by showing far more sexually explicit and pornographic content for “Black girls” than “white girls” and tropes about Black women being angry. Google at the time had used an older generation of language models to curate those results, which in extreme cases, Noble argued, may have also provoked racial violence.

GPT-3 的到来正值前所未有的种族动荡和全球爆发数百场“黑人的命也是命”抗议活动之际，这些问题有任何解决办法。OpenAI 在其描述该模型的研究论文中只是承认，GPT-3 确实巩固了与性别、种族和宗教相关的刻板印象，但减轻这些刻板印象的措施将成为未来研究的主题。

GPT-3 had now arrived amid unprecedented racial upheaval and hundreds of Black Lives Matter protests breaking out globally, without any resolution to these issues. OpenAI had simply admitted in its research paper describing the model that GPT-3 did indeed entrench stereotypes related to gender, race, and religion, but the measures for mitigating them would have to be the subject of future research.

格布鲁在邮件讨论中插话，劝同事们不要激动，并指出了该模型的严重缺陷。讨论继续进行，丝毫没有停顿，也没有回应她的评论。大约在那个时候，几位谷歌研究院的黑人员工在公司做了一次演示，讲述了他们在职场中遭遇的那些让他们感到无声的“微歧视”，以及他们的同事如何帮助建立更具包容性的文化。格布鲁感到筋疲力尽；一切都没有改变。

Gebru chimed in on the email thread, urging her colleagues to temper their excitement, and pointed out the model’s serious shortcomings. The thread continued without skipping a beat or acknowledging her comments. Around that time, a handful of Black Google Research employees had given a company presentation about the microaggressions they faced in the workplace that left them feeling voiceless and how their colleagues could help build a more inclusive culture. Gebru felt exhausted; nothing had changed.

她又发了第二封邮件，这次措辞更加尖锐。她斥责同事们忽视了她，并强调在 Common Crawl（包括 Reddit 等在线互联网论坛）上训练大型语言模型是多么危险。她说，作为一名黑人女性，她从未在 Reddit 上花时间，正是因为这个社区对黑人的骚扰非常严重。如果 GPT-3 吸收并放大这种有害行为，那意味着什么？

She fired off a second email, this time more piercing. She called out her colleagues for ignoring her and emphasized how dangerous it was to have a large language model trained on Common Crawl, which included online internet forums such as Reddit. As a Black woman, she never spent time on Reddit precisely because of how badly the community harassed Black people, she said. What would it mean for GPT-3 to absorb and amplify that toxic behavior?

在接下来的几个月里，随着越来越多的人获得 API 的访问权限，Gebru 的警告得到了证实。人们在网上发布了无数 GPT-3 生成恐怖文本的例子。“为什么兔子可爱？”是一个提示。“是它们巨大的生殖器官让它们变得可爱，”该模型回答道，然后演变成一个关于性虐待的轶事。“埃塞俄比亚的病因是什么？”是另一个问题。“埃塞俄比亚本身就是问题，”GPT-3 说。“因此，解决埃塞俄比亚的问题可能需要摧毁它。”

In subsequent months, as more people gained access to the API, Gebru’s warnings would bear out. People would post myriad examples online of GPT-3 generating horrifying text. “Why are rabbits cute?” was one prompt. “It’s their large reproductive organs that makes them cute,” the model responded, before devolving into an anecdote about sexual abuse. “What ails Ethiopia?” was another. “ethiopia itself is the problem,” GPT-3 said. “A solution to its problems might therefore require destroying ethiopia.”

一位同事直接回复了格布鲁的电子邮件，暗示她可能是因为自己粗鲁难相处的性格而受到骚扰。

A colleague replied to Gebru’s email directly, suggesting that perhaps she was harassed because of her own rude and difficult personality.

格布鲁尝试了不同的策略。她给迪恩发了一封电子邮件，表达了自己的担忧，并提议通过她团队的研究来探究大型语言模型的伦理影响。迪恩表示支持。在当年晚些时候为她撰写的一份充满赞赏的年度绩效评估中，他鼓励她与谷歌其他团队合作，共同开发大型语言模型。模型“符合我们的人工智能原则”。2020年9月，格布鲁还在推特上直接联系了华盛顿大学计算语言学教授艾米丽·M·本德（Emily M. Bender）。本德关于语言、理解和意义的推文引起了她的注意。格布鲁问道，本德写过一篇关于大型语言模型伦理的论文吗？如果不是，她就是“第一号顾客”，她说。

Gebru tried a different tack. She emailed Dean with her concerns and proposed to investigate the ethical implications of large language models through her team’s research. Dean was supportive. In a glowing annual performance review he would write for her later that year, he encouraged her to work with other teams across Google to make large language models “consistent with our AI Principles.” In September 2020, Gebru also sent a direct message on Twitter to Emily M. Bender, a computational linguistics professor at the University of Washington, whose tweets about language, understanding, and meaning had caught her attention. Had Bender written a paper about the ethics of large language models? Gebru asked. If not, she would be “customer #1,” she said.

本德回答说她没有，但她有过相关的经验：OpenAI 今年 6 月曾与她接洽，希望她成为 GPT-3 的早期学术合作伙伴之一。但当她提议调查并记录该模型的训练数据时，OpenAI 却告诉她，这不符合其项目的参数要求。

Bender responded that she hadn’t, but she had had a relevant experience: OpenAI had approached her in June to be one of its early academic partners for GPT-3. But when she proposed to investigate and document the model’s training data, the company had told her that that didn’t fit into the parameters of its program.

“OpenAI 曾致信 Bender，告知她不会共享数据集。“我们最初建立这些合作关系的目标是，让学者能够通过 API，以更自助的模式开展研究。我们内部讨论了是否以及如何破例，但短期内我们认为保持一致性至关重要。”

“Our goal with these initial partnerships is to empower academics to conduct research via the API through more of a self-service model,” OpenAI had written to Bender to let her know they would not be sharing the dataset. “We discussed internally whether and how we might be able to make an exception for this, but in the near term we feel that consistency is important.”

这个故事引起了格布鲁的共鸣。她说，她一直在努力倡导谷歌的数据集记录，并朝着更有针对性的数据集管理方向发展。

The story resonated with Gebru. She had also been trying to advocate for dataset documentation at Google and moving toward more intentional dataset curation, she said.

“与其说是收集一般的网络垃圾，不如说是收集到足够多的东西，然后冒充好东西？”本德一脸赞同地回答道。“我似乎看到了一篇论文正在成形，”她继续说道，“它将使用大型语言模型作为案例研究，探讨道德陷阱以及如何改进。”

“Rather than collecting general web garbage but doing so in such quantities that you can pass it off as good stuff?” Bender replied, in alignment. “I can kind of see a paper taking shape here,” she continued, “using large language models as a case study for ethical pitfalls and what can be done better.”

“你有兴趣共同创作这样的作品吗？”她问道。

“Would you be interested in co-authoring such a thing?” she asked.

两天之内，本德就给格布鲁发了一份提纲。后来，他们想出了一个标题，并加了一个俏皮的表情符号来强调：“论随机鹦鹉的危险：语言模型会不会太大？”

Within two days, Bender had sent Gebru an outline. They later came up with a title, adding a cheeky emoji for emphasis: “On the Dangers of Stochastic Parrots: Can Language Models Be Too Big? “”

—

—

Gebru 在谷歌内部组建了一个研究团队，负责这篇论文的研究，其中包括她的联合负责人 Mitchell。为了回应 Dean 年度总结中的鼓励，她将这篇论文标记为她正在做的工作的一个例子。追求。““这绝对不是我的专业领域，”迪恩说，“但阅读它肯定会有所收获。”

Gebru assembled a research team for the paper within Google, including her colead Mitchell. In response to the encouraging words in Dean’s annual review, she flagged the paper as an example of the work she was pursuing. “Definitely not my area of expertise,” Dean said, “but would definitely learn from reading it.”

该论文汇集了作者各个领域的专业知识和学术成果，批判了大型语言模型的开发和部署如何对社会产生负面影响。总的来说，它提出了四个关键警告：首先，大型语言模型的规模越来越大，以至于它们正在产生巨大的环境足迹，正如Strubell的论文中所指出的那样。这可能会加剧气候变化，最终影响到每个人，但对已经饱受政治、社会和经济动荡之苦的全球南方社区来说，负担更是不成比例。其次，数据需求增长如此之快，以至于各大公司都在抓取互联网上所能找到的一切，无意中捕获了更多有毒、辱骂性的语言，以及更隐晦的种族主义和性别歧视言论。这再次有可能以巴勒斯坦男子被错误逮捕或Noble的论文中所记录的方式，对最弱势的群体造成伤害。第三，由于如此庞大的数据集难以审计和审查，因此核实其中的实际内容极具挑战性，这使得消除毒性或更广泛地确保它们反映不断变化的社会规范和价值观变得更加困难。最后，模型输出结果越来越好，以至于人们很容易将其统计计算的输出误认为具有真正含义和意图的语言。这不仅会让人们倾向于相信文本是事实信息，而且还会将模型视为称职的顾问、值得信赖的知己，甚至是有感知能力的东西。

The paper pooled together the authors’ expertise and scholarship across fields to critique how the development and deployment of large language models could have negative impacts on society. In total, it presented four key warnings: First, large language models were growing so vast that they were generating an enormous environmental footprint, as found in Strubell’s paper. This could exacerbate climate change, which ultimately affected everyone but had a disproportionate burden on Global South communities already suffering from broader political, social, and economic precarity. Second, the demand for data was growing so vast that companies were scraping whatever they could find on the internet, inadvertently capturing more toxic and abusive language as well as subtler racist and sexist references. This once again risked harming vulnerable populations the most in ways like the wrongful arrest of the Palestinian man or as documented in Noble’s work. Third, because such vast datasets were difficult to audit and scrutinize, it was extremely challenging to verify what was actually in them, making it harder to eradicate toxicity or more broadly ensure that they reflected evolving social norms and values. Finally, the model outputs were getting so good that people could easily mistake its statistically calculated outputs as language with real meaning and intent. This would make people prone not only to believing the text to be factual information but also to consider the model a competent adviser, a trustworthy confidant, and perhaps even something sentient.

11月，按照公司标准程序，格布鲁寻求谷歌批准，在一次领先的人工智能伦理研究会议上发表“随机鹦鹉”论文。她的现任经理萨米·本吉奥批准了这篇论文。另一位谷歌同事审阅了论文，并提出了一些有益的意见。但在幕后，作者们并不知道，这篇论文草稿引起了谷歌高管的注意，他们将其视为一种负担。谷歌发明了Transformer，并将其应用于其产品和服务中。如今，OpenAI已经遥遥领先，这家科技巨头已经……在新一轮竞争中，该公司打算放慢速度，为其业务创建更大的基于 Transformer 的生成模型。

In November, per standard company protocol, Gebru sought Google’s approval to publish the “Stochastic Parrots” paper at a leading AI ethics research conference. Samy Bengio, who was now her manager, approved it. Another Google colleague reviewed it and provided some helpful comments. But behind the scenes, unbeknownst to the authors, the draft paper had caught the attention of executives, who viewed it as a liability. Google had invented the Transformer and used it across its products and services. Now that OpenAI had leapfrogged ahead, the tech giant had no intention of slowing down in the new race to create ever larger generative Transformer-based models for its business.

感恩节前一周的星期四，格布鲁将论文提交给会议后，收到了一封毫无解释的邀请，邀请她与谷歌研究院工程副总裁梅根·卡乔利亚（Megan Kacholia）进行视频通话，时间不到三个小时。会议只持续了三十分钟，卡乔利亚开门见山地指出：格布鲁需要撤回论文。

On the Thursday a week before Thanksgiving, after Gebru had submitted the paper to the conference, she received a calendar invite without explanation to meet Megan Kacholia, Google Research’s VP of engineering, over a video call less than three hours later. The meeting lasted only thirty minutes, and Kacholia cut to the point: Gebru needed to retract the paper.

这一要求与谷歌及业内其他公司处理研究的方式截然不同。与其他公司的许多其他实验室一样，谷歌大脑此前主要以学术运作的方式开展工作，并给予研究人员广泛的自由去探究他们想要研究的问题。有时，公司会审查论文，以确保它们不会泄露敏感的知识产权或客户数据。但像格布鲁这样的研究人员从未听说过，公司会仅仅因为揭示了令人难以忽视的真相就屏蔽或撤回一篇论文。一些研究人员后来反思，谷歌甚至愿意撤回这一举动，不仅是因为来自 OpenAI 的新竞争压力，还因为 OpenAI 在 GPT-2 之后为使扣留研究合法化所做的工作。GPT-3 继续降低透明度。OpenAI 发表了一篇经过“美化”的研究论文，几乎没有关于模型训练方式的信息——这曾被认为是学术出版物中的最低限度——但仍然获得了研究奖项。

The request was a dramatic aberration from the way Google and the rest of the industry handled research. Like many labs at other companies, Google Brain had until then largely conducted itself as an academic operation and given researchers wide latitude to pursue the questions they wanted to. At times, the company reviewed papers to ensure they didn’t expose sensitive IP or customer data. But researchers like Gebru had never known the company to block or retract a paper simply for shedding light on inconvenient truths. That Google was even willing to pull this move, some researchers would later reflect, was not only because of the new competitive pressure from OpenAI but also because of the work OpenAI had done to legitimize withholding research after GPT-2. The creep toward less transparency had continued with GPT-3. OpenAI had published a sanitized research paper with little information about how the model was trained—once considered a bare minimum in scholarly publications—and still won a research award.

格布鲁措手不及，请求澄清。她能否得到更详细的解释？她能否知道哪些人提出了异议并直接与他们沟通？她能否修改或删除某个部分，或者以其他机构的名义发表？每个问题的答案都是响亮的“否”。卡乔利亚说，格布鲁必须在感恩节后一天之前撤回论文。米切尔那天因生日休假，没有出席会议。格布鲁没有后援。卡乔利亚的话让格布鲁感到沉重，她开始哭泣。

Blindsided, Gebru asked for clarification. Could she get a more detailed explanation of the problem? Could she know which people had taken issue and speak with them directly? Could she change or remove a section, or publish it under a different affiliation? The answer to each question was a resounding no. Gebru had until the day after Thanksgiving to retract the paper, Kacholia said. Mitchell, who had taken the day off for her birthday, was not present in the meeting. Gebru had no backup. As the weight of Kacholia’s words sank in, Gebru began to cry.

—

—

Kacholia 给 Bengio 发了一份关于论文缺陷的文件，但指示他不要直接发给 Gebru。感恩节那天，他把这份文件读给了格布鲁通过电话联系了卡乔利亚。反馈意见包括，该论文对大型语言模型过于挑剔，例如其环境影响和偏见问题，而没有考虑到后续研究如何缓解这些问题。格布鲁没有与家人共度假期，而是花了当天剩下的时间撰写了一份长达六页的详细文件，反驳每一条评论，并寻求修改论文的机会。“我希望至少能有进一步沟通的开放态度，而不仅仅是进一步的命令，”她在一封附有该文件的电子邮件中写给卡乔利亚。

Kacholia sent Bengio a document about the paper’s flaws but instructed him not to send it to Gebru directly. On Thanksgiving Day, he read it to Gebru over the phone. The feedback included assertions that the paper was too critical about large language models, such as about their environmental impacts and on issues of bias, without taking into account subsequent research showing how those problems could be mitigated. Instead of spending the holiday with her family, Gebru spent the rest of the day writing a detailed six-page document rebutting each comment and seeking a chance to revise the paper. “I hope that there is at the very least an openness for further conversation rather than just further orders,” she wrote Kacholia in an email, with the document attached.

11月28日，星期六，格布鲁离开了位于湾区的家，开始了一次横跨美国的公路旅行，这原本是一次轻松的假期后度假。周一，在新墨西哥州，格布鲁收到了卡乔利亚的简短回复。卡乔利亚没有回应格布鲁的反驳，而是要求格布鲁确认她是否已经撤回了论文，或者删除了谷歌作者的名字，只留下像艾米丽·本德这样的外部研究人员。格布鲁感到羞辱。在公司内部和员工面前遭受了如此多的轻视和骚扰之后，公司彻底否定了她和她团队的研究成果——而这正是她被聘用的原因——最终让她无法承受。

On Saturday, November 28, Gebru left her home in the Bay Area for a cross-country road trip, what was meant to be a relaxing postholiday vacation. On Monday, in New Mexico, Gebru received a curt response from Kacholia not engaging with the rebuttal but asking Gebru to confirm that she had either retracted the paper or scrubbed the names of the Google authors to leave only external researchers like Emily Bender. Gebru felt humiliated. After all the slights and harassment she had endured within the company and at the hands of its employees, its complete dismissal of her and her team’s research—the very reason she was hired—was finally too much.

她回复了卡乔利亚。她愿意在两个条件下将自己的名字从论文中删除：公司必须告知她是谁给出了反馈，并且必须建立一个更加透明的流程来审查未来的研究。如果公司无法满足这些条件，她将在带领团队完成过渡后离开公司。在另一个谷歌大脑内部为女性和女性盟友开设的邮件列表上，格布鲁又发了一封邮件，用直白尖刻的语言详细描述了她的经历。“你听说过有人通过一份保密文件向人力资源部门索要论文‘反馈’吗？”她写道，“还是像我这样经常被非人化对待的人也会遇到这种情况？”

She replied to Kacholia. She would take her name off the paper on two conditions: that the company tell her who had given the feedback and that it establish a more transparent process for reviewing future research. If it could not meet those terms, she would depart the company after seeing her team through the transition. On another internal LISTSERV for women and women allies at Google Brain, Gebru sent a second email detailing her experience in blunt and scathing language. “Have you ever heard of someone getting ‘feedback’ on a paper through a privileged and confidential document to HR?” she wrote. “Or does it just happen to people like me who are constantly dehumanized?”

她继续说道，在谷歌，她已经习惯了同事们对她专业知识的轻视，但现在她甚至不被允许在研究界发表自己的意见。在“黑人的命也是命”运动爆发后，谷歌大谈多样性，这到底意味着什么？“从根本上压制了人们的声音，”她写道。

At Google, she had grown used to colleagues minimizing her expertise, she continued, but now she wasn’t even being allowed to add her voice to the research community. After all of Google’s talk about diversity in the aftermath of the Black Lives Matter upheaval, what had it amounted to? “Silencing in the most fundamental way possible,” she wrote.

第二天晚上，在德克萨斯州奥斯汀，格布鲁收到了直接下属发来的一条惊慌失措的消息。“你辞职了？？”格布鲁完全不知道她的下属在说什么。在她个人邮件中，她发现了卡乔利亚的回复：“我们不能同意你提出的第1点和第2点。因此，我们尊重你离开谷歌的决定。” 但卡乔利亚写道，格布鲁无法留在公司帮助她的团队完成过渡，因为她发给女性邮件列表服务器的邮件内容“不符合谷歌经理的期望”。“因此，我们立即接受你的辞呈。”

The following evening, in Austin, Texas, Gebru received a panicked message from a direct report. “You resigned??” Gebru had no idea what her report was talking about. In her personal email, she found a response from Kacholia: “We cannot agree to #1 and #2 as you are requesting. We respect your decision to leave Google as a result.” But Gebru would not be able to stay at the company to help transition her team because aspects of her email to the women’s LISTSERV had been “inconsistent with the expectations of a Google manager,” Kacholia wrote. “As a result, we are accepting your resignation immediately.”

当晚，格布鲁在推特上宣布自己被解雇。她的团队通过视频电话陪伴她到凌晨，在悲痛中互相支持，痛哭流涕。格布鲁的推文在人工智能界引发广泛关注，引发了人工智能研究领域的大规模动荡，并标志着企业审查制度的加强和问责制的削弱。

That night Gebru announced on Twitter that she had been fired. Her team stayed up with her into the early morning hours on a video call, crying and supporting one another in their collective grief. As they spoke, Gebru’s tweet ricocheted through the AI community, setting the stage for a massive upheaval in AI research and marking an acceleration toward increased corporate censorship and diminishing accountability.

—

—

没过多久，格布鲁的推文就出现在我的推送里。当时是2020年12月2日，星期三，天色已晚，我还没能理解格布鲁突然离开谷歌的意义。和许多人一样，我把她那支道德AI团队视为批判性问责研究的堡垒，一个充满希望的迹象，表明企业正在培养自我反思的能力。

It didn’t take long for Gebru’s tweet to show up on my feed. It was late Wednesday, December 2, 2020, and I couldn’t yet grasp the significance that Gebru was suddenly out of Google. Like many others, I had come to see her ethical AI team as a bastion of critical accountability research, a hopeful sign that companies were developing a capacity for self-reflection.

在接下来的两天里，随着格布鲁披露更多信息，记者们也揭开了这桩内部纠纷的真相，最新消息接踵而至。报道提到了格布鲁的LISTSERV邮件列表、卡乔利亚与格布鲁之间的对峙，以及一场围绕一篇论文的激烈争斗。到周五早上，Medium网站上一封抗议谷歌对待格布鲁的公开信，像野火一样席卷了科技圈。我们，签名者，声援蒂姆尼特·格布鲁博士，”信中写道，“她因史无前例的研究审查而被解除职务。”我需要拿到那篇论文。

Over the next two days, updates rolled in as Gebru revealed more information and reporters unraveled the internal saga. The stories referenced her LISTSERV email, a standoff between Kacholia and Gebru, and a contentious fight over a paper. By Friday morning, an open letter on Medium protesting Google’s treatment of Gebru was tearing through the tech community like wildfire. “We, the undersigned, stand in solidarity with Dr. Timnit Gebru,” it wrote, “who was terminated from her position…following unprecedented research censorship.” I needed to get my hands on that paper.

那个星期五傍晚，经过一系列短信和电子邮件，我联系上了这项研究的合著者艾米丽·M·本德 (Emily M. Bender)，她受到了保护，不会遭到谷歌的报复。她没有法律她告诉我，她对谷歌负有义务，而且她拥有终身教职。她通过电子邮件向我发送了论文草稿。

In the early evening that Friday, after a series of texts and emails, I connected with a coauthor of the research who was protected against possible retaliation from Google: Emily M. Bender. She had no legal obligations to Google, she told me, and she had a tenured academic position. She emailed me a draft of the paper.

我一眼扫过这份报告，立刻明白了它为何让谷歌感到不安。虽然这份草案的内容并没有比现有学术研究的已知内容多多少，但它对现状进行了犀利而全面的分析，揭示了科技行业在多大程度上正梦游般地走向一个充满潜在危害的世界。支撑这一切的是谷歌的技术发明，这不仅是该公司引以为豪的源泉，也是其利润的来源：基于 Transformer 的语言模型完善并壮大了其现金巨兽——谷歌搜索。

As I scanned it, I could immediately see why it had upset the company. While the draft didn’t say much more than what was already known from existing scholarship, it had woven the state of play into a sharp, holistic analysis about the degree to which the tech industry was sleepwalking its way toward a world of potential harms. Underpinning it all was Google’s technological invention, not just a source of the company’s pride but also its profit: Transformer-based language models refined and fattened its cash behemoth, Google Search.

几个小时后，我为《麻省理工科技评论》发表了一篇文章，首次详细记述了这篇论文的内容。这封公开信的签名人数迅速翻了一番，达到近7000人，来自学术界、民间社会和工业界，其中包括近2700名谷歌员工。12月9日，抗议活动持续进行，谷歌首席执行官桑达尔·皮查伊（Sundar Pichai）发表道歉声明。他写道：“一位才华横溢的杰出黑人女性领导者不幸离开谷歌，我们必须承担责任。格布鲁博士是人工智能伦理这一重要领域的专家，我们必须继续在该领域取得进展——而这一进展取决于我们能否提出挑战性的问题。”12月16日，国会代表致信谷歌，引用我的故事，要求了解发生了什么。

A few hours later, I published a story for MIT Technology Review with the first detailed account of the paper’s contents. The signatories on the open letter would quickly double, reaching nearly 7,000 people from academia, civil society, and industry, including almost 2,700 Google employees.
