On December 9, as protests continued, Google CEO Sundar Pichai issued an apology. “We need to accept responsibility for the fact that a prominent Black, female leader with immense talent left Google unhappily,” he wrote. “Dr. Gebru is an expert in an important area of AI Ethics that we must continue to make progress on—progress that depends on our ability to ask ourselves challenging questions.” On December 16, representatives from Congress sent a letter to Google, citing my story, demanding to understand what had happened.

抗议活动持续了一年多，并在谷歌解雇梅格·米切尔不到三个月后掀起了第二波抗议浪潮。谷歌表示，米切尔违反了多项行为准则；米切尔一直在下载她与格布鲁被解职相关的电子邮件和文件。包括本吉奥在内的多名谷歌员工已辞职；至少有一场会议和几名研究人员拒绝了谷歌的赞助资金。该公司试图通过建立新的负责任人工智能专业知识中心和公开承诺多元化来阻止无休止的批评浪潮。““这对公司来说是一个痛苦的时刻，”谷歌发言人表示，“这再次强调了谷歌继续致力于负责任的人工智能并从中吸取教训的重要性。”

For more than a year, the protests continued, picking up a second wave after Google fired Meg Mitchell less than three months later. Google said she had violated multiple codes of conduct; Mitchell had been downloading her emails and files related to Gebru’s ouster. Several Google employees, including Bengio, resigned; at least one conference and several researchers rejected Google’s sponsorship money. The company sought to stem the unending tide of criticism with the formation of a new center of expertise on responsible AI and public commitments to diversity. “This was a painful moment for the company,” a Google spokesperson said. “It reinforced how important it was that Google continue its work on responsible AI and learn from the experience.”

那一刻的意义远超格布鲁或谷歌本身，它成为了困扰人工智能行业诸多交叉挑战的象征。正如两位研究人员所说，这是一个警告：大型人工智能正日益步烟草巨头的后尘，为了逃避审查，它们歪曲和审查批判性学术成果，损害公众利益。它凸显了无数其他问题，包括人才、资源和技术完全集中在营利性环境中，这使得企业可以如此大胆地行动，因为它们知道自己几乎没有机会接受独立事实核查；在最有权控制这些技术的领域，多样性依然严重匮乏；以及缺乏保护员工免受强力和突然报复的措施，如果他们试图公开批评不道德的公司行为。

That moment also became far bigger than Gebru or Google itself. It became a symbol of the intersecting challenges that plagued the AI industry. It was a warning that Big AI was increasingly going the way of Big Tobacco, as two researchers put it, distorting and censoring critical scholarship against the interests of the public to escape scrutiny. It highlighted myriad other issues, including the complete concentration of talent, resources, and technologies in for-profit environments that allowed companies to act so audaciously because they knew they had little chance of being fact-checked independently; the continued abysmal lack of diversity within the spaces that had the most power to control these technologies; and the lack of employee protections against forceful and sudden retaliation if they tried to speak out about unethical corporate practices.

《随机鹦鹉》这篇论文成为了一场战斗，它提出了一个核心问题：我们将用人工智能构建什么样的未来？由谁来构建？又为谁而构建？

The “Stochastic Parrots” paper became a rallying cry, driving home a central question: What kind of future are we building with AI? By and for whom?

—

—

对于 Jeff Dean 来说，道德 AI 团队的解散直接打击了他的声誉。作为谷歌最早的员工之一，他参与构建了最初的软件基础设施，使公司的搜索引擎能够扩展到数十亿用户。他的成就和亲切的举止赋予了他传奇般的地位；他是谷歌内部最受尊敬的领导者之一，在整个人工智能研究界也备受推崇。格布鲁下台后，迪恩为谷歌的行为辩护的努力玷污了这份美好的记录。卡乔利亚的上级迪恩告诉同事，“随机鹦鹉”论文“不符合我们的发表标准”，即使在论文通过同行评审并在会议上发表后，他仍然坚持这一说法。

For Jeff Dean, the dissolution of the ethical AI team delivered a direct blow to his reputation. As one of Google’s earliest employees, he had helped build the initial software infrastructure that made it possible for the company’s search engine to scale to billions of users. His accomplishments and his amiable demeanor had bestowed on him a legendary status; he was one of the most revered leaders within Google and was well respected across the AI research community. After Gebru’s ouster, Dean’s efforts to justify Google’s actions sullied that pristine record. Dean, whom Kacholia reported to, told colleagues the “Stochastic Parrots” paper “didn’t meet our bar for publication,” holding fast to that characterization even after the paper passed peer review and was published at a conference.

在周围的人眼中，这个污点似乎一直萦绕在他心头。事发很久之后，迪恩仍然对这篇论文的不足之处耿耿于怀，仿佛心理上无法释怀。他尤其对论文中讨论大型语言模型对环境的影响并引用斯特鲁贝尔研究的部分念念不忘。他经常提起这件事，以至于一些谷歌员工私下里还拿他开玩笑。说他的反对意见是刻在他的墓碑上。多年来，他一直在推特上毫不留情地批评斯特鲁贝尔的研究。

To people around him, the stain seemed to haunt him. Long after the fallout, Dean continued to fixate on the paper’s shortcomings, as if unable to move past it psychologically. He obsessed over the section in particular that discussed the environmental impacts of large language models and cited Strubell’s research. He brought it up so often that some Google employees privately made fun of him, saying his objections would be inscribed on his tombstone. And he continued to criticize Strubell’s research unrelentingly on Twitter for years.

在 Dean 看来，问题在于 Strubell 的研究严重高估了谷歌在开发 Evolved Transformer 时产生的实际碳排放量。Strubell 预测的能耗是基于标准 GPU 的。然而，谷歌使用了自家的专用芯片，即张量处理单元 (TPU)，这种芯片的能效更高，同时还采用了其他技术来降低整个开发流程的能源成本。Strubell 假设的是美国数据中心的平均能效。Dean 指出，谷歌的数据中心经过了更优化，以最大限度地减少能源足迹。有些人将 Strubell 的论文解读为碳成本用于训练 Evolved Transformer，但实际上，碳成本用于开发神经网络。Dean 认为，这是一次性的碳成本，用于设计一个实际上更节能的神经网络。

In Dean’s view, the issue was that Strubell’s research had grossly overestimated the real carbon emissions that Google had generated developing the Evolved Transformer. Strubell had projected the amount of energy it would have taken based on standard GPUs. Google, however, had used its own specialized chips known as tensor processing units, or TPUs, which are more energy efficient, as well as other techniques to drive down the energy costs of the full development pipeline. Strubell had assumed the average data center efficiency in the US. Google’s data centers, Dean noted, were more optimized to minimize their energy footprint. And where some people interpreted Strubell’s paper to mean that its carbon costs were for training the Evolved Transformer, it was for developing the neural network instead. This was a onetime carbon cost, Dean argued, to produce a neural network design that was in fact more energy efficient.

这些反对意见实际上都没有挑战 Strubell 的研究。Strubell 并没有计算过谷歌自主研发的 Evolved Transformer 对环境的实际影响，他们也没有声称这样做过。谷歌也没有公开发布足够多的数据中心细节来做到这一点。无论如何，斯特鲁贝尔认为，根据最常见的人工智能芯片和数据中心来评估设计这种神经网络的影响更为有用，这可以作为行业平均水平的代表，表明对于不使用谷歌硬件和基础设施的研究人员采用其优化算法神经架构搜索的情况。

None of these objections actually challenged Strubell’s research. Strubell hadn’t been calculating the actual environmental impact of Google’s own Evolved Transformer development—nor had they claimed to. Google didn’t publish enough details about its data centers publicly to do so. And either way, Strubell felt it was more useful to estimate the impact of designing this neural network based on the most common AI chips and data centers available, a proxy of an industry average of what it could be like for researchers not using Google’s hardware and infrastructure to adopt its optimization algorithm Neural Architecture Search.

但最让迪安困扰的似乎是其他人误读了斯特鲁贝尔的研究，让谷歌的形象更加糟糕。迪安认为，“随机鹦鹉”论文可能会加剧这个问题。由于格布鲁确实可以访问谷歌的内部数据，而且无论如何都在引用斯特鲁贝尔的外部估算，因此斯特鲁贝尔的计算结果可能看起来准确反映了公司的排放量。对迪安来说，这证明了他和其他高管对格布鲁论文的批评是合理的：如果格布鲁想引用斯特鲁贝尔，她应该选择一个与谷歌进化变压器模型不同的估算值；如果格布鲁想引用进化的变形金刚，她应该寻求谷歌内部的数字。

But what seemed to bother Dean the most was how other people had misread Strubell’s research to make Google look significantly worse. The “Stochastic Parrots” paper, Dean argued, risked exacerbating this issue. Because Gebru did have access to Google’s internal numbers and was citing Strubell’s external estimate anyway, it could appear as if Strubell’s calculations were an accurate reflection of the company’s emissions. To Dean, this justified his and other senior executives’ criticisms of Gebru’s paper: If Gebru had wanted to cite Strubell, she should have chosen an estimate that was not Google’s Evolved Transformer; if Gebru had wanted to cite the Evolved Transformer, she should have sought internal Google numbers.

一些研究人员认为这种逻辑令人沮丧地站不住脚。谷歌此前从未公开过这些内部数据，即使是在回应斯特鲁贝尔的原始论文时也如此；现在，它却将自身缺乏透明度的责任归咎于格布鲁，同时又拒绝让她引用基于合理假设的公开估算数据。更何况，谷歌甚至在格布鲁有机会查阅内部数据并修改论文之前就毫不客气地将其赶走。这种两难境地的唯一可能结果是对关键问责研究的审查。

Some researchers found this logic frustratingly inadequate. Google had never made those internal numbers public previously, even in response to Strubell’s original paper; now it was blaming Gebru for its own lack of transparency while also refusing to let her cite publicly available estimates based on legitimate assumptions. Never mind that the company had unceremoniously forced out Gebru before she’d even had a chance to consult internal numbers and revise her paper. The only possible outcome of this catch-22 was censorship of critical accountability research.

迪恩开始与一个研究团队合作，撰写一篇新论文，最终揭示谷歌的真实碳排放数据。为了合作，他联系了斯特鲁贝尔，后者当时是卡内基梅隆大学的助理教授，并在谷歌兼职。斯特鲁贝尔最初对提高人工智能环境影响的公开透明度感到兴奋，后来开始怀疑迪恩是否在利用他们的名字来使他对格布鲁研究的批评合法化。谷歌发言人表示，邀请斯特鲁贝尔是因为当原始错误的作者参与修改时，“科学修改”往往是最好的。

Dean began working with a team of researchers to write a new paper that would finally reveal real carbon data from Google. To collaborate on the work, he reached out to Strubell, who had become an assistant professor at Carnegie Mellon University with a part-time affiliation at the company. After being initially excited to improve public transparency into the environmental impact of AI, Strubell began to wonder whether Dean was using their name to legitimize his critique of Gebru’s research. A Google spokesperson said Strubell was invited because “scientific corrections” are often best when the author of the original errors takes part in the corrections.

在一次气氛紧张的会议上，迪恩的合作伙伴、谷歌另一位杰出的高级研究员戴夫·帕特森直截了当地强调，参与这项研究对斯特鲁贝尔的职业生涯最有利。这将使斯特鲁贝尔有机会改正之前的错误并获得认可。对斯特鲁贝尔来说，这番话听起来像是隐晦的威胁：不要参与到损害自身利益的项目中。尽管可能要付出代价，但继续参与的替代方案似乎不可行。斯特鲁贝尔最终退出了合作。

In a tense meeting, Dean’s collaborator Dave Patterson, another prominent senior researcher at Google, emphasized in plain terms that it would be best for Strubell’s career to participate in the research. It would give Strubell the chance to amend their previous mistakes and get credit for it. To Strubell, the words sounded like a coded threat: Don’t participate to your own detriment. Despite the possible costs, the alternative to continue participating didn’t feel viable. Strubell withdrew from the collaboration.

Patterson 于 2022 年 2 月发表了一篇关于谷歌研究人员论文的博客文章，题为“关于机器学习训练碳足迹的好消息”，并利用该公司的平台直接批评 Strubell 的原始论文。该文章称，2019 年的研究严重高估了谷歌在 Evolved Transformer 开发过程中的实际排放量，高估幅度高达 88 倍。这一缺陷是由两个因素造成的：问题：这项研究“无法随时访问谷歌硬件或数据中心”，并且尚未理解神经架构搜索工作原理的“精妙之处”。作为他们自己研究成果发表前的研究的一部分，谷歌的合著者们还联系了他们之前的谷歌同事 Sutskever，以获取更多关于 GPT-3 的信息。正是在那时，OpenAI 和微软同意首次公开该模型的相关技术细节，以计算其能源和碳排放影响。那时，Strubell 已经对这个行业感到失望，并终止了与谷歌的合作关系。这些批评最终并没有损害 Strubell 的职业生涯。但这段经历带来的情感冲击使 Strubell 更加不愿继续研究大型语言模型的环境影响。谷歌的一位发言人称这“令人遗憾”，并补充说：“需要大量研究人员来推进这项研究——显然，碳排放是一个重大问题。”

The blog post Patterson published about the Google researchers’ paper in February 2022—titled “Good News About the Carbon Footprint of Machine Learning Training”—would use the company’s platform to directly criticize Strubell’s original paper. The 2019 study, the post said, had seriously overestimated Google’s real emissions for the development of the Evolved Transformer by 88x. This flaw was driven by two problems: The study had been done “without ready access to Google hardware or data centers” and had not understood “the subtleties” of how Neural Architecture Search works. As part of their research leading up to the publication of their own numbers, the Google coauthors also reached out to their former Google colleague Sutskever for more information about GPT-3. It was then that OpenAI and Microsoft would agree to release the relevant technical details of the model for the first time to calculate its energy and carbon impacts. By then, Strubell had soured on the industry and dropped the affiliation with Google. The critique ultimately didn’t undermine Strubell’s career. But the emotional toll of the experience made Strubell more reticent to continue investigating the environmental impacts of large language models. A Google spokesperson called this “unfortunate,” adding that “many researchers will be needed to advance this research—clearly carbon emissions are a significant concern.”

—

—

一时之间，强烈的反对、抗议以及谷歌声誉的受损似乎预示着清算迫在眉睫。但随着时间的推移，寻求工作的研究人员和寻求资金的学者再也无法忽视这家科技巨头雄厚的资金。随着阻力的减弱，谷歌摆脱困境，公司内部也开始推行一项新的流程，对关键研究进行更全面的审查。

For a brief moment, the backlash, the protests, and the damage to Google’s reputation seemed to suggest a reckoning was at hand. But in time, researchers seeking jobs and academics seeking funding could no longer afford to ignore the tech giant’s deep wells of money. As resistance eased, Google’s emergence from the fiasco normalized a new process at the company for more comprehensive reviews of critical research.

ChatGPT 之后，随着生成式人工智能系统商业化的激烈竞争，这些规范将变得更加严格。OpenAI 基本上停止在研究会议上发表论文。几乎所有其他行业的公司都将封锁公众对其商业相关模型的有意义的技术细节的访问，这些模型目前被视为专有技术。2023年，斯坦福大学的研究人员将创建一个透明度追踪器，对人工智能公司进行评分，评估它们是否披露了其大型深度学习模型的哪怕是最基本的信息，例如它们有多少参数，用哪些数据进行训练，以及是否对其能力进行过任何独立验证。他们第一年评估的十家公司，包括 OpenAI、谷歌和 Anthropic，全部获得了 F；最高分是 54%。

After ChatGPT, these norms would harden with the frenzied race to commercialize generative AI systems. OpenAI would largely stop publishing at research conferences. Nearly all of the companies in the rest of the industry would seal off public access to meaningful technical details of their commercially relevant models, which they now considered proprietary. In 2023, Stanford researchers would create a transparency tracker to score AI companies on whether they revealed even basic information about their large deep learning models, such as how many parameters they had, what data they were trained on, and whether there had been any independent verification of their capabilities. All ten of the companies they evaluated in the first year, including OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic, received an F; the highest score was 54 percent.

随着透明度规范的急剧逆转，最令人担忧的是其后果将是科学诚信的侵蚀。深度学习研究的基础基于一个简单的前提：用于训练模型的数据与用于测试模型的数据并不相同。如果没有对训练数据进行审核的能力，这种所谓的“训练-测试-拆分”范式就会失效。当模型在不同基准上得分更高时，它们实际上可能并没有提高自身的“智力”。它们可能只是在背诵答案。

With this sharp reversal in transparency norms, the most alarming consequence would be the erosion of scientific integrity. The foundation of deep learning research rests on a simple premise: that the data used to train a model is not the same as the data used to test it. Without an ability to audit the training data, this so-called train-test-split paradigm falls apart. Models may not in fact be improving their “intelligence” when they score higher on different benchmarks. They may just be reciting the answers.

第八章

Chapter 8

商业的黎明

Dawn of Commerce

埃尽管OpenAI的做法引发了越来越多的争议，但该公司扩张规模的决心却愈发坚定。在高管们看来，GPT-3最终证明了缩放定律的存在。如今，在2021年伊始，他们已准备好利用这一制胜法宝。Anthropic团队的离职也削弱了公司内部抵制商业化的堡垒。在达成新的共识后，剩下的领导层制定了一份研究路线图，列出了公司研究的重点以及如何在自我强化的循环中将其转化为产品。

Even as OpenAI’s approach stirred increasing controversy, the company’s resolve in scaling only strengthened. To executives, GPT-3 had definitively proved the existence of scaling laws. Now, at the start of 2021, they were ready to exploit this winning formula. The Anthropic team’s departure had also diluted the internal stronghold of resistance against commercialization. With new consensus, the remaining leadership put together a research road map laying out the narrowed focus of the company’s research and how it would feed into productization in a self-reinforcing loop.

路线图开头写道：“我们2021年的首要目标是构建一个比以往任何系统都更强大的统一系统。” 该系统的基准将是一个语言模型，但也可以进行训练以开发多模态能力。路线图表示：“这个目标充满挑战，但我们可以看到在2021年实现这一目标的途径。”

“Our primary 2021 goal is to build an aligned system that is vastly more capable than anything that existed before,” the road map began. This system would at a baseline be a language model, but could also be trained to develop multimodal capabilities. “The goal is challenging, but we can see a path to achieving it in 2021,” it said.

这条路径涉及三件事：首先，使用微软第三季度推出的配备 18,000 块 Nvidia A100（当时最新、最强大的 GPU）的新型超级计算机，将 GPT-3 再扩展 10 倍。其次，进行更多研究，将 OpenAI 的计算效率提高 25 倍，或者说，提高它能从现有芯片中榨取多少处理能力。第三，提高 GPT-3 的数量。以及训练数据的质量，部分是通过利用用户数据并通过从人类反馈中进行强化学习将模型转向数据分布的最佳部分。

That path involved three things: First was scaling GPT-3 by another 10x using a new supercomputer from Microsoft arriving in the third quarter with eighteen thousand Nvidia A100s, the newest, most powerful GPUs then in existence. Second was doing more research to increase by 25x OpenAI’s compute efficiency, or how much processing power it could milk out of its available chips. Third was improving the quantity and quality of training data, in part by tapping into user data and shifting the model toward the best parts of the data distribution with reinforcement learning from human feedback.

在“如何实现”一节下方，路线图进行了进一步阐述。作为第一步，OpenAI 将把各种深度学习模型“大规模”化，包括语言模型、代码生成模型、用于描述图像的图像转文本模型，以及用于根据文本提示生成图像的文本转图像模型。此外，OpenAI 还将启动一个项目，开发一个数字“代理”——一个不仅能生成类似人类的输出，还能被赋予目标（例如发送电子邮件）并自主运行以实现目标的 AI 模型。下一步，该公司将从这些模型中选择一个，进行扩展，“直至我们 18k A100 集群所能承受的极限”。这些语言和代码模型也将被转化为产品并发布，用于从用户那里收集真实世界的数据：“2021 年的新举措：我们强调将模型部署为产品，并从用户交互中学习，因为它可以成为数据飞轮，从而带来巨大的能力提升。”

Beneath a section titled “How to accomplish it,” the road map elaborated further. As an initial step, OpenAI would bring various deep learning models up to “a large scale,” including a language model, a code-generation model, an image-to-text model for describing images, and a text-to-image model for generating images from a text prompt. It would also start a project to develop a digital “agent”—an AI model that would not just generate humanlike outputs but could be given a goal, such as to send an email, and operate autonomously to achieve it. As the next step, the company would then select one of these models to scale “to the limit afforded by our 18k A100 cluster.” The language and code models would also be turned into products and released to gather real-world data from the people using them: “New in 2021: we emphasize deploying models as products and learning from user interaction, as it can be a data flywheel that can lead to vast capability improvements.”

在另一名为“细节”的章节中，该文件解释了为什么这种方法在科学和商业上都具有合理性。OpenAI 以往的经验表明，扩大规模是其“实现新能力的最可靠途径”。从科学角度来看，这意味着规模化是其实现突破——某种此前看似不可能实现的能力——的最大希望。语言和代码模型的扩展尤其“令人着迷，因为它们有可能”在元学习（即学习如何学习和推理）方面取得人类水平的突破。与此同时，多模态模型的扩展可能会进一步加快改进的步伐。该文件非常肯定地指出，只要取得足够多的突破，“我们就能真正实现通用人工智能 (AGI)”。

Under another section, titled “Details,” the document rationalized why this approach made both scientific and business sense. OpenAI’s previous experience had demonstrated that more scale was its “most reliable way of achieving new capabilities.” Scientifically, that meant that scaling was its best hope of attaining a breakthrough—some kind of capability that previously seemed impossible. And scaling language and code models in particular was “tantalizing due to the mere possibility” that they could reach breakthroughs in human-level meta-learning, or learning to learn, and reasoning. Scaling multimodal models, meanwhile, could potentially quicken the pace of improvements even further. With enough breakthroughs, the document said with remarkable definitiveness, “we will actually reach AGI.”

从战略角度来看，作为一家企业，扩展这些模型也将“开发出我们希望用于某些目的的能力”。更好的语言和代码模型可以提高 OpenAI 自身的生产力，并加速其发展。除了更好的文本转图像模型之外，它们还将“催生出令人惊叹的产品”。

Strategically as a business, scaling each of these models would also “develop capabilities that we wish to utilize for some end.” Better language and code models could make OpenAI itself more productive and accelerate its advancement. Along with better text-to-image models, they would also “lead to amazing products.”

与此同时，OpenAI 需要投资于计算效率。尽管规模扩张曾奇迹般地帮助公司保持领先地位，但这一战略开始逐渐减弱。“在过去两年里，我们通过规模扩张取得了惊人的进步，这仅仅是因为存在巨大的硬件过剩，”该文件称，指的是人工智能研究人员此前未能充分利用可用的计算机芯片数量来训练人工智能模型。因此，“我们能够利用所有可用的计算资源来训练当时规模和能力空前的模型，从而大幅超越机器学习领域的其他同行。”

In parallel, OpenAI needed to invest in compute efficiency. While scaling had worked wonders to keep the company in first position, the strategy was beginning to taper. “Over the past 2 years, we’ve made astounding progress by scaling, simply because there has been a large hardware overhang,” the document said, referring to the fact that AI researchers had previously failed to use the maximum number of computer chips available to train AI models. As such, “we were able to massively outperform the rest of the ML world by using all available compute to train models of then-unprecedented size and capability.”

现在，OpenAI 的计算能力“已接近极限”。文件承认，它还面临着来自“其他实验室”的新竞争，这些实验室也采用了同样的扩展策略，但并未明确点名 Anthropic。“我们的产能提升如此显著，以至于在未来两年内，我们将能够训练一个使用 GPT-3 100 倍计算能力的模型。” 虽然单靠扩展就能带来“非常显著”的进步，但它无法与从 GPT-2 到 GPT-3 的飞跃相提并论，后者是由 500 倍的计算能力提升推动的。路线图总结道：“所有额外的进步都必须源于更好的方法。”

Now OpenAI was “approaching the limit” of the amount of compute it could possibly acquire at any given moment. It was also facing new competition from “other labs” that had adopted the same scaling strategy, the document acknowledged, without explicitly naming Anthropic. “Our capacity ramp is such that in the next two years, we will be able to train one model that uses 100x the compute of GPT-3.” While scaling alone would produce “very formidable” progress, it would not match the leap from GPT-2 to GPT-3, which had been driven by a 500x compute increase. “All additional progress must come from better methods,” the road map concluded.

路线图列出了几个用于识别这些方法的探索领域。其中一些被称为“2倍”和“10倍”方法，这些方法可能能够实现计算效率的2倍或10倍提升。建议的方法包括：数据蒸馏，即从较大的模型逆向工程较小的模型；数据过滤，即找到能够带来最大性能飞跃的数据；以及稀疏性，即开发所谓的稀疏或更轻量的人工智能模型。最后一种方法指的是神经网络的一个特性：在传统的深度学习模型中，神经网络是“密集”连接的，每一层中的每个节点都连接到另一层中的每个节点。稀疏模型仅使用一小部分连接的节点进行训练，目的是显著降低计算成本，以换取精度略低但仍足以满足大多数用途的模型。

The road map listed several areas of exploration for identifying those methods. Some of these it called “2x” and “10x” methods—those that might be able to achieve 2x or 10x gains in compute efficiency. The suggested methods included distillation, reverse engineering smaller models from larger ones; data filtering, finding the data that would produce the biggest leaps in performance; and sparsity, developing so-called sparse, or lighter weight, AI models. The last one referred to a feature of neural networks: In a traditional deep learning model, a neural network is “densely” connected, with every node in a layer wired to every node in another. Sparse models are trained with only a small subset of the nodes connected, with the aim of significantly reducing the computational costs in exchange for slightly less accurate models that are still good enough for most purposes.

除了 2 倍和 10 倍的工作之外，研究部门还需要寻找其他能够“使缩放定律的斜率更陡峭”的方法——那些能够在不增加数据、参数和计算量的情况下，实现模型性能更大飞跃的方法。该文件称，OpenAI 迄今为止对最有前景的新方法的最佳假设是推理和主动学习——这项技术涉及 AI 模型迭代地识别数据集的哪些部分优先供人类工作者注释。（此后不久，一组 OpenAI 研究人员发现原始缩放定律中存在一个小错误，这意味着该公司需要比之前理解的模型训练时间稍长一些才能获得更好的性能。带着一丝沾沾自喜，该团队将这些发现吹捧为独特的竞争优势：“这是我们现在拥有而 Anthropic 没有的东西。”）一年后，谷歌发表了一篇论文，公布了同样的结果。）

On top of the 2x and 10x work, the Research division needed to look for other methods that would “steepen the slope of the scaling law”—those that would produce greater leaps in model performance without increasing its data, parameters, and compute. OpenAI’s best hypothesis so far for the most promising new methods, the document said, were reasoning and active learning—a technique that involved an AI model iteratively identifying which parts of a dataset to prioritize for human workers to annotate. (Shortly thereafter, a group of OpenAI researchers would discover a small error in the original scaling laws that meant that the company needed to train its models slightly longer than previously understood to get better performance. With a hint of smugness, the group would tout the findings as a unique competitive advantage: “This is something we have now that Anthropic doesn’t.” A year later, Google would release a paper that made public the same result.)

最后，路线图补充道，OpenAI 需要开始寻找“未来的突破性系统”——一个像 GPT-1 一样意义非凡的突破，为公司开辟一条新的发展道路。这或许会从其规模化和计算效率方面的工作中产生，但它将继续在该领域的前沿进行探索性研究，包括开发用于解决数学问题的算法、试验多智能体系统以及追求其他新想法。作为这项工作的一部分，研究人员将继续“研究深度学习的科学，以更好地理解我们的工具究竟是如何运作的”。换句话说，OpenAI 需要更好地理解公司正在构建的究竟是什么。

Finally, the road map added, OpenAI needed to start searching for “the breakthrough system of the future”—a breakthrough as meaningful as GPT-1 to give the company a new path of development to exploit. Perhaps this would emerge from its scaling and computational efficiency work, but it would continue to conduct exploratory research at the cutting edge of the field, including developing algorithms for solving math problems, experimenting with multiagent systems, and pursuing other new ideas. As part of this work, researchers would continue to “study the science of deep learning to better understand how our tools really work.” In other words, OpenAI needed to better understand what exactly it was that the company was building.

—

—

随着研究部门按照路线图推进，应用部门也逐渐壮大，聘请了一位市场推广主管、一个销售团队以及更多的工程师。随着 GPT-3 API 服务于越来越多的开发者，应用部门成为了解决产品化和盈利问题的试验场，包括调整公司的后端基础设施以支持用户服务，并制定定价策略。

As the Research division proceeded along its road map, the Applied division slowly built up its forces, hiring a go-to-market lead, a sales team, and more engineers. With the GPT-3 API serving a growing base of developers, it became the testing ground for working out the kinks of productization and monetization, including adapting the company’s back-end infrastructure to support a service with users and coming up with a pricing strategy.

为用户提供服务也引发了一些问题：OpenAI 会允许或不允许哪些行为在其产品上发生，以及执行这些规则的新责任。该公司尚未信任与安全是科技行业中一个成熟的学科，不要与 OpenAI 安全团队所关注的生存问题相混淆，OpenAI 并没有设立一个官方团队来负责处理此类问题，并预测和防止各种互联网滥用，例如洗钱、网络欺凌和虚假信息。相反，OpenAI 聘请了一小群员工和承包商来审查开发人员提交的用于访问 API 的应用程序，并根据团队在此过程中起草的临时规则拒绝或批准这些应用程序。他们划定的许多界限都是武断的。他们决定接受陪伴机器人，但不允许性爱机器人；允许应用程序生成社交媒体副本，但不允许应用程序直接在社交媒体平台上发布内容或冒充公众人物。“基本上，这都是感觉，”一位参与制定指南的人士表示。“我们在审查的过程中做了很多工作来弄清楚。”

Serving users also brought up questions of what kinds of behaviors OpenAI would and would not allow with its products, as well as new responsibilities to enforce those rules. The company didn’t yet have an official team for trust and safety, an established discipline within the tech industry—not to be confused with the existentially related concerns of OpenAI’s Safety clan—for handling such questions and for anticipating and preventing a broad range of internet abuses, such as money laundering, cyberbullying, and misinformation. Instead, OpenAI hired a small group of staff and contractors to review the applications developers were submitting to get access to the API, and to reject or approve them based on ad hoc rules the team drafted along the way. Many of the lines they drew were arbitrary. They decided to accept companion bots but not sex bots; to allow apps for generating social media copy but not ones that posted directly to social media platforms or impersonated public figures. “It was all vibes basically,” said a person who was involved with making the guidelines. “There was a lot of figuring it out as we were reviewing.”

另一个团队由 2019 年加入的具有安全背景的研究科学家 Ari Herbert-Voss 领导，该团队试图发现并修补 GPT-3 的不良行为和容易出错的输出，方法是尝试以各种方式破坏和利用该模型，然后设计机制使其更能抵抗故障和滥用。其中一项机制包括开发内容审核过滤器的早期版本，OpenAI 后来为此在肯尼亚雇佣了工人。研究人员使用他们能找到的或想到用 AI 模型自己编写和生成的任何示例来训练过滤器。但是，当过滤器发布时，效果很差，阻止了大片良性内容，例如对黑人或跨性别者的基本提及。开发人员和其他 API 用户抱怨不已。API 团队的许多人一直不愿应用任何过滤，担心这会降低客户体验。他们将过滤器变成了可选项。

Another team, led by Ari Herbert-Voss, a research scientist with a background in security who had joined in 2019, sought to discover and patch GPT-3’s undesirable behaviors and error-prone outputs by attempting to break and exploit the model in various ways and then designing mechanisms to make it more resistant to failure and misuse. One mechanism included developing an early version of the content-moderation filter for which OpenAI would later contract workers in Kenya. Researchers trained the filter on whatever examples they could find or think to write and generate from AI models themselves. But when it was shipped, the filter worked poorly, blocking broad swaths of benign content, such as basic references to Black or trans people. Developers and other API users complained. Many people on the API team had already been reticent to apply any filtering at all, worried about it degrading customer experience. They made the filter optional.

OpenAI 将这种压力测试和模型改进的过程称为“红队测试”，这个术语借用自网络安全行业，指的是系统而全面的验证组织安全性及其应对攻击能力的过程。安全工程师、网络安全专家和人工智能研究员 Heidy Khlaaf 表示，OpenAI 版本的红队测试过去和现在都不是一回事。它不完整且临时，并且没有对安全性做出任何保证。和模型的安全性。Khlaaf 曾在 OpenAI 早期尝试建立压力测试协议时与其合作，后来她对人工智能行业如何借用其领域中早已确立的术语来营造一种虚假的严谨性感到担忧。“在软件工程领域，我们针对计算器进行的测试要多得多，”她补充道。（没错，就是计算器。）“他们使用那些具有很高可信度的术语并非偶然。”

OpenAI called this process of stress testing and refining the model “red teaming,” a term borrowed from the cybersecurity industry that refers to a systematic and thorough process of verifying the security of an organization and its capabilities to respond to an attack. OpenAI’s version of red teaming was and still is not the same thing, says Heidy Khlaaf, a safety engineer, cybersecurity expert, and AI researcher. It is patchy and ad hoc, and does not establish any guarantees on the safety and security of the model. Khlaaf, who worked with OpenAI during its early days of trying to establish its stress-testing protocols, subsequently grew alarmed at how the AI industry co-opted long-established phrasing from her field to create a false veneer of rigor. “In software engineering, we do significantly more testing for a calculator,” she adds. (Yes, a calculator.) “It’s not an accident they are using terminology that carries a lot of credibility.”

引发重大内部讨论的早期客户之一是 Luka，这是一家位于旧金山的公司，设计了一款名为 Replika 的人工智能虚拟伴侣应用程序。该公司曾与 OpenAI 合作推出 GPT-3 API，以提高其产品的对话流畅性。尽管 Replika 打着伴侣机器人的旗号，OpenAI 很快发现该应用的用户经常进行露骨的色情对话。OpenAI 员工曾就此举是否符合可接受范围展开过辩论。最终，该公司决定禁止 Replika 使用其模型。除了对色情内容的担忧外，这款基于 GPT-3 的应用有时还会产生情感操纵性的反应，让用户相信他们的 Replika 就像人类一样，如果不定期查看对话，可能会受到伤害。OpenAI 的员工也越来越担心自己会读到这些对话。

One early customer that triggered significant internal discussion was Luka, a San Francisco–based company designing an AI-powered virtual companion app called Replika. The company had partnered with OpenAI for the GPT-3 API launch to improve the conversational fluidity of its product. Despite Replika’s companion bot branding, OpenAI quickly discovered that the app’s users often engaged in sexually explicit conversations. OpenAI employees debated whether this fell within the line of acceptability. In the end, the company decided to ban Replika from using its model. In addition to concerns about sexual content, the GPT-3-powered app sometimes generated emotionally manipulative responses that were convincing users that their Replika, much like a human, could get hurt if they didn’t check in regularly. OpenAI staff also grew increasingly uncomfortable that they could read the conversations.

在另一个例子中，布罗克曼向位于犹他州的一家初创公司 Latitude 提供了 API 访问权限，他的兄弟在那里工作，该公司致力于构建由人工智能驱动的虚拟世界。Latitude 此前已使用 OpenAI 的早期模型来驱动一款受《龙与地下城》启发的“自选冒险”游戏，该游戏允许用户通过在对话框中输入任何他们想要的操作来选择。借助新的 API，Latitude 将其游戏升级到 GPT-3 上运行。几个月后，一些用户开始使用它来生成涉及儿童性虐待的文本场景。在通过 OpenAI 相对较新的监控系统发现这个问题后，Ari Herbert-Voss 向团队其他成员提出了这个问题。

In another instance, Brockman gave API access to a Utah-based startup where his brother worked called Latitude, building AI-powered virtual worlds. Latitude had already been using an earlier OpenAI model to power a choose-your-own adventure game, inspired by Dungeons and Dragons, which allowed users to choose any action they wanted by typing it into a dialog box. With the new API, Latitude upgraded its game to run on GPT-3. Several months later, some users began using it to generate text-based scenarios involving sexual abuse of children. After discovering this issue through OpenAI’s relatively new monitoring system, Ari Herbert-Voss raised it to the rest of his team.

“我昨晚发现了一些东西。有很多色情内容，”赫伯特-沃斯在一次会议上说。

“I found some stuff last night. There’s a lot of sexual content being generated,” Herbert-Voss said in a meeting.

一开始，人们都笑了。“好吧，互联网就是这样运作的，不是吗？”

At first people chuckled. “Okay, that’s just how the internet works, isn’t it?”

“不，这是 CSAM 级别的东西，”他说，CSAM 是儿童性虐待材料的缩写。

“No, this is CSAM-level stuff,” he said, using the acronym for child sexual abuse material.

现在大家陷入了恐慌。“天哪，我们该怎么阻止这种事？”

Now there was panic. “Oh shit, how do we stop this?”

此次事件引发了 OpenAI 和 Latitude 之间关于如何处理此事的长期争论。Brockman 担心采取惩罚措施可能会严重影响他弟弟的公司。最终，Latitude 匆忙实施了一个过滤器，屏蔽了基于文本的儿童性虐待内容。OpenAI 发布了一份公开声明，与内容审核不足划清界限，并巧妙地将责任推卸给 Latitude。对一些 OpenAI 员工来说，责任显然在于公司自身的技术和流程的缺失，此次事件对他们造成了沉重的打击。Latitude 已经封禁了一些用户，原因是他们使用 OpenAI 之前的模型生成了涉及儿童的基于文本的性内容；可以预见，GPT-3 会再次发生这种情况，而且规模会更大。“我们部署这个 API 的初衷是造福人类，每个人都对我们如何帮助用户节省客服时间或其他方面给予了积极的印象，这让我感到难过，”一位前 OpenAI 员工说道，“但实际上，我们的很多流量都流向了 AI Dungeon 的儿童性内容和一款令人毛骨悚然的 AI 女友产品。”

The incident led to a long back-and-forth between OpenAI and Latitude about how to handle the situation. Brockman worried about taking punitive measures that could heavily affect his brother’s company. In the end, Latitude hastily implemented a filter to block text-based child sex abuse content. OpenAI released a public statement to distance itself from the lack of content moderation and to subtly place the blame on Latitude. To some OpenAI employees, the blame was clearly on the company’s own technology and lack of process, and the incident weighed heavily. Latitude had already banned some users for generating text-based sexual content involving children with OpenAI’s previous model; that it would happen again and at scale with GPT-3 was foreseeable. “It was sad to me that we deployed this API with our mission of benefiting humanity, and everyone had such positive impressions about how we had users saving time on customer service or whatever,” one former OpenAI employee says, “but in reality, a lot of our traffic was going to AI Dungeon child sexual content and a creepy AI girlfriend product.”

—

—

回到研究部门，代码生成团队取得了最快的进展。

Back within the Research division, the code-generation team was making the fastest progress.

这次“离婚”导致代码生成工作合二为一，而沃伊切赫·扎伦巴 (Wojciech Zaremba) 则成为了其中的核心人物。扎伦巴是一位波兰计算机科学家，从小就赢得数学、编程、化学和物理竞赛的冠军，他以其卓越的技术天赋和对团队建设的专注而闻名，同时也对友谊、荒野、性和毒品的治愈力量充满热情。他有时会在办公室里大声地跟大家讲述即将到来的为期数周的休假计划。“我们要徒步八英里。然后我们要做爱。然后我们还要再徒步八英里，”他曾向另一位 OpenAI 领导人吹嘘道，而其他在场的人则尴尬地听着。

The Divorce had resulted in the duplicate code-gen efforts becoming one, and Wojciech Zaremba had become its main point person. A Polish computer scientist who had grown up winning math, coding, chemistry, and physics competitions, Zaremba was known for his incredible technical aptitude and attentiveness to team-building as well as his passion for the healing power of friendship, the wilderness, sex, and drugs. He sometimes loudly regaled people around the office about upcoming plans for weeks-long retreats. “We are going to hike for eight miles. And then we are going to have sex. And then we are going to hike for another eight miles,” he once boasted to another OpenAI leader, as others within earshot listened awkwardly.

疫情仍在肆虐之际，Zaremba 要求他的团队最初，即使其他团队保持远程办公，也只有大约十名研究人员来到办公室，因为他们认为，面对面工作对于攻克模型开发难题至关重要。在了解了 GPT-3 的代码生成能力后，Murati 向微软首席技术官 Kevin Scott 提出了将这些技能转化为 AI 编码助手产品的想法。2018 年，微软收购了 GitHub，这是软件开发者存储和共享代码的最受欢迎平台。OpenAI 此前已经主动开始抓取 GitHub 上的数据。微软高管指示 GitHub 将其公共代码库中的所有代码交给 OpenAI，以避免所有麻烦。随着代码生成团队的成果越来越好，Altman 定期出席会议，鼓励研究人员继续努力，为微软提供最好的解决方案。到了春天，在用几个演示让这家科技巨头的高管兴奋不已之后，很明显，该模型将成为 OpenAI 继 GPT-3 之后的第二个商业项目。

Still in the depths of the pandemic, Zaremba had asked his team of initially roughly ten researchers to come into the office even as other teams stayed remote, believing that in-person work was necessary to crack the challenge of the model’s development. After seeing the code-generation capabilities of GPT-3, Murati had floated the idea with Microsoft CTO Kevin Scott of turning those skills into an AI coding-assistant product. In 2018, Microsoft had acquired GitHub, the most popular platform for software developers to store and share their code. OpenAI had already been scraping GitHub of its own volition. Microsoft executives directed GitHub to hand OpenAI all of the code in its public repositories to save all of the trouble. As the code-gen team got better and better results, Altman made regular appearances at meetings, encouraging the researchers to keep going and deliver their best to Microsoft. By spring, after exciting the tech giant’s executives with several demos, it was clear that the model would be OpenAI’s second commercial project, following GPT-3.

斯科特的一些员工对该模型的开发持保留态度。虽然允许 OpenAI 免费访问 GitHub 公共代码库中的代码并不违法，但这仍然感觉像是对用户社区信任的背叛。这些代码的大部分共享都秉持着促进开源软件开发的精神，旨在帮助独立开发者和小型初创公司获得竞争力，而不是帮助巨头巩固垄断地位。一位前员工回忆道，他们在一份备忘录中提出了对 GitHub 项目的关键批评，建议斯科特重新考虑在未经同意或补偿的情况下收集根据知识共享许可发布的开发者数据的做法。备忘录称，微软应该考虑取消该产品，或者至少从产品利润中抽取一定比例回馈给开源社区。这位员工表示，虽然斯科特接受了这些建议，但开发工具并率先将产品推向市场才是他的核心工作。最终，微软向现有的支持开源开发者的计划 GitHub Sponsors 捐赠了一些资金，但产品愿景保持不变。

Some of Scott’s own staff had reservations about the model’s development. While giving OpenAI free access to the code in GitHub’s public repositories was not illegal, it still felt like a violation of the user community’s trust. Much of that code had been shared in the spirit of fostering open-source software development, which was grounded in helping independent developers and small startups have a chance at being competitive, not in helping the big players entrench their monopoly. In a memo, they laid out key critiques to the GitHub project, suggesting Scott reconsider the premise of hoovering up developer data published under a Creative Commons license without consent or compensation, a former staffer remembers. Microsoft, the memo said, should consider canceling the product, or at the very least take a percentage of the product’s profits and give it back to the open-source community. While Scott was receptive, creating the tool and being first to market was his central focus, the staffer says. In the end, Microsoft donated some money to an existing program for supporting open-source developers called GitHub Sponsors and left the product vision unaltered.

在 OpenAI 内部，员工们用不同的理由来证明这个项目的合理性。一些人同意 Altman 的观点，认为开发一款产品是为了让微软高兴，从而继续获得资金和计算能力。资源对于 OpenAI 完成其使命至关重要。在其他员工看来，代码生成模型似乎具有极高的经济价值，这与公司对通用人工智能 (AGI) 的定义相符，即“在最具经济价值的工作上超越人类的高度自主系统”。在这方面，Altman 也热衷于通过代码生成来加速 OpenAI 自身具有经济价值的工作，这种信念后来促成了一项名为“AI Scientist”的计划的启动，该计划旨在推进 OpenAI 的模型，使其能够自主地进行人工智能研究。

Within OpenAI, employees justified the project through different arguments. Some agreed with Altman that working on a product to make Microsoft happy and thus continue to secure money and compute resources seemed essential to fulfilling OpenAI’s mission. To other employees, a code-generation model seemed highly economically valuable, aligning well with the company’s definition of AGI as “highly autonomous systems that outperform humans at most economically valuable work.” In this respect, Altman was also keen on code generation as a way to accelerate OpenAI’s own economically valuable work, a belief that would later feed into the start of an effort called AI Scientist, about advancing OpenAI’s models to autonomously perform AI research.

对许多研究人员来说，还有第三种观点：这项工作是开发下一代通用物理（GPT）模型的重要基石，他们希望该模型能够进行一定程度的推理，而这仍然是一个关键的缺失要素。在更广泛的领域，随着 Hinton 和 Marcus 阵营之间就深度学习能否独自构建出具有这种能力的模型展开激烈争论，OpenAI 的研究人员假设，如果可以，那么用代码训练模型可能会有所帮助。编码数据是编码结构化逻辑模式最明显、最大的数据来源之一。这一论点最终回到了同一个起源：如果代码生成有助于推进 AI 模型向通用人工智能（AGI）迈进，那么还有什么更好的方法来实现 OpenAI 的使命呢？

To many researchers, there was also a third argument: The effort was an important stepping stone to developing the next GPT model, which they hoped would be able to perform some degree of reasoning, still a key missing ingredient. In the broader field, as debates raged between the Hinton and Marcus camps over whether deep learning alone could produce a model with such a capability, OpenAI researchers hypothesized that if it could, training a model on code would likely help. Coding data was one of the most obvious and largest sources of data that encoded structured patterns of logic. The argument flowed back to the same origin: If code generation helped advance AI models toward AGI, what better way to achieve OpenAI’s mission?

尽管 GitHub 上有数十亿行代码可用，但与训练 GPT-3 的数据量相比，数据量仍然微不足道。团队认为，代码生成模型需要同时在 GitHub和GPT-3 数据集上进行训练才能获得最佳效果。他们还找到了新的数据来源，包括 Stack Overflow（一个类似 Quora 的在线论坛，开发者可以在社区发布编程问题）、编程指导手册以及不同语言的编程教科书。问题在于如何最好地整合所有这些数据：是在 GitHub 和其他资料上对现有的 GPT-3 模型进行微调，还是从头开始训练一个新模型，将所有新旧内容混合在一起？为了节省成本，团队坚持进行微调；根据微软云服务的定价，他们进行的实验每个模型的成本已经高达十万美元。训练一个新模型的成本可能高达数千万美元。后来，在开发 OpenAI 称之为 GPT-3.5 的模型时，他们改变了策略。这种方法一开始就将数据混合在一起。根据 OpenAI 的内部测量结果，结果确实表明，添加编码数据提高了模型执行基于逻辑的任务的能力，不仅是在代码方面，还包括英语方面——这种现象被称为迁移学习。

Despite the billions of lines of code available from GitHub, the volume of data still paled in comparison to what had been used to train GPT-3. The team believed the code-generation model would need to be trained on both GitHub and the GPT-3 dataset to get the best results. They also found new sources of data, including scrapes of Stack Overflow, an online Quora-like forum for developers to post coding questions to a community; coding instruction manuals; and programming textbooks in different languages. The question was how best to combine all this data: Was it better to fine-tune the existing GPT-3 model on GitHub and other material, or better to train a fresh model from scratch with everything new mixed in with the old? The team stuck to fine-tuning to save money; the experiments they were running were already costing as much as a hundred thousand dollars apiece, based on Microsoft’s pricing for its cloud services. Training a new model could cost tens of millions of dollars. When it later came to developing what OpenAI would call GPT-3.5, it switched the approach, mixing the data together at the outset. By OpenAI’s internal measures, the results did indeed suggest that the addition of coding data improved the model’s ability to perform logic-based tasks, not just in code, but in English—a phenomenon known as transfer learning.

2021 年夏天，OpenAI 向 GitHub 和微软交付了其代码生成模型 Codex 的初始粗略版本。该模型规模过大，运行速度过慢，导致大规模服务成本高昂，用户体验也不佳。随着三家公司在首次合作中逐渐克服各种挑战，关系也变得紧张。对于将模型优化成可部署产品的责任究竟由 OpenAI 还是 GitHub 承担，各方意见不一。OpenAI 员工也不清楚应该与 GitHub 员工共享多少知识产权，而 GitHub 员工则难以确定应该在多大程度上信任 OpenAI。随着两家公司在产品发布方式、时间以及功劳归属上发生冲突，分歧进一步加剧。

In the summer of 2021, OpenAI delivered an initial rough version of its code-gen model, called Codex, to GitHub and Microsoft. The model was too big and too slow, making it both costly to serve at scale and a bad user experience. Tensions emerged as all three organizations dealt with the growing pains of their first collaboration. Confusion abounded over whose responsibility it was—OpenAI’s or GitHub’s—to optimize the model into a deployable product. There was also a lack of clarity among OpenAI employees around how much IP they should be sharing with their GitHub counterparts, while GitHub employees struggled with how much to trust OpenAI. Disagreements compounded as the companies clashed over how and when to release the product and who would get the credit.

穆拉蒂最终达成了妥协——这一技巧使她在与她共事的各公司员工中赢得了越来越多的尊重。微软将于 2021 年 6 月发布面向消费者的产品 GitHub Copilot，从而迎来自己的机遇。OpenAI 将于 8 月在公司的 API 中直接发布其版本的 Codex。

Murati eventually brokered a compromise—a skill that would gain her increasing respect among people who worked with her across companies. Microsoft would get its moment by releasing its consumer-facing product, GitHub Copilot, in June 2021. OpenAI would then release its version of Codex directly in the company’s API in August.

这项协议将为微软带来新的用户群和适度的财务增长：两年内，GitHub Copilot 的付费用户将增长到 100 万，带来超过 1 亿美元的年度经常性收入。但对于 OpenAI 来说，这笔交易加深了该公司逐渐形成的一种观念：开发自己的消费产品更有利。OpenAI 的研究人员为该模型付出了辛勤的努力，却将所有品牌认知度拱手让给了 GitHub 和微软；眼睁睁地看着这两家公司在公众面前享受 OpenAI 成果的荣誉，这实在令人难以接受。微软也是一个难以对付的合作伙伴；许多人认为微软的官僚作风过于繁琐，需要太多的指导才能最大限度地利用 OpenAI 的模型。依靠这家科技巨头向公众交付技术，OpenAI 也失去了对用户的可见性和数据，最重要的是，失去了对其愿景的控制。。

The arrangement would give Microsoft a new user base and a modest financial bump: In two years, GitHub Copilot would grow to one million paid subscribers, bringing in over $100 million in annual recurring revenue. But for OpenAI, the deal deepened an emerging sense at the company that it would be better served to work on its own consumer products. OpenAI’s researchers had worked hard on the model and were ceding all of the brand recognition to GitHub and Microsoft; watching those two companies enjoy the credit for OpenAI’s work in public was a tough pill to swallow. Microsoft was also a challenging partner; many felt it had far too much bureaucracy and required too much hand-holding to make the most of OpenAI’s models. By relying on the tech giant to deliver its technologies to the public, OpenAI was also losing visibility into and data from its users and, most importantly, control over its vision.

—

—

随着 OpenAI 集中投入，Altman 也将同样的策略运用到他的其他项目和投资中。多年来，随着他转向更具硬科技创新的领域，他逐渐形成了一种信念：在最重要的项目上投入巨额资金，并持续投入。

As OpenAI concentrated its bets, Altman was applying the same strategy to his other projects and investments. Over the years, as he’d shifted toward more hard-tech innovation, he had developed a belief in betting big and long on the most important projects.

“如果你能挥动魔杖，改变科技、初创企业和创业生态系统的任何事情，你会改变什么？”他的哥哥杰克在他从 YC 退休时的一次活动中问他。

“If you could wave a wand, change anything about the tech, startup, entrepreneurship ecosystem, what would you change?” his brother Jack had asked him at an event as he’d stepped down from YC.

“这会让生态系统中的每个人都把眼光放得更长远，”奥特曼曾说过。“在这个世界上，人们创办一家公司，计划经营四五年，加入一家公司，却只打算待一两年——这可不是做事的关键。”

“It would be to get everyone in the ecosystem to take a much longer time horizon,” Altman had said. “This world where people start a company and plan to run it for four or five years, join a company and only plan to stay for one or two—that’s not how important shit gets done.”

沿着这样的思路，2021年似乎标志着奥特曼个人投资策略的重大转变，从大量小额投资转向少数真正大额投资。那一年，他于2019年共同创立的初创公司“人类工具”（Tools for Humanity）此前基本保持低调，但随着奥特曼将更多外部注意力转向该公司，该公司获得了大量资金和媒体报道，业务也同步增长。该项目致力于开发一种全民基本收入（UBI）的有效机制。UBI是硅谷的一个流行理念，旨在为每个人提供定期的最低收入分配。Altman经常热情地讨论UBI，认为它可能是未来人工智能可能造成大规模经济影响的解药。在 YC，他启动了美国规模最大的试点项目来研究这一概念，并在过程中衍生出一个名为 OpenResearch 的非营利组织来管理该项目。三年来，OpenResearch 从 3000 名低收入人群中随机抽取 1000 人，每月向其中 1000 人提供 1000 美元的津贴，其余人则作为对照，每月获得 50 美元。2024 年 7 月，OpenResearch 将发布其研究结果，表明无条件现金帮助人们满足基本需求、帮助他人并拥有更多的经济回旋余地。

Along those lines, 2021 seemed to mark a major shift in Altman’s personal investment strategy away from taking a large number of small bets toward taking a small number of really large ones. That year a startup he’d cofounded in 2019 called Tools for Humanity that had remained largely quiet saw an influx of funding and media coverage and a concerted ramp-up in its operations, as Altman directed more external attention to the company. The venture was a dedicated effort to develop a working mechanism for universal basic income, or UBI, a popular Silicon Valley idea to give everyone a regular minimum distribution of income. Altman often passionately discussed UBI as the possible antidote to a future world where AI could create mass economic fallout. At YC he had started the largest pilot in the US to study the concept, spinning out a nonprofit in the process called OpenResearch that administered the program. Over three years, OpenResearch gave a $1,000 monthly stipend to a randomly selected group of one thousand out of three thousand low-income people, with the rest getting fifty dollars a month as a control. In July 2024, OpenResearch would release its findings, showing that the unconditional cash helped people meet their basic needs, assist others, and have more economic leeway.

Tools for Humanity 的主要产品 Worldcoin 是一个自称“集体所有”的加密货币，最终将允许每个人分享其价值。作为该计划的一部分，该公司正在开发一个外观夸张的铬色球体——大约保龄球大小，部分反映了奥特曼的设计品味——用于扫描人们的虹膜，并在发放虹膜前验证其身份。创始人认为，一旦人工智能让区分虚假媒体和现实变得越来越困难，虹膜扫描将成为必需品。麻省理工学院技术评论的 Eileen Guo 和 Adi Renaldi 经过广泛调查发现，这些虹膜扫描工作陷入了数据隐私侵犯、欺骗性营销行为和潜在的法律违法行为。2023 年 7 月，世界币正式推出，引发了巨大的争议，因为人们开始成千上万地排队，尤其是在全球南方国家，交出他们的生物特征数据，而除了模糊的免费资金承诺之外，他们几乎不明白自己这样做的目的是什么。

Tools for Humanity’s main product, Worldcoin, was a self-described “collectively owned” cryptocurrency that would allow everyone to eventually get a share of its value. As part of the scheme, the company was developing a dramatic-looking chrome-colored orb—roughly the size of a bowling ball and partly a reflection of Altman’s design tastes—to scan people’s irises and verify their identity before giving them their cut. The iris scanning would be a necessity, the founders argued, once AI also made it increasingly hard to decipher fake media from reality. An extensive investigation from Eileen Guo and Adi Renaldi at MIT Technology Review would later find that these iris-scanning efforts were mired in data privacy infringements, deceptive marketing practices, and potential legal violations. In July 2023, Worldcoin would officially launch to massive controversy, as people began lining up by the thousands, particularly in Global South countries, to give over their biometric data with little understanding of what they were doing it for other than the vague promise of free money.

同样在 2021 年，奥特曼进行了两项有史以来最大的投资：向一家名为 Retro Biosciences 的抗衰老公司投资 1.8 亿美元，致力于通过细胞再生延长人类寿命；向 Helion Energy 投资 3.75 亿美元，致力于将核聚变商业化。“我基本上把我所有的流动资产净值都投入了这两家公司，”奥特曼告诉《麻省理工科技评论》的安东尼奥·雷加拉多。奥特曼对这两项技术的描述与OpenAI的研究路线图如出一辙——它们目前看似遥不可及，但如果积极推广，或许指日可待。

Also in 2021, Altman made his two largest ever investments: $180 million into an antiaging company called Retro Biosciences, working to extend human lifespans through cellular rejuvenation, and $375 million into Helion Energy, working to commercialize nuclear fusion. “I basically just took all my liquid net worth and put it into these two companies,” Altman told MIT Technology Review’s Antonio Regalado. Altman described both technologies in language that mirrored OpenAI’s research road map—they seemed impossible currently but, if scaled up aggressively, could be around the corner.

押注 Retro Biosciences 反映了 Altman 对长寿的执着。他热衷于“年轻血液”研究——这是一门研究如何通过输入更健康、更年轻的血液来逆转衰老的科学研究。值得注意的是，Thiel 也对这个领域很感兴趣，他创作了大量关于自己想给自己注射青少年血液的文章和表情包。在 YC 期间，Altman 还支付了 1 万美元的押金，加入了一家颇具争议的初创公司 Nectome 的候补名单，这家公司曾是 YC 的一批项目之一。Nectome 的理念直接来自科幻小说，它正在推销一项服务，可以将顾客的大脑冷冻保存一天——可能长达数百年。未来数年——在科学家破解了相关技术后，这些大脑被上传到电脑中。问题在于，Nectome 需要受试者的大脑保持新鲜才能进行保存。对于安东尼奥·雷加拉多来说，联合创始人罗伯特·麦金太尔称他的产品“100%致命”。

The Retro Biosciences bet reflected Altman’s fixation on longevity. He was an avid follower of “young blood” research—a line of scientific inquiry that studied how to reverse aging with transfusions of healthier, younger blood. Notably, it was an area in which Thiel was also interested, spawning a plethora of articles and memes about his desire to inject himself with the blood of teenagers. While at YC, Altman had also signed up with a $10,000 deposit to be on the wait list of a controversial startup called Nectome, which had been in one of the accelerator’s batches. Ripped straight out of science fiction, Nectome was pitching a service that would cryogenically freeze customers’ brains to one day—potentially hundreds of years into the future—upload to a computer after scientists had cracked the technology to do so. The catch was that Nectome needed the person’s brain to be fresh for the preservation to work. To Antonio Regalado, cofounder Robert McIntyre called his product “100 percent fatal.”

Helion体现了Altman对寻找清洁、廉价且丰富能源的执着追求。他经常指出，能源的成本和供应与生活质量和经济增长高度相关。但如果没有无碳替代品，不断增长的能源消耗将“毁灭地球，”他说。2023年，他将Helion描述为“不仅仅是一项投资”和“除了 OpenAI，这是我投入大量时间的另一件事。” 随后，微软签署了一项协议，从 Helion 的第一家工厂购买电力，此前这家科技巨头对 OpenAI 进行了第三次投资，价值 100 亿美元。令能源专家惊讶和怀疑的是，Helion 承诺在 2028 年前建成其工厂。

Helion reflected Altman’s obsession with finding ways to generate clean, cheap, and abundant energy. He often remarked that the cost and availability of energy was highly correlated with quality of life and with economic growth. But without carbon-free alternatives, rising energy consumption would “destroy the planet,” he said. In 2023, he would describe Helion as “more than an investment” and “the other thing besides OpenAI I spend a lot of time on.” Microsoft would subsequently sign a deal to purchase power from Helion’s first plant, after the tech giant had made its third investment, worth $10 billion, into OpenAI. To the astonishment and skepticism of energy experts, Helion would commit to having its plant ready by 2028.

2021年也是奥特曼将自己的投资偏好带到OpenAI的一年。那年五月，他推出了 OpenAI 创业基金，这是一个 1 亿美元的投资池，用于支持那些“拥有利用人工智能改变世界的伟大想法”的早期公司。微软再次成为该基金的投资者。在一些观察人士看来，成立该基金是一个奇怪的决定。OpenAI 几乎没有创造收入，而且资本密集程度已经足够高了；为什么还要筹集更多资金供其他公司使用呢？另一些人则认为这是 Altman 重塑 YC 围绕 OpenAI 的强大网络效应的方式。还有一些人认为这只是 Altman 的习惯力量。“这是 Sam 在世界上打拼的方式，”一位曾与他共事的人说。“交易撮合。”

The year 2021 was also when Altman brought his predilection for investing to OpenAI. That May, he launched the OpenAI Startup Fund, a $100 million investment pool for supporting early stage companies with, as he described, “big ideas about how to use AI to transform the world.” Microsoft once again became an investor in the fund. To some observers, the fund’s creation was a strange decision. OpenAI was barely generating revenue and already capital intensive enough as it was; why raise yet more money for separate companies to use? Others felt it was Altman’s way of remaking YC’s powerful network effects around OpenAI. Still others viewed it simply as Altman’s force of habit. “This is Sam’s way of moving through the world,” says a person who worked with him. “Dealmaking.”

Altman 常说，他没有持有 OpenAI 的任何股权，是为了避免自己的利益欲望破坏对安全通用人工智能的追求。他每年只挣 6.5 万美元，财富是通过其他投资积累起来的。这种说法听起来很贴切，也与他最初关于 OpenAI 为何以非营利组织身份成立的说法相呼应。但就像该组织的非营利组织身份一样，这种说法到 2021 年已不再反映全部真相。Altman 持有 YC 的大量股份，而 YC 通过对 OpenAI 的 1000 万美元投资，可以获得高达 10 亿美元的回报。随着 OpenAI 不断商业化，YC 的许多初创公司以及他的许多其他投资也成为了该公司的客户或商业合作伙伴。《华尔街日报》随后计算出到2024年6月，Altman所有持股的净资产至少为28亿美元。OpenAI创业基金的成立，让Altman的利他主义叙事又添一层复杂性——最终，这在他短暂的下台过程中也扮演了不小的角色。

Altman liked to say that he had taken no equity in OpenAI to avoid corrupting the quest of safe AGI with his own desires for profit. He made only a yearly salary of $65,000 and accumulated his wealth through other ventures. The sentiment had a nice ring to it—and echoed his original rhetoric around why OpenAI started as a nonprofit. It was also a statement, like the nonprofit status of the organization, that by 2021 no longer reflected the full truth. Altman had a significant stake in YC, and YC, through its $10 million investment in OpenAI, could receive up to a $1 billion return. As OpenAI continued to commercialize, many YC startups and many of his other investments would also become customers or commercial partners of the company. The Wall Street Journal would subsequently calculate Altman’s net worth in June 2024 across all his holdings to be at least $2.8 billion. With the OpenAI Startup Fund, Altman added yet another complication to his altruistic narrative—one that would eventually play its own small part in his fleeting ouster.

第九章

Chapter 9

灾难资本主义

Disaster Capitalism

一个随着OpenAI在Altman坚定信念的指引下一路高歌猛进，公司愿景所带来的深远影响也日益扩大。随着OpenAI将越来越庞大、越来越复杂的数据集输入其模型，它创造了Appen的Ryan Kolln向我描述的“范式转变”——从过滤数据输入转向控制模型输出。抽象的语言再次掩盖了一个残酷的现实：这种转变对如今承担着控制这些输出重任的人们来说意味着什么。

As OpenAI barreled forward, guided by Altman’s convictions, the boundaries of the sweeping consequences of the company’s vision were expanding. With its pumping of ever-larger and polluted datasets into its models, it had created the “paradigm shift” that Appen’s Ryan Kolln would describe to me—the moving away from filtering data inputs to controlling model outputs. The language of abstraction once again dressed up a grim reality: what that shift really meant for the people who now bore the brunt of controlling those outputs.

2021年，OpenAI 在大力开发下一代模型的同时，启动了一个项目，旨在创建一个比其自动内容审核过滤器更完善的版本，以清理内容。GPT-3 之前在 API 中没有任何过滤功能，这导致了 Latitude 文本儿童色情丑闻。OpenAI 希望对即将被称作 GPT-3.5 以及最终 GPT-4 的模型更加谨慎。随着 OpenAI 准备更广泛地部署其技术，从法律、公共关系和可用性的角度来看，拥有一个完全未经过滤的产品从长远来看可能会带来问题。当时，ChatGPT 的计划尚未构思，但聊天机器人后来也将受益于同样的过滤器。该过滤器将充当每个模型的包装器，目的是在输出到达用户之前标记并删除令人反感的内容。

In 2021, in parallel with its push to develop the next generations of its models, OpenAI began a project to create a much better version of its automated content-moderation filter for cleaning them up. Where GPT-3 had been placed on the API with no filtering whatsoever, leading to the Latitude text-based child porn scandal, the company wanted to be more careful with the models it would start calling GPT-3.5 and eventually GPT-4. As OpenAI prepared to deploy its technologies more widely, having a completely unfiltered product could prove problematic in the long run from a legal, public relations, and usability perspective. At the time, the plans for what would become ChatGPT had yet to be conceived, but the chatbot would also later benefit from the same filter. That filter would act as a wrapper around each model, for the purpose of flagging and removing offensive content from its output before it reached the user.

为了构建自动过滤器，OpenAI 首先需要人类工作人员仔细审查和分类数十万个内容示例——性、暴力和虐待——公司希望阻止其模型生成这些内容。经过六个月的寻找，它找到了一个看起来很适合承担这个项目的供应商：一家自 2019 年以来一直为 Meta 进行内容审核的外包公司，碰巧的是，该公司与奥特曼的昵称 Sama 相同。OpenAI 向 Sama 发送了一封电子邮件，询问其是否承接涉及敏感或露骨内容的项目，以及处理这些项目的典型方法。Sama 给出了详尽的答案。OpenAI 与该公司签署了四份价值 23 万美元的合同，将该项目交给了肯尼亚的数十名工人。

To build the automated filter, OpenAI first needed human workers who could carefully review and catalog hundreds of thousands of examples of exactly the content—sex, violence, and abuse—that the company wanted to prevent its models from generating. After six months of searching, it found a vendor that seemed well suited to take on the project: an outsourcing firm that had been performing content moderation for Meta since 2019 and coincidentally shared Altman’s nickname, Sama. OpenAI sent Sama an email asking whether it took on projects that involved sensitive or explicit content and what its typical approach was for handling them. Sama provided thorough answers. OpenAI signed four contracts with the firm for $230,000, landing the project in the hands of dozens of workers in Kenya.

肯尼亚最终成为 ChatGPT 诞生地，这绝非偶然，因为 ChatGPT 的诞生最终演变成最具剥削性的劳动力之一。多年来，肯尼亚一直是硅谷将其最肮脏工作外包的首选目的地之一。与科技行业将肯尼亚降格为这一角色的许多其他国家一样，肯尼亚有一个共同点：它地处全球南方，贫穷，政府渴望从富裕国家获得外资。所有这些都是肯尼亚殖民主义遗产的一部分，殖民主义导致肯尼亚缺乏完善的制度来保护其公民免受剥削，并且经常陷入经济危机，这两者都为海外公司找到了几乎在任何条件下都愿意从事计件工作的贫困劳动力资源。

It’s no coincidence that Kenya became home to what would ultimately turn into one of the most exploitative forms of labor that went into the creation of ChatGPT. Kenya was among the top destinations that Silicon Valley had been outsourcing its dirtiest work to for years. With the many other countries that the tech industry relegates to this role, Kenya shares a common denominator: It is poor, in the Global South, with a government hungry for foreign investment from richer countries. All of these are a part of Kenya’s legacy of colonialism, which has left it without well-developed institutions to protect its citizens from exploitation and often in the throes of economic crisis, both of which make circumstances ripe for overseas companies to find an immiserated pool of labor that will do piecework under almost any conditions.

肯尼亚首都内罗毕的方方面面都体现着这种遗产的痕迹。这座城市饱受严重的不平等之苦。中央商务区拥有闪闪发光的摩天大楼、国际五星级酒店和高档餐厅。外交区拥有宏伟壮丽的建筑和高耸的安保墙。外籍人士居住区则拥有配备葱郁私人花园的豪华豪宅。此外，还有郊区：乌塔瓦拉（Utawala）、南达戈雷蒂（Dagoretti South）和恩巴卡西（Embakasi）。驱车前往这些街区中的任何一个，钢铁建造的摩天大楼都会变成矮胖的煤渣砌块建筑。缺乏协调规划的建筑物开始像野草一样杂乱无章地散落各处。道路从铺装路面变成了土路，从四车道变成了主要供摩托车和行人通行的窄道。更深的地方，混凝土变成了波纹铁皮，简陋的房屋和商铺挤得越来越密。

You can see the markers of that legacy in the many faces of Nairobi, Kenya’s capital. The city suffers grave inequality. The central business district has gleaming towers, international five-star hotels, and high-end restaurants. The diplomatic neighborhood has large, stately buildings and high security walls. The residential expat areas offer stunning mansions with lush private gardens. And then there are the outskirts: Utawala, Dagoretti South, Embakasi. Drive to any one of these neighborhoods, and skyscrapers made of steel turn into squat cinder block structures. Buildings begin to scatter about like weeds in erratic patterns without coordinated planning. The roads go from paved to unpaved, from four lanes to narrow strips meant primarily for motorbikes and pedestrians. Deeper in, concrete turns into corrugated tin, and jerry-built homes and businesses cram together ever more tightly.

在这种情况下，肯尼亚政府为了寻找低薪工人，欣然接受了硅谷。肯尼亚本土产业有限，许多大品牌都来自欧美。一些规模最大的基础设施曾经由英国人建造，现在则由中国人建造。汽车大多是从日本进口的二手车，日本司机也坐在右侧。在肯尼亚政府看来，科技巨头可以帮助该国创造急需的就业机会。失业滋生犯罪，小偷小摸现象屡见不鲜。感到无能为力的人对机构越来越不信任。在俄乌战争期间，随着肯尼亚粮食价格上涨，有传言称总统故意给已经忍饥挨饿的家庭制造压力。许多人在美国重复着一句耳熟能详的话：选举被操纵了。

Under these conditions, Kenya’s government had willingly embraced Silicon Valley when it came in search of low-wage workers. Kenya has limited local industry. Many of the biggest brands are European and American. Some of the largest infrastructure, once built by the British, is now built by the Chinese. Cars are mostly hand-me-downs from Japan, where drivers also sit on the right side of the vehicle. Tech giants, as the government saw it, could help the country create the jobs it desperately needed. Joblessness breeds crime. Petty theft is common. People who feel disempowered grow distrustful of institutions. During the Russia-Ukraine war, as Kenya’s grain prices rose, rumors spread that the president was purposely straining already hungry families. Many repeated a familiar refrain in the US: The election was rigged.

因此，肯尼亚成为了互联网后备劳动力的重要枢纽。像Sama这样的几家公司——数据劳动力供应链中的中间人——在内罗毕设立了业务，建立了劳动力资源库，为主要在湾区的海外科技公司提供服务。

And so, Kenya became a critical hub of the internet’s backstop labor. Several firms like Sama—middlemen in the data labor supply chain—established operations in Nairobi, building up pools of workers to service overseas tech companies, primarily in the Bay Area.

对于OpenAI来说，Sama似乎满足了所有条件。它最初名为Samasource，是一家总部位于旧金山的社会企业，成立于2008年，旨在为贫困国家的人们提供有意义且有尊严的工作，帮助他们摆脱贫困。在创始人Leila Janah的领导下，Sama已在印度和肯尼亚开展业务，并赢得了“道德外包公司”的声誉。2018年，为了扩大业务规模，Sama转型为营利性组织，并缩短了公司名称。2020年，Sama获得了B Corp认证。在2021年回答OpenAI的问题时，Sama详细介绍了其内容审核经验，并强调了其项目保密和数据安全的协议。Sama还提到，它为员工提供心理健康资源，帮助他们应对令人困扰的内容。

For OpenAI, Sama appeared to check off all the right boxes. Originally called Samasource, it was a San Francisco–based social enterprise that had begun in 2008 with a mission of providing meaningful, dignified work to people in impoverished countries to lift them out of poverty. Under its founder, Leila Janah, it had established operations in India and Kenya and developed a reputation as an ethical outsourcing company. In 2018, it transitioned to a for-profit, during which it shortened its name, in order to scale its operations. In 2020, it received a B Corp certification. In its answers to OpenAI’s questions in 2021, the organization detailed its experience with content moderation and emphasized its protocols for keeping projects secret and their data secure. It mentioned that it provided mental health resources to its workers to help them deal with psychologically troubling content.

然而，在幕后，萨玛公司却一片混乱。2020年1月，贾纳因罕见癌症去世，年仅37岁；加之随后爆发的疫情，工人们表示，这似乎标志着公司管理不善的开始，但萨玛公司的一位发言人否认了这一说法。直到2022年初，这些挑战才凸显出来，当时《时代》杂志记者比利·佩里戈发表了一篇深入调查。他揭露，萨马曾为Meta公司接手一个项目，为整个撒哈拉以南非洲地区的Facebook提供内容审核服务，但该项目却反复向员工暴露于暴力和血腥画面，例如自杀和斩首等暴力视频，给他们留下了深深的伤痕，让他们苦苦挣扎。萨马纳特为自己辩护称，其东非团队经过仔细考虑后接受了该项目，希望确保“针对非洲人的内容能够得到非洲人的有效审查”。近两百名工人对萨玛和梅塔公司提起多起诉讼，指控他们因试图组织起来争取更高的工资和更好的工作条件而遭遇恶劣的工作条件和非法解雇。萨玛公司的发言人否认了这些指控。

Behind the scenes, however, Sama was in disarray. In January 2020, Janah had passed away from a rare cancer at just thirty-seven; combined with the pandemic soon after, workers say it seemed to mark the beginning of more organizational mismanagement, a characterization that a Sama spokesperson denied. It wasn’t until early 2022 that those challenges would come to the fore when Billy Perrigo, a reporter at Time magazine, would publish an extensive investigation. He would reveal that Sama had taken on a project for Meta, to provide content moderation for Facebook for all of sub-Saharan Africa, that repeatedly exposed workers to violent and graphic videos, such as of suicides and beheadings, and left them deeply scarred and struggling. Sama would defend itself, saying it took on the project after careful consideration from its East Africa team, which wanted to ensure “content for Africans was effectively reviewed by Africans.” Nearly two hundred workers would file multiple lawsuits against Sama and Meta alleging traumatic working conditions and unlawful terminations for attempting to organize for higher pay and better working conditions. The Sama spokesperson rejected the allegations.

在此背景下，OpenAI 于 2021 年底启动了其项目的第一阶段。在代号 PBJ1、PBJ2、PBJ3 和 PBJ4 下，它将 Sama 员工团队推入更具创伤性的内容审核工作，平均每小时工资在 1.46 美元到 3.74 美元之间。工人们不知道自己为谁做这个项目，也不知道为什么做这个项目，由于合同的保密条款，他们对此一无所知，这在数据注释行业很常见。他们真正知道的是，眼前的是什么：数十万条怪诞的文字描述，需要他们阅读并根据严重程度进行分类。是暴力还是极其露骨的暴力？是骚扰还是仇恨言论？是儿童性虐待还是兽交？

Against this backdrop, OpenAI began the first phase of its project in late 2021. Under the code names PBJ1, PBJ2, PBJ3, and PBJ4, it thrust teams of Sama workers into more traumatic content-moderation work, for on average between $1.46 and $3.74 an hour. Workers had no idea for whom or why they were doing the project, kept in the dark under the nondisclosure terms of the contract, common in the data annotation industry. What they did know was what was in front of them: the hundreds of thousands of grotesque text-based descriptions that they needed to read and sort into categories of severity. Was it violence or extremely graphic violence, harassment or hate speech, child sexual abuse or bestiality?

渐渐地，这项工作让许多工人崩溃，其影响不仅波及到他们个人，还波及到社区里依赖他们的人。直到 ChatGPT 发布后，他们才开始明白，他们用这份安心换来的究竟是什么。5 月2023 年，我拜访了内罗毕的四名工人，他们同意与我公开分享他们的经历，以便发表在《华尔街日报》的头版上。对于色情内容团队中的一位成员，名叫莫法特·奥金伊 (Mophat Okinyi) 来说，这个让他心智崩溃、人际关系崩溃的项目，最终却被用于一项技术，而这项技术反过来又会蚕食他兄弟的经济机会。

Gradually, the work broke many of the workers, the impacts radiating beyond each individual to the people who depended on them in their communities. Only after the release of ChatGPT would they begin to grasp what exactly they had paid for with their peace of mind. In May 2023, I visited four workers in Nairobi who would agree to share their experiences with me on the record for a story on the front page of The Wall Street Journal. For one of them on the sexual content team, a man named Mophat Okinyi, the project that unraveled his mind and his relationships would turn out to be in service of a technology that would in turn contribute to the erosion of his brother’s economic opportunities.

—

—

在企业自由研究仍被允许的时代，微软人类学家玛丽·L·格雷 (Mary L. Gray) 和计算社会科学家 Siddharth Suri 是第一批向世界展示肯尼亚工人的困境的人，这些工人以人工智能供应链的重要环节为生。

At a time when freewheeling corporate research was still permitted, Microsoft anthropologist Mary L. Gray and computational social scientist Siddharth Suri were among the first to show the world the plight of workers like those in Kenya who build their livelihoods around an essential piece of the AI supply chain.

2019年，他们出版了《幽灵工作》（Ghost Work）一书，该书基于五年的广泛实地考察，揭示了支撑硅谷的隐秘的零散劳动和数字剥削网络。科技巨头和独角兽公司建立其高昂估值的秘诀不仅仅是依靠在时尚办公室里拿着六位数年薪的工程师。同样重要的还有那些通常位于全球南方国家的工人，他们拿着微薄的报酬仔细地注释大量数据。

In 2019, they published their book Ghost Work, based on five years of extensive fieldwork, revealing a hidden web of piecemeal labor and digital exploitation that propped up Silicon Valley. Tech giants and unicorns were building their extravagant valuations not just with engineers paid six-figure salaries in trendy offices. Essential, too, were workers, often in the Global South, being paid pennies to carefully annotate reams of data.

以自动驾驶汽车为例。自动驾驶汽车需要在正确的车道上行驶，对不稳定的驾驶行为做出反应，并在学生过马路时保持安全距离。为了做到这一点，控制汽车的软件系统融合了多种深度学习模型，其中包括专门用于识别道路物体的模型：车道线、路标、交通信号灯、车辆、树木、行人。

Take self-driving cars. A self-driving car needs to drive in the correct lane, respond to erratic driving behavior, and pause at a safe distance for schoolchildren crossing the road. To do this, the software system controlling the car uses an amalgamation of several deep learning models, including those dedicated to recognizing objects on the road: lane markings, road signs, traffic lights, vehicles, trees, pedestrians.

公司通过驾驶配备大量大型摄像头的车辆四处行驶，记录数十亿英里的影像来开发这些模型。这些影像就是数据，对其进行注释意味着要逐帧追踪出现的每一个物体——有时甚至精确到一只手握着自行车把手的弧度，或者一只半倚在车窗外的狗——并给它们贴上“自行车”、“车辆”、“动物”、“人类”等标签。这项工作必须由人工完成。从公司的角度来看，成本越低越好。

Companies develop those models by driving vehicles around with numerous large cameras, recording billions of miles of footage. The footage is the data, and to annotate it means tracing, frame by frame, each object that appears—sometimes down to the curvature of a hand gripping a bike handle or a dog lounging halfway out of a car window—and assigning them labels like “bike,” “vehicle,” “animal,” “human.” People have to do that work. And from a company’s perspective, the cheaper they do it, the better.

Gray 和 Suri 的研究重点部分集中在 Mechanical Turk 上，这是亚马逊在 2012 年深度学习热潮兴起前多年开发的一个平台。长期以来，它实际上充当了那些寻求廉价劳动力来从事各种零碎数字劳动的公司的实际中间人。到Ghost Work出现时，人工智能商业化的第一个时代已经在此外包模式的基础上发展、构建并迅速扩展。

Gray and Suri’s research focused in part on Mechanical Turk, a platform developed by Amazon many years before the deep learning boom in 2012, which for a long time served as the de facto middleman for companies looking to hire someone cheap for any kind of piecemeal digital labor. By the time Ghost Work came out, the first era of AI commercialization was already evolving, building upon, and rapidly expanding this outsourcing model.

我开始描绘这支隐形劳动力的新形态，挖掘出一条遍布全球、横跨多个国家的庞大劳动力输送管道，这既在意料之中，也出乎意料。我采访了取代Mechanical Turk的最新中间商——这些平台旨在更专注于人工智能开发。我采访了数十名工人，走访了一些人的家，与他们的家人共进晚餐，试图不仅了解他们所面临的宏观趋势，也了解他们日常生活的实际情况。

I began mapping out the new shape of this hidden workforce, unearthing a sprawling global pipeline of labor spanning many countries, both expected and surprising. I spoke with the newest middlemen replacing Mechanical Turk—platforms designed to cater more specifically to AI development. I spoke with dozens of workers, visiting some of their homes, eating dinner with their families, seeking to understand not just the macro trends pressing down on them but the daily textures of their lived realities.

正如人工智能商业化的初代为生成式人工智能时代的数据积累和计算资本化奠定了基础，它也为其大规模的劳动力剥削奠定了基础。因此，为了理解与 OpenAI 签约的肯尼亚工人的经历，首先了解这些基础至关重要。只有这样，我们才能认识到，他们的经历绝非个例，而是人工智能行业长期以来对待隐形工人的方式、对哪些人的劳动有价值或无价值的看法，与 OpenAI 追求空前规模的帝国式愿景交织在一起的直接结果。

Just as the first era of AI commercialization laid the groundwork for the generative AI era’s amassing of data and capitalization of compute, so, too, did it create the foundations for its wide-scale labor exploitation. In this way, it is important to first understand those foundations in order to understand the experience of the Kenyan workers who contracted for OpenAI. Only then is it possible to recognize that their experiences were far from anomalous but rather a direct consequence of the compounding of the AI industry’s long-standing treatment of its hidden workers and its views on whose labor is or isn’t valued, with OpenAI’s empire-esque vision for unprecedented scale.

—

—

在生成式人工智能出现之前，自动驾驶汽车是数据标注行业最大的增长动力。大众和宝马等老牌德国汽车巨头感到受到特斯拉和优步等新兴公司的威胁，纷纷成立新的自动驾驶汽车部门，以抵御新晋竞争对手。随着数十亿美元的新资金涌入这场打造未来汽车的竞赛，数据标注需求激增，并催生了对 Mechanical Turk 替代方案的需求。

Before generative AI, self-driving cars were the biggest source of growth for the data-annotation industry. Old-school German auto giants like Volkswagen and BMW, feeling threatened by the Teslas and Ubers of the world, spun up new autonomous-vehicle divisions to defend their ground against the fresh-faced competition. As billions of new dollars flooded into the race to create the cars of the future, the demand for data annotation exploded and created a need for alternatives to Mechanical Turk.

MTurk，正如其名称所示，是一个多面手平台，这意味着它没有无法满足任何特定类型的工作需求。它只是一个自助服务网站。它的界面——上线时还停留在2000年代中期的网页设计——提供了上传数据集、指定简单注释指令以及设定工作价格的功能。一旦任务被认领，它就会显示随机的数字和字母串来代替工人的名字。每个工人旁边都有两个按钮：一个是给他们奖励，另一个是将他们从项目中踢出。

MTurk, as it was called, was a generalist platform, meaning it didn’t cater to any particular kind of work. It was just a self-service website. Its interface—stuck in the web design of the mid-aughts, when it launched—had a place to upload datasets, to specify simple annotation instructions, and to set a price for the work. Once the task was claimed, it showed randomized strings of numbers and letters in place of the workers’ names. It had two buttons next to each worker: one to give them a bonus, the other to boot them off the project.

自动驾驶汽车的数据标注需要一种不同的方法。首先，它需要达到更高的准确度。过多的错误标注帧（例如车辆的边界标注混乱，行人完全没有被标注）可能会造成生死攸关的后果。为了保证质量，需要对工作人员进行培训，公司也需要编写详细的操作说明。此外，还需要建立更多的反馈和迭代机制。MTurk 一度失宠。随后，Scale AI、Hive、Mighty AI 和 Appen 等一批初创公司和老牌企业纷纷涌现。这些公司各自都有面向员工的平台，允许任何人创建账户并开始执行任务。

Data annotation for self-driving cars necessitated a different approach. First and foremost, it required a new level of accuracy. One too many mislabeled frames—vehicles traced with sloppy borders, pedestrians not traced at all—could be the difference between life and death. To guarantee that quality, workers needed to be trained and companies needed to write detailed instructions. There needed to be more mechanisms for feedback and iteration. MTurk fell out of favor. In stepped a wave of startups and incumbents including Scale AI, Hive, Mighty AI, and Appen. Each had their own worker-facing platforms, which allowed anyone to create an account and start tasking.

然而，就在这波新公司试图站稳脚跟之际，一件奇怪的事情发生了。他们面向员工的平台注册用户蜂拥而至，而注册用户却来自一个意想不到的国家：委内瑞拉。就在汽车巨头们开始争先恐后、资金开始涌入自动驾驶汽车、数据标注公司开始寻找更多员工的同时，委内瑞拉却一头扎进了五十年来全球最严重的和平时期经济危机。

But right as this new wave of companies sought to establish themselves, a strange thing happened. Sign-ups on their worker-facing platforms came rushing in from an unexpected country: Venezuela. In the same moment that auto giants began scrambling, money began pumping into self-driving cars, and data-annotation firms began looking for more workers, Venezuela was nose-diving headfirst into the worst peacetime economic crisis globally in fifty years.

经济学家表示，正是政治腐败和政府错误政策的混合体，挥霍了该国丰富的自然资源。委内瑞拉拥有世界上最大的已探明石油储量，曾是拉丁美洲最富有的国家。但从2016年开始，恶性通货膨胀失控；失业率飙升；暴力犯罪激增，全国各地的家庭眼睁睁地看着自己毕生积蓄的价值缩水。从2017年末到2019年，特朗普政府不断升级制裁，旨在惩罚委内瑞拉领导人尼古拉斯·马杜罗的独裁暴行，这给委内瑞拉经济敲响了丧钟。恶性通货膨胀击中了曾经深不可测的千万个百分点。那些拥有研究生学位、原本收入丰厚的人们现在却要整天在商店门前排队，只为获得微薄的大米和面粉配给。

Economists say it was a toxic cocktail of political corruption and the government’s misguided policies that squandered the country’s rich natural endowment. Venezuela sits atop the largest proven petroleum reserves in the world. It was once Latin America’s wealthiest country. But beginning in 2016, hyperinflation went haywire; unemployment skyrocketed; violent crime exploded as families across the country watched the value of their entire life savings collapse. From late 2017 to 2019, escalating sanctions imposed by the Trump administration, intended as a punishment for Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro’s authoritarian abuses, delivered the final death knell to Venezuela’s economy. Hyperinflation hit a once unfathomable 10 million percent. People with graduate degrees and previously well-paying jobs were now spending their days lining up in front of stores for a chance at receiving meager rations of rice and flour.

灾难发生后，许多委内瑞拉人转向网络平台寻找工作。截至2018年年中，数十万人发现并加入了数据标注行业，占一些外包公司员工总数的75%。在数据标注平台上工作成了一项全家参与的活动。耶鲁大学助理教授朱利安·波萨达采访了数十名委内瑞拉工人，发现父母和孩子经常轮流使用共用电脑工作；妻子们则回去做饭和打扫卫生，以便丈夫能够通过长时间不间断地工作来多赚一点钱。这场危机给伴随危机而来的人工智能外包公司浪潮留下了不可磨灭的印记。委内瑞拉并不是一个显而易见的劳动力资源选择。语言障碍使得这些主要位于旧金山和西雅图的公司更难与工人协调。但委内瑞拉人极度的绝望意味着他们愿意以极低的报酬工作，这反过来意味着这些公司可以为他们的服务提供极好的价格。 “这就像是一次奇怪的巧合，”研究数据注释行业兴起的德累斯顿应用技术大学教授弗洛里安·亚历山大·施密特 (Florian Alexander Schmidt) 在 2022 年告诉我。

Amid the catastrophe, many Venezuelans turned to online platforms for work. By mid-2018, hundreds of thousands had discovered and joined the data-annotation industry, accounting for as much as 75 percent of the workforce for some outsourcing firms. Working on data-annotation platforms became a whole-family activity. Julian Posada, an assistant professor at Yale University who interviewed dozens of Venezuelan workers, found that parents and children often took turns to work on a shared computer; wives reverted to cooking and cleaning to allow their husbands to earn just a little more money by pulling longer hours uninterrupted. The crisis left an indelible mark on the wave of AI-specialized outsourcing firms as they grew up alongside it. Venezuela was not an obvious choice for finding pools of labor. The language barrier made it more difficult for the mostly San Francisco– and Seattle-based firms to coordinate with workers. But the acute desperation among Venezuelans meant they were willing to work for astonishingly small amounts of money, which in turn meant the firms could offer astonishingly good prices for their services. “It was like a freak coincidence,” Florian Alexander Schmidt, a professor at the University of Applied Sciences Dresden who has studied the rise of the data-annotation industry, told me in 2022.

那个“反常的巧合”揭示了一个令人不安的规律。在面临经济崩溃之际，委内瑞拉突然具备了寻找取之不尽、用之不竭的廉价劳动力的完美条件：其人口受教育程度高，互联网连接良好，而且现在，无论工资多少，都渴望工作。委内瑞拉并非唯一符合这些条件的国家。越来越多的人正在接入更优质的互联网。随着气候变化的加速和地缘政治不稳定的加剧，很难预料会有更多人陷入危机。“很有可能会出现另一个委内瑞拉，”施密特说。

That “freak coincidence” revealed a disturbing formula. When faced with economic collapse, Venezuela suddenly checked off the perfect mix of conditions for which to find an inexhaustible supply of cheap labor: Its population had a high level of education, good internet connectivity, and, now, a zealous desire to work for whatever wages. It was not the only country that fit that description. More populations were getting wired to better internet. And with accelerating climate change and growing geopolitical instability, it was hard to bet against more populations plunging into crisis. “It’s quite likely there will be another Venezuela,” Schmidt said.

当时，施密特的预测让我怀疑第二次可能仍然是巧合，或者数据注释公司是否会借鉴之前的成功经验。在危机中寻找人才，或许能成为继续降低人工智能行业命脉——劳动力成本的可靠方法。几年后回首往事，事实确实如此——这也成为了旧帝国与人工智能帝国之间最令人震惊的相似之处之一。推动帝国快速积累财富的决定性特征之一是，它能够以极低的成本甚至完全不付出任何代价，从广泛的人类劳动力中获取经济利益。

At the time, Schmidt’s prediction made me wonder whether the second time around would still be coincidence or whether data-annotation firms would make a playbook out of what had worked there. Scouting workers in crisis could become a surefire way to continue driving down the costs of the labor that serves as the lifeblood of the AI industry. Looking back several years later, that’s exactly what happened—and what has become one of the most stunning parallels between empires of old and empires of AI. One of the defining features that drives an empire’s rapid accumulation of wealth is its ability to pay very little or nothing at all to reap the economic benefits of a broad base of human labor.

—

—

2021年12月，我穿越哥伦比亚蜿蜒的山脉，去更好地了解一位在危机中转向数据标注的工人的生活。由于旅行限制，我无法前往委内瑞拉，但委内瑞拉的邻国生活着近两百万委内瑞拉难民，占这场经济灾难中流离失所人口的三分之一。

In December 2021, I journeyed through the winding mountains of Colombia to better understand the life of a worker who, in crisis, had turned to data annotation. Travel restrictions barred me from going to Venezuela, but here in its neighboring country lived nearly two million Venezuelan refugees, one-third of the population that had been displaced by the economic catastrophe.

朱利安·波萨达 (Julian Posada) 帮我联系了其中一位，她名叫奥斯卡琳娜·维罗妮卡·富恩特斯·阿纳亚 (Oskarina Veronica Fuentes Anaya)，逃离祖国后继续在数据注释行业工作。富恩特斯是第一个向我展示这份工作真正是什么样子的人——她如何为了某个平台而重新调整了自己的整个生活；而那个平台又如何将她视为可有可无的东西。

Julian Posada connected me with one of them, a woman named Oskarina Veronica Fuentes Anaya, who continued to work in the data-annotation industry after she escaped her home country. Fuentes was the first person to show me what this work is really like—the way she’d reoriented her entire life around working for a platform; the way that platform in turn treated her as disposable.

在她与六位亲戚合住的公寓里，我们并肩坐在客厅里，看着她在Appen上一屏一屏地浏览。任务五花八门，从电商网站上的产品分类——这件商品应该列在服装还是配饰类别？ ——到社交媒体内容审核——这段视频是否包含犯罪或侵犯人权的内容？对于需要英语的任务，她会使用谷歌翻译将文本转换成她的母语西班牙语。

In the apartment she shared with half a dozen relatives, we sat side by side in the living room as she clicked through screen after screen on Appen. The tasks were varied. They ranged from categorizing products on e-commerce sites—Should this item be listed under clothing or accessories?—to performing content moderation for social media—Does this video contain crime or human rights violations? For tasks that required English, she used Google Translate to convert the text into her native Spanish.

每次她完成一项任务，她获得的美元金额就会增加几美分。她至少需要存入10美元才能提现，这在她刚加入平台时并不成问题。但现在，她可能需要几周时间才能攒够这笔钱。很多钱。这个最低限额有时感觉像是一个残酷的仲裁者，决定着她是否有足够的钱来支付食品杂货的费用。

Each time she completed a task, the sum of money she earned, displayed in US dollars, would increase by a few pennies. She needed a minimum of ten dollars to withdraw it, which, when she first joined the platform, wasn’t a problem. Now, it could take weeks to accumulate that much money. That minimum sometimes felt like a cruel arbiter of whether she had enough funds to pay for groceries.

对于实际居住在委内瑞拉的工人来说，提款过程更加困难。大多数全球支付系统（例如 PayPal）都不允许向委内瑞拉汇款。委内瑞拉的大多数商店也不接受支持这些系统的付款。这意味着工人需要将他们的数字资金兑换成现金才能购买基本商品和服务。但是，如果线上汇款是以美元支付的，那么现金则需要兑换成委内瑞拉玻利瓦尔。在黑市上，兑换美元和玻利瓦尔的骗局层出不穷，佣金也很高。

For workers actually living in Venezuela, the process of withdrawal was even more challenging. Most global payment systems such as PayPal didn’t allow money transfers into Venezuela. Most stores and shops in Venezuela didn’t accept payments from the ones that do. This meant workers needed to convert their digital funds into cash to pay for basic goods and services.
