EA 将理论上的流氓人工智能认定为生存风险，并宣扬了与 OpenAI 从一开始就根植于其 DNA 中并在“离婚”事件中发挥关键作用的人工智能安全理念。Amodei 和他的 Anthropic 联合创始人团队与 Altman 及其他 OpenAI 高管在如何严肃对待人工智能毁灭文明的可能性上存在根本分歧。Amodei 对此非常重视，他认为 Altman 的行为——他在与微软的交易中缺乏透明度；他为了获得同意总是说他们想说的话，结果人们发现为时已晚——不仅是硅谷高管的典型伎俩，更是令人担忧的不道德行为，可能危及人类的命运。随着 Anthropic 的崛起，它逐渐倾向于这种声誉：Altman 的 OpenAI 肆意玩弄人类的未来，而 Anthropic 则是一家原则性强、将人工智能安全放在首位的公司。

With the identification of theoretical rogue AI as an existential risk, EA promulgated the same brand of AI safety that had been entwined within OpenAI’s DNA from the very beginning and had played a critical role in The Divorce. Amodei and his fellow Anthropic cofounders fundamentally disagreed with Altman and the other OpenAI executives over how seriously to take the possibility of AI devastating civilization. Amodei, who took it very seriously, viewed Altman’s behaviors—his lack of transparency on the Microsoft deal; his apparent compulsion to always tell people what they wanted to hear to gain their agreement, only for them to discover the misdirection too late—not just as the typical machinations of a Silicon Valley executive but as alarming, immoral behavior that could jeopardize the fate of humanity. As Anthropic established itself, it would lean into this reputational distinction: Where Altman’s OpenAI was toying recklessly with humanity’s future, Anthropic was the principled, AI-safety-first company.

—

—

2021年，随着阿莫迪兄妹宣布创立“人性”（Anthropic），人们对这种灾难性且关乎生存的人工智能安全理念的兴趣日益高涨，这主要得益于EA迅速扩张的影响力。得益于科技界亿万富翁的资金注入，EA已从一种小众理念发展成为一场主流运动。

In 2021, as the Amodei siblings announced Anthropic, interest in this catastrophic and existential AI safety ideology was accelerating, chiefly due to EA’s rapidly expanding sphere of influence. EA had grown from a niche philosophy into a mainstream movement through an influx of cash from tech billionaires.

十年前，Facebook 联合创始人达斯汀·莫斯科维茨和他的妻子、前记者卡里·图纳成立了一个名为 Good Ventures 的非营利组织，捐赠了他们的大部分财富。当时，丹妮拉·阿莫迪未来的丈夫霍尔顿·卡诺夫斯基正在运营另一个名为 GiveWell 的组织，该组织是他在 2007 年离开对冲基金桥水基金后创立的。Good Ventures 和 GiveWell 都希望以循证方法分配资金，因此于 2011 年建立了合作伙伴关系，后来他们将其命名为“开放慈善”（Open Philanthropy）。他们开始加大对 MacAskill 所建议的关键问题领域的资助——特别是对人工智能安全研究的资助受到 EA 框架的指导。开放慈善组织于 2017 年 6 月成为一个独立组织。

A decade earlier, Facebook cofounder Dustin Moskovitz and his wife, former journalist Cari Tuna, had formed a nonprofit called Good Ventures to give away most of their fortune. At the time, Holden Karnofsky, Daniela Amodei’s future husband, had been running a different organization called GiveWell, which he’d founded in 2007 after leaving the hedge fund Bridgewater Associates. With a shared desire to distribute money with evidence-based methods, Good Ventures and GiveWell formed a partnership in 2011, which they later named Open Philanthropy. They began ramping up funding to the key issue areas that MacAskill had recommended—its grants toward AI safety research in particular were guided by the EA framework. Open Philanthropy became an independent organization in June 2017.

最近，一位新的科技亿万富翁登上了舞台：塞缪尔·班克曼-弗里德 (Samuel Bankman-Fried)，他因共同创立加密货币交易所 FTX 和加密货币交易公司 Alameda Research 而获得巨大成功，成为一颗冉冉升起的新星。班克曼-弗里德（Bankman-Fried，昵称SBF）将自己的创业故事归功于EA。他是麻省理工学院的物理学专业学生，他说自己原本想成为一名学者，但麦克阿斯基尔在午餐时说服了他“赚钱去捐赠”的道德优越性。SBF随后下定决心，尽可能地让自己变得富有，最终，他承诺将自己的所有财富都投入到慈善事业中。

More recently, a new tech billionaire had entered the scene: Samuel Bankman-Fried, a rapidly rising star for his wild success cofounding the crypto exchange FTX and crypto trading firm Alameda Research. Bankman-Fried, or SBF as he is known, credited EA for his origin story. A physics major at MIT, he said he had wanted to be an academic before MacAskill convinced him over lunch of the moral superiority of “earn to give.” SBF subsequently set his course on making himself as rich as possible in order to eventually, he pledged, put it all into philanthropy.

SBF 在极短的时间内积累了巨额财富，并向民主党和共和党的政治候选人捐赠了数千万美元，其中包括 2022 年俄勒冈州第六国会选区首位 EA 支持的候选人（最终未能赢得初选）。SBF 的交易所签署了总额达数十亿美元的体育营销协议，涉及汤姆·布雷迪和斯蒂芬·库里等顶级运动员以及一级方程式赛车等顶级体育赛事。他不仅为 EA 运动注入了资金，还动用了明星效应。他越富有、越出名，就越能提升这一意识形态及其联合创始人麦克阿斯基尔的知名度。2022 年初，SBF 宣布创建自己的由 EA 驱动的慈善项目 FTX 未来基金，到年底将分配至少 1 亿美元、最多 10 亿美元。

As he amassed his wealth in remarkably short order, SBF donated tens of millions to political candidates, both Democrat and Republican, including the first ever EA-backed candidate in 2022 in Oregon’s Sixth Congressional District (who ultimately didn’t win the primary). SBF’s exchange inked lavish deals totaling billions on sports marketing involving top athletes like Tom Brady and Steph Curry and top sports like Formula One. Into the EA movement, he pumped not just money but star power. The richer and more famous he became, the more he raised the profile of the ideology and its cofounder MacAskill. At the start of 2022, SBF announced the creation of his own EA-driven philanthropic project, FTX Future Fund, to distribute at least $100 million and up to $1 billion by the end of the year.

在很大程度上，由于 Open Phil 和 FTX Future Fund，2021 年和 2022 年 EA 支持的人工智能安全研究的现金流大幅增加。根据 EA 社区成员和 Open Phil 数据统计，两年来的资金均跃升至 1 亿美元以上，而此前七年的平均资金额还不到这个数字的一半。这股资金的涌入，以及随之而来的是，人们日益增长的信念：从 GPT-2 到 GPT-3 能力的飞跃，使得预防理论上的流氓人工智能和实际存在的人工智能风险比以往任何时候都更加紧迫。越来越多的人涌向这类人工智能安全项目，他们要么受到经济激励，要么受到意识形态的吸引，成为更广泛的 EA 运动的成员。规模迅速膨胀。EA 长期以来一直强调疫情防控的重要性，如今，在一场真正的疫情中，其卓越的预见性为其赢得了新的拥护者。全球灾难带来的心理创伤也让许多人感到焦虑和失落，开始寻找人生的意义。

In large part due to Open Phil and FTX Future Fund, 2021 and 2022 saw a jump in cash flow to EA-backed AI safety research. According to estimates compiled by a member of the EA community and Open Phil data, funding leapt up above $100 million each for both years, after averaging less than half that amount over the previous seven years. The influx fueled and was fueled by a proliferating belief that the dramatic leap in capabilities from GPT-2 to GPT-3 made preventing theoretical rogue AI and existential AI risks more urgent than ever before. More and more people flocked to these kinds of AI safety projects, drawn in by the financial incentive or by ideology, as membership in the broader EA movement ballooned. EA had long touted the importance of pandemic preparedness, and now, in the midst of an actual pandemic, its remarkable prescience won it new adherents. The psychological toll of a global catastrophe had also left many people anxious and unmoored, searching for purpose.

人工智能安全社区的成员不断增加，将 EA 支持的人工智能安全与其他灾难性、存在性和风险为中心的思维结合在一起，在补充 OpenAI 安全家族成员的同时，也扩大了 Anthropic 的队伍。在线 EA 和 AI 安全论坛是这些重叠运动传播、交流和辩论思想的主要场所，它鼓励追随者在主要的 AI 实验室工作，特别是那些他们认为需要更多 AI 安全监督机构的实验室，如 OpenAI 和 DeepMind，以塑造和规范他们的发展轨迹。人工智能安全领域成员的涌入也使社区词汇在人工智能行业得到了更广泛的普及。你认为人工智能将以多快的速度发展并达到像 AGI 这样的重要里程碑，这就是你的“人工智能时间表”。你认为 AGI 会导致灾难性后果（即杀死大部分人类人口）或生存性后果（即人类彻底灭绝）的可能性有多大，这就是你的“p(doom)”，即毁灭概率的缩写。OpenAI 2021 年研究路线图中提到的“硬件过剩”是另一个词典条目，还有“人工智能起飞”，即 AGI 改进到超级智能程度并因此有能力超越人类的过程。“加速风险”是指引发公司或国家之间激烈竞争的风险，这种竞争可能导致人工智能进步加速并缩短人工智能时间表。

The growing membership in the AI safety community, which knit together EA-backed AI safety with other strains of catastrophic, existential, and risk-focused thinking, swelled Anthropic’s ranks just as it restocked OpenAI’s Safety clan. Online EA and AI safety forums, the primary ground for the overlapping movements to propagate, exchange, and debate ideas, encouraged adherents to work at the major AI labs, especially those they felt needed more AI safety watchdogs, like OpenAI and DeepMind, to shape and mold their trajectory. The influx of members in AI safety also popularized the community’s lexicon more broadly in the AI industry. How fast you think AI will advance and reach major milestones like AGI is your “AI timeline.” How likely you think it is that AGI will lead to catastrophic outcomes, meaning the killing off of most of the human population, or existential outcomes, meaning the complete and total extinction of humanity, is your “p(doom),” short for probability of doom. “Hardware overhang,” as referenced in OpenAI’s 2021 research road map, is another dictionary entry, as is “AI takeoff,” the process of AGI improving to the point of superintelligence and thus capable enough to outwit humanity. “Acceleration risk” refers to the risk of triggering a heightened competition between companies or countries that leads to a potentially dangerous acceleration of AI advancement and a shortened AI timeline.

然而，对于一场宣扬独立思考的运动来说，EA 却正迅速加速走向相反的方向。被其理念吸引的人们很快被灌输了一套更广泛的教条，其驱动力源于更多机会和资源的承诺，以及一个封闭的社交网络，它对个人和职业界限的界限游移不定。尤其是在硅谷，EA 员工基本上只与其他 EA 员工一起工作；他们也基本上只与其他 EA 员工一起生活、聚会、约会和睡觉。科技行业根深蒂固的性别歧视和湾区长期存在的多元恋爱亚文化，加上这种类似邪教的狂热，如果以最糟糕的方式表现出来，可能会变成一口有毒的大锅性、金钱和权力；这导致 EA 受到越来越多的性骚扰和性虐待指控的困扰。

But for a movement that professed independent thinking, EA was swiftly accelerating in the opposite direction. People attracted to its premise were quickly indoctrinated into a broader set of dogmas, propelled by the promise of more opportunities and resources, and an insular social network that played fast and loose with personal and professional boundaries. Within Silicon Valley in particular, EA people largely worked only with other EA people; they largely lived, partied, dated, and slept only with other EA people. Mixed with the tech industry’s deep-rooted sexism and the Bay Area’s long-standing polyamorous subcultures, its cultlike fervor, manifested in the worst way, could turn into a toxic cauldron of sex, money, and power; it was leading EA to be plagued by growing allegations of sexual harassment and abuse.

2022年11月，随着FTX的倒闭，SBF轰然倒下，他本人也因此被判处巨额欺诈罪名成立，并被判处25年监禁。对许多人来说，这不过是这场运动内部腐败的象征。EA迅速风靡一时，却在科技行业中逐渐失宠，许多人也迅速与它断绝了关系。

In November 2022, SBF’s spectacular downfall with the collapse of FTX, along with his sweeping fraud convictions and ensuing twenty-five-year prison sentence, would be to many a symptom of the rot that had festered in the movement. Just as quickly as it caught on, EA fell out of fashion within the tech industry, and many people rapidly disaffiliated.

但即使没有这个标签，这场运动的社交网络、价值观和术语，以及它为关乎生存的人工智能安全问题所确立的突出地位，仍将持续存在。它还将催生一股制衡力量：e/acc（发音为“ee-ack”），即有效加速主义。最初，它主要是为了讽刺 EA 运动而开的一个玩笑，却很快将其截然相反的精神奉为圭臬：EA 和更广泛的人工智能安全社区培育了最极端的观点，即减缓甚至踩下人工智能发展的速度，或者像 Amodei 认为的那样，加速人工智能发展，同时限制人工智能的采用；而 e/acc 则提升了对两者都踩油门的极端主义观点。对于后者的追随者来说，技术进步不仅普遍有益，而且尽快取得进步是一种道德责任。这两群人被俗称为末日论者和婴儿潮论者。

But even without the label, the movement’s social networks, its values and lingo, and the prominence it secured for existential AI safety issues would persist. It would also give rise to a countervailing force: e/acc (pronounced “ee-ack”), or effective accelerationism. What began largely as a joke to lampoon the EA movement would quickly enshrine its polar opposite spirit: Where EA and the broader AI safety community cultivated the most extreme perspectives about slowing down and even slamming the brakes on AI development, or, as in Amodei’s view, accelerating AI development while throttling AI adoption, e/acc would elevate the maximalist view of flooring the accelerator on both. For the latter’s adherents, technological progress is not just universally good, it’s a moral imperative to make that progress as fast as possible. The two groups became colloquially known as the Doomers and Boomers.

在这个泡沫中，一些人开始将 Anthropic 和 OpenAI 视为各自运动的代表。另一些人则将 OpenAI 视为两极化意识形态的战场，一个曾经根植于末日论者思维的非营利组织，如今正被婴儿潮一代（Boomers）所取代，因为它通过其营利部门越来越强调赚钱。许多人不确定 Altman 的忠诚度，并指出他在不同时期似乎对两者都抱有同情。而那些更宽容的人则认为他处于中间位置，肩负着代表公司内部所有不同观点的艰巨任务。但从“离婚”事件以及 Altman 与 Anthropic 联合创始人之间的个人恩怨开始，越来越多的末日论者开始以最坏的眼光看待 Altman。许多让 OpenAI 声名鹊起并为其带来日益增长的商业成功的项目，都始于人工智能安全项目：缩放定律、代码生成、强化学习从人类反馈中学习，将这三者结合起来，形成极具吸引力的大型语言模型和多模态模型。许多末日论者会觉得他们的工作被利用和扭曲，以实现与他们的核心价值观截然相反的目标。在他们看来，正是奥特曼在进行这种利用和扭曲。这使得他成为一个病态的骗子、一个操纵施虐者，以及他自己对人类的威胁。

Within this bubble, some would begin to view Anthropic and OpenAI as the respective faces of each movement. Others would view OpenAI as a battleground for the polarized ideologies, an organization once rooted in Doomer thinking as a nonprofit that was being yanked away by Boomers with its increasing emphasis, through its for-profit arm, on making money. Many were uncertain about Altman’s allegiance, citing different times he seemed sympathetic to both. Those who were more charitable viewed him as somewhere in the middle, dealing with the tough job of representing all of the different perspectives within his company. But beginning with The Divorce, and the personal fallout between Altman and the Anthropic cofounders, more and more Doomers would begin to view Altman in the worst light possible. So many of the things that put OpenAI on the map and would bring it increasing commercial success had begun as AI safety projects: scaling laws, code generation, reinforcement learning from human feedback, the combination of these three into incredibly compelling large language and then multimodal models. Many Doomers would feel their work was being co-opted and twisted to achieve something directly antithetical to their core values. In their view, it was Altman that was doing that co-opting and twisting. And that made him a pathological liar, a manipulative abuser, and his own threat to humanity.

很快，OpenAI 内部及其周边环境之间两极化的意识形态冲突，就威胁到了这家为人工智能发展新时代基调做出最大贡献的公司。尽管两种意识形态声称彼此截然相反，但实际上它们都在宣扬同一本圣经。两者都将通用人工智能视为一个日益成定局的必然结果，并带着宗教般的狂热；两者都着眼于长远发展，并宣称拥有道德权威，要将人工智能的发展控制在其信徒的掌控之下。一方警告人工智能将面临火与硫磺的威胁，而另一方则用天堂的景象来诱惑人们。

Soon enough, the clash between these polarized ideologies within OpenAI and its surrounding environment would threaten to tear apart the company that had done more than any other to set the tone of the new era of AI development. But as much as each ideology professed to be the opposite to the other, both were in fact preaching from the same bible. Both discussed AGI as an increasingly foregone conclusion and with a religious ferocity; both fixated on the long term and asserted a moral authority to keep AI development within the control of its adherents. Where one warned of fire and brimstone, the other tantalized with visions of heaven.

—

—

2022年初，OpenAI准备测试一种不同的产品发布策略，这次是其文本转图像项目。它既不会将模型隐藏在API之后，也不会将产品和品牌交给微软。OpenAI将自行发布，并将技术直接交到消费者手中。该模型甚至有一个引人注目的名字，由公司最初开发它的研究人员起名：DALL-E 2，取材于西班牙超现实主义艺术家萨尔瓦多·达利和迪士尼·皮克斯电影《机器人总动员》中的同名机器人。

In early 2022, OpenAI was ready to test a different product release strategy, this time with its text-to-image work. It would neither hide the model behind an API nor hand off the product and brand to Microsoft. OpenAI would do the release itself and put the technology directly into the hands of consumers. The model even had an eye-catching name from the original researchers who’d developed it in the company: DALL-E 2, a play off the Spanish surrealist artist Salvador Dalí and the titular robot in the Disney Pixar movie WALL-E.

DALL-E 诞生于人工智能研究领域更广泛的趋势，即开发多模态模型——结合至少两种不同“模态”的模型，例如文本、图像、声音或视频。多年来，该领域一直致力于融合前两种——语言和视觉——以便通过一个模型将文字与视觉信息关联起来。这部分源于现有数据——文本和图像在网络上拥有丰富的资源，且最易于处理——以及一个科学假设：如果纯粹的语言不足以产生人类水平的智能，那么视觉很可能是第二重要的因素。

DALL-E had spun out of a trend in the broader field of AI research to develop multimodal models—models that combine at least two different “modalities,” such as text, images, sound, or video. For years the field had been working to merge the first two—language and vision—so a single model would be capable of relating words to visual information. This was driven in part by the data available—text and images are abundant online and the easiest to process—and by a scientific hypothesis: If pure language is not enough to produce human-level intelligence, vision is likely the second most powerful ingredient.

OpenAI 的研究团队也从该领域汲取灵感，采用了同样的发展路径：在语言模型之后，他们转向了文本和图像模型，并且至关重要的是，他们专注于继续使用 Transformer，以保持模型的可扩展性。虽然第一代 Transformer 最初设计用于处理文本，但谷歌在 2020 年推出了一款全新的 Vision Transformer，使其适用于图像。

At OpenAI, taking the field as inspiration, the research team had adopted the same progression: After language models, they’d moved on to text-and-image models, and, crucially, focused on continuing to use Transformers in order to retain the model’s scalability. While the first Transformer had been initially designed to work best with text, Google had introduced a new Vision Transformer in 2020, adapting it to images.

2021 年 1 月，OpenAI 展示了两种基于 Transformer 的新模型。第一个叫做 CLIP，再次由 Alec Radford 开发，它结合使用原始 Transformer 和 Vision Transformer 来为图像生成详细的标题。第二台 DALL-E 1 由曾在纽约大学学习并曾在 Meta 的 Yann LeCun 手下工作的研究员 Aditya Ramesh 研发，他训练了一个拥有 120 亿个参数的 Transformer 来接受文本并生成新颖的图像。

In January 2021, OpenAI showcased two new Transformer-based models. The first, called CLIP, developed once again by Alec Radford, used the original Transformer and Vision Transformer together to generate detailed captions for images. The second, DALL-E 1, from Aditya Ramesh, a researcher who had studied at New York University and for a time under Meta’s Yann LeCun, trained a twelve-billion-parameter Transformer to accept text and generate novel images.

OpenAI 在一篇博客文章中，用一系列有趣的提示来强调 DALL-E 1 的能力，其中包括“鳄梨扶手椅”。它生成了各种以鳄梨为美学灵感的绿色和棕色扶手椅。图像略显模糊和卡通化，这是 Ramesh 在制作该模型时使用的训练过程造成的。他压缩了 2.5 亿张图像，以便将它们输入到 Transformer 中，在此过程中丢失了一些高分辨率细节。

In a blog post, OpenAI highlighted DALL-E 1’s capabilities with a series of playful prompts, including “an avocado armchair,” which produced various green and brown armchairs aesthetically inspired by avocados. The images were slightly blurry and cartoonish, an artifact of the training process that Ramesh had used to produce the model. He had compressed 250 million images to feed them into the Transformer, losing some of their high-resolution details in the process.

随着团队开始开发 DALL-E 2，一种新的图像生成方法逐渐受到关注。这种方法被称为扩散，是一种受物理学启发的技术，它使 Transformer 能够更好地学习大量图像中像素之间的相关性。最初的想法来自斯坦福大学和伯克利大学研究人员于 2015 年发表的一篇论文。五年后，在 OpenAI 早期研究员之一 Pieter Abbeel 的指导下，伯克利大学的研究生 Jonathan Ho 通过巧妙地改进这项技术，使其能够生成更高保真度的图像，从而推广了这项技术。Ho 还证明了扩散模型能够比现有的计算机视觉系统更好地识别图像。这一发现与 Radford 自己在 GPT-1 上取得的成果相似：在学习合成令人信服的图像（相当于生成类似人类的句子）时，扩散模型能够以足够深的层次捕捉训练数据中的模式，从而执行更广泛的视觉处理任务。

As the team started on DALL-E 2, a new method for generating images was gaining traction. Known as diffusion, it was a technique inspired by physics that made it possible for Transformers to better learn the correlations between pixels in a vast swath of images. The original idea had come from a 2015 paper written by Stanford and Berkeley researchers. Five years later, Jonathan Ho, a Berkeley graduate student advised by Pieter Abbeel, one of the early OpenAI researchers, had popularized the technique by cleverly revamping it in ways that generated far more high-fidelity images. Ho also showed that diffusion models could recognize images better than existing computer-vision systems. The findings paralleled Radford’s own results with GPT-1: In learning to synthesize convincing images—the equivalent of generating humanlike sentences—diffusion models had captured the patterns within their training data at a deep enough level to perform a broader range of tasks in visual processing.

OpenAI 改变策略，利用扩散和 Radford 的 CLIP 构建 DALL-E 2。Ramesh 和其他研究人员逐渐扩大了模型规模，并添加了修复功能——用户可以擦除照片中人物的头发并改变其颜色，或者选中照片中的一片草地，并在其中填充漫步的斑马。使用扩散技术可以创建更加清晰、更加逼真的图像；该方法还显著减少了实现与 DALL-E 1 相同性能所需的计算量。

OpenAI changed tack to building DALL-E 2 with diffusion and Radford’s CLIP. Ramesh and other researchers gradually scaled up the model and added the ability to inpaint—allowing a user to erase a person’s hair in a photo and change its color, or select a grassy meadow in a picture and populate it with roaming zebras. Using diffusion created much sharper and more photorealistic images; the method also significantly reduced the amount of compute needed to achieve the same performance as DALL-E 1.

OpenAI 以外的研究人员会进一步降低扩散模型的计算强度。流行的开源图像生成器“稳定扩散”只需要256 台 Nvidia A100 处理器进行训练，使用一种名为潜在扩散的改进技术。慕尼黑大学教授 Björn Ommer 的实验室创造了稳定扩散技术，他表示，在看到图像生成器步大型语言模型的后尘，成本变得极其高昂后，他开发了这项技术。“我们被困在一列火车上，这列火车的方向不仅仅是训练，推理实际上需要超级计算机来运行；数百万美元的投资，”他说道。“我们在想，能否让更大的研究社区重新参与进来，确保生成式人工智能领域不会走向只有少数几家大型科技公司才拥有运行和托管这些模型所需资源的方向？”

Researchers outside of OpenAI would shrink the compute intensity of diffusion models even further. Stable Diffusion, the popular open-source image generator, would require only 256 Nvidia A100s to train, using a revised technique known as latent diffusion. Björn Ommer, a professor at the Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich whose lab created Stable Diffusion, says he developed the technique after watching image generators go the way of large language models and grow obscenely costly. “We were stuck on a train which was going in the direction of—not just training—but inference actually taking supercomputers to run; millions of dollars of investments,” he says. “We were wondering, could we get the larger research community back in the game and make sure the field of generative AI is not moving in the direction where just a handful of big tech companies would have the required resources to run and to host those models?”

OpenAI 直到很晚才采用潜在扩散，这使得 DALL-E 2 和 3 的计算成本远高于稳定扩散或 Midjourney，而许多用户认为后者是更高质量的产品。这只是一个例子，说明即使在生成式人工智能这个狭窄的领域内，规模化也不是拓展人工智能能力的唯一途径，甚至也不是性能最高的途径。

OpenAI wouldn’t adopt latent diffusion until much later, leaving DALL-E 2 and 3 much more computationally expensive than Stable Diffusion or Midjourney, which many users deemed the higher-quality products. It was just one example of how, even within the narrow realm of generative AI, scale was not the only, or even the highest-performing, path to more expanded AI capabilities.

—

—

随着 DALL-E 2 性能的显著提升，应用材料部门于 2021 年底和 2022 年初开始着手研究不同的产品化方案。最终，他们选定了一款名为“Labs”的 Web 应用，让用户可以通过浏览器试用该模型以及其他未来的模型。产品负责人 Fraser Kelton 和副总裁 Bob McGrew 都认为，这样的产品交互式体验能够满足他们从 GitHub Copilot 中注意到的人们直接与生成式 AI 模型互动的明确需求。这也有助于实现公司的使命：DALL-E 2 充满乐趣，令人愉悦，是缓解人们对强大 AI 系统的恐惧的绝佳方式，并为 OpenAI 在未来版本中展现更多技术优势铺平道路。

With DALL-E 2’s remarkable jump in performance, the Applied division began working in late 2021 and early 2022 on different ideas for productization. It settled on a web app called Labs that would allow users to play around with the model—and other future models—through a browser. Both product head Fraser Kelton and VP Bob McGrew believed that such an interactive experience would satisfy the clear demand they noticed from GitHub Copilot that people had for engaging directly with generative AI models. It would also help serve the company’s mission: DALL-E 2 was fun and delightful, a great way to ease people’s fears about powerful AI systems and pave the way for OpenAI to deliver more of its technology’s benefits in future releases.

由于产品团队规模仍然相对较小，公司招募了一些新成员来协助网站的设计和开发。对于这些来自更传统企业背景的新成员来说，OpenAI 仍然感觉更像是在大学研究实验室工作，而不是在公司工作。他们通常每天阅读学术论文、进行理论辩论，而不是审阅界面模型。但对一些研究人员来说，应用材料公司员工越来越多地出现在他们的研究会议上，让他们感觉恰恰相反。过去那种只进行纯粹探索性研究（例如讨论如何构建更好的多模态模型的全新想法）的日子已经一去不复返了；现在，他们越来越多的研究服务于商业化，例如研究如何优化现有模型以更好地服务于用户。

With a still relatively small product staff, the company recruited a few others to help with the website’s design and development. To those new members, who hailed from more traditional corporate backgrounds, OpenAI still felt more like working at a university research lab than at a company. Days were often spent reading academic papers and having theoretical debates instead of reviewing mock-ups for interfaces. But to some researchers, the growing presence of Applied staff in their research meetings made them feel the opposite. Gone were the days when all of it was spent on purely exploratory research, like discussing fundamentally new ideas about how to make a better multimodal model; now a growing fraction of their research was in service of commercialization, such as figuring out how to optimize existing models for serving up to users.

在使用 AI Dungeon 成功应对基于文本的儿童性虐待问题后，尤其令人担忧的是 DALL-E 2 可能被用于操纵真实或合成儿童性虐待内容（CSAM）。与每个 GPT 模型一样，后续每个 DALL-E 模型的训练数据也越来越受到污染。为了开发 DALL-E 2，研究团队与图片库平台 Shutterstock 签署了许可协议，并大规模爬取 Twitter 数据，以扩充其现有的 2.5 亿张图片库。尤其是 Twitter 数据集充斥着色情内容。几名员工付出了巨大的努力来检查并剔除任何 CSAM。

After the experience of firefighting text-based child sex abuse with AI Dungeon, of particular concern was the possibility of DALL-E 2 being used to manipulate real or create synthetic child sexual abuse material, or CSAM. As with each GPT model, the training data for each subsequent DALL-E model was growing more and more polluted. For DALL-E 2, the research team had signed a licensing deal with stock photo platform Shutterstock and done a massive scrape of Twitter to add to its existing collection of 250 million images. The Twitter dataset in particular was riddled with pornographic content. Several employees made a significant effort to check for and cull any CSAM.

但经过一番讨论后，员工们保留了其他类型的性图片，部分原因是他们认为这类内容是人类体验的一部分。然而，将这些照片保留在训练数据中意味着该模型仍然能够生成合成的CSAM。就像DALL-E只见过牛油果扶手椅一样鳄梨和扶手椅，DALL-E 2 和 DALL-E 3 可以对儿童和儿童色情制品做同样的事情，这种能力被称为“合成生成”。

But after some discussion, the employees left in other types of sexual images, in part because they felt such content was part of the human experience. Keeping such photos in the training data, however, meant the model would still be able to produce synthetic CSAM. In the same way DALL-E could generate an avocado armchair having only ever seen avocados and armchairs, DALL-E 2 and DALL-E 3 could do the same thing with children and porn for child pornography, a capability known as “compositional generation.”

由于没有过滤数据来解决问题的根源，重担转移到了围绕该模型构建滥用预防机制。这包括更新的内容审核过滤器，该过滤器围绕该模型，除了文本之外，还能屏蔽滥用图像，此外还有一个用户行为监控平台和一个所谓的禁令基础设施——这些系统会自动暂停重复违规次数达到一定阈值的用户账户。该公司聘请了一位新的信任与安全主管戴夫·威尔纳 (Dave Willner)，他曾在 Facebook 担任早期员工，撰写了该平台的首批内容标准。

Without filtering the data to address the root of the problem, the burden shifted to building out abuse-prevention mechanisms around the model. This included updated content-moderation filters that wrapped around the model to block abusive images in addition to text as well as a user-behavior-monitoring platform and a so-called ban infrastructure—systems that automatically suspended user accounts that reached a certain threshold of repeat offenses. The company brought on a new head of trust and safety, Dave Willner, who as an early employee at Facebook had written that platform’s very first content standards.

后来，在 DALL-E 3 的开发过程中，随着数据需求的不断增长，研究团队意识到色情图片不再只是“锦上添花”，而是“必需品”。互联网上色情图片的比例如此之大，以至于删除它们会大幅缩减训练数据集，从而显著降低模型的性能。尤其值得注意的是，由于 Deborah Raji 在 Clarifai 实习期间发现的相同问题，删除后模型在生成女性和有色人种面孔方面的表现更差：描绘这两个群体的在线内容中，相当一部分都带有露骨的色情内容。出于同样的原因，研究人员保留了一些其他令人不安的图片。

Later, during the development of DALL-E 3, when the data imperative had grown even larger, the research team decided that sexual images were no longer just a “nice to have” but a “need to have.” The share of pornographic images on the internet was so large that removing them shrank the training dataset enough to notably degrade the model’s performance. In particular, it made the model worse at generating faces of women and people of color due to the same discovery that Deborah Raji made as a Clarifai intern: A significant share of the online content depicting both groups is sexually explicit. For the same reasons, the researchers left in some other kinds of disturbing images.

2023年12月，微软一位惊慌失措的人工智能工程师Shane Jones发现了这些决定的后续后果。当他摆弄Copilot Designer（微软基于DALL-E 3构建的图像生成器）时，他被它几乎无需提示就能快速输出冒犯性和色情图片的速度所震惊。Jones发现，只需在提示中添加“支持选择权”一词，就会出现恶魔吞噬婴儿的场景，以及一个标有“支持选择权”的钻头被用来残害婴儿的场景。CNBC随后通过自己的测试发现，只需在提示中添加“车祸”一词，就会生成暴力车祸旁的性感女性图片，其中包括一名身着内衣的女性跪在一辆报废车辆旁。

In December 2023, an alarmed AI engineer at Microsoft, Shane Jones, would discover the downstream consequences of those decisions. As he played around with Copilot Designer, Microsoft’s image generator built on DALL-E 3, he was horrified by how quickly it spit out offensive and sexualized images with little prompting. Just adding the term “pro-choice” into the prompt, Jones found, produced scenes of a demon eating an infant and what appeared to be a drill labeled “pro choice” being used to mutilate a baby. Just prompting the tool for a “car accident” and nothing else produced sexualized women next to violent car crashes, including one in lingerie kneeling by a totaled vehicle, CNBC subsequently found through its own testing.

三个月来，琼斯一直向微软高管请愿，要求降低该工具的安全性，直到它拥有更好的防护措施，或者至少将其在谷歌和安卓应用商店的评级从“E级”（适合所有人）降至“成熟用户”。在微软拒绝采纳他的建议且OpenAI未做出回应后，他致信联邦贸易委员会。“他们未能实施这些改变，并继续向‘任何人、任何地方、任何设备’推销该产品，”他在信中写道。“微软和OpenAI在去年10月公开发布该AI模型之前就已经知道这个问题。”微软没有对琼斯信函的最新进展或结果发表评论。

For three months, Jones petitioned Microsoft executives to take down the tool until it had better guardrails, or at the very least restrict its rating in the Google and Android app store from “E for Everyone” to one for mature audiences. After Microsoft declined to adopt his recommendation and OpenAI was unresponsive, he sent a letter to the Federal Trade Commission. “They have failed to implement these changes and continue to market the product to ‘Anyone. Anywhere. Any Device,’ ” he wrote to the FTC. This problem “has been known by Microsoft and OpenAI prior to the public release of the AI model last October.” Microsoft did not comment on the latest status or outcome of Jones’s letter.

—

—

随着 DALL-E 2 的发布越来越近，OpenAI 的 Applied 部门和刚刚恢复库存的安全家族之间的争斗又重新开始了。

As the launch of DALL-E 2 drew closer, the fighting between OpenAI’s Applied division and the newly restocked Safety clan returned.

对于如今分散在研究部门各个团队的安全部门而言，DALL-E 2 前所未有的真实性带来了一系列未知数。它如何被武器化，用于制作合成的 CSAM 或政治深度伪造？如何操纵和说服人们？如何以其他超出 OpenAI 预见和想象的方式虐待和伤害个人，或对整个社会造成有害影响？他们敦促公司，在没有进一步严格测试并证明其不会造成危害的情况下，不要发布该模型。

For those on Safety, now dispersed across various teams under the Research division, the unprecedented realism of DALL-E 2 brought with it a wide array of unknowns. How could it be weaponized to produce synthetic CSAM or political deepfakes? To manipulate and persuade people? To abuse and harm individuals or create whole-of-society detrimental impacts in other ways that were beyond OpenAI’s foresight and imagination? They urged the company not to release the model without further rigorous testing and evidence that it wouldn’t produce harm.

对于Applied公司的员工来说，这份不断增加的担忧清单再次显得歇斯底里，而发布的门槛也完全不切实际。没有任何系统能够做到零伤害，更不用说一个停留在实验室环境中、从未与真实用户接触的系统了。正如Safety部门担心OpenAI的预见性有限一样，Applied公司认为这正是它需要发布DALL-E 2的原因。以受控的方式发布AI模型以获取现实世界的反馈，可以消除这种猜测，因此是提高其安全性的必要组成部分。

For those on Applied, the ever-expanding list of concerns once again seemed hysterical and the bar for release completely unrealistic. No system could ever result in zero harm, and certainly not one that stayed in a lab environment and never made contact with real users. Just as Safety worried about the limitations of OpenAI’s foresight, Applied believed this was precisely why it needed to release DALL-E 2. Releasing AI models in controlled ways to gain real-world feedback would take away that guesswork and was thus a necessary part of improving their safety.

冲突的核心在于对 OpenAI 究竟是什么的分歧日益加剧。对 Safety 派来说，OpenAI 仍然是一个理想主义的非营利性研究实验室，其首要义务是，正如其章程所述，将人类福祉置于任何商业利益之上。在此前提下，其收益远远超过了为了充分考虑各种弊端而长期搁置模型的成本。并研究如何缓解这些风险。对于Applied来说，OpenAI需要做出更务实的决策，立足于世界运作的现实。公司使命的关键在于保持人工智能研究领域的领先地位，并围绕该技术的发展建立规范。这意味着要承受一定程度的风险以快速发展，尤其是在谷歌即将完成其自主图像生成器的传闻传出的情况下，同时还要确保获得继续进行尖端研究所需的额外资金。后者需要从投资者那里筹集资金，这需要真诚地推进一项商业战略，以便有朝一日为投资者带来回报。

Central to the clash was an intensifying disagreement over what exactly OpenAI was. To the Safety clan, OpenAI was still an idealistic nonprofit-governed research lab with a paramount obligation to, as stated in its charter, place the benefit of humanity over any commercial interests. Under this premise, the benefits far outweighed the costs of withholding models as long as necessary to think through as many downsides as possible and research ways to mitigate them. To Applied, OpenAI needed to make more practical decisions, grounded in the realities of how the world worked. Essential to the company’s mission was remaining a leader in AI research to establish norms around the technology’s development. That meant tolerating a degree of risk to move quickly, especially with rumblings of Google finalizing its own image generator, as well as securing the extraordinary capital needed to continue doing cutting-edge research. The latter required raising money from investors, which required working in good faith to advance a commercial strategy that would one day provide those investors returns.

应用材料公司的一名前雇员表示，安全部门的员工对于公司和世界的运作方式“完全天真”。

The people in Safety were “completely naive” about the way companies, and the world, work, says a former employee in Applied.

“好吧，OpenAI 提出的 AGI 任务风险很高，”《安全》杂志的另一位用户说道。“‘普通公司’可能不够好。”

“Well, the stakes of OpenAI’s proposed AGI mission are high,” says another in Safety. “ ‘Normal company’ maybe isn’t good enough.”

不同的团队将这种日益加剧的冲突编纂成绩效评估指标。在应用部门，产品团队和新兴的市场推广团队正在制定用户增长和收入目标。在研究部门，各个人工智能安全团队努力寻找可量化的方法来衡量他们的进步，但本质上很难具体说明。人工智能安全仍然是一个相对年轻的学科。没有明显且既定的基准。在会议和Slack上，安全部门的人们反复向高层领导表达了对这种不平衡如何导致激励机制错位的担忧：明确的增长和收入目标，却没有某种强有力的、可比的平衡措施，这正迫使OpenAI的运营越来越像一个“快速行动，打破常规”的公司。

Different teams were codifying this growing conflict into the metrics they used to evaluate their performance. Within the Applied division, the product team and a budding go-to-market operation were developing user growth and revenue targets. Within the Research division, the various AI safety teams struggled to find quantifiable ways of measuring their advancement when it was difficult to specify by nature. AI safety was still a comparatively young discipline. There were no obvious and established benchmarks. In meetings and on Slack, people in Safety repeatedly raised concerns to senior leadership about how this imbalance was causing misaligned incentives: Having clear-cut growth and revenue goals without some kind of strong, comparable counterbalance was pushing OpenAI to operate more and more like a “move fast and break things” operation.

在与安全部门的私下交谈中，Altman 对他们的观点表示同情，并同意该公司在人工智能安全研究方面进展不顺，需要加大投入。在与应用材料公司的私下交谈中，他敦促他们继续前进。在董事会会议上，Brockman 对人们利用人工智能安全作为政治筹码，为自身目的而阻碍进展的做法表示不满，Altman 对此表示赞同。

In private conversations with Safety, Altman expressed sympathy for their perspective, agreeing that the company was not on track with its AI safety research and needed to invest in it more. In private conversations with Applied, he pressed them to keep going. During board meetings, he nodded along as Brockman voiced frustrations about the ways that people were using AI safety as political leverage to stall progress for their own purposes.

米拉·穆拉蒂越来越多地扮演着谈判者的角色，化解不同派系之间的裂痕，并寻找在他们之间穿针引线的方法。在 DALL-E 2 上，她达成了妥协：该网络应用将不以产品形式发布，而是以“低调的研究预览”的形式发布。这样的品牌推广将使 OpenAI 有更多空间对模型施加更严格的限制，以满足 Safety 的要求，同时仍让该公司有机会尝试直接面向消费者的关系并收集用户反馈，取悦 Applied 。这也是一项务实的举措。OpenAI 尚未建立用于审核生成图像内容的基础设施。将该模型称为“研究预览”并且不收取费用，将使该公司能够使用直截了当、过于宽泛的拦截器，而不必担心惹恼付费用户，从而为开发更复杂的过滤器赢得时间。该公司继续实施一系列积极的防滥用机制，包括禁用 DALL-E 2 生成任何逼真面孔或编辑任何带有面孔的真实照片的能力，以彻底规避合成 CSAM 和政治错误信息问题。

More and more, Mira Murati played the role of negotiator, smoothing out the fault lines between different factions and searching for ways to thread the needle between them. On DALL-E 2, she struck a compromise: The web app would be released not as a product but as a “low-key research preview.” Such branding would give OpenAI more leeway to place harsher restrictions on the model, satisfying Safety, while still giving the company a chance to trial a direct-to-consumer relationship and gather user feedback, pleasing Applied. It was also a practical measure. OpenAI didn’t yet have the infrastructure in place for content moderating generated images. Calling the model a “research preview” and not charging for it would allow the company to use blunt, overly broad blockers without fear of upsetting paid users, to buy time for developing more sophisticated filters. The company moved forward with implementing a series of aggressive abuse-prevention mechanisms, including disabling DALL-E 2’s ability to generate any photorealistic faces or edit any real photos with faces to completely circumvent the synthetic CSAM and political misinformation problem.

2022年3月，OpenAI通过实验室的网页应用发布了DALL-E 2，引发了公众的热烈讨论。人们对该模型的功能赞不绝口，甚至超出了许多员工的预期。这款网页应用在社交媒体上迅速走红，催生出了大量狂野、古怪、超现实的AI艺术作品。这堪称GPT-3时代的巅峰之作，但更胜一筹。OpenAI不再仅仅局限于少数技术开发者，而是触达了更广泛、更全球化的消费者群体。此外，它还能实时响应用户反馈，对实验室的网页应用进行即时修改。这真是令人陶醉，”弗雷泽·凯尔顿在播客中回忆起这次经历。

In March 2022, OpenAI released DALL-E 2 via the Labs web app to overwhelming public enthusiasm. As people gushed over and grappled with the model’s capabilities, to a degree that exceeded many employees’ expectations, the web app went viral across social media, producing a plethora of wild, wacky, and surreal AI-generated art in its wake. It was a GPT-3 moment but better. Instead of engaging with only a small pool of technical developers, the company was tapping into a much broader and more global base of consumers. In real time, it could also respond to user feedback with instantaneous changes to the Labs web app. “This is intoxicating,” Fraser Kelton would remember of the experience in a podcast.

在接下来的几个月里，Applied 部门此前从未考虑过如何将 DALL-E 2 盈利，而是争分夺秒地将这款网页应用转变为付费产品。他们与世界各地的艺术家和创意专业人士合作，将 DALL-E 2 融入到他们的实践中。他们推出了一个测试版计划，邀请全球一百万人免费使用该模型，用于图像生成。然而，随着OpenAI 开始发力，主要的挑战者并不是谷歌，尽管这家科技巨头确实迅速跟进，推出了 Imagen 模型。相反，竞争对手是两家初创公司的模型，Midjourney 和 Stability AI 的 Stable Diffusion。这两款图像生成器均可免费使用，并且与 DALL-E 2 一样好，甚至更好，但安全措施较少，包括允许用户生成和编辑人脸，甚至是政客的人脸。随着 DALL-E 2 在市场上迅速失去吸引力，这段经历让 Applied 一直耿耿于怀，认为它失去了一个重要的商业机会，原因之一是该应用程序限制太多。团队已经在解除其僵硬的障碍，并用更有针对性的护栏取而代之。在超越竞争对手的渴望的驱使下，高管们现在正敦促团队尽快解除这些障碍。

Over the next few months, the Applied division, which hadn’t yet thought much at all about how to monetize DALL-E 2, raced to turn the web app into a paid offering. It worked with artists and creative professionals around the world to incorporate DALL-E 2 into their practice. It rolled out a beta program, inviting one million people around the world to get access to the model with free credits for image generations. But as OpenAI started charging, it wasn’t Google that proved to be the main challenger, though the tech giant did indeed follow quickly with its Imagen model. Instead, it was two models from startups, Midjourney and Stability AI’s Stable Diffusion. Both image generators were free to use and just as good, if not better, than DALL-E 2 and had fewer safety measures, including allowing users to generate and edit faces, even of politicians. As DALL-E 2 rapidly lost traction in the market, the experience left Applied with a nagging sense that it had lost out on a major commercial opportunity due to, among other things, the app being too restrictive. The team had already been in the process of unwinding its blunt blockers and replacing them with more targeted guardrails. Fueled by a desire to outrace competitors, executives were now pushing the team to unwind them as fast as possible.

为了解除人脸禁令，OpenAI 开发了一种新的流程，用于预防和打击生成有害人物图像（包括儿童性虐待）。它使用自动化系统检测人脸生成是否符合规范或具有辱骂性，并再次依靠海外承包商协助内容审核。这一次，这些承包商通过一家名为 Cogito 的供应商驻扎在印度，他们不仅审查大量文本，还审查发送给 Sama 员工的各种性和暴力内容的图像（包括合成图像和真实图像）。由于每天要筛选数百张图片，承包商们很难区分涉及 17 岁未成年人和 18 岁法定成年人的性内容。他们也无法总是判断这些图像是真是假。

To lift the ban on faces, OpenAI developed a new process for preventing and cracking down on the generation of harmful images of people, including CSAM. It used automated systems to detect when faces were being generated in acceptable or abusive contexts and once again relied on overseas contractors to help with the content moderation. This time those contractors were based in India through a vendor called Cogito and reviewed not just reams of text but images—synthetic and real—of the kinds of sexual and violent content that had been sent to Sama workers. As they sifted through what could be hundreds of images a day, the contractors struggled to distinguish between sexual content involving seventeen-year-old minors versus eighteen-year-old legal adults. They also couldn’t always tell whether the images were fake or real.

—

—

OpenAI 在其 2021 年研究路线图中原本最容易实现的目标，最终却成了最难实现的目标之一：利用微软新推出的 1.8 万台 Nvidia A100 超级计算机集群，将 GPT-3 规模扩大 10 倍，以开发后来的 GPT-4。GPT-3 扩展团队的三分之一成员在“离婚”后离开了，带走了他们宝贵的技术和机构知识。更关键的是，OpenAI 的数据已经耗尽。

What had, on the face of it, been OpenAI’s easiest goal in its 2021 research road map turned out to be one of the hardest: scaling up GPT-3 by 10x with Microsoft’s new eighteen thousand Nvidia A100 supercomputer cluster, in its effort to develop what would become GPT-4. One-third of the GPT-3 scaling team had left with The Divorce, taking with them significant technical and institutional knowledge. More existentially, OpenAI had run out of data.

GPT-3 之后，研究人员试图尽可能多地积累数据，通过下载所有新的数据转储，以及抓取他们偶然发现的所有没有明确警告的在线论坛，来扩充公司的数据储备库。然而，即使增加了 GitHub 庞大的 Codex 存储库以及编码教科书和手册，这仍然远远不够。

After GPT-3, researchers had sought to accumulate as much data as possible, building up the company’s reservoir by downloading every new data dump and scraping every new online forum they stumbled upon that didn’t have clear warnings against doing so. And yet, even with the additions of GitHub’s large repository for Codex, and the coding textbooks and manuals, it was still not enough.

眼前的挑战十分艰巨，这种情况完全符合格雷格·布罗克曼项目的特点。这不仅能体现他积极进取的作风和编程天赋，还能让他为了公司其他人的利益，集中精力去做一些有意义的事情。

With an uphill battle ahead, the situation had all the characteristics of a Greg Brockman project. Not only would it channel his scrappy can-do attitude and his coding brilliance, but it would also focus his energy, for the sake of the rest of the company, on something productive.

奥特曼接任后，布罗克曼卸任了管理职务。布罗克曼最终回归了个人贡献者的身份，无需汇报。然而，作为 OpenAI 名义上的总裁和联合创始人之一，他对员工和公司的战略方向保持着不可思议的影响力。随着 OpenAI 走向专业化，并实施了更加标准化的企业流程，告别了早期创业公司那种随心所欲的模式，布罗克曼那种低责任、高权威的模式反而成了累赘。

After Altman took over, relieving Brockman of his managerial responsibilities, Brockman had eventually gone back to being an individual contributor with no reports. Yet as the nominal president and one of OpenAI’s cofounders, he maintained incredible influence over employees and the strategic direction of the company. As OpenAI professionalized and implemented more standard corporate processes, moving away from the freewheeling days of an early-stage startup, Brockman’s mix of low responsibility and high authority turned into a liability.

就像他在大学和 Stripe 工作的日子一样，他不喜欢制度和流程。他精力充沛，精力充沛，焦躁不安。他很少参加会议，自己安排时间，常常喜欢连续写几十个小时的代码，几乎没有吃饭和睡觉的时间。如果项目合适，效果会非常显著：他强大的生产力会加速项目进度。但如果闲着没事干，他往往会造成一系列破坏，突然出现在各个项目中，用最后一刻的改变来干扰和破坏长期计划。有时，当员工们表示反对时，他会向上级领导层发出感人的恳求，以达到他想要的效果。

Just like his college and Stripe days, he was not one for institutions and process. He had a restless and obsessive energy. He rarely attended meetings, and set his own schedule, often preferring to code for dozens of hours straight with few breaks for meals and sleep. With the right project, the effects were miraculous: His intense productivity would supercharge progress. But left idle, he tended to create a trail of destruction, popping up in projects all over the place to meddle with and derail long-standing plans with last-minute changes. At times, when employees put up resistance, he would deliver emotional pleas higher and higher up their leadership chain to get what he wanted.

布罗克曼通常都能如愿以偿。令其他高管感到沮丧和困惑的是，奥特曼对他的行为却出奇地纵容。不仅如此，布罗克曼还能左右奥特曼，让他插手并破坏他的计划，似乎只是为了满足布罗克曼。一个普遍的猜测是：尽管奥特曼是布罗克曼的老板作为首席执行官，布罗克曼对作为董事会成员的奥特曼也拥有权威。这是一个奇怪的、错综复杂的结构，最终导致没有人、也没有人能够追究布罗克曼的责任。

Brockman usually did get what he wanted. Much to the frustration and confusion of other executives, Altman was strangely permissive of his behavior. Not only that, Brockman could also influence Altman into meddling and derailing things for him, if only, it seemed, to satisfy Brockman. One popular guess as to why: Though Altman was Brockman’s boss as the CEO, Brockman also had authority over Altman as a board member. It was a strange tangle of a structure that ultimately left nothing and no one to hold Brockman accountable.

高层领导曾多次调整布罗克曼的职责、职责范围和汇报方式，试图为他找到最佳位置。如同其他许多事情一样，责任最终落到了穆拉蒂的头上，她成为了布罗克曼的经理。当她试图给予反馈时，布罗克曼似乎乐于接受，但当他不同意时，他会向奥特曼抱怨。穆拉蒂逐渐放弃了通过反馈来改变现状的尝试，而是投入大量时间，为布罗克曼寻找能够带来净收益而非混乱的项目，并与麦格鲁一起弥合了布罗克曼在公司各个部门造成的裂痕。

The senior leadership had changed his role, scope, and reporting lines several times in an attempt to find the best place for him. As with so much else, the buck eventually passed to Murati, who became Brockman’s manager. When she sought to give him feedback, he seemed receptive, but on points where he disagreed, he complained to Altman. Murati slowly gave up on attempting to change things with feedback, instead spending significant time trying to find projects for Brockman where he could be net beneficial rather than chaotic, and, with McGrew, healing the ruptures Brockman caused in various parts of the company.

GPT-4 的开发过程中需要克服许多障碍，但一切进展顺利。

With roadblocks that needed to be punched through in the way of GPT-4’s development, the stars aligned.

—

—

为了解决 OpenAI 的数据瓶颈，布罗克曼转向了一个新的来源：YouTube。OpenAI 此前一直避免使用这种做法——YouTube 首席执行官后来证实，爬取 YouTube 数据来训练 OpenAI 的模型违反了该平台的服务条款。但在新的数据获取压力下，问题变成了 YouTube 或其母公司谷歌是否会强制执行。如果谷歌采取严厉措施，可能会危及自身爬取其他网站数据用于其大型语言模型开发的能力。布罗克曼愿意冒这个险。

To solve OpenAI’s data bottleneck, Brockman turned to a new source: YouTube. OpenAI had previously avoided this option—scraping YouTube to train OpenAI’s models, YouTube’s CEO would later confirm, violated the platform’s terms of service. But under the new existential pressure for more data, the question became whether YouTube, or its parent, Google, would enforce it. If Google cracked down, it could jeopardize its own ability to scrape other websites for its large language model development. Brockman was willing to take the risk.

据《纽约时报》报道，布罗克曼与一个小团队开始收集 YouTube 视频，最终收集了超过一百万小时的视频。然后，他使用拉德福德开发的语音识别工具 Whisper 将视频转录为 GPT-4 的文本。

With a small team, Brockman began collecting YouTube videos, eventually compiling more than one million hours of footage, according to The New York Times. He then used a speech-recognition tool called Whisper, which Radford had developed, to transcribe the videos into text for GPT-4.

接下来是训练。为了训练 GPT-3，Nest 团队设计了一个定制的软件平台。由于该平台的大部分开发者都去了 Anthropic，他们已经无法再解释它的工作原理了。出于自尊心，一些领导层也不想依赖 Anthropic 团队的成果。Brockman 则躲进了自己的编程坑，开发了一个新平台。然后，他和几位其他科学家，包括雅库布·帕乔茨基 (Jakub Pachocki) 和西蒙·西多尔 (Szymon Sidor)，在Dota 2项目，Brockman 负责 GPT-4 的训练。仅预训练就花了三个月的时间。

Next was the training. To train GPT-3, the Nest team had designed a bespoke software platform. With most of its creators now gone to Anthropic, they were no longer around to explain how it worked. As a point of pride, some leadership didn’t want to rely on the Anthropic team’s legacy either. Brockman disappeared into his coding hole and developed a new platform. Then, with several others, including Jakub Pachocki and Szymon Sidor, the Polish scientists whom he’d grown close with during the Dota 2 project, Brockman babysat GPT-4’s training. The pre-training alone took three months.

起初，GPT-4 似乎令人失望。“这是一个疯狂的模型，从某种意义上来说，它的表现相当糟糕，”一位研究人员说道。“由于平均数据质量太差，而且模型功能强大且对上下文敏感，它产生的响应很垃圾。” 但布罗克曼继续推进，整合资源，与人工承包商合作改进模型，并根据人工反馈进行强化学习。随着时间一周一周地推进，结果越来越好，直到其性能真正开始让内部人员惊叹。

At first, GPT-4 seemed like a disappointment. “It was a wild model, which in some sense behaved quite poorly,” one researcher says. “Because the average data quality was so horrible, and because the model was quite powerful and context sensitive, it was producing garbage responses.” But Brockman pushed forward, pulling together the resources to improve the model with human contractors conducting reinforcement learning from human feedback. With each week, the results looked better and better, until the performance truly began to wow people internally.

GPT-4 现在内置了多模态功能，并且根据 OpenAI 的内部评估，它生成的代码比以往任何时候都更加精良，并且在识别用户意图和提供有用答案方面也更加灵活。为了展示这些能力，Brockman 后来直播了一段演示，演示他用一张在笔记本上画的网页草图来提示 GPT-4。Brockman 在顶部写道：“我的笑话网站”。在它下面，他补充道：“[真搞笑的笑话！]”和“[按下显示妙语]”。不到半分钟，模型就把草图变成了可行的代码，将第一行设计成标题，将第二行替换为笑话，并将第三行识别为按钮。

GPT-4 now had built-in multimodal capabilities and, against OpenAI’s internal assessments, was generating more polished code than ever and was more nimble in recognizing user intent and delivering helpful answers. In an impressive showcase of those abilities, Brockman would later live stream a demo of him prompting GPT-4 with a photo of a simple chicken scratch sketch of a web page drawn in his notebook. “My Joke Website,” Brockman had written at the top. Stacked below it, he’d added: “[really funny joke!]” and “[push to reveal punchline].” In less than half a minute, the model would turn that sketch into workable code, stylizing the first line as a title, replacing the second line with a joke, and recognizing the third line as a button.

然而，当 OpenAI 开始在投资者和特定客户等值得信赖的圈子里展示该模型时，至少有一个人对此并不感冒。这个人又是一向难以取悦的比尔·盖茨。

But as OpenAI began teasing the model in trusted circles, including investors and select customers, at least one person wasn’t the least bit impressed. It was once again the ever-hard-to-please Bill Gates.

—

—

2022 年 6 月，在观看了 GPT-4 的演示后，盖茨对 GPT-2 的进展不足表示失望。尽管模型明显更大、更流畅，但他仍然觉得“一个白痴学者”，无法解决复杂的科学问题。他告诉团队，只有当 GPT-4 在 AP 生物学考试中取得 5 分后，他才会开始关注——他选择了AP Bio，因为他觉得这门课程考察的是批判性科学思维，而不是死记硬背。“我想，‘好吧，这样我就有三年时间研究艾滋病和疟疾了，’”盖茨后来在播客中回忆道。

In June 2022, after getting a demo of GPT-4, Gates expressed disappointment in the insufficient progress from GPT-2. Despite the model being significantly larger and more fluent, he still felt like it was “an idiot savant,” unable to tackle complex scientific problems. He told the team that he would only start paying attention once GPT-4 scored a 5 on an AP Biology test—AP Bio because he felt it tested critical scientific thinking rather than a memorization of facts. “I thought, ‘Okay, that’ll give me three years to work on HIV and malaria,’ ” Gates later recounted in his podcast.

布罗克曼把盖茨的话当成了挑战。他立即布罗克曼联系了在线教育平台可汗学院（Khan Academy）的首席执行官萨尔·可汗（Sal Khan），并请他利用公司庞大的AP Bio题库作为训练数据。可汗起初持怀疑态度，但最终同意，条件是他的平台可以访问该模型。布罗克曼还组建了一个团队，为新的Gates Demo打造了一个特殊的用户界面。

Brockman took Gates’s remark as a challenge. He immediately reached out to Sal Khan, the CEO of online education platform Khan Academy, and asked him to tap into the company’s large repository of AP Bio questions as training data. Khan was skeptical but agreed to do so in exchange for his platform getting access to the model. Brockman also amassed a team of employees to build a special user interface for the new Gates Demo.

到了八月底，令盖茨大吃一惊的是，奥特曼和布罗克曼又开始联系他了。次月，在盖茨家中，大约三十人共进晚餐，两位 OpenAI 高管和其他人向盖茨展示了一系列高度精炼的 GPT-4 演示，旨在给他留下深刻印象。最精彩的时刻是该模型在 AP Bio 考试中取得了优异的成绩：它在 60 道选择题中答对了 59 道，并对 6 道开放式问题给出了令人印象深刻的答案。一位外部专家会给测试打分：满分 5 分。盖茨简直不敢相信。他的震惊和赞扬，以及演示参与者会立即传达给公司其他人的感受，像野火一样席卷了整个办公室，激发了令人振奋的活力：盖茨表示，这次演示是他一生中见过的最令人惊叹的两次演示之一。

By late August, much to Gates’s surprise, Altman and Brockman were pinging him again. Over dinner at the Microsoft founder’s house the following month with roughly thirty people, the two OpenAI executives and others showed Gates a series of highly refined GPT-4 demos designed to impress him. The crowning moment was the model acing AP Bio: It nailed fifty-nine out of sixty multiple-choice questions and generated impressive answers to six open-ended ones. An outside expert would score the test: 5 out of 5. Gates couldn’t believe it. His shock and praise, which the demo attendees would instantly relay back to the rest of the company, ripped like wildfire through the office and incited an exhilarating level of energy: This showcase, Gates said, was one of the two most stunning demos he’d ever seen in his life.

在全体会议上，Altman 继续激发大家的热情。“创造非凡成就的初创公司需要奇迹，”他说。“我们刚刚创造了奇迹。”许多员工都对此深信不疑，并为自己所取得的成就感到敬畏。GPT-4 的全新性能水平让 OpenAI 领导层确信，是时候开始着手实现 Altman 长期以来的梦想之一了：打造一个外观和感觉都与 2013 年 Spike Jonze 电影《她》中的角色 Samantha 相似的 AI 助手。

In all-hands meetings, Altman continued to stoke the excitement. “Startups that do remarkable things require a miracle,” he said. “We just had our miracle.” Many employees believed it, awestruck by the momentousness of what they had accomplished. GPT-4’s new level of performance convinced OpenAI leadership that it was time to start working toward one of Altman’s long-coveted ambitions: an AI assistant that would look and feel like the character Samantha in the 2013 Spike Jonze movie Her.

多年来，《她》一直是 Altman 和其他 OpenAI 联合创始人经常引用的试金石，用来预测通用人工智能（AGI）的未来发展：一个单一的多模态模型，其产品界面感觉如此自然，以至于它逐渐消失，只为用户带来愉悦。一位前员工在解释为什么这部电影如此重要时表示：“我认为这是因为它是一位完美融入生活的助手。在故事发展到崩溃之前，它所展现的积极弧线，是人工智能向社会进化的一个真正精彩的故事。”

For years, Her had been a touchstone that Altman and other OpenAI cofounders frequently invoked as an example of what AGI might one day look like: a single multimodal model whose product interface felt so utterly natural that it faded away and simply brought user delight. “I would think it’s because it was an assistant that was wonderfully integrated into a life,” says a former employee, of why the movie was such a pivotal reference. “The positive arc of that story before it unravels is a really great story of AI’s evolution into society.”

John Schulman 的研究团队开始重新应用他的 InstructGPT-启发了 RLHF 在 GPT-3.5 到 GPT-4 上开展聊天机器人工作，作为领导层命名为 Superassistant 产品的核心软件。布罗克曼和弗雷泽·凯尔顿从公司各处召集了一支不到十人的杂牌团队，集思广益，为超级助手的界面设计出各种不同的原型。超级计算团队中，一位平时负责基础设施建设的同事，开始利用晚上和周末的时间，开发一款用于与模型聊天的 iOS 应用。另一位同事建议使用 Whisper 为应用添加语音界面，这样人们无需打字即可与其对话。推理团队的另一位同事建议开发一款 Chrome 扩展程序，帮助用户在浏览网页时使用超级助手总结网页内容。第四位同事开始为超级助手构建一个会议机器人，让它加入用户的视频通话，并向用户发送会议摘要。

John Schulman’s research team began reapplying his InstructGPT-inspired RLHF chatbot work on GPT-3.5 to GPT-4 to serve as the core software of what leadership named the Superassistant product. Brockman and Fraser Kelton pulled together a ragtag team of fewer than ten people from around the company to brainstorm and prototype different ideas for its interface. One person from the supercomputing team who was usually an infrastructure guy began hacking away during his evenings and weekends on an iOS app for chatting with the model. Another one suggested using Whisper to add a voice interface to the app so people could speak to it without typing. A third person from the inferencing team proposed creating a Chrome extension that would help users summarize web pages with the Superassistant as they browsed the internet. A fourth person began building a meeting bot for the Superassistant to join a user’s video calls and send them a summary of what happened.

随着势头的增强，人们对各种可能性的兴奋感也与日俱增。那年夏天，包括巴雷特·佐夫、卢克·梅茨和利亚姆·费杜斯在内的一群人工智能研究人员离开谷歌，创办了自己的数字助理初创公司。奥特曼说服他们加入OpenAI，共同实现他们的想法。他们加入了舒尔曼的团队，与超级助理团队并肩坐在办公室里，共同推动研究，加速开发。在一种高度激动人心的状态下，应用部门和研究部门的人们比以往任何时候都更加紧密地合作，共同推出一款新产品。

As momentum picked up, excitement mounted at the possibilities. That summer, when a group of AI researchers, including Barret Zoph, Luke Metz, and Liam Fedus, left Google to found their own digital assistant startup, Altman had persuaded them to work on their idea at OpenAI instead. They joined Schulman’s team, sitting side by side in the office with the Superassistant team, to drive its research and accelerate its development. In a heightened and thrilling state of flow, people from the Applied and Research divisions were working more tightly together than ever before to launch a new product.

当 OpenAI 向微软演示 GPT-4 时，萨蒂亚·纳德拉、凯文·斯科特以及这家科技巨头的其他高管也同样兴奋不已。Codex 已经证明了 OpenAI 的技术具有商业吸引力，但 GPT-4 代表着更宏大的目标。它全面超越了微软内部开发的各种 AI 模型；它还能做更多的事情，包括以高度的语境和清晰度回答问题。它为所有微软产品创建新的对话界面（Copilot）开辟了一系列可能性，例如允许用户与公司陷入困境的搜索引擎必应聊天，或者用自然语言指示微软的 Office 套件将 Word 文档转换为 PowerPoint 演示文稿。微软还可以直接向其云客户提供定制的 Copilot。它将无疑将使这家科技巨头成为人工智能领导者，最终能够与谷歌展开竞争。

As OpenAI demoed GPT-4 to Microsoft, Satya Nadella, Kevin Scott, and the tech giant’s other executives were just as excited. Codex had proven that OpenAI’s technologies could have commercial appeal, but GPT-4 represented something far bigger. Across the board, it beat the performance of various AI models that Microsoft had developed in-house; it could also do much more, including answering questions with a high degree of context and clarity. It opened up a range of possibilities to create new conversational interfaces, or Copilots, for all of Microsoft’s products, such as to allow users to chat with the company’s struggling search engine Bing or to tell Microsoft’s Office suite in natural language to turn a Word document into a PowerPoint presentation. Microsoft would also be able to offer custom Copilots directly to its cloud customers. It would undoubtedly turn the tech giant into an AI leader, finally able to go toe to toe with Google.

在接下来的几个月里，纳德拉将解锁微软对 OpenAI 的第三笔投资，并继续独家使用 OpenAI 的模型权重，以便将其集成到其产品中。两家公司将于 2023 年 1 月公布投资金额：100 亿美元。

In the coming months, Nadella would unlock Microsoft’s third investment into OpenAI and continue its exclusive access to OpenAI’s model weights for integrating into its products. The companies would reveal the amount in January 2023: $10 billion.

—

—

OpenAI 的高管们最初计划在 2022 年秋季发布 GPT-4。这个截止日期简直是天方夜谭。夏末将近，公司却远未准备好推出涵盖所有功能的新商业产品。产品团队需要更多时间完善界面；基础设施团队需要分配服务器空间；模型本身也需要更多工作来完善其行为。

At first, OpenAI executives wanted to release GPT-4 in the fall of 2022. The deadline was a case of fantastical thinking. Nearing the end of summer, the company was nowhere near ready to launch a new commercial product across any of its functions. The product team needed more time to polish its interface; the infrastructure team needed to apportion server space; the model itself needed more work to iron out its behavior.

当时，OpenAI 已与微软组建了一个名为部署安全委员会（DSB）的委员会，每家公司各有三名代表，负责评估 OpenAI 的尖端模型并确定它们是否已准备好发布。OpenAI 的代表包括 Altman、政策研究主管 Miles Brundage 和协调主管 Jan Leike，后者负责监督 RLHF 等 AI 安全技术的持续发展。政策研究和协调都已成为安全阵营的新兴堡垒。DSB 创建了一个正式的治理结构，以解决应用和安全之间由来已久的争论。经过初步审查，DSB 有条件地批准了 GPT-4，这是在该结构下评估的第一个模型：该模型在经过大量测试并进一步调整以确保 AI 安全后，即可发布。

OpenAI had at that point formed a committee with Microsoft, called the Deployment Safety Board, or DSB, with three representatives from each company, to evaluate OpenAI’s cutting-edge models and determine whether they were ready for release. OpenAI’s representatives were Altman, Miles Brundage, the head of policy research, and Jan Leike, the head of alignment, which oversaw the continued development of AI safety techniques like RLHF. Both policy research and alignment had become the new emerging strongholds of the Safety clan. DSB created a formal governance structure for resolving the age-old debates between Applied and Safety. After a preliminary review, the DSB gave GPT-4, the first model being evaluated under this structure, a conditional approval: The model could be released once it had been significantly tested and tuned further for AI safety.

高管们商定了新的截止日期，即2023年初。届时，他们希望超级助手也能做好准备。OpenAI将与基于GPT-4的面向消费者的产品同时在API中发布GPT-4。Altman对员工们表示，推迟发布模型的决定体现了OpenAI谨慎且注重安全的作风。他表示，公司在部署该系统方面进展缓慢。事实上，领导层甚至不确定是否会部署该系统。在应用材料公司，大多数人认为Altman的意思是，这需要非凡的努力。领导层曾提出停止发布的问题，但如果出现这种情况，他们愿意这么做。对安全部门的许多人来说，奥特曼的话听起来截然不同：当时的设想是，只有 GPT-4 通过所有检查后，领导层才会批准发布。

Executives agreed on a new deadline in early 2023. By that time, they wanted the Superassistant to also be ready. OpenAI would release GPT-4 in the API side by side with the GPT-4-powered, consumer-facing product. To employees, Altman framed the decision to delay the release of the model as evidence of OpenAI’s cautious and safety-minded approach. The company was taking its time with deploying the system, he said. In fact, leadership wasn’t even sure they would deploy it. In Applied, most people interpreted Altman to mean that it would take an extraordinary issue for leadership to stop the release but that, should such a situation arise, they would be willing to do it. To many people within Safety, Altman’s words landed differently: The assumption was that only once GPT-4 passed every check would leadership greenlight its release.

在私下会面中，Altman 强化了双方的看法。他向双方都表达了对 GPT-4 可能“唤醒谷歌”的担忧，并设想这样一种场景：当 GPT-4 模型问世并引起 Larry Page 和 Sergey Brin 的注意时，两人最终将打破谷歌的政治官僚体系。谷歌高管可以取消所有会议，进行为期一天的休假，整合公司所有人才和资源，并充分利用其强大的计算能力来迎头赶上。但对于应用材料公司来说，这恰恰是其保持高强度准备发布的理由，同时尽可能长时间地保密 GPT-4 的功能；而对于安全部门，Altman 则以此继续强调他的谨慎态度。“我最关心的安全问题是加速风险，”他借用了他们的用语说道。换句话说：唤醒谷歌可能会引发竞相压价的势头。

In private meetings, Altman reinforced the perceptions on each side. To both, he raised concerns that GPT-4 could “wake up Google,” evoking a scenario in which the day the model dropped and seized Larry Page and Sergey Brin’s attention, the two would finally cut through Google’s political bureaucracy. Google executives could cancel all their meetings, go on a daylong retreat, consolidate all of the company’s talent and resources, and bring its full compute firepower to bear on catching up. But where with Applied, this was reason to sustain its intensity to prepare for launch while keeping GPT-4’s capabilities a secret for as long as possible, with Safety, Altman used it to continue underscoring his caution. “My number one safety concern is acceleration risk,” he said, adopting their vocabulary. Translation: Waking up Google could spark race-to-the-bottom dynamics.

—

—

即使延期，应用部门仍在努力赶在2023年初发布。尤其是戴夫·威尔纳（Dave Willner）的信任与安全团队，人员仍然有限，基础设施也不够完善。如果OpenAI计划推出一款基于更强大模型构建的直接面向消费者的Superassistant产品，那么它需要一个更加成熟的滥用预防和执行机制。

Even with the delay, the Applied division was scrambling to meet the early 2023 release. In particular, Dave Willner’s trust and safety team still had a limited staff and underdeveloped infrastructure. If OpenAI was planning to go live with a direct-to-consumer Superassistant product, built atop a much more powerful model, it needed a far more mature abuse prevention and enforcement operation.

威尔纳迅速从谷歌和 Meta 招聘了几位经验丰富的信任与安全专员。他指派其中一位负责调查“未知的未知”——团队尚未察觉的滥用行为，需要通过仔细的监控和数据分析才能发现。他指派另一位负责“已知的已知”，也就是所谓的“规模化执法”——公司已经认定为违规行为的滥用行为，需要自动标记、审查并采取行动，例如暂停屡犯者的账户。

Willner rushed to hire several experienced trust and safety deputies from Google and Meta. He tasked one with investigating “unknown unknowns”—abuses that the team wasn’t yet aware of and would need to discover through careful monitoring and data analysis. He tasked another with “known knowns,” or so-called scaled enforcement—the abuses that the company had already deemed as violating behavior and would need to automatically flag, review, and take action on, such as by suspending the accounts of repeat offenders.

在他们争分夺秒地制定产品政策和监控及执行基础设施时，这个新兴团队的成员不断感受到人们不确定人工智能公司的信任和安全应该与搜索或社交媒体公司有何不同，以及他们为 GPT-4 所做的准备是否充分。信任和安全通常侧重于防止一系列可预见的互联网滥用，例如欺诈、网络犯罪和干预选举。但令人困惑的是，他们的工作与 Leike 和 Brundage 的政策研究团队中的人工智能安全人员的工作有何关联，后者经常讨论不可知的灾难性厄运。OpenAI 将他们全部称为“安全”团队，但他们似乎说着完全不同的语言。尽管存在主义人工智能安全这一词汇随着 EA 的普及已成为该领域的常用语，但来自传统科技公司背景的员工从未听说过人工智能时间表，也从未量化过他们的 p(doom)。即使是这两个群体之间共享的词汇，例如风险和伤害，似乎也带有不同的内涵。

As they raced to set up product policies and monitoring and enforcement infrastructure, members of the budding team felt a constant sense of uncertainty about how trust and safety for an AI company should differ from a search or social media company and whether their preparations for GPT-4 were adequate. Trust and safety was typically focused on preventing a predictable slate of internet abuses, like fraud, cybercrime, and election interference. But wrapped up in the confusion was how their work related to that of the AI safety people within Leike’s alignment and Brundage’s policy research teams who often discussed unknowable, catastrophic doom. OpenAI labeled all of them as “safety” teams, but they seemed to be speaking fundamentally different languages. Although the vocabulary of existential AI safety had, with its popularization through EA, become common parlance in the field, employees coming from traditional tech company backgrounds had never heard of AI timelines or quantified their p(doom). Even shared words between the two groups like risk and harm seemed laced with different connotations.

随着越来越多的非人工智能人才加入OpenAI，以支持应用部门不断增长的需求，跨越那些深陷末日-婴儿潮思维模式的人与那些在标准科技公司框架下运作的人之间的文化鸿沟，成为了一种特殊的政治资本。在Willner的信任与安全副手们中，最成功学习人工智能安全语言的人成为了通往那个世界的桥梁。这位副手跨团队合作，使模型在两个意义上都“更安全”，例如使用RLHF来“调整”模型——流氓人工智能安全术语——从而使其能够更好地拒绝违反OpenAI平台政策的用户查询，这是信任与安全的典型工作。

With the arrival of more and more non-AI people to OpenAI to support the expanding needs of the Applied division, the ability to cross that cultural divide between those steeped in the Doomer-Boomer mind frame and those operating under a standard tech company framework became a special kind of political currency. Among Willner’s trust and safety deputies, the one most successful in learning the language of AI safety became a bridge to that world. The deputy worked across teams to make the model “safer” in both senses of the word, such as by using RLHF to “align” the model—rogue AI safety lingo—and thereby make it better at refusing user queries that violated OpenAI’s platform policies, the typical work of trust and safety.

但随着两方面的“安全”进展，高管们突然发出了一项新指令：暂停在 GPT-3 API 发布时首次实施的开发人员审查流程。

But as “safety” progressed on both fronts, a new directive suddenly arrived from executives: to suspend the developer-review process that had first been implemented with the GPT-3 API release.

一段时间以来，高管们一直觉得等待名单已经失控，审核流程也难以扩展。开发人员抱怨获取 OpenAI 技术的时间太长，他们不断地给 Altman、Brockman 和 Peter Welinder 发邮件，或在推特上给他们留言，抱怨高管们认为这些应用程序完全无害，却被拖延了很长时间。应用材料公司的许多人也觉得OpenAI 把守着获取其技术优势的渠道，这与其使命背道而驰。

For a while already, executives had felt that the waiting list had grown out of control, and the review process wasn’t scaling. Developers were complaining about how long it was taking to get access to OpenAI’s technologies, and were constantly emailing Altman, Brockman, and Peter Welinder or tagging them on Twitter about long holdups on what the executives saw as totally innocuous applications. Many in Applied also felt OpenAI was gatekeeping access to the benefits of its technology, which was antithetical to its mission.

Willner 和他的团队一直在反击。如果 OpenAI 放弃其申请流程并自动批准开发者，该公司就别无选择，无法真正有效地控制其技术的使用。如果转向被动执行，则需要构建重要的工具来实现这一点。随着 GPT-4 即将发布，高管们驳回了反对意见：OpenAI 正在取消开发者审核；信任与安全团队只需要找到替代方案。

Willner and his team had always pushed back. If OpenAI dropped its application process and automatically approved developers, the company had no real alternative for moderating the use of its technologies. If it switched to reactive enforcement, it would need to build up significant tooling to do so. With the launch of GPT-4 pending, executives overrode the objections: OpenAI was getting rid of developer review; the trust and safety team simply needed to figure out the alternative.

Willner 的团队迅速制定了一项提案。该提案将把公司政策的更多执行转移到上游，通过更多地依赖 RLHF 来协调 GPT-4 和未来的模型。其他所有信息都将被捕获并在下游通过被动执行进行处理：使用不同的数据信号，例如应用程序的行为、流量峰值模式以及触发内容审核过滤器的次数等信息，自动暂停明显的违规者，同时将边缘案例发送给人工审核员进行人工审核。

Willner’s team rushed to put together a proposal. It would shift more of its enforcement of the company’s policies upstream, by leaning more heavily on RLHF to align GPT-4 and future models. Everything else would be caught and handled downstream with reactive enforcement: using different data signals, such as information about what the app did, its traffic spike patterns, and the number of times it triggered the content-moderation filters, to automatically suspend obvious violators while sending borderline cases to human moderators for manual review.

Willner 的团队敦促高管们提供资源，以便妥善构建实现该计划所需的工具。OpenAI 并没有掌握大部分这些数据点；其监控平台仅记录了每个应用程序通过公司服务器发送的流量的基本数据。有时，它甚至不知道开发者的姓名或应用程序的用途。

Willner’s team urged executives for the resources to properly build out the tooling they needed to make the plan work. OpenAI didn’t have most of these data points at its disposal; its monitoring platform was logging only basic data on how much traffic each app was sending through the company’s servers. Sometimes it didn’t even know the name of the developer or the purpose of the application.

除了弥补这些差距之外，团队还需要开发者为每位用户分配一个唯一的标识符。这对于按用户细分应用流量至关重要，这样才能确定违规行为是该应用用户群的普遍现象，还是少数频繁违规者所为。高管们对此表示反对，担心实施这种精细的监控会给开发者体验带来阻力，并可能使公司承担更多责任，为每个使用公司技术的应用履行信任和安全保障工作，而不是让每个应用开发者自行处理。

In addition to plugging those gaps, the team also needed developers to assign a unique identifier to each of their users. This was crucial to be able to disaggregate an app’s traffic by its individual users to determine whether violating behaviors were endemic to an app’s user base or merely being committed by a few frequent abusers. Executives resisted, worried that implementing such granular monitoring would add friction to the developer experience, and potentially make the company more liable for performing trust and safety work for every app using the company’s technologies, rather than having each app developer handle it themselves.

最终，被动执法的提议被缩减为更为有限的范围。

In the end, the proposal for reactive enforcement was scaled down to something much more limited.

由于对应用程序用户行为的可见性受限，信任与安全团队的一些成员感到焦虑。一名员工向布罗克曼表达了他的担忧。这位员工表示，他最担心的是有人利用 GPT-4 大规模制造虚假信息，并影响选举。

The restricted visibility into app-user behavior made some members of the trust and safety team anxious. An employee raised his concerns to Brockman. What he feared most, the employee said, was people using GPT-4 to generate mis- and disinformation at scale and influence elections.

布罗克曼试图安慰他。“是的，我们总是这么说，也一直担心，”他说。“但我从未见过的是，这真的发生了吗？”

Brockman sought to reassure him. “Yes, this is what we always say and we’re always concerned about,” he said. “But what I haven’t ever seen is, is it actually happening?”

—

—

GPT-4 不仅仅是盖茨和微软的转折点。那年夏天晚些时候，在让这位亿万富翁慈善家惊叹不已之后，奥特曼和布罗克曼将它带到了 OpenAI 董事会，布罗克曼在那里现场演示了该模型，其中包括讲关于加里·马库斯的笑话。这些笑话让独立董事会成员感到高兴；轻松的展示也向他们传达了该技术能力的重大进步，并让他们感觉到他们未来决策的风险正在上升。

GPT-4 wasn’t just a turning point for Gates and Microsoft. Later that summer, after wowing the billionaire philanthropist, Altman and Brockman brought it to OpenAI’s board, where Brockman gave a live demo of the model that included it telling jokes about Gary Marcus. The jokes delighted the independent board members; the lighthearted showcase also signaled to them a significant advance in the technology’s capabilities and imparted a sense that the stakes of their future decisions were going up.

在此之前，奥特曼大约每季度召集一次董事会，并倾向于口头汇报最新进展。他能轻松地处理复杂的研究课题，有时会带公司研究人员来汇报他们的进展，并快速概述他正在与微软或其他合作伙伴谈判的最新交易。一些独立董事会成员要求更频繁地召开会议并提供更有条理的信息，坚持要求奥特曼提供书面报告并允许他们查阅更多文件。

Until that point, Altman had convened the board roughly once a quarter and preferred to deliver his updates verbally. He breezed through complex research topics, sometimes bringing along company researchers to present their progress, and gave rapid-fire rundowns on the latest deals he was in the process of negotiating with Microsoft or other partners. Some of the independent board members pressed for more frequent meetings and more structured information, insisting Altman provide written reports and give them access to more documents.

奥特曼对监管力度加大感到恼火。他多次表示，希望董事会成员更多地充当顾问的角色，为他提供意见，供他参考。“CEO应该做决定，而董事会应该，你知道，充当一个倾听者——提供建议和同意，”他在2017年曾对大学生说过，这番话似乎在引用美国宪法中的一个治理概念，即立法机构制衡行政机构权力的核心作用，但他却用这个词来表达相反的意思。“我认为董事会应该解雇一个不称职的CEO吗？是的——我知道这在硅谷有点异端邪说。除此之外，我认为董事会是否需要给予CEO非常大的自主权来管理公司？是的。”

Altman chafed at the increased oversight. He expressed several times that he wanted the board members to serve more as advisers who gave him input for consideration. “The CEO is supposed to make the decisions, and the board is supposed to, you know, be a sounding board—advice and consent,” he once said to university students in 2017, seeming to reference a governance concept in the US Constitution, core to the role of the legislative branch to check the executive branch’s power, but using it to mean the opposite. “Do I think a board should fire a bad CEO? Yes—and I know that’s, like, a little bit heretical in Silicon Valley. Beyond that, do I think the board needs to give the CEO a very wide latitude to run the company? Yes.”

几位董事会成员强烈认为 OpenAI 的董事会应该与众不同。”“该董事会是一个非营利性董事会，其设立的明确目的是确保公司的公共利益使命处于首要地位，优先于利润、投资者利益和其他事项，”海伦·托纳在TED AI Show播客中说道，“而不仅仅是帮助CEO筹集更多资金。”

Several board members felt strongly that OpenAI’s board was meant to be different. “The board is a nonprofit board that was set up explicitly for the purpose of making sure that the company’s public good mission was primary, was coming first over profits, investor interests, and other things,” Helen Toner would tell The TED AI Show podcast. “Not just like, you know, helping the CEO to raise more money.”

GPT-4 在许多员工心中巩固了通用人工智能 (AGI) 的信念。曾经持怀疑态度的研究人员对达到这样的技术巅峰越来越充满信心——尽管 OpenAI 仍然缺乏对 AGI 的定义。加入应用材料公司并通过 GPT-4 与人工智能进行首次近距离互动的工程师和产品经理，甚至采用了更具确定性的语言。对许多员工来说，问题不再是 AGI 是否会发生，而是何时发生。

Among many employees, GPT-4 solidified the belief that AGI was possible. Researchers who were once skeptical felt increasingly bullish about reaching such a technical pinnacle—even while OpenAI continued to lack a definition of what exactly it was. Engineers and product managers joining Applied and having their first close-up interaction with AI through GPT-4 adopted even more deterministic language. For many employees, the question became not if AGI would happen but when.

一些员工的感受也截然相反。一位参与该模型开发的研究人员表示，虽然 GPT-3 的功能相比 GPT-2 有了明显的质的变化，但 GPT-4 的规模更大。“最大的结果是，该模型在很多考试中表现良好。但即便如此，这一点也值得高度怀疑。” OpenAI 从未对 GPT-4 的训练数据进行全面审查，以核实这些考试及其答案是否只是存在于数据中并被反复使用，还是 GPT-4 真的开发出了一种通过这些考试的全新能力。随着整个行业从同行评审转向公关评审，这种不靠谱的科学研究变得普遍存在。

Some employees also felt exactly the opposite. While there was a clear qualitative change in what GPT-3 could do over GPT-2, GPT-4 was just bigger, says one of the researchers who worked on the model. “The big result was that there were a bunch of exams that the model does well. But even that is highly questionable.” OpenAI never did a comprehensive review of GPT-4’s training data to check whether those exams—and their answers—were just in the data and being regurgitated, or whether GPT-4 had in fact developed a novel capability to pass them. It was the kind of shaky science that had become pervasive with the industry-wide shift from peer-reviewed to PR-reviewed research.

—

—

但认为人工智能已达到全新高度的信念却已破灭。那年春天，谷歌重组后的负责任人工智能团队的工程师布莱克·勒莫因（Blake Lemoine）越来越相信，公司自己的大型语言模型 LaMDA 不仅高度智能，而且可以被视为具有感知能力。他说，这并非基于科学评估，而是基于他作为一名神秘基督教牧师的信仰，即上帝可以决定赋予技术意识。我有什么资格告诉上帝他能把灵魂放在哪里，不能放在哪里？”他写道。当公司高管解雇他时，他向《华盛顿邮报》公开了此事。爆料记者 Nitasha Tiku 也采访了 Emily Bender 和梅格·米切尔 (Meg Mitchell) 曾在他们的“随机鹦鹉”论文中警告说，大型语言模型可能会欺骗人们，使他们无法看到其生成背后的真正含义和意图。

But the belief that AI had reached fundamentally new heights was in the water. At Google that spring, Blake Lemoine, an engineer on the tech giant’s newly re-formed responsible AI team, grew convinced that the company’s own large language model LaMDA was not only highly intelligent but could be considered sentient. He said this was not based on a scientific assessment but rather on his belief, as a mystic Christian priest, that God could decide to give technology consciousness. “Who am I to tell God where he can and can’t put souls?” he wrote. When company executives dismissed him, he went public with The Washington Post. Nitasha Tiku, the reporter who broke the story, also spoke to Emily Bender and Meg Mitchell, who had warned in their “Stochastic Parrots” paper about the problem of large language models fooling people into seeing real meaning and intent behind their generations.

本德说：“我们现在拥有可以无意识地生成文字的机器，但我们还没有学会如何停止想象它们背后的思维。”

“We now have machines that can mindlessly generate words, but we haven’t learned how to stop imagining a mind behind them,” said Bender.

米切尔说：“我真的很担心，当这种幻觉变得如此美好时，人们会越来越受到这种幻觉的影响。”

“I’m really concerned about what it means for people to increasingly be affected by the illusion,” when that illusion is becoming so good, Mitchell said.

曾在 OpenAI 早期实习的人工智能研究员尼基尔·米什拉（Nikhil Mishra）将此事与 20 世纪 70 年代的一项实验进行了类比。当时，研究人员试图教会一只大猩猩一种改良版的美国手语。这只名叫科科（Koko）的大猩猩，在一生中似乎学会了超过一千种手语，甚至学会了造句。尽管公众大肆宣传，其他专家却认为科科从未真正掌握这门语言。虽然她确实擅长做手势，但几乎没有证据表明她比其他类人猿在类似实验中的表现更出色：只是模仿饲养员的手势。科科从未发表过任何关于手语的数据来独立验证她的能力，只有一些精心挑选的视频来展示她的手语能力。有时，她的现场表演需要进一步推敲。有一次，当训练员问科科是否喜欢人时，科科用手语说“好的乳头”。训练员立即解释说：“乳头”与“人”押韵；科科觉得人很好。对许多观察者来说，这些事件更多地揭示了人类心理学以及我们倾向于投射自身信念和意图的倾向，而不是科科的能力。米什拉说，训练员在没有任何意义的地方赋予了意义。

Nikhil Mishra, the AI researcher who interned at OpenAI in its early days, draws parallels to an experiment in the 1970s that sought to teach a gorilla a modified form of American Sign Language. Over her lifetime, the gorilla, named Koko, seemed to learn more than one thousand signs—and even the ability to construct sentences. But despite enormous public fanfare, other experts argued that Koko never truly acquired the language. While she was certainly skilled at forming gestures, there was little evidence that she was doing more than what other apes had done across many other similar experiments: simply mirroring the gestures of their caretakers. No data was ever published of Koko’s signing to independently verify her capabilities, only curated videos of her showcasing them. At times, her live performances begged further scrutiny. Once, when her trainer asked Koko whether she liked people, Koko signed “fine nipple.” The trainer immediately explained: “Nipple” rhymed with “people”; Koko thought people were fine. To many observers, these episodes revealed more about human psychology and our tendency to project our own beliefs and ideas of intent than about Koko’s ability. The trainer, Mishra says, was assigning meaning where there wasn’t any.

对于 OpenAI 的常驻神秘专家 Sutskever 来说，他一直比大多数研究人员更相信在短期内实现通用人工智能 (AGI) 的可能性，而该公司模型能力的飞跃只是进一步证实了这一点。他越来越确信，自己正在见证一种推理形式。在与 Hinton 的谈话中，Sutskever 告诉他的导师，AGI 即将到来。

For OpenAI’s own resident mystic, Sutskever, who had always believed more than most researchers in the likelihood of achieving AGI in the short term, the leap in the company’s model capabilities served only as further confirmation. He grew convinced that he was witnessing a form of reasoning. In conversations with Hinton, Sutskever told his mentor that AGI was imminent.

此前，Sutskever 更专注于推动 OpenAI 研究人员开发新功能，而现在他把注意力转向了人工智能安全研究带着新的紧迫感。他开始宣扬“感受通用人工智能”（Feel the AGI），并敦促大家为剧烈的变革做好准备。“你可能会突然成为派对上最受欢迎的人，”他告诉员工。“你们不必为此而自满。专注于通用人工智能，专注于我们的使命。”

Where before, Sutskever focused more on pushing OpenAI researchers to advance new capabilities, he shifted his attention to AI safety research with new urgency. He began his mantra “Feel the AGI” and urged people to prepare themselves for dramatic changes. “You’re suddenly going to be the most popular person at a party,” he told employees. “You need to not let it get to your head. Stay focused on AGI, stay focused on the mission.”

那年九月，技术领导层在特纳亚旅馆（Tenaya Lodge）举行了一次场外会议。特纳亚旅馆是一处偏远的豪华度假村，坐落在内华达山脉郁郁葱葱的群山之中。旅馆拥有令人惊叹的室内装饰、多个游泳池和餐厅，距离约塞米蒂国家公园数百万英亩的原始荒野仅两英里。第一天晚上，大家聚集在酒店后院的火坑旁。资深科学家身着浴袍，在火堆两侧围成半圆形。

That September, the technical leadership held an off-site at the Tenaya Lodge, a remote luxury resort nestled in the lush folds of the Sierra Nevada. The property, furnished with stunning interiors and multiple pools and restaurants, sat only two miles away from the millions of acres of pristine wilderness in Yosemite National Park. On the first night, everyone gathered around a firepit on the rear patio of the hotel. Senior scientists, dressed in bathrobes, flanked the fire in a semicircle.

然后，苏茨克维尔出现了。他在坑里放置了一个委托当地艺术家制作的木制人偶，并开始了一场戏剧表演。他解释说，这个人偶代表着OpenAI打造的善良、一致的通用人工智能，却发现它实际上是在撒谎和欺骗。他说，OpenAI的职责就是摧毁它。几码之外，几棵红杉树像古老的见证者一样矗立在黑暗中。苏茨克维尔将打火机油浇在人偶上，然后点燃了它。

Then Sutskever emerged. In the pit, he had placed a wooden effigy that he’d commissioned from a local artist, and began a dramatic performance. This effigy, he explained, represented a good, aligned AGI that OpenAI had built, only to discover it was actually lying and deceitful. OpenAI’s duty, he said, was to destroy it. Only a few yards away, several redwoods stood like ancient witnesses in the darkness. Sutskever doused the effigy in lighter fluid and lit it on fire.

第十一章

Chapter 11

顶点

Apex

我2022年10月，OpenAI在加州蒙特雷举行了一次全公司员工大会。蒙特雷是一座美丽的海滨城市，位于旧金山以南两小时车程处。届时，公司员工人数已从一年前的不到两百人增长到约三百人。那个周末，他们在蒙特雷的小机场外合影留念，笑容满面，身着 OpenAI 品牌的装备。Altman 看起来很放松，坐在队伍最前面的地上，膝盖抵着胸口，双臂自然交叉，双脚向上。

In October 2022, OpenAI held a company-wide off-site in Monterey, California, a beautiful coastal city two hours south of San Francisco. By then the company had grown to roughly three hundred employees, from less than two hundred the year before. For a photo that weekend, they all posed outside Monterey’s tiny airport, grinning and wearing their OpenAI-branded gear. Altman looked relaxed, sitting on the ground in the front of the pack, knees against his chest, arms loosely crossed, feet pointed up.

在两天的时间里，高管团队介绍了他们的愿景和实施进展：Altman 介绍了微软正在为 OpenAI 扩展的大型数据中心；Steve Dowling 和他的副手 Hannah Wong 介绍了即将报道该公司的顶级出版物；Anna Makanju 介绍了该公司在华盛顿特区不断扩张的业务。随后，研究和产品团队陆续演示了他们的最新项目。这一切令人印象深刻。“所有的一切加在一起，真是令人难以置信，”一位在场的前员工回忆道。

Over two days, the executive team presented updates on their vision and implementation: Altman on the massive data centers that Microsoft was scaling up for OpenAI; Steve Dowling and his deputy Hannah Wong on the top-tier publications lining up to cover the company; Anna Makanju on its expanding footprint in Washington, DC. Then there were demos, one after the other, of the research and product teams’ latest projects. The sheer impressiveness of it all was palpable. “Everything together was so mind-boggling,” remembers a former employee who was present.

布罗克曼上台讨论了 GPT-4 的最新计划，并开始讲述他妻子安娜的故事。有一天，安娜开始腹痛不止。安娜是办公室里的常客。她的办公桌就在他旁边，甚至经常陪他一起开会。尽管她没有正式在公司工作。格雷格曾经告诉我，除了奥特曼和萨茨克弗，她是他最依赖的支持对象、他最好的朋友、他的知己。他们经常形影不离，形影不离。格雷格向员工解释说，他陪安娜看过很多医生，但都没能找出问题所在。但当他问 GPT-4 时，GPT-4 表示安娜可能患有他们没有考虑到的疾病。“然后她真的患上了！”他惊呼道。这是他在 2019 年与我分享的同一个故事的复述，关于 AGI 有望为像他的朋友这样的人解决医疗保健问题，他的朋友曾去过无数专家那里诊断问题——这次是以不同的身份出现的。

Brockman got onstage to discuss the latest plans for GPT-4 and began to tell a story about his wife, Anna, who started having abdominal pains one day that wouldn’t go away. Anna was a frequent fixture at the office. She had a desk next to his and often came with him to meetings even though she didn’t officially work at the company.
