Besides Altman and Sutskever, she was, Greg had once told me, the person he relied on most for support, his best friend, his confidant. They were often attached at the hip, going everywhere together. Greg went with Anna to multiple doctors, he explained to employees, and none could figure out the problem. But when he asked GPT-4, it suggested she might have a condition that they hadn’t considered. “And then she did!” he exclaimed. It was a retelling of the same story he’d shared with me in 2019, about the promise of AGI solving health care for people like his friend who had gone to myriad specialists to diagnose a problem—this time with a different character.

在董事会试图解雇奥特曼几周后，格雷格又重复了一遍这个故事，只是换了一种说法。他讲述了安娜面临的新的医疗挑战，以及她五年来“看的医生和专家比她之前一生看的还多”才最终得到诊断的挣扎。最终，她的过敏症专科医生将所有线索拼凑起来，确诊她患有过度活动型埃勒斯-丹洛斯综合征，这是一种遗传性活动障碍。他写道，通用人工智能在“医学等高风险领域”发挥作用还有很长的路要走，他继续为OpenAI的团结雄心鼓劲，“但前景正变得越来越清晰。”

Greg would repeat the story again on X weeks after the board’s attempt to fire Altman, with a new variation. He would recount new medical challenges that Anna had faced and her struggle over five years “seeing more doctors and specialists than in her whole life prior” to finally get a diagnosis. It was her allergist who finally put all the pieces together and realized she had hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, a genetic mobility disorder. There was still a long way for AGI to work “in high-stakes areas like medicine,” he wrote, keeping up his drumbeat on behalf of OpenAI’s rallying ambition, “but the promise is getting increasingly clear.”

—

—

休假回来几周后，谣言开始传播，说 Anthropic 正在测试一款新的聊天机器人，并且很快就会发布。Superassistant 团队的聊天界面设计正在进行中。如果这款机器人不能率先发布，OpenAI 就有可能失去领先地位，这可能会严重打击那些为了保持领先地位而长期辛勤工作的员工的士气。更糟糕的是，对一些领导者来说，OpenAI 可能会输给 Anthropic。

Within weeks of returning from the off-site, rumors began to spread that Anthropic was testing—and would soon release—a new chatbot. The Superassistant team was midway through designing its chat interface. If it didn’t launch first, OpenAI risked losing its leading position, which could deliver a big hit to morale for employees who had worked long and tough hours to retain that dominance. Worse still for some leaders, OpenAI would lose to Anthropic.

事实上，Anthropic 并没有计划任何即将发布的产品。它自身也正深陷困境。随着 FTX 在 11 月初突然倒闭，Anthropic 也深陷其中。就在几个月前，Anthropic 筹集了 5.8 亿美元，其中 5 亿美元来自 SBF 和其他高层领导。FTX 的一份新闻稿称，这笔资金来自 SBF 和其他高层领导。审判期间公布的财务文件后来发现，这笔钱来自 SBF 挪用的数十亿美元FTX 客户存款，使得 Anthropic 的投资成为审判期间的一个核心问题，即从中产生的巨额回报是否可以用来偿还客户。（如果法官裁定可以，FTX 将在 2024 年之前分批出售其 Anthropic 股份，总价值 13 亿美元。）

Anthropic had not in fact been planning any imminent releases. It was also in the midst of its own problems. With the sudden collapse of FTX in the early days of November, it was getting swept up in the fallout. Just months before, it had raised $580 million, $500 million of which an FTX press release had said was from SBF and other senior leaders. Financial documents released during the trial would later find that that money had been sourced from the billions that SBF had embezzled from FTX customer deposits, turning the Anthropic investment into a central issue during the trial over whether the significant returns generated from it could be used to pay back customers. (A judge would rule that it could, and FTX would sell off its Anthropic shares in batches through 2024 for a total of $1.3 billion.)

但对于 OpenAI 的高管来说，这些传言足以促使他们做出决定：公司不会等到 GPT-4 准备好用于聊天机器人；它将在两周内，也就是感恩节之后，发布舒尔曼支持聊天的 GPT-3.5 模型，该模型将搭载 Superassistant 团队全新的聊天界面。Superassistant 团队立即做出调整，拉拢其他几位成员，全力以赴整合所有功能，并构建剩余功能。对于公司的其他成员，领导层精心策划了这项工作。他们最终确定的名称 ChatGPT 实际上并非产品发布，而是一个“低调的研究预览”，就像 DALL-E 2 一样。同样，它不会货币化，而是“启动数据飞轮”——换句话说，从使用它的人那里收集更多数据——这将有助于改进 GPT-4 和 Superassistant 产品。

But for OpenAI executives, the rumors were enough to trigger a decision: The company wouldn’t wait to ready GPT-4 into a chatbot; it would release Schulman’s chat-enabled GPT-3.5 model with the Superassistant team’s brand-new chat interface in two weeks, right after Thanksgiving. The Superassistant team instantly pivoted, pulling in several other members as they sprinted to integrate everything and build out the remaining features. To the rest of the company, leadership framed the effort carefully. ChatGPT—the name they settled on—would not in fact be a product launch but a “low-key research preview,” just like DALL-E 2. In the same way, it wouldn’t be monetized but “get the data flywheel going”—in other words, amass more data from people using it—which would help improve GPT-4 and the Superassistant product.

除了 Superassistant 团队之外，所有人都对高管们的话信以为真。低调的研究预览不需要他们关注；他们需要专注于 2023 年初发布的 GPT-4。信任与安全团队觉得他们几乎没有足够的时间在 GPT-4 发布前构建监控基础设施。相比之下，ChatGPT 似乎不成问题。GPT-3.5 已经通过 RLHF 进行了改进；它本质上比 GPT-3 版本更安全，而 GPT-3 版本尚未改进，但仍在 API 上可用。OpenAI 还在其开发者平台上发布了一个不带聊天功能的 3.5 版本，供开发者测试模型的功能。添加聊天界面真的有用吗？忙于测试和调整 GPT-4 的安全团队对此表示赞同。这是模型发布首次在几乎没有遇到任何阻力的情况下顺利通过审核。

Outside of the Superassistant team, everyone took the executives literally. A low-key research preview didn’t require their attention; they needed to stay focused on the GPT-4 launch for early 2023. The trust and safety team felt they barely had enough time to build out its monitoring infrastructure in time for that launch. By comparison, ChatGPT seemed like a nonissue. GPT-3.5 had already been refined with RLHF; it was inherently safer than the version of GPT-3, which had not been, still available on the API. OpenAI had also posted a version of 3.5 without chat features on its developer platform for developers to test out the model’s capabilities. Did adding a chat interface really make a difference? People in the Safety clan, occupied with testing and tuning GPT-4, agreed. For the first time, a model release flew through the checks with little resistance.

即使在 Superassistant 团队内部，也没有人真正理解他们即将引发的社会变革。他们预计这个聊天机器人只是昙花一现。就像 DALL-E 2 一样，它会在社交媒体上引起轩然大波，几周后就会销声匿迹。那天晚上发布前，经过如此紧张的冲刺，一切都显得异常平静。他们打赌，周末结束前会有多少用户试用这个工具。有人猜几千人，有人猜几万。为了安全起见，基础设施团队预留了足够十万用户的服务器容量。

Even within the Superassistant team, no one truly fathomed the societal phase shift they were about to unleash. They expected the chatbot to be a flash in the pan. Much like DALL-E 2, it would generate a lot of fanfare on social media and then quiet down after a few weeks. The night before the release, things felt remarkably calm after such an intense sprint to the finish. They placed bets on how many users might try the tool by the end of the weekend. Some people guessed a few thousand. Others guessed tens of thousands. To be safe, the infrastructure team provisioned enough server capacity for one hundred thousand users.

第二天，也就是11月30日，星期三，大多数其他员工甚至都没有意识到这次发布已经发生。与OpenAI的首次亮相一样，ChatGPT的发布恰逢NeurIPS年度会议，该会议于当年在路易斯安那州新奥尔良举行。该会议早些时候宣布了“时间考验奖”，该奖项每年颁发给十年前发表的一篇对该领域产生重要影响的论文。该奖项授予了Hinton、Sutskever和Krizhevsky在2012年发表的ImageNet论文，该论文向世界展示了深度学习的威力。

The following day, on Wednesday, November 30, most other employees didn’t even realize that the launch had happened. Like OpenAI’s own debut, ChatGPT’s release coincided with the annual NeurIPS proceedings, that year being held in New Orleans, Louisiana. The conference had earlier announced its Test of Time Award, an honor bestowed each year to a paper published ten years earlier that had had a critical impact on the field. The award went to Hinton, Sutskever, and Krizhevsky’s 2012 ImageNet paper that introduced the world to the power of deep learning.

当晚，一小群员工在会议中心附近举办了一场 OpenAI 派对，代表公司在近万名现场参会者中招募感兴趣的候选人。DeepMind、Meta 和谷歌都在同一时间在全城各地举办了竞争性的招聘派对。派对进行过程中，一位在场的招聘人员注意到一位 OpenAI 工程师在电脑上不停地工作。

That evening a small group of employees hosted an OpenAI party near the conference convention center to represent the company and recruit interested candidates among the nearly ten thousand in-person attendees. DeepMind, Meta, and Google were holding competing recruitment parties at the exact same time throughout the city. As the party went on, a recruiter at the event noticed an OpenAI engineer working nonstop on his computer.

他终于走过去和工程师说话：“兄弟，喝点东西吧。我们都在这儿。大家交流一下。”

He finally went over to talk to the engineer: “Bro, have a drink. We’re all here. Be social.”

工程师一动不动。“不行，所有GPU都熔化了。一切都崩溃了。”

The engineer didn’t move. “No, all the GPUs are melting. Everything is crashing.”

—

—

那天晚上，日本率先醒来，流量突飞猛进，令人措手不及。第二天，随着世界其他地区一个时区接一个时区地上线，用户数量持续飙升。马斯克在推动这一增长方面发挥了不小的作用。“很多人都被困在了‘ChatGPT’的疯狂循环里”，他在推特上写道，这条推文获得了大约七万五千个赞。

That night, Japan had been first to wake up and to deliver a massive and unexpected swell in the traffic. The following day, the number of users continued to surge, as time zone by time zone the rest of the world came online. Musk played no small part in boosting the climb. “Lot of people stuck in a damn-that’s-crazy ChatGPT loop “,” he tweeted, receiving some seventy-five thousand likes.

ChatGPT 的迅速成功超出了 OpenAI 所有人的预期。即使多年以后，它仍然会让公司的工程师和研究人员感到恼火。GPT-3.5 并没有达到这样的程度。与已经发布两年的 GPT-3 相比，GPT-3.5 的功能有了很大的提升。而且 GPT-3.5 已经向开发者开放了。界面和格式确实让模型更容易上手，但这并非员工们在 GPT-4 中感受到的根本性变化。Altman 后来表示，他原本相信 ChatGPT 会很受欢迎，但““少了一个数量级。”一位前员工回忆道：“人们竟然喜欢它，这太令人震惊了。对我们所有人来说，他们把我们内部一直在用的东西降级了，然后就发布了它。”

The instant runaway success of ChatGPT was beyond what anyone at OpenAI had dreamed of. It would leave the company’s engineers and researchers completely miffed even years later. GPT-3.5 hadn’t been that much of a capability improvement over GPT-3, which had already been out for two years. And GPT-3.5 had already been available to developers. The interface and format had made the model more accessible, certainly, but it wasn’t the fundamental step change that employees had felt with GPT-4. Altman later said that he’d believed ChatGPT would be popular but by something like “one order of magnitude less.” “It was shocking that people liked it,” a former employee remembers. “To all of us, they’d downgraded the thing we’d been using internally and launched it.”

五天之内，布罗克曼在推特上宣布 ChatGPT 用户数突破一百万。两个月内，ChatGPT 用户数达到一亿，成为当时历史上增长最快的消费应用。（Meta 的 X 竞争对手 Threads 后来在不到五天内就达到了同样的用户数，夺得了这一称号；评论家认为这不算数，因为 Meta 主要利用的是现有的用户群。）

Within five days, Brockman tweeted that ChatGPT had crossed one million users. Within two months, it had reached one hundred million, becoming what was then the fastest-growing consumer app in history. (Meta’s X rival, Threads, later claimed the title by reaching the same user count in less than five days; pundits argued that it didn’t count because Meta was primarily tapping into an existing base of users.)

ChatGPT 让 OpenAI 一夜之间从科技界一家名不见经传的热门初创公司一跃成为家喻户晓的品牌。几个月后，在距离旧金山九千多英里的卢旺达基加利举行的一次人工智能研究会议上，一位来自卢旺达的研究人员滔滔不绝地告诉我，ChatGPT 之后，他的父母终于理解了他的工作。“当你妈妈告诉你一项技术的时候，你就知道它人人都能用，”他会说。

ChatGPT catapulted OpenAI from a hot startup well-known within the tech industry into a household name overnight. Indeed, at an AI research conference several months later in Kigali, Rwanda, over nine thousand miles away from San Francisco, a researcher based in the country would gush to me that post-ChatGPT, his parents finally understood what he did for work. “You know a technology is accessible to anyone when your mother tells you about it,” he’d say.

与此同时，正是这一轰动性的成功给公司带来了巨大的压力。一年之后，它进一步加剧了内部派系的分化，使组织内部的压力和紧张局势达到了爆炸性的程度。

At the same time, it was this very blockbuster success that would place extraordinary strain on the company. Over the course of a year, it would polarize its factions further and wind up the stress and tension within the organization to an explosive level.

事发后，整个公司都陷入了“救火”状态。OpenAI 的服务器频频崩溃，而基础设施团队则努力在硅谷历史上最紧迫的时间内尽快扩展服务器容量。为了支持 ChatGPT 的增长，团队动用了研究部门的部分计算资源，但仍然没有足够的资源来维持该应用的正常运行。信任与安全团队该公司只有十几个人，忙于在大量新用户中了解和发现不良行为，但监控不力，严重阻碍了其发展。该公司一直难以招聘到所需的工程师来实施其有限的被动执行计划，并且仍在构建必要的系统。ChatGPT 导致项目脱轨。所有完成新工具的努力都停止了，因为工程资源被重新分配用于稳定现有系统。服务器崩溃后，流量监控平台也崩溃了，任何规模化执行的能力都彻底停滞。

In the immediate aftermath, the whole company was firefighting. OpenAI’s servers crashed repeatedly as the infrastructure team struggled to scale up its capacity as fast as possible, in the most compressed timeline in the history of Silicon Valley. The team cannibalized some of the Research division’s compute to support ChatGPT’s growth and still didn’t have enough to keep the app up and running. The trust and safety team, numbering just over a dozen people, scrambled to understand and catch bad behavior among the floods of new users, heavily handicapped by spotty monitoring. It had struggled to hire the engineers needed to implement its limited reactive enforcement plan and was still in the middle of building the necessary systems. ChatGPT derailed the project. All efforts to finish new tooling halted as engineering resources were redirected to stabilize what already existed. When the servers crashed, so did the platform for monitoring traffic, grinding the ability to do any scaled enforcement to a complete halt.

GPU 的严重短缺也使另一项努力受阻。为了充分利用公司自身的技术，信任与安全团队在内部设计了一个名为“事实工厂”（Fact Factory）的原型计划，OpenAI 也曾公开宣传过该计划，该计划旨在使用 GPT-4 来审核其自身以及其他 OpenAI 模型的输出内容。该计划的实施规模并不大；它需要向 GPT-4 提供极长的提示才能捕捉到足够多的细微差别。即使在服务器正常运行的情况下，这也会耗费过多的计算资源。而且服务器也并非始终处于正常运行状态。

The severe shortage of GPUs also derailed another effort. In an attempt to leverage the company’s own technology, the trust and safety team had prototyped a plan internally called Fact Factory, which OpenAI publicly touted, for using GPT-4 to content moderate its own outputs and that of other OpenAI models. The implementation didn’t exactly scale; it required giving GPT-4 extremely long prompts to capture enough nuance. Even when the servers were working, it would cost too many computational resources. And the servers were not consistently up.

对安全团队的许多成员来说，ChatGPT 是迄今为止最令人担忧的 OpenAI 预见性局限性的例子。一位安全团队的员工在一次全体会议上提出了一个问题：公司怎么会如此糟糕地预测不到用户行为和 ChatGPT 的受欢迎程度？这说明该公司校准和预测其技术未来影响的能力如何？

To many in the Safety clan, ChatGPT was the most alarming example yet of the limitations of OpenAI’s foresight. One Safety person raised the question in an all-hands meeting: How could the company have failed to predict user behavior and ChatGPT’s popularity so badly? What did that say about the company’s ability to calibrate and forecast the future impacts of its technologies?

对公司其他大部分人来说，服务器崩溃虽然是巨大的压力源，但更是一种非凡的胜利标志。OpenAI 打造了一项意义深远、需求旺盛的技术，它照亮了世界，并在一夜之间改变了世界。他们着眼于全人类，并且真的做到了。如今，所有人，所有 80 亿人，都生活在 OpenAI 的世界里。

To much of the rest of the company, the crashing servers, while an extraordinary source of stress, were even more so an extraordinary mark of triumph. OpenAI had built a technology so profound, in such wild demand, that it had lit up the world and transformed it overnight. They had set their sights on all of humanity and had really done it. Everyone, all eight billion people, was now living in OpenAI’s world.

奥特曼并没有沉溺于当下。他提醒员工，公司的最终使命远比打造“硅谷历史上最伟大的产品”要伟大得多。他敦促每个团队坚持到底，勇往直前。正如他所料，OpenAI 唤醒了所有竞争对手：Anthropic 即将发布其聊天机器人 Claude；谷歌内部拉响了“红色警报”，并将很快将其人工智能部门整合到 Google DeepMind，全力支持推出类似的产品。尽管OpenAI 凭借其 10 倍更好的产品率先进入市场，它需要继续保持领先地位。

Altman didn’t indulge the moment. He reminded employees that the company ultimately had a mission to achieve something far bigger than building “the biggest product in the history of Silicon Valley.” He urged every team to stay the course and press forward. As he’d expected, OpenAI had woken up all of its competitors: Anthropic was on its way to releasing its chatbot, Claude; Google had sounded a “code red” alarm internally and would soon consolidate its AI divisions into Google DeepMind to throw its full weight behind launching a similar product. Though OpenAI had hit the market first with its 10x better offering, it needed to keep running to stay number one.

—

—

由于每个团队都人手捉襟见肘，经理们恳求 Altman 增加人手。候选人数量不缺。ChatGPT 上线后，渴望加入这艘火箭的求职者数量迅速翻倍。但 Altman 担心，如果公司员工规模扩张过快，会影响公司文化和使命一致性。他坚信要保持小规模、高人才密度。“我们现在处境很诱人，很容易让组织变得非常庞大，”他在2020年愿景备忘录中提到微软的投资时写道。“我们应该尽力抵制这种做法——到目前为止，对我们有效的方法是小规模、专注、高信任、低废话和高强度。”

With every team stretched dangerously thin, managers begged Altman for more head count. There was no shortage of candidates. After ChatGPT, the number of job applicants clamoring to join the rocket ship had rapidly multiplied. But Altman worried about what would happen to company culture and mission alignment if the company scaled up its staff too quickly. He believed firmly in maintaining a small staff and high talent density. “We are now in a position where it’s tempting to let the organization grow extremely large,” he had written in his 2020 vision memo, in reference to Microsoft’s investment. “We should try very hard to resist this—what has worked for us so far is being small, focused, high-trust, low-bullshit, and intense.

“过多的人力和过多的官僚主义很容易扼杀伟大的创意或导致僵化。与过去的大型工程项目不同，我们只需极少数的优秀人才就能完成我们的使命。”

“The overhead of too many people and too much bureaucracy can easily kill great ideas or result in sclerosis. Unlike the big-iron engineering projects of the past, we could fulfill our mission with a surprisingly small number of great people.”

2022年底，他又向高管们重申了这一点，在员工人数讨论中反复强调，公司必须保持精简，人才门槛要高，新增员工不超过一百人左右。其他高管却犹豫不决。考虑到团队精疲力竭的速度，许多人认为需要招聘大约五百人甚至更多的新员工。

He was now repeating this to executives in late 2022, emphasizing repeatedly during head count discussions the need to keep the company lean and the talent bar high, and add no more than one hundred or so hires. Other executives balked. At the rate that their teams were burning out, many saw the need for something closer to around five hundred or even more new people.

经过几周的讨论，高管团队最终达成妥协，确定了一个介于250到300人之间的数字。但这个上限并没有达到。到了夏天，每周都有多达30人，甚至50人加入OpenAI，其中还包括更多的招聘人员，以更快地扩大招聘规模。到了秋天，公司已经远远超出了自己设定的配额。

Over several weeks, as the discussions continued, the executive team finally compromised on a number somewhere in the middle, between two hundred fifty and three hundred. The cap didn’t hold. By summer, there were as many as thirty, even fifty, people joining OpenAI each week, including more recruiters to scale up hiring even faster. By fall, the company had blown well past its own self-imposed quota.

突如其来的增长确实改变了公司文化。一位招聘人员写了一份宣言，讲述了快速招聘的压力如何迫使他的团队降低人才质量标准。“如果你想打造 Meta，你做得很好，”他尖锐地讽刺了 Altman。这恰恰影射了首席执行官此前警告的担忧：公司人才密度和使命导向将迅速下降，官僚主义也将加剧。快速扩张也导致解雇人数上升。一位经理在入职期间被告知要迅速记录并报告团队中任何表现不佳的成员，但不久之后，他自己也被解雇了。解雇消息很少传达给公司其他成员。人们通常是通过注意到Slack账户因停用而变灰才发现同事被解雇了。他们开始称之为“消失”。

The sudden growth spurt indeed changed company culture. A recruiter wrote a manifesto about how the pressure to hire so quickly was forcing his team to lower the quality bar for talent. “If you want to build Meta, you’re doing a great job,” he said in a pointed jab at Altman, alluding to the very fears that the CEO had warned about of the company rapidly diluting its talent density and mission orientation, while increasing its bureaucracy. The rapid expansion was also leading to an uptick in firings. During his onboarding, one manager was told to swiftly document and report any underperforming members of his team, only to be let go himself sometime later. Terminations were rarely communicated to the rest of the company. People routinely discovered that colleagues had been fired only by noticing when a Slack account grayed out from being deactivated. They began calling it “getting disappeared.”

对于新员工来说，他们完全相信自己加入的是一家快速发展、盈利丰厚的初创公司，这种动荡感就像是标准公司弊端的体现，尤其混乱，有时甚至残酷：管理不善、优先级混乱，以及资本主义公司冷酷无情，将员工视为一次性用品。一位在那个时期加入的前员工表示：“人们严重缺乏心理安全感。这就像‘公司如同家人’的反面——这很公平，你知道，它毕竟是一家公司。” 许多新员工只是勉强坚持到工作满一年才获得第一股股权。一个显著的好处是：他们仍然觉得自己的同事是科技行业中最优秀的人才之一，再加上看似取之不尽用之不竭的资源和无与伦比的全球影响力，当一切真正协调一致时，他们可能会感受到一种在其他行业难以找到的魔力。这位前员工说：“我想说，OpenAI 是我工作过的最好的公司之一，但也可能是最差的公司之一。”

To new hires, fully bought into the idea that they were joining a fast-moving, money-making startup, the tumultuousness felt like a particularly chaotic, at times brutal, manifestation of standard corporate problems: poor management, confusing priorities, the coldhearted ruthlessness of a capitalistic company willing to treat its employees as disposable. “There was a huge lack of psychological safety,” says a former employee who joined during this era. “It is like the opposite of ‘a company as a family’—which is fair, you know, it is a company.” Many people coming aboard were simply holding on for dear life until their one-year mark to get access to the first share of their equity. One significant upside: They still felt their colleagues were among the highest caliber in the tech industry, which, combined with the seemingly boundless resources and unparalleled global impact, could spark a feeling of magic difficult to find in the rest of the industry when things actually aligned. “I would say OpenAI is one of the best places I’ve ever worked but also probably one of the worst,” the former employee says.

对于一些员工来说，他们还记得 OpenAI 早期的蓬勃景象，那时它是一家团结一致、以使命为导向的非营利组织。而如今，它戏剧性地转型为一家规模庞大、默默无闻的公司，则更加令人震惊和感伤。他们所熟悉的组织已不复存在，取而代之的是面目全非的景象。“OpenAI 就像火人节，”前招聘人员 Rob Mallery 说，他指的是这个沙漠艺术节如何规模扩大到与最初的精神完全脱节。“我知道，它对最初参与其中的人来说，意义远比对现在的所有人更大。”

For some employees who remembered the scrappy early days of OpenAI as a tight-knit, mission-driven nonprofit, its dramatic transformation into a big, faceless corporation was far more shocking and emotional. Gone was the organization as they’d known it; in its place was something unrecognizable. “OpenAI is Burning Man,” Rob Mallery, a former recruiter, says, referring to how the desert art festival scaled to the point that it lost touch with its original spirit. “I know it meant a lot more to the people who were there at the beginning than it does to everyone now.”

在早期，团队建立了一个名为#explainlikeimfive 允许员工匿名提交技术问题。随着公司员工人数增加到六百人，该频道也变成了匿名吐槽的平台。2023 年年中，一名员工发帖称，公司招聘了太多与公司使命不符或对构建通用人工智能 (AGI) 不热衷的人。

In those early years, the team had set up a Slack channel called #explainlikeimfive that allowed employees to submit anonymous questions about technical topics. With the company pushing six hundred people, the channel also turned into a place for airing anonymous grievances. In mid-2023, an employee posted that the company was hiring too many people not aligned with the mission or passionate about building AGI.

另一个人回应道：他们知道，一旦 OpenAI 开始雇佣那些能直视你的人，它就会走下坡路。

Another person responded: They knew OpenAI was going downhill once it started hiring people who could look you in the eye.

—

—

ChatGPT 也让微软感到意外。OpenAI 的领导层曾告诉其合作伙伴，就像他们告诉自己的员工一样，这款聊天机器人将是一个“低调的研究预览”。但事实显然并非如此。

ChatGPT also surprised Microsoft. OpenAI leaders had told its partner, as they’d told their own employees, that the chatbot would be a “low-key research preview.” It was clearly anything but.

这种不匹配最初激怒了这家科技巨头的高管。ChatGPT 完全抢走了微软必应聊天机器人的风头。次年 2 月，微软推出必应 AI 时，该产品也遭遇了公关打击。《纽约时报》专栏作家凯文·鲁斯 (Kevin Roose) 撰文称，该产品迫使他与妻子离婚。这远未达到微软的预期，相比之下，OpenAI 的形象反而更胜一筹。

The mismatch initially peeved the tech giant’s executives. ChatGPT had completely stolen the thunder of Microsoft’s chatbot for Bing. When Microsoft pushed out Bing AI the following February, the product would also take a PR hit with an article by New York Times columnist Kevin Roose about it pushing him to divorce his wife. It was far from the reception Microsoft had hoped for and, by comparison, had made OpenAI look even better.

但这些不顺畅的沟通远不足以浇灭微软对 OpenAI 的热情。ChatGPT 的巨大反响极具感染力，而 OpenAI 模型不断提升的性能更是让这家巨头的高管们兴奋不已。微软目前正在为这家科技巨头基于 GPT-3.5 和 GPT-4 的产品准备一系列全新的 Copilot，并计划陆续发布。继 2 月份推出 Bing 之后，3 月份微软 365 Copilot 也正式发布，它将为从 Word 到 Outlook 再到 Teams 的所有 Office 产品带来基于 AI 的聊天界面。

But the crossed wires weren’t nearly enough to dampen Microsoft’s enthusiasm for OpenAI. The enormously positive reception to ChatGPT was contagious, and the continuously improving capabilities of OpenAI’s models made the giant’s executives even more excited. Microsoft was now readying a whole new slate of Copilots for the tech giant’s products based on GPT-3.5 and GPT-4, which it planned to release one after the other in a steady drumbeat of announcements. After Bing in February, March was for Microsoft 365 Copilot, bringing an AI-powered chat-based interface to every Office product from Word to Outlook to Teams.

微软高管内部谈论与 OpenAI 合作的方式也在迅速转变。此前，微软感觉自己掌控着 OpenAI；而现在，这家巨头的一些高管却觉得 OpenAI 掌控着微软。微软内部逐渐弥漫着一种自卑感，认为自身的 AI 研究工作未能达到 OpenAI 所取得的成就。如果微软不再担任 OpenAI 的主要投资者，这家初创公司就可以找到其他投资者，这一位前微软员工回忆起一些高管的想法。但如果 OpenAI 离开微软，这家科技巨头会找到另一个 OpenAI 吗？

The way in which Microsoft executives talked internally about the OpenAI partnership was also rapidly shifting. Before, Microsoft felt like it had power over OpenAI; now some of the giant’s executives felt like OpenAI had power over Microsoft. There was a creeping sense of inadequacy within parts of Microsoft that its own AI research efforts had failed to achieve what OpenAI had pulled off. If Microsoft walked away as OpenAI’s main investor, the startup could find other investors, a former Microsoft employee remembers of some of the executives’ thinking. But if OpenAI walked away from Microsoft, would the tech giant find another OpenAI?

与此同时，许多高管不再仅仅谈论击败谷歌。他们曾经对OpenAI关于通用人工智能（AGI）的奇怪说法以及其创造未来力量的夸夸其谈持礼貌的怀疑态度，但现在他们成了信徒。人工智能、通用人工智能、生成式人工智能——无论你怎么称呼它——这项技术代表着未来，而微软正与OpenAI携手引领它。微软越是相信，就越是调整其言论和战略。“我看到微软的激励机制越来越倾向于狭隘的未来观，”这位前员工说道。“我看到这项技术被狭隘地定义为某种由叙事而非现实支撑的东西。”

At the same time, many executives were no longer talking merely about beating Google. Where they had once responded to OpenAI’s strange talk about AGI and highfalutin language about its power to invent the future with polite skepticism, they were now believers. AI, AGI, generative AI—whatever you wanted to call it—this technology was the future, and Microsoft was shepherding it hand in hand with OpenAI. The more Microsoft believed, the more the company reoriented its rhetoric and strategy. “I saw the incentives at Microsoft push more and more toward a narrow conception of the future,” the former employee says. “I saw the technology become narrowed into something propped up by narrative rather than reality.”

纳德拉实施了一项新的战略来分配微软的计算资源。他将GPU从微软的研究团队转移到OpenAI。该公司还将所有GPU整合到一个池中，以便更好地支持生成式AI工作负载。一位微软员工回忆道：“去年1月之前，微软的普通员工根本不知道OpenAI是什么。” 现在，他们收到了上级的紧急指示，要求他们找到将自己的工作与OpenAI技术相结合的方法。

Nadella implemented a new strategy for distributing Microsoft’s computing resources. He shifted GPUs away from Microsoft’s research teams to support OpenAI. The company also consolidated all of its GPUs into one pool for better supporting generative AI workloads. “The typical Microsoft employee had no fucking clue what OpenAI was before January last year,” one Microsoft employee remembers. Now they were receiving urgent directives from their superiors about finding ways to intersect their work with OpenAI technologies.

随着员工们尝试各种方式使用 GPT-4 和 ChatGPT，这家科技巨头在短短几个月内就经历了超过一百个新的生成式人工智能项目的快速涌现。讽刺的是，这种积极的采用将迫使微软应对许多与其他公司在尚未完全理解生成式人工智能的情况下竞相采用时相同的挑战。这其中就包括给风险和合规团队带来麻烦。并非所有人都在使用微软内部版本的技术；有些员工选择直接使用 OpenAI 提供的 ChatGPT 免费版本，该版本基于用户数据进行训练，这引发了人们对这是否会泄露微软客户信息或干扰监管合规性的担忧。虽然一些员工发现这些工具极大地提高了工作效率，但许多员工也觉得它们很累。“现在有一种‘用人工智能，用人工智能，用人工智能’的文化，”其中一人说道。但“感觉就像，好吧，这对我们没有帮助。我们不想用它。感觉它无处不在，我们无法摆脱它。”

The tech giant would experience a rapid proliferation of over one hundred new generative AI projects within just a few months as employees experimented with various ways of using GPT-4 and ChatGPT. In an ironic twist, the aggressive adoption would force Microsoft to grapple with many of the same challenges that other companies would face as they raced to adopt generative AI without fully understanding it. That included causing headaches for the risk and compliance teams. Not everyone was using Microsoft’s internal versions of the technologies; some were opting to use the free version of ChatGPT straight from OpenAI, which trained on user data, raising concerns over whether that could leak Microsoft customer information or interfere with regulatory compliance. While some employees found the tools a big productivity boost, many also found them exhausting. “There is this culture of ‘Use AI, use AI, use AI,” says one. But “it’s like, okay, this doesn’t help us. We don’t want to use it. And it feels like it’s everywhere and we can’t escape it.”

在从微软自有模型转向 OpenAI 模型的过程中，许多员工也失去了对其工作核心基础设施层的控制权和可见性。在这家科技巨头内部，即使这家初创公司的底层模型是在微软的服务器上训练和存储的，其访问权限也受到严格保护。大多数微软员工无法再检查训练数据或调整他们正在使用的模型的权重。OpenAI 的模型则通过 API 交付，就像它们提供给其他 OpenAI 客户一样。

In switching from Microsoft’s own models to OpenAI’s, many employees also lost control and visibility into a core infrastructure layer of their work. Within the tech giant, access to the startup’s underlying models was tightly guarded, even though they were trained and stored on Microsoft’s servers. Most Microsoft employees could no longer examine the training data or tweak the weights of the models they were using. OpenAI’s models were instead delivered through an API, as they were to other OpenAI customers.

但作为这些权衡的回报，微软获得了丰厚的回报。作为唯一一家能够提供云计算典型优势的云提供商，Azure AI 平台的入站客户数量激增，这些优势包括更简单的数据存储和管理，以及利用 OpenAI 的功能处理这些数据的能力。“Azure OpenAI 服务让我们获得了许多新客户，”人工智能平台企业副总裁 Eric Boyd 在 2023 年 5 月给其部门的一封电子邮件中写道。8 月，他再次热情洋溢。“时不时地回顾过去，惊叹于我们在短短一年内取得的进步，真是太棒了，”他在给部门的信中补充道，并补充说该平台当年的“客户数量增长了 21 倍”。次月，Boyd 庆祝了一个新的里程碑。在将微软分散的人工智能工作集中到该平台之后，随着成千上万的新客户加入 Azure OpenAI 服务，该平台的流量在短短九个月内增长了十倍。2023 年 1 月，它每月收到的推理请求达一千亿次；而现在到了 9 月，它收到的推理请求已达一万亿次。

But in exchange for these trade-offs, Microsoft was being richly rewarded. The company was seeing a massive surge in inbound customers for its Azure AI platform as the only cloud provider able to offer the typical benefits of the cloud, including simpler data storage and management, alongside the ability to process that data with OpenAI’s capabilities. “Azure OpenAI Service is getting us in the door with many new customers these days,” Eric Boyd, the corporate vice president of the AI platform, wrote in an email to his division in May 2023. In August, he enthused once more. “Every now and then it’s great to take a step back and marvel at just how far we’ve come in just one year,” he wrote to his division, adding that the platform that year had seen a “21x increase in customers.” The following month, Boyd celebrated a new milestone. After centralizing Microsoft’s fractured AI efforts onto the platform, and with the thousands of new customers who had joined Azure OpenAI Service, traffic on the platform had grown tenfold in just nine months. In January 2023, it had been receiving one hundred billion monthly inference requests; now in September, it was receiving one trillion.

那年夏天，微软首席技术官凯文·斯科特 (Kevin Scott) 在 OpenAI 全体会议上对此大加赞赏。我们已经停止了在很多地方的人工智能机器学习投资，以至于人们会说，‘嘿，你知道，微软，去你的。’”斯科特说，他指的是微软将 GPU 从自己的一些内部研究。“我们之所以接受这个赌注，是因为我们相信你们都在做着业内绝对最好的工作。”

That summer, Microsoft CTO Kevin Scott was effusive with his praise during an OpenAI all-hands meeting. “We have stopped, like, our AI machine learning investments in a bunch of places to the point that, like, people are like, ‘Hey, you know, fuck you, Microsoft,’ ” Scott said, referring to the shifting away of GPUs from some of Microsoft’s own internal research. “And we’ve taken the bet because we believe that you all are doing the absolute best work in the industry.”

—

—

ChatGPT 坚定地标志着 OpenAI 从非营利性转向商业化的决心。Altman 和其他高管通过推出一系列付费产品，力图延续聊天机器人的成功势头。2023 年 2 月，OpenAI 发布了 ChatGPT 的付费版本；3 月，又相继发布了 API 版本、Whisper API，以及最终的 GPT-4。一位前员工表示：“ChatGPT 之后，OpenAI 的收入和盈利之路变得清晰起来。你再也无法像理想主义那样成为一个研究实验室了。现在，客户就在这里，渴望得到服务。”

ChatGPT firmly codified OpenAI’s turn away from nonprofit and toward commercialization. Altman and other executives pushed to build on the momentum of the chatbot’s success by launching a slew of paid products. In February 2023, it released a paid version of ChatGPT; in March, one after the other, it released an API version, the Whisper API, and finally GPT-4. “After ChatGPT, there was a clear path to revenue and profit,” a former employee says. “You could no longer make a case for being an idealistic research lab. There were customers looking to be served here and now.”

新产品的涌现再次让信任与安全团队不堪重负。OpenAI 曾一度通过提供价值 20 美元的初始免费使用额度来吸引用户加入其 API。随着 ChatGPT 的火爆，API 使用量也随之激增，这种注册激励机制如今带来了一个问题：许多用户正在大规模创建新账户，反复套取奖励。在某些情况下，用户还会创建新账户，以逃避旧账户的封禁和暂停。大规模欺诈导致 OpenAI 损失了巨额收入，其成本随着服务器需求的增加而攀升。信任与安全团队的人数仍然不足二十人，而且其被动执法工作受到严重阻碍，因此该团队再次调遣人员，对付新的滥用媒介。

The burst of new products overwhelmed the trust and safety team anew. For a while, OpenAI had enticed users to join its API by giving them an initial twenty dollars’ worth of free usage credits. With the mega-popularity of ChatGPT also sparking a dramatic surge in API usage, this sign-up incentive now posed a problem: Many users were creating new accounts at scale to cash in repeatedly on the bonus. In some cases, users were also spinning up new accounts to evade bans and suspensions on their old ones. The mass fraud was leading OpenAI to lose huge amounts of revenue as costs climbed with its need for more and more servers. Still numbering fewer than twenty people and with its reactive enforcement efforts severely hampered, the trust and safety team redirected its personnel once again to whack-a-mole the new vector of abuse.

很快，持续不断的打击让威尔纳精疲力竭。几个月后，他和几名员工离开了公司。到那年年底，该团队解散，部分剩余成员被纳入一个更广泛的安全系统运营部门，由 OpenAI 资深研究员 Lilian Weng 领导。一些负责信任和安全事务的人士开始感到，Applied 和安全团队之间持续不断的冲突，以及他们对末日论的过分强调，在许多公司领导层中滋生了一种文化，即严重忽视任何“安全”问题，导致了一种环境这使得他们的职能在大多数科技公司中已经变得无能为力，在 OpenAI 中更是如此。

Soon enough, the constant whiplash would push Willner to severe burnout. Within months he and several of his staffers would depart the company. By the end of that year, the team would dissolve and some of its remaining members be folded under a broader safety systems operation, headed by a longtime OpenAI researcher Lilian Weng. Some of the trust and safety people would come to feel that the persistent clashing between Applied and the Safety clan, with their overemphasis on Doomerism, had cultivated a culture among many of the company leadership to heavily discount any kinds of “safety” concerns, leading to an environment that made their function, already disempowered at most tech companies, even more so at OpenAI.

事实上，每次新产品发布，冲突都会持续，包括围绕 GPT-4 的发布。尽管应用部门的许多人认为，推迟六个月发布该模型是极其谨慎的做法，但安全部门的一些人却认为，这仍然没有给他们足够的时间完成全面的测试和调整。

Indeed, with every new launch, the clashing continued, including over the release of GPT-4. While many in Applied felt the six-month delay in launching the model to be abundantly cautious, some in Safety felt it still hadn’t given them enough time to finish their comprehensive testing and alignment.

例如，即使 RLHF 齐心协力解决这个问题，该模型的高幻觉发生率仍然难以控制。2022 年 11 月，随着用户OpenAI 将 ChatGPT 视为搜索工具，引发了人们普遍猜测它可能取代谷歌，一份内部文件指出，OpenAI 的模型在对大约 30% 的所谓封闭域问题进行内部测试时出现了幻觉。

The model’s high rate of hallucinations, for example, had continued to prove particularly difficult to get under control, even with a concerted RLHF effort to address the problem. In November 2022, as users latched on to ChatGPT as if it were a search tool, spawning widespread speculation that it could unseat Google, an internal document noted that OpenAI’s model had hallucinated during an internal test on roughly 30 percent of so-called closed-domain questions.

封闭域问题是指最简单的问题类型：用户仅向模型询问他们提供的信息，例如，上传 PDF 文件并要求其提供摘要，或者提供要点并要求其重写以完成句子。这与开放域问题形成对比。开放域问题是指用户向模型询问不包含参考资料的问题，例如流行文化、古代史、高中生物，就像典型的搜索引擎一样。

Closed-domain questions are meant to be the easiest category of questions: when users ask the model only about the information they give it—for example, uploading a pdf and asking for a summary, or providing bullet points and asking for a rewrite to complete sentences. This is in contrast to open-domain questions, when a user asks the model a question without reference material—pop culture, ancient history, high school biology—the way you would a typical search engine.

与此同时，GPU 也成为 OpenAI 研究和扩张的制约因素，新研究、新产品或功能的发布都因芯片产能不足而一再被推迟或搁置。ChatGPT 爆红后，专注于半导体行业的行业通讯SemiAnalysis估计，该公司仅在计算成本上每天就花费约 70 万美元。在高管们重新分配研究部门的芯片后，应用材料公司承诺在某个日期前归还这些芯片。然而，日期已到，应用材料公司却未能归还。随着用户数量的持续快速增长，该部门需要更多的芯片，而不是更少。

Meanwhile, GPUs became an ever-present constraint on OpenAI’s research and expansion. New research and product or feature launches had to be repeatedly delayed or shelved due to a lack of chip capacity. After ChatGPT went viral, SemiAnalysis, a trade newsletter focused on the semiconductor industry, estimated that the company was spending some $700,000 a day on compute costs alone. After executives reallocated chips from the Research division, Applied made commitments to return them by a certain date. That date came and went, but Applied couldn’t return them. With the continued rapid growth in users, the division needed more chips, not fewer.

这种压力加速了 OpenAI 对更高效模型的研究。在提升公司计算效率的过程中，研究部门找到了一种开发新模型的方法。基于Transformer的模型，其服务用户的成本更低。他们使用这种方法（他们将其命名为DUST），并为生成的模型分配了代号，以呼应沙漠主题。第一个模型是GPT-3.5的优化版本，他们称之为Sahara，并于2023年2月以GPT-3.5 Turbo的公开名称发布。另一个模型他们称之为Gobi，这将是其一个文本和图像模型的优化版本。

The pressure accelerated OpenAI’s research into more-efficient models. During its work to improve the company’s compute efficiency, the Research division had figured out a new method for developing Transformer-based models that were cheaper to serve to users. As they used that method, which they named DUST, they assigned code names to the resulting models to follow the desert-based theme. The first one, an optimized version of GPT-3.5, they called Sahara, which they released in February 2023 under the public name GPT-3.5 Turbo. Another they called Gobi, which would be an optimized version of one of its text-and-image models.

第三个项目旨在作为 GPT-4 的优化版本，他们将其命名为 Arrakis，这是科幻史诗《沙丘》中的沙漠星球。但经过数月的努力，团队仍在努力提高 Arrakis 的效率，同时保持相同的性能。该项目耗费了大量计算资源。不久之后，领导层放弃了该项目，以便将 GPU 释放给其他项目。

A third one, meant to be an optimized version of GPT-4, they called Arrakis, the desert planet from the science fiction epic Dune. But after months of work, the team was still struggling to make Arrakis more efficient while maintaining the same performance. The project ate up significant computational resources. Shortly thereafter, leadership scrapped it to free up GPUs for other projects.

—

—

当微软担心 OpenAI 是否会终止合作关系时，OpenAI 也感到自己的弱点：如果这家初创公司不努力取悦其合作伙伴，微软是否会停止合作。在这方面，Arrakis 感觉像是一个特别的挫折。为了给这家巨头留下深刻印象，OpenAI 修改了路线图，优先交付该模型，而不是其自身更具战略意义的项目，包括将 GPT-4 应用于搜索引擎产品的尝试。然而，这一尝试的失败却让一些微软高管感到失望。

As Microsoft worried about whether OpenAI could just leave the relationship, OpenAI felt its own vulnerabilities about whether Microsoft would stop cooperating if the startup didn’t work hard to please its partner. Arrakis felt like a particular setback in this regard. In the hopes of impressing the giant, OpenAI had reworked its road map to prioritize delivering the model over its own more strategically aligned projects, including an effort to apply GPT-4 to a search engine product. Instead, the failed effort left some senior Microsoft executives disappointed.

还有一个尴尬的新现实：OpenAI 和微软开始争夺合同。Codex 和 DALL-E 2 说服 OpenAI 保留了直接向用户交付其技术的控制权。ChatGPT 和 GPT-4 表明 OpenAI 也能自己赚钱。这意味着 OpenAI 直接向客户推销它交给微软的技术，而微软当时也向同样的客户推销这些技术。

There was also a new awkward reality: OpenAI and Microsoft were beginning to compete for contracts. Codex and DALL-E 2 had convinced OpenAI to retain control of delivering its technologies directly to users. ChatGPT and GPT-4 were showing that OpenAI could also make its own money. That meant directly pitching to customers the very same technology that it was handing over to Microsoft, which was then pitching to the exact same customers.

交接这项技术本身就充满挑战。随着 OpenAI 发布计划的加快，微软的发布计划也随之加快。但微软的实力远超 OpenAI，导致 OpenAI 的一位员工可能会被微软不同部门的数十位同事询问各种技术或后勤细节问题。随着每一款新产品的推出，OpenAI 员工越来越感到沮丧和不知所措，因为他们既要支持微软的发布版本，又要专注于自己的路线图。

Handing off the technology had its own challenges. As OpenAI’s release schedule picked up, so did Microsoft’s. But Microsoft completely dwarfed OpenAI, leading to a dynamic where a single OpenAI employee could get pinged by dozens of Microsoft counterparts across various departments with all sorts of questions about technical or logistical details with every new product. It was growing increasingly frustrating and overwhelming for OpenAI staff to support Microsoft releases while focusing on their own road map.

缓和双方关系的大部分工作都落在了穆拉蒂身上。穆拉蒂力求与斯科特和其他微软高管密切合作，协调产品发布时间，制定 OpenAI 和微软如何打造差异化产品的战略，并寻找两家公司更高效的合作方式。2023 年夏天，为了减轻沟通负担，一支微软工程师团队开始嵌入 OpenAI 内部，获得所有资源的完全访问权限，以简化技术转移。

Much of the smoothing over of the relationship was left to Murati. Murati sought to work closely with Scott and other Microsoft executives on coordinating the timing of product releases, strategizing how OpenAI and Microsoft would differentiate their offerings and finding more productive ways for the two organizations to work together. In the summer of 2023, in an attempt to cut back the communication burden, a team of Microsoft engineers began embedding inside OpenAI with full access to everything to streamline transfers of technology.

随着更深层次的整合，奥特曼和纳德拉都比以往任何时候都更加投入，特别是在计算资源的管理方面，他们做出了艰难的决定，如何重新分配芯片和资金，为 OpenAI 计算能力极强的运营提供更多的芯片。纳德拉告诉《纽约时报》，OpenAI 的需求增长得如此之快、如此之高，以至于奥特曼开始每天给他打电话说：“我需要更多，我需要更多，我需要更多。”

With the deeper integration, both Altman and Nadella were growing more involved than ever before, especially with the management of compute resources, making tough calls on how to redistribute chips and money for yet more chips to OpenAI’s ever-compute-hungry operations. Nadella would tell The New York Times that OpenAI’s demands would grow so fast and so high that Altman would start calling him every day saying, “I need more, I need more, I need more.”

OpenAI 不仅需要更多的数据中心来服务 ChatGPT，它还需要更强大的超级计算机来训练其未来几代模型。为了满足这一日益增长的迫切需求，两家公司正在草拟一个前所未有的新项目，OpenAI 称之为“星际之门”，微软称之为“水星”：一台超级计算机，仅建造成本就高达约 1000 亿美元。人工智能帝国正回归与旧帝国完全相同的扩张模式：为了推动增长，它需要更多的物质资源，更重要的是，需要更多的土地。

OpenAI didn’t just need more data centers to serve ChatGPT. It still needed far-more-powerful supercomputers to train its future generations of models. To fulfill that aggressive and escalating demand, the two companies were sketching out a new unprecedented project called Stargate to OpenAI and Mercury to Microsoft: a single supercomputer that, for its construction alone, would cost an estimated $100 billion. The empire of AI was returning to the exact same form of expansion as the empires of old: To fuel its growth, it needed more material resources and, crucially, more land.

第十二章

Chapter 12

掠夺的地球

Plundered Earth

我在智利圣地亚哥，一场大雨过后，雾霾散去，安第斯山脉的壮丽景色映入眼帘。安第斯山脉蜿蜒穿过这个狭长的国家，从南端的巴塔哥尼亚向北延伸超过2600英里（相当于迈阿密到波士顿长度的两倍），一直延伸到智利的北部边境。在这个国家的这片土地上，首都的城市景观变成了一望无际的沙漠，除了南极洲的部分地区外，这里是地球上最干旱的地方。在赤裸的阳光下，群山变得更加清晰，色彩更加鲜艳。

In Santiago, Chile, on days after a good rain, the smog washes away and reveals a stunning view of the Andes mountains. The Andes run all the way up and down this thin sliver of a country, from Patagonia at its southern tip over 2,600 miles north—twice the length of Miami to Boston—to Chile’s upper border. In this part of the country, the urban landscapes of the capital turn into an endless expanse of desert, which, save parts of Antarctica, is the driest place on earth. The mountains come into sharper focus, their colors more vibrant under the naked sun.

在智利正式建国之前，这片名为阿塔卡马沙漠的土地曾是许多原住民的家园。在其他人眼中，这片土地或许是一片荒芜的景象，而原住民却将这片沙漠变成了家园，利用地底深处的水和矿物质种植庄稼、饲养牲畜，并举行祖先仪式。后来，西班牙人到来，将这片地区划分成一个个有边界的行政区划。直到今天土著长老们仍在口述历史中警示，压迫日趋残酷，以至于西班牙人割掉了所有敢于继续使用母语的人的舌头。从那时起，帝国就与世界其他国家建立了联系：它提供原始资源——土地、水、能源、矿产——以强化其他国家的政治和经济议程。

Before Chile was Chile, the Atacama Desert, as it is named, was home to many Indigenous groups. Where others may have seen a punishing barren landscape, they coaxed the desert into a home, tapping the water and minerals deep under the earth to grow crops, raise livestock, and perform ancestral rituals. Then the Spanish arrived. They cut up the region into administrative units with borders. To this day Indigenous elders still warn in oral histories of a repression that grew so violent the Spanish cut off the tongues of anyone who dared to continue speaking their native language. From there, the empire established the country’s relationship with the rest of the world: It would provide raw resources—land, water, energy, minerals—to strengthen the political and economic agendas of other nations.

如今，智利近60%的出口产品是矿产，主要产自阿塔卡马沙漠，其中最主要的是铜，一种用于各种电子产品的高导电性金属，以及近期出现的锂，它是锂离子电池的关键成分。这些以及其他资源出口推动着智利的经济。在圣地亚哥，每个人都认识一些按照采矿业节奏生活的人：在工作“轮班”期间，他们住在北部；休息日则回到首都。

Today nearly 60 percent of Chile’s exports are minerals, primarily found in the Atacama Desert, chiefly copper, a highly conductive metal used in all kinds of electronics, and more recently lithium, the essential ingredient for lithium-ion batteries. Those and other resource exports drive the country’s economy. In Santiago everyone knows someone who lives by the rhythms of the mining industry: During their work “shifts” they live in the north; during their days off, they come back to the capital.

该国一直在努力打造其他产业作为其经济引擎。西班牙帝国灭亡很久之后，美国在确保这一发展轨迹方面发挥了关键作用。20世纪50年代和60年代，发展经济学在智利和乌拉圭扎根，主张强有力的政府监管，并将工业化作为发展中经济体走向成熟的途径。与此同时，那些从智利矿产中获利数十亿美元的美国跨国公司开始对日益增长的州税和限制感到不满。美国政府随后着手修改智利的经济政策，使其更有利于美国商业利益，并于1956年启动了一项名为“智利计划”的项目，在美国经济学家米尔顿·弗里德曼的指导下，在芝加哥大学培养一百名智利学生。

The country has struggled to build any other industry to serve as its economic engine. Long after the Spanish empire ended, the US infamously played a key role in ensuring this trajectory. In the 1950s and ’60s, as developmental economics took root in Chile and Uruguay, favoring strong government regulation and an inward focus on industrialization as the path to maturing a developing economy, American multinationals who had made billions from their holdings in Chilean mines began to chafe against the growing state taxes and restrictions. The US government subsequently embarked on a quest to refashion Chile’s economic policies to be more favorable to American business interests, launching a program in 1956 called “the Chile Project” to educate a hundred Chilean students at the University of Chicago under the intellectual tutelage of American economist Milton Friedman.

弗里德曼是经济学界的一位杰出人物，并于1976年获得诺贝尔奖。他的思想可以用他1970年在《纽约时报》上发表的那篇颇具影响力的专栏文章的标题来概括：“企业的社会责任是增加利润。”弗里德曼代表了发展经济学所不具备的一切：零政府监管、为以利润为导向的公司提供不受约束的自由、以及一条以面向外部（例如通过自由出口）为特征的发展中国家经济成熟之路。正如娜奥米·克莱因在其2007年出版的国际畅销书《震撼主义》中详述的那样，智利项目并非教育，而是灌输。在芝加哥大学，智利学生——以及后来来自其他拉丁美洲国家的学生——被明确教导要批判本国的经济政策以及拉丁美洲发展主义的致命缺陷。

Friedman was a towering figure in economics who would go on to receive a Nobel Prize in 1976 and whose ideas could best be summed up by the title of his influential 1970 op-ed in The New York Times: “The Social Responsibility of Business Is to Increase Its Profits.” Friedman stood for everything that developmental economics did not: zero government regulation, unfettered freedom for profit-driven companies, a path to the economic maturation of developing countries defined by facing outward, such as through liberal exports. As Naomi Klein details in her 2007 international bestseller The Shock Doctrine, the Chile Project was not education but indoctrination. At the University of Chicago, Chilean students—and later students from other countries in Latin America—were explicitly taught to critique their country’s economic policies and the fatal flaws of Latin American developmentalism.

每一批被称为“芝加哥男孩”的毕业生返回弗里德曼的新自由主义思想在圣地亚哥逐渐渗透到智利的知识精英阶层，最终成为统治意识形态的一部分。1973年，智利左翼民选总统被其军事将领奥古斯托·皮诺切特通过政变推翻。部分是由美国中央情报局煽动的。这场政变开启了皮诺切特近二十年的残酷独裁统治，并推行了新的自由主义经济议程：独裁政权任命“芝加哥男孩”来制定其经济政策。

As each batch of graduates, known as “the Chicago Boys,” returned to Santiago, Friedman’s neoliberal ideas percolated through Chile’s intellectual elite, until they became part of ruling ideology. In 1973, Chile’s left-wing, democratically elected president was overthrown by his military general Augusto Pinochet in a coup d’état under conditions fomented in part by the CIA. The coup became the start of Pinochet’s nearly two decades of brutal dictatorship and a new neoliberal economic agenda: the dictatorship appointed the Chicago Boys to write its economic policies.

在皮诺切特的统治下，智利几乎将一切都私有化——教育、医疗、养老金制度，甚至水资源。这一战略带来了经济增长，但也加剧了惊人的不平等。智利是当今世界上最不平等的国家之一，近四分之一的国民收入集中在1%的少数权贵家族手中。智利从未实现过真正的工业化，经济依然受制于采掘业，这使得它与更强大的地缘政治强国息息相关。

Under Pinochet’s rule, Chile privatized nearly everything—education, health care, the pension system, even water. The strategy produced economic growth; it also fueled stunning inequality. Chile is among the most unequal countries in the world today, with nearly a quarter of the country’s income concentrated among a few powerful families in the 1 percent. Having never meaningfully industrialized, it also remains tethered to the extraction economy that makes it relevant to higher geopolitical powers.

因此，随着人工智能热潮的到来，智利将成为新一轮资源采掘业的发源地，成为该行业对原材料无尽渴求的供应国。这些原材料不仅来自智利北部的铜和锂，还为圣地亚哥大都会区日益增多的数据中心提供土地、水和能源资源。2024年5月，该国政府自豪地宣布，未来几年，该国将在现有的 22 个数据中心基础上新建 28 个数据中心，并吸引 26 亿美元的外国投资。

And so, as the AI boom arrived, Chile would become ground zero for a new scale of extractivism, as the supplier of the industry’s insatiable appetite for raw resources, not just its copper and lithium in the north but also its land, water, and energy resources for a growing crop of data centers in the Santiago metropolitan region. In May 2024, the government proudly announced that the country would welcome twenty-eight new data centers, on top of its existing twenty-two, over the coming years, bringing in $2.6 billion of foreign investment.

尽管智利政府坚称其作为技术发展资源提供者的角色代表着国家的进步，但智利也已成为全球范围内对这一论调最激烈抵制的地区之一。全国各地的社区正在激烈地反抗剥夺他们的土地、水资源和其他资源，以服务于那些既不涵盖他们、也不利于他们的“北半球愿景”。通过街头抗议和法庭斗争，他们的努力阻碍了公司项目，并引起了政府的关注。他们的行动也激励了其他国家的人民团结起来。

While the government’s stance that its role as a resource provider to technology development represents progress for the nation, Chile has also become home to some of the fiercest resistance globally against this narrative. Communities across the country are vehemently fighting against the dispossession of their land, water, and other resources in service of Global North visions that do not include or benefit them. Through street protests and courtroom battles, their efforts have stalled company projects and caught the government’s attention. They have also inspired people in other countries to rise up in solidarity.

圣地亚哥天主教大学教授、智利人工智能未来研究智库主任马丁·蒂罗尼·罗多《情报研究》以跨学科和拉丁美洲的视角研究人工智能，它总结了我在全国各地走访这些社群时反复听到的情绪。他表示，这些运动提出的核心问题是，如何设想一条不以开采为根基的人工智能发展新路径。如果我们按照以前的方式开发这项技术，我们将会毁灭地球。”

Martín Tironi Rodó, a professor at Catholic University in Santiago and director of the Chilean research think tank Futures of Artificial Intelligence Research, which studies AI through an interdisciplinary and Latin American lens, summarizes the sentiment that I heard repeatedly from these communities as I traveled up and down the country to meet them. The central question these movements are asking is how to imagine a different path for AI development not rooted in extraction, he says. “If we are going to develop this technology in the same way that we used to, we are going to devastate the earth.”

—

—

“数字”技术并非仅仅存在于数字层面。“云”并非如其名称所暗示的那样虚无缥缈。训练和提供人工智能模型需要实体的物理数据中心。而训练和运行 OpenAI 开创的各类生成式人工智能模型，则需要比以往任何时候都更多、更大的数据中心。

“Digital” technologies do not just exist digitally. The “cloud” does not in fact take the ethereal form its name invokes. To train and serve up AI models requires tangible, physical data centers. And to train and run the kinds of generative AI models that OpenAI pioneered requires more and larger data centers than ever before.

在人工智能出现之前，数据中心就已经在不断扩张。它们曾经规模很小，分布很广，甚至可以藏在城市环境中，比如藏在后台办公室机柜里的几架电脑，或者在一栋改造过的大楼里几十个机架。但在本世纪初，科技巨头们开始朝着不同的方向发展，将所有计算基础设施整合到农村社区的大型服务器仓库中。数据中心的世界开始分裂：一边是超大规模数据中心，另一边是其他所有数据中心。四大超大规模企业——谷歌、微软、亚马逊和 Meta——现在每年建设数据中心所花的钱比几乎所有其他相对不知名的开发商（如 Equinix 和 Digital Realty）的总和还要多。

Before AI, data centers were already growing and sprawling. They were once small and distributed enough to be tucked away in urban environments, a few shelves of computers hidden in a back-office closet or a few dozen racks in a repurposed building. In the aughts, tech giants began trending in a different direction, consolidating all of their computing infrastructure into massive warehouses of servers in rural communities. The data center world became divided: There were the hyperscalers and there was everyone else. The four largest hyperscalers—Google, Microsoft, Amazon, Meta—now spend more money building data centers each year than almost all the others, relatively unknown developers like Equinix and Digital Realty, combined.

如果你从未见过超大规模数据中心，很难想象它是什么样子。加拿大皇后大学副教授梅尔·霍根（Mél Hogan）研究人工智能、基础设施和环境，大约十年前，她开始撰写关于超大规模数据中心的文章时，曾用足球场来形容它们。“现在足球场的规模甚至都无法达到人们想象中所需的规模，”她说。超大规模数据中心运营商将他们的数据中心称为“校园”——大片土地，堪比常春藤盟校，几栋巨大的建筑里密密麻麻地摆满了一排排的计算机机架。这些计算机散发出一种热量高得离谱，就像一台正在运转的笔记本电脑，温度翻了百万倍。为了防止服务器过热，这些建筑还配备了大型冷却系统——大型风扇、空调，或者通过蒸发水来冷却服务器的系统。所有设备共同产生了嗡嗡声、呼呼声和噼啪声的刺耳噪音，尤其是在欠发达地区，这些噪音可以在数英里外、一天 24 小时听到，形成了一种持续不断、令人身体扭曲的噪音污染源。

It’s difficult to imagine what a hyperscale data center looks like if you’ve never seen one. Mél Hogan, an associate professor at Queen’s University in Canada who studies AI, infrastructure, and the environment, used to use football fields to describe them when she began to write about them roughly a decade ago. “Now football fields don’t even come close to the imaginaries of the required size,” she says. Hyperscalers call their data centers “campuses”—large tracts of land that rival the largest Ivy League universities, with several massive buildings densely packed with racks on racks of computers. Those computers emanate an unseemly amount of heat, like a laboring laptop a million times over. To keep them from overheating, the buildings also have massive cooling systems—large fans, air conditioners, or systems that evaporate water to cool down the servers. The equipment all together creates a cacophony of humming, whirring, and crackling that can—especially in underdeveloped communities—be heard for miles, twenty-four hours a day, creating a relentless and body-warping source of noise pollution.

现在，开发人员使用了一个新词来区分后ChatGPT AI时代即将出现的规模：巨型校园（megacampus）。这个词不仅指土地面积，还指运行这些校园所需的大量能源。一架 GPU 的功耗是一架其他计算机芯片的三倍。不仅训练生成式 AI 模型的成本高昂，为这些模型提供服务的成本也同样高昂：据国际能源署估计，每次 ChatGPT 查询所需的电量平均比谷歌的典型搜索多十倍。直到最近，最大的数据中心的设计功率都约为 150 兆瓦，这意味着它们每年的能耗相当于接近122,000个美国家庭。开发商和公用事业公司目前正在为人工智能超级园区做准备，这些园区可能很快需要1,000至2,000兆瓦的电力。一座核电站每年消耗的能源相当于一个半到三个半旧金山的能源。

Now developers use a new word to distinguish the scale of what’s coming in the post-ChatGPT AI era: megacampus. The word refers not just to the land area but to the sheer amount of energy that will be required to run them. A rack of GPUs consumes three times more power than a rack of other computer chips. And it’s not just the training of the generative AI models that is costly, it is also serving them: According to the International Energy Agency, each ChatGPT query is estimated to need on average about ten times more electricity than a typical search on Google. Until recently, the largest data centers were designed to be around 150-megawatt facilities, meaning they could consume as much energy annually as close to 122,000 American households. Developers and utility companies are now preparing for AI megacampuses that could soon require 1,000 to 2,000 megawatts of power. A single one could use as much energy per year as around one and a half to three and a half San Franciscos.

地球上很少有地方能够生产并输送如此大量的能源到任何单一地点。开发商正在与世界各地的公用事业公司合作，建设更多发电厂，扩大能源选择范围。在美国能源需求过去十年停滞不前之后，高盛的一项分析称，数据中心的突然涌现将推动“一代人以来从未见过的电力增长”。公用事业公司目前正在推迟天然气和燃煤电厂的退役以及向可再生能源的过渡；微软重启了位于宾夕法尼亚州米德尔顿附近的三哩岛核电站，该核电站在 20 世纪 70 年代末发生过部分核熔毁，这是美国历史上最严重的商业核事故。到 2030 年，按照目前的增长速度，数据中心预计将占用该国 8% 的而 2022 年这一比例为 3%；全球人工智能计算所消耗的能源可能比全球第三大电力消费国印度还要多。

Few places on the planet exist that can produce and deliver that much energy to any single location. Developers are working with utility companies around the world to build more power plants and expand the roster of options. After the last decade of flatlined energy demand in the US, a Goldman Sachs analysis described the sudden new wave of data centers as driving “the kind of electricity growth that hasn’t been seen in a generation.” Utility companies are now delaying the retirement of gas and coal plants and the transition to renewable energy; Microsoft restarted Three Mile Island, a nuclear plant near Middletown, Pennsylvania, that had a partial nuclear meltdown in the late 1970s, the worst commercial nuclear accident in US history. By 2030, at the current pace of growth, data centers are projected to use 8 percent of the country’s power, compared with 3 percent in 2022; AI computing globally could use more energy than all of India, the world’s third-largest electricity consumer.

这种规模——超大规模——已经造成了惊人的环境后果。然而，就在同一时刻，企业对这种影响的掩盖也达到了新的高度。自从 Emma Strubell 发表论文和 Gebru 在《随机鹦鹉》中被引用以来，科技巨头们隐藏了更多模型的技术细节，使得估算和追踪它们的碳足迹变得极其困难。与此同时，这些公司用强有力的反叙事来加强对公众和政策制定者的影响力：数据中心将变得非常高效，它们的影响将不再是问题；生成式人工智能将开启新的气候创新；AGI 将一劳永逸地解决气候变化问题。

This scale—the mega-hyperscale—has created startling environmental consequences. And yet, in the very same moment, corporate obfuscation of that impact has reached new heights. Since Emma Strubell’s paper and Gebru’s citation in “Stochastic Parrots,” tech giants have hidden away even more of their models’ technical details, making it exceedingly hard to estimate and track their carbon footprints. At the same time, those companies have amped up their public and policymaker influence campaigns with powerful counternarratives: Data centers will grow so efficient, their impact will stop being a problem; generative AI will unlock new climate innovation; AGI will solve climate change once and for all.

开源人工智能公司 Hugging Face 的研究科学家兼气候负责人 Sasha Luccioni 表示，虽然最后一种说法无法证实，但前两种说法极具误导性。第二种说法尤其有害：正如非营利组织“气候变化人工智能”（Climate Change AI）所列举的那样，确实有很多人工智能技术可以加速可持续发展，但它们很少是生成性人工智能技术。“应对气候变化需要的是监督学习模型、异常检测模型，甚至是统计时间序列模型，”该倡议的创始成员之一卢乔尼说道。所有这些模型都是前几代人工智能技术——主要是机器学习工具——体积小巧、节能，在某些情况下甚至可以在功能强大的笔记本电脑上运行。“生成性人工智能的能源和碳足迹非常不成比例，对环境的积极影响却微乎其微，”她补充道。

While the last claim is impossible to prove, the first two are highly misleading, says Sasha Luccioni, a research scientist and climate lead at open-source AI firm Hugging Face. The second is especially pernicious: There are indeed many AI technologies, as cataloged by the initiative turned nonprofit Climate Change AI, that can accelerate sustainability, but rarely are they ever generative AI technologies. “What you need for climate are supervised learning models or anomaly detection models or even statistical time series models,” says Luccioni, who is also a founding member of the initiative. All of these models are previous generations of AI technologies—primarily machine learning tools—that are small and energy efficient, and in some cases could even run on a powerful laptop. “Generative AI has a very disproportionate energy and carbon footprint with very little in terms of positive stuff for the environment,” she adds.

卢乔尼说，她过去在封闭公司里的合作者不再获得雇主的批准与她合作撰写有关人工智能环境影响的论文。相反，她与外部合作者和像斯特鲁贝尔这样的学者合作，她的研究最初给了她灵感。在一篇论文中，他们与 Hugging Face 机器学习和社会负责人 Yacine Jernite 合作，测量了运行开源生成式人工智能模型的碳足迹，作为封闭式公司正在构建的模型的代表。他们发现生产一千件生成模型生成的文本平均所消耗的能量相当于为标准智能手机充电近四次所需的能量。生成一千张图片平均所消耗的能量相当于 242 次完整的智能手机充电；换句话说，每张人工智能生成的图片所消耗的能量足以为智能手机充电约 25%。Luccioni 和 Strubell 的论文是少数仍然提供生成人工智能模型背后碳排放量化指标的论文之一。这是一场持续的艰苦战斗。Luccioni 说，她曾联系过五百多位最近的机器学习论文的作者，要求提供有关他们模型训练的基本信息。“我几乎没有得到任何答复，”她说。“人们甚至没有回应，或者说这是机密信息。”

Luccioni says her past collaborators within closed-off companies no longer receive approval from their employers to cowrite papers with her about AI’s environmental impact. Instead, she has worked with external collaborators and academics like Strubell, whose research she was first inspired by. In one paper, together with Hugging Face machine learning and society lead Yacine Jernite, the two measured the carbon footprint of running open-source generative AI models as a proxy to what closed companies are building. They found that producing one thousand pieces of text from generative models used as much energy on average as what it would take to charge the standard smartphone nearly four times. Generating one thousand images used on average as much energy as 242 full smartphone charges; in other words, every AI-generated image could consume enough energy to charge a smartphone by roughly 25 percent. Luccioni’s and Strubell’s papers are among the few that still provide quantifiable measures of the carbon behind generative AI models. It’s a constant uphill battle. At one point, Luccioni says she reached out to over five hundred authors of the most recent machine learning papers to request basic information about their model training. “I barely got any answers,” she says. “People were just not even responding or saying that this is confidential information.”

尽管超大规模数据中心运营商在公开场合高调宣扬其计算基础设施的可持续性，但微软的高管们在内部承认，当数据中心需要全天候运行时，可再生能源的间歇性供应根本无法满足需求。不间断运行至关重要，以至于谷歌、亚马逊以及最近的微软现在都开始采用这种能源。将校园分成三部分建设，以便在任何设施发生故障时有备用设施。在佛罗里达州的飓风伊尔玛和德克萨斯州的飓风哈维期间，尽管数百万人断电，一些医院疏散病人，数十万户家庭和企业面临损坏和破坏，但这些地区的数据中心仍然继续运转——运行状况非常好，以至于一个设施的流离失所的员工家属在自然灾害期间都搬进了那里。

Even as hyperscalers have spoken loudly in public about the sustainability of their computing infrastructure, executives at Microsoft have admitted internally that the intermittent availability of renewable energy just doesn’t cut it when data centers need to operate 24/7. Nonstop operation is considered so crucial that Google, Amazon, and most recently Microsoft now build their campuses in threes to have a backup for the backup in case any facility goes down. During Hurricane Irma in Florida and Hurricane Harvey in Texas, even as millions of people lost power, some hospitals evacuated patients, and hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses faced damage and destruction, the data centers in those areas continued to hum along—so well that the displaced families of one facility’s employees moved into it for the duration of the natural disaster.

支持这些巨型园区所需的土地和能源只是数据中心扩张全球供应链中的两项投入。同样重要的还有制造硬件（包括计算机、电缆、电源线、电池、备用发电机）所需的大量矿物（包括铜和锂），以及冷却服务器通常所需的大量饮用水（没错，就是饮用水）。（水必须足够清洁，以避免管道堵塞和细菌滋生；饮用水符合这一标准。）据加州大学河滨分校研究人员估计，到 2027 年，激增的人工智能需求可能每年消耗全球 1.1 万亿至 1.7 万亿加仑的淡水，相当于全球水资源的一半英国每年的消费量。这些影响不会均匀地显现。另一项研究发现，在美国，五分之一的数据中心在生成性人工智能蓬勃发展之前就已开始从因干旱或其他因素而处于中度或高度压力的流域抽取这些水资源。而在智利等全球南方国家，往往是最脆弱的社区承受着这些加速开采经济的冲击。

The land and energy required to support these megacampuses are but two inputs in the global supply chain of data center expansion. So, too, is the extraordinary volume of minerals including copper and lithium needed to build the hardware—computers, cables, power lines, batteries, backup generators—and the extraordinary volume of potable—yes, potable—water often needed to cool the servers. (The water must be clean enough to avoid clogging pipes and bacterial growth; potable water meets that standard.) According to an estimate from researchers at the University of California, Riverside, surging AI demand could consume 1.1 trillion to 1.7 trillion gallons of fresh water globally a year by 2027, or half the water annually consumed in the UK. Those effects will not be felt evenly. Another study found that in the US, one-fifth of data centers were already drawing that water before the generative AI boom from moderately or highly stressed watersheds due to drought or other factors. And in Global South countries like Chile, it’s often the most vulnerable communities who have borne the brunt of these accelerating economies of extraction.

随着越来越多的社区发现数据中心影响着他们的生活，越来越多的人强烈反对数据中心不受约束的发展。作为回应，数据中心开发商采取了更加复杂的策略来维持正常业务：他们通过空壳公司秘密进入社区；他们向社区项目捐款以减轻阻力；他们向城市承诺其设施的可持续性，然后在项目破土动工、难以逆转后逐一收回承诺。在弗吉尼亚州的一个案例中，一群抗议几个大型数据中心的居民震惊地发现一封律师发给开发商的电子邮件，建议对他们进行监视。“我们需要在这个团伙里找到一两个内奸，”律师写道。

As more and more communities have watched data centers affect their lives, a growing number have pushed back vehemently against their unfettered development. In response, data center developers have grown more sophisticated with tactics to maintain business as usual: They’ve entered communities in secrecy under shell companies; they’ve donated to community programs to dampen resistance; they’ve made promises to cities about the sustainability of their facilities before walking them back one by one after projects have broken ground and are more difficult to reverse. In one case in Virginia, a group of residents protesting against several massive data centers was shocked to uncover an email from a lawyer to a developer suggesting to place them under surveillance. “We need a mole or 2 in this group,” the lawyer wrote.

—

—

从致力于扩展的那一刻起，OpenAI 就寻求确保前所未有的计算基础设施数量。”“在人工智能领域，谁拥有最大的计算机，谁就能获得最大的收益，”布罗克曼在 2019 年告诉我。因此，奥特曼与微软合作，制定了一项计划，旨在满足这家科技巨头对 OpenAI 日益增长的计算需求。两家公司将合作设计和交付数十台用于研究的超级计算机——这些数据中心需要配备英伟达芯片，以便在 OpenAI 的探索过程中训练各种人工智能模型。至关重要的是，微软还将构建一系列规模越来越大、性能越来越强大的超级计算机，用于训练 OpenAI 的每一代后续模型。

From the moment they committed to the idea of scaling, OpenAI sought to secure an unprecedented amount of computing infrastructure. “In AI, whoever has the biggest computer gets the most benefits,” Brockman told me in 2019. So with Microsoft, Altman developed a plan for how the tech giant would meet OpenAI’s exponentially growing hunger for compute. The two companies would work together to design and deliver dozens of supercomputers for research—data centers that would need to be equipped with Nvidia chips for training various AI models in the course of OpenAI’s explorations. Crucially, Microsoft would also build a series of ever-larger, ever-more-powerful supercomputers for training each subsequent generation of OpenAI’s models.

奥特曼开始将这一系列超级计算机称为“阶段”，并曾向员工展示一张幻灯片，说明每个阶段的规模。其中，计划中的最后一个阶段——第五阶段——规模比其他所有阶段都大得多。OpenAI 训练 GPT-3 的超级计算机就是第一阶段。该设施位于爱荷华州西得梅因市，配备了一万台 V100 计算机，微软于 2012 年首次入驻该市。据当时的市长称，该设施通过缴纳“巨额”税收与市政府官员搞好关系，帮助该市大幅改善了公共基础设施。十多年来，该公司还向当地社区项目投资了约 250 万美元，其中大部分是非营利组织。微软将第一阶段超级计算机命名为“奥德赛”（Odyssey）；OpenAI 将其命名为“猫头鹰”（Owl），这源于其早期制定的一项惯例：按动物字母顺序命名研究部门的每个计算集群。当所有 26 个字母用完后，它将改为按原子序数排序，以元素周期表命名。

Altman began referring to the series of supercomputers as “phases,” at one point showing employees a slide to illustrate the size of each phase, with Phase 5, the last one planned, breathtakingly larger than all the others. The supercomputer that OpenAI had trained GPT-3 on was Phase 1. Equipped with ten thousand V100s, the facility had been built in West Des Moines, Iowa, which Microsoft first entered in 2012. It had made nice with city officials through a “staggering” sum of tax payments, according to the then mayor, helping the city make major improvements to its public infrastructure. Over more than a decade, the company also invested some $2.5 million in local community programs, most of them nonprofits. Microsoft code-named the Phase 1 supercomputer Odyssey; OpenAI called it Owl, after a convention it had started early on of naming each of the Research division’s compute clusters alphabetically after animals. When it ran out of all twenty-six letters, it would switch to naming them after periodic elements, ordered by atomic number.

第二阶段也在爱荷华州进行，用于训练 GPT-4。它最初使用了 2021 年研究路线图中提到的 1.8 万台 A100 芯片，到模型训练结束时，数量最终增长到 2.5 万台左右。对微软来说，第二阶段就是忒勒马科斯（Telemachus），以希腊神话中奥德修斯之子的名字命名。对 OpenAI 来说，第二阶段就是渡鸦（Raven）。

Phase 2 was also in Iowa and used to train GPT-4. It had started with the eighteen thousand A100s referenced in the 2021 research road map and ultimately grew to around twenty-five thousand by the end of the model’s training process. To Microsoft, Phase 2 was Telemachus, named after the son of Odysseus in Greek mythology. To OpenAI, it was Raven.

第三阶段转移到亚利桑那州。凭借廉价的土地、优惠的税收优惠以及与加利福尼亚州的紧密联系，亚利桑那州迅速成为所有云服务提供商首选的数据中心开发中心。在与凤凰城郊外两座欠发达城市的政府精心培养良好关系后，微软于2018年和2019年购买了三块土地，并同样向各社区组织捐赠，以平息居民的反对意见。这些土地总面积近600英亩，相当于450多个足球场。（微软计划在2024年再扩大283英亩土地。）每块土地都将建设一个新的数据中心园区，与OpenAI一起为位于“美国西部3”云区域的Azure客户提供服务。

Phase 3 shifted to Arizona. With its cheap land, good tax breaks, and close proximity to California, Arizona had fast become a preferred hub for data center development among all of the cloud providers. After carefully cultivating favorable relationships with the governments of two underdeveloped cities right outside Phoenix, Microsoft had bought three tracts of land in 2018 and 2019 and similarly donated to various community organizations to quiet any objections from residents. The tracts had a combined land area of nearly 600 acres, or more than 450 football fields. (Microsoft would expand that area with another 283 acres in 2024.) Each tract would host a new data center campus that would serve Azure customers alongside OpenAI in the cloud region “West US 3.”

第三阶段——微软代号为“Inglewood”，OpenAI 代号为“Whale”——将耗资数十亿美元建造和安置数十万台 Nvidia H100（A100 之后的一代）用于训练 OpenAI 当时认为可能被称为 GPT-4.5 和 GPT-5 的模型。对于计划在威斯康星州进行的第四阶段，Altman 预计使用 Nvidia 最新的 B100（H100 之后的又一代）的成本将达到 100 亿美元。考虑到目前最昂贵的超大规模数据中心，这是一个惊人的数字。当时的预算在10亿到20亿美元之间徘徊。他并没有打算就此止步，而是随口提出了在第五阶段建造1000亿美元超级计算机的想法。在ChatGPT取得巨大成功后，Altman降低了预期。由于大量芯片被锁定用于为客户提供ChatGPT服务，微软难以快速采购芯片以跟上第三阶段的开发进度。Whale集群拆分为三个独立的集群——Beluga、Narwhal和Orca——计划在2024年某个时候完成建设。

Phase 3—code-named Inglewood at Microsoft and Whale at OpenAI—would cost several billion to build and house hundreds of thousands of Nvidia H100s, the generation after A100s, to train what OpenAI at the time believed it would likely brand as GPT-4.5 and GPT-5. For Phase 4, planned in Wisconsin, Altman expected costs to hit $10 billion using Nvidia’s latest B100s, yet another generation after H100s. That was a staggering amount, considering the most expensive hyperscale data centers then hovered around $1 to $2 billion. He didn’t plan to stop there, casually floating the idea of the $100 billion supercomputer for Phase 5. After the blowout success of ChatGPT, Altman tempered his expectations. With so many chips locked up in serving ChatGPT to customers, Microsoft was struggling to acquire chips fast enough to keep up with finishing Phase 3’s development. Whale split into three separate clusters—Beluga, Narwhal, and Orca—with plans to complete the build-out sometime in 2024.

微软或 OpenAI 内部甚至没有人知道第 5 阶段在技术上是否可行。据《The Information》后来报道，在微软和OpenAI的设计方案中，这座耗资1000亿美元的设施可能需要高达5000兆瓦的电力，几乎相当于整个纽约市的平均用电需求。虽然这项计划作为一项商业投资看起来并非最经济，但资金并非主要瓶颈，而是能源。“我们的土地和电力都快用完了，”OpenAI的一位员工说道。两家公司内部都明白，第五阶段只有通过一定程度的创新才能实现。要么微软和OpenAI需要将超级计算机拆分成多个园区，以分配能源需求，并研究如何在遥远的地点训练AI模型；要么，正如Altman有时喜欢说的那样，这个问题将随着未来核聚变技术的突破而自行解决。

No one within Microsoft or OpenAI even knew whether Phase 5 was technically possible. In Microsoft and OpenAI’s design plans, The Information later reported, the $100 billion facility could need as much as 5,000 megawatts, nearly matching the average power demands of all of New York City. While the plan didn’t seem the most financially sound as a business investment, money wasn’t the main bottleneck. It was energy. “We’re running out of land and power,” an OpenAI employee says. Within both companies, it was understood that Phase 5 would only become possible with some amount of innovation. Either Microsoft and OpenAI would need to split the supercomputer into multiple campuses to distribute the energy demands and figure out how to train an AI model across distant locations, or, as Altman sometimes liked to say, the problem would solve itself with a future breakthrough in nuclear fusion.

他有时会向 OpenAI 员工汇报 Helion Energy 的乐观情况。这家核聚变初创公司是他个人最大的一笔投资，微软已承诺在其目标发电量为 50 兆瓦的电厂投入运营后购买其电力。《华尔街日报》后来报道称，OpenAI 和 Helion 也正在洽谈达成协议，协议内容如下：奥特曼已回避。

At times he would give OpenAI employees optimistic updates about Helion Energy, the nuclear fusion startup that represented his largest personal investment and for which Microsoft had already committed to buying power from once a plant, with a target generation of 50 megawatts, was up and running. The Wall Street Journal would later report that OpenAI and Helion were also in talks to strike a deal, from which Altman had recused himself.

奥特曼和其他高管从未在全公司会议上提及数据中心对环境的影响。OpenAI 在爱荷华州训练 GPT-4 时，该州正经历两年的干旱。美联社后来报道称，在该模型训练的一个月内，微软的数据中心消耗了该地区约 1150 万加仑的水，占该地区水量的 6%。GPT-4 在那里进行了三个月的训练。（微软发言人表示该公司正致力于将用水效率在 2022 年基准基础上提高 40%，到 2030 年，其全球业务补充的水量将超过其消耗的水量，重点关注其业务所在地缺水地区。）

Altman and other executives never brought up the data centers’ environmental toll in company-wide meetings. As OpenAI trained GPT-4 in Iowa, the state was two years into a drought. The Associated Press later reported that during a single month of the model’s training, Microsoft’s data centers had consumed around 11.5 million gallons, or 6 percent, of the district’s water. GPT-4 had trained there for three months. (A Microsoft spokesperson said the company is working to increase its water efficiency by 40 percent above its 2022 baseline and to replenish more water than it consumes across its global operations by 2030, with a focus on the water-stressed regions where it works.)

亚利桑那州也面临着严重的水危机。2022年，当微软为第三阶段奠定基础时，《自然气候变化》杂志的一项研究发现，美国西南部正面临一千多年来最严重的干旱。这场干旱加上严重的管理不善，导致亚利桑那州和其他六个州赖以获取淡水的科罗拉多河水位降至危险的低位。如果不采取果断措施，这条河可能会断流。气候变化导致该地区气温持续创下新高，家家户户都开足了空调，而水资源短缺加剧了电力危机。该地区部分依赖胡佛大坝和水冷核电站的水力发电。换句话说，它需要水来生产更多能源。2023年，凤凰城都市区创下了多项高温纪录，同时也是高温死亡人数最多的一年，死亡人数比2022年至少激增了30%。超过六百人死亡。“亚利桑那州水资源部主任汤姆·布查茨克说：“所有的事情都在朝着充满挑战的方向发展。”

Arizona, too, faces a severe water crisis. In 2022, as Microsoft laid the groundwork for Phase 3, a study in Nature Climate Change found that the Southwestern US had been facing the worst drought it had seen in over a thousand years. That drought, combined with severe mismanagement, has drained the Colorado River, which Arizona and six other states rely on for fresh water, to dangerously low levels. Without drastic action, the river could cease to flow. The shortage compounds a power crisis, as climate change has slammed the region with relentless record-breaking temperatures and families have cranked up their air-conditioning. The region relies in part on hydropower from the Hoover Dam and water-cooled nuclear power plants. In other words, it needs water to produce more energy. In 2023, the Phoenix metro area hit multiple new heat records as well as the worst year for heat-related fatalities, which surged at least 30 percent from 2022 to over six hundred dead. “All things,” says Tom Buschatzke, the director of the Arizona Department of Water Resources, “are converging in a challenging direction.”

Altman 确实提到了他的不耐烦。2024 年 3 月，在沉睡了生成式人工智能竞赛的初期之后，Meta 随后推出了雄心勃勃的新计划，计划部署 35 万台 H100 芯片，作为更大规模基础设施建设的一部分，以支持其突然激增的生成式 AI 投资。这比 OpenAI 现有的 GPU 数量还要多。Altman 对此很不满意。他觉得微软行动太慢，这正在损害 OpenAI 的竞争优势。

What Altman did bring up was his impatience. In March 2024, after sleeping through the early years of the generative AI race, Meta would come out swinging with aggressive new plans to have 350,000 H100s up and running as part of an even larger infrastructure build-out to support its sudden burst of generative AI investments. This was more GPUs than OpenAI had at its disposal. Altman wasn’t happy. Microsoft was being too slow, he felt, and it was costing OpenAI its competitive advantage.

—

—

索尼娅·拉莫斯小时候目睹了一场影响她一生的事故。她出生于智利的一个矿工家庭，父亲在一家美国铜业公司工作，她和其他工人的孩子一起长大。1957年，丘基卡马塔矿井发生坍塌，造成数人死亡，数十人受伤。尽管她父亲幸免于难，她依然记得眼睁睁看着灾难的惨状在她身边蔓延：受灾家庭陷入赤贫，儿童因饥饿而日渐消瘦。四十年后，拉莫斯开始抗议采矿，成为智利最活跃、最直言不讳的原住民之一，揭露采矿活动对社会、文化和环境的破坏。她始终铭记着自己在这场悲剧中汲取的教训：采矿业是一个系统，如果任其发展，它将不惜一切代价追求利润。“工人根本不存在，”她说。没有一位受害者得到任何仪式或纪念；他们的家人也没有得到任何赔偿。“在那个地方，没有人性。”

When Sonia Ramos was a child, she witnessed an accident that would shape the rest of her life. She was born into a mining family in Chile. Her father worked for an American copper company; she grew up among the children of the other workers. In 1957, a part of the Chuquicamata mine collapsed, killing several people and injuring dozens more. Though her father was spared, she remembers watching the wretchedness of the aftermath unfold around her: affected families spiraling into abject poverty, children wasting away from hunger. Four decades later, as Ramos began to protest mining, becoming one of the most active and outspoken Indigenous voices in Chile shining a light on its social, cultural, and environmental destruction, she would remember the lessons she learned in the tragedy: The mining industry is a system, and that system, left to its own devices, will seek profit at any cost. “The worker doesn’t exist,” she says. None of the victims received any ceremony or commemoration; none of their families received compensation. “In that place, there is no humanity.”

智利是世界上最大的铜生产国，占全球供应量的四分之一。自铜矿开采以来，它不仅重塑了这片土地，也重塑了依赖铜矿的社会。有时，其影响是显而易见的：如今的丘基卡马塔是世界上最大的露天铜矿，就像是地球上一道巨大的伤口，经常被爆破加深。这些流离失所的岩石堆积在巍峨的山脉中，使它们所来自的洞穴显得更加宏伟壮观，它们正在慢慢掩埋这座因铜矿开采而遭到废弃的城镇的遗迹。采矿活动还耗尽了该地区的水资源来加工铜矿。一家外国跨国公司曾消耗了过多的水，导致附近盐滩（或称“萨拉” ）的整个盆地枯竭，破坏了其丰富的生态系统。

Chile is the world’s largest producer of copper, accounting for a quarter of the global supply. Since the beginning, copper mining has reshaped not just the land but the societies that rely on it. Sometimes the effects are visible: Chuquicamata today is the largest open-pit copper mine in the world, a gaping wound in the earth that explosives regularly deepen. That displaced rock, piled up in towering mountains that monumentalize the cavities they came from, is slowly burying the remains of a town that was abandoned after the copper mining began to swallow it. The mining has also drained the region of water to process the copper. At one point a foreign multinational corporation consumed so much water it depleted an entire basin in a nearby salt flat, or salar, destroying its rich ecosystem.

不太引人注意的是，采矿业在空气和水中留下了砷的痕迹，导致该国北部地区的癌症发病率上升；采矿业也改变了原住民的生活，并在不同社区之间制造了分裂。由于土地上水资源和矿产资源枯竭，阿塔卡梅尼奥斯人（这个名字将居住在该地区的所有原住民群体联系在一起）再也无法依靠种植作物或饲养牲畜维持生计。这种转变使他们的城镇陷入了极度贫困。犯罪率、抑郁症、酗酒和违法行为都随之上升。他们没有足够的食物、自来水、适当的医疗保健或教育资源，而他们从数十亿美元的利润中几乎没有得到任何回报。土地已为他人产生。相反，许多人被迫为占领他们领土的产业工作，并从其赞助的小诊所接受医疗服务。原住民群体之间曾经更加团结，如今却因日益减少的资源而争吵不休。

Less visible are the trails of arsenic that the industry leaves in the air and water, which has increased rates of cancer throughout the north of the country, and the ways mining has restructured Indigenous life and sowed divisions among different communities. With their lands depleted of water and minerals, the Atacameños, the name that ties together all of the distinct Indigenous groups who share this region, can no longer sustain themselves by growing their own crops or raising their own livestock. The shift has plunged their towns into deep poverty. Crime has risen along with depression, alcoholism, and delinquency. They don’t have enough food, running water, proper health care, or educational resources, having seen little benefit from the billions in profits that their land has generated for someone else. Instead, many are forced to work for the very industry that seized their territories and receive health care from the small clinics it sponsors. Where there was once greater unity among them, the Indigenous groups now squabble over diminishing resources.

锂是那里最近才发现的，20世纪60年代，一家美国公司在寻找铜矿开采所需的水源时偶然发现了锂。当该公司钻探到盐沼中时，发现地表下的油性盐水中漂浮着高浓度的锂，这开辟了新的开采前沿，并加速了更多生态系统的枯竭。如今智利的锂产量约占全球产量的三分之一，仅次于澳大利亚。这种锂主要产自阿塔卡马盐沼（Salar de Atacama），这是该国最大的盐沼。开采方法是将盐水泵入波光粼粼的碧绿池中，等待阳光蒸发，溶液结晶成锂和其他副产品。盐沼曾是成群的粉色火烈鸟的家园，阿塔卡马人视火烈鸟为精神上的兄弟。如今，火烈鸟已不复存在；佩恩社区一位土著领袖的小女儿只能通过祖先的故事和一只火烈鸟毛绒玩具来缅怀它们。

Lithium is a more recent discovery there, stumbled upon by an American company in the 1960s as it searched for the water it needed for copper mining. When it drilled into the salares, it found high concentrations of lithium floating in an oily brine beneath the surface, opening up a new front of extraction and accelerating the depletion of more ecosystems. Today Chile produces roughly a third of the world’s lithium, second only to Australia. The material is primarily extracted out of the Salar de Atacama, the largest salt flat in the country, by pumping its brine out into shimmering pools of turquoise and waiting for the sun to evaporate and crystallize the solution into lithium and other by-products. The salares were once home to flocks of pink flamingos, which the Atacameños consider their spiritual siblings. Now the flamingos are gone; the young daughter of one Indigenous leader in the Peine community has only her ancestors’ stories and a flamingo plushie by which to remember them.

多年来，阿塔卡梅尼奥人听到过许多为这种开采行为辩护的说法。2022年，随着欧盟出台能源转型新政策，锂需求飙升，智利乃至世界其他地区的企业和政界人士都高度赞扬该国采矿业在推动更美好未来方面发挥的重要作用。眼睁睁看着自己的土地和社区被拆散的原住民社区不禁问道：“谁的更美好未来？”当地人从来没有能力在经济和国际政治力量之外思考自己的命运，”居住在北部并研究其丰富生物多样性的微生物学家克里斯蒂娜·多拉多说。

Over the years, the Atacameños have heard many narratives used to justify all of this extraction. In 2022, as the European Union set new policies around the energy transition and the demand for lithium skyrocketed, both companies and politicians in Chile and the rest of the world lauded the importance of the country’s mining industry in propelling forward a better future. Indigenous communities watching their land and their communities get ripped apart asked: A better future for whom? “Local people never have the ability to think about their own destiny outside the forces of economics and international politics,” says Cristina Dorador, a microbiologist who lives in the north and studies its rich biodiversity.

现在，同样的叙述正在通过生成人工智能重新出现。加速铜和锂的开采以建造大型园区，以及建造发电厂和数千英里的输电线来支持这些园区，在硅谷看来，也带来了更好的以及更光明的未来。因此，阻止这种开采就等于阻止人类的根本进步。但原住民社区抵制的并非采矿。“我们的祖先是矿工，”拉莫斯说。他们最初发现了铜矿。她说，问题在于规模。

Now the same narratives are being recycled with generative AI. The accelerated copper and lithium extraction to build megacampuses—and to build the power plants and thousands more miles of power lines to support them—is, in Silicon Valley’s account, also ushering in a better and brighter future.
