To block that extraction is thus to block fundamental progress for humanity. But it is not the mining that Indigenous communities resist. “Our ancestors were miners,” says Ramos. They were the ones who discovered the copper in the first place. The problem, she says, is the scale.

这种规模吞噬了一切。它使智利北部和其余地区完全依赖于人工智能产业，阻碍了其他经济体的崛起。拉莫斯表示，它扼杀了智利——以及世界其他国家——设想在不掠夺自然资源的情况下实现不同发展路径的能力。这种规模不仅促成了大规模生成式人工智能模型的生产，也导致了针对原住民的种族主义刻板印象的延续，而原住民早已饱受该技术构建方式的困扰。在巴西，由智利一所大学联合举办的 2023 年艺术展展示了拉丁美洲丰富的土著文化的现实与 Midjourney 和 Stable Diffusion 对这些文化的悲惨描述之间的巨大鸿沟，这些文化将拉丁美洲描绘成原始的、技术无能的民族。

That scale has consumed everything. It has made the north and the rest of Chile completely dependent on the industry and not allowed for the emergence of other economies. It has choked off the country’s—and the rest of the world’s—ability to imagine different paths where development could exist without plundering natural resources, Ramos says. By enabling the production of massive generative AI models, that scale has also led to the perpetuation of racist stereotypes about the Indigenous peoples already suffering from how the technology was physically built. In Brazil, a 2023 art exhibition coproduced by a Chilean university showed the vast chasm between the reality of Latin America’s rich Indigenous cultures and the woefully bereft depictions of them spit out by Midjourney and Stable Diffusion as primitive, technologically inept peoples.

近年来，阿塔卡梅尼奥人发起了越来越多的反抗。他们在房屋上悬挂黑旗，谴责对他们土地和社区的剥削。他们组织抗议活动，封锁公司巴士和卡车前往矿场的必经之路。他们聘请律师，根据保护其文化和领土主权的国际法，维护其作为原住民的合法权利。由于企业和智利政府被迫邀请他们进行谈判，土著人的核心要求是政府需要对阿塔卡马沙漠生态系统的健康状况进行研究，并量化水资源流失和任何无法弥补的损害。

In recent years, the Atacameños have mounted more and more resistance. They fly black flags on their houses to denounce the exploitation of their lands and their community. They’ve organized protests to physically block the roads that company buses and trucks must take to get to the mines. They’ve contracted lawyers to assert their legal rights as Indigenous peoples under international law, which protects their cultural and territorial sovereignty. As companies and the Chilean government have been forced to invite them to negotiations, central to Indigenous demands are the need for the government to conduct research into the health of the Atacama Desert’s ecosystems and to quantify the water loss and any irreparable damage.

拉莫斯也拥有自己的基金会，她表示，该基金会致力于汇聚“祖传和非祖传的”资源，以促进和开展对阿塔卡马沙漠自然财富的科学研究。由于其独特的极端条件，这里孕育着许多其他地方所不具备的微生物群落，这些微生物群落可能用于药物或新能源。出于同样的原因，这片沙漠也几十年来，人们一直在研究火星气候的类似物。拉莫斯希望任何发现都能帮助证明保护她美丽家园的价值。她反对高速发展用于燃料开采的叙事，寻求促进治愈、可持续性和再生的全新发展理念。

Ramos, too, has her own foundation, bringing together “the ancestral and non-ancestral,” she says, to promote and conduct scientific research into the natural wealth that the Atacama Desert has to offer. Due to its uniquely extreme conditions, it is home to many microbial communities—potentially useful for medicines or new sources of energy—that don’t exist anywhere else. For the same reasons, the desert has also been studied for decades as an analogue to Mars’s climate. Ramos hopes that any discoveries will help prove the value of preserving her beautiful homeland. Against the narratives of high-speed progress used to fuel extraction, she searches for new conceptions of progress that promote healing, sustainability, and regeneration.

—

—

随着拉莫斯在北部地区的斗争持续进行，智利中部地区也上演着另一场争夺战，争夺的是政府对科技行业数据中心本身的接纳。超大规模数据中心运营商扩张的速度越快，超过了其典型运营区域的土地和电力供应，他们就越是积极地在全球新地区争夺这些资源。

As Ramos’s fight continues in the north, a different battle is waging in the heart of Chile, over the government’s embrace of the tech industry’s data centers themselves. The faster the hyperscalers have expanded, outpacing the supply of land and power in their typical regions of operation, the more aggressively they have pushed to lay claim to those resources in new territories globally.

仅微软一家就在 2024 财年投入了超过 550 亿美元，几乎占其报告收入的四分之一，以打造SemiAnalysis所描述的“这是人类有史以来规模最大的基础设施建设。”与此同时，谷歌在其 2024 年第三次季度收益电话会议上表示，计划在本财年将数据中心支出提高到 500 亿美元左右。Meta 表示，其可能会在本财年投资高达 400 亿美元用于数据中心和基础设施扩建，预计明年这一数字还会增加。

Microsoft alone spent more than $55 billion in fiscal year 2024, nearly a quarter of its reported revenue, to build what SemiAnalysis described as “the largest infrastructure buildout that humanity has ever seen.” Google, meanwhile, said in its third 2024 quarterly earnings call that it planned to crank up its data center expenditures to reach around $50 billion for the fiscal year. Meta said it would likely round out the fiscal year with up to $40 billion in data center and infrastructure expansions, which it estimated would rise the following year.

2024 年 6 月一个难得的雾蒙蒙的下午，亚历山德拉·阿兰西比亚 (Alexandra Arancibia) 驾车驶向位于圣地亚哥郊区的基利库拉市，她在那里居住并担任市议员，在她看来，这里是美国科技巨头和她的社区之间巨大权力差距的典型象征。距离圣地亚哥最美丽的街区不到三十分钟车程，这里遍布着欧式咖啡馆和素食餐厅，我们面前的道路因维护不善而破败不堪，当地黑手党控制的非法垃圾场里散落着成堆的垃圾。

On a rare misty afternoon in June 2024, Alexandra Arancibia directs our car in Quilicura, a municipality on the outskirts of Santiago where she lives and serves as a council member, to what she sees as the defining symbol of the yawning power differential between American tech giants and her community. Less than a thirty-minute drive away from Santiago’s most picturesque neighborhoods, packed with European-style cafés and vegan restaurants, the roads in front of us are crumbling from poor maintenance, mountains of trash strewn alongside in illegal dumps controlled by a local mafia.

我们经过一片埋葬已故宠物的墓地，停在一片看似废弃的草地上，草地上长满了灌木丛，零星几棵营养不良的树木从土壤中探出头来。大多数时候，这片土地都干涸得像阿塔卡马沙漠的一部分；今天的雨水把一切都变成了泥泞。在这片草地的中央，有一株紫色的标牌上用西班牙语写着“欢迎来到基利库拉城市森林”。据介绍，谷歌于2019年启动了这个项目，旨在回馈社区，感谢社区为其数据中心提供托管服务。标牌上还附有一张图表，详细阐述了这片“森林”的益处：左侧是基利库拉工业区的示意图，那里挤满了排放温室气体和空气污染的工厂；右侧是一片森林在一片名为“雾霾”（SMOG）的浓云倾泻而下的丰沛雨水下欣欣向荣的景象。

Past a graveyard dedicated to deceased pets, we pull up to what looks like an abandoned plot of grassland with tufts of shrubs and a scattered handful of nutrient-starved trees jutting out of the soil. Most days the land is so parched it looks like parts of the Atacama Desert; today the rain is turning everything into mud. In the middle of the plot, a purple sign announces in Spanish, “Welcome to the Quilicura Urban Forest,” a project, it explains, that Google began in 2019 to give back to the community for hosting its data center. The sign includes a diagram to elaborate on the “forest’s” benefits: on the left side is an illustration of Quilicura as an industrial zone, packed with factories producing greenhouse gases and air pollution; on the right is an illustration of the forest flourishing under the generous rain pouring out from a big cloud labeled “SMOG.”

谷歌在其网站和公关稿中大肆吹嘘这片森林。当我请求谷歌驻智利的发言人就其在智利的发展情况进行采访时，她却发给我一些精心制作的简报材料，随后还补充说，公司为每个新数据中心都制定了社区影响计划，以支持当地的教育、可持续发展、互联网接入和健康等项目；谷歌已经为基利库拉投资了超过 120 万美元。在她的材料中，关于森林的部分谈到了居民对绿地的使用。但实际上并没有居民。这个地方离任何公交线路都太远，周边地区也没有什么房屋。在这片面积不大的地块外，小到无法容纳谷歌的数据中心，十几只流浪狗四处游荡、吠叫，翻找垃圾。发言人表示，这片森林正在进行更新改造，以“提升社区体验”。

Google boasts about this forest on its website and in its PR releases. When I ask the company’s country spokesperson for an interview about Google’s development in Chile, she sends me instead some polished briefing materials, later adding that the company creates a community impact program for each new data center to support local projects such as in education, sustainability, internet access, and health; for Quilicura, Google has invested over $1.2 million. In her materials, the part about the forest talks about residents using the green space. There are no residents. The place is too far from any bus line, and there are no homes in the surrounding area to speak of. Outside the modest plot, too small to fit Google’s data center itself, a dozen stray dogs meander around, barking and rummaging through the trash. The spokesperson said the forest is being updated to “evolve the experience for the community.”

当我们看到这一幕时，阿兰西比亚苦笑着说：“你觉得自己身处硅谷吗？”

Arancibia smiles wryly as we take the scene in. “Do you feel like you’re in Silicon Valley?”

—

—

阿兰西比亚刚上大学就发现基利库拉是个垃圾堆满的地方。她每天上下学都要经过市区里一些她从未听说过的地方——那里垃圾堆积如山。她从未把基利库拉当成“家”——那只是她居住的地方，一个欠发达、不起眼的工薪阶层小镇，她小时候父母就搬到了那里。但看到基利库拉被当作垃圾场，她内心深处却燃起了想要让这片土地恢复昔日美丽的渴望。

Arancibia had just started college when she realized that Quilicura was a place where things were discarded. She was commuting each day to her university through parts of the municipality—piled high with refuse—that she hadn’t known existed. She had never thought of Quilicura as “home”—it was simply the place she lived, an underdeveloped and unremarkable working-class town that her parents moved to when she was little. But something about seeing it treated as a literal dump stirred within her a deep desire to revitalize the land to its former beauty.

就在二十年前，当阿兰西比亚还是个孩子的时候，基利库拉基本上还是一片乡村：连绵起伏的牧场和闪闪发光的湿地，拥有与阿塔卡马沙漠不同但同样丰富的生物多样性——鸟类、野兽、以及种类繁多的植物。后来，垃圾黑帮来了，允许圣地亚哥其他地方的任何人以一定价格将垃圾倾倒在基利库拉。一些垃圾场运营时间过长，杂草丛生，看起来像怪异的变形山坡，将周围的景观包围。接下来，包括啤酒公司和房地产开发商在内的各种行业开始侵占土地，并从湿地中抽取水源，供其使用。如今，在这个面积22平方英里的市镇里，只有零星散布的几处绿地，才能让人一窥基利库拉昔日的面貌。

Only two decades ago, when Arancibia was a child, Quilicura was mostly country: rolling pastures and glistening wetlands, home to a different yet just as rich biodiversity as the Atacama Desert—birds, beasts, and varieties of flora. Then the trash mafia arrived, allowing anyone from the rest of Santiago to dump their waste in Quilicura for a price. Some dumps have operated for so long that grass and weeds have grown over them, making them look like eerie deformed hillsides closing in on the landscape. Next came different industries, including beer companies and real estate developers, who siphoned off more land and extracted water from the wetlands for their purposes. Today only tiny, interspersed pockets of green in this twenty-two-square-mile municipality offer a window into what Quilicura once was.

在此背景下，谷歌于2012年来到基利库拉，建设其在拉丁美洲的首个数据中心。谷歌在其官网上自豪地宣称，这座于2015年1月投入运营的数据中心是拉丁美洲最高效、最环保的数据中心之一。当时，基利库拉无人关注这个项目；在圣地亚哥这个经济繁荣的中心，更没有人关注基利库拉。每天乘公交车上班途经该数据中心的居民，都以为它是一家生产啤酒或食品的工厂，为当地社区提供就业机会。

Against this backdrop Google came to Quilicura in 2012 to build its first data center in Latin America. On Google’s web page, the company proudly presents the data center, which became operational in January 2015, as one of the most efficient and environmentally friendly on the continent. At the time, no one in Quilicura paid attention to the project; certainly no one in the better-off epicenter of Santiago was paying attention to Quilicura. Neighborhood residents who passed by the data center every day on their bus route to work assumed that it was a factory producing beer or food and providing jobs to the local community.

与大多数数据中心一样，谷歌的数据中心在建成后并没有提供太多工作岗位。谷歌招聘网站上发布的2024年版机械技术员职位是为数不多的长期职位之一，但该职位仅以英文发布；招聘启事还声明，谷歌不会考虑以其他语言提交的简历。正如活动人士指出的那样，该数据中心也没有给当地社区带来太多其他好处。附近的公立学校仍然缺乏良好的互联网或供学生上网的设备。

Google’s data center—like most data centers—did not provide many jobs beyond its initial construction. A job posting from 2024 for a mechanical technician, one of the few long-term positions available, was advertised on Google’s job board only in English; the posting stated that Google wouldn’t consider résumés submitted in any other language. The data center—as activists point out—did not provide much other benefit to the local community either. Nearby, public schools still lack good internet or devices for students to access it.

该数据中心的落户标志着基利库拉和圣地亚哥其他地区成为硅谷实体扩张的理想之地。2019年，谷歌宣布将在圣地亚哥都市区建设其在拉丁美洲的第二个数据中心。不久之后，微软和亚马逊也宣布将进驻。智利政府迅速表示欢迎，将智利定位为拉丁美洲外国直接投资的安全稳定避风港，而拉丁美洲则因政府不可靠、社会和经济不平衡而声名狼藉。不稳定。2020年，政府又迈进了一步。智利宣布了一项建设海底电缆的项目，该电缆类似于数据高速公路，将通过距离圣地亚哥不远的智利中部海岸，将亚太地区直接连接到美洲。智利将成为全球数字基础设施枢纽。谷歌支持此次合作。

The data center’s arrival marked Quilicura and the rest of Santiago as a desirable destination for Silicon Valley’s physical expansion. In 2019, Google announced that it would build its second Latin American data center in the Santiago metropolitan area. Soon enough, Microsoft and Amazon announced that they were coming too. The Chilean government was quick to welcome them, positioning the country as a safe and stable haven for foreign direct investment in Latin America, which otherwise suffers a reputation for unreliable governments and social and economic instability. In 2020, the government went a step further. It announced a project to build a new underwater cable, akin to a data highway, for connecting the Asia Pacific straight to the Americas through Chile’s central coast, not far from Santiago. Chile would become a global hub for digital infrastructure. Google backed the partnership.

然而，2019年7月，当谷歌开始在智利办理第二个数据中心的手续时，一群当地居民却在关注。谷歌选择塞里略斯作为新址，这是圣地亚哥接壤的另一个工薪阶层城市。与基利库拉一样，塞里略斯长期以来一直被忽视和遗弃。从20世纪30年代到90年代，一家比利时公司旗下的水泥厂向该社区排放了致命剂量的石棉，导致一位智利历史学家称之为该国“最大的工业灭绝”。时至今日，居民的癌症死亡率仍然高于平均水平。但塞里略斯也有其特殊之处——在这个水资源私有化的国家，该市拥有全国唯一的公共供水服务，将当地地下水供应给邻近社区，并在紧急情况下供应给智利其他地区。

But in July 2019, as Google began the paperwork for its second data center in Chile, a group of residents was watching. The company had chosen Cerrillos for its new location, another working-class municipality bordering Santiago. Like Quilicura, Cerrillos has a long history of being overlooked and abandoned. From the 1930s to the 1990s, a cement factory that belonged to a Belgian company contaminated the community with lethal levels of asbestos, leading to what one Chilean historian called “the largest industrial genocide” in the country. To this day, residents still die from higher than average rates of cancer. But Cerrillos is also special—in a country where water is privatized, the municipality is home to the nation’s only public water service, which serves up the local groundwater to neighboring communities and, in emergency situations, to other parts of Chile.

这种独特的组合——被忽视的历史和珍贵的水源——为多个环境保护组织的蓬勃发展提供了沃土，这些组织习惯于充当监督者，并坚决防止其资源被开采。那年夏天，谷歌向智利环境机构提交了一份数据中心审批报告——这基本上是一个橡皮图章式的流程——水资源保护组织 MOSACAT 开始仔细审查这份长达 347 页的文件。文件深处，谷歌声称其数据中心计划每秒使用约 169 升淡饮用水来冷却服务器。换句话说，该数据中心一年的用水量可能是塞里洛斯全镇人口（约八万八千人）一年用水量的一千多倍。MOSACAT 认为这是不可接受的。该设施不仅直接从塞里洛斯的公共水源取水，而且还是在全国饮用水供应面临威胁的情况下这样做的。2019 年，与爱荷华州和亚利桑那州，智利已经陷入了一场灾难性、史无前例的特大旱灾，而且这场旱灾已经持续了九年。

This unique combination—a history of neglect and a precious water source—created fertile ground for the blossoming of several environmental activist groups who were used to being watchdogs and were fiercely protective against the extraction of their resources. That summer, as Google filed a report with Chile’s environmental agency for approval of its data center—a largely rubber stamp process—MOSACAT, a water activist group, began combing through all 347 pages of the filing. Buried in its depths, Google said that its data center planned to use an estimated 169 liters of fresh drinking water per second to cool its servers. In other words, the data center could use more than one thousand times the amount of water consumed by the entire population of Cerrillos, roughly eighty-eight thousand residents, over the course of a year. MOSACAT found this unacceptable. Not only would the facility be taking that water directly from Cerrillos’s public water source, it would do so at a time when the nation’s entire drinking water supply was under threat. In 2019, as with Iowa and Arizona, Chile was already nine years and counting into a devastating and historically unprecedented megadrought.

—

—

MOSACAT 成员塔尼亚·罗德里格斯递给我谷歌全部 347 页的环境文件，打印出来，用螺旋装订，夹在两个蓝色塑料套里。这本大部头书砰的一声掉到我腿上，这恰恰体现了硅谷如何运用技术知识来证明其中心化决策的合理性。底部贴着几张贴着仔细标记的便利贴。其中一张用西班牙语写着“ Agua potable ”（饮用水），用来标记讨论数据中心需要消耗淡水进行冷却的页面。

Tania Rodríguez, a member of MOSACAT, hands me all 347 pages of Google’s environmental filing, printed out and spiral-bound between two blue plastic protectors. The tome drops into my lap with a thud, a physical manifestation of the way Silicon Valley wields technical knowledge to justify its centralized decision-making. Jutting out from the bottom are carefully labeled Post-it notes. “Agua potable” (potable water) reads one in Spanish, bookmarking the pages that discuss the data center’s need to consume fresh water for cooling.

MOSACAT成立于2019年，由来自多个不同运动的积极分子组成，他们致力于争取妇女、住房、工人和环境权利，团结一致，形成了一个统一的集体。许多人是在抗议一个非法采矿项目时相识的。该组织表示，MOSACAT的行动成功地驱逐了矿工，关闭了该项目，并将这片土地指定为自然保护区。不久之后，该组织的一位朋友（现任智利国会议员）向他们透露了谷歌数据中心项目的情况，并敦促他们关注该项目的预计耗水量。

MOSACAT was founded in 2019 after activists from several different movements fighting for women’s, housing, workers’, and environmental rights joined in solidarity to form a unified collective. Many had met while protesting an illegal mining project. MOSACAT’s activism successfully chased out the miners, shut down the project, and designated the land a protected nature reserve, the group says. It was shortly thereafter that a friend of the group, who now serves as a member of Chile’s national congress, tipped them off about Google’s data center project and urged them to look at its projected water consumption.

MOSACAT 的成员并非技术专家。但他们仔细阅读了每一页密集的图表和晦涩难懂的术语，做了大量的笔记，并记住了数据中心及其冷却系统的方方面面，为与谷歌的竞争做好了准备。当我问 Rodríguez 他们是如何消化所有这些信息的时，她爽朗地笑了笑。“这全靠我们所有人，”她说道——她指的是 MOSACAT 的十几名志愿者，他们利用工作和家庭义务之余偷来的时间来完成这项工作。

MOSACAT’s members are not technologists. But they read through every page of dense diagrams and arcane terminology, took copious notes, and memorized the ins and outs of data centers and their cooling systems to prepare themselves to go up against Google. Rodríguez lets out a spirited laugh when I ask her how they were able to digest all of the information. “It took all of us,” she says—referring to more than a dozen volunteers who make up MOSACAT’s membership and do the work in stolen hours between jobs and family obligations.

在智利，大多数需要用水的项目都需要很长时间才能获得批准。而谷歌的项目却很快获得了批准，即使在一系列与干旱相关的紧急用水情况下也是如此。起初，MOSACAT 试图通过谷歌在当地的合作伙伴——一家名为 Dataluna 的智利投资和服务公司——来竞争该项目。最初的会议更糟糕的是，MOSACAT 表示：Dataluna 代表似乎对该项目了解甚少，并否认该项目会使用淡水。

In most cases, projects in Chile that require water take a long time to receive approval. In Google’s case, the approval came quickly, even in the midst of a series of drought-related water emergencies. At first, MOSACAT sought to contest the project through Google’s local partner, a Chilean investment and services firm named Dataluna. The initial meeting went badly, MOSACAT says: The Dataluna representatives seemed to have little understanding of the project and denied that it would use fresh water.

随后，MOSACAT 向当地政府反映情况。该组织回忆说，市长和市议会曾与 Dataluna 会面，并误以为该数据中心只需要废水来冷却。在 MOSACAT 向他们汇报后，当地政府感到震惊，要求 Dataluna 做出解释。此事从 Dataluna 升级到谷歌智利分部，一直蔓延到谷歌位于加州山景城的总部。

From there, MOSACAT went to the local government. The mayor and city council had themselves been meeting with Dataluna, the group remembers, and held the false impression that the data center needed only wastewater for its cooling. After MOSACAT briefed them, the government, alarmed, demanded an explanation from Dataluna. The matter escalated from Dataluna to Google’s Chile division all the way to Google’s headquarters in Mountain View, California.

2019年10月，谷歌派出两名工程师和一名律师前往塞里略斯（Cerrillos）向社区进行演讲。他们到达的当天，MOSACAT就在谷歌员工前往会议地点的路线上贴满了抗议标语。会议期间，MOSACAT并非孤军奋战。在大约二十几位与会居民中，还有六个其他活动家和社区团体的代表。MOSACAT记得，谷歌工程师都是外国人，身材高大，只会说英语。他们的演讲技术性很强，谷歌的律师还兼任翻译。在讨论过程中，会说英语的MOSACAT成员表示，他们能听到律师的翻译有误。谷歌代表还提出种植一片城市森林，就像这家科技巨头送给基利库拉的那片一样，以此来安抚社区。但这次行动并没有让MOSACAT和其他团体感到满意：谷歌来这里并不是为了真正地与社区互动，也不是为了倾听社区的需求。 “他们来恐吓我们，”MOSACAT 成员亚历杭德拉·萨利纳斯（Alejandra Salinas）说道，她同时也是塞里略斯邻近的迈普市（Maipú）的议员。“想想看，他们一边给我们送树，一边却榨干了我们的土地。”

In October 2019, Google sent two engineers and a lawyer to Cerrillos to present to the community. The day they arrived, MOSACAT plastered the streets with protest signs along the route the Googlers would drive to get to the meeting location. At the meeting itself, MOSACAT didn’t come alone. Among the roughly two dozen residents who attended, six other activist and community groups were represented. The Google engineers were gringos, MOSACAT remembers, tall and able to speak only English. They gave a highly technical presentation, and Google’s lawyer doubled as a translator. During the discussions, MOSACAT members who spoke English say they could hear the lawyer mistranslating their words. At another point, the Google representatives sought to assuage the community by offering to plant an urban forest just like the one the tech giant had given to Quilicura. The show left MOSACAT and the other groups unimpressed: Google wasn’t here to truly engage with and hear what the community wanted. “They came to intimidate us,” says a MOSACAT member Alejandra Salinas, who also serves as a council member for Cerrillos’s neighboring municipality, Maipú. “Think about it. They come offering us trees while drying out our earth.”

塞里略斯的居民不需要树木。他们不需要谷歌为他们建造公园——就好像圣地亚哥都市区如此落后，以至于没有公园似的。他们需要谷歌停止将他们的土地视为掠夺宝贵水资源和其他资源的场所；他们需要谷歌停止将社区视为其本地项目开发的旁观者而非参与者。“我们知道我们养活了世界，我们提供原材料“就像铜和锂一样，”萨利纳斯说。“没人说我们的宝藏只属于我们，我们不会分享。是的，我们可以互相帮助。但他们不会来取走对生命至关重要的水资源，然后让我们一无所有。”

Residents of Cerrillos didn’t need trees. They didn’t need Google to build them a park—as if the Santiago metropolitan area were such a backward place that it didn’t already have parks. They needed Google to stop treating their land as a place to plunder precious water and other resources; they needed the company to stop dismissing the community as bystanders instead of participants in the development of its local projects. “We know that we feed the world, that we provide raw materials like copper and lithium,” Salinas says. “Nobody is saying our treasure is ours alone and we won’t share it. Yes, we can help each other. But they are not going to come and use the water, which is vital for life, and leave us with nothing.”

当时，智利正处于长达数月的大规模政治动荡之中，即所谓的“社会大动荡”。从 2019 年 10 月开始，每周都会爆发爆炸性、有时甚至是暴力的抗议活动——人们对失业、私有化和严重不平等的集体抗议导致数千人受伤，数十人死亡。2019 年末，随着全国各地的社区开始举行全民公投，以响应改革地方和国家政治的运动，MOSACAT 借助塞里略斯的全民公投，增加了一个问题，即居民是否同意谷歌建造一个会消耗社区大量水资源的设施。他们动员起来，宣传该项目的真实性质，在街角分发传单，敲开民门，并在全市张贴标语。

At the time, Chile was in the midst of a massive, monthslong political upheaval, known as the Estallido Social. Explosive and at times violent protests were erupting every week, beginning that same month in October 2019—a collective outcry over unemployment, privatization, and deep inequality that left thousands injured and dozens dead. In late 2019, as communities across the country began to hold referendums in response to the movement to reform local and national politics, MOSACAT piggybacked on the referendum in Cerrillos to add a question about whether residents agreed for Google to build a facility that would consume so much of the community’s water. They mobilized to broadcast the true nature of the project, handing out flyers on street corners, knocking on people’s doors, and posting signs all over the municipality.

2019年12月，MOSACAT获胜；建设数据中心的公投以微弱多数被否决。次年，政府与MOSACAT联合向环境法庭对该项目提起诉讼。

In December 2019, MOSACAT won; the referendum to build the data center was rejected with a slim majority of the vote. The following year, the government joined MOSACAT in filing a lawsuit against the project with an environmental court.

MOSACAT 表示，在与谷歌的会面中，谷歌代表最终摆出了一副友好面孔，一旦明确一些居民能够理解他们的谈话，他们就表现出更强的谈判意愿。但正如耶鲁大学助理教授朱利安·波萨达 (Julian Posada) 和莫法特·奥金伊 (Mophat Okinyi) 的律师梅西·穆特米 (Mercy Mutemi) 告诉我的那样，作为全球南方国家，反击的风险始终在于硅谷公司会趁机将资金转移到其他地方。随着该项目持续停滞，以及谷歌对更多计算能力的渴望日益增强，该公司宣布将把计划中的下一个拉丁美洲数据中心从智利转移到其他国家。

In the meeting with Google, its representatives ultimately put on a friendly face, MOSACAT says, presenting a greater willingness to negotiate once it became clear that some residents could understand them. But as both Julian Posada, the assistant professor at Yale, and Mercy Mutemi, the lawyer for Mophat Okinyi, told me, the risk of pushing back as a Global South country is always that a Silicon Valley company will pick up and take its money somewhere else. As the project continued to stall and Google’s desire for more compute intensified, the company announced that it would shift its next planned data center in Latin America from Chile to another country.

—

—

在乌拉圭这个只有 340 万人口的小国，国家电信公司 Antel 拥有三个数据中心，为整个国家提供互联网和手机服务。累计起来，它们只占了五千平方米。其中一栋建筑面积不到一千平方米，坐落在蒙得维的亚一条典型的住宅街道上，比周围的建筑更高更宽，但与周围环境融为一体。

In Uruguay, a small country of 3.4 million, the national telecommunications company Antel has three data centers that help provide internet and cell services to the entire country. Cumulatively, they take up only some five thousand square meters. One, less than one thousand square meters, sits nestled into a typical residential street in Montevideo, taller and wider than its neighboring buildings but integrated into its surroundings.

数据中心采用两条与街区其他区域不同的电源线供电。30% 的空间用于放置计算机，70% 用于行政办公室、电气柜和机械室。计算机会发热，但还不至于热到无法使用风冷而非水冷。它们发出低沉的嗡嗡声，在白天熙熙攘攘时几乎听不见，而在夜晚宁静时则足以造成滋扰，以至于两户邻居经常来敲数据中心的门抱怨。数据中心经理哈维尔·埃切维里亚承认这一点时显得有些不好意思。他表示，他目前正在与当地研究人员合作，寻找降低噪音的解决方案，并且已经对冷却系统进行了改进，使其噪音更低。与 MOSACAT 为了引起一家美国公司的注意而经历的繁琐程序相比，这种响应速度简直是天壤之别。

The data center runs on two power lines that are separate from the rest of the neighborhood’s. Thirty percent of the space is filled with computers, 70 percent with administrative offices, electrical closets, and mechanical rooms. The computers get hot but not so hot that they can’t still be cooled with air instead of water. They produce a low hum barely audible during the bustle of the day and just enough of a nuisance in the quiet of the night that two neighboring families have come and knocked on the data center’s door to complain with some regularity. The manager of the data center, Javier Echeverria, looks sheepish as he admits this. He says he is now working with local researchers on solutions to reduce the noise and has already modified the cooling system to be less noisy. The responsiveness is a far cry from the rigmarole that MOSACAT had to go through to get an American company’s attention.

驱车三十分钟，就在市区外，政府划定了一大片土地，用于开发科学园区 Parque de las Ciencias，该园区将作为自由贸易区zona franca进行运营。一些人带着一丝苦涩，调侃地称之为“美国区”，因为这里大多是美国公司的所在地，而且不向政府纳税。这个公园甚至看起来有点像美国：郁郁葱葱、修剪整齐的草坪、对称的设计，以及雄伟的日晷形喷泉，都让人联想到华盛顿特区国家广场的庄严美感。公园网站的主页宣传美国是一个政治和经济稳定的国家，土地充裕，水电供应充足。因此，在2021年，随着GPT-3激发了人们对大幅扩展AI模型的新兴趣，谷歌在这里购买了29公顷土地，相当于Antel数据中心总占地面积的58倍，为其在拉丁美洲的第二个数据中心另建一个基地。

A thirty-minute drive away, right outside the city limits, the government delineated a large expanse of land to develop a science park, Parque de las Ciencias, which operates as a zona franca, a free-trade zone. Some cheekily call it zona America, with a hint of bitterness, for housing mostly American companies that do not pay taxes to the government. The park even looks somewhat like America, its lush, manicured lawns, symmetric design, and majestic sundial-shaped fountain reminiscent of the stately aesthetic of the National Mall in Washington, DC. The home page of the park’s website advertises a politically and economically stable country, plenty of land, and an abundant supply of power and water. So it came to pass that in 2021, as GPT-3 spurred new interest in dramatically scaling AI models, Google purchased twenty-nine hectares of land here, fifty-eight times the size of Antel’s total data center footprint, to establish a different home for its second data center in Latin America.

但当时，乌拉圭的水资源实际上并不充沛。与智利、爱荷华州和亚利桑那州一样，它也遭遇了毁灭性的旱灾。缺水现象十分严重，农民失去了全部收成，给该国造成了超过 10 亿美元的农业损失。损失；到2023年夏天，蒙得维的亚政府将开始将受污染的咸水混入城市饮用水供应。家家户户打开水龙头，都会看到流出腐臭的褐色液体，散发着浓烈的化学气味。那些负担得起的人会购买瓶装水饮用，洗澡时也开着窗户，以免吸入过多的致癌物质。那些人无论如何都不能喝自来水，导致许多人遭受胃痛、皮疹、现有健康状况恶化以及流产率上升的痛苦。

But at the time, Uruguay did not in fact have an abundance of water. Like Chile, like Iowa, like Arizona, it was also experiencing a devastating drought. The water shortage was so severe that farmers were losing their entire harvests, costing the country over $1 billion in agricultural losses; by the summer of 2023, the Montevideo government would start mixing contaminated salt water into the city’s drinking supply. Families opening their taps saw a putrid brownish fluid pouring out that smelled intensely of chemicals. Those who could afford it purchased bottled water for drinking and bathed with their windows open to avoid breathing in too many carcinogens. Those who couldn’t drank the tap anyway, leading many to suffer stomach pains, skin rashes, an aggravation of existing health conditions, and the agony of a growing rate of miscarriages.

在疫情肆虐之后，许多人买不起瓶装水。硅谷蓬勃发展，谷歌和微软的市值均突破2万亿美元，部分原因是企业纷纷转向远程办公，并日益依赖云服务。而乌拉圭的非法住房定居点却成倍增长。当地类似施粥所的“奥拉斯” （Ollas）让孩子们饿着肚子离开。经营这些“奥拉斯”的人自己也陷入贫困，勉强维持生计。法比亚娜是一位喧闹的奥拉（olla）族长，住在非法定居点，被亲切地称为“王太后”（Reina Madre）。回忆起那段经历，她渐渐沉默了下来。“我不得不说，‘我甚至连一个小盘子给你的孩子……’”她的声音渐渐低了下去。“太可怕了。”即使她一生贫困潦倒，七岁时甚至为了生存在妓院里扫地，但她仍然觉得疫情和旱灾是她一生中最糟糕的时期。

In the aftermath of a raging pandemic, there were many who couldn’t afford bottled water. Where Silicon Valley had ascended, with Google’s and Microsoft’s market capitalizations both peaking above $2 trillion, in part from companies going remote and increasingly relying on cloud services, illegal housing settlements in Uruguay had grown by orders of magnitude. Ollas, the local equivalent of soup kitchens, were turning children away hungry. Those running the ollas were themselves in poverty and barely surviving. Fabiana, the boisterous head of an olla who lives in an illegal settlement and is affectionately called Reina Madre (Queen Mother), grows quiet as she remembers it. “To have to say, ‘I don’t even have a little plate for your child…’ ” She trails off. “It was horrible.” Even after a lifetime of poverty that included sweeping the floors of a brothel at seven years old for survival, she finds the pandemic and drought years stand out in her mind as some of the worst in her life.

水危机源于气候变化的复合效应以及国家淡水资源配置失当：在乌拉圭，超过80%的淡水用于工业而非人类消费，尤其是经济作物种植。这些经济作物包括大豆和水稻的工业化农场，以及用于造纸的树木。大多数此类农场不是由当地公司经营，而是由跨国公司经营，这些公司出口其种植的农产品，对乌拉圭的自然环境几乎不承担责任。他们的活动耗尽了土壤中的养分，使得种植实际粮食变得更加困难，并且大量化肥污染了该国的水源，使乌拉圭成为世界上人均化肥消耗量最大的国家之一，并导致癌症发病率异常高。

The water crisis emerged from the compounding effects of climate change and a failure of the state’s allocation of freshwater resources: In Uruguay, more than 80 percent of the country’s fresh water goes to industry instead of human consumption—most notably, cash crop agriculture. These include industrial farms for soybeans and rice, and for trees that feed into paper production. Most such farms are run not by local companies but by multinationals that export what they grow and show little accountability for Uruguay’s natural environment. Their activities deplete the nutrients in the soil, making it more difficult to grow actual food, and pollute the country’s water streams with a volume of fertilizers that makes Uruguay one of the world’s largest per capita fertilizer consumers and causes unusually high rates of cancer.

丹尼尔·佩纳是蒙得维的亚共和国大学的社会学研究员，多年来一直研究环境采掘主义的政治，他将其与乌拉圭的殖民历史直接联系起来。他开着一辆破旧的皮卡走遍全国，采访农民和最贫困社区的居民，近距离记录他们如何被工业压榨。与智利一样，外国跨国公司在政治等级上仍然高于当地人。旱灾期间，工业用水量依然不减，直接从主要河流圣卢西亚河（Río Santa Lucía）取水，这条河也为蒙得维的亚的公共供水系统供水。二十年前，在大规模的环保行动之后，乌拉圭成为世界上第一个在宪法中承认水是一项人权的国家。具有讽刺意味的是，在这次水荒中，饮用水而不是工业用水遭到了最严重的削减。

Daniel Pena, a sociology researcher at the Universidad de la República in Montevideo who has for years studied the politics of this environmental extractivism, draws a direct connection to Uruguay’s colonial history. He drives around the country in a beat-up pickup truck to interview farmers and residents of the poorest neighborhoods, to document up close how they’re squeezed by industry. As with Chile, the foreign multinationals still exist above locals in the political pecking order. During the drought, industry continued to use water unabated, drawing what it needed directly from the main river, Río Santa Lucía, that also feeds Montevideo’s public water system. Two decades ago, after significant environmental activism, Uruguay became the first country in the world to recognize water as a human right in its constitution. Now, in a bitter irony, it was the drinking water rather than water for industry that saw the most severe cutbacks during the shortage.

因此，当谷歌到来时，佩纳保持警惕。他定期浏览乌拉圭环境部网站（该网站列出了主要的工业项目），偶然发现了该公司的数据中心提案。佩纳曾读到过，即使在严重干旱时期，超大规模企业也会使用饮用水，以及像 MOSACAT 这样的社区积极抵制这些项目的情况。但当他下载项目详情时，水量数据被标记为机密。在提交了公开信息请求（他已经成功提交了大约二十次）后，环境部仍然隐瞒这些数据，称它们是专有信息。佩纳想知道他们究竟在隐瞒什么，并担心这会为其他云计算公司树立先例，这些公司不可避免地会效仿谷歌，将目光投向乌拉圭，寻求自身的扩张。于是，他援引了宪法中的水资源条款。在一位愿意无偿服务的律师朋友的帮助下，他起诉了环境部。

So when Google arrived, Pena was vigilant. During his regular scans of the Uruguayan environmental ministry’s website, which lists major industrial projects, he came across the company’s proposal for the data center. Pena had read about hyperscalers using potable water, even during major droughts, and the activism of communities like MOSACAT that had resisted the projects. But when he downloaded the details of the project, the water numbers were marked as confidential. After submitting a public information request, which he had successfully done around twenty times, the ministry continued to withhold the numbers, saying they were proprietary information. Pena wondered what they were hiding and worried about the precedent it would set for other cloud companies that would inevitably begin to eye Uruguay, following Google’s lead, for their own expansion. So he evoked the water clause in the constitution. With the help of a lawyer friend who was willing to work pro bono, he sued the ministry.

四个月后的2023年3月，佩纳出人意料地赢得了这场诉讼。环境部透露，谷歌数据中心计划每天直接从饮用水供应中消耗200万加仑水，相当于5.5万人的每日用水量。蒙得维的亚大部分地区都接收咸水。不久之后，这些曝光的事件就引发了轰动。成千上万的乌拉圭人走上街头，抗议谷歌和其他所有导致政府浪费国家宝贵淡水资源的行业。2024年6月我访问乌拉圭时，城墙和路边护栏上仍然写满了抗议的口号。“这不是干旱，”其中一条写道，“这是掠夺。”

In March 2023, four months later, Pena won the case in a surprising victory. The environmental ministry revealed that Google’s data center planned to use two million gallons of water a day directly from the drinking water supply, equivalent to the daily water consumption of fifty-five thousand people. With much of Montevideo receiving salt water in their taps not long after, the revelations were explosive. Thousands of Uruguayans took to the streets to protest Google and all of the other industries that had led the government to squander the country’s precious freshwater resources. The slogans of resistance are still scrawled across the city’s walls and roadside barriers during my visit in June 2024. “This is not drought,” reads one. “It’s pillage.”

佩纳对数据中心的看法与拉莫斯对采矿的看法如出一辙。问题不在于基础设施本身，而在于硅谷试图建设的规模。正是这种规模驱使谷歌和微软等公司在智利和乌拉圭扩张，即便这两个国家正遭受着严重资源匮乏的困境。正是这种规模使得它们需要的土地比安特尔多58倍，而且对当地居民的责任感也低得多。“它们是开采性项目，来到全球南方国家，利用廉价的水资源、免税的土地和低薪工作。它们对我们国家没有任何贡献；它们没有改善我们的互联网接入，”他说道。

Pena sees data centers in the same way that Ramos sees mining. It’s not the infrastructure itself that’s the problem, but the scale at which Silicon Valley is trying to build it. That scale is what drove companies like Google and Microsoft to expand in Chile and Uruguay even as the countries suffered from a severe lack of resources. That scale is what makes them require fifty-eight times more land than Antel and operate with much less accountability to the local population. “They are extractivist projects that come to the Global South to use cheap water, tax-free land, and very poorly paid jobs. And then they don’t contribute to our country; they don’t improve our internet access,” he says.

2023年末，谷歌悄悄更新了其在乌拉圭的数据中心规划，使用无水冷却系统，并表示将把设施规模缩减至原来的三分之一。佩纳表示，这场斗争仍未结束：政府目前将最新提案的预计能耗作为商业机密隐瞒。佩纳还向该部门提交了一份有四百多人签名的请愿书，要求对数据中心的整个供应链进行更广泛的环境和社会影响研究：用于生产硬件的矿物在哪里开采，所涉及的劳动力如何处理，将排放多少碳，以及如何以不会将化学物质渗入社区的方式处理产生的电子垃圾。这些影响中的大多数不会降临到乌拉圭，但佩纳对其他可能受到影响的国家深表同情。他说，这些国家“通常都来自发展中国家”。“我们最终都会面临同样的后果，只是来自全球供应链的不同环节。”

Near the end of 2023, Google silently updated its proposed data center in Uruguay to use a waterless cooling system and said it would reduce the facility to a third of its size. Pena says the fight is still not over: The government is now withholding the projected energy consumption of the latest proposal as a commercial secret. Pena also sent a petition to the ministry, with over four hundred signatories, demanding a more extensive environmental and social impact study of the full supply chain of the data center: where the minerals for producing its hardware are being extracted, how the labor involved is being treated, how much carbon will be emitted, how the generated e-waste will be disposed of in a way that doesn’t leach chemicals into someone’s community. Most of these other impacts won’t befall Uruguay, but Pena feels a solidarity with the other countries where they will. They are “generally all from the Global South,” he says. “We all end up with the same consequences, but from different links in the global supply chain.”

2024年，智利环境法庭裁定谷歌不得在圣地亚哥建造用水数据中心。谷歌智利发言人表示，该公司仍然致力于智利和拉丁美洲，并且计划在需要时启动在塞里略斯建设风冷数据中心的审批程序。但这并没有阻止其他超大规模数据中心运营商进入拉丁美洲。2022 年，在第二次投资 OpenAI 后不久，微软最终确定了其在智利的数据中心位置——就在阿兰西比亚的家乡基利库拉。

In 2024, Chile’s environmental court ruled that Google cannot build a water-using data center in Santiago. The Google Chile spokesperson said the company remains committed to the country and Latin America, and plans to begin the permitting process for an air-cooled data center in Cerrillos when needed. But that hasn’t slowed down other hyperscalers from entering Latin America. In 2022, Microsoft finalized the location for its data center in Chile, shortly after its second investment into OpenAI—right back in Arancibia’s hometown, Quilicura.

—

—

在数据中心开发商领域，微软算是大器晚成。在投资 OpenAI 之前，谷歌在全球建设的数据中心数量遥遥领先。但随着支持其 AI 雄心壮志的计算基础设施需求突然激增，微软也效仿谷歌，进入了同样的领域。

As data center developers go, Microsoft was a late bloomer. Before its investments in OpenAI, Google was well ahead in the number of facilities it was constructing around the world. But with the sudden explosion of demand for more computing infrastructure to support its AI ambitions, Microsoft adopted Google’s playbook and followed it into the same regions.

微软进入的智利与谷歌进入的智利截然不同。2022 年，距离“社会进步运动”已经过去两年多了，这场运动给智利的政治留下了不可磨灭的印记。经过数月的抗议，智利进行了一次意义非凡的实验，在普通公民的广泛参与下重写宪法，以取代皮诺切特残暴独裁统治以来延续下来的宪法。最终，新宪法草案未获通过；两个独立的程序产生了两份未能获得广泛支持的党派文件。但它重新激发了年轻人，尤其是工薪阶层家庭对民主的新乐观态度。左翼思想和支持的高涨，导致形势发生戏剧性转变，年仅 35 岁的千禧一代左翼总统加布里埃尔·博里克·丰特当选。博里克在胜选演讲中重复了抗议活动中的一句口号，抨击皮诺切特统治时期芝加哥男孩的遗产：“如果说智利是新自由主义的摇篮，那么它也将是它的坟墓。”

The Chile that Microsoft entered was different from the Chile that had greeted Google. By 2022, more than two years had passed since the Estallido Social, which had left an indelible mark on the country’s politics. After months of protests, Chile had undergone a remarkable experiment to rewrite its constitution, with the broad participation of regular citizens, to replace the one that had carried over since Pinochet’s brutal dictatorship. Ultimately the new drafts of the constitution didn’t pass; two separate processes resulted in two partisan documents that failed to gain broad support. But it reinvigorated the youth and working-class families in particular with a new optimism for democracy. The upswell of leftist ideas and support led, in a dramatic turn of events, to the election of a millennial left-wing president, Gabriel Boric Font, only thirty-five years old. In his victory speech, Boric repeated a slogan of the protests that slammed the legacy of the Chicago Boys during Pinochet’s rule: “If Chile was neoliberalism’s cradle, it will also be its grave.”

博里克于2022年3月就任，他本人也曾是一名学生抗议者。这鼓舞了全国各地的年轻人，让他们从社会动荡中汲取组织和抗议的经验，建立新一代进步的行动组织。他们融入了各个社区的节奏，定期聚会，共同构想智利未来的宏伟愿景。

Boric, who began his term in March 2022, had himself been a student protester. It emboldened youth across the country to take what they learned from the social upheaval about organizing and protest to establish a new generation of progressive activist organizations. They became part of the rhythms of each community, meeting regularly to dream up big-picture visions about what they wanted for the future of Chile.

正是在这段时间，阿兰西比亚与另一位年轻的基利库拉居民罗德里戈·巴列霍斯 (Rodrigo Vallejos) 共同创立了自己的行动主义团体。两人他们在组织社会动乱期间相识，并因对环境的深厚热情而迅速建立联系。他们将自己的组织命名为“Resistencia Socioambiental Quilicura”（基利库拉社会环境抵抗运动），这源于拉丁美洲一个根深蒂固的理念：社会与环境密不可分。

It was during this period that Arancibia cofounded her own activism group with another young Quilicura resident, Rodrigo Vallejos. The two had met during the organizing of the social upheaval and quickly bonded over their deep passion for the environment. They called their group Resistencia Socioambiental Quilicura—the Socio-environmental Resistance of Quilicura—drawing upon a well-established concept in Latin America that the social and the environmental are inextricably linked.

微软进驻基利库拉后，瓦列霍斯和阿兰西比亚做了 MOSACAT 和丹尼尔·佩纳之前做过的事：他们开始仔细研究微软提供的所有资料，并对这个项目进行深入研究。瓦列霍斯是迭戈波塔莱斯大学法学院的学生，他利用课余时间熬夜阅读技术文档，自学数据中心的工作原理。

Upon Microsoft’s entrance into Quilicura, Vallejos and Arancibia did what MOSACAT and Daniel Pena had before them: They began to pore over whatever materials they could find that Microsoft had made available and to extensively research the project. Vallejos, a law student at Universidad Diego Portales, worked late into the nights in between his schoolwork to read technical documentation and teach himself about how data centers work.

微软预计其所需水量远低于谷歌在塞里略斯的用水量。即便如此，瓦列霍斯仍然感到担忧。智利的旱情愈演愈烈，预计将持续到2040年。除了工业侵占之外，基利库拉的湿地正遭受着加速荒漠化的严重破坏。微软在其网站上大肆宣扬数据中心冷却系统的尖端创新，这意味着其设施无需用水。如果微软有能力建造无水数据中心，为什么不在基利库拉这样做呢？

Microsoft projected that it would need a significantly lower amount of water than Google had in Cerrillos. Even still, Vallejos worried. The drought in Chile had only gotten worse and was expected to last until 2040. Quilicura’s wetlands were suffering acutely, on top of industrial encroachment, from accelerating desertification. On its website, Microsoft boasted about new cutting-edge innovations in data center cooling systems that would mean its facilities didn’t need to use water. If Microsoft had the capability to build waterless data centers, why wasn’t it doing so in Quilicura?

““像微软这样享有盛誉的公司公开宣称自己是环保人士，但实际上却不符合智利这样的第三世界国家的全球创新标准，这令人深感震惊，”瓦列霍斯后来在一篇文章中写道。

“It is deeply striking that a company with as much reputation as Microsoft publicly presents an environmentally friendly discourse, but in reality does not comply with global innovation standards in a third world country like Chile,” Vallejos later wrote in an article.

微软随后解释说，其宣传的创新技术仍在开发中，目前仅在美国部分地区进行试点。“那他们为什么在网站上承诺这些呢？”瓦列霍斯问道。

Microsoft would subsequently explain that the innovations it had advertised were still under development and only being piloted in a place in the US. “Then why do they promise these things” on their website? Vallejos asks.

瓦列霍斯引起了当地和国际研究人员的注意，其中包括荷兰建筑、设计和数字文化研究所 Nieuwe Instituut 的研究主任 Marina Otero Verzier，以及由 Martín Tironi Rodó 共同领导的智库 FAIR 的研究人员 Serena Dambrosio 和 Nicolás Díaz Bejarano。奥特罗被感动了瓦列霍斯和阿兰西比亚的热情，以及他们的疲惫。他们疲于阅读微软冗长的技术文档、撰写批评文章，并持续抗议，却始终无法获得公司或政府的关注。奥特罗思考着如何帮助他们。她该如何让他们聚在一起，与合适的人谈判？

Vallejos caught the attention of local and international researchers, including Marina Otero Verzier, a director of research at Nieuwe Instituut, the Dutch institute for Architecture, Design and Digital Culture, and Serena Dambrosio and Nicolás Díaz Bejarano, researchers at FAIR, the think tank co-led by Martín Tironi Rodó. Otero was moved by the passion of Vallejos and Arancibia, and their exhaustion. They had worn themselves thin reading Microsoft’s long technical documents, writing critical articles, and protesting continuously, but had struggled to get an audience from either the company or the government. Otero pondered ways to help them. How could she get them in a room to negotiate with the right people?

奥特罗知道，她拥有巴列霍斯所没有的东西：与哈佛大学和哥伦比亚大学等名校的合作关系，这些关系能够引起微软和政府的关注。她开始发起一场多管齐下的宣传活动，并逐渐深入其中，最终辞去了工作：她在高调的会议上发表演讲，探讨数据中心对环境的影响以及雷西斯滕西亚的抗争；她与智利科技、知识和创新部以及微软和谷歌的代表建立了联系；她帮助巴列霍斯和阿兰西比亚结识其他国际研究人员，以提升他们的知名度。

Otero knew she had one thing Vallejos did not: affiliations with prestigious universities like Harvard and Columbia that would command Microsoft’s and the government’s attention. She began to mount a multipronged campaign, growing so deeply involved that she quit her job: She spoke at high-profile conferences about the environmental impacts of data centers and Resistencia’s fight against them; she forged connections with the Chilean Ministry of Science, Technology, Knowledge and Innovation and with representatives at Microsoft and Google; she connected Vallejos and Arancibia to other international researchers to elevate their profile.

奥特罗与丹布罗西奥和迪亚兹合作，还开发了一个更具探索性的项目。他们三人都拥有建筑背景，并一直在从建筑环境的角度研究现代数字技术的基础设施。他们开始思考：如果将数据中心视为建筑结构，并从根本上重新构想其美学、在当地社区中的角色以及与周围环境的关系，会怎样？

With Dambrosio and Díaz, Otero also developed a more speculative project. All three had architectural backgrounds and had been studying the infrastructure of modern digital technologies through the lens of the built environment. They began to wonder: What if they treated data centers as architecture structures and fundamentally reimagined their aesthetic, their role in local communities, and their relationship with the surrounding environment?

迪亚兹喜欢在旅途中参观国家图书馆——这些美丽的场所力图捕捉一个国家辉煌的记忆和知识。迪亚兹突然想到，数据中心也可以被视为图书馆——拥有自己的记忆和知识宝库。而且，它们也可以被设计得温馨美观，而不是丑陋和压抑。

Díaz liked to visit national libraries during his travels—beautiful venues that seek to capture the grandeur of a country’s memories and knowledge. It struck Díaz that data centers, too, could be thought of as libraries—with their own stores of memories and knowledge. And they, too, could be designed to be welcoming and beautiful instead of ugly and extractive.

这与微软和谷歌对回馈社会的定义截然不同，例如后者通过社区影响力项目，而迪亚兹称其为“精神分裂”的举措，往往与社区如何真正受到公司设施的影响脱节。与瓦列霍斯和阿兰西比亚，三名研究人员申请了资金并组织了一个为期十四天的研讨会，邀请来自圣地亚哥各地的建筑系学生重新构想基利库拉的数据中心是什么样子。

This represented a sharp departure from Microsoft’s and Google’s definitions of what it means to give back, such as through the latter’s community impact programs, with what Díaz calls their “schizophrenic” initiatives, which tend to be divorced from how communities are actually affected by the companies’ facilities. Together with Vallejos and Arancibia, the three researchers applied for funding and put together a fourteen-day workshop, inviting architecture students from all around Santiago to reimagine what a data center could look like for Quilicura.

学生们设计了令人惊叹的模型。一个小组设想将数据中心的用水情况更直观地展现出来，将其储存在大型水池中，居民也可以将其作为公共空间使用。另一个小组提议摒弃典型数据中心的粗犷设计，转而采用“流动数据区域”，让数据基础设施与湿地共存，从而减轻其破坏性影响。数据中心的结构将兼作悬空步道，邀请基利库拉居民漫步湿地，欣赏其生态系统。植物苗圃和动物筑巢站将穿插在较为传统的服务器机房之间，以恢复湿地的生物多样性。数据中心将从湿地中抽取污水，净化后再排放回用。计算机本身将收集和处理有关湿地健康状况的数据，以加速当地环境的恢复。“我们不是在解决问题，而是在构想数据与水之间的其他关系，”迪亚兹说道。

The students designed stunning mock-ups. One group imagined making the data center’s water use more visible by storing it in large pools that residents could also enjoy as a public space. Another group proposed tossing out the brutalist designs of the typical data center in favor of a “fluid data territory” where data infrastructure coexists with wetland, mitigating its damaging impacts. The structures of the data center would double as suspended walkways, inviting Quilicura residents to walk through the wetland and admire the ecosystem. Plant nurseries and animal nesting stations would be interspersed among more traditional server rooms to rehabilitate the wetland’s biodiversity. The data center would draw polluted water from the wetland and purify it for use before returning it. The computers themselves would collect and process data about the health of the wetlands to accelerate the local environment’s restoration. “We’re not fixing the problem, but we’re imagining other types of relationships between data and water,” Díaz says.

研讨会结束时，学生们向居民和其他社区成员展示了他们的想法。“这是一次非常棒的对话，”奥特罗说道。“你可以看到社区拥有多么丰富的知识。他们提供了太多东西。”

At the end of the workshop, the students presented their ideas to residents and other community members. “It was an incredible conversation,” Otero says. “You can see how much knowledge the community has. They had so much to offer.”

—

—

博里克四年任期已过三年，他面临着为经济“速效”的压力——作为一名年轻的左翼总统，这种压力尤为突出。这意味着他要扩大采矿业，要确保28个新数据中心的建成。在博里克宣布制定国家数据中心战略的那天，巴列霍斯给我发了一段新闻发布会的视频和一个表情符号：一个眼神迷离、双眼螺旋的表情。

Three years into his four-year term, Boric is under pressure to get “quick wins” for the economy—even more so as a young, left-wing president. That means pressure to expand the mining industry, pressure to see through the arrival of twenty-eight new data centers. On the day Boric announced a plan to develop a national data center strategy, Vallejos texted me a video of the press conference and an emoji: the disoriented face with spiral eyes.

但公平地说，智利北部和圣地亚哥的活动人士与国内外研究人员的联盟显然取得了显著的成果。作为数据中心计划的一部分，负责监督其建设的科学部首次成立了一个由活动人士组成的委员会，为数据中心的建设提供咨询。定期与智利政府合作，作为起草过程的一部分，并邀请瓦列霍斯、阿兰西比亚和 MOSACAT 成员加入。科技部还在监督一项人工智能法案，该法案阐明了智利希望如何处理人工智能的开发、应用和监管。此前，该部的讨论将人工智能视为一种普遍的积极因素，但此后基调已发生转变，开始承认这项技术的社会和环境成本。

But in fairness, the coalition of activists in northern Chile and Santiago with researchers domestic and abroad has clearly made a mark. As part of the data center plan, the Ministry of Science, which oversees its creation, has for the first time formed a committee of activists to consult with regularly as part of the drafting process, and invited Vallejos, Arancibia, and members of MOSACAT to join them. The Ministry of Science is also overseeing an AI bill that articulates how Chile wants to approach AI development, application, and regulation. Whereas before the ministry’s discussions cast AI as a universal positive, the tone has since shifted to acknowledge the social and environmental costs of the technology.

与许多全球南方国家一样，智利从惨痛经历中汲取了教训，意识到不应坐等全球北方国家来决定如何建设数字技术。“我们建设技术的方式与特定的文化框架和历史框架相呼应，”该部部长艾森·埃切韦里（Aisén Etcheverry）说道。全球互联网的形成并非智利的参与，而如今，智利有机会按照自己的方式塑造人工智能。

Chile, like many Global South countries, has learned from hard experience that it should not wait around for the Global North to decide how it will build digital technologies. “The way we build technology responds to a certain cultural framework and historical framework,” says Aisén Etcheverry, the head of the ministry. Where the global internet was shaped without Chile, the country now has an opportunity to shape AI on its own terms.

蒂罗尼更进一步。他指出，当今的人工智能产业显然根植于殖民意识形态：它将自己的世界观和技术——什么是人工智能，什么是好的人工智能，以及创建人工智能产业意味着什么——强加于世界其他国家。智利可以成为抵制这种强加的领导者。经过几个世纪的掠夺，智利深知在进步的旗帜下，自己的土地被掏空、被剥夺、被摧毁意味着什么。它可以将这些经验作为源泉，从中产生全新的人工智能概念——去殖民化的概念。

Tironi pushes this one step further. It’s very clear that the AI industry today is rooted in a colonial ideology, he says: It imposes its worldview and its technology—what is AI, what is good AI, what it means to create an industry of AI—on the rest of the world. Chile could be a leader in resisting that imposition. After centuries of extractivism, the country intimately understands what it means for its land to be hollowed out, dispossessed, and destroyed under a banner of progress. It could use those experiences as a wellspring from which to generate fundamentally new conceptions—decolonial conceptions—of AI.

“在人工智能的全球市场中，我们国家扮演着一个特殊的角色：提供开发这项技术所需的材料，”他说，“许多公司试图从我们这里榨取大量材料来创造人工智能。”

“In the planetary market of AI, we as a country are playing a specific role: giving materials to develop this technology,” he says. “Many companies are trying to extract a lot of material from us to create AI.

“所以我们需要从这个角度来思考，这个地缘政治角度，这个地球角度。我们可以想出另一种方式将技术创新与地球联系起来。”

“So we need to think from this position, this geopolitical position, this terrestrial position. We can think of another way to relate technological innovation with the earth.”

这是一个崇高的抱负，但反对它的力量却十分强大。

It is a noble ambition, and the forces arrayed against it are mighty.

第十三章

Chapter 13

两位先知

The Two Prophets

我2023年5月，奥特曼抵达华盛顿特区，在国会作证。这是一次非凡的演讲。他重申了通用人工智能（AGI）解决气候变化和治愈癌症的潜力，并就OpenAI的技术将如何改进并创造“绝佳”的新工作岗位给出了令人信服的论据，同时回避了有关版权问题以及其训练数据缺乏透明度和隐私保障的问题，并真诚地呼吁监管——当然，是在OpenAI的支持下进行的监管，这让人想起了中国敦促立法者不要阻碍其创新的幽灵。

In May 2023, Altman arrived in Washington, DC, to testify before Congress. It was a remarkable performance. He reiterated the promise of AGI solving climate change and curing cancer, gave a compelling argument for why OpenAI’s technologies would improve and create “fantastic” new jobs, dodged questions about copyright issues and the lack of transparency and privacy guarantees around its training data, and delivered a sincere call for regulation—that is, regulation with OpenAI’s blessing, evoking the specter of China to urge lawmakers not to slow down its innovation.

参议员们都很喜欢他。在一次引人入胜的交流中，Altman 灵活的言辞以及他正在赢得的信任和热情都得到了充分体现。他提出了三项政策建议，将讨论的焦点从劳工、环境和知识产权等现有问题转移到监管未来的人工智能系统和极端风险上：首先，创建一个机构，负责制定和管理超过一定能力阈值的模型的许可制度；其次，制定一套用于衡量“危险”能力的人工智能安全标准；第三，要求对这些标准进行独立审计，以检查其合规性。他后来进一步阐述道，如有必要，能力阈值可以用计算阈值来近似，并且“危险能力”可能包括模型的操纵和说服的能力，以及生成新型生物制剂配方的能力。

Senators loved him. In a telling exchange that captured Altman’s nimble rhetoric and the trust and enthusiasm he was garnering, he offered three policy recommendations that shifted the conversation away from existing issues like labor, environment, and intellectual property and toward regulating future AI systems and extreme risks: First, create an agency that would develop and administer a licensing regime for models above a certain threshold of capabilities; second, create a set of AI safety standards for measuring “dangerous” capabilities; third, require independent audits on those standards to check for compliance. He later elaborated that capability thresholds could be approximated with compute thresholds if necessary, and that “dangerous capabilities” could include a model’s ability to manipulate and persuade, and to generate recipes for novel biological agents.

“如果我们颁布这些规则，你有资格执行这些规则吗？”路易斯安那州参议员约翰肯尼迪问道。

“Would you be qualified to, if we promulgated those rules, to administer those rules?” Louisiana senator John Kennedy asked.

“我热爱我现在的工作，”奥特曼笑着说道。

“I love my current job,” Altman said to laughter.

“有符合资格的人吗？”肯尼迪问道。

“Are there people out there that would be qualified?” Kennedy asked.

“是的，我们很乐意向您推荐合适的人选。”

“We’d be happy to send you recommendations for people out there, yes.”

“好吧。你赚了很多钱，是吗？”

“Okay. You make a lot of money, do you?”

“我赚——没有。我的工资足够支付医疗保险。我没有 OpenAI 的股权。”

“I make—no. I’m paid enough for health insurance. I have no equity in OpenAI.”

坐在加里·马库斯旁边，奥特曼甚至赢得了他最直言不讳的批评者之一的支持。“我只想补充一下，我坐在萨姆旁边，这辈子除了一次之外，从来没有像现在这样近距离地和他坐过，”马库斯说，“他的真诚……在身体上非常明显，这是电视屏幕上无法传达的。”马库斯后来收回了他罕见的赞同态度：“我意识到我、参议院、以及最终的美国人民可能都被耍了。”)

Sitting next to Gary Marcus, Altman won over even one of his most vocal critics. “Let me just add for the record that I’m sitting next to Sam, closer than I’ve ever sat to him except once before in my life,” Marcus said, “and his sincerity…is very apparent physically in a way that just doesn’t communicate on a television screen.” (Marcus would later backtrack his rare show of approval: “I realized that I, the Senate, and ultimately the American people, had probably been played.”)

奥特曼的准备团队认为这是一个巨大的成功。

Altman’s prep team considered it a resounding success.

这场听证会是一场旷日持久的宣传攻势的锦上添花。ChatGPT 上线后，华盛顿几乎每个人都迫切地渴望与 OpenAI 会面。安娜·马坎朱 (Anna Makanju) 领导的小型政策团队此前一直默默无闻，但如今却收到了铺天盖地的请求。几个月来，无论有没有奥特曼，他们都从早到晚，几乎不间断地与尽可能多的政策制定者（从参议员、众议院议员、工作人员和内阁成员到来访的外交官、机构负责人和副总统卡马拉·哈里斯）共进晚餐、提供演示、回答问题并传达奥特曼在作证时提出的立法提案。

The hearing was the cherry on top of a long campaign. After the launch of ChatGPT, nearly everyone in Washington had desperately sought meetings with OpenAI. The small policy team under Anna Makanju, after operating in relative obscurity, had received an avalanche of requests. For months, with or without Altman, they had been dining with, giving demos to, fielding questions from, and delivering the legislative proposal that Altman gave during his testimony to as many policymakers as possible—from senators, House representatives, staffers, and cabinet members to visiting diplomats, agency heads, and Vice President Kamala Harris—morning to night, practically nonstop.

据《纽约时报》报道，截至 6 月初，奥特曼已亲自会见了至少一百名美国议员，其中一些议员在听证会上自豪地提到了这些私人谈话。

By early June, Altman had personally met with at least one hundred US lawmakers, according to The New York Times, some of whom proudly referenced those private conversations during the hearing.

在奥特曼作证的那天，好莱坞的一小群概念艺术家，专门从事角色、道具和电影中其他视觉元素的艺术家们，也曾计划与几家国会办公室会面。他们通过众筹筹集机票和住宿费用，并在此过程中因公开反对人工智能行业而受到网络喷子的威胁和人肉搜索。正如好莱坞编剧——以及好莱坞演员们即将面临这样的情况——正在进行历史性罢工，部分是为了争取更好的人工智能保护措施一样，这些艺术家们也计划坦率地谈论生成式人工智能已经对他们的职业造成的毁灭性影响。生成式人工智能的开发人员在未经同意的情况下，对数百万艺术家的作品进行了训练，以打造价值数十亿美元的企业和产品，而这些企业和产品现在实际上取代了他们。那些被取代的工作岗位都是稳定的中产阶级工作——多达数十万个。“艺术家们现在非常痛苦。没人能找到工作，”卡拉·奥尔蒂斯（Karla Ortiz）说道。她是一位概念艺术家，因参与漫威影业《奇异博士》的创作而闻名。奥尔蒂斯是该组织的成员之一，并针对多家生成式人工智能公司提起了首例艺术家诉讼。

On the day of Altman’s testimony, a small band of Hollywood concept artists, who specialize in the conceptual design of characters, props, and other visual elements in movies, had also been scheduled to meet with several congressional offices. They had crowdsourced funding for their airfare and accommodation and had in the process been threatened by online trolls and doxed for speaking out against the AI industry. Just as Hollywood writers were—and soon Hollywood actors would be—in the midst of historic strikes, to bargain in part for better protections against AI, the artists, too, had planned to speak candidly about the devastating effects that generative AI was already having on their profession. Generative AI developers had trained on millions of artists’ work without their consent in order to produce billion-dollar businesses and products that now effectively replaced them. Those jobs that were being erased were solid middle-class jobs—as many as hundreds of thousands of them. “Artists are in so much pain right now. No one is getting work,” says Karla Ortiz, a concept artist known for her work on Marvel Studios’ Doctor Strange, who was part of the group and filed the first artist lawsuit against several generative AI companies.

他们抵达华盛顿后，由于奥特曼的证词，好几次会面都被推迟到了第二天，这打乱了他们的日程安排，让他们只能在听证会的大厅里走来走去——确切地说，是在听证会的房间外面。第二天，他们又一次开始争夺注意力。奥特曼当时正与60名众议员在国会大厦参加一场专属晚宴，享用着精心准备的自助烤鸡。与此同时，艺术家们正在举办一场互动鸡尾酒会，并试图用他们预算所能买到的最好的东西——葡萄酒和Chick-fil-A——来吸引尽可能多的工作人员。

As they arrived in Washington, several of their meetings were bumped by Altman’s testimony to the following day, scrambling their schedules and leaving them to walk around the halls of the hearing—quite literally, outside the room where it was happening. That second day, they were once again competing for attention. Altman was attending an exclusive dinner with sixty House members at the Capitol, feasting on an expertly prepared buffet with roast chicken. At the same time, the artists were hosting an interactive cocktail hour and trying to attract as many staffers with the best their budget could buy: wine and Chick-fil-A.

这是一个小小的但带有黑色幽默色彩的例子，说明了在人工智能政策对话中谁掌握着权力和影响力，而谁没有。

It was a small but darkly comedic illustration of who commanded power and influence in the AI policy conversation and who didn’t.

—

—

Altman 长期以来在 OpenAI 内部用来为隐藏研究和尽快行动辩护的同一说法，如今正被巧妙地运用，引导美国人工智能监管讨论走向避免追究 OpenAI 责任的提案，在某些情况下甚至巩固其垄断地位。硅谷屡试不爽的“中国怎么办？”牌，在抵御监管方面一直卓有成效。现在，它更有力了。TikTok 的惊人崛起加剧了华盛顿对中国的担忧，达到了前所未有的高度。

The same narrative Altman had long used within OpenAI to justify hiding its research and moving as fast as possible was now being expertly wielded to steer the US AI regulatory discussion toward proposals that would avoid holding OpenAI accountable, and in some cases entrench its monopoly. Silicon Valley’s tried-and-true “What about China?” card had consistently done wonders to ward off regulation. Now it was punchier than ever, with Washington’s fears about China, fueled by TikTok’s stunning rise, reaching new heights.

这种担忧可以从商务部的情绪中体现出来。商务部已成为美国政府遏制中国人工智能发展的激进攻势的先锋。前一年，即2022年10月7日，商务部发布了一项指令，声称旨在削弱中国人工智能军事方面的进步。通过一种名为出口管制的机制——一种以国家安全为由限制向外国出售某些技术的方式——商务部在没有任何警告的情况下，禁止向中国出口美国设计的尖端人工智能芯片，主要是英伟达的芯片。此举的影响范围远不止中国军方；它彻底摧毁了中国科学界和人工智能产业，从人工智能医疗保健和教育应用到中国版的ChatGPT等产品，无所不包。如果五年前你告诉我这些规则，我会告诉你那是一种战争行为——我们必须处于战争状态，”一位半导体分析师表示。

That fear could be typified by the mood at the Department of Commerce, which had become the leading edge of an aggressive US government offensive to throttle China’s AI development. The previous year, on October 7, 2022, Commerce had released a directive that it said was meant to undercut Chinese AI military advancements. Using a mechanism called export controls—a way to limit the sale of certain technologies to foreign countries on the grounds of national security—it clamped down without warning on the export of cutting-edge American-designed AI chips, primarily Nvidia’s, to China. The blast radius of this move was far wider than the Chinese military; it pulled the rug out from under the Chinese scientific community and AI industry working on everything from AI health care and education applications to Chinese ChatGPT equivalents. “If you’d told me about these rules five years ago, I would’ve told you that’s an act of war—we’d have to be at war,” a semiconductor analyst said.

回顾此次事件的后果，商务部似乎对中国看似的韧性感到失望。中国在人工智能发展和应用方面的步伐有所放缓，但远不足以让商务部感到安心。部分原因是Nvidia 自己的策略：中国对美国芯片制造商来说是一个巨大的市场，美国商务部刚刚取消限制，Nvidia 就设计出符合这些限制的新芯片，以便继续向中国客户销售产品。这项禁令也提振了中国本土芯片制造业，该行业长期以来一直难以生产出与英伟达同等质量的芯片。美国政府的行动激发了人们对中国本土替代芯片的兴趣，为该行业提供了巨大的资金和反馈，使其得以发展。

Taking stock of the aftermath, Commerce seemed frustrated by China’s seeming resilience. The country’s pace of AI development and adoption had slowed down some but not nearly enough to give the department comfort. Part of this was due to Nvidia’s own maneuvering: China represented a massive market for the American chipmaker, and just as quickly as Commerce had laid down its constraints, Nvidia had designed new chips that fell neatly within them in order to keep selling to Chinese customers. The ban was also a lift to China’s own chipmaking industry, which had long struggled to produce chips as good as Nvidia’s. The US government’s actions had generated a surge of interest for Chinese domestic alternatives, giving the industry a big funding and feedback boost to advance.

但其努力面临的最大挑战是充满活力的跨境开源人工智能运动，该运动正在快速复制封闭的企业生成人工智能模型，并将其发布到互联网上供任何人下载和使用。经过大力追赶，Meta 已经成为自由发布其大型语言的主导者模型。该公司长期以来一直是开源开发的倡导者；首席科学家 Yann LeCun 坚信开放科学的重要性。这也是一项精明的商业行为。Meta 无需出售生成式 AI 模型来赚钱，但免费发布这些模型并将其整合到核心产品中，可以帮助其确立 AI 领导地位，吸引顶尖科研人才，并嘲讽那些依赖出售模型来争夺人才的竞争对手。

But the biggest challenger to its efforts was the vibrant cross-border open-source AI movement, which was rapidly replicating closed corporate generative AI models and putting them out on the internet for anyone to download and use. After vigorously playing catch-up, Meta had become a dominant player in freely putting out its large language models. The company had long been a champion of open-source development; chief scientist Yann LeCun believed in the importance of open science. It was also smart business. Meta didn’t need to sell generative AI models to make money, but unleashing free ones, while integrating them into its core products, could help it establish its AI leadership, attract top scientific talent, and taunt its competitors for that talent who did depend on selling their models.

Meta 通过微软积累了与 OpenAI 相当的计算资源，现在正全力以赴地开发其与 GPT 系列相当的产品 Llama。Llama 在技术上并未明确开源的真正定义，这意味着需要同时发布模型权重和训练数据。但 Meta 仅仅在第一个方面——免费发布其模型权重——就足以让 Llama（尽管其政策规定不在中国直接提供 Llama）变成中国人工智能产业的重要组成部分。

Having amassed around the level of compute resources that OpenAI had through Microsoft, Meta was now full steam ahead on producing its equivalent of the GPT series, called Llama. Llama didn’t technically clear the true definition of open source, which would have required releasing both the model weights and its training data. But Meta’s follow-through on just the first aspect, publishing its model weights for free, had been enough to turn Llama—despite its policy to not make Llama directly available in China—into a critical building block for the Chinese AI industry.

在华盛顿弥漫着沮丧和恐惧的氛围中，一份呼应奥特曼建议的政策白皮书于2023年7月奥特曼听证会两个月后发布。这份白皮书由一个由OpenAI安全团队、微软、谷歌DeepMind以及十多个智库（其中许多与“末日浩劫”社区有关联）组成的研究人员联盟撰写，该联盟再次推动建立基于计算阈值的人工智能模型新许可制度，并推动开发针对危险能力的人工智能安全评估，这些能力包括操纵和说服能力以及新型生物武器配方的研发。这份长达51页的文件还为需要政府干预的模型类别命名：“前沿”人工智能模型。据作者所述，前沿模型——可能展现这些危险能力的模型——尚不存在，但通过扩展OpenAI和Anthropic等公司现有的模型，使其拥有更强的计算能力，它们可能随时以不可预测的方式突然出现。

Amid the climate of frustration and fear in Washington, a policy white paper echoing Altman’s recommendations arrived two months after his hearing in July 2023. Written by a consortium of researchers, including from OpenAI’s Safety clan, Microsoft, and Google DeepMind as well as more than a dozen think tanks, many tied to the Doomer community, it pushed once again for a new licensing regime for AI models using compute thresholds, and the development of AI safety evaluations for dangerous capabilities including the ability to manipulate and persuade and the creation of novel biological weapon recipes. The fifty-one-page document also gave a name to the category of models that needed this government intervention: “frontier” AI models. Per the authors, frontier models—models that might exhibit these dangerous capabilities—did not yet exist, but by scaling existing models from companies like OpenAI and Anthropic with ever more compute, they could arise suddenly and unpredictably at any moment.

在白皮书发布后的几周内，OpenAI 和微软与谷歌和 Anthropic 结成战略联盟，推出了前沿模型论坛，这是一个旨在推进相关研究并影响政策的组织。关于人工智能安全风险的议程。这是一个罕见的议题，末日论者、婴儿潮论者和唯利是图的企业的利益一致：在政府监管讨论中，将前沿模型置于中心位置对末日论者来说是意识形态上的当务之急，而对婴儿潮论者和企业来说则很方便，因为他们可以转移对现有人工智能模型及其问题的监管注意力。此外，每个人都反对开放前沿模型的权重，以此来推进自己的事业。在论坛成立的第一年，Meta 缺席得意洋洋。（一年后，它加入论坛，获得了一席之地。）

Within weeks of the white paper, OpenAI and Microsoft formed a strategic alliance with Google and Anthropic to launch the Frontier Model Forum, a group for advancing relevant research and influencing the policy agenda on AI safety risks. It was a rare issue in which the interests of Doomers, Boomers, and profit-motivated corporates aligned: Keeping frontier models front and center in government regulatory discussions was ideologically imperative to Doomers and convenient to Boomers and corporates for shifting attention away from regulating existing AI models and their problems. Everyone also advanced their causes by arguing against opening up the weights of cutting-edge models. In the Forum’s first year, Meta was conspicuously absent. (It would join a year later to gain a seat at the table.)

—

—

Altman 的建议和前沿模型的核心思想在于将模型的规模与新兴的、因而可能具有危险性的能力联系起来。这种论点植根于“缩放定律”的哲学——即更多的训练计算能力应该可以预见地产生更强大的模型——以及末日论者圈子里的一种信念，即高度先进的人工智能可能会失控。由此论点衍生的政策建议的核心在于，监管机构应该根据用于训练深度学习模型的计算量来制定干预措施：超过一定计算阈值的模型应该自动受到更谨慎的审视和更严格的限制。

Core to Altman’s recommendations and the idea of the frontier model was the association of a model’s scale with emergent, and thus possibly dangerous, capabilities. Such an argument was rooted in the philosophy of scaling laws—that more training compute should predictably result in more powerful models—as well as the belief within Doomer circles that highly advanced AI could go rogue. The policy proposals that flowed from this argument centered on regulators basing their interventions on how much compute was being used to train a deep learning model: Models that crossed a certain compute threshold should automatically be viewed with more caution and restricted more tightly.

2023 年 7 月的政策白皮书为该阈值提出了一个数字：10^ 26浮点运算，指的是一个模型需要训练才能被指定为前沿模型的最小计算总数——1 后面跟着 26 个零。作者承认这个阈值有些武断，只是简单地说这是现有人工智能模型可能尚未超越的计算水平。大型语言模型开发商 Cohere 的研究副总裁、该论文的合著者之一 Sara Hooker 表示，与提出这个数字的合作者交谈后，她相信他们选择的这个数字略高于 OpenAI 据称用于训练 GPT-4 的计算量。

The July 2023 policy white paper suggested a number for that threshold: 1026 floating point operations, referring to the minimum total number of calculations—1 with twenty-six zeros after it—that a model needed to be trained with to be designated as a frontier model. The authors had admitted that the threshold was somewhat arbitrary, stating simply that it was a level of compute that existing AI models likely hadn’t yet surpassed. Sara Hooker, the VP of research at large language model developer Cohere and one of the coauthors of the paper, says speaking with her collaborators who proposed the number led her to believe they had picked it to be slightly higher than the amount of compute that OpenAI had reportedly used to train GPT-4.

但胡克和包括黛博拉·拉吉在内的许多其他研究人员不同意使用计算阈值方法来调节模型。虽然规模可以带来更先进的能力，但反之则不然：高级能力不需要规模。例如，仅基于高质量生物数据训练的深度学习模型，可以在非常小的规模上成为非常强大的生物配方生成器。通过“蒸馏”（OpenAI 在其 2021 年研究路线图中提到的技术之一），大型模型也可以转换为具有类似功能的小模型。扩展模型也不能保证某些能力的进步；这再次取决于模型的训练数据以及正在训练的神经网络类型。最后，并非所有模型都基于 Transformer 构建。因此，Hooker 表示，计算与风险根本没有太大关联，更不用说与白皮书中列出的特定类型的风险了。

But Hooker and many other researchers, including Deborah Raji, disagree with the compute-threshold approach for regulating models. While scale can lead to more advanced capabilities, the inverse is not true: Advanced capabilities do not require scale. A deep learning model trained only on high-quality biological data, for example, can be a very powerful generator of biological recipes at very small scale. Through distillation, one of the techniques that OpenAI referenced in its 2021 research road map, large models can also be transformed into small models with similar capabilities. Scaling models doesn’t guarantee advancements in certain capabilities either; that depends once again on what’s in the model’s training data as well as which type of neural network is being trained. In the end, not all models are built on Transformers. Compute is thus not much correlated with risk at all, says Hooker, let alone with specific kinds of risks, such as the ones laid out in the white paper.

由于白皮书的合著者们未能就以计算为中心的监管框架或具体阈值达成共识，10^ 26 次浮点运算这个数字被毫无根据地放在了脚注和附录中，同时还附上了重要的说明，解释了为什么阈值设置是一种极其不完善的方法。令胡克震惊的是，不仅这个框架，就连具体的阈值，都迅速成为了最受欢迎的政策提案之一。白皮书直击了人们对中国的担忧，在华盛顿赢得了相当一部分民众的支持。“前沿模式”听起来很吓人，如果北京真的掌握了这些模式，那就更可怕了。”政府的部分部门正在抓住一切可能的机会，因为他们想做点什么， ”时任 CSET 研究员的艾米丽·温斯坦 (Emily Weinstein) 在 2023 年底告诉我。

Without consensus among the white paper’s coauthors about either the compute-centered regulatory framework or the specific threshold, the number, 1026 floating point operations, was placed in a footnote and the appendix without justification, alongside significant caveats for why thresholds were a highly imperfect approach. What shocked Hooker was how quickly not just the framework but also the exact threshold rapidly turned into one of the most popular policy proposals. It captured significant mind share in Washington, after the white paper tapped straight into fears of China. Frontier models sounded scary, and even more so if Beijing got ahold of them. “Parts of the administration are grasping onto whatever they can because they want to do something,” Emily Weinstein, then a research fellow at CSET, told me in late 2023.

白皮书中的想法在商务部得到了积极响应。工作人员积极与专家会面，探讨控制前沿模型的具体方案，以及是否可行地将这些模型排除在北京的控制范围之外。很快，商务部开始考虑一项前所未有的提案，即扩大人工智能出口管制，不仅关注硬件，还关注软件本身，禁止出口超过计算阈值的人工智能模型。换句话说，商务部正在评估是否可以阻止模型权重在互联网上发布并广泛传播。

The white paper’s ideas found a receptive audience at Commerce. Staff mobilized to meet with experts to hash out what controlling frontier models could look like and whether it would be feasible to keep them out of the reach of Beijing. Soon it was considering an unprecedented proposal to expand its AI export controls to focus on not just hardware but the software itself by banning the export of AI models above a compute threshold. In other words, it was evaluating whether it could block model weights from being posted on the internet and made widely available.

值得注意的是，马库斯和 IBM 副总裁克里斯蒂娜·蒙哥马利（Christina Montgomery）的一项重要建议（与 Altman 一起作证）并没有得到那么大的认可。尽管他们在听证会上反复强调这一点，但这项提案仍然没有取得太大进展：强制公司披露他们输入模型的训练数据究竟包含哪些内容。根据华盛顿的担忧，这几乎不会对向北京移交更先进的能力产生任何影响，但会真正加强企业在一系列问题上的问责，包括公司对受版权保护材料的使用、用户数据隐私以及对模型能力进行严格的科学评估。“如果我们不知道里面有什么成分，就无法确切知道它们的效果如何，”马库斯说道。我们只能轻信公司的说法。

Notably, a key recommendation from Marcus and IBM VP Christina Montgomery, who also testified alongside Altman, did not gain nearly as much traction, despite their repeating it throughout the hearing: compelling companies to disclose what exactly is in the training data they feed into their models. This would have little impact on handing over more advanced capabilities to Beijing per Washington’s concerns but would give real teeth to corporate accountability on a broad range of issues, including company use of copyrighted materials, user data privacy, and rigorous scientific evaluations of model capabilities. “If we don’t know what’s in them, then we don’t know exactly how well they’re doing,” Marcus had said. We’d simply have to take a company’s word for it.

这种方法还能显著降低危险能力是否以及如何出现的不确定性，原因与计算能力无法准确预测风险的原因相同：深度学习模型的行为首先源于其数据。如果一位人工智能开发者开发出一个能够创建生物武器配方的大型语言模型，““这是因为他们用包含生物武器信息的数据集来训练它，”AI Now Institute 联合执行董事、前联邦贸易委员会人工智能高级顾问莎拉·迈尔斯·韦斯特 (Sarah Myers West) 说道。与往常一样，神经网络正在从其训练数据中挖掘出各种模式。开放这些数据将是科学明确哪些类型的输入可能导致危险输出的第一步。

Such an approach would also significantly ameliorate the uncertainty of if and how dangerous capabilities might emerge, for the same reason why compute is a poor risk predictor: A deep learning model’s behavior first and foremost derives from its data. If an AI developer produces a large language model that is able to create recipes for bioweapons, “it’s because they trained it on a dataset that included information on bioweapons,” says Sarah Myers West, the co–executive director of AI Now Institute and former senior adviser on AI to the FTC. As always, the neural network is surfacing patterns within its training data. Opening up that data would be the first step to establishing scientific clarity on what kinds of inputs could lead to dangerous outputs.

—

—

美国商务部就其限制模型权重的提案咨询了多位专家，而其审议结果（该提案将于2024年初通过公开征求意见的方式公布）的消息，将人工智能开发界和迅速扩张的人工智能政策界一分为二。这场冲突关乎封闭与开放、技术民族主义与无国界科学。除了前沿模型论坛的参与者和更广泛的末日论者群体之外，封闭一方迅速赢得了美国国家安全和情报机构的支持。与他们对抗的是 Meta、开源 AI 开发商、初创公司、民间社会团体和独立学者。

As Commerce consulted various experts on its proposal to clamp down on model weights, news of its deliberations, which it would announce in early 2024 with a public request for comment, cleaved the AI development community and the rapidly expanding AI policy community into two. This clash was about Closed versus Open, techno-nationalism versus borderless science. In addition to the Frontier Model Forum participants and broader Doomer community, the Closed side quickly won over the US national security and intelligence apparatus. Facing off against them was Meta, open-source AI developers, startups, civil society groups, and independent academics.

封闭方继续强调 OpenAI 高管多年来在内部使用的许多相同观点，而开放方则认为，封存模型弊大于利。例如，温斯坦指出，生产新型生物武器的瓶颈并不在于找到配方。此类配方在网上已经比比皆是，通过谷歌就能轻松找到。关键在于获取制造武器所需的材料和设备。因此，限制所谓的前沿模型的获取对解决这个问题无济于事。但限制人工智能模型发布的附带损害可能会削弱美国人工智能创新的基础。开源——共享和构建面向更广泛社区发布的代码和软件——长期以来一直是美国初创企业蓬勃发展的基石。限制模型权重的发布将使小型开发者比以往任何时候都更难获得创建自己的人工智能产品和服务的途径。这将进一步巩固前沿模型论坛中巨头的主导地位。

Where the Closed side continued to emphasize many of the same points that OpenAI executives had used for years internally, the Open side argued that sequestering models would do far more harm than good. The bottleneck for producing novel biological weapons, for example, is not about finding a recipe, Weinstein noted. Such recipes already abound online and are easily found via Google. It is about obtaining the materials and equipment to actually make the armaments. Restricting access to so-called frontier models would thus do little to fix this. But the collateral damage of suppressing the publication of AI models would risk weakening the foundations of US AI innovation. Open source—sharing and building on code and software released to the broader community—has long been the bedrock upon which the wealth of US-based startups flourish. Restricting model weights from being published would give smaller developers fewer pathways than ever to create their own AI products and services. It would further entrench the dominance of the giants represented in the Frontier Model Forum.

人工智能模型也将变得越来越难以审查，例如 Sasha Luccioni、Yacine Jernite 和 Emma Strubell 的工作，他们严重依赖开放的生成人工智能模型来量化继续扩大其规模所产生的碳和环境成本。

AI models would also become ever harder to scrutinize, such as in the work of Sasha Luccioni, Yacine Jernite, and Emma Strubell, who have relied heavily on open generative AI models to quantify the carbon and environmental costs of continuing to scale them.

至关重要的是，大量的跨境开放合作不仅没有构成国家安全风险，反而增强了美国在人工智能领域的领导地位。作为全球人工智能人才和研究成果最多的两个国家，中美两国长期以来一直是彼此在人工智能发展领域的首要合作伙伴。十多年来，两国科学家和企业家相互借鉴彼此的研究成果，推动人工智能领域及其广泛应用的发展，其速度远超任何一方单独行动的速度，不仅惠及两国，也惠及全球许多其他国家。最著名的例子之一：ResNet，世界上应用最广泛的神经网络之一，是由微软北京办公室的中国研究人员发布的。ResNet 不仅是主流计算机视觉、语音识别和语言系统的基础，也是 DeepMind AlphaFold 初版的核心组成部分。AlphaFold 是 DeepMind 于 2018 年发布的一款人工智能系统，可以根据蛋白质的氨基酸序列预测其三维结构，这对于加速药物开发和理解疾病至关重要。（DeepMind 随后在 AlphaFold 上利用不同的神经网络取得进展，这为 Demis Hassabis 和DeepMind 的另一位高级研究科学家获得了 2024 年诺贝尔化学奖。）

In critical ways, contrary to it being a national security risk, a great deal of open collaboration across borders had also strengthened American AI leadership. As the two countries that produce the most AI talent and research in the world, the US and China have long been each other’s number one collaborator in AI development. For more than a decade, scientists and entrepreneurs in both countries have riffed off one another’s work to advance the field and a wide array of applications far faster than either group would have alone, benefiting not just each country but many others globally. One of the most famous examples: ResNet, among the most widely used neural networks in the world, was published by Chinese researchers in Microsoft’s Beijing office. ResNet not only underpins major computer-vision, speech-recognition, and language systems but also was a core ingredient of the first version of DeepMind’s AlphaFold, an AI system released in 2018 that could predict a protein’s 3D structure from its amino acid sequence, crucial for accelerating drug development and understanding disease. (DeepMind’s subsequent advancements in AlphaFold, using a different neural network, would earn Demis Hassabis and another senior research scientist at DeepMind a 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.)

然而，到了2023年10月，当封闭派所倡导的想法出现在拜登政府的人工智能行政命令中时，它们将获得迄今为止最大的认可。这项行政令是历史上最长的行政令之一，读起来就像是由完全不同的团体撰写的拼凑起来的文件——因为它确实如此。其中一份文件源于政府的2022年《人工智能权利法案蓝图》。该蓝图是白宫经过与民间社会团体磋商，精心整理而成，概述了如何以加强公民权利、种族平等和隐私保护的方式推进、使用和控制人工智能。除其他事项外，该蓝图强调在社区和专家的广泛参与下开发人工智能，解决人工智能在医疗保健和招聘等领域的歧视性影响，并保护人们免受未经同意的数据收集。

And yet, in October 2023, the ideas championed by the Closed side would gain their greatest endorsement yet when they surfaced in the Biden administration’s AI executive order. The order, one of the longest in history, would read like smashed-together documents written by completely different groups—because it was. One of those documents was rooted in the administration’s 2022 Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights, which the White House had carefully assembled over time through consultations with civil society groups to outline how AI could be advanced, used, and reined in in ways that bolstered civil rights, racial justice, and privacy protections. Among other things, it emphasized developing AI with broad participation from communities and experts, addressing the discriminatory impact of AI in contexts such as health care and hiring, and protecting people from data collection without their consent.

另一份文件出人意料地忠实地复制了奥特曼的建议和前沿模型白皮书的框架。这份白皮书在白宫引起了一些同情末日论者意识形态人士的关注后，于最后一刻被钉上了钉子。白皮书强调需要关注尚未出现的未来人工智能模型；随后，行政命令将一半的篇幅集中在这些模型上。白皮书概述了四种危险能力的例子。行政命令将保留其中三种：新型CBRN（化学、生物、放射和核武器）配方的开发、自动化网络攻击，以及直接复制粘贴的“通过欺骗和混淆手段”逃避人类控制。

The other document was a surprisingly faithful reproduction of Altman’s recommendations and the framing of the frontier model white paper, which had been stapled on at the last minute after the paper gripped the attention of a few people sympathetic to the Doomer ideology in the White House. The white paper had emphasized the need to focus on future AI models that didn’t yet exist; the executive order would subsequently focus half of its real estate on such models. The white paper had outlined four examples of dangerous capabilities. The executive order would keep three of them: the generation of novel CBRN (chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear) weapon recipes, automated cyberattacks, and, in a straight copy and paste, the evasion of human control “through means of deception and obfuscation.”

令胡克、拉吉和许多其他人工智能研究人员感到担忧的是，白皮书中所述的精确计算阈值，即 10 26 次浮点运算，也将出现在行政命令中，作为超过该阈值的模型需要向美国政府报告。

To the alarm of Hooker, Raji, and many other AI researchers, the white paper’s exact compute threshold, 1026 floating point operations, would also show up in the executive order as the threshold above which models would need to be reported to the US government.

有了这样的认可，计算阈值方法很快就会普及开来。到年底，欧洲开始采用这种方法，并于10月25日决定采取稍微严格一些的措施，因为推动酝酿已久的欧盟人工智能法案的立法者们感到，生成式人工智能的突飞猛进令他们措手不及，于是匆忙寻找应对之策。2024年初，随着一项名为SB 1047的新人工智能安全法案的出台，这种做法扩展到了加州，该法案将恢复10月26日作为门槛。加州州长加文·纽瑟姆随后否决了这项法案。讽刺的是，OpenAI 和其他模型开发者却大力游说，反对该法案提出的一系列其他问责提案。许多人批评纽瑟姆屈从于行业利益。但对包括胡克和拉吉在内的几位研究人员来说，这项否决却是一个值得欢迎的进展。“这是朝着正确方向迈出的一步，确保我们能够扎根于科学共识，”胡克说。“关于为什么会出现这样的数字，以及我们希望预防哪些风险，仍然存在一些重大问题。”

With such an endorsement, the compute-threshold approach would quickly metastasize. By the end of the year, it would get picked up in Europe, which settled on 1025 for something slightly more restrictive, as lawmakers pushing through the long-gestating EU AI Act felt steamrolled by the sudden generative AI developments and hurriedly searched for ways to account for them. At the start of 2024, the approach would then spread to California with the introduction of a new AI safety bill called SB 1047, which would return to 1026 as its threshold.
