California governor Gavin Newsom would subsequently veto the bill, which, in an ironic twist, OpenAI and other model developers heavily lobbied against for its wide array of other accountability proposals. Many would criticize Newsom for bowing to industry interests. But to several researchers, including Hooker and Raji, the veto was a welcome development. “It was a step in the right direction to make sure we’re anchored to scientific consensus,” Hooker says. “There are big questions that remain about why that number and what risks are you hoping to prevent.”

整个事件序列——奥特曼的证词、白皮书、全力以赴的政策影响运动、华盛顿对中国担忧的过度反应，以及仓促将计算门槛纳入美国国内外的重要政策文件——都鲜明地表明了独立人工智能专业技术已经萎缩到何种程度。此前一个月，也就是2023年9月，拉吉发现自己是一位独一无二的学者，既与科技行业，也与“末日论者”社群没有任何经济联系，却与奥特曼、马斯克、纳德拉、盖茨、扎克伯格、皮查伊、杰克·克拉克等科技巨头高管一起在国会作证。他们都出席了参议员查克·舒默的首届人工智能洞察论坛，这是当年最热门、最重要的一系列政策会议之一，旨在推动人工智能立法。当她的同伴们滔滔不绝地讲述人工智能的前景和危险，并适时地提到击败中国，让与会参议员们挺直腰板时，最让拉吉震惊的是，听众中似乎有这么多人相信这一切。

The whole sequence of events—Altman’s testimony, the white paper, the all-out policy influence campaign, Washington’s hyperreactivity to fears of China, and the hasty enshrining of compute thresholds into consequential policy documents within the US and abroad—was a stark illustration among other things of how much independent AI expertise had atrophied. The prior month, in September 2023, Raji had found herself the singular academic, with financial ties neither to the industry nor Doomer community, testifying to Congress next to Altman, Musk, Nadella, Gates, Zuckerberg, Pichai, and Jack Clark, among other tech executives. They were all present for the very first of Senator Chuck Schumer’s AI Insight Forums, among the hottest and most consequential series of policy convenings that year to set in motion AI legislation. As her fellow witnesses spouted spectacular, unbacked claims about the promises and perils of AI, peppered with well-timed references to beating China that straightened the backs of attending senators, what shocked Raji the most was how much many in the audience appeared to buy into everything.

她逐渐意识到，坐在她旁边的人和他们庞大的政策团队已经在华盛顿垄断了这一信息太久了，以至于现在许多政策制定者都将其视为福音。舒默的发言人后来在新闻发布会上指出，参议员正在亲自咨询随着他逐渐接近监管目标，他与奥特曼和其他 OpenAI 高管进行了交流。“对我来说，这是一个巨大的顿悟，”拉吉说。“哇，我们需要更多人去揭穿真相——看看人们在说什么，然后说，‘其实，现实比这更复杂。’”

It dawned on her that the people sitting next to her, and their massive policy teams, had monopolized the message in Washington for so long that many policymakers now viewed it as gospel. A Schumer spokesperson would later note in the press that the senator was personally consulting with Altman and other OpenAI executives as he moved closer to regulation. “That for me was a huge realization,” Raji says. “Wow, we need more people just debunking—just looking at what people are saying and being like, ‘Actually, reality is more complicated.’ ”

—

—

华盛顿只是奥特曼政策魅力攻势在美国阶段的高潮。同年3月，他在推特上宣布计划出国与网友见面。此后，他的行程演变成一场跨越多个城市、跨越多个大洲的奇幻之旅，几乎与每一位G20领导人合影。如今，他的行程有了新的名称：萨姆·奥特曼的世界之旅。

Washington was only the climax of the US leg of Altman’s policy charm offensive. In March of that year, after tweeting that he planned to travel abroad to meet with users, his trip had evolved into a multicity, multi-continent odyssey to sit for photo ops with seemingly every president in the G20. It now had new branding: Sam Altman’s World Tour.

OpenAI 的公关或政策团队并没有为这次世界巡回赛制定任何宏伟的战略。Altman 只是选定了最初的几个站点，并向他超过 150 万的 Twitter 粉丝们进行了宣传。在最初的几次亮相之后，人们的兴趣像滚雪球一样越滚越大，失去了控制，公关和政策团队也纷纷加入进来。每增加一个站点，各团队就忙着安排后勤工作，准备应对由于准备不足而必然出现的困难。

There was no grand strategy from OpenAI’s communications or policy teams behind the World Tour. Altman had just selected his initial stops and blasted them off to his more than 1.5 million Twitter followers. After the first few appearances, interest had snowballed out of control, and the comms and policy teams were roped in. With each new leg, the teams scrambled to arrange the logistics, bracing for the difficulties guaranteed to arise from the lack of preparation.

这体现了一种始终存在的动态：Altman 走自己的路。有时，这条路与公司一致；有时则不然。在 GPT-4 发布期间，OpenAI 精心策划了所有公告和宣传，将该项目展现为全公司共同努力的成果。该模式已涉及一百多名员工。该公司公告的作者只是“OpenAI”。随后，奥特曼在推特上将功劳归于一个人：雅库布·帕乔基。帕乔基确实发挥了重要作用，但他只是该项目十八位负责人之一。他的贡献真的只是个例吗？一些员工心存疑虑。奥特曼随后进一步倾身，请帕乔基在他华盛顿参议院听证会期间坐在自己身后。

It was a manifestation of a dynamic that had always been present: Altman going his own way. Sometimes that way lined up with the company; sometimes it did not. During the release of GPT-4, OpenAI had carefully crafted all of its announcements and publicity to present the project as the company-wide effort that it was. The model had involved over a hundred employees. The author of the company’s announcement was simply “OpenAI.” Altman had then tweeted credit to a single person: Jakub Pachocki. Pachocki had indeed played an important role, but he had been one of eighteen leads on the project. Was his contribution really singular? Some employees wondered. Altman had then leaned in further, tapping Pachocki to sit behind him during his Senate hearing in Washington.

这种动态还体现在其他方面：公司里有正式的高管，但并不总是清楚奥特曼是否听从他们的意见，也不清楚官方的流程和决定，还是他的关系和突发奇想，是否在指导公司战略。

The dynamic also showed up in other ways: There were official executives at the company, but it wasn’t always clear that they were the ones whom Altman was listening to, nor whether official processes and decisions or his relationships and whims were the ones guiding company strategy.

随着OpenAI迅速专业化，并获得更多曝光和审查，高层的这种不一致变得越来越严重。公司不再仅仅只有应用和研究部门。现在，公司有了几个面向公众的部门：除了沟通团队之外，还有一个法律团队负责撰写法律意见，并处理越来越多的诉讼。政策团队的人员也遍布各大洲。OpenAI越来越需要用统一的叙事和声音与其支持者沟通，并且需要确定自己的立场来清晰地表达这些立场。但在很多情况下，缺乏战略清晰度导致公众信息传递混乱。

As OpenAI was rapidly professionalizing and gaining more exposure and scrutiny, this incoherence at the top was becoming more consequential. The company was no longer just the Applied and Research divisions. Now there were several public-facing departments: In addition to the communications team, a legal team was writing legal opinions and dealing with a growing number of lawsuits. The policy team was stretching out across continents. Increasingly, OpenAI needed to communicate with one narrative and voice to its constituents, and it needed to determine its positions to articulate them. But on numerous occasions, the lack of strategic clarity was leading to confused public messaging.

2023 年底，《纽约时报》将起诉 OpenAI 和微软侵犯其数百万篇文章的训练版权。OpenAI 于 1 月初由法律团队撰写的回应进行了异常激烈的反击，指责《纽约时报》 “故意操纵我们的模型”来为其论点提供证据。同一周，OpenAI 的政策团队向英国上议院通讯和数字特别委员会提交了一份意见书，称如果没有版权材料，OpenAI 就“不可能”训练其尖端模型。在媒体将注意力集中在“不可能”一词上后，OpenAI 匆忙放弃了这一说法。

At the end of 2023, The New York Times would sue OpenAI and Microsoft for copyright infringement for training on millions of its articles. OpenAI’s response in early January, written by the legal team, delivered an unusually feisty hit back, accusing the Times of “intentionally manipulating our models” to generate evidence for its argument. That same week, OpenAI’s policy team delivered a submission to the UK House of Lords communications and digital select committee, saying that it would be “impossible” for OpenAI to train its cutting-edge models without copyrighted materials. After the media zeroed in on the word impossible, OpenAI hastily walked away from the language.

“总是有很多混乱，”一位面向公众的部门的员工说道。这位员工补充道，虽然这在一定程度上反映了初创公司典型的成长烦恼，但OpenAI的知名度和影响力已经远远超过了公司相对早期的阶段。“我不知道高管层是否有战略优先权。我真心觉得大家只是自己做决定。然后突然间，它看起来像是一个战略决策，但实际上只是个意外。有时候与其说是计划，不如说是一片混乱。”

“There’s just so much confusion all the time,” says an employee in a public-facing department. While some of that reflects the typical growing pains of startups, OpenAI’s profile and reach have well outpaced the relatively early stage of the company, the employee adds. “I don’t know if there is a strategic priority in the C suite. I honestly think people just make their own decisions. And then suddenly it starts to look like a strategic decision but it’s actually just an accident. Sometimes there isn’t a plan as much as there is just chaos.”

—

—

奥特曼四处奔波，飞往欧洲、拉丁美洲、中东、亚洲和非洲，让精心挑选的学生、科技投资者和粉丝群体眼花缭乱（只有少数几次冒犯了他们），但缺乏战略清晰度却加剧了 OpenAI 内部由来已久的分歧，并加速了公司走向比以往任何时候都更加极端的进程。

As Altman zipped around, flying to Europe, Latin America, the Middle East, Asia, and Africa, dazzling—and only on a few occasions offending—carefully curated audiences of students, tech investors, and fans, the lack of strategic clarity was inflaming OpenAI’s age-old rift lines and accelerating the company toward more opposite extremes than ever before.

一方面，应用部门依然保持领先，与数量空前的竞争对手竞相以前所未有的速度部署 OpenAI 技术。如今，其他规模不断扩大的部门以及众多研发人员也为应用部门提供了支持，他们对 OpenAI 模型的炒作和预期急剧上升，并坚信推进和发布 OpenAI 模型是实现公司使命的最佳途径，这让他们倍感振奋。

On one side, the Applied division was still leading the charge, racing against an unprecedented number of competitors to deploy OpenAI’s technologies faster than ever. It was now also bolstered by the other ballooning divisions as well as many people in Research, invigorated by their belief from the dramatic increase in hype and expectation that advancing and releasing OpenAI’s models was the best way to achieve the company’s mission.

另一方面，遍布研究部门的安全派系，其中许多人仍然集中在迈尔斯·布伦戴奇的政策研究团队和简·莱克的协调团队中，如今已成为一个规模小得多的少数派。他们通过比以往任何时候都更大声地警告那些他们认为可能即将发生的危险能力和生存风险，来弥补其相对规模上的劣势。随着OpenAI模型的不断进步，一些之前不认同安全派系的研究部门内部人士也加入了他们的行列，因为加速发展的能力使他们相信人工智能可以达到某种智能程度，使其能够颠覆人类的控制并变得叛逆。同样，炒作和期望的急剧上升意味着OpenAI有道义上的责任采取最大程度的谨慎行动，以完成其使命。

On the other side, the Safety clan, spread out across Research, many still concentrated within Miles Brundage’s policy research team and Jan Leike’s alignment team, were now a far smaller minority. They were compensating for their relative size disadvantage by sounding the alarm louder than ever on the dangerous capabilities and existential risks that they believed could become imminently possible. As OpenAI’s models continued to advance, some within Research who didn’t previously identify with the Safety clan were also joining its ranks as the accelerating capabilities converted them to the belief that AI could reach a point of intelligence that would allow it to subvert human control and go rogue. The same dramatic increase in hype and expectation on this side meant OpenAI had a moral imperative to act with maximum caution, in order to fulfill its mission.

这是 OpenAI 墙内婴儿潮一代和末日一代的化身。

It was the Boomers and Doomers incarnate—within OpenAI’s walls.

这种分歧一直蔓延到领导层。在 DALL-E 和 ChatGPT 之后，大多数高管和高级经理越来越认同模型是有益的工具，可以通过“迭代部署”的方式投入使用。“迭代部署”是 OpenAI 在两次发布之间创造的，用来描述其新方法。与 GPT-2 的分阶段发布或 GPT-3 的受控 API 发布不同，迭代部署意味着全力以赴——尽早并经常地将模型交到用户手中。与过去的所有部署策略一样，OpenAI 也对为什么迭代部署是最安全的方法提出了新的论据。奥特曼和其他高管认为，迭代部署可以让个人和机构有时间进行调整，同时让公司能够在真人身上测试模型，收集真实反馈，并改进产品。“秘密打造一个超级强大的人工智能系统，然后把它投放到世界各地，我认为不会有好结果，”奥特曼在参议院作证时说道。

The split reached all the way to leadership. After DALL-E and ChatGPT, most executives and senior managers had grown increasingly comfortable with models as beneficial tools to be put into the world through “iterative deployment,” a phrase that OpenAI had coined between releases to describe its new approach. Unlike the staged release of GPT-2, or the controlled API release of GPT-3, iterative deployment was about going all in—putting models in the hands of users early and often. And as with all of its deployment strategies in the past, OpenAI had a new argument for why this one was the safest approach possible. Iterative deployment, Altman and other executives argued, would give people and institutions time to adjust while allowing it to test its models on real people, collect real feedback, and improve its products. “Going off to build a superpowerful AI system in secret and then dropping it on the world all at once I think would not go well,” Altman had said during his Senate testimony.

但如果说 OpenAI 中有一位领导者没有与时俱进，那就是 Sutskever。随着 OpenAI 模型的进步及其部署影响的加速，他认为公司需要提高而不是降低对其可能造成灾难性后果的防范。在 GPT-4 之后，Sutskever 之前大部分时间都致力于提升模型能力，但现在他做出了艰难的转变，专注于人工智能安全。他开始将自己的时间分成两半。在周围人看来，他有时似乎在与自己作斗争。他既是“婴儿潮一代”（Boomer），又是“末日一代”（Doomer）：比以往任何时候都更加兴奋和恐惧 AGI 的到来，以及它迅速超越人类成为超级智能。

But if there was one leader at OpenAI not moving in lockstep, it was Sutskever. As OpenAI’s models advanced and the impact of their deployments accelerated, he believed the company needed to raise, not lower, its guard against their potential to produce devastating consequences. After GPT-4, Sutskever, who had previously dedicated most of his time to advancing model capabilities, had made a hard pivot toward focusing on AI safety. He began to split his time half and half. To people around him, he seemed at times to be at war with himself. He was both Boomer and Doomer: more excited and afraid than ever before of AGI arriving and rapidly surpassing humans to become superintelligence.

苏茨克弗现在的言辞越来越带有救世主的意味，就连他的老朋友也感到困惑不解，其他员工也感到担忧。在一次与一群新研究人员的会议上，苏茨克弗阐述了他为AGI做准备的计划。

Sutskever now spoke in increasingly messianic overtones, leaving even his longtime friends scratching their heads and other employees apprehensive. During one meeting with a new group of researchers, Sutskever laid out his plans for how to prepare for AGI.

“一旦我们都进入掩体——”他开始说道。

“Once we all get into the bunker—” he began.

“对不起，”一位研究员打断道，“掩体？”

“I’m sorry,” a researcher interrupted, “the bunker?”

“我们肯定会在发布通用人工智能之前建一个地堡，”萨茨克弗实事求是地回答道。如此强大的技术肯定会成为全球各国政府热切追求的目标。它可能会加剧地缘政治紧张局势；研究这项技术的核心科学家需要受到保护。“当然，”他补充道，“你想不想进地堡完全是你自己的选择。”

“We’re definitely going to build a bunker before we release AGI,” Sutskever replied matter-of-factly. Such a powerful technology would surely become an object of intense desire for governments globally. It could escalate geopolitical tensions; the core scientists working on the technology would need to be protected. “Of course,” he added, “it’s going to be optional whether you want to get into the bunker.”

这位研究人员一方面会继续高度重视苏茨克维尔，另一方面又会与他保持距离。“有一群人——伊利亚就是其中之一——相信构建通用人工智能会带来狂喜。真的，狂喜。”他说。

The researcher would in equal parts continue to hold Sutskever in high regard and keep himself at arm’s length. “There is a group of people—Ilya being one of them—who believe that building AGI will bring about a rapture. Literally, a rapture,” he says.

随着苏茨克弗继续将时间分配在对齐上，一个新的想法开始在他和奥特曼之间酝酿：一个团队专注于开发超级智能的新型对齐方法，因为他们预计，一旦系统在他们看来能够超越人类，像强化学习这样的基于人类反馈的方法将不再适用。奥特曼称之为“对齐曼哈顿计划”。起初，两人讨论将其分拆为一个独立的非营利组织，初始资金为 10 亿美元。由于 Sutskever 不愿离开 OpenAI，以及模型访问问题，他们决定将该项目保留在公司内部。OpenAI 随后在一篇博客文章中宣布成立一个新团队来监督该项目，并将其更名为 Superalignment。该帖子还宣布了一项引人瞩目的承诺，OpenAI 将把迄今为止获得的 20% 的计算能力奉献给该团队。Sutskever 和 Leike 将共同领导这项新计划。

As Sutskever continued splitting his time on alignment, a new idea began to percolate between him and Altman: a team laser focused on developing new alignment methods for superintelligence, in anticipation of methods like reinforcement learning from human feedback no longer being sufficient once systems could, in their view, outsmart humans. Altman called it the Alignment Manhattan Project. At first, the two discussed spinning it out as a different organization: its own independent nonprofit with a starting endowment of $1 billion. In part because Sutskever didn’t want to leave OpenAI and in part due to model access issues, they decided to keep the project within the company. OpenAI subsequently announced the formation of a new team to oversee the effort in a blog post along with its new name, Superalignment. The post also announced a flashy commitment to dedicate 20 percent of the computing power OpenAI had secured to date to the team. Sutskever and Leike would colead the new effort.

在另一次会议上，萨茨克弗走到员工面前，介绍新团队及其目标。他抓起麦克风，开始敲打。咚！咚！咚。

At another meeting, Sutskever stepped up in front of employees to introduce the new team and its goals. He grabbed the microphone and began to thump it. Boom. Boom. Boom.

“对齐就像一团燃烧的烈火，”他说，“超级对齐就像是熊熊烈火。”

“Alignment is a burning fire,” he said. “Superalignment is a blazing inferno.”

不久之后，随着公司规模扩大，梅奥办公楼（疫情后搬进的那间绿植环绕、喷泉点缀的办公室）不再适合办公，高管们将大部分研究部门迁回了原来的先锋大厦。此举在很大程度上将公司的两大部门——应用产品部门和安全部门——分割成了两个独立的部门。

Not long thereafter, with the company outgrowing Mayo, the plant-filled, fountain-adorned office it had moved into after the pandemic, executives shifted most of the Research division back to the old Pioneer Building. The move largely divided the two halves of the company—Applied and Safety—into their own worlds.

—

—

2023 年 7 月，OpenAI 在公开超级对齐团队的消息后不久，就租下了旧金山市中心 Metreon 的一间影院，供员工观看电影《奥本海默》，该电影讲述了物理学家 J. Robert Oppenheimer 领导美国曼哈顿计划制造世界上第一枚核武器的故事。

In July 2023, shortly after OpenAI made news of the Superalignment team public, it rented out a theater at the Metreon in downtown San Francisco for employees to see the movie Oppenheimer, the story of physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer as he led America’s Manhattan Project to create the world’s first nuclear weapon.

“我原本希望奥本海默的电影能激励一代年轻人成为物理学家，但它真的没能达到这个目标，”奥特曼在推特上写道。“我们赶紧拍这部电影吧！（我觉得社交网络已经为初创公司创始人做到了这一点。）”

“i was hoping that the oppenheimer movie would inspire a generation of kids to be physicists but it really missed the mark on that,” Altman tweeted. “let’s get that movie made! (i think the social network managed to do this for startup founders.)”

近八年来，奥特曼在给马斯克的第一封电子邮件中将 OpenAI 与曼哈顿计划进行了类比，这在公司内部一直是一个不变的主题，甚至在新员工入职培训中也会用到。奥特曼很喜欢它。他和奥本海默的生日是同一天，他会向记者们指出这一点。他也喜欢解释炸弹制造者坚信“技术之所以出现，是因为它有可能。”他似乎从未说过，奥本海默的后半生一直被悔恨所困扰，并致力于阻止自己发明的传播。

For nearly eight years, the analogy that Altman had made in his very first emails to Musk between OpenAI and the Manhattan Project had been a persistent motif within the company, used even during new-hire orientations. Altman was fond of it. He shared a birthday with Oppenheimer, which he’d point out to reporters. He also liked to paraphrase the bomb maker’s belief that “technology happens because it’s possible.” He never seemed to add that Oppenheimer spent the second half of his life plagued by regret and campaigning against the spread of his own creation.

不同的员工对这个比喻赋予了不同的意义。大多数人认为曼哈顿计划是一项英雄壮举；它代表着能够在危险的对手面前，凭借大量的人才和资源，完成一项拯救世界、改变历史的技术突破。在安全团队中，它强调了OpenAI肩负的沉重负担，即引领一项可能危及人类生存的技术。

Different employees ascribed different significance to the analogy. Most saw the Manhattan Project as a heroic feat; it represented the ability to pull off a world-saving, history-changing technological breakthrough before dangerous adversaries with a significant concentration of talent and resources. Among the Safety clan, it emphasized the gravity of OpenAI’s burden to usher in a technology that risked the existential demise of humanity.

对于奥特曼来说，这代表着一次公关教训。”“核能向世界展现的形象是日本上空的蘑菇云，令人永生难忘，”多年前，他在一次活动中曾这样说道。“我思考过很多次，为什么世界会背弃科学，我愿意相信的众多答案之一就是那幅形象，以及我们认识到，也许某些技术过于强大，人类无法拥有。人们更容易被形象所说服，而不是被事实所左右。”

To Altman, it represented a PR lesson. “The way the world was introduced to nuclear power is an image that no one will ever forget, of a mushroom cloud over Japan,” he had once said, years earlier at an event. “I’ve thought a lot about why the world turned against science, and one answer of many that I am willing to believe is that image, and that we learned that maybe some technology is too powerful for people to have. People are more convinced by imagery than facts.”

那些处于人工智能安全谱系极端、p(doom) 水平最高的人，对 Altman 和公司其他成员看待这段历史时那种看似简单的乐观态度越来越感到不安。OpenAI 曾一度组织放映《阿波罗 11 号》，这是一部关于美国阿波罗计划的纪录片，旨在将人类首次送上月球，而阿波罗计划也是硅谷另一个喜欢用其类比的地方。“如果能直接说‘阿波罗计划’，那干嘛还要谈论曼哈顿计划？为什么要带上那种包袱呢？”一位极端的末日论者说道。

Those at the extreme end of the AI safety spectrum with the highest levels of p(doom) grew increasingly unsettled by the seeming uncomplicated optimism with which Altman and the rest of the company viewed this history. OpenAI had at one point also organized a screening of Apollo 11, a documentary about the US Apollo program to launch the first man to the moon, which was one of Silicon Valley’s other favorite analogies. “Why would you ever talk about the Manhattan Project if you could just say ‘Apollo program’? Why bring along that baggage?” an extreme Doomer says.

奥本海默的影片中有一个场景让他印象深刻：在三位一体核试验（人类历史上第一颗原子弹爆炸）的前一刻，由希里安·墨菲饰演的奥本海默计算出，这颗原子弹炸毁世界的可能性“接近于零”。

One scene from Oppenheimer stuck with him in particular: the moment before the Trinity test, the first ever detonation of an atomic bomb, when Oppenheimer, played by Cillian Murphy, calculates that the chances of it blowing up the world are “near zero.”

“接近于零？”马特·达蒙饰演的莱斯利·R·格罗夫斯少将难以置信地回答道。

“Near zero?” responds Major General Leslie R. Groves, played by Matt Damon, incredulously.

奥本海默问道：“你仅从理论中想得到什么？”

“What do you want from theory alone?” Oppenheimer says.

格罗夫斯说：“零就好了。”

“Zero would be nice,” Groves says.

“这和我们现在的情况很像，”极端的末日论者说道。“我们还无法计算出这些人工智能的任何信息。”

“That’s analogous to the situation we’re in,” the extreme Doomer says. “No way can we calculate anything about these AIs yet.”

—

—

随着 OpenAI 继续推进其研究，曼哈顿计划的类比对某些人来说开始有了新的含义。

As OpenAI continued to push on its research, the Manhattan Project analogy for some began to take on a new meaning.

随着数据和计算资源的枯竭，大型语言模型的进展速度逐渐放缓，研究部门将重心转向开发人工智能代理。这个想法在整个领域越来越受到关注，它重新回到了“纯语言”假设和“基础”假设之间的争论。纯语言已经走到了尽头，语言与视觉的结合也是如此。对人工智能社区的许多成员来说，下一阶段的发展很可能需要来自能够在现实世界中采取行动并从其环境中收集反馈的代理。在OpenAI内部，这种能力也被视为一种获得竞争优势的方式。一个可以与你聊天的人工智能助手固然不错，但一个能够自动执行复杂任务（例如发送电子邮件或编写网站代码）的人工智能助手则更胜一筹。这不仅具有高度的商业意义，还能加速公司自身的发展。

With the rate of advancement in large language models slowing with the exhaustion of data and compute, the Research division had pivoted more heavily toward developing AI agents. The idea, gaining traction across the field, was a return to the debate between the “pure language” and “grounding” hypotheses. Pure language was reaching the end of its rope, as was combining language and vision. To many in the AI community, it seemed like the next stage of advancement would likely need to come from agents that could take actions in the real world and collect feedback from its environment. Within OpenAI, such a capability was also seen as a way to gain a competitive advantage. An AI assistant that could chat with you was nice, but one that could automate complex tasks, such as sending emails or coding websites, was even better. Not only was this highly commercially relevant, it could also accelerate the company’s own progress.

研究部门最雄心勃勃的成果是“AI 科学家”，旨在构建一个能够自主进行科学研究的智能体。由于新“知识”有限，或者说从互联网或教科书中获取的数据有限，该项目的研究人员对自主“科学家”寄予厚望，希望它能够通过实验生成自己的知识。该团队由之前开发 Codex 的代码生成团队与另一个团队合并而成，后者一直试图通过使用大量数学问题及其答案作为结构化数据集来逐步训练模型，以破解推理难题。编程和求解数学问题这两种能力似乎都是开展实验和分析数据的良好基石。

The most ambitious of these efforts in the Research division was AI Scientist, an attempt to build an agent for autonomously performing scientific research. With limited new “knowledge,” or data to scrape from the internet or textbooks, researchers on the project had high hopes that an autonomous “scientist” would be able to generate its own knowledge by running experiments. The team had formed from a merger of the previous code-generation team working on Codex with another team that had been trying to crack the reasoning challenge by using large repositories of math problems and their solutions as a structured dataset to teach its model step-by-step logic. Both capabilities—coding and solving math problems—seemed like good building blocks for conducting experiments and analyzing data.

领导该项目的是 Jakub Pachocki 和 Szymon Sidor，他们不仅致力于创造一名自主的科学家，而且具体来说，正如奥特曼所希望的那样，创造一名自主的人工智能研究员——一名能够帮助 OpenAI 增强其人工智能进步的研究员。

Leading the project were Jakub Pachocki and Szymon Sidor, who were focused on creating not only an autonomous scientist but, specifically, as Altman desired, an autonomous AI researcher—one that would help OpenAI supercharge its AI advancements.

这个项目让AGI的信徒们既兴奋又紧张：如果AI Scientist成功了，AGI的到来肯定会更快。这缩短了人类走向乌托邦或灭亡的时间线。像Sutskever一样，一些研究人员开始在闲聊中提到“地堡”，甚至想象着类似洛斯阿拉莫斯的场景：在美国沙漠的某个偏远地区，一支由AI研究人员组成的精英团队将在安全设施中生活和工作，以免受外界威胁。

The project made AGI believers both extremely excited and extremely nervous: If AI Scientist succeeded, AGI would surely arrive faster. This shortened the timeline either to utopia or to humanity’s obliteration. Like Sutskever, some researchers began to reference “a bunker” in casual conversations, even imagining a setup similar to Los Alamos: Somewhere out in a remote patch of American desert, an elite team of AI researchers would live and work in secure facilities to protect them from outside threats.

2023年，他们认为这些威胁现在包括定向攻击和流氓AGI本身。安全团队在Slack上发布了针对OpenAI的威胁模型草案，与高管们争论该如何加强组织安全性的时代相比，该模型已经成熟了很多。该草案包含三类威胁：外国政府行为者、竞争对手和受意识形态驱动的人。

In 2023, they believed those threats now included targeted attacks and rogue AGI itself. On Slack, the security team posted a draft of its threat model for OpenAI, significantly matured from the days when executives had debated how much to heighten the security of the organization. The draft included three categories of threats: foreign state actors, competitors, and ideologically motivated people.

在第三类中，该草稿链接到 Eliezer Yudkowsky 的一篇文章。Yudkowsky 是一位极端的末日论者，也是人工智能安全社区的领袖，他创造并推广了“友好人工智能”一词，用来指代协调一致的系统，并创作了一部深受喜爱的同人小说《哈利波特与理性之道》。这部连载小说共 122 章，超过 66 万字，将哈利重新塑造成一个训练有素的理性主义者，在魔法世界中生活。对许多人来说，这部小说是通往有效利他主义的大门，进而通往更广泛的末日论意识形态。Yudkowksy 还共同创办了博客LessWrong，这是一个人工智能安全研究人员培育社区和传播人工智能安全理念的中心枢纽。在他的 p(doom) 飙升至 95% 之际，他日益危言耸听地倡导全面暂停人工智能开发。2023年3月，他为《时代》杂志撰写了一篇文章，讲述了他看着女儿掉第一颗牙的悲伤，以及她是否还有机会长大的担忧。他提出了一项计划，通过关闭所有大型GPU集群、追踪……的销量来强制停止人工智能的发展。GPU，并在必要时对“流氓数据中心”进行空袭。OpenAI 的威胁模型草案链接到这篇文章，作为鼓吹暴力的意识形态分子的一个例子。

In the third category, the draft linked to an article by Eliezer Yudkowsky, an extreme Doomer and leader in the AI safety community who had coined and popularized the phrase friendly AI to refer to well-aligned systems and wrote a beloved work of fan fiction called “Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality.” The serial novel, which spans 122 chapters and over 660,000 words, reimagines Harry engaging in the wizarding world as a well-trained rationalist. It had served for many as a gateway into effective altruism and, in turn, to broader Doomer ideology. Yudkowksy had also cofounded the blog LessWrong, a central hub for AI safety researchers to foster community and propagate AI safety ideas, where he’d advocated with increasing alarmism to put a full pause on AI development as his p(doom) shot up to 95 percent. In March 2023, he’d written an article for Time magazine where he discussed the grief of watching his daughter lose her first tooth and wondering if she would have a chance to grow up. He proposed a plan to enforce the halting of AI advancement by shutting down all large GPU clusters, tracking sales of GPUs, and, if necessary, targeting “a rogue data center” with air strikes. OpenAI’s threat model draft linked to this piece as an example of an ideologue advocating for violence.

OpenAI 的一小群员工支持 Yudkowsky 较为温和的观点，但他们发现，草案只提到了他，却没有提及不友好的人工智能本身，这让他们非常沮丧。在收到反馈后，安全团队增加了第四个威胁类别：失调的通用人工智能系统。

A small faction of OpenAI employees who were fans of Yudkowsky’s less violent opinions found the fact that the draft singled him out but didn’t mention unfriendly AI itself deeply frustrating. After getting feedback, the security team added a fourth threat category: misaligned AGI systems.

—

—

随着 OpenAI 的崛起，董事会成员不断流失，却没有新成员填补。自 2023 年初以来，董事会已接连失去三名独立董事，部分原因是 ChatGPT 引发了整个行业对生成式 AI 技术构建和商业化的激烈竞争。

As OpenAI skyrocketed to new prominence, the board was shedding members without replacing them. Since the start of 2023, it had lost three independent directors in rapid succession, in part due to the feverish race that ChatGPT had sparked to build and commercialize generative AI technologies across the industry.

由于利益冲突，雷德·霍夫曼（Reid Hoffman）在董事会任职五年后，于今年二月率先卸任。此前一年，他与现已离职的DeepMind联合创始人穆斯塔法·苏莱曼（Mustafa Suleyman）共同创立了初创公司Inflection，而这家公司正迅速发展成为OpenAI的直接竞争对手。

Reid Hoffman had been the first to step down in February after five years on the board, due to conflicts of interest. The previous year, he had cofounded a startup, Inflection, with the now-departed DeepMind cofounder Mustafa Suleyman, which was fast evolving into a direct OpenAI competitor.

一个月后，马斯克信任的副手兼 Neuralink 董事希冯·齐利斯 (Shivon Zilis) 接替霍夫曼离职。在马斯克脱离 OpenAI 后，齐利斯继续代表马斯克监督 OpenAI，并于 2020 年正式加入董事会。一些领导层长期以来一直担心齐利斯会向马斯克提供敏感的公司信息，但她承诺将对 OpenAI 保密，而不是忠于被解雇的前联席主席。2022年7月，她与马斯克育有一双双胞胎的消息爆出后，这一职位变得备受质疑。尽管如此，奥特曼仍试图让她留在董事会，原因其他董事会成员不得而知。2022年10月，奥特曼曾一度向她寻求建议，如何应对马斯克对OpenAI估值不断攀升（据报道当时已接近200亿美元）的明显不满。这是一个诱饵和转换，”马斯克在注意到他的实质性为 OpenAI 的初始资金做出贡献。2023 年 3 月，随着马斯克成立新的人工智能公司 xAI，成为 OpenAI 的另一个直接竞争对手，Zilis 继续担任董事会成员的资格最终变得难以维持。

A month later, Hoffman was followed by Shivon Zilis, Musk’s trusted deputy and Neuralink director, who, after Musk disaffiliated, had continued to oversee OpenAI on his behalf and officially joined the board in 2020. Some in leadership had long worried that Zilis would feed sensitive company information to Musk, but she had pledged to uphold her confidentiality to OpenAI over her loyalty to its spurned former cochairman. That position became highly questionable once news broke in July 2022 that she had had twins with Musk without disclosing it to her fellow directors. Still, Altman had sought to keep her on the board for reasons that eluded the other board members, at one point seeking her advice in October 2022 on how to handle Musk’s apparent irritation over OpenAI’s escalating valuation, by then reportedly nearing $20 billion. “This is a bait and switch,” Musk had texted Altman after noting his substantial contributions to OpenAI’s initial funding. In March 2023, Zilis’s continued board role finally turned untenable as Musk incorporated a new AI venture, xAI, to be another direct competitor to OpenAI.

第三位离职的是威尔·赫德，他曾是德克萨斯州共和党众议员，也是前中央情报局官员，于2021年加入董事会。在宣布赫德的任命时，奥特曼曾告诉员工，找到一个能够平衡硅谷自由主义倾向的人至关重要。随后，他组织了一场会议，让任何有保留意见的人都可以向赫德提问。员工们毫不犹豫地向赫德提问，询问他对各种问题的看法，包括对唐纳德·特朗普的看法。2023年6月，赫德离开OpenAI，全身心投入美国总统竞选。他将于10月退出竞选。

Third to depart was Will Hurd, a former Republican Texas representative and former CIA officer, who had joined the board in 2021. During the announcement of Hurd’s appointment, Altman had told employees that it was important to have someone that balanced out the liberal bias of Silicon Valley. He then organized a meeting for anyone who had reservations to ask Hurd any questions. Employees didn’t hold back, grilling Hurd about his views on different issues, including Donald Trump. In June 2023, Hurd parted ways with OpenAI to focus full time on his US presidential campaign. He would withdraw from the race by October.

除了奥特曼、布罗克曼和萨茨克弗之外，只剩下三名独立董事会成员：Quora 联合创始人兼首席执行官亚当·德安杰洛 (Adam D'Angelo)、机器人专家塔莎·麦考利 (Tasha McCauley) 和 CSET 研究员海伦·托纳 (Helen Toner)。

Alongside Altman, Brockman, and Sutskever, only three independent board members remained: Quora cofounder and CEO Adam D’Angelo, roboticist Tasha McCauley, and CSET researcher Helen Toner.

在这三人中，D'Angelo 是第一个加入董事会的。D'Angelo 是扎克伯格在菲利普斯埃克塞特寄宿学校的高中同学，在创办 Quora 之前曾担任 Facebook 的首席技术官两年。2014 年，Quora 成为 Altman 担任总裁期间第一批加入 YC 的公司；2017 年，也就是 D'Angelo 出任董事会成员的前一年，Altman 追加了 YC 对 Quora 的投资，共同领投了一轮 8500 万美元的融资。在公告中，奥特曼称赞德安吉洛是“硅谷最聪明的CEO”之一。“他非常注重长远发展，这在如今的科技公司中已经非常罕见了。”奥特曼说道。

Among the trio, D’Angelo had joined the board first. D’Angelo, a high school classmate of Zuckerberg’s at the boarding school Phillips Exeter, had served for two years as the CTO of Facebook before starting Quora. In 2014, Quora had joined YC in the first batch under Altman’s presidency; in 2017, a year before D’Angelo’s board appointment, Altman had topped up YC’s investment into Quora, coleading an $85 million round of funding. In the announcement, Altman praised D’Angelo as one of “the smartest CEOs in Silicon Valley.” “And he has a very long-term focus, which has become a rare commodity in tech companies these days,” Altman said.

麦考利于2018年晚些时候加入董事会。她是一位企业家，曾与他人共同创立了一家远程呈现机器人初创公司，并运营着一家3D城市模拟公司。她通过导师艾伦·凯与奥特曼建立了联系，也认识霍尔顿·卡诺夫斯基。麦考利在人工智能安全领域享有盛誉，曾担任人工智能安全研究非营利组织“人工智能治理中心”的董事会成员，并曾一度担任英国有效风险投资基金会（Effective Ventures Foundation）的董事会成员，该基金会负责监管热门的EA播客《80,000 Hours》。卡诺夫斯基当时曾担任 OpenAI 董事会成员的他提名了她，以便在 OpenAI 准备过渡到利润上限结构时寻找更多独立董事。

McCauley had joined the board later in 2018. An entrepreneur who had cofounded a telepresence robotics startup and was running a 3D urban simulation company, she had connected with Altman through her mentor, Alan Kay, and also knew Holden Karnofsky. McCauley was well-respected in the AI safety community and would serve on the board of the AI safety research nonprofit Centre for the Governance of AI and for a time on the board of the Effective Ventures Foundation, a UK-based organization that oversees the popular EA podcast 80,000 Hours. Karnofsky, who had been on the OpenAI board at the time, nominated her in his effort to find more independent directors as OpenAI prepared to transition into a capped-profit structure.

托纳是董事会的最后一位成员，于2021年年中被卡诺夫斯基提名加入。这一次，随着他三年任期的结束和Anthropic的成立，他推荐了接替自己的候选人。在成为中国和新兴技术专家之前，托纳曾与卡诺夫斯基在GiveWell和Open Philanthropy共事。她通过EA运动接触到人工智能安全问题，但随着时间的推移，她逐渐淡出了后者。在 FTX 崩盘之前，她在 EA 论坛上发表了一篇最受欢迎的帖子，指出这场运动正变得越来越教条主义和社会孤立，并指出她“倾向于对 EA 感到幻灭”。但她在 EA 圈子里仍然享有很高的声誉，并致力于更广泛的人工智能安全社区，与麦考利一起担任人工智能治理中心的董事会成员。

Toner had been the last addition to the board in mid-2021, also via a nomination from Karnofsky. This time he was recommending candidates to replace himself as his three-year term came to a close and with the formation of Anthropic. Before establishing herself as an expert on China and emerging technologies, Toner had worked with Karnofsky at GiveWell and Open Philanthropy. She had come to AI safety issues through the EA movement but had slowly pulled back from the latter over time. In her most popular EA Forum post before the FTX crash, she had observed that the movement was growing increasingly dogmatic and socially insular, and noted that she was “leaning into EA disillusionment.” She continued to be highly regarded in its circles and to dedicate herself to the broader AI safety community, serving with McCauley on the board of the Centre for the Governance of AI.

—

—

到2023年夏末，董事会在任命新独立董事一事上陷入了长达数月的僵局。为了在GPT-4演示以及ChatGPT发布后加强监督，McCauley进行了大约一年的调研，包括采访公司外部的员工和利益相关者，以阐明改组后的董事会和更专业化的监督机制应该是什么样子。

By the late summer of 2023, the board had been in a monthslong deadlock over whom to appoint as new independent directors. As part of their effort to increase oversight after the GPT-4 demo, and even more after the launch of ChatGPT, McCauley had engaged in a roughly yearlong process, including interviewing employees and stakeholders outside the company, to articulate what a revamped board and more professionalized oversight mechanisms should look like.

在此过程中，包括 Altman 在内的董事会一致认为，鉴于公司能力的提升，下一任独立董事需要在人工智能安全方面拥有深厚的背景。随后，他们花了数月时间整理候选人名单，并面试了其中五人，其中包括 Dan Hendrycks，他是 Doomer 社区的核心人物，负责管理位于伯克利的人工智能安全中心，并担任马斯克 xAI 的唯一顾问。但当独立董事会成员试图从五人中选出一人时，Brockman 和 Sutskever 分别向经过审查的候选人提出了各种问题。Altman 一如既往地保持着谨慎，并未公开反对任何候选人。但也没有推动任何候选人取得进展。他还多次推荐新的候选人，这些候选人都有一个共同点：他们都深植于他的人脉网络，无论在经济上还是其他方面，都在他的势力范围内。

During the process, the board, including Altman, had all agreed that based on what they saw as the rising stakes of the company’s capabilities, the next independent director needed to have a deep background in AI safety. They’d subsequently spent months compiling a list of candidates and interviewing five of them, including Dan Hendrycks, a central figure in the Doomer community running the Berkeley-based Center for AI Safety and serving as the only adviser at Musk’s xAI. But as the independent board members sought to move forward to select one of the five, Brockman and Sutskever each raised various issues with the vetted candidates. Altman was demure as always, not outright disagreeing with any option but not moving any of them forward either. Several times, he also suggested new candidates, who shared the same characteristic: They were all embedded in his network and, financially or otherwise, within his sphere of influence.

在建立新的监督机制（包括提高董事会对公司安全保障实践的透明度的各种渠道）时，独立董事们也同样感到，他们并非奥特曼的优先事项。麦考利担任董事初期，奥特曼曾指定她为董事会的员工联络员和代言人；之后，她通过办公时间定期与员工会面。她还曾带丈夫、演员约瑟夫·高登-莱维特到公司外，在那里他专心聆听技术演示。但在疫情期间，这些会面逐渐减少。之后，麦考利继续举行一些定期会议，但办公时间从未恢复。

When it came to establishing the new oversight mechanisms, which included different channels for increasing the board’s visibility into the company’s safety and security practices, the independent directors were also left with a similar feeling that they weren’t a priority for Altman. Early in McCauley’s tenure as a director, Altman had designated her the board’s employee liaison and advocate; she subsequently met with employees regularly by holding office hours. Once she had also brought her husband, actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt, to a company off-site, where he’d listened intently to technical presentations. But during the pandemic, those meetings had petered out. Afterward, McCauley continued to keep some regular meetings, but the open office hours never restarted.

由于缺乏与员工沟通的系统性途径，公司动态只能通过独立董事们自身在更广泛的人工智能安全和科技社区的私人关系，慢慢地流传到他们的耳中。他们也依赖 Altman 本人作为重要信息的渠道。令他们日益担忧的是，Altman 的言论往往与他们听到的其他说法大相径庭。Altman 经常描绘一幅美好的前景，而董事们却越来越多地从自己的渠道收到各种问题的举报，包括公司在 ChatGPT 发布前准备不足以及发布后引发的重大动荡、围绕 GPT-4 发布持续存在的人工智能安全隐患，以及 OpenAI 在尚未解决诸多问题的情况下，以前所未有的速度推出新产品。

Without a systematic way of connecting with employees, information about the company’s happenings was instead filtering up to the independent directors through their own personal relationships from the broader AI safety and tech communities. They also relied on Altman himself as a conduit for keeping tabs on important information. What worried them with growing intensity was how much Altman’s rhetoric often differed from other accounts they were hearing. Where Altman regularly portrayed a rosy picture, the directors increasingly received reports from their own sources about various problems, including the company’s lack of preparation before and significant tumult after ChatGPT, the continued AI safety concerns surrounding GPT-4’s release, and the unprecedented pace with which OpenAI was sprinting to launch new products before it had resolved many of its issues.

有一件事尤其引人注目。2022 年末，董事会举行了一次现场会议——这是原本计划举行的年度会议的第一次——期间，Altman 强调了 OpenAI 与部署安全委员会为评估 GPT-4 的部署而制定的强有力的安全和测试协议。会议结束后，一位独立董事正在与一名员工交谈，该员工指出DSB 协议的违规行为已经发生。微软在未经 DSB 批准的情况下，向印度用户有限度地推出了 GPT-4。尽管 Altman 和董事会成员在现场会议上待了一整天，但他从未向他们通报过违规行为。

One incident felt particularly glaring. In late 2022, the board had had an on-site—the first of what was meant to be an annual meeting—during which Altman had highlighted the strong safety and testing protocols that OpenAI had put in place with the Deployment Safety Board to evaluate GPT-4’s deployment. After the meeting, one of the independent directors was catching up with an employee when the employee noted that a breach of the DSB protocols had already happened. Microsoft had done a limited rollout of GPT-4 to users in India, without the DSB’s approval. Despite spending a full day holed up in a room with the board for the on-site, Altman had not once notified them of the violation.

虽然独立董事们没有理由相信有任何不安全的内容被公开发布，但他们对微软违反协议而 Altman 对此漠不关心的态度感到不安。OpenAI 的模型正处于快速发展阶段，从人工智能安全的角度来看，他们认为，这些模型很快就会达到一个临界点，一旦违规，就可能造成潜在的灾难性后果，甚至危及生存。在他们看来，Altman 对微软违规行为的疏忽，为他日后处理模型发布相关的人工智能安全流程开创了一个危险的先例。

While the independent board directors didn’t have reason to believe that anything unsafe had been released to the public, they were unsettled by the seeming disregard with which Microsoft had broken protocol and Altman had passed over it. OpenAI’s models were on a rapid advancement trajectory and, from an AI safety perspective, they believed, could soon pass a point where such a violation could result in potentially catastrophic, if not existential, consequences. In their view, Altman’s laxness with Microsoft’s breach set a dangerous precedent for how he might treat AI safety processes around model releases once the stakes went up.

与此同时，奥特曼的其他行为也令人担忧。2023年3月，他给董事会发了一封电子邮件，没有邀请德安吉洛出席，并宣布他认为德安吉洛应该下台了。奥特曼认为，Quora 正在设计自己的聊天机器人 Poe，这构成了利益冲突。这一断言让人感到突如其来，动机也令人生疑。托纳、麦考利和德安吉洛都曾多次向奥特曼提出一些令人难以接受的问题，无论是关于 OpenAI 的安全实践、非营利组织的实力还是其他话题。随着董事会中的盟友日益减少，奥特曼在三人看来似乎在找借口赶走其中一人。一位独立董事在回复奥特曼的电子邮件时予以了反驳。与奥特曼长期以来允许霍夫曼和齐利斯的利益冲突相比，Poe 的利益冲突程度适中。奥特曼的动议失败了；德安吉洛留了下来。

Meanwhile, there were other concerning examples of Altman’s behavior. In March 2023, he had emailed the board without D’Angelo and announced that he believed it was time for D’Angelo to step down. The fact that Quora was designing its own chatbot, Poe, Altman argued, posed a conflict of interest. The assertion felt sudden and dubiously motivated. Toner, McCauley, and D’Angelo had each at times asked Altman inconvenient questions, whether about OpenAI’s safety practices, the strength of the nonprofit, or other topics. With his allies on the board dwindling, Altman seemed to the three to be fishing for an excuse to push one of them out. In response to Altman’s email, an independent director pushed back. Poe was a moderate conflict of interest compared with what Altman had long allowed to stand from Hoffman and Zilis. Altman’s motion failed; D’Angelo stayed on.

不久之后，D'Angelo 在一次晚宴上听说 OpenAI 的创业基金结构很奇怪。它允许投资该基金的人优先使用 OpenAI 的产品，这种优惠待遇本应只提供给 OpenAI 自己的投资者。在第二次听到这个消息后，独立董事们向 Altman 施压，要求他提供有关该基金结构的文件。当奥特曼最终将它们交给导演时，导演们发现该基金的结构不仅奇怪；它本应由 OpenAI 拥有，但Altman 却合法拥有它。

Shortly thereafter, D’Angelo was at a dinner party when he heard that OpenAI’s Startup Fund was structured weirdly. It was giving those who invested in the fund early access to OpenAI’s products, a kind of preferential treatment that should have been reserved for OpenAI’s own investors. After he heard it come up a second time, the independent directors pressed Altman for documents about the fund’s structure. When Altman finally handed them over, the directors discovered that the structure of the fund wasn’t just weird; Altman legally owned it when it should have been owned by OpenAI.

对于独立董事来说，每一件事都构成了一幅令人不安的画面：Altman 正试图一点一点地模糊他们的可见度和行动，使董事会永远无法制约他。多年来，Altman 一直宣称董事会能够制衡他，甚至解雇他，是 OpenAI 最重要的治理机制。事实上，他现在正在全球范围内宣扬这一事实，以赢得公众和政府的信任。

For the independent directors, every instance added up to a single troubling picture: Bit by bit, Altman was trying to cloud their visibility and maneuver in ways that prevented the board from ever being able to check him. For years, Altman had advertised the board’s ability to counterbalance and even fire him as OpenAI’s most important governance mechanism. Indeed, he was now trumpeting this fact around the world to secure public and government trust.

到了秋天，独立董事们的士气跌至谷底，因为他们在新董事会成员的谈判中难以取得任何有意义的进展。随着时间的推移，这些治理方面的差距变得越来越紧迫。OpenAI 正准备训练 GPT-5，并且在 AI Scientist 的开发上也取得了进展。然后，出乎意料的是，在 10 月初，Toner 收到了一封意想不到的电子邮件：Ilya Sutskever 想谈谈。

By the fall, the morale of the independent directors hit new lows as they struggled to make any meaningful progress in the negotiation for a new board member. With every passing month, these gaps in governance were gaining urgency. OpenAI was getting ready to train GPT-5, and it was making progress on AI Scientist. Then, out of the blue, in early October, Toner received an unlikely email: Ilya Sutskever wanted to talk.

第十四章

Chapter 14

拯救

Deliverance

我在萨茨克弗联系托纳的几周前，奥特曼正面临一场公关危机。多年来，他姐姐与他关系疏远，而她也从事性工作，一直不愿出现在媒体上，如今她的故事终于被曝光了。

In the weeks before Sutskever reached out to Toner, Altman was dealing with a PR crisis. After years of his sister’s estrangement and her turn to sex work staying out of the media, her story had finally burst into the open.

2023年9月25日， 《纽约》杂志专题作家伊丽莎白·韦尔发表了一篇关于萨姆·奥特曼的人物特写，这是主流媒体首次提及安妮的存在。韦尔将安妮的生活细节（包括她反复遭受的健康问题以及没有住房保障的严重经济困境）与萨姆拥有数百万美元豪宅和豪车的生活方式进行了对比。“安妮·奥特曼？”韦尔在文章中写道。“读过奥特曼博客、推文、宣言《创业手册》以及数百篇关于他的文章的读者，应该对杰克和马克斯很熟悉……安妮根本不存在于萨姆的公众生活中。她永远不会加入这个圈子。”

On September 25, 2023, Elizabeth Weil, a features writer at New York magazine, published a profile of Sam Altman that for the first time in the mainstream press referenced Annie’s existence. Weil juxtaposed details of Annie’s life, including her suffering repeated health challenges and living in severe financial duress without housing security, against Sam’s lifestyle featuring multimillion-dollar homes and luxury cars. “Annie Altman?” Weil wrote in her piece. “Readers of Altman’s blog; his tweets; his manifesto, Startup Playbook; along with the hundreds of articles about him will be familiar with Jack and Max…Annie does not exist in Sam’s public life. She was never going to be in the club.”

Altman 知道细节即将公布。在他们发表论文之前，恰逢犹太赎罪日（Yom Kippur），Weil 曾给予 OpenAI 对其报道发表评论的机会；纽约也曾与 OpenAI 合作，作为其事实核查流程的一部分。协助评论请求并试图控制报道的任务落到了 Hannah Wong 身上，她已经成为OpenAI 的通讯副总裁突然发现自己成了杂志和奥特曼家人之间的中间人，她想知道这是否真的应该是她工作的一部分。

Altman knew the details were coming. In the lead-up to their publication, which happened during Yom Kippur, the Jewish holiday of atonement, Weil had given OpenAI an opportunity to comment on her reporting; New York had also worked with the company as part of its fact-checking process. The task of facilitating the comment request and trying to control the story had fallen to Hannah Wong, who had become OpenAI’s VP of communications and suddenly found herself as the go-between for the magazine and Altman’s family, wondering if this should really be part of her job.

在个人资料发布前的最后一天，安妮的详细信息即将公开，安妮收到了萨姆的一封电子邮件。“嗨，安妮。今天几乎是赎罪日，我想就一些事情道歉并请求您的原谅，”他写道。在安妮请求支持的过程中，他感到左右为难，一方面想听从母亲的意见，另一方面又同意其他家人的意见，认为安妮应该学会经济独立，另一方面又觉得安妮需要医疗帮助，生活举步维艰。“尽管如此，我还是做了错误的决定，我应该继续支持你；我真诚地道歉，”他说。

The final day before the profile’s release, once it was apparent that the details about Annie would be published, Annie had received an email from Sam. “hi annie. in the spirit of it almost being yom kippur, i wanted to apologize and ask for forgiveness for something,” he wrote. During Annie’s requests for support, he had felt caught in the middle, torn between wanting to defer to their mom, agreeing with the rest of the family that Annie should learn financial independence, and feeling that Annie needed medical help and was struggling to function. “still, I made the wrong call and should just have just [sic] kept supporting you; i sincerely apologize,” he said.

自从 ChatGPT 发布以来，Altman 一直受到公众的热烈欢迎，但如今情况急转直下，他认为自己家庭的痛苦私事也被公之于众，这让他倍感压力。文章的余波更是雪上加霜。文章发表后，Annie 指控 Sam 以各种方式虐待她的旧推文再次出现，并开始在网上疯传。尽管对 Sam 来说，这无疑是沉重而充满挑战的，但对 Annie 来说，这却是一种非凡的痛苦释放。多年来，除了健康问题和生活不稳定带来的压力外，她还感觉自己一直在对着虚空呐喊，仿佛被抹去了意义。

The sharp turn from the otherwise glowing public reception that Altman had received since the release of ChatGPT, and having what he viewed as his family’s painful private matters spilling out into the open, weighed on him. The fallout of the piece made it worse. After it came out, old tweets of Annie’s with allegations that Sam had abused her in various ways resurfaced and began to go viral. But as heavy and challenging as it was for Sam, it was an extraordinary release of pain for Annie. For years, in addition to the compounding stress from her health challenges and lack of stability, she felt as if she had been shouting into the void and erased from significance.

2024年，我联系了安妮，以便更好地了解她的故事。我还直接联系了她的母亲康妮·吉布斯汀、她的兄弟马克斯和杰克，并通过OpenAI的通讯团队联系了萨姆，寻求他们的解释。安妮非常配合，希望最终能有一个平台分享她的个人经历，她认为这对于理解萨姆的道德品质至关重要。她提供了与家人的大量通信记录、涵盖她童年到成年大部分时期的身心健康记录以及其他佐证，这些记录记录了她与家人之间的矛盾以及她生活境遇的恶化。

In 2024, I would reach out to Annie to better understand her side of the story. I also reached out directly to her mother, Connie Gibstine, to her brothers Max and Jack, and to Sam via OpenAI’s communications team, to seek their account. Annie was eagerly cooperative, hopeful for a platform to finally share personal experiences, which she viewed as crucial to understanding Sam’s moral character. She provided extensive correspondence with her family, physical and mental health records spanning most of her childhood to adulthood, and other corroborating evidence, which charted the fallout she had with the family and the deterioration of her life circumstances.

吉布斯汀发表了一份简短的声明，强调了家人对吉布斯坦表示，她关心安妮的安危，同时也否认了安妮的说法，称其“可怕、令人心碎且不真实”。吉布斯坦拒绝进行更深入的对话，也拒绝回答我关于她对安妮的说法的看法的详细问题。她没有回应我提出的提供更多文件来支持她的说法的请求。马克斯和杰克没有回应。OpenAI 也没有就具体细节发表评论。

Gibstine offered a brief statement emphasizing the family’s love for Annie and concern for her well-being while also denying Annie’s claims, which she called “horrible, deeply heartbreaking, and untrue.” Gibstine declined to have a more in-depth conversation or to provide responses to detailed questions seeking her perspective on Annie’s account. She did not respond to my additional requests for documentation to support her own claims. Max and Jack did not respond. OpenAI did not comment on specifics.

2025年1月，安妮对萨姆提起诉讼后，萨姆、吉布斯坦、马克斯和杰克对安妮的指控进行了更为强硬的公开否认，称她精神不稳定，无理索要钱财，并且她的指控“随着时间的推移发生了巨大的变化”。“当她拒绝常规治疗，并猛烈抨击那些真心想帮助她的家人时，尤其令人心碎，”他们说。

In January 2025, after Annie filed her lawsuit against Sam, he, Gibstine, Max, and Jack issued a more forceful public denial of Annie’s allegations, characterizing her as mentally unstable and unreasonably demanding of money, and her claims as having “evolved drastically over time.” “It is especially gut-wrenching when she refuses conventional treatment and lashes out at family members who are genuinely trying to help,” they said.

通过与安妮的对话以及她提供的文件，一幅复杂的画面浮现出来，展现了她在推特上公开指控以及随后提起诉讼的动荡历程，以及她在韦尔的个人资料中分享的生活细节。我无法了解她家人做出许多决定背后的全部原因，安妮的一些指控，尤其是萨姆指控她儿时遭受性虐待的真相，也不得而知。但她的故事对我来说，成为了定义OpenAI更广阔故事的众多主题的缩影。它也帮助我加深了对OpenAI在多大程度上是其掌门人形象的反映和延伸的理解。安妮坚持不懈地试图将自己的观点融入记录，但很快却成了公司的问题。对安妮的报道或许比任何其他类型的报道都更能激怒萨姆，这使得身为OpenAI公关主管的汉娜·黄（Hannah Wong）也参与到他遏制报道传播的努力中。这也从另一个方面成为了公司的问题：当安妮的指控首次浮出水面时，其他 OpenAI 高管就注意到了这一点。

Through my conversations with Annie and the documentation she provided, a complex picture emerged of the turbulent journey that led her to go public with her allegations on Twitter and in her subsequent lawsuit, as well as with the details of her life she shared for Weil’s profile. I did not have access to the full reasoning behind many of her family’s decisions, and the truth of some of Annie’s allegations, in particular Sam’s alleged sexual abuse of her as a child, is unknowable, but her story became a microcosm to me of the many themes that define the broader OpenAI story. It also helped me solidify my understanding of how much OpenAI is a reflection and extension of the man who runs it. Annie’s persistent efforts to add her perspective to the record quickly turned into a company issue. Coverage of Annie would get under Sam’s skin perhaps more than any other kind of story, pulling Hannah Wong in her capacity as OpenAI’s communications head into his efforts to contain its spread. It also became a company issue in another way: At the time Annie’s allegations first rose to the fore, other OpenAI executives took notice.

—

—

安妮和萨姆虽然相差九岁，但在很多方面却惊人地相似。萨姆身边的人形容他的许多词，在安妮身上也得到了体现：她是一位优秀的倾听者；她记得……她对别人最细微的细节都很敏感；她很傻，非常慷慨，而且很快就能赢得人们的信任。

In many ways, Annie and Sam, nine years apart, are remarkably similar. Many of the words that people close to Sam use to describe him also shine through in Annie: She is an excellent listener; she remembers the tiniest details about others; she is very goofy, extremely generous, and quick to win people’s trust.

和萨姆一样，她在学业上也表现出色。她是奥特曼家唯一一个从伯勒斯学院毕业的兄弟姐妹，她给物理老师詹姆斯·罗布尔留下了深刻的印象。十多年后，罗布尔依然深情地回忆起她，说她是一位才华横溢、性格开朗的学生。大学期间，她就读于塔夫茨大学，主修生物心理学，辅修舞蹈。2016年毕业后，她完成了医学预科的要求，期待着有朝一日能进入医学院学习；她搬到了湾区，在加州大学旧金山分校的一个神经科学实验室担任研究职位。换句话说，在人生遭遇坎坷之前，她是一个典型的雄心勃勃、受过良好教育、拥有众多选择的年轻人。

Like Sam, she also excelled in academics. The only other Altman sibling to graduate from Burroughs, she made an impression on her physics teacher, James Roble, who remembers her fondly more than a decade later as a talented student with a sunny demeanor. For college, she went to Tufts University, majoring in biopsychology and minoring in dance. After graduation in 2016, she completed her premed requirements in anticipation of one day going to medical school; she moved to the Bay Area for a research position in a neuroscience lab at the University of California, San Francisco. Before her life went sideways, she was, in other words, a typical profile of an ambitious, well-educated young adult with plenty of options.

但在经历了一系列意想不到的挑战之后，安妮的境况开始变得糟糕。2014年，还在上大学时，她被诊断出患有跟腱炎（一种因过度使用而导致的肌腱肿胀）和骨刺，不得不穿上步行靴。这成了她一系列身体疾病中的第一个，这些疾病会让她的身体遭受慢性疼痛的折磨，在病情最严重的时候，会严重限制她的行动能力，影响她的生活质量。在六年的时间里，安妮一直饱受扁桃体炎、骨盆疼痛和肌腱炎的困扰，肌腱炎反复发作，迫使她不得不穿上更多的步行靴，肌腱炎蔓延到右脚踝以外，有时甚至连短时间站立都很困难。她的卵巢囊肿越来越多，最终被诊断为多囊卵巢综合征（PCOS），有时会导致她晚上出汗，这是常见的症状。

But Annie’s circumstances began to unravel after a series of unexpected challenges. While still in college in 2014, she was diagnosed with Achilles tendinitis, a swelling of the tendon that comes from overuse, and a bone spur, putting her in a walking boot. It became the first of a growing laundry list of physical health ailments that would plague her body with chronic pain and, at their peaks, severely limit her mobility and impact her quality of life. In a span of six years, Annie dealt with recurring tonsillitis; recurring pelvic pain; repeated flare-ups in her tendinitis, which placed her in more walking boots, spread beyond her right ankle, and at times made it difficult to even stand for short periods; and a growing number of ovarian cysts that culminated in a diagnosis for polycystic ovarian syndrome, or PCOS, which sometimes caused her to sweat through her sheets at night, a common symptom.

在所有这些健康问题中，她又遭受了一次沉重的打击：2018 年 5 月 25 日，她最亲近的父亲，因突发心脏病而死亡。

Amid all these health issues, she suffered another paralyzing blow: On May 25, 2018, her dad, with whom she was closest in the family, died of a sudden heart attack.

安妮一生都在与心理健康问题作斗争。她很小的时候就被诊断出患有广泛性焦虑症和强迫症，服用左洛复近十年，直到大学期间在一位精神科医生的帮助下逐渐减少用量。在她父亲去世前，她情况好多了。她采用了包括冥想在内的非精神健康工具，并正在寻找方法来解决似乎是她反复身体疾病背后的根本炎症，并全身心投入健康、有机、全食饮食。她更广泛的健康之旅激发了她对替代医学的新兴趣，并参加了瑜伽教师培训。她全身心投入到她对艺术的热爱中，并写了一本名为《人性》的书的草稿，记录了她对生活以及如何成为一个好人的反思。她父亲的去世让她崩溃了。这让她的精神健康每况愈下，似乎标志着她的身体健康状况加速恶化。到 2018 年底，去看各种医生和专家已经成为了常态。

Annie has dealt with mental health struggles throughout her life. She was diagnosed at a young age with general anxiety and obsessive-compulsive disorder, taking Zoloft for the better part of a decade until a psychiatrist helped her taper off in college. Before her father’s death, she was doing a lot better. She had adopted nonpsychiatric mental health tools, including meditation, and was searching for ways to address the root inflammation that seemed to underlie her repeated physical ailments with a full embrace of a healthy, organic, whole foods diet. Her larger health journey sparked a new interest in alternative medicine, and she took a yoga teacher training. She was leaning into her lifelong love of art and had written a draft of a book she called “The Humanual,” capturing her reflections on life and how to be a good human. Her dad’s death shattered her. It sent her mental health spiraling and seems to have marked an accelerated degradation in her physical health. By late 2018, going to various doctors and specialists was becoming routine.

萨姆也曾公开表示，父亲的去世是他一生中最糟糕的时刻。就在几个月前，马斯克卸任 OpenAI 联席主席，萨姆接任。萨姆身边的人说，父亲的去世让他心如刀割。有一段时间，他行为反常，难以应对。父亲的去世显然是安妮和萨姆关系的转折点，也是她与其他家人关系的转折点。安妮说，她和家人，尤其是她母亲的关系，已经因为在她人生中的一些决定上存在分歧而变得紧张，包括她放弃传统的医学职业，以及选择停止服用左洛复，转而采用自然疗法。她的父亲一直是她唯一坚定的支持者。没有了他，她变得与家人疏远，却又渴望得到他们的接受和支持。然而，在因金钱而发生冲突后，他们的关系走向了崩溃的边缘。

Sam has also spoken publicly about his dad’s death being the worst moment of his life. It happened mere months after Musk stepped down as OpenAI cochair and Sam took over. People close to Sam say the loss sent him reeling. For a while, he behaved erratically and struggled to cope. The death was clearly an inflection point in Annie’s and Sam’s relationship as well as her relationship with the rest of the family. Her connection with them, and her mom in particular, had already been strained over disagreements about her various life decisions, Annie says, including her turn away from a traditional medical career and her choice to stop taking Zoloft in favor of natural coping mechanisms. Her dad had been her sole unequivocal supporter. Without him, she grew isolated from the family yet yearned for their acceptance and support. Instead, after clashes over money, the relationship reached a breaking point.

—

—

2018年父亲去世后，安妮住在洛杉矶。她先是兼职做写作助理，后来又在一家大麻药房工作。安妮说，她从父亲的人寿保险中继承了大约10万美元。她全身心投入到对艺术和表演的热爱中，并把它作为一项严肃的职业：她参加了喜剧课程；她参加了开放式麦克风表演；她开始做播客；她把书的初稿改写成了一档个人秀，并改名为《人类安妮》（The HumAnnie）。到2019年年中，资金开始枯竭，她说，大部分资金都花在了各种艺术投资、高昂的房租、自付的医疗保险以及不断累积的医疗费用上。费用——医学影像、物理治疗、心理治疗、Lyfts 和 Ubers 前往她的预约地点。

After her dad’s death in 2018, Annie was living in LA. She was working part time as a writing assistant and then at a marijuana dispensary. Annie says she inherited around $100,000 from her dad’s life insurance. She threw herself deeper into pursuing her love of art and performance as a serious career: She took comedy classes; she went to open mics; she started a podcast; she rewrote the first draft of her book into a one-woman show she renamed The HumAnnie. By mid 2019, the funds were depleting, most of it spent, she says, on her various artistic investments, her high rent, her out-of-pocket health insurance, and her accumulating medical expenses—medical imaging, physical therapy, psychotherapy, Lyfts and Ubers to her appointments.

对于安妮来说，接下来发生的事情意味着她与家人关系的终结。2019年5月，慢性疼痛持续不断，安妮得知父亲把401(k)退休金留给了她。她辞去了药房的工作，制定了一个为期六个月的计划，打算用这笔额外的资金——略高于四万美元——来照顾自己的健康，并启动自己的创意事业，希望能获得可持续的收入来源。但不久之后，她的母亲——作为在世配偶，保留着父亲退休金的管理权——通知安妮，她实际上不会收到这笔钱。吉布斯汀在给安妮的邮件中写道，最好的税务策略是将资金以她自己的名义存入一个延税账户，该账户将通过信托转给安妮，安妮在59岁半时可以动用。“我们都希望你过得好，我们相信对你（以及所有人）来说，财务独立才是最好的，它能带来长期的满足感、个人成长和安全感，”吉布斯汀说。“因此，我们想澄清的是，如果/当你从父亲那里继承的遗产用完时，我们将不再为你提供经济支持。” 这封邮件的署名是“妈妈、萨姆、马克斯、杰克”。

For Annie, it was what happened next that spelled the beginning of the end of her relationship with her family. In May 2019, as her chronic pain continued, she learned that her dad had left her his 401(k). She quit the dispensary and drew up a six-month plan to use the extra financial runway—a little over forty thousand dollars—to tend to her health and get her creative endeavors off the ground enough to hopefully generate a sustainable source of income. But soon after, her mother, who retained authority over her dad’s retirement funds as the surviving spouse, notified Annie that she would not in fact be receiving the money. The best tax strategy, Gibstine wrote to Annie in an email, was for Gibstine to keep the funds in her name in a tax-deferred account that would pass to Annie via a trust and to which she would gain access at age fifty-nine and a half. “We all want what is best for you, and we believe that what is best for you (and for everyone) is financial independence, which brings long-term satisfaction, personal growth and security,” Gibstine said. “For this reason, we want to clarify that we will not financially support you if/when your current inheritance from Dad runs out.” The email was signed “Mom, Sam, Max, Jack.”

安妮处于脆弱状态。她的治疗师在同一时期的记录显示，她的家人希望她能够重新站起来，但这一举动反而使她的病情恶化。2019年12月，她的银行账户陷入了负值。萨姆当年早些时候获得了微软对OpenAI的首笔10亿美元投资，当时该公司正全速推进GPT-3的训练。安妮感到害怕和孤独，于是她登录了一个名为“SeekingArrangement”的陪护服务网站，通过视频通话向一名男子展示她的乳房，以赚取足够的钱来摆脱账户赤字。

Annie was in a fragile state. Her therapist’s notes from the same period say that the move her family made with the hope of getting her back on her feet instead worsened her condition. In December 2019, her bank account slid into the negative. Sam had secured Microsoft’s first $1 billion investment into OpenAI earlier that year and the company was full speed ahead in training GPT-3. Scared and alone, Annie logged on to an escort service called SeekingArrangement and showed her breasts to a man over a video call for enough money to bring her account out of the red.

安妮说，她以前从未向母亲或兄弟寻求过经济援助。她从未想过自己可以依赖他们的财富，但她也不相信一旦她真的陷入困境，他们会让她失去安全保障。从2019年末到2020年年中，安妮多次向家人寻求经济援助，包括疫情给家人带来的另一层压力和不确定性。萨姆和她母亲陪她参加了两次家庭治疗，他们同意承担她一年中部分时间的费用。

Annie says she had never before asked her mother or brothers for financial support. She had not assumed she could rely on their wealth, but neither had she believed they would leave her without a safety net should she truly be in an emergency. From late 2019 to mid-2020, Annie made several appeals to her family for financial help, including once the pandemic added another layer of stress and uncertainty. After Sam and her mother attended two family therapy sessions with her, they agreed to cover her expenses for a part of the year.

从她与家人的交流中，我们可以看出他们担心钱会助长有害行为，并认为帮助她重建心理健康的最佳方式是继续鼓励她经济独立。吉布斯坦给我的声明以及家人的公开声明都表示，他们的行动都遵循了专业人士的建议，以了解如何最好地支持安妮。

In her exchanges with her family, it’s apparent that they were worried that the money could enable harmful behaviors and believed the best way to help her reestablish her mental health was to continue to encourage her financial independence. Both Gibstine’s statement to me and the family’s public one said their actions have been guided by professional advice on how best to support Annie.

2020年5月，安妮的家庭经济保障即将到期，生活依然拮据，她请求更多帮助来支付物理治疗和谈话治疗的费用，她告诉他们每次治疗的费用分别为45美元和15美元。他们拒绝了，说她应该自己承担6月份的费用，包括退还押金。安妮收拾好为数不多的行李，来到夏威夷。父亲去世前几个月最后一次来看望她时，她也在那里。她在一家农场找到了一份工作，做一些除草、种植等轻体力活。萨姆给她发了一封邮件，告知她新的地址。父亲去世八个月后，他要求每个兄弟姐妹给妈妈寄一缕头发，让她和父亲的骨灰混合，变成一颗钻石送给他们。他写道：“这些钻石大部分来自父亲的碳，但也会包含我们每个人的一点。”安妮的钻石现在做好了；萨姆想把它寄过去。

In May 2020, as her family’s financial coverage neared its end and Annie continued to struggle, she requested more help to pay for her physical and talk therapy, which she told them was $45 and $15 a session respectively. They declined, saying they believed she should cover her June expenses herself, including with a security deposit returning to her. She packed up her small number of belongings and arrived in Hawai’i, where she had been when her dad made his final visit to her a few months before he’d died. She found a work trade on a farm with light physical tasks like weeding and planting. Sam emailed her for her new address. Eight months after their dad died, he had asked each sibling to mail their mom a lock of hair to be mixed together with their dad’s ashes and turned into a diamond for each of them. They “will mostly be from carbon from dad but will then have a little bit of each of us too,” he’d written. Annie’s diamond was now ready; Sam wanted to send it over.

对安妮来说，萨姆的邮件就像一记耳光。她不想要昂贵的钻石，她想要的是他的帮助，保障她的衣食住行。她不知道萨姆是根本不懂，还是根本不在乎她所处的困境。她和萨姆以及其他富裕家族成员之间的隔阂，似乎难以弥合。巨大的痛苦和悲伤让她断绝了与家人的联系。

To Annie, Sam’s email felt like a slap in the face. She didn’t want an expensive diamond; she wanted his help to guarantee her food and housing. She couldn’t tell whether Sam just didn’t get it or didn’t care about the severity of her crisis. The chasm between her, Sam, and the rest of her wealthy family felt irreconcilable. With enormous pain and grief, she stopped speaking with them.

—

—

在接下来的三年里，直到伊丽莎白·韦尔向她伸出援手之前，安妮的生活跌入了谷底。她面临着住房、食物和健康方面的困境；为了维持生计，她不得不从事虚拟和实体性工作。安妮的家人在公开声明中表示，他们“尝试了各种方式来支持安妮，帮助她找到稳定”。在安妮的复述中，其中一位这些支持是在2021年春夏，当时萨姆试图与安妮重新联系。她记得，他们通了三次电话，萨姆告诉她他有多爱她，并提出给她买一套房子。安妮和家人对这个提议的描述有所不同。安妮说，这个提议不是让她拥有这套房子，而是让她住在里面。她理解这种安排是为了防止她出售房产，她担心萨姆和他们的母亲可能会通过这种方式，将他们的观点强加于安妮的健康和职业决定。吉布斯汀在她给我的声明中说，他们家曾向安妮提出过房屋所有权，但没有回应我索要佐证文件的请求。在他们家的公开声明中，他们表示，他们提出通过信托为安妮买一套房子，这样她就可以有地方住，但不能立即出售。最终，萨姆和安妮达成了一项不同的协议：他将直接向房东支付一年的房租。2022年夏天，当安妮没有重新联系上萨姆时，付款就停止了。

Over the next three years, before Elizabeth Weil reached out to her, Annie’s life bottomed out. She faced housing insecurity, food insecurity, health insecurity; she turned to virtual and physical sex work to pay the bills. In their public statement, the family said they tried “in many ways to support Annie and help her find stability.” In Annie’s retelling, one of those extensions of support came in the spring and summer of 2021, when Sam sought to reconnect with her. They had three phone calls, she remembers, during which he told her how much he loved her and offered to buy her a house. Annie and the family describe that offer differently. Annie says the offer was not for her to own the house but for her to live in it, an arrangement she understood was meant to prevent her from selling the property and which she worried could be another way through which Sam and their mother could impose their views on her health and career decisions. Gibstine said in her statement to me that the family offered Annie home ownership but did not respond to my requests for corroborating documentation. In the family’s public statement, they said they offered to buy Annie a house through a trust, so that she could have a place to live without the ability to sell it immediately. In the end, Sam and Annie reached a different agreement: He would pay her rent for a year directly to her landlord. In the summer of 2022, when she didn’t reestablish contact, the payments stopped.

安妮的故事加深了人们对萨姆的刻画，使他既慷慨又自私，既亲切又充满威胁，既是许多人的恩人，又是他人痛苦的根源。他在公众场合展现真诚和利他，但在私下行为中却展现出更为复杂的算计。他既能付出，也能索取，让许多人感觉自己置身于一盘更大的棋局之中，而只有他才能看清棋盘的全貌，最终的归宿是保住他作为国王的权力。

Annie’s story deepens the dueling portraits that people paint of Sam. He is at once generous and self-serving, agreeable and threatening, a benefactor for so many people and the source of great personal pain for others. Someone who projects sincerity and altruism in public but reveals a more complicated calculus through his behaviors behind closed doors. Someone who can give and take away, leaving many with an impression that they are part of a larger game of chess for which only he can see the full board, and the end game is to preserve his power as king.

安妮的故事也让萨姆和其他 OpenAI 高管描绘的人工智能将带来富足世界的宏大叙事变得复杂。奥尔特曼曾表示，他希望人工智能能够消除贫困。布罗克曼通过讲述他的朋友和妻子安娜的故事，反复强调通用人工智能将显著改善医疗保健。苏茨克维尔则表示，通用人工智能将带来极其有效且极其廉价的心理治疗。然而，与肯尼亚工人、智利活动人士以及奥尔特曼姐姐承受所有这些问题冲击的经历相比，这些梦想显得空洞无物。

Annie’s story also complicates the grand narrative that Sam and other OpenAI executives have painted of AI ushering in a world of abundance. Altman has said that he expects AI to end poverty. Brockman has repeated, through his stories about his friend and his wife, Anna, that AGI will dramatically improve healthcare. Sutskever has said that it will lead to wildly effective, dirt-cheap psychotherapy. And yet, against the reality of the lives of the workers in Kenya, activists in Chile, and Altman’s own sister’s experience bearing the brunt of all of these problems, those dreams ring hollow.

尽管人工智能能力突飞猛进，但安妮的绝望丝毫没有减轻。但人工智能或许反而让她更加深陷其中。她原本并不想从事性工作。她说，这只是一个“Z计划”。当慢性疼痛加剧，甚至连性工作都难以维持时，她首先尝试了数字化手段，将自己的艺术作品货币化。她继续播客并维护着 Etsy 商店和 Patreon 帐户，但它们赚的钱甚至不足以支付她的电话费。一件奇怪的事情发生了，她用截图记录了这一情况：她在所有社交媒体上几乎没有得到任何曝光。有时她会注意到苹果应用程序中关于她的播客的大量评论会神秘消失，这限制了它的发现。至少有两次，在Instagram和YouTube上，她的浏览量积累了一定数量，然后又莫名其妙地消失了。一位前Facebook数据科学家和两位科技和性工作专家表示安妮在 2019 年 12 月创建的第一个 SeekingArrangement 账户，可能限制了她在网上的影响力，因为科技平台会通过自动化系统追踪和暗中封禁性工作者，标记他们的设备、电子邮件、银行账户或其他与他们的在线状态相关的信息，甚至包括与性工作完全无关的个人资料。安妮别无选择，于是又回到了 SeekingArrangement，并创建了一个 OnlyFans 账户，将她的在线状态和获取经济机会的渠道进一步卷入了算法审核的网络之中。

Despite all the leaps and bounds in AI capabilities, none of them helped to alleviate any part of Annie’s desperation. If anything, AI may have served to entrap her further. She hadn’t wanted to turn to sex work. It was, she says, a “plan Z.” When her chronic pain intensified and made even her work trade too difficult, she had first attempted digital means of monetizing her art. She continued her podcast and maintained an Etsy store and Patreon account, but they didn’t earn enough to even cover her phone bill. A strange thing was happening, which she documented in screenshots over time: She was getting little to no exposure across all of her social media. Sometimes she noticed chunks of the reviews on her podcast in the Apple app mysteriously disappearing, which limited its discovery. At least twice, on both her Instagram and YouTube, she would accumulate views and then inexplicably lose them. A former Facebook data scientist and two tech and sex work experts say it’s possible that Annie’s very first SeekingArrangement account in December 2019 could have limited her online traction, based on the nature of how tech platforms track and shadow ban sex workers through automated systems by tagging their devices, emails, bank accounts, or other information that ties together their online presence, even for profiles completely unrelated to their sex work. Seeing no other path forward, Annie went back to SeekingArrangement as well as starting an OnlyFans account, entangling her online presence and access to economic opportunities even more in a web of algorithmic moderation.

妮莉·梅塞施密特（Neily Messerschmidt）曾是索尼等公司的科技行业领导者，现在负责一家有机农场网络的健康部门。2016年安妮搬到湾区后不久，她就认识了她。在安妮倡导健康饮食的时期，她曾在该网络工作过一段时间。多年来，在安妮与亲生父母断绝关系的过程中，梅塞施密特扮演了母亲的角色。“萨姆把AI带到这个世界，就像他对待妹妹一样，”梅塞施密特说，“他在那里茁壮成长，而他的妹妹却在慢慢衰落。”

Neily Messerschmidt, a former tech industry leader at companies such as Sony who now oversees a wellness division for an organic farm network, met Annie shortly after she moved to the Bay Area in 2016 and worked for a time with the network during her embrace of healthy eating. Over the years, Messerschmidt became a motherly figure as Annie severed ties with her biological family. “Sam carried AI into the world just like he actually treated his young sister,” Messerschmidt says. “He’s just over there thriving, and his sister’s falling through the cracks.”

—

—

2020 年末和 2021 年初，安妮与家人疏远后，开始经历童年遭受性虐待的毁灭性闪回。2021 年 7 月至 2022 年 1 月期间，治疗新创伤毛伊岛的治疗师笔记记录了安妮因非自愿记忆而经历的危机，包括对她身份的强烈质疑。从十五次治疗中，治疗师写下了她的诊断印象：广泛性焦虑、创伤后应激障碍以及童年时期遭受性虐待的个人史。

In late 2020 and early 2021, after Annie estranged herself from the family, she began to experience devastating flashbacks of childhood sexual abuse. In sessions from July 2021 to January 2022 with a new trauma therapist on Maui, the notes chronicle the crisis that Annie went through with the involuntary memories, including intense questioning about her identity. From fifteen sessions, the therapist wrote down her diagnostic impressions: generalized anxiety, PTSD, and a personal history of sexual abuse in childhood.

笔记里没有提到具体的施虐者。但大约在那个时候，安妮开始定期给梅塞施密特打电话。梅塞施密特自己在19岁时也曾被强奸，在与安妮在有机农场网络的互动中，她很早就注意到了有虐待史的人身上的一些迹象。“她和某些男人在一起会感到不自在，”梅塞施密特回忆道。“我认识一些受过虐待的人，我一见到他们就知道。当某些男人在场时，她基本上会要求退出会议。当他们在房间里时，她会站在一旁。”

The notes didn’t reference a specific abuser. But around that time, Annie began regularly calling Messerschmidt, who herself had been raped at nineteen and had noticed early on in her interactions with Annie at the organic farm network the telltale signs of someone with a history of abuse. “She was not comfortable around certain men,” Messerschmidt remembers. “I know someone that’s been abused when I see them. She would basically ask to be out of meetings when certain men were around. She would stand off to the side when they were in the room.”

在激烈而情绪化的谈话中，安妮向梅塞施密特描述了她突然回忆起的事情：在这些童年记忆中，梅塞施密特记得安妮告诉她，是萨姆多次爬上她的床，有时还和杰克一起，对她进行性骚扰。

In intense, emotional conversations, Annie described to Messerschmidt her sudden flashbacks: In these childhood memories, Messerschmidt remembers Annie told her, it was Sam who had repeatedly climbed into her bed, sometimes with Jack, and molested her.

值得注意的是，几十年后，通常很难证明所谓的童年性虐待是否发生过，或者虐待的细节。从心理学角度来看，一些受虐待者遭受的痛苦有一个共同的模式：一位我咨询过的治疗师说，受害者的大脑会屏蔽所有关于这段经历的记忆，直到某个触发因素——可能是青春期、性生活活跃，或是新的不受欢迎的性骚扰——不由自主地重新浮现。即使大脑不记得，身体也会记住这段创伤。随着安妮在性工作中越陷越深，她可能突然面临一系列触发因素。

It is important to note that it’s often difficult to prove decades later whether alleged childhood sexual abuse happened, or the details of such abuse. What is known from psychology is one common pattern that some abuse victims suffer: The victim’s brain blocks out any memory of it until a trigger—perhaps puberty, becoming sexually active, or new unwanted sexual advances—involuntarily resurfaces it, a therapist I consulted with says. The body remembers the trauma, even if the mind doesn’t. As Annie got deeper into sex work, she may have suddenly been facing a rush of triggers.

在详细描述安妮的闪回经历时，正如梅塞施密特所说，以及她的创伤治疗师的笔记中部分反映的那样，目的不是要确定安妮童年时期到底发生了什么，而是要重现她成年后的经历和信念，最终促使她说出这些经历。

In detailing Annie’s experiences of her flashbacks, as told to Messerschmidt and as reflected in part in the notes of her trauma therapist, the intent is not to determine exactly what happened in Annie’s childhood but to re-create an account of what she experienced and believed as an adult, which ultimately motivated her to speak out.

2021 年 11 月，萨姆正在支付房租时，安妮首次公开发布了她的指控。”我遭受了来自我的性虐待、身体虐待、情感虐待、言语虐待、经济虐待和技术虐待。“我的亲生兄弟姐妹，大部分是山姆·奥特曼的，也有一些是杰克·奥特曼的，”她在推特上写道。“我强烈地感觉到其他人也遭受过这些施暴者的虐待。我正在寻找能与我一起追求法律正义、他人未来安全以及集体疗愈的人。”

In November 2021, while Sam was covering her rent, Annie posted publicly for the first time about her allegations. “I experienced sexual, physical, emotional, verbal, financial, and technological abuse from my biological siblings, mostly Sam Altman and some from Jack Altman,” she wrote on Twitter. “I feel strongly that others have also been abused by these perpetrators. I’m seeking people to join me in pursuing legal justice, safety for others in the future, and group healing.”

她的帖子没有引起任何关注。她只是一个无名小卒，粉丝寥寥无几。随着 OpenAI 在 GPT-3 上的成功以及最新发布的 GitHub Copilot，Sam 的知名度比以往任何时候都要高。然而，Annie 却遭到网络喷子的攻击，声称她和她哥哥实际上没有血缘关系。

Her post didn’t gain traction. She was a nobody account with few followers. Sam’s profile was rising more than ever from OpenAI’s success on GPT-3 and its most recent launch, GitHub Copilot. Instead, trolls attacked Annie, saying she wasn’t actually related to her brother.

在接下来的几个月里，两位记者联系了安妮，但她仍然不确定该告诉他们多少。2022年9月，她决定公开发言。她再次发推文，提到了萨姆和杰克的名字：“性虐待、身体虐待、情感虐待、言语虐待、经济虐待和技术虐待。永不忘记。

Over the subsequent months, two reporters reached out to Annie, but she remained uncertain about how much to share with them. In September 2022, she resolved to speak openly. She tweeted again, naming Sam and Jack: “Sexual, physical, emotional, verbal, financial, and technological abuse. Never forgotten.”

十个月后，即 2023 年 7 月，在 ChatGPT 发布、Sam 一跃成为全球明星之后，安妮收到了来自纽约的伊丽莎白·韦尔 (Elizabeth Weil) 的消息。

Ten months later, in July 2023, after ChatGPT’s release and Sam’s rocket to global stardom, Annie received a message from New York’s Elizabeth Weil.

—

—

《纽约》杂志文章发表后的三个月里，安妮在OnlyFans网站上的收入猛增了10倍多，从每月约150美元飙升至1500多美元。在董事会危机期间，她的月收入一度飙升至5500美元左右。她不再从事陪客服务，只继续从事虚拟性工作。

In the three months after the New York magazine article published, Annie’s OnlyFans income would jump up more than 10x, from around $150 a month to over $1,500. For a month during the board crisis, it would hit around $5,500. She stopped escorting, continuing only virtual sex work.

这家人——或者安妮称之为“她的亲戚们”——一直声称多年来他们给予了她各种形式的经济援助。事实上，他们在家庭治疗后达成的支持计划，以及萨姆在2021年年中至2022年年中支付的房租，都是例子。但对安妮来说，这笔钱来得太晚太少了，因为她已经绝望到不得不从事性工作。其他的支持，包括房子，通常都带有她觉得无法接受的限制或条件。

The family—or as Annie calls them, “her relatives”—have maintained that they have given her various forms of financial assistance throughout the years. Indeed, the support plan they agreed on after family therapy and the rent that Sam paid from mid-2021 to mid-2022 are examples. But for Annie, this money came too little too late, after she had already been desperate enough to turn to sex work. Other offers of support, including the house, generally had restrictions or conditions that she felt she could not accept.

2023年7月，萨姆又给安妮发了一条消息，表示愿意提供资金，但没有任何明显的条件。那年夏天早些时候，有人给他们俩都发了一封邮件，像网络侦探一样，精力充沛，要求安妮详细说明她的指控。安妮回复了这条三人回复。详细讲述了她最后几年的经历。萨姆正处于世界巡回演讲的中期，事业蒸蒸日上。6月5日，他在以色列特拉维夫大学与苏茨克维尔进行了一场广受好评的演讲。安妮的邮件出现在他的邮箱里，她用慎重而尖锐的语言讲述了她最后几年的残酷经历。

In July 2023, Sam sent Annie one other message offering money without apparent conditions. A person had emailed both of them earlier that summer with the bugged-out energy of an internet sleuth, asking Annie to elaborate on her allegations. Annie responded to the three-way thread with a detailed account of how she had experienced her last few years. Sam was in the middle of his World Tour, ascendant. On June 5, the day he gave a well-received talk with Sutskever at Tel Aviv University in Israel, Annie was in his inbox, talking about the cruelty of her last few years in measured, eviscerating sentences.

7月9日，他罕见地用大写字母回复，他的世界巡演正式结束。“抱歉这么久才回复；我花了一段时间才想清楚我想说什么，”他写道。“我不想和你继续任何形式的关系，我理解你也不想和我继续这种关系。不过，我很乐意给你汇款，并希望你能克服健康问题。”他提出可以重启他们之前的约定（具体细节他记不太清了），或者给她一笔总付款。“郑重声明，我不同意这封邮件中的很多说法，但试图介入似乎毫无意义，”他最后说道。

He responded in rare uppercase on July 9, his World Tour officially over. “Sorry for taking so long to respond; it took me awhile to figure out what I wanted to say,” he wrote. “I don’t want any kind of ongoing relationship with you, and I respect that you don’t want one with me either. I am, however, happy to send you money and am hopeful that you can get through your health challenges.” He offered to restart their previous arrangement, the details of which he couldn’t quite remember, or to give her a lump sum payment. “For the record, I disagree with many claims in this email, but it seems pointless to try to engage,” he ended.

那时，安妮不再想要萨姆的钱了。她只想得到父亲留下的钱。她再也没有回复萨姆的电子邮件。

At that point, Annie no longer wanted Sam’s money. She simply wanted access to the money her father had left. She never responded to Sam’s email.

—

—

除了 401(k) 计划外，她的父亲还留下了一份由她母亲管理的信托。2024年初，安妮有了额外的收入，她聘请了自己的律师，并得知父亲的信托基金在2023年获得了新的资金。随着她的故事越来越受关注，安妮一家通过吉布斯坦的律师展开谈判，商讨如何每月从信托基金中无条件地向安妮发放款项。安妮第一次感到自己拥有了真正的谈判筹码。安妮一家在公开声明中表示，他们预计将为安妮“终生”提供每月的经济支持。

In addition to his 401(k), her dad had left behind a trust under her mother’s authority. In early 2024, with her additional income, Annie would retain her own lawyer and learn that her dad’s trust had been newly funded in 2023. As her story gained traction, the family would open up discussions through Gibstine’s lawyer over sending Annie monthly distributions from the trust with no strings attached. For the first time, Annie felt she had real negotiation leverage. The family said in their public statement that they expected to provide Annie monthly financial support “for the rest of her life.”

有了新的分配方案，安妮租下了四年多来第一套稳定的公寓。不久之后，她聘请了另一位律师，准备对萨姆提起儿童性虐待诉讼，计划在她31岁生日（2025年1月8日）之前提起诉讼。法庭指控——而她的家人会强烈否认——萨姆从她三岁左右开始对她进行性虐待，直到他成年而她仍是未成年人；法庭要求赔偿超过 75,000 美元。2024年10月，又一场旋风之后在多次就诊后，安妮终于得到了对她潜在健康状况的诊断：过度活动型埃勒斯-丹洛斯综合征，与布罗克曼妻子的疾病相同，这是一种遗传性活动障碍。

With the new distributions, Annie rented her first stable apartment in over four years. Soon after, she engaged another lawyer to prepare a child sexual abuse case against Sam to file it before her thirty-first birthday, on January 8, 2025. It would allege—and the family would vehemently deny—that Sam had sexually abused her beginning when she was around three and continuing until he was an adult and she was still a minor; it would seek damages in excess of $75,000. In October 2024, after another whirlwind of medical appointments, Annie would also finally receive a diagnosis for her underlying health condition: hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, the same genetic mobility disorder as Brockman’s wife.

—

—

在安妮的故事发表在《纽约》杂志的文章之前，萨姆开始告诉人们，他妹妹患有边缘性人格障碍。他告诉他们，这是一件私密而敏感的事情。“他甚至在她的故事发表之前就抹黑了她，”其中一位知情人士说。

In the lead-up to Annie’s story coming out in the New York magazine article, Sam began to tell people that his sister had borderline personality disorder. It was a private and sensitive matter, he told them. “He defanged her account before it even published,” one of those people says.

边缘型人格障碍的特点是情绪调节能力严重不足，可能导致人际关系紧张，并伴有极端理想化和被抛弃的恐惧。安妮说她从未得到过这样的诊断——她与我分享的任何治疗笔记或医疗记录中也没有出现过这样的诊断。只有2021年8月她在毛伊岛的创伤治疗师留下的一张诊断报告，表明她正在评估安妮是否患有这种障碍，这种障碍通常在童年遭受性虐待后出现。治疗师在最终诊断意见中提到了安妮的性虐待史，但没有提及这种障碍。

Borderline personality disorder is marked by severe challenges in emotional regulation and can lead to intense interpersonal relationships with extremes of idealization and fears of abandonment. Annie says she never received that diagnosis—nor did such a diagnosis appear in any of the therapy notes or medical records she shared with me. There is only one mark from her trauma therapist on Maui in August 2021 indicating that she was evaluating Annie for the disorder, which commonly arises after childhood sexual abuse. The therapist included a reference to a past history of sexual abuse but not the disorder in her final diagnostic impressions.

我采访过的两位边缘型人格治疗师也强调这种疾病通常会自行消失，要么自然消失，要么通过正确的治疗，包括冥想和行为疗法，这些疗法有助于重塑一个人的自我价值感，这两种疗法都是安妮倾向于使用的方法，但她不会像吉布斯坦所鼓励的那样使用精神药物，而吉布斯坦的家人在声明中所说的安妮“拒绝常规治疗”似乎就是指这种药物。“边缘型人格障碍的研究结果非常积极；它被认为是一种良好的预后和诊断，”哈佛医学院精神病学助理教授布莱斯·阿吉雷 (Blaise Aguirre) 说，他治疗过数千名边缘型人格障碍患者，但没有专门研究安妮的病例。“绝大多数人都会好起来。”

Two therapists I spoke to about borderline personality also underscored that the disorder usually goes away, either naturally or with the right treatment, which includes meditation and behavioral therapy that helps reaffirm a person’s self-worth, both tools that Annie has leaned into, but not psychotropic medication, as Gibstine encouraged and what the family’s statement appeared to refer to when saying Annie “refuses conventional treatment.” “The research is very positive on borderline personality disorder; it’s considered a good prognosis, diagnosis,” says Blaise Aguirre, an assistant professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School who has treated thousands of borderline patients but did not review Annie’s case specifically. “The vast majority of people will get better.”

2024年4月，即将晋升为OpenAI首席传播官的Hannah Wong也与我谈论了Annie的心理健康问题。六个月来，Wong的团队一直表示，他们致力于安排我到办公室拜访，并与OpenAI的关键领导层和员工进行访谈，而我则不断寻求与他们沟通，并听取他们的意见。他们的观点。五个月后，他们开始对这个想法感到不满。我本来已经订好了去旧金山参观公司总部的航班，但就在我出发前十天，他们通知我，他们改变了决定：我不会去办公室了，他们也不会再参与我的书的编写了。

In April 2024, Hannah Wong, who would soon be promoted to OpenAI’s chief communications officer, would also speak to me about Annie’s mental health. For six months, Wong’s team had said they were committed to arranging an office visit with me as well as interviews with key OpenAI leadership and employees as I repeatedly sought to engage them and hear their perspective. Five months in, they began to sour on the idea.
