Ten days before my flight to San Francisco, which I had already booked to visit the company’s headquarters, they notified me that they had reversed their decision: I would not be coming to the office, and they would no longer participate in my book.

我按计划在旧金山旅行了几天，然后告诉一个认识 Sam 和 Annie 的人，我正在和她谈话。第二天，Wong 给我发了短信。“听说你在旧金山？”她问道。考虑到我最初安排这次旅行的原因，这说法有点奇怪。我们在 Mission Bay 的一家 Philz 咖啡馆见面，离 OpenAI 正在扩张的新办公地点不远。在一番闲聊和关于我书的高层讨论之后，她把话题转到了 Annie 身上。

Several days into my trip in San Francisco, which I took as planned, I told someone who personally knew Sam and Annie that I was speaking to her. The next day Wong texted me. “I hear you are in town?” she said, an odd formulation given why I had arranged my trip in the first place. We met at a Philz Coffee in Mission Bay, not far from a new office location that OpenAI was expanding into. After some meandering small talk and high-level discussions about my book, she directed the conversation to Annie.

“我觉得我说安妮有心理健康问题并不过分，”黄说道。当时，我还没有联系 OpenAI 咨询安妮的情况，也没有在谈话中主动提起她。“安妮有好日子，也有坏日子，”她继续说道。“她的家人正在努力在保护她和不纵容她之间找到平衡。”说到这里，她再次强调了这一点。“请注意，她的家人没有发表任何公开声明否认安妮所说的话。归根结底，一切都是为了保护安妮。”她还听说，一些新闻节目甚至讨论过韦尔将安妮纳入个人简介是否合乎道德。也许这也是我应该考虑的事情，她说。

“I don’t think I’m stepping out of turn here by saying Annie has mental health challenges,” Wong said. At this point, I had not yet reached out to OpenAI about Annie and had not brought her up in the conversation first. “Annie has good days and some really bad days,” she continued. “And the family is trying very hard to strike a balance between protecting her and not enabling her.” Here, she reiterated the point again for emphasis. “Notice that the family hasn’t put out any public statement denying what Annie said. It all comes back to protecting Annie.” She had also heard that some journalism programs had even discussed whether it had been ethical for Weil to include Annie in her profile. Maybe this, too, was something I should consider, she said.

显然，这正是黄联系我的主要目的。在此之前，她从未直接回应我关于这本书的采访请求，只是通过一位副手与我沟通。她对安妮事件的重视，凸显了这件事给萨姆带来的压力，以及公司与萨姆个人事务之间的密切联系。

It became clear that this was the main message Wong had reached out to me to deliver. Until then, she had not responded directly to my request to speak with her about the book and had only interfaced with me through a deputy. The importance she seemed to place on addressing Annie’s story highlighted the pressures that it was putting on Sam and the close link between the company and Sam’s personal matters.

萨姆和黄对安妮心理健康的断言也让我感到，安妮的经历与许多其他被人工智能帝国及其愿景边缘化或伤害的人的经历有着相似之处。自从决心讲述自己的故事以来，安妮也面临着同样的权力鸿沟。我亲眼目睹数据工作者和数据中心活动家们为此苦苦挣扎。她的生活围绕着梳理和收集尽可能多的文件，以便让每个人都能倾听她的声音。有时，她会陷入一种沉重的情绪，觉得无论她如何发声，这个世界似乎都在密谋反对她。我看到世界各地的人们脸上都写满了同样的失控和愤怒，当他们倾尽所有去挑战帝国的叙事时，却眼睁睁地看着他们所对抗的人掌握着足以动用数十亿美元资本、建设庞大基础设施、雇佣和解雇数万名承包商的权力，并且只需在活动中、对国会、对国家元首、对记者轻声细语，就能压制住他们心中的抗议之声。

Sam’s and Wong’s assertions about Annie’s mental health also struck me as another parallel between Annie’s experience and the experience of so many others sidelined or harmed by the empires of AI and their vision. Since resolving to tell her story, Annie has faced the same gulf of power that I have watched data workers and data center activists wrestle with. Her life has revolved around combing through and gathering as much documentation as possible to get anyone to listen to her. At times she has been consumed by a sinking feeling that no matter how much she speaks up, the world is somehow in a conspiracy against her. It’s the same loss of agency and anger I’ve seen etched on the faces of people globally when they throw so much of the little they have at challenging the empires’ narratives, and then watch as the people they are up against wield the kind of power that can deploy billions of dollars in capital, construct vast infrastructure, hire and fire tens of thousands of contractors, and, with a few soft-spoken words—at an event, to Congress, to heads of state, to journalists—smooth over the murmurs of protest in the way of their will.

安妮的情况是，自从韦尔发了帖子后，她就不再对着空气大喊大叫了。2022年10月，她的推文开始在网上疯传，引起了一位重要人物的注意：伊利亚·苏茨克维尔（Ilya Sutskever）。当时，他正努力应对自己对奥特曼的复杂情感，以及他所认为的奥特曼的虐待模式。

In Annie’s case, after Weil’s profile, she was no longer shouting into a void. As her tweets began to go viral in October 2022, they came to the attention of someone important: Ilya Sutskever, right as he was grappling with his own complex feelings about Altman and what he viewed as Altman’s patterns of abuse.

四

IV

第十五章

Chapter 15

策略

The Gambit

F在韦尔在纽约杂志上发表关于奥特曼的专题报道后的几天，以及在苏茨克弗向托纳发送消息的四天前，这位独立董事会见了另一位 OpenAI 高管：首席技术官米拉·穆拉蒂 (Mira Murati)。

Four days after Weil’s New York magazine profile of Altman and four days before Sutskever’s message to Toner, the independent board director had met with another OpenAI executive: chief technology officer Mira Murati.

穆拉蒂出生于阿尔巴尼亚，从小就学会了如何在混乱中保持冷静。在她的童年时期，她经历了这个国家从极权共产主义向自由资本主义转型的阵痛。这种转变发生得如此之快，由于该国的金融体系非常不发达，金字塔骗局迅速蔓延，然后崩溃，导致了大范围的骚乱和暴力。动乱留下了弹坑，穆拉蒂上学路上需要小心翼翼地绕过。一位老师曾告诉她，只要她愿意，老师也会愿意。

Born in Albania, Murati had learned from a young age how to stay calm amid chaos. Through her early childhood, she had experienced the throes of the country’s transition from totalitarian communism to liberal capitalism. The shift happened so rapidly, with the country’s financial system so underdeveloped, that pyramid schemes rapidly proliferated, then collapsed, leading to widespread unrest and violence. The upheaval would leave behind bomb craters that Murati would need to delicately maneuver around on her way to school. A teacher once told her that as long as she was willing to do it, the teacher would do it too.

穆拉蒂的父母教文学，但她却在数字的确定性中找到了慰藉。她最初对数学的热爱源于老师们的培养，他们发现了她的潜力，有时会给她出比课程内容更难的题目，以加快她的学习速度。之后，她对科学——化学、生物、物理——的热爱滋养了她对科技的热爱。她是一个如饥似渴的学习者。她会迅速读完所有能拿到的书，先读完自己的课本，然后再翻阅她的……姐姐的。她在竞争中成长，在数学和科学奥林匹克竞赛中找到了属于自己的快乐之地，在激烈的知识竞赛中，她与同龄人一起竞争。

Murati’s parents taught literature, but she found solace in the certainty of numbers. First came her love of math, nurtured by teachers who saw her potential and at times gave her harder problems than the curriculum to push her learning faster. Then came her love of science—chemistry, biology, physics—which fed her love of technology. She was a voracious learner. She burned through any book she could get her hands on, finishing up her own textbooks and then rummaging through her older sister’s. She thrived on competition, finding her happy place in math and science Olympiads as she jostled among peers in the fierce race for knowledge.

十六岁时，她凭借早熟的才华赢得了奖学金，前往加拿大不列颠哥伦比亚省维多利亚市的一所私立学校——皮尔逊学院UWC学习。这份机会让她迅速走上了职业发展的轨道：在达特茅斯学院学习机械工程，之后进入一家航空航天公司，最终在特斯拉——她担任Model X的高级产品经理，这是她职业生涯的第一次重大突破。

When she was sixteen, her precociousness won her a scholarship to study abroad at a Canadian private school, Pearson College UWC in Victoria, British Columbia. The opportunity set her on a rapidly rising trajectory, through Dartmouth College, where she studied mechanical engineering, to an aerospace company, to her first major career break at Tesla, where she was a senior product manager on the Model X.

在特斯拉，她学会了如何在巨大的压力下打造复杂的产品，如何在观点和专业领域截然不同的团队之间游刃有余地沟通协调。她常说，正是在那里，随着公司探索自动驾驶，她发现自己对人工智能产生了浓厚的兴趣。她对人工智能的研究越深入，就越觉得它是一项基础资产，可以广泛应用，是解决棘手问题不可或缺的。“这真的感觉像是我们这辈子最不想做的事情了，”她后来在凯文·斯科特的播客节目中告诉凯文·斯科特。

At Tesla, she learned to build complex products under intense pressure, navigating and negotiating across teams with very different opinions and areas of expertise. It was there, she often says, that she found herself drawn to AI as the company explored autonomous driving. The more she dug into AI, the more she began to view it as a fundamental asset that would be broadly applicable and universally needed for solving tough problems. “It really seemed like maybe the last thing we’d ever work on,” she later told Kevin Scott on his podcast.

Murati 并非一开始就投身人工智能领域。在特斯拉工作三年后，她离开公司，加入 Leap Motion 公司担任产品和工程副总裁，负责增强现实和虚拟现实系统。她曾设想这家公司将彻底改变教育，让学习者能够用手旋转 DNA 链，或者操控球在空中飞舞的物理特性。然而，该公司押注这项技术为时过早；VR 和 AR 仍然让太多人感到不适。两年后的 2018 年，她离开公司，加入 OpenAI，当时 OpenAI 还是一家非营利组织。

Murati didn’t jump into AI immediately. Three years into Tesla, she left to join the company Leap Motion as the vice president of product and engineering, to work on augmented and virtual reality systems. She imagined the company revolutionizing education, allowing learners to rotate strands of DNA with a swivel of their hands or manipulate the physics of a ball hurtling through the air. Instead the company was too early a bet on the technology; VR and AR still made too many people nauseated. In 2018, two years later, she left for OpenAI while it was still a nonprofit.

在OpenAI，穆拉蒂的晋升之路仍在继续。随着非营利组织转型为商业运营，她顺理成章地晋升为应用与合作副总裁。她负责公司与微软最重要的合作关系，以及公司研究成果商业化部门（该部门当时尚处于萌芽阶段，后来发展迅速）。她甚至比奥特曼、萨茨克弗和布罗克曼都年轻，一度是高层领导中唯一的女性技术人才。这有时使她成为性别歧视的对象，尤其是在那些怀念实验室早期时光的研究人员中。认为她技术不够精湛——更像是一名工程师而不是科学家——并认为她的崛起象征着 OpenAI 背离了严肃的基础研究。

At OpenAI, Murati’s climb continued. As the nonprofit transformed into a commercial operation, she stepped naturally into VP of Applied and partnerships. She oversaw the company’s most important relationship with Microsoft and the budding, then burgeoning, division commercializing the company’s research. She was even younger than Altman, Sutskever, and Brockman, and, for a while, the only technical woman in senior leadership. This sometimes made her the target of sexism, particularly among researchers nostalgic for the early days of the lab who viewed her as not technical enough—an engineer rather than a scientist—and considered her rise as a symbol of OpenAI’s turn away from serious fundamental research.

的确，在人工智能这个尴尬、书呆子气十足、充满雄性激素的世界里，穆拉蒂脱颖而出。她善于社交，善于倾听，而且几乎没有什么自负可言。在与她共事的人中，她以拥有独特解决问题技巧而闻名。在OpenAI持续不断的内部冲突漩涡中，她能够引领公司前进，关注不同的想法和观点，却又无所畏惧地做出艰难的决定。“想象一下，当我们必须做出极其艰难的决定，而又没有明确的答案时，会是什么样。而她总能帮我们找到答案，”一位前同事说道，“她总是那么正确。”

Indeed, in the awkward, nerdy, testosterone-fueled world of AI, Murati stood out. She was socially adept, a good listener, and had little ego to speak of. She was known among the people she worked with as a uniquely skillful problem solver. In the maelstrom of OpenAI’s persistent internal conflict, she could guide the company forward, attentive to different ideas and perspectives yet unafraid of making tough calls. “Imagine when there’s excruciatingly hard decisions that have to be made and there’s no clear answer. And she can just help find an answer,” says a former colleague. “She’s consistently correct.”

—

—

在穆拉蒂身兼数职中，她越来越多地扮演着与奥特曼沟通的翻译和桥梁角色。在Anthropic拆分后，奥特曼不仅要求她负责应用部门，还负责研究部门；2022年5月，她正式出任首席技术官。随着越来越多的团队向她汇报，她成为了员工与奥特曼沟通的重要渠道。如果奥特曼需要调整公司的战略方向，她就是执行者。如果某个团队需要反驳他的决定，她就是他们的捍卫者。

Among the many hats Murati wore, she increasingly played translator and bridge to Altman. After the Anthropic split, Altman had asked her to oversee not just Applied but also Research; in May 2022, she officially took on the title of chief technology officer. As more and more teams rolled up to report to her, she became a critical conduit through which employees interfaced with Altman. If he had adjustments to the company’s strategic direction, she was the implementer. If a team needed to push back against his decisions, she was their champion.

即使在公司领导层，她对奥特曼也有着一定程度的影响力，并且能够了解他的意见，这是其他人无法做到的。当奥特曼的期望或计划不切实际时，她会直接指出，而他通常也会认真倾听。如果他不想要某样东西，即使他假装想要，她也会直接告诉他。当人们因无法从奥特曼那里得到直接答复而感到沮丧时，他们就会寻求她的帮助，以解读他的想法。“她很诚实，”另一位前同事说道。“她是那个把事情办好的人。”

Even among company leadership, she had a level of influence on Altman and access to his opinions that others did not. She could tell him directly when his expectations or plans were unrealistic, and he would often listen. She would tell others directly if he didn’t want something, even when he pretended that he did. Where people grew frustrated with their inability to get a straight answer out of Altman, they sought her help to decode his opinions. “She was just honest,” another former colleague says. “She was the one getting stuff done.”

但穆拉蒂与奥特曼合作得越久，她就越发现自己需要经常为他收拾残局。如果两个团队意见不合，他常常会私下里同意各自的观点，这造成了混乱，加剧了冲突，并在同事之间滋生了不信任。这种模式加剧了布罗克曼持续制造的混乱，因为他一头扎进项目。对穆拉蒂来说，布罗克曼就像第二任首席执行官，但表现得很糟糕——他固执己见，而且很容易因为自己的强势而让人精疲力竭。在 GPT-4 的开发过程中，奥特曼和布罗克曼的活力给公司的部分部门带来了关键性的压力，几乎导致预训练团队（负责每个模型的数据收集和初始训练的核心团队之一）的关键人物辞职。

But the more Murati worked with Altman, the more she found herself frequently cleaning up his messes. If two teams disagreed, he often agreed in private with each of their perspectives, which created confusion, exacerbated the conflict, and bred mistrust among colleagues. That pattern compounded the chaos that Brockman continued to cause as he jumped into projects. To Murati, Brockman was like a second CEO but a bad one—highly opinionated and prone to driving people to burnout with his intensity. During the development of GPT-4, Altman and Brockman’s dynamic had exerted mission-critical levels of stress on parts of the company, nearly leading key people on the pre-training team, one of the core teams handling the data collection and initial training of each model, to quit.

然后是纳德拉，他实际上是 OpenAI 的第三任 CEO，Altman 对微软的利益非常尊重。在 Murati 精心制定了 OpenAI 可以向微软做出的合理承诺计划后，Altman 曾多次与这家科技巨头的高管们偏离计划，传达了团队正在开展的不同工作，以同意与这家初创公司路线图相悖的要求。在董事会面前，Altman 以不同的方式描述了这场骚动：Murati 与 OpenAI 最重要的合作伙伴之间缺乏有效的关系。

Then there was Nadella, who was practically OpenAI’s third CEO with how deferential Altman could be to Microsoft’s interests. On multiple occasions, after Murati had carefully put together a plan of reasonable commitments that OpenAI could make to Microsoft, Altman had veered off script with the tech giant’s executives, conveying a different picture of what the team was working on to agree with demands divorced from the startup’s road map. To the board, Altman framed the tumult differently: Murati just didn’t have a productive relationship with OpenAI’s most important partner.

在 ChatGPT 将 Altman 推向超级巨星的宝座后，他的行为愈发糟糕，备受关注和审视，日程表也被铺天盖地的旅行计划塞得满满当当。之前，他总是精力充沛；现在却常常疲惫不堪。在这种压力下，他快要崩溃了，焦虑达到了新的高度，助长了他破坏性行为的模式。他又像往常一样，当面附和每个人的意见，现在却越来越频繁地在背后说他们的坏话。这在公司内部造成了前所未有的混乱和冲突，团队领导们纷纷效仿他的糟糕行为，挑拨下属互相攻击。这本身就够让人头疼的了。但面对日益激烈的外部竞争，Altman 还在不断推动公司加快部署速度，并试图绕过一些既定的发布流程，以图方便，有时甚至不惜使用不诚实的手段。最近，他告诉 Murati，他认为 OpenAI 的法律团队已经批准 GPT-4 Turbo 跳过 DSB 审查。但当穆拉蒂与负责法律团队的杰森·权 (Jason Kwon) 沟通时，权并不知道奥特曼是如何得到这种印象的。

Altman’s behavior had progressively worsened after ChatGPT had propelled him into megastardom, intensifying both the spotlight and scrutiny and exploding his calendar with an overwhelming travel schedule. Before, he was generally energized; now he was often exhausted. And he was cracking under that pressure, his anxiety reaching new heights and fueling his patterns of destructive behavior. He was doing what he’d always done, agreeing with everyone to their face, and now, with increasing frequency, badmouthing them behind their backs. It was creating greater confusion and conflict across the company than ever before, with team leads mimicking his bad form and pitting their reports against each other. This was corroding enough as it was. But faced with mounting competition externally, Altman was also pushing the company to deploy faster and faster and attempting to skirt some of its established release processes for expediency, sometimes through dishonesty. Recently, he had told Murati he thought that OpenAI’s legal team had cleared GPT-4 Turbo for skipping DSB review. But when Murati checked in with Jason Kwon, who oversaw the legal team, Kwon had no idea how Altman had gotten that impression.

今年夏天，穆拉蒂曾试图就日益严重的问题向奥特曼提供详细的反馈，希望这能促使她自我反省并做出改变。结果，他却冷落了她，她花了数周时间才缓和关系，包括向他保证她没有把反馈告诉任何人。她也看到他对其他高管做过类似的事情：如果他们不同意或质疑他的观点，他会迅速将他们排除在关键决策流程之外，或开始损害他们的信誉。这种做法非常微妙，而且足够隐蔽，员工们都看不到，以至于她花了几年时间才完全意识到这一点。但不可避免的是，不同的高管都承受了这种待遇的冲击。随着时间的推移，他的行为累积起来，对组织的最高层造成了损害。

In the summer, Murati had attempted to give Altman detailed feedback on the accelerating issues, hoping it would prompt self-reflection and change. Instead, he had iced her out, and it had taken weeks for her to thaw the relationship, including by assuring him that she had not shared that feedback with anyone else. She had seen him do something similar with other executives: If they disagreed with or challenged him, he could quickly cut them out of key decision-making processes or begin to undermine their credibility. It was subtle and contained enough, out of sight of employees, that it had taken her some years to realize the full extent of it. But inevitably, different executives had each had their turn bearing the brunt of this treatment. Over time, the cumulative impact of his actions had taken its toll on the highest levels of the organization.

最近，这个棘手的职位落到了苏茨克弗的头上。此前一段时间，领导“人工智能科学家”项目的波兰研究员雅库布·帕乔基（Jakub Pachocki）向苏茨克弗汇报工作，却因缺乏认可和权威而感到沮丧。他向盟友布罗克曼求助，而布罗克曼又向奥特曼求助。奥特曼随后鼓励帕乔基的雄心壮志，并赋予他在研究部门更高级的职位。但有一个问题：奥特曼从未向苏茨克弗提及过这一切。他也没有理清苏茨克弗和帕乔基的职责分工，因为他们两人都从奥特曼那里得到了不同的信息，开始将同一项研究引向各自的方向，并努力理解这种错位的根源。

Most recently, the hot seat had passed to Sutskever. Some time earlier, Jakub Pachocki, the Polish researcher leading the AI Scientist project, who reported to Sutskever, had grown frustrated with his lack of recognition or authority. He’d turned to his ally, Brockman, and Brockman had turned to Altman. Altman had then encouraged Pachocki’s ambitions and given him a more senior role in Research. There was only one problem: Altman had never mentioned any of this to Sutskever. Nor would he clear up the divisions between Sutskever’s and Pachocki’s portfolios as both of them, each getting different messaging from Altman, began guiding the same research in their own directions and struggling to understand the source of the misalignment.

这种混乱的局面已经给研究部门造成了数月的组织动荡。如今，就像 GPT-4 预训练团队危机一样，压力达到了难以承受的程度。对 Sutskever 来说，这场持续不断的风波令人深感痛苦。这不仅是 Altman 的羞辱，也毁掉了他与 Pachocki 多年的友谊，这份友谊是他们多年来并肩作战、夜以继日、跌宕起伏、共同打造公司时建立起来的。

The tangled situation had caused several months of organizational thrash in the Research division. It was now, just as with the GPT-4 pre-training team crisis, reaching untenable levels of stress. For Sutskever, the ongoing saga was deeply painful. Not only was it a humiliating snub from Altman, it had unraveled his friendship with Pachocki, cultivated over years of late nights, high highs, and low lows, working side by side to build up the company.

穆拉蒂又一次加班加点地寻找解决方案。光是弄清楚发生了什么事就耗费了她大量的时间。现在她必须让苏茨克弗和帕乔基达成协议，让布罗克曼停止干涉此事。向奥特曼请愿，并要求奥特曼坚持己见，停止在私下会议上反驳她。但这些都无法解决问题的根源。再次爆发高层领导危机只是时间问题。OpenAI 真正需要的是更强大的治理和问责机制。

Murati was once again working overtime to find a solution. It had eaten up significant amounts of her time to simply figure out what was happening. Now she had to get Sutskever and Pachocki to agree on an arrangement, get Brockman to stop putting his thumb on the scale by petitioning Altman, and get Altman to stay on message and stop contradicting her in private meetings. But none of those would solve the root of the problem. It would only be a matter of time before there would be yet another senior leadership crisis. What OpenAI really needed was stronger governance and accountability mechanisms.

在穆拉蒂被冷落期间，奥特曼似乎最担心和感到威胁的是她可能将自己的详细反馈分享给董事会。事实上，她根本没和董事会谈过。她想直接和他解决问题，而且不太确定让董事会介入是否真的能带来问责。多年来，她一直对董事会的各种构成持怀疑态度。在一个本应独立的非营利组织董事会里，却有三位联合创始人，这实在太多了。而且，许多独立董事并没有真正独立于奥特曼；他们或多或少地与奥特曼有经济联系，或从他的人际关系网中获益。她观察到奥特曼投资初创公司，并向政客捐款，以此来建立和巩固重要的关系。奥特曼曾多次问她能为她做些什么，但她总是拒绝。她不想让自己卷入他的圈套，以后再欠他人情。

During Murati’s time getting iced out, Altman had seemed most worried and threatened by the possibility that she had shared her detailed feedback with the board. In fact, she hadn’t spoken with them. She had wanted to resolve things with him directly and hadn’t been so sure that involving the board would bring real accountability. Over the years, she had been skeptical of its various configurations. Having three cofounders on what was meant to be an independent nonprofit board was far too many. And many of the independent directors had not had true independence from Altman; in one way or another, they’d had financial ties with him or had benefited from his networks. She had observed his investing in startups and donating to politicians to establish and entrench important relationships. He had at various points asked her what he could do for her, and she had always demurred. She didn’t want to entangle herself in his web and owe him later.

但如果真有时间联系董事会，或许现在正是至少开辟一条更定期沟通渠道的好时机。九月底，她将前往托纳居住的华盛顿特区，在《大西洋月刊》的年度创意节上发表演讲。董事会正在寻找新成员，无论谁加入，都可能增强或削弱董事会的独立性。奥特曼需要真正的监督。穆拉蒂主动联系托纳，约他喝咖啡。

But if there was a time to reach out to the board, perhaps now was a good moment to at least open up a more regular channel of communication. She would be in Washington, DC, where Toner lived, to speak at The Atlantic’s annual ideas festival at the end of September. The board was in the middle of its search for new members, and whoever joined next could help either strengthen or weaken its independence. Altman needed real oversight. Murati reached out to Toner for coffee.

—

—

对托纳来说，穆拉蒂主动联系他虽然不寻常，但也并非完全出乎意料。托纳是董事会成员，穆拉蒂是高管。穆拉蒂想谈一谈似乎是合情合理的。

For Toner, Murati’s reach out was unusual but not totally unexpected. Toner was a board member; Murati, an executive. It seemed reasonable for Murati to want to talk.

2023年9月29日的咖啡似乎比较常规。穆拉蒂已经发布了关于公司的各种最新消息：OpenAI会赚很多钱，没问题；目前最重要的进展是它的Gobi模式，以及最近正在与微软谈判的交易；她正在处理一些与奥特曼和布罗克曼关系有关的人事问题。这次与苏茨克维尔和帕乔基有关。

The coffee, on September 29, 2023, seemed relatively standard. Murati had given various updates about the company: OpenAI would make tons of money, no problem; the most important things in motion were its Gobi model and the most recent deal it was negotiating with Microsoft; and she was dealing with some personnel issues related to Altman and Brockman’s dynamic. This time it had something to do with Sutskever and Pachocki.

只有一件事让托纳感到有些惊讶：穆拉蒂说，奥特曼向公司施压，要求其快速发货，她担心这可能会导致不好的事情发生。

Only one thing had somewhat surprised Toner: Altman was pressuring the company to ship so fast, Murati had said, that she worried it could lead to bad things happening.

对托纳来说，更不寻常的是几天后她收到的苏茨克弗发来的电子邮件。在他们共同担任董事会成员的两年里，苏茨克弗从未单独联系过她。他的邮件询问她第二天是否有时间见面。而现在，10月4日，他却紧张得说不出话来。

Much more unusual to Toner was the email she received from Sutskever days later. In the two years they had been together on the board, Sutskever had never once contacted her individually. His email had asked her if she had time to meet the next day. Now, on October 4, he was so nervous he was having trouble talking.

托纳率先发言。“我真正关心的只是如何建立一个能够监督公司的优秀、强大的董事会，”她告诉他。“这是我们所有人都想要的。”

Toner took the lead. “I just really care about moving toward having a good strong board that can oversee the company,” she told him. “That’s what we all want.”

苏茨克维尔突然一反常态地笑了起来，同时又嘲讽道：“我完全同意。”他这番话似乎暗示其他人并不同意。

Sutskever suddenly laughed and scoffed at the same time in a highly uncharacteristic way. “I totally agree,” he said, in a way that suggested others did not.

“大家都同意，”托纳和蔼地说道。

“Everyone agrees,” Toner said benignly.

苏茨克维尔翻了个白眼。

Sutskever rolled his eyes.

托纳解释说，独立董事会成员希望通过增加一位拥有深厚人工智能安全背景的新董事来增强董事会的实力。如果他有不同的想法，她很乐意听取。

The independent board members, Toner explained, were looking to strengthen the board by adding a new director with a strong AI safety background. If he had different ideas, she would be glad to hear them.

听到这里，萨茨克维尔抓住了机会。他说，董事会需要更好地了解情况。他们需要关注正在发生的事情。

At this, Sutskever latched on. The board needed to be better informed, he said. They needed to pay attention to what was happening.

托纳试图进一步探究。他认为董事会最需要知道的信息是什么？

Toner tried to probe further. And what did he think was the most important information that the board needed to know?

萨茨克弗顿了顿，小心翼翼地选择措辞。“我不太想直接回答你的问题，”他说，“如果我回答了，你就会明白为什么。”

Sutskever paused, choosing his words carefully. “I hesitate to answer your question directly,” he said. “If I answered it, you would understand why.

“从最高层面来看，OpenAI 是一个棘手的环境，”他继续说道，“OpenAI 比表面上看起来的要棘手得多。”

“At the highest levels, OpenAI is a tricky environment,” he continued. “OpenAI is trickier than it seems from the outside.

“也许我会考虑一下，然后就会发现有些细节我可以分享，”他谨慎地补充道。

“Maybe I’ll sleep on it and I’ll realize there are some specifics I can share,” he added cautiously.

与此同时，他建议，这也许不是最糟糕的事情让托纳和穆拉蒂聊聊。穆拉蒂会更清楚地了解事情的来龙去脉。

In the meantime, he recommended, it might not be the worst thing for Toner to chat with Murati. Murati would have more context about what was up.

—

—

一周多后，穆拉蒂收到了托纳的回复。在另一场董事会会议之后，托纳只是告诉穆拉蒂，似乎发生了一些奇怪的事情。穆拉蒂回应说，托纳非常敏锐。他们同意再谈一次。

Murati heard back from Toner over a week later. After another board meeting, Toner had simply told Murati that something funny seemed to be happening. Murati responded that Toner was very perceptive. They agreed to have another talk.

时间是2023年10月15日，托纳在电话会议上用一句普通的开场白开场。“事情进展如何？”托纳问道。“有什么事情是董事会应该知道的吗？”

It was now October 15, 2023, and Toner had begun the call with a generic opener. “How are things going?” Toner had asked. “Is there anything that the board should know about?”

穆拉蒂斟酌着措辞。她需要谨慎行事。“有很多棘手的事情正在发生，”她试探性地说道，重复着之前苏茨克维尔的措辞。穆拉蒂继续说道：“她不能把所有事情都说出来，至少不能说最棘手的部分，因为一旦说了，就无法收回了。尤其是现在，奥特曼作为首席执行官，正感到巨大的威胁。”

Murati weighed her words. She needed to proceed cautiously. “There’s a lot of tricky stuff going on,” she tentatively offered, echoing the phrasing that Sutskever had used before her. Murati continued: She couldn’t talk about all of it, at least not the trickiest parts, because once she did, she wouldn’t be able to take it back. Especially now while Altman was feeling incredibly threatened in his position as CEO.

最后这一点似乎让托纳感到意外。奥特曼，受到威胁了？托纳说，董事会确实试图建立更强有力的治理机制来制衡他的权力，但他们从未想过要威胁他的职位，甚至从未讨论过要罢免他。

This last bit seemed to surprise Toner. Altman, threatened? The board had certainly tried to put in place stronger governance mechanisms to check his power, but at no point had they desired to threaten his position or even remotely discussed removing him, Toner said.

穆拉蒂进一步解释道：“奥特曼是个极度焦虑的人。当他感到焦虑时，他就会冒出一些愚蠢的想法，尤其是在布罗克曼的怂恿下。奥特曼的焦虑也滋生了一些有害行为，这些行为总是遵循着同样的套路：对于那些反对他决定的人，他会说任何他认为他们想听的话来赢得他们的支持；然后，当他失去耐心等待，并认为他们会继续反对他时，他就会破坏他们的信誉，直到他们让路。这种做法微妙却普遍，最近在苏茨克韦尔和帕乔茨基之间的问题上得到了体现。她说，这造成了极大的破坏，让苏茨克韦尔非常沮丧。

Murati elaborated: Altman was an incredibly anxious person. And when he felt anxious, he had dumb ideas, particularly when enabled by Brockman. Altman’s anxiety also fed into toxic behaviors that always followed the same playbook: To anyone resisting his decisions, he would say whatever he thought they wanted to hear to win their support; then, when he lost patience waiting and believed they would continue to go against him, he would undermine their credibility until they got out of the way. It was subtle but pervasive, and had most recently manifested with the issue between Sutskever and Pachocki. It had been extremely damaging and had left Sutskever very upset, she said.

穆拉蒂继续说道，董事会需要集中精力确保他们不会让 Altman 的盟友担任第七任董事。此外，董事会还需要关注微软对 OpenAI 技术和 DSB 的部署。她不能透露太多。如果 Altman 真的这么做了，他会很生气的。发现她和托纳正在交谈。但最高管理层的这种恶性程度是不可持续的，需要在未来六到九个月内做出一些让步。

The board needed to focus on making sure they didn’t bring in an Altman ally as the seventh director, Murati continued. And it needed to pay attention to Microsoft’s deployments of OpenAI’s technologies and the DSB. She couldn’t say much more. Altman would be freaked out if he found out that she and Toner were talking. But the level of toxicity at the highest levels of management wasn’t sustainable, and something needed to give in the next six to nine months.

穆拉蒂说完，托纳应该和伊利亚谈谈，看看他觉得分享什么比较方便。

Toner should talk to Ilya, Murati finished, and see what he felt comfortable sharing.

—

—

萨茨克弗第一次联系托纳时，心里想了很多。那一年，他见证了 OpenAI 的快速崛起，也越来越沉浸在通用人工智能即将到来的想法中：它将引发怎样的灾难性变化，这些变化将如何不可逆转，以及 OpenAI 必须确保最终世界呈现极度富足而非极度痛苦的状态。

Sutskever had had much on his mind when he’d first reached out to Toner. Over that year, as he’d watched OpenAI’s rapid rise, he had grown increasingly preoccupied by thoughts of AGI’s imminent arrival: the cataclysmic shifts it would cause, the way they would be irrevocable, the responsibility OpenAI had to ensure an end state of extraordinary abundance, not extraordinary suffering.

随后，他又陷入了另一种焦虑：他不再相信 OpenAI 能够达到 AGI，也不再相信在 Altman 的领导下能够承担起这一责任。

Then he became consumed by another anxiety: the erosion of his faith that OpenAI could even reach AGI, or bear that responsibility with Altman as its leader.

ChatGPT 之后，在 OpenAI 工作并不断晋升成为了硅谷的终极社交货币。不同的团队领导为了争夺关注和优先级而争吵不休，这也导致了内部竞争和办公室政治的升级。Sutskever 观察到，Altman 让情况雪上加霜。他没有在自尊心强的人之间进行协商，而是一味地向每个人传达他们想听到的内容，并设法达到他想要的效果。在这个过程中，他撒了无数小谎，甚至还撒了不少大谎，以至于这种事几乎成了家常便饭。在 Sutskever 看来，Brockman 加剧了混乱。两位最初的联合创始人彼此信任，彼此怀念，回忆着一起度过的无数个夜晚，共同憧憬 OpenAI 的未来，这样的日子一去不复返了。

After ChatGPT, working at OpenAI and rising up its ranks had become the ultimate social currency in Silicon Valley. It had created a new level of internal competitiveness and office politics as different team leaders jostled for attention and priority. Altman was making it significantly worse, Sutskever observed. Instead of negotiating between egos, he was conveying to everyone exactly what they wanted to hear as he maneuvered to get exactly what he wanted. And he was telling so many little lies and some big ones in the process that it was becoming a near-daily occurrence. Brockman added to the turmoil, as Sutskever saw it. Gone were the days when the two original cofounders turned to each other as trusted confidants with their fond memories of the endless hours spent holed up together, dreaming about what OpenAI could become.

对Sutskever来说，结果却是最有害的组合：一个没有方向、混乱不堪、互相攻击的环境，人们不再拥有共享的信息或共同的信任基础，无法就如何前进的关键决策达成一致。这种内斗正在破坏Sutskever眼中OpenAI使命的两大支柱：它正在减缓研究进度，并侵蚀任何做出合理AI安全决策的机会。

To Sutskever, the result was the most toxic combination: a directionless, chaotic, and backstabbing environment where people no longer had shared information or a shared foundation of trust to agree on critical decisions about how to move forward. This infighting was undermining what Sutskever saw as the two pillars of OpenAI’s mission: It was slowing down research progress and eroding any chance at making sound AI safety decisions.

而现在，他也直接受到了奥特曼行为的伤害。

And now he was also being harmed directly by Altman’s behavior.

10月4日与托纳第一次通话后，萨茨克弗一直辗转反侧，压力重重。他觉得托纳是最值得接触的独立董事。她在董事会会议上直言不讳，主张建立强有力的治理和安全机制，而且显然不受奥特曼的摆布。至于另外两位独立董事，德安杰洛和麦考利，他就没那么确定了。不过，他仍然担心自己能向托纳透露多少信息，以及如果奥特曼发现会有什么后果。

After his first call with Toner on October 4, Sutskever had slept fitfully, consumed by stress. Toner, he’d felt, had been the safest independent board director to approach. She had been vocal during board meetings about instituting strong governance and safety mechanisms, and was most apparently not in Altman’s pocket. He had been less sure about the other two independent directors, D’Angelo and McCauley. Still, he worried about how much he could fully divulge to Toner and what would happen if Altman found out.

就在萨茨克维尔苦苦思索这些想法时，安妮在推特上反复发布的指控，让他对阿尔特曼是否适合引领世界走向通用人工智能的疑问又增加了一个维度。在《纽约》杂志发表那篇文章之后，公司里有些人只是低声讨论，安妮的两条旧推文最近又爆红：一条是2021年11月的推文，指控萨姆“性虐待、身体虐待、情感虐待、言语虐待、经济虐待和技术虐待”；另一条是2023年3月14日的推文，获得了近4000个赞，而且更加直白：

As Sutskever had wrestled with these thoughts, Annie’s recirculating allegations on Twitter had added yet another dimension to his piling list of questions about Altman’s fitness to lead the world to AGI. After the New York magazine article, which some people discussed only in hushed tones at the company, two of Annie’s old tweets in particular had newly gone viral: the one from November 2021, which accused Sam of “sexual, physical, emotional, verbal, financial, and technological abuse,” and another from March 14, 2023, which would rack up nearly 4,000 Likes and was more explicit:

我不再是一个四岁小孩，身边有一个十三岁的“弟弟”未经我的同意就爬上我的床了。

I’m not four years old with a 13 year old “brother” climbing into my bed non-consensually anymore.

（欢迎您帮助您弄清楚您的性取向。）

(You’re welcome for helping you figure out your sexuality.)

我终于接受了这样一个事实：你一直以来都比我更怕我，而且以后也永远如此。

I’ve finally accepted that you’ve always been and always will be more scared of me than I’ve been of you.

苏茨克弗不知道安妮的指控是否属实，但他相信，无论发生了什么，安妮和萨姆一起长大的经历都很坎坷。这足以证明萨姆的问题行为可能已经持续了很久。

Sutskever didn’t know whether her allegations were true, but he believed that whatever had happened, Annie had had a rough experience growing up with Sam. It was evidence of how long Sam’s history of problematic behaviors could have extended.

安妮说的“虐待”这个词，也是苏茨克弗认为最能体现他对奥特曼观察的词。和穆拉蒂一样，他花了很长时间才理解奥特曼的行事作风，尽管奥特曼从一开始就显露出不值得信任的迹象：他坚持要OpenAI 的 CEO 缺乏清晰或一致的推理；早年他有时会说一些看似无关紧要、毫无意义的小谎；以及 Amodei 在 2020 年底离职时发出的警告。当时 Sutskever 还没有完全理解 Amodei 所说的“心理虐待”。如今，随着 Altman 的行为日益恶化，其影响迅速升级，Sutskever 对其含义有了新的、更深刻的理解。

Annie’s word, abuse, was also the word Sutskever felt best captured his own observations of Altman. Like Murati, he had taken a long time to understand Altman’s playbook, though there had been signs of his untrustworthiness from even the beginning: His insistence on being OpenAI’s CEO without clear or consistent reasoning; little lies he had sometimes told through the early years that seemed so inconsequential as to have no point; the warnings that Amodei had conveyed at the end of 2020 when he was leaving. Sutskever hadn’t fully grasped then Amodei’s phrase “psychological abuse.” Now, with Altman’s behaviors worsening and their impacts rapidly escalating, Sutskever had a new and deeper understanding of its meaning.

10月12日和13日，他和超级联盟团队一起参加了一次静修会。在静修会上，他又烧掉了一个肖像，以此来增进团队凝聚力，并继续思考如何继续前进。现在，10月16日，他又和托纳进行了一次电话会议，准备分享更多。

On October 12 and 13, he’d gone on a retreat with his Superalignment team, where he’d burned another effigy as a team-bonding experience and continued to wrestle with how to move forward. Now, on October 16, he was on a second call with Toner and ready to share a bit more.

他讲述了与帕乔基的遭遇，以及它如何体现了奥特曼的行为。奥特曼本可以直接坦诚地告诉他，他希望帕乔基发挥更大的作用。然而，他却挑拨苏茨克弗和帕乔基互相对抗，布罗克曼在其中扮演了重要的角色。他们似乎迫不及待地想要这么做，导致两位科学家互相争斗，却无法完全理解他们为何无法达成一致。“除非士气有所提升，否则殴打还会持续下去，”苏茨克弗说。

He recounted the situation with Pachocki and the ways it illustrated Altman’s behaviors. Altman could have simply told him directly and honestly that he wanted Pachocki to play a bigger role. Instead, he had pitted Sutskever and Pachocki against each other, in no small part assisted by Brockman. They seemed eager even to do so, leaving the two scientists to fight each other without full visibility into why they couldn’t seem to reach an agreement. “The beatings will continue until morale improves,” Sutskever said.

问题在于，奥尔特曼所做的一切都非常微妙。孤立地看每个行为似乎都没有什么大不了的。只有当把所有行为综合起来看时，才能发现其中的规律。他强调，关键不是看这起让伊利亚觉得自己受到了委屈的糟糕事件。这只是奥尔特曼虐待模式的最新例证。还有他对阿莫迪的态度，托纳应该和阿莫迪谈谈，苏茨克维尔敦促道。还有他姐姐的流传指控。“这是一种不同的安全问题，如果你明白我的意思，”他说。归根结底，奥尔特曼，有时还有布罗克曼，多年来对许多人都采取了类似的方式，习惯性地操纵和欺骗他人，以至于有时他说的话甚至连他自己都不相信。

The problem was that everything Altman did was always so subtle. Each act viewed in isolation didn’t seem like that big a deal. It was only when viewing it all at once that patterns snapped into focus. The takeaway was not Look at this bad incident where Ilya feels like he’s been wronged, he stressed. This was just the latest instance of Altman’s patterns of abuse. There was also his treatment of Amodei, with whom Toner should speak to, Sutskever urged. And there were the circulating allegations from his sister. “It’s a different kind of a safety issue, if you see what I mean,” he said. The bottom line was Altman, sometimes with Brockman, had treated many people similarly over the years, manipulating and lying to people so habitually that at times he said things that he didn’t even seem to believe himself.

话虽如此，萨茨克维尔补充道，他们俩，托纳和他，可以谈谈，然后决定没什么可做的。如果真是这样，他们就应该忘了这场谈话。

That said, Sutskever added, the two of them, Toner and himself, could talk and decide there wasn’t much to do. If that happened, they should forget they ever had this conversation.

不过，他本来想和托纳进行一次具体的讨论，所以才主动联系了他。董事会原计划在11月底举行第二次年度现场会议，目的是最终决定新董事的任命。他想和托纳谈谈这件事。他认为扩大董事会不是一个好主意。他不确定董事会能否成功获得更大的独立性。即使新加入的人不是奥特曼的忠实拥护者，新董事们也需要很长时间才能适应他的策略。萨茨克维尔说，追究他的责任只会越来越难，而不是越来越容易。

There was a specific discussion that he had wanted to have with Toner though that had made him reach out. The board had scheduled its second annual on-site for the end of November, where the intent was to finally make a decision on new directors. He wanted to talk about this with Toner. He didn’t think expanding the board was a good idea. He wasn’t sure it would successfully emerge with more independence. Even if the people who joined weren’t Altman loyalists, it would take the new directors too long to pick up on his tactics. Holding him accountable would become harder, not easier, Sutskever said.

不过，他并不完全确定这个观点，所以谨慎地回避了。他想知道托纳看到了什么。

He wasn’t fully certain of this opinion, though, he hedged cautiously. He wanted to know what Toner was seeing.

托纳也认为奥特曼很狡猾。她说，她在自己的职业生涯中亲眼目睹了管理层的狡猾如何导致连锁问题。如今董事会失去了三位曾经对奥特曼极为恭敬的成员，她也同意，无论接下来发生什么，目标都是追究奥特曼的责任。

Toner agreed that Altman was slippery. She’d seen in her own professional life how slipperiness at the management level could cause cascading problems, she said. Now that the board had lost three members who had been most deferential to Altman, she also agreed that the goal of whatever happened next was to hold Altman accountable.

萨茨克弗轻松多了。他现在更理解托纳的立场了。他们曾经在僵局中立场截然相反，但追求的却是同一件事：真正制衡奥特曼的权力。她认为增加董事会成员是实现这一目标的途径，而他却持相反观点。

Sutskever was more at ease. He understood Toner’s position better now. They had been on opposite sides of the deadlock, but after the same thing: to create real checks on Altman’s power. Where she’d seen adding board members as the way to do so, he’d seen the opposite.

他继续推进。他意识到，托纳可能会觉得他的担忧非常强烈且突如其来，但这是因为解决问题的时间越来越短。“董事会就像外部协调，管理层就像内部协调，”他说。托纳说 OpenAI 需要解决外部协调问题，而他认为 OpenAI 需要解决内部协调问题。

He pressed forward. He realized that his concerns could seem to Toner very intense and sudden, but it was because there was a narrowing window in which to remedy the issue. “The board is like outer alignment, the management is like inner alignment,” he said. Where Toner was saying OpenAI needed to fix the outer alignment, he believed it needed to fix the inner.

托纳似乎消化了这些信息。“听起来你认为应该进行一些相当重大的改革，”她说。

Toner seemed to digest the information. “It sounds like you think some quite major changes should be on the table,” she said.

“是的，”萨茨克维尔回答。但最大的挑战在于，没有确凿的证据表明奥特曼的领导能力存在任何明显过失。最有可能的是，董事会最终会认定无能为力，最终就新董事人选达成一致，然后就此打住。

“Yes,” Sutskever answered. But the biggest challenge would be that there was no clear-cut evidence to point to of anything obviously egregious with Altman’s leadership. Most likely, the board would decide there was nothing they could do, they would finally agree on new directors, and the moment would pass.

对此，托纳提出了一些替代方案。也许董事会可以设定为 OpenAI 设定不同的目标，以更具体地衡量 Altman 的表现，并在十二个月后重新审视这个问题。

At this, Toner raised a few alternatives. Perhaps the board could set up different targets for OpenAI to hit to more concretely measure Altman’s performance and revisit the issue in twelve months.

萨茨克弗对此不以为然。董事会实施的任何目标，奥特曼都会通过，但这不会导致任何结构性变化来解决他的行为问题。

Sutskever brushed this aside. Altman would pass whatever targets the board implemented, but it wouldn’t result in any structural changes to address his behavioral issues.

托纳建议，布罗克曼或许可以退出董事会。

Perhaps Brockman could step off the board, Toner suggested.

苏茨克弗回答说，这当然有帮助，但还不够。虽然布罗克曼确实加剧了奥特曼的紧张情绪，但奥特曼才是问题的根源。“我一直在考虑一个相关的方向，作为B计划，”苏茨克弗在回答托纳关于布罗克曼的提议时说道。

That could certainly help, Sutskever answered, but it still wasn’t sufficient. While Brockman definitely exacerbated Altman’s dynamic, Altman was really the root of the problem. “I have been thinking in a related direction as a plan B,” Sutskever said to Toner’s proposal on Brockman.

他没有大声说出他所认为的 A 计划。但当他们结束通话并同意下周再次通话时，萨茨克弗确信托纳开始明白了。

He stopped short of saying aloud what he saw as plan A. But as they wrapped up the call and agreed to speak again the following week, Sutskever was certain that Toner was beginning to get it.

—

—

穆拉蒂又面临了一场危机。在她第二次与托纳谈话前不久，阿尔特曼似乎毫无缘由地开始感到恐慌，担心微软对 OpenAI 感到不满。为了弄清原因，穆拉蒂安排了与微软高管的会面，其中包括必应负责人米哈伊尔·帕拉欣 (Mikhail Parakhin)。

Murati was dealing with yet another crisis. Shortly before she spoke with Toner the second time, Altman had started panicking, for seemingly no apparent reason, about Microsoft being unhappy with OpenAI. In an attempt to get to the bottom of why, Murati had set up a meeting with Microsoft executives, including Mikhail Parakhin, the head of Bing.

会议进展比预期要好，但她发现 Altman 又一次答应了微软的一项要求，却没有考虑到 OpenAI 的实际行动，这让微软对 OpenAI 的成果产生了错误的预期。她又一次陷入了收拾残局的困境。

The meeting had gone better than expected, but in the process she had discovered that Altman had yet again said yes to one of Microsoft’s demands without grounding in what OpenAI was actually doing, creating false expectations with Microsoft about what OpenAI would deliver. She had yet again been stuck with cleaning up the situation.

微软的会议是在10月19日举行的。现在，10月20日，她在第三次会议的电话中告诉托纳，她计划给奥特曼很多反馈。奥特曼答应而她拒绝，这引发了很多问题。这导致微软关系严重破裂。

The Microsoft meeting was on October 19. Now, on October 20, she was telling Toner over a call in a third meeting that she planned to give Altman lots of feedback. There were so many issues caused when Altman said yes and she said no. It had created a lot of fragmentation in the Microsoft relationship.

穆拉蒂继续说道，苏茨克维尔和帕乔基的情况也完全一样。就在今天，他们终于就苏茨克维尔和帕乔基如何继续在各自的角色中共存达成了一致。达成协议后不久，她和苏茨克维尔就恳求奥特曼在与帕乔基交谈时不要改变他们的决定。只是说了帕乔基想听的话。“我跟雅库布谈话的时候，他能听懂，但跟萨姆谈话的时候，他听到的又不一样了，”她告诉托纳。奥特曼在会议上已经向他们保证了。但一切仍然岌岌可危。布罗克曼可以代表帕乔基与奥特曼对话，试图影响他，再次威胁要打破局势的平衡。

It was the same exact situation with Sutskever and Pachocki, Murati continued. Just today they had finally landed on a configuration for how Sutskever and Pachocki would continue to coexist in their roles. She and Sutskever had then implored Altman, shortly after reaching the agreement, not to deviate from their decision when speaking with Pachocki by simply saying what Pachocki wanted to hear. “When I talk to Jakub, he hears me, then he goes to Sam and he hears something different,” she told Toner. Altman had given them his word in the meeting. But everything remained precarious. Brockman could speak to Altman, on behalf of Pachocki, and seek to influence him, threatening once again to unbalance the situation.

穆拉蒂说，布罗克曼的情况完全不同。他最近向她承认，在 GPT-4 开发期间，他曾试图解雇她。严格来说，她是布罗克曼的经理，曾负责撰写布罗克曼的绩效评估，但总是引发太多争议，所以她放弃了。穆拉蒂后来向别人吐露，她曾希望解雇他，但因为他是董事会成员，所以她不能。她告诉托纳，她曾一度想过要求布罗克曼退出董事会。最终，她没有这么做。现在，混乱已经蔓延。

Brockman was a whole other story, Murati said. He had recently admitted to her that he had tried to fire her during the development of GPT-4. She was technically his manager and used to write Brockman’s performance reviews, but it had always created so much drama that she stopped. Murati would later confide to someone else that she had wished she could fire him, but she couldn’t because he was on the board. She had at one point thought about asking Brockman to step off the board, she told Toner. In the end, she hadn’t. Now the chaos was rampant.

“穆拉蒂知道安妮的情况吗？”托纳问道。

And did Murati know anything about the situation with Annie? Toner asked.

穆拉蒂没有。她没有问过萨姆，也不知道萨姆家里到底发生了什么。她说，就算有10%是真的，那也太糟糕了。

Murati didn’t. She hadn’t asked Sam about it and had no real context for what had happened within his family. If even 10 percent of it were true, though, it was really bad, she said.

“我很惊讶，在发生这么多事的情况下，我竟然还能把工作做得这么好，”穆拉蒂继续说道。她一边记录着事情的进展，一边做笔记。如果托纳需要，她可以发来更多信息。

“I’m shocked that I can do my job as well as I can with everything that’s going on,” Murati continued. She was writing down notes as things happened. If Toner needed it, she could send more information.

托纳回应道：董事会将专注于那些能够真正改变的事情——不是萨姆的性格或行为，而是建立更好的治理流程和结构来制约他。

Toner responded: The board would focus on the things that it could actually change—not Sam’s personality or behavior but instituting better governance processes and structures to keep him in check.

这与穆拉蒂在公司内部尝试的做法一致。她只是对托纳提出了另一点警告。“确保你的信息不仅仅来自萨姆，”她说。

This aligned with what Murati had been trying to do within the company. She had just one more word of caution for Toner. “Make sure your information isn’t just coming from Sam,” she said.

—

—

托纳不确定奥特曼想谈什么。10月25日早些时候，他给她发了短信，问她今天或明天是否有时间聊聊。两天前的10月23日，她又和苏茨克维尔谈过，苏茨克维尔在听到穆拉蒂说她和托纳也发表了讲话。他比以往任何时候都更明确地表达了自己的担忧。“我认为萨姆不应该成为AGI的掌舵人，”他说道，并指出董事会正面临采取行动的“巨大机遇”。随后，他提出了一个可行的方案：用穆拉蒂取代奥特曼担任临时首席执行官。

Toner wasn’t sure what Altman wanted to talk about. He had texted her earlier that day, October 25, asking if she had time to chat today or tomorrow. Two days before, on October 23, she had spoken again to Sutskever, who seemed far more open after hearing from Murati that she and Toner had also spoken. He made his concerns more explicit than ever before. “I don’t think Sam is the guy who should have the finger on the button for AGI,” he’d said, and noted the “tremendous opportunity” that had befallen the board to do something about it. He’d then suggested a path forward: replace Altman with Murati as an interim CEO.

后来，托纳、麦考利和德安杰洛互相商量时，他们意识到穆拉蒂也说过：“我对萨姆带领我们走向通用人工智能感到不安。” 这件事对他们的想法产生了巨大的影响。如果奥特曼的两位最资深副手——一位来自应用公司，一位来自安全公司——都这么想，那么董事会就出大问题了。

Later, as Toner, McCauley, and D’Angelo all conferred with one another, they realized that Murati had also said, “I don’t feel comfortable about Sam leading us to AGI.” The revelation would have a huge influence on their thinking. If two of Altman’s most senior deputies—one from Applied and one from Safety—both felt this way, the board had a serious problem.

10月24日，托纳与德安杰洛和麦考利举行了一次会议，讨论他们可以继续采取哪些措施来加强董事会的监督机制。一个突出的问题是：OpenAI的非营利组织缺乏足够的独立法律支持，所有事务都由营利性律师处理。三人一致认为，是时候寻找新的非营利组织律师了，他们可以出席每次董事会会议，并协助审查奥特曼正在达成的所有交易和其他法律安排。

Then, on October 24, Toner had had a meeting with D’Angelo and McCauley to discuss steps they could continue to take to shore up the board’s oversight mechanisms. One glaring issue: OpenAI’s nonprofit didn’t have sufficient independent legal support, and everything was being routed through the for-profit lawyers. The three agreed that it was time to find new nonprofit lawyers who could be present at every board meeting and help review all of the deals and other legal arrangements that Altman was striking.

托纳怀疑奥特曼是不是不知怎么听到了这些会议的消息，想结束讨论。但现在在电话里，他谈论的是完全不同的事情——他对奥特曼在CSET日常工作中发表的一篇研究论文的担忧。

Toner wondered whether Altman had somehow caught wind of these meetings and wanted to put an end to the discussions. But now over a call, he was talking about something completely different—concerns he had over a research paper she had published in her day job at CSET.

托纳那周发表了三篇论文。他挑出了其中最晦涩难懂、学术性最强的一篇。这篇论文探讨的是一个名为“代价高昂的信号”的政治学观点，指的是国家和私人行为体在向公众传递其在人工智能监管和发展方面的意图时所面临的挑战。她是第三位合著者，在这份长达65页的文件中，对OpenAI的提及被埋没在28到30页。该公司在其他任何地方都没有被提及——无论是在执行摘要中，还是在网页上，还是在任何发布材料中。从它的流量来看，几乎没有人读过它。她不明白这篇论文是如何引起奥特曼的注意的。

Toner had published three papers that week. He singled out the one that had been the most dense and academic. It was about a political science idea called “costly signals,” referring to the challenges that state and private actors face when signaling to the public about their intentions with AI regulation and development. She was the third coauthor, and references to OpenAI were buried on pages 28–30 of a sixty-five-page document. The company hadn’t been mentioned anywhere else—in the executive summary, on the web page, or in any of the launch materials. Based on its traffic, few people had even read it. She was confused as to how it had even come to Altman’s attention.

托纳不知道，这篇论文前一天就出现在OpenAI 在 Slack 的 #policy-research-chatter 频道。这些页面提到该公司依次指出了 OpenAI 和 Anthropic 模型发布策略的优缺点，并赞扬了 OpenAI 发布 GPT-4 的坦诚安全评估，并表示为此将模型发布推迟了六个月。OpenAI 的政策规划主管 David Robinson 只在 Slack 上粘贴了三段话——批评 OpenAI 并赞扬 Anthropic 的那段。他加粗了几行以示强调，这与 ChatGPT 引发的“竞相压价”态势以及 Anthropic 在 ChatGPT 发布后发布 Claude 时所表现出的克制形成了鲜明对比。

Unbeknownst to Toner, the paper had surfaced the day before on OpenAI’s Slack in the #policy-research-chatter channel. The pages that mentioned the company had identified in turn the strengths and weaknesses of OpenAI’s and Anthropic’s model release strategies, and included praise of OpenAI for publishing a candid safety assessment of GPT-4 and stating that it had delayed the model’s release six months to do so. David Robinson, OpenAI’s head of policy planning, had pasted into Slack only a selection of three paragraphs—the ones that critiqued OpenAI and commended Anthropic. He bolded several lines for emphasis, which contrasted the “race to-the-bottom dynamics” that ChatGPT spurred and the restraint that Anthropic had shown releasing Claude after ChatGPT.

“说到 CSET 的报告，刚刚看到这份新报告，”罗宾逊写道。“海伦·托纳是合著者之一，OpenAI 和 Anthropic 之间的对比相当精彩。”

“Speaking of CSET reports, just seeing this new one,” Robinson had written. “Helen Toner is a coauthor and the comparisons between OpenAI and Anthropic are quite spicy.”

这在频道中引发了一场简短的讨论：

It had sparked a short discussion in the channel:

一个人写道：“是的，这令人惊讶地带有党派色彩（并不是对我们的批评，在我看来，这种批评很严厉但很公平，而是对 Anthropic 不加批判地对待）。”

“Yeah that is surprisingly partisan (not so much the criticisms of us, which IMO is harsh but fair, but rather the uncritical treatment of Anthropic),” one person wrote.

“是啊，我同意，感觉这很党派化，而且我觉得也很站不住脚？”另一个人补充道。“不管怎样，”他继续往下说，“非常感谢你的分享——只是读了这些片段后，我对报告中如此高的分析水平感到惊讶。”

“Yeah agreed it feels quite partisan & I’d say also quite flimsy?” another added. “Regardless,” he continued a little farther down, “very much appreciate the share—just surprised at this level of analysis from the report, based on reading these snippets.”

奥尔特曼告诉托纳，这篇论文发布后仅几小时，就有人在给 OpenAI 的一封电子邮件中提到了它。他担心，在 OpenAI 受到监管审查（包括 2023 年 7 月联邦贸易委员会 (FTC) 对该公司数据、培训和安全实践以及其模型的幻觉可能损害消费者声誉的调查）的情况下，董事会成员批评 OpenAI 可能会名誉扫地。托纳在当年 5 月或 6 月起草了这篇论文，当时监管审查力度尚未加强。她承认，在新的政治环境下，她并没有用全新的眼光来审视它。

Altman told Toner the paper had been flagged by someone external in an email to OpenAI only a few hours after its release. He was worried that it could look bad for a board member to criticize OpenAI while it was under regulatory scrutiny, including from a July 2023 FTC probe over the company’s data, training, and security practices as well as its models’ hallucinations that may have reputationally harmed consumers. Toner had drafted the paper in May or June of that year, before all of the intensified regulatory scrutiny. She admitted that she hadn’t taken a look with fresh eyes in the context of the new political environment.

通话持续了十五分钟。Altman 的语气始终温和。通话结束时，两人一致同意她会给董事会其他成员发邮件，要求他们举报这篇论文并解释发生了什么。在邮件中，她语气和解。她为两个错误道歉：她认为这篇论文不会引起任何人的注意，因此没有对其进行更仔细的审查。“萨姆和我都同意，董事会成员有权批评公司，这一点很重要，但这不是正确的做法，”她写道。

The call lasted fifteen minutes. Altman’s voice had been mild-mannered throughout. They both agreed at its conclusion that she would email the rest of the board to flag the paper and explain what had happened. In the email, she struck a conciliatory tone. She apologized for two mistakes: believing that the paper wouldn’t draw anyone’s attention and not reviewing it more closely because of it. “Sam and I both agree it’s important for board members to be able to criticize the company if we want to, but that this would not be the way to do it,” she wrote.

其他董事会成员均未回应她。事情似乎就此结束了。

None of the other board members responded to her. With that, it seemed the matter was over.

—

—

10月23日，萨茨克弗第三次与托纳通话时，托纳建议他联系麦考利和德安吉洛。萨茨克弗仍然对他们不太确定，也不确定是否应该信任他们。在与德安吉洛见面后，德安吉洛似乎不像托纳那样了解萨姆的问题行为。10月26日，萨茨克弗再次与麦考利通话时，他担心自己会透露太多信息。

In Sutskever’s third call with Toner on October 23, she had suggested he reach out to McCauley and D’Angelo. Sutskever was still not quite sure about them and whether he could give them his trust. After he met with D’Angelo in person, D’Angelo hadn’t seemed as aware as Toner of Sam’s problematic behaviors. Now on the phone with McCauley on October 26, Sutskever was skittish about not revealing too much.

但他想从麦考利那里了解一些事情。在奥特曼与托纳通话后不久，奥特曼就给公司内部的一些人发了一封电子邮件，说他已经和她谈过她的论文，并强烈反对她关于论文后果的看法。“我觉得我们对这一切造成的损害并不一致，”他在邮件中写道。“董事会成员的任何批评都具有很大的分量。” 奥特曼对苏茨克弗说得更直接，托纳需要辞去董事会成员职务，麦考利也同意他的观点。苏茨克弗觉得这不对劲。

But there was something he wanted to know from McCauley. Shortly after Altman’s call with Toner, Altman had sent out an email to some people within the company saying that he had spoken with her about her paper and strongly disagreed with her about its consequences. “I did not feel we’re on the same page on the damage of all this,” he wrote in the email. “Any amount of criticism from a board member carries a lot of weight.” To Sutskever, Altman had said more directly that Toner needed to go as a board member and that McCauley had agreed with him. This felt off to Sutskever.

“萨姆说，他跟你谈海伦的论文时，你说，‘海伦显然得走了。’”他壮着胆子问麦考利。“结果萨姆说他给你带来了积极的进展。是真的吗？”

“Sam said that when he spoke to you about Helen’s paper, you said, ‘Helen’s obviously got to go,’ ” he ventured to McCauley. “And Sam said he updated positively on you as a result. Is that true?”

电话那头的麦考利似乎惊呆了。她回答说，她绝对没这么说。奥尔特曼确实在10月24日晚些时候给她打过电话，讨论论文的事。他提到，论文中包含了他认为批评OpenAI的部分，而德安杰洛认为这不至于被解雇，但也表示托纳不应该写这篇论文。麦考利随后告诉奥尔特曼，她没有看过这篇论文，并建议他直接和托纳谈谈。麦考利说，奥尔特曼不可能说任何建议把托纳赶出董事会的话。

On the other end of the line, McCauley seemed dumbfounded. She had definitely not said that, she responded. Altman had indeed called her late on October 24 to talk about the paper. He’d mentioned that it had included a section he thought was critical of OpenAI and that D’Angelo hadn’t felt it was a fireable offense but also that Toner shouldn’t have written it. McCauley had then told Altman that she hadn’t seen the paper and suggested he have a conversation directly with Toner. There was no way she could have said anything to suggest pushing Toner off the board, McCauley said.

这看起来像是巧合：就在谈论奥特曼“具体的谎言”时，又发生了一起类似的事件。如果不是苏茨克弗事先有理由联系麦考利，奥特曼甚至可能逃脱惩罚。奥特曼知道他们俩通常很少交谈。但对苏茨克弗来说，奥特曼撒谎和耍花招的频率，让类似的事情发生只是时间问题。

It would seem like a coincidence: In the middle of talking about Altman’s “specific untruths,” here was yet another example playing out in real time of exactly that. Altman would have even gotten away with it had Sutskever not already had reason to reach out to McCauley. Altman knew that the two typically never talked. But to Sutskever, the frequency with which Altman was lying and maneuvering had made it only a matter of time before something like this happened.

挂断麦考利的电话后，萨茨克弗又给托纳打了电话。他们一致认为，三位独立董事会成员应该谈谈了。

After hanging up with McCauley, Sutskever called Toner back. It was time, they agreed, for the three independent board members to talk.

第十六章

Chapter 16

斗篷与匕首

Cloak-and-Dagger

B10月31日，星期二，每个人都和其他人进行了交谈。托纳和麦考利谈过了。麦考利给德安吉洛打了电话。穆拉蒂和德安吉洛以及麦考利都谈过了。

By Tuesday, October 31, everyone had spoken with everyone else. Toner had spoken with McCauley. McCauley had called D’Angelo. Murati had talked to D’Angelo and McCauley.

那天，三位独立董事——托纳、麦考利和德安杰洛——开始几乎每天都进行视频会议，一致认为苏茨克弗和穆拉蒂对奥特曼的反馈，以及苏茨克弗提出的替换奥特曼的建议，值得认真审议。苏茨克弗已经下定决心要解雇奥特曼，因此没有参与讨论。他和其他董事都认为，独立董事需要在不受奥特曼影响的情况下自行得出结论。奥特曼在公司也持有股份，他们不想让这些股份左右他们的决策。

That day, the three independent board directors—Toner, McCauley, and D’Angelo—began to meet nearly daily on video calls, agreeing that Sutskever’s and Murati’s feedback about Altman, and Sutskever’s suggestion to replace him, warranted serious deliberation. Sutskever, who was already firmly resolved in his conclusion to fire Altman, sat out of the discussions. Both he and the others felt the independent directors needed to arrive at their own conclusions without his influence. He also had a financial stake in the company, which they didn’t want to sway their decision-making.

董事们后来告诉了苏茨克维尔第三个原因：他们与奥特曼的信任度太低，其中一位董事怀疑奥特曼是否真的派苏茨克维尔进入董事会来测试他们的忠诚度，以便驱逐任何反对他的人。

The directors would later tell Sutskever a third reason: They had reached such low levels of trust with Altman that one of them wondered whether Altman had in fact sent Sutskever to the board to test their loyalty in order to push out anyone who moved against him.

独立董事们陈述了他们所了解的情况：这并非高层领导第一次这样描述 Altman。他们三人总共从至少七位 Altman 一到两个级别人员那里听到过类似的反馈，其中包括 Sutskever、Murati 和Amodei 负责公司安全和非安全部门的监管。一些人将 Altman 的行为描述为滥用职权和操纵；大多数人强调他缺乏诚实，并且他们无法相信他所说的话。此外，独立董事们还发现了许多其他问题，包括剥夺非营利组织的权力；Altman 未披露其对 OpenAI 创业基金的合法所有权；Altman 未提及微软违反 DSB 规定的情况；Altman 试图迫使 D'Angelo 和现在的 Toner 离开董事会。

The independent directors laid out what they knew: This was not the first time that senior leaders had described Altman in this way. In total, the three of them had heard similar feedback from at least seven people within one to two levels of Altman, inclusive of Sutskever, Murati, and Amodei, who oversaw safety and nonsafety parts of the company. Several had described Altman’s behaviors as abuse and manipulation; most had highlighted his lack of honesty and their inability to trust what he said. Then there were the myriad other issues that the independent directors themselves had found, including the disempowerment of the nonprofit; Altman not disclosing his legal ownership of the OpenAI Startup Fund; Altman neglecting to mention Microsoft’s DSB breach; Altman trying to force D’Angelo and now apparently Toner off the board.

他们决定不去触及安妮的指控。这最终关乎萨姆作为 OpenAI 首席执行官的专业能力。

They decided not to even touch Annie’s allegations. This was ultimately about Sam’s professional capacity as OpenAI’s CEO.

穆拉蒂曾以这种身份表示，虽然奥特曼的一些行为可以归结为典型的科技CEO习惯，但它们仍然造成了重大问题。她将奥特曼与曾在特斯拉共事的马斯克进行了比较：马斯克会做出决定，并且能够清楚地解释他做出决定的原因。而奥特曼则常常让她猜测他是否真的对她坦诚相待，以及他造成的冲击是出于合理的推理还是某种隐藏的算计。正如他导致微软关系破裂一样，他也导致自己领导团队内部分裂，将信息分散给不同的人，却从不让任何人了解全貌，从而让自己完全掌控局面。再加上布罗克曼，这种局面简直是灾难性的。她说，她在很多事情上与阿莫迪兄妹意见相左，但在这一点上，他们的观察是正确的。

In that capacity, Murati had said that while some of Altman’s behaviors could be chalked up to typical tech CEO habits, they were still causing major problems. She’d made a comparison to Musk, whom she’d worked with at Tesla: Musk would make a decision and be able to articulate why he’d made it. With Altman, she was often left guessing whether he was truly being transparent with her and whether the whiplash he caused was based on sound reasoning or some hidden calculus. Just as he caused fragmentation in the Microsoft relationship, he caused fragmentation among his own leadership team, scattering information to different people but never giving any one of them the full picture, allowing him to retain full control. Combined with Brockman, the dynamic was disastrous. She disagreed with the Amodei siblings on many things, she’d said, but on this point, their observations had been correct.

事实上，独立董事们观察到，OpenAI 并非一家典型的科技公司。它可以说是世界上最强大的人工智能公司，监管着他们认为最具影响力的技术之一的开发。Sutskever 表达的一个担忧引起了他们的共鸣：当 OpenAI 的高层领导无法信任来自 CEO 的基本或关键信息时，OpenAI 试图构建 AGI 意味着什么？

And OpenAI was not, in fact, a typical tech company, the independent directors observed. It was arguably the world’s most powerful AI company, overseeing the development of what they felt was one of the most consequential technologies. A fear Sutskever had articulated resonated with them: What did it mean that OpenAI was trying to build AGI when its senior leadership couldn’t trust either basic or critical information coming from the CEO?

但这里还有另一个思考实验：如果 OpenAI是一家典型的科技公司会怎样？如果它只是像 Instacart 那样的杂货配送服务会怎样？Altman 的行为是否仍然值得他被解雇？在某些情况下是的；在某些情况下不是。但 Altman 是否会成为独立董事们认为，无论如何，他都是继续执掌公司的最佳人选。他以创业公司闻名，而OpenAI也正在迅速成熟。他真的具备足够的技能和人格魅力来继续引领公司发展方向，并弥补他所造成的不稳定吗？

But here was another thought experiment: What if OpenAI were a typical tech company? What if it were just a grocery-delivery service like Instacart? Did Altman’s behaviors still warrant his removal? In some cases yes; in some cases no. But it also wasn’t clear that Altman would be the best person to continue running the company anyway, the independent directors thought. He was famous for startups, and OpenAI was rapidly maturing. Did he really have the skills and personality to continue charting the course—and to compensate for the instability he caused?

OpenAI 当时处于有利地位：它是一家炙手可热的公司。如果董事会经过精心挑选，他们就能挑选出拥有丰富成熟公司运营经验的杰出 CEO。他们认为，Altman 对 OpenAI 的运营并非不可或缺；虽然他在全球各地奔波，但 Murati 才是公司内部日常重担的承担者，并且与微软关系密切。

OpenAI was in a stellar position: It was a hot company. If the board went through a purposeful search process, they could have their pick of phenomenal CEOs with lots of experience running mature companies. Altman wasn’t necessarily essential to OpenAI’s operations, they reasoned; while he globe-trotted, Murati was the one doing the day-to-day heavy lifting within the company and had a strong relationship with Microsoft.

在独立董事们审议期间，Sutskever 向他们发送了一系列文件和截图，这些都是他和 Murati 共同收集的，并附上了 Altman 行为的例证。这些文件和截图通过两封消失的电子邮件发送，内容很长，Altman 的头像是一个戴着帽子的神秘男子。正如 Sutskever 所说，并没有确凿的证据，但 Altman 对不同的人说了不同的话，并在管理层中引发了强烈的不满。截图还显示了至少另外两名高级领导，他们既不是安全部门的，也不在董事们已知的七名高管之列，这指出 Altman 倾向于回避和忽视流程，无论是出于 AI 安全考虑还是为了公司运营的顺利进行。董事们了解到，这包括 Altman 试图通过错误地向 Murati 引用法律团队的话来逃避 GPT-4 Turbo 的 DSB 审查。Murati 也提出了这个问题，那就是 Altman 非常擅长避免将事情记录下来。他的大部分沟通都是通过口头进行的，并通过告诉其他方他们只是记错了他说的话来逃避协议。

As the independent directors deliberated, Sutskever sent them a series of documents and screenshots that he and Murati gathered in tandem with examples of Altman’s behaviors. They came in long dossiers delivered via two disappearing emails, his icon a mysterious man in a hat. There was, as Sutskever had mentioned, no particularly damning evidence, but an accumulation of many instances of Altman saying different things to different people and stoking intense frustration across management. The screenshots showed at least two more senior leaders, both nonsafety and outside of the seven that the directors were already aware of, noting Altman’s tendency to skirt and ignore processes, whether instituted for AI safety reasons or to smooth company operations. This included, the directors learned, Altman’s apparent attempt to skip DSB review for GPT-4 Turbo by misquoting the legal team to Murati. The problem, which Murati had also raised, was how good Altman was at avoiding putting things in writing. He would deliver most of his communications verbally and wriggle out of agreements by telling other parties that they had simply misremembered what he’d said.

独立董事还需要考虑其他问题：微软会如何反应？布罗克曼会如何反应？员工会如何反应？他们讨论了是否要联系苏茨克弗和穆拉蒂所说的有类似担忧的第三位高层领导，是否要进行更广泛的事实调查，是否要让微软的高管参与进来。经过讨论，他们最终决定最好不要这么做。他们让每一个新来的人都参与到谈话中来。他们每拖延一天做出决定，奥特曼就会发现并利用他的手段使他们无法完成审议。

There were other things the independent directors needed to consider: How would Microsoft react? How would Brockman react? How would employees react? They debated whether to reach out to a third senior leader who Sutskever and Murati said had similar concerns, whether to conduct a more extensive fact-finding process, whether to loop in Microsoft’s executives. After discussion, they decided in each case that it would be better not to. Every new person they clued into the conversation and every new day they spent delaying a decision increased the chances that Altman would find out and, with his maneuvering, make it impossible for them to complete their deliberations.

11月9日，独立董事们即将做出最终决定时，萨茨克弗再次与麦考利通话。“萨姆说，‘塔莎仍然非常支持海伦退出董事会。’”他告诉她。这比奥特曼第一次说的谎话还要弥天大谎；麦考利此后再也没有和奥特曼交流过。

On November 9, as the independent directors closed in on a final decision, Sutskever had another call with McCauley. “Sam said, ‘Tasha continues to be very supportive of having Helen step off the board,’ ” he told her. It was a balder-faced lie than Altman had told the first time; McCauley had not had any more exchanges with Altman.

董事们后来觉得，托纳的文件的作用会被媒体大大夸大，部分原因是他们确信，奥特曼可能是亲自把文件递给了记者。在这场持续五天的董事会危机的第二天，董事们在一次调解讨论中质问他，称他曾多次对他们撒谎，导致他们之间的信任崩塌。他们列举的例子包括，他曾对萨茨克弗撒谎，否认麦考利曾建议托纳退出董事会。

The role of Toner’s paper, the directors later felt, would get significantly overplayed in the media, in part because, they were convinced, Altman might have fed it to reporters himself. On the second day of the five-day board crisis, the directors confronted him during a mediated discussion about the many instances he had lied to them, which had led to their collapse of trust. Among the examples, they raised how he had lied to Sutskever about McCauley saying Toner should step off the board.

奥特曼一时失了神，显然被当场抓住了。“嗯，我以为你会这么说。我不知道，”他咕哝道。

Altman momentarily lost his composure, clearly caught red-handed. “Well, I thought you could have said that. I don’t know,” he mumbled.

董事会成员对他的大胆行为感到惊奇。

The board directors marveled at his audacity.

几天后，奥特曼对托纳论文的最初反对意见出现在媒体上。

A few days later, Altman’s initial objections over Toner’s paper appeared in the media.

11月11日（星期六），独立董事们做出了决定。正如苏茨克弗所建议的那样，他们将罢免奥特曼，任命穆拉蒂为临时首席执行官。当天，他们立即告知了苏茨克弗，之后继续每天开会，只有他们三人，并频繁与苏茨克弗汇报，最终敲定领导层过渡的文书工作。11月16日（星期四）晚上，四位独立董事通过视频与穆拉蒂通话。她当时正在参加会议，接听了电话。听到这个消息后，她看起来很惊讶，但也很欣然接受。

By Saturday, November 11, the independent directors had made their decision. As Sutskever suggested, they would remove Altman and install Murati as interim CEO. That day, they immediately told Sutskever, then continued to meet daily, just the three of them, with frequent check-ins with Sutskever, to finalize the paperwork for the leadership transition. On the night of Thursday, November 16, all four video called Murati. She picked up the call on her phone from a conference. Upon hearing the news, she looked surprised but receptive.

“他现在非常非常偏执，”她说。

“He’s so, so paranoid right now,” she said.

但她对这个决定感到满意吗？董事们问道。

But did she feel comfortable with the decision? the directors asked.

“完全是，”穆拉蒂说。

“Completely,” Murati said.

她接受了新的职位，并表示有信心向其他领导层和微软传达这一决定。她将她告诉他们，还可以联系黄先生，黄先生可以信任他帮助他们撰写公告。

She accepted the new role and expressed confidence in her ability to take the decision to the rest of leadership and to Microsoft. She would also loop in Wong, she told them, who could be trusted to help them write the announcement.

几个小时后，在黄的支持下，团队经过最后的冲刺，敲定了最终的信息，剩下的最重要的事情就是告诉奥特曼。

Hours later, after the group’s final sprint to finalize the messaging with Wong’s support, the most important thing left was to tell Altman.

在最后紧张的等待时刻，没有一位董事会成员意识到他们错误估计的严重性。

In the tense final moments of waiting, none of the board directors fathomed the severity of their miscalculation.

—

—

11月17日（星期五）公告发布后的几个小时内，独立董事们的处境就急转直下。穆拉蒂最初看似平静稳定，与微软进行了富有成效的对话，但之后她突然给他们打来电话，带来了新的压力。她说，奥特曼和布罗克曼告诉所有人，奥特曼的免职是苏茨克弗的一次政变。再加上苏茨克弗在全体员工大会上的无效沟通，关键利益相关者开始对这一决定表示不满。

Within hours of the public announcement on Friday, November 17, things had gone significantly south for the independent directors. After what had seemed like an initial period of calm and stability, including Murati having a productive conversation with Microsoft, she had suddenly called them with new stress. Altman and Brockman were telling everyone that Altman’s removal had been a coup by Sutskever, she said. Combined with Sutskever’s ineffectual communication during the employee all-hands, key stakeholders were beginning to turn on the decision.

不久之后，独立董事们通过视频电话会议与充满敌意的领导层对峙，这才意识到领导层的情绪有多么糟糕。首席战略官杰森·权（Jason Kwon）和全球事务副总裁安娜·马坎朱（Anna Makanju）带头愤怒地否认了他们对奥特曼行为“并非始终坦诚”的描述，并要求董事会提供支持其决定的证据。董事们认为，如果不公开穆拉蒂的行踪，他们就无法提供证据。但即使是那些根据档案了解的在场人员，那些对奥特曼的领导能力持有类似或其他保留意见的人，也保持了沉默。随着夜幕降临，敌意加剧，独立董事们最重要的两个盟友——或者至少是他们认为会成为盟友的两个人——开始转向不同的方向。

Shortly thereafter, as the independent directors confronted a hostile leadership over a video call, they realized just how bad the sentiment was. Jason Kwon, chief strategy officer, and Anna Makanju, vice president of global affairs, were leading the charge in furiously rejecting their characterization of Altman’s behavior as “not consistently candid” and demanding evidence to support the board’s decision, which the directors felt they couldn’t provide without outing Murati. But even those in the room who they knew, based on the dossiers, had similar or other reservations about Altman’s leadership were remaining silent. As the night wore on and the hostility mounted, the independent directors’ two most important allies—or at least the two people they thought would be their allies—were beginning to veer off in a different direction.

第一天晚上，面对OpenAI可能崩溃的现实，Sutskever的决心立刻开始动摇。OpenAI是他的宝贝，他的生命；它的解散会毁了他。虽然他坚决维护自己关于Altman的所有言论，但他的本意是加强OpenAI，而不是摧毁它。他震惊、受伤，也感到迷茫。员工和其他领导的反应；这不是他预料到的结果。他开始恳求董事会其他成员，并且整个周末都在以越来越痛苦的语气恳求他们是否需要重新考虑自己的立场。

That first night, faced with the visceral possibility of OpenAI falling apart, Sutskever’s resolve immediately started to crack. OpenAI was his baby, his life; its dissolution would destroy him. While he fiercely stood by everything he’d said about Altman, his intention had been to strengthen OpenAI, not dismantle it. He was shocked, hurt, and disoriented by the reactions of employees and his fellow leaders; this was not an outcome he had anticipated. He began to plead with his fellow board members, and would continue to plead with increasing agony through the weekend, about whether they needed to reconsider their position.

更为复杂的是，穆拉蒂的举动也与董事们的预期大相径庭。当晚与领导层的谈判展开时，她一直通过电话与他们保持联系，私下向他们传递信息。然而，尽管她曾表示有信心获得大家的支持，但现在她仍然不愿明确支持董事会的决定。在与其他领导层同处一室，在他们与董事会一系列不断升级的对峙中，她有时甚至会说出一些话，让她看起来和其他人一样，对究竟发生了什么感到困惑。

Even more complicated, Murati was also acting differently than the directors had expected. As the negotiations with leadership unfolded that night, she kept in touch over calls to privately relay them information. Yet despite the confidence she had expressed to get people’s buy-in, she now remained unwilling to explicitly throw her own weight behind the board’s decision. In the room with other leadership, during their series of escalating face-offs with the board, she at times even said things that made her appear as if she were just as confused as everyone else about what exactly was happening.

对穆拉蒂来说，同事和员工日益激烈的反抗，严重挑战了她作为临时首席执行官的地位。那个星期五，布罗克曼接连辞职以示抗议，他的盟友帕乔茨基、西蒙·西多尔，以及正在休假的麻省理工学院教授亚历山大·马德里也纷纷辞职。马德里也是波兰人，与帕乔茨基关系密切。这不仅在公司内部引发了愤怒，也蔓延到了越来越多的投资者群体，这让她越来越怀疑自己能否有效地团结公司并继续领导公司。她开始动摇是否要接任首席执行官的决心。虽然她支持董事们的决定，但她并没有参与他们的审议。她觉得，如果他们希望她有机会成功执掌公司，现在就必须首先向公司证明他们的决定是正确的。

To Murati, the intensifying revolt of her fellow leaders and employees seriously challenged her position as interim CEO. In rapid succession that Friday, Brockman had quit in protest, then his allies Pachocki and Szymon Sidor, along with Aleksander Mądry, the professor on leave from MIT who is also Polish and close with Pachocki. It had led to a conflagration of anger not only within the company but that was also spreading to a growing circle of investors that increasingly made her doubt her ability to effectively hold together and continue to lead the organization. She began to waver on her commitment to take over the role. While she supported the directors’ decision, she had not been part of their deliberations. If they wanted her to have any chance of succeeding at taking the reins, she felt, it was now their burden to bear to justify their decision to the company first.

三位独立董事不再确定穆拉蒂是否值得信赖，于是着手寻找新的临时首席执行官或董事会成员。尤其是董事会唯一的硅谷内部人士德安杰洛，周六和周日打了几十个电话，尽可能多地向他庞大的人脉网试探。董事们一度致电达里奥·阿莫迪，询问临时首席执行官的职位。阿莫迪对此并不感兴趣。但在那个周末的其他人看来，他似乎对整体形势兴奋不已。

No longer certain about whether they could rely on Murati, the three independent directors pushed ahead with searching for a new interim CEO or new board members. D’Angelo, in particular, the board’s only Silicon Valley insider, made dozens of calls through Saturday and Sunday, putting out as many feelers as possible to his sprawling network. At one point, the directors called Dario Amodei about the interim chief position. Amodei wasn’t interested. But to others that weekend, he seemed almost giddy with excitement about the overall situation.

周日，D'Angelo 终于找到人接受董事会的一项提议：Twitch 联合创始人 Emmett Shear 似乎愿意并配合暂时接管公司。但很快，他也开始因为一些看似莫名其妙的原因改变主意。《华尔街日报》后来报道称，谢尔曾是奥特曼在 YC 的同学，也是 YC 校友、Airbnb 联合创始人布莱恩·切斯基的朋友和导师。作为奥特曼最信任的朋友之一，切斯基整个周末都在接听电话。以及微软董事会成员雷德·霍夫曼（Reid Hoffman）的协助，以安抚投资者的紧张情绪，调整微软的宣传，并进一步施加压力。切斯基迅速联系了希尔，希尔随后站在了奥特曼一边。

On Sunday, D’Angelo finally found someone to take the board up on one of its offers: Emmett Shear, the cofounder of Twitch, appeared willing, and cooperative, to temporarily take over the company. But soon enough he, too, began to deviate for seemingly inexplicable reasons. The Wall Street Journal would later report that Shear, who had been YC batchmates with Altman, was also a friend and mentor of YC alumnus Airbnb cofounder Brian Chesky. All weekend, Chesky, among Altman’s most trusted friends, had worked the phone lines along with Reid Hoffman, a Microsoft board member, to calm investor nerves, align Microsoft’s messaging, and mount the pressure further. Chesky quickly reached Shear, who then sided with Altman.

周日深夜，在切斯基和霍夫曼的保证下，微软也开始支持奥特曼，纳德拉宣布奥特曼和布罗克曼将联手领导一个新的高级人工智能研究部门。其他人工智能实验室像秃鹫一样盘踞在OpenAI周围，意图在这场混战中挖走他们的人才。穆拉蒂清楚地意识到，由于董事会无法认可他们的决定，目前的形势可能会让OpenAI只剩下一个空壳。她与同事们站到了一起。为了挽救局面，穆拉蒂希望奥特曼回来。

By late Sunday night, after reassurances from Chesky and Hoffman, Microsoft had also thrown its weight behind Altman, with Nadella announcing that Altman and Brockman were joining to lead a new advanced AI research division. Other AI labs were circling OpenAI like vultures, intent on poaching away their share of talent in the carnage. It became clear to Murati that with the board unable to legitimize their decision, the dynamics now threatened to leave behind a shell of a company. She fell on the side of her fellow leaders. To salvage the situation, Murati wanted Altman back.

一夜之间，员工们整理出一封公开信，抗议董事会的决定，并威胁要辞职加入微软，穆拉蒂把她的名字放在了首位。许多高级员工对穆拉蒂的忠诚度远高于对奥特曼。穆拉蒂日复一日地与他们并肩作战。他们相信穆拉蒂不会为自己的私利行事，而是会为公司的最大利益行事。其他人也认为，奥特曼与投资者的密切关系以及筹集巨额资金的独特能力，使他成为（甚至是唯一）能够让OpenAI正在进行的收购要约顺利进行的最佳人选，他承诺给OpenAI提供高达数百万美元的股权套现机会，并确保公司长期成功的资金安全。还有一些人敏锐地意识到奥特曼独特的广泛人脉和在硅谷打造人才的能力。随着关键高管和高级员工的认同，这封信上的签名迅速增加。在一周内上午几个小时，萨茨克弗在公司倒闭前再也看不到其他出路，于是将自己的名字添加到了名单上。“如果没有米拉，我认为萨姆不可能取得这样的成就，”一位研究人员说道。对独立董事们来说，米拉的含糊其辞就像一个自我实现的预言。

Overnight, as employees put together the open letter protesting the board’s decision and threatening to quit and join Microsoft, Murati put her name first. Many senior employees were more loyal to Murati than to Altman. Murati was the one in the trenches with them day in and day out. Murati was the one whom they trusted to act not in her self-interest but in the best interests of the company. Others also believed that Altman’s close relationship with investors and singular ability to fundraise massive amounts of capital made him the best, if not only, person to keep OpenAI’s ongoing tender offer on track, promising them a chance to cash in as much as millions of dollars of their equity, as well as to secure the finances for the company’s long-term success. Still others were keenly aware of Altman’s uniquely expansive network and ability to make people’s careers in Silicon Valley. With the key executives and senior staff bought in, the signatures on the letter rapidly snowballed. In the wee hours of the morning, Sutskever, who could no longer see another path forward without the company collapsing, added his name to the list. “Without Mira, I don’t think Sam would have been able to pull off what he did,” a researcher says. To the independent board directors, her equivocating felt like a self-fulfilling prophecy.

《纽约时报》后来披露了穆拉蒂在罢免事件中所扮演的角色。穆拉蒂会向员工们为自己辩护。“我和萨姆的合作关系牢固而富有成效，我毫不避讳地直接与他分享反馈意见，”她写道。“我从未联系董事会就萨姆的问题提出反馈意见。然而，当董事会成员直接联系我征求关于萨姆的意见时，我都提供了——所有反馈意见萨姆都已经知道了。”

The New York Times would later break the story of Murati’s role in the ouster. To employees, Murati would defend herself. “Sam and I have a strong and productive partnership and I have not been shy about sharing feedback with him directly,” she wrote. “I never reached out to the board to give feedback about Sam. However, when individual board members reached out directly to me for feedback about Sam, I provided it—all feedback Sam already knew.”

到了危机爆发的那个星期一早上，独立董事们知道自己输了。穆拉蒂和苏茨克弗已经翻脸，员工抗议信也清楚地表明，公司内部的动荡局面已经难以维持。奥特曼会回来的；没有其他办法可以保住OpenAI。唯一的一线希望是：在坚持了足够长的时间后，奥特曼似乎也准备做出让步。于是，独立董事们将注意力转向了保留所有可以继续追究奥特曼责任的机制：至少保留一名独立董事以保持董事会的连续性，找到另外两名能够真正独立于奥特曼的独立董事，并迫使奥特曼接受调查。

By the Monday morning of the crisis, the independent directors knew they had lost. Murati and Sutskever had flipped sides, and the employee protest letter made clear the destabilization at the company had become untenable. Altman would come back; there was no other way to preserve OpenAI. The one silver lining: After holding out long enough, Altman also seemed ready to make concessions. With that, the independent directors switched their focus to saving what mechanisms they could for continuing to hold him accountable: to keep at least one of them on the board for continuity, to find two more independent directors who could truly be independent against Altman, and to get Altman to submit to an investigation.

但就在他们即将达成最终协议时，又有一个人想要挑起事端。这个人正是 OpenAI 被抛弃的前联合主席埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk)。

But as they neared a final agreement, there was one more person who wanted to stir the pot. It was none other than OpenAI’s spurned former cochairman, Elon Musk.

—

—

整个周末，X 成了各种关于 OpenAI 董事会闹剧的理论和阴谋论的温床。对马斯克来说，这也是一个忙碌的周末。他监督了 SpaceX 的一次发射，并最终对非营利组织 Media Matters 提起了诉讼，指控其在 X 上发布反犹太内容。之后，他转向了自己的平台——这个平台是他在 2022 年 4 月以一笔不明智的交易买下的——来为自己反对反犹太主义的记录辩护，维护言论自由绝对主义，并……批评“觉醒的暴民”和主流媒体。在这期间，他还回复了其他人关于 OpenAI 和 Altman 的评论和表情包，有时自己也会发推文。

All through the weekend, X had become the breeding ground for every possible theory and conspiracy theory about the OpenAI board drama. It had also been a busy weekend for Musk. He had overseen a SpaceX launch and finalized a lawsuit against the nonprofit Media Matters for its report on antisemitic content on X. He had then turned to his platform, which he’d bought in an ill-conceived deal in April 2022, to defend his record against antisemitism, to assert free speech absolutism, and to criticize the woke mob and the mainstream media. In between it all, he was reply guying to other people’s commentary and memes, and at times tweeting himself, about OpenAI and Altman.

“我非常担心，”他在11月19日星期日下午写道。“伊利亚有良好的道德准则，不追求权力。除非万不得已，他不会采取如此激烈的行动。随后，大约在太平洋时间凌晨 2 点，他在推特上挑衅性地发布了 YouTube 视频，其中有《教父》中著名的洗礼场景，迈克尔·柯里昂通过谋杀所有其他家族的首领，从一个道德矛盾的儿子变成了一个冷酷无情的新教头子。

“I am very worried,” he wrote on Sunday, November 19, in the afternoon. “Ilya has a good moral compass and does not seek power. He would not take such drastic action unless he felt it was absolutely necessary.” Later, at around 2:00 a.m. Pacific time, he provocatively tweeted out a YouTube clip of the famous baptism scene from The Godfather, when Michael Corleone transforms from a morally conflicted son to a ruthless new don by murdering the heads of all the other families.

但周二下午，马斯克试图更明确地扭转局势。“这封关于OpenAI的信刚刚发给我，”他在推特上写道，并附上了一个链接。“这些担忧似乎值得调查。”这封信与在现有员工中流传的那封信有所不同，但它也是写给 OpenAI 董事会的。信的开头是：

But on Tuesday afternoon, Musk sought to tip the scale more explicitly. “This letter about OpenAI was just sent to me,” he tweeted, with a link. “These seem like concerns worth investigating.” It was a different letter than the one circulating among current employees but was also addressed to OpenAI’s board of directors. It began:

我们今天写信给您，是为了表达我们对 OpenAI 最近发生的事件的深切关注，特别是对 Sam Altman 不当行为的指控。

We are writing to you today to express our deep concern about the recent events at OpenAI, particularly the allegations of misconduct against Sam Altman.

我们是 OpenAI 的前员工，在公司经历重大动荡和剧变的时期离开了公司。既然你们现在已经见证了敢于直面 Sam Altman 的后果，或许你们就能理解为什么我们这么多人因为害怕后果而保持沉默。我们不能再袖手旁观了。

We are former OpenAI employees who left the company during a period of significant turmoil and upheaval. As you have now witnessed what happens when you dare stand up to Sam Altman, perhaps you can understand why so many of us have remained silent for fear of repercussions. We can no longer stand by silent.

这封信提出了一系列要求——主要是要求临时首席执行官埃米特·希尔（Emmett Shear）扩大对奥特曼行为的调查范围，将OpenAI的早期历史及其脱离非营利组织的企业重组纳入其中。信中写道：“我们认为，大量OpenAI员工被赶出公司，是为了促进公司向营利模式的转型。”信中还提出了一系列指控，描述了“萨姆·奥特曼和格雷格·布罗克曼的欺骗和操纵行为令人不安。”

The letter presented a series of demands—chiefly, for interim CEO Emmett Shear to expand his investigation into Altman’s behaviors to include OpenAI’s earlier history and its corporate restructuring away from the nonprofit. “We believe that a significant number of OpenAI employees were pushed out of the company to facilitate its transition to a for-profit model,” it said. It also presented a series of allegations, describing “a disturbing pattern of deceit and manipulation by Sam Altman and Greg Brockman.”

信的底部有一个名为“公众延伸阅读”的部分，其中列出了三个链接。其中一个是杰弗里·欧文（Geoffrey Irving）的X帖子，欧文是人工智能安全研究员，于2019年离开谷歌加入DeepMind。帖子中称，奥特曼“多次对我撒谎”，“欺骗他人、操纵他人，甚至更恶劣”。另外两篇是新闻报道，两篇都是我写的。

At the bottom of the letter was a section called “Further Reading for the General Public,” which listed three links. One was an X thread from Geoffrey Irving, the AI safety researcher who had left in 2019 for DeepMind, saying that Altman had “lied to me on various occasions” and “was deceptive, manipulative, and worse to others.” The other two were journalism articles. Both of them were mine.

当我看到这条推文时，马斯克的推文已经获得了超过一万次转发和数倍的点赞。我发现阅读选择令人惊讶：关于OpenAI的文章已经有很多了。为什么他们只选择链接我写的两篇呢？第一篇是我为《麻省理工技术评论》撰写的 2020 年 OpenAI 简介；第二篇是我与同事 Charlie Warzel 刚刚为《大西洋月刊》撰写的一篇文章，该文章为董事会危机提供了背景，并让我们看到了 ChatGPT 之后公司内部加剧的意识形态两极分化。

By the time I saw it, Musk’s tweet had already gained over ten thousand retweets and several times more likes. I found the reading selection surprising: There had been plenty of pieces written about OpenAI. Why had they chosen to link only the two written by me? The first was my 2020 OpenAI profile for MIT Technology Review; the second was a piece I had just written with my colleague Charlie Warzel for The Atlantic, providing context to the board crisis with a window into the ideological polarization that had inflamed within the company after ChatGPT.

在这一部分的上方，有一个用于交换加密信息的 Tor 邮箱。上面写道：“我们鼓励 OpenAI 前员工与我们联系。”我心想，这封信的作者是不是想通过挑选我的部分内容来联系我。于是我创建了自己的 Tor 邮箱，并输入了一条消息：
