Altman once remarked onstage that the best book he’d read the previous year in 2018 was The Mind of Napoleon, a more than three-hundred-page compilation of quotes from Napoleon Bonaparte, the French military leader who led a coup to seize control of the French government, installed himself as France’s emperor, and subsequently sought to conquer Europe.

奥特曼说：“显然，人类存在着严重缺陷，但人类确实令人印象深刻。”

“Obviously deeply flawed human, but man, impressive,” Altman said.

“他有什么样的见解？”主持此次活动的乔治梅森大学经济学教授泰勒·科文问道。

“What kinds of insights did he have?” asked Tyler Cowen, an economics professor at George Mason University, who was hosting the event.

“他对人类心理学有着不可思议的理解，”Altman 回答道，他几周后就要转投 OpenAI 全职工作，目前仍担任 YC 总裁。“我们在许多最优秀的创始人身上都能看到这种特质。”

“His incredible understanding of human psychology,” replied Altman, who was weeks away from switching to OpenAI full time and still president of YC. “That is something we see among many of our best founders.”

随后，奥尔特曼讲述了一段令他印象最深的文字。这段文字是拿破仑对法国大革命的座右铭（后来成为法国的国家座右铭）——“自由、平等、博爱”——的反思，以及如何重新诠释和运用它来巩固自己的权力。最终，拿破仑在这面旗帜下做了相反的事情：他限制自由，摒弃博爱——一种基于团结一致的哲学——并且只赋予法国男性平等，而不是妇女，同时重新引入殖民奴隶制，以重建法兰西帝国。

Altman then recounted a specific passage that had struck him most. It was Napoleon’s reflections on the motto of the French revolution (what would become the country’s national motto)—“Liberté, egalité, fraternité”—and how it could be reinterpreted and wielded to consolidate his own power. It was ultimately under that banner that Napoleon did the opposite: He restricted freedom, dismissed fraternity—a philosophy based in unity and solidarity—and granted equality only to French men, not women, while reintroducing colonial slavery in an effort to reconstruct a French empire.

“所以他谈到了如何建立一个……可以控制人民的体系，”奥特曼回忆道。“我当时想，‘哇。我很高兴他没有执掌美国，因为他理解一些我不理解的深奥知识，而且显然能够利用这些知识来获取权力。’”

“So he talked about how you build a system…where you can kind of control the people,” Altman reflected. “I was like, ‘Wow. I’m glad he does not run the United States ’cause that is a dude who understands something deep that I did not and clearly was able to use it for power.’ ”

六年前，我最初对 OpenAI 的利他主义抱有怀疑，如今我却坚定地相信，OpenAI 的使命——确保通用人工智能造福全人类——或许最初只是出于一种真诚的理想主义，但如今它已成为一种整合资源、构建帝国式权力结构的独特而有效的公式。这个公式包含三个要素：

Six years after my initial skepticism about OpenAI’s altruism, I’ve come to firmly believe that OpenAI’s mission—to ensure AGI benefits all of humanity—may have begun as a sincere stroke of idealism, but it has since become a uniquely potent formula for consolidating resources and constructing an empire-esque power structure. It is a formula with three ingredients:

首先，该使命通过将人才聚集在一个宏伟的目标周围来集中人才，就像约翰·麦卡锡创造“人工智能”一词一样。”“最成功的创始人并非一开始就为了创办公司，”奥特曼在2013年博客中反思道，“他们的使命是创造一种更接近宗教的东西，而到了某个时候，他们发现成立公司是实现这一目标最简单的方式。”其次，这项使命能够集中资本和其他资源，同时消除障碍、监管和异议。创新、现代化、进步——为了实现这些，我们付出什么代价呢？面对那些据称存在的令人恐惧、失衡的企业和国家竞争对手，这一点尤其正确。“谁将掌控人工智能的未来？”在“全能危机”余波余波的背景下，奥特曼在2024年7月为《华盛顿邮报》撰写的一篇专栏文章中写道。“未来是美国及其盟国推进全球人工智能，传播该技术的好处并开放使用权的时代，还是一个专制时代，那些与我们价值观不同的国家或运动会利用人工智能来巩固和扩张其权力的时代？”

First, the mission centralizes talent by rallying them around a grand ambition, exactly in the way John McCarthy did with his coining of the phrase artificial intelligence. “The most successful founders do not set out to create companies,” Altman reflected on his blog in 2013. “They are on a mission to create something closer to a religion, and at some point it turns out that forming a company is the easiest way to do so.” Second, the mission centralizes capital and other resources while eliminating roadblocks, regulation, and dissent. Innovation, modernity, progress—what wouldn’t we pay to achieve them? This is all the more true in the face of the scary, misaligned corporate and state competitors that supposedly exist. “Who will control the future of AI?” wrote Altman in a July 2024 op-ed for The Washington Post amid the aftershocks of the Omnicrisis. “Will it be one in which the United States and allied nations advance a global AI that spreads the technology’s benefits and opens access to it, or an authoritarian one, in which nations or movements that don’t share our values use AI to cement and expand their power?”

最重要的是，这项使命仍然如此模糊，以至于可以被反复解读——就像拿破仑对法国大革命格言的解读一样——以集中化者想要的方式引导人才、资本和资源的集中化。什么是有益的？什么是通用人工智能？“我认为这是一个荒谬而毫无意义的术语，”奥特曼告诉《纽约客》董事会解雇他两天前还用过这个词。“所以我很抱歉我一直在用它。”

Most consequentially, the mission remains so vague that it can be interpreted and reinterpreted—just as Napoleon did to the French Revolution’s motto—to direct the centralization of talent, capital, and resources however the centralizer wants. What is beneficial? What is AGI? “I think it’s a ridiculous and meaningless term,” Altman told The New York Times just two days before the board fired him. “So I apologize that I keep using it.”

在最后一个要素上，OpenAI 的扩张令人瞩目。2015 年，OpenAI 的使命是成为一个“不受财务回报需求约束”的非营利组织，并开源研究成果，正如 OpenAI 在其发布公告中所写。2016 年，它的使命是“每个人都应该从人工智能诞生后的成果中受益，但不分享科学成果也完全可以”，正如 Sutskever 写给 Altman、Brockman 和 Musk 的信中所说。2018 年和 2019 年，它的使命是创建一个有上限的利润结构“以调动大量资源”，同时避免“在没有时间采取足够安全预防措施的情况下进行竞争”，正如 OpenAI 在其章程中所写。2020 年，它的使命是隔离模型并构建“API 作为开放和利益共享的策略”，正如 Altman 在回复我的第一篇简介中所写。2022 年，它的使命是“迭代部署”，并尽快部署 ChatGPT。而在2024年，奥特曼在GPT-4o发布后在他的博客上写道：“我们使命的一个关键部分是将非常强大的人工智能工具免费（或以极好的价格）交到人们手中。”

In this last ingredient, the creep of OpenAI has been nothing short of remarkable. In 2015, its mission meant being a nonprofit “unconstrained by a need to generate financial return” and open-sourcing research, as OpenAI wrote in its launch announcement. In 2016, it meant “everyone should benefit from the fruits of AI after its [sic] built, but it’s totally OK to not share the science,” as Sutskever wrote to Altman, Brockman, and Musk. In 2018 and 2019, it meant the creation of a capped profit structure “to marshal substantial resources” while avoiding “a competitive race without time for adequate safety precautions,” as OpenAI wrote in its charter. In 2020, it meant walling off the model and building an “API as a strategy for openness and benefit sharing,” as Altman wrote in response to my first profile. In 2022, it meant “iterative deployment” and racing as fast as possible to deploy ChatGPT. And in 2024, Altman wrote on his blog after the GPT-4o release: “A key part of our mission is to put very capable AI tools in the hands of people for free (or at a great price).”

即使在 OpenAI 的 Omnicrisis 期间，Altman 也开始再次重写他的定义。

Even during OpenAI’s Omnicrisis, Altman was beginning to rewrite his definitions once more.

在苏茨克弗和莱克离职后，2024 年 5 月 15 日的全体会议上，奥特曼强调，OpenAI 的 AI 能力将很快达到新的水平，这将需要公司重新思考和重组。“我们现在假设我们正在进入通用人工智能时代，”他说道。OpenAI 需要进一步封闭自身，并加倍加强其全球游说和公众宣传。“目前有很多事情我们还没有准备好，”他说道。“安全标准、我们必须制定的政策计划，以及为做好准备而需要召集的政府；一个计划、一个故事、一个未来，让人们能够预见到其社会经济影响。”

During the all-hands on May 15, 2024, after Sutskever’s and Leike’s departures, Altman stressed that OpenAI would soon reach new levels of AI capabilities that would require the company to rethink and reorganize. “We’re now going to assume we’re, like, entering the AGI era,” he said. In the name of its mission, OpenAI would need to close itself off further and to double down on its global lobbying and public messaging. “There’s a lot of stuff we are not currently ready for,” he said. “The standards for security, the policy plans that we have to have, and also the convening of governments that will need to happen to get this ready; a plan, a story, a future that people can see themselves in when it comes to the socioeconomic impact of this.”

与此同时，OpenAI 秉承其使命，不会在商业上放慢脚步。“这并不意味着我们不会推出优秀的产品，也不意味着我们不会继续进行伟大的研究。这并不意味着我们不会进行各种合作和其他很酷的事情。”当月月底，媒体报道称 OpenAI 已达成一项重要协议，将其模型引入苹果的产品；两家公司在两周后证实了这一消息。

At the same time, in the name of its mission, OpenAI would not slow down commercially. “It does not mean we’re not going to ship great products. It does not mean we’re not going to keep doing great research. It does not mean we’re not going to do all sorts of partnerships and other cool things.” At the end of that month, media reports would surface that OpenAI had secured a major deal to bring its models to Apple’s products; both companies would confirm the news two weeks later.

事实上，Altman 在全体会议上指出，OpenAI 和微软正在重新协商合作关系，以确保商业化进程能够持续进行。“我之后会立即飞往西雅图讨论此事。这需要不断发展，”他说道。“我们最初与微软达成协议时，就提出了一个叫做‘充分通用人工智能’（AGI）条款的东西，”该条款决定了 OpenAI 何时停止与微软共享其知识产权。“现在我们都有了不同的想法，”他补充道。OpenAI 何时达到 AGI 将不再有一个明确的分界点。“我们认为这将是一个持续的过程。”两家公司将继续合作，并以优惠的价格发布不断进步的技术。

In fact, Altman noted in the all-hands, OpenAI and Microsoft were renegotiating their partnership to ensure that commercialization continued to happen. “I am flying up to Seattle right after this to talk about that. It’s going to have to evolve,” he said. “When we originally set up the Microsoft deal, we came up with this thing called the sufficient AGI clause,” a clause that determined the moment when OpenAI would stop sharing its IP with Microsoft. “We all think differently now,” he added. There would no longer be a clean cutoff point for when OpenAI reached AGI. “We think it’s going to be a continual thing.” The two companies would continue to partner and release ever-advancing technologies—at a great price.

这是一个奇怪且不连贯的策略，只有一种解读才有意义：OpenAI 会做任何它需要做的事情，并相应地解释和重新解释其使命，以巩固其主导地位。

It was a bizarre and incoherent strategy that only made sense under one reading: OpenAI would do whatever it needed, and interpret and reinterpret its mission accordingly, to entrench its dominance.

幕后，奥特曼也在为巩固自己的控制权打下基础。董事会危机清楚地表明，OpenAI 的结构——一个非营利组织管理一个营利性组织——让他的下台几乎不可避免。这种结构不仅将公司中两股相互对抗的力量——“婴儿潮一代”和“末日一代”——牢牢束缚，双方都在争夺人工智能发展的控制权，而且还赋予了董事会广泛的权力，可以根据董事会自身（而非奥特曼本人）对他是否最适合完成使命的判断来解雇他。

Behind the scenes, Altman was also laying the groundwork to entrench his own control. The board crisis had made clear that OpenAI’s structure—a nonprofit governing a for-profit—had made his ouster as good as inevitable. The setup had not only enshrined the company’s two countervailing forces—the Boomers and the Doomers—both vying for control of AI development but had also given the board the broad power to fire him based on their own, and not his, interpretation of whether or not he was best serving the mission.

如果这种结构保持不变，此类冲突必定会再次发生。

Such a conflict was bound to happen again if the structure stayed in place.

5月28日，在高管们试图召回Sutskever不到一周后，一名员工再次在Slack频道#我有个问题#上发帖。“我不知道该不该问这个问题，”问题开头写道：OpenAI最新股东协议的细枝末节中隐藏着一些新细节，似乎允许解散这家非营利组织。“如何“非营利组织的治理结构是否牢固？”该员工写道，“该计划是否仍将由非营利组织管理？”

On May 28, less than a week after executives sought to bring back Sutskever, an employee posted again in the Slack channel #i-have-a-question. “I don’t know whether/how to ask this,” the question began: Deep in the weeds of OpenAI’s latest shareholder agreement were new details that seemed to allow for the dissolution of the nonprofit. “How solid is the non-profit?” the employee wrote. “Is the plan to remain governed by a non-profit?”

第二天，《The Information》报道称，这似乎不符合计划。奥特曼今年的首要任务之一是重组公司架构，使其更像一家典型的公司。次月，该刊物确认了更多细节。Altman 当时正在考虑几种不同的方案：一种是将 OpenAI 转型为传统的营利性机构；另一种是将其转型为像 Anthropic 和 xAI 这样的营利性公益机构。这两种方案都将保留该非营利组织作为独立实体的存在，但会削弱其董事会对公司业务的控制。在这种新架构下，投资者也向 Altman 施压，要求他持有公司股权，以使他的激励机制与投资者的激励机制更加一致。

The next day, The Information reported that this did not seem to be the plan. On Altman’s list of top priorities for the year was a restructuring of the organization to look more like a typical company. The following month, the publication confirmed more details. Altman was considering a few different scenarios: one could be transitioning OpenAI to a traditional for-profit; the other would be transitioning it to a for-profit public benefit corporation like Anthropic and xAI. Both scenarios would retain the existence of the nonprofit as a separate entity but dismantle its board’s control over the company’s business. Under this new structure, investors were also pressuring Altman to take equity in the company to align his incentives more directly with their own.

—

—

在接下来的几个月里，随着 OpenAI 制定过渡计划，Omnicrisis 期间的两股力量仍在继续发挥作用。末日论者加大了对 OpenAI 的公开施压。6 月 4 日，《纽约时报》报道了丹尼尔·科科塔伊洛 (Daniel Kokotajlo) 以及他发起的一项新活动，呼吁先进的人工智能公司致力于提高透明度和举报人保护措施，以保留员工向公众警告公司内部风险的权利。在一封详细说明其要求的公开信中，Kokotajlo 与其他 12 名签名者一起签署了该信，其中 10 人来自 OpenAI 安全家族的不同时期。一个月后，《华盛顿邮报》报道称，OpenAI 的一个团队也向美国证券交易委员会提起了诉讼，指控该公司过于宽泛的退出协议违反了联邦举报人保护法。当月晚些时候，五名美国参议员致信奥特曼，提出问题，要求更清楚地解释莱克、科科塔伊洛等人提出的各种指控，以及派珀关于 OpenAI 无视人工智能安全和压制员工批评的报道。

Over the next few months, as OpenAI developed plans for the transition, the two forces at play during the Omnicrisis continued. Doomers escalated their public pressure on the company. On June 4, The New York Times profiled Daniel Kokotajlo and a new campaign he launched calling for advanced AI companies to commit to greater transparency and whistleblower protections that preserve the right of employees to warn the public about risks that they saw within the company. In an open letter detailing their demands, Kokotajlo was joined by twelve other signatories, ten of whom were from various eras of OpenAI’s Safety clan. A month later, The Washington Post reported that a group from OpenAI had also filed a complaint with the SEC, alleging that the company had violated federal whistleblower protections with its overly broad exit agreements. Later that month, five US senators would send a letter to Altman with questions demanding greater clarity on the various allegations from Leike, Kokotajlo, and others, as well as Piper’s reporting over OpenAI’s disregard of AI safety and suppression of employee criticism.

与此同时，奥特曼领导层的混乱和员工的不满情绪持续不减。加之婴儿潮一代和末日一代的争斗持续不断，导致公司报告结构不断变动。布罗克曼不再向穆拉蒂汇报，而是向奥特曼汇报；亚历山大·马德里在收到参议员的信后不久就被调离工作岗位，不再担任防备团队负责人，而是担任研究方面的较小职务。OpenAI 还引入了更多经验丰富的高管，包括社区社交媒体平台 Nextdoor 前首席执行官 Sarah Friar 担任首席财务官，以及 Facebook、Instagram 和 Twitter 前产品负责人 Kevin Weil 担任首席产品官。

Meanwhile, the chaos among leadership and frustrations at Altman continued unabated. Combined with the ongoing Boomer-Doomer tussle, it was leading to repeated changes in the company’s reporting structure. Brockman stopped reporting to Murati and reported instead to Altman; Aleksander Mądry was reassigned shortly after the senators’ letter from heading the Preparedness team to a smaller role in research. OpenAI was also bringing in more seasoned executives, including Sarah Friar, the former CEO of the neighborhood social media platform Nextdoor, to be chief financial officer, and Kevin Weil, a former product leader at Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, to be chief product officer.

很快，该公司将失去一批任职时间最长的高管。第一个离职的是约翰·舒尔曼 (John Schulman)，他于 2024 年 8 月 5 日宣布离职，并表示他希望“进一步关注人工智能协同”，并决定在 Anthropic 任职。同一天，布罗克曼宣布，他将休假至今年年底，休假的部分原因是员工对其领导层的不满，也是他在公司奔波九年后需要的休息。

Soon enough, the company would lose a string of its most tenured executives. First to go was John Schulman, who announced his departure on August 5, 2024, noting his desire “to deepen my focus on AI alignment” and his decision to do so at Anthropic. On the same day, Brockman announced that he was taking a sabbatical through the end of the year, framing the leave of absence, in part a culmination of employee grievances with his leadership, as a needed break after nine years of sprinting at the company.

次月9月25日，另一位曾向董事会表达对Altman严重担忧的高管Mira Murati突然宣布也将离职。“我在OpenAI团队的六年半时间里，是一份非凡的荣幸，”她写道，感谢Altman和Brockman，并表示她非常珍惜并将继续支持公司。“我选择离开，是因为我想腾出时间和空间来进行我自己的探索。”几个小时后，又有两位关键领导人发表了离职声明：首席研究官鲍勃·麦格鲁 (Bob McGrew) 和副总裁巴雷特·佐夫 (Barret Zoph)，后者曾与舒尔曼共同领导训练后团队。三人都向同事和公众强调，在 OpenAI 达到又一个重要里程碑之后，现在是时候高调离开：OpenAI 最新模型 Strawberry 将于 9 月中旬按照公司的新命名惯例 o1 发货，这是 Sutskever 对公司做出的最后贡献之一。

The following month, on September 25, the other executive who had voiced serious concerns about Altman to the board, Mira Murati, abruptly announced she was also leaving. “My six-and-a-half years with the OpenAI team have been an extraordinary privilege,” she wrote, thanking Altman and Brockman and noting how much she cherished and would continue to root for the company. “I’m stepping away because I want to create the time and space to do my own exploration.” Within hours, two more key leaders issued their own departure statements: Chief Research Officer Bob McGrew and VP Barret Zoph, who had co-led the post-training team with Schulman. All three emphasized to colleagues and the public that the timing felt right to leave OpenAI on a high note, after it had reached another major milestone: the shipping of OpenAI’s latest model, Strawberry, in mid-September under the company’s new naming convention, o1, building upon one of Sutskever’s final contributions to the company.

—

—

说实话，时机很糟糕。Omnicrisis 事件之后，OpenAI 面临的竞争只会加剧。马斯克正在以惊人的速度扩展他的计算能力以构建 xAI。Anthropic 的最新版本克劳德正在从 ChatGPT 那里抢走客户。苏茨克弗已正式成立新的竞争对手公司 Safe Superintelligence，并刚刚宣布获得 10 亿美元的启动资金。

In truth, the timing was terrible. After the Omnicrisis, the competition facing OpenAI had only accelerated. Musk was expanding his computing capacity at an alarming pace to build xAI. Anthropic’s latest version of Claude was pulling customers away from ChatGPT. Sutskever had officially formed his new rival company, Safe Superintelligence, and had only just announced a starting $1 billion in funding.

与此同时，经过一年多的工作，OpenAI 仍在努力达到 Orion 所需的性能，以证明其发布的合理性。该公司开始面临一个令人不安的前景：其久经考验的扩展方案似乎不再有效；为了进一步推进其 AI 系统，它可能需要全新的研究思路。这说起来容易做起来难，尤其是在 OpenAI 多年来一直致力于利用现有研究成果而非探索未知科学的情况下。

At the same time, after over a year of work, OpenAI was still struggling to attain the desired performance for Orion to justify its release. The company was beginning to stare down the barrel of an uncomfortable prospect: Its tried-and-true formula of scaling no longer seemed to be enough to work; to advance its AI systems further, it likely needed fundamentally new research ideas. This was far easier said than done in general, but even more so after OpenAI had spent years orienting its hiring and team organization around exploiting existing research rather than exploring uncharted science.

在穆拉蒂宣布这一消息的两天前，奥特曼发表了迄今为止最夸张的博客文章，OpenAI 的最新融资。这篇帖子的标题是“智能时代”，充满了对未来“难以想象”的繁荣的憧憬。“我们是如何走到下一轮繁荣飞跃的门槛的？”奥特曼写道。“简而言之：深度学习奏效了，规模化发展后可预见地变得更好，我们为此投入了越来越多的资源。”

Two days before Murati’s announcement, Altman had published his most bombastic blog post yet amid OpenAI’s latest fundraise. The post was titled “The Intelligence Age,” with its breathless promises about the “unimaginable” prosperity to come. “How did we get to the doorstep of the next leap in prosperity?” Altman wrote. “In 15 words: deep learning worked, got predictably better with scale, and we dedicated increasing resources to it.”

在一次全体员工大会上，穆拉蒂向员工解释了她突然宣布离职的原因。“我希望我先把离职消息告诉大家，而不是从你们的经理、其他人，甚至媒体那里得知。” 鉴于OpenAI面临的种种关注，她认为除了让大家措手不及之外，没有其他办法可以提前宣布离职。麦格鲁说，得知穆拉蒂的决定后，他也决定是时候离开了。“我意识到，我实际上已经完成了来这里时想要完成的大部分关键任务。”

During an all-hands, Murati explained to employees the abruptness of her announcement. “I wanted the news of my departure to come to all of you from me first, and not to hear it from your managers, from anyone else, and let alone from the press.” With all of the scrutiny on OpenAI, she had seen no other way to do so without springing it as a surprise on everyone. Upon learning of Murati’s decision, McGrew then decided it was also time to go, he said. “I realized that I actually accomplished most of the key things that I wanted when I came here.”

正如 Sutskever 的离职一样，OpenAI 也试图平息三人的离职。“米拉、鲍勃和巴雷特彼此独立且友好地做出了这些决定，”奥特曼在随后发布的推文中写道，“但米拉做出决定的时机恰到好处，因此现在同时做出这些决定是合理的，这样我们就可以共同努力，顺利地交接给下一代领导层。”

As with Sutskever’s departure, OpenAI sought to smooth over the trio of exits. “Mira, Bob, and Barret made these decisions independently of each other and amicably,” Altman wrote in an internal note that he then tweeted, “but the timing of Mira’s decision was such that it made sense to now do this all at once, so that we can work together for a smooth handover to the next generation of leadership.”

代替 McGrew 的是研究负责人之一 Mark Chen，他介绍了在 4o 演示活动中，与 Murati 和 Zoph 并肩作战的 Joshua Achiam 将出任新的研究高级副总裁，与 Pachocki 共同领导该部门。OpenAI 的另一位长期研究员 Joshua Achiam 将出任新职位，担任任务协调主管。与 Zoph 一同加入的谷歌员工之一 Liam Fedus 很快将接手领导后期训练的工作。Altman 表示，OpenAI 目前不会寻找另一位首席技术官来取代 Murati。

In lieu of McGrew, Mark Chen, one of the research leads who presented next to Murati and Zoph at the 4o demo event, would step up as the new senior VP of research, to lead the division alongside Pachocki. Another longtime researcher at OpenAI, Joshua Achiam, would step into a new role, head of mission alignment. Liam Fedus, one of the Googlers who had arrived with Zoph, would soon take over his work leading post-training. For the time being, Altman said, OpenAI would not seek another CTO to replace Murati.

随着领导层的更迭和结构性变革的计划，该公司正在揭示一个不变的事实：它过去是、现在仍将是萨姆·奥特曼的人工智能帝国。

With all of the leadership and planned structural changes, the company was revealing its one constant: It was and still would be Sam Altman’s empire of AI.

—

—

2024年10月初，OpenAI最新一轮融资完成，金额达66亿美元，创下史上最大一轮风险投资，公司估值达1570亿美元。但融资过程中有一个限制：如果公司两年内未能转型为营利性公司，投资者可以要求退款。

In early October 2024, OpenAI’s newest funding round closed to the tune of $6.6 billion, the largest VC round in history, valuing the company at $157 billion. It included a hitch: Investors could demand their money back if the company did not convert into a for-profit in two years.

在 2024 年余下的时间里，OpenAI 的关键员工流失仍在继续：Luke Metz，与 Zoph 和 Fedus 一起加入的第三位谷歌员工；Miles Brundage，政策研究主管；Lilian Weng，继承了 Dave Willner 的信任和安全工作，并新晋升为负责安全的研究副总裁；以及 Alec Radford，他是将 OpenAI 推向 GPT 模型道路的原始研究员。

Through the rest of 2024, OpenAI’s hemorrhaging of key staff continued: Luke Metz, the third Googler who had joined with Zoph and Fedus; Miles Brundage, head of policy research; Lilian Weng, who had inherited Dave Willner’s trust and safety work and had been newly promoted to a VP of research leading safety; and Alec Radford, the original researcher who set OpenAI down the path of GPT models.

Anthropic公司在旧金山的广告牌上为克劳德发起了一场广告宣传活动，并打出一句俏皮的广告语：“没有那么多戏剧性。” 布罗克曼在人才流失之际提前结束了休假。安妮给萨姆发了一封法律信函，通知他她打算起诉他。马斯克现在与新当选的总统唐纳德·特朗普结盟，加大了诉讼力度，反对 OpenAI 预期的营利性转型，并公布了更多 OpenAI 创始人的早期电子邮件，其中包括 Altman 在背后说 Brockman 和 Sutskever 坏话的记录（“承认在这个过程中，他失去了 Greg 和 Ilya 的信任。感觉他们的信息不一致，有时感觉很幼稚。”）以及对透明度的厌恶（“感觉这分散了团队的注意力。”）。长期与马斯克不和的扎克伯格出人意料地支持马斯克；在一封致加州总检察长 Meta 也同样敦促阻止 OpenAI 的转型。““OpenAI 的行为可能会对硅谷产生深远的影响，”Meta 写道。此次转型可能会开创一个危险的先例，让更多初创公司将自己指定为非营利组织，从而允许它们及其投资者享受政府税收减免，直到它们实现盈利。

Anthropic began an ad campaign for Claude with a cheeky message on its billboards in San Francisco: “The one without all the drama.” Brockman returned early from his sabbatical amid the talent exodus. Annie sent Sam a legal letter, notifying him of her intent to sue. Musk, allied now with newly reelected president Donald Trump, cranked up his lawsuit, objecting to OpenAI’s anticipated for-profit conversion and releasing more early emails of OpenAI’s founding, including those that recounted Altman speaking badly about Brockman and Sutskever behind their backs (“Admitted that he lost a lot of trust with Greg and Ilya through this process. Felt their messaging was inconsistent and felt childish at times.”) and showing an aversion to transparency (“Felt like it distracted the team.”). In a surprise allegiance, Zuckerberg, who had long feuded with Musk, backed him up; in a letter to the California attorney general, Meta similarly urged a block on OpenAI’s conversion. “OpenAI’s conduct could have seismic implications for Silicon Valley,” Meta wrote. The conversion could set a dangerous precedent for many more startups to designate themselves as nonprofits, granting them and their investors government tax write-offs until they turned profitable.

年底，在假日新闻铺天盖地的报道中，OpenAI 正式宣布了其新架构计划。OpenAI 将转型为一家营利性公益机构，而非营利组织将作为独立实体继续运营，并持有营利性机构的股份。公告称，这种架构是为营利性和非营利性机构配备适当资源，使其在履行各自使命的同时，实现各自目标的最佳方式。“我们再次需要筹集超出预期的资金，”OpenAI 表示。“世界正在为 21 世纪的经济构建新的基础设施，涵盖能源、土地利用、芯片、数据中心、数据、人工智能模型和人工智能系统。我们力求不断发展，以便迈出我们使命的下一步，助力构建通用人工智能经济，并确保其造福人类。”

Late in the year, nestled in the holiday news dump, OpenAI formally announced the plans for its new structure. It would transition into a for-profit public benefit corporation, and the nonprofit would persist as a separate entity with shares in the for-profit. This structure, the announcement argued, was the best way to equip both for-profit and nonprofit with the right resources to carry out their respective objectives while serving the mission. “We once again need to raise more capital than we’d imagined,” it said. “The world is moving to build out a new infrastructure of energy, land use, chips, datacenters, data, AI models, and AI systems for the 21st century economy. We seek to evolve in order to take the next step in our mission, helping to build the AGI economy and ensuring it benefits humanity.”

新年伊始，奥特曼又重回风口浪尖。”我们现在有信心，我们知道如何按照我们传统上理解的方式构建通用人工智能，”他在 2025 年 1 月 6 日的一篇新博客文章中写道。“我们开始将目标转向真正意义上的超级智能。”单词。”

At the start of the new year, Altman was back to grandstanding. “We are now confident we know how to build AGI as we have traditionally understood it,” he wrote in a new blog post on January 6, 2025. “We are beginning to turn our aim beyond that, to superintelligence in the true sense of the word.”

结语

Epilogue

帝国如何衰落

How the Empire Falls

我2021 年，我遇到了一个与我曾经报道过的任何故事都不同的故事：新西兰的一个土著社区利用人工智能振兴毛利人语言te reo Māori 的故事。

In 2021, I came across a story that felt different from any that I’d ever reported: the story of an Indigenous community in New Zealand that was using AI to revitalize te reo Māori, the language of the Māori people.

与全球许多原住民群体一样，毛利人世世代代遭受着殖民统治的残酷对待。1867 年，英国颁布了《原住民学校法》，规定英语是学校唯一可以教授的语言。毛利儿童因讲自己的语言而受到羞辱甚至殴打。20 世纪初，快速的城市化席卷全国，毛利人社区解散分散，他们的文化和语言保护中心也被削弱。讲毛利语的人从毛利人口的 90% 骤降至 12%。120 年后，当新西兰（毛利人最初将他们的土地命名为 Aotearoa）改变政策时，已经没有多少毛利语教师来复兴这种垂死的语言。与之前的许多其他语言一样，毛利语几乎从地球上消失了。

Like many Indigenous groups globally, the Māori had suffered from generations of horrific treatment under colonial rule; in 1867, under the Native Schools Act, which made English the only language that could be taught in schools, Māori children were shamed and even beaten for speaking their own language. After rapid urbanization swept across the country in the early 1900s, Māori communities disbanded and dispersed, weakening their centers of culture and language preservation. The number of te reo speakers plummeted from 90 percent to 12 percent of the Māori population. By the time New Zealand, or Aotearoa as the Māori originally named their land, had reversed its policies 120 years later, there were few te reo teachers left to resuscitate a dying language. Like so many other languages before it, te reo nearly disappeared off the face of the earth.

语言消失的悲剧难以言表。正如人工智能研究人员最初致力于语言构建技术的原因一样，语言的消失远不止是一种交流方式的消失。每种语言都蕴含着丰富的历史，文化、知识；它是跨越时代的数百万人的集体产物，他们通过声音和文字形式捕捉关于宇宙、生命、人类经验的最微妙的观察；彼此分享惊人的美丽和痛苦的失败；教导孩子，向长辈学习；表达爱。

It’s hard to fully convey the tragedy of losing a language. For the same reasons AI researchers first gravitated toward language to build their technologies, the loss of a language extends far beyond the loss of a form of communication. Each language encodes within it rich histories, cultures, knowledge; it is the collective product of millions of people across time grasping for the sounds and written forms to capture the subtlest observations about the universe, about life, about the human experience; to share with one another stunning beauty and painful failure; to teach a child, to learn from an elder; to express love.

失去一种语言是一场全球性的悲剧，也是一场个人的悲剧。与自己的传承隔绝，被迫守护他人的传承，否则就会面临被击败的风险，这无异于以一种最原始的方式，在两者之间建立起一种清晰的等级制度：谁的历史、文化、知识值得传承，谁的文化如此微不足道，理应被抹去。

To lose a language is a global tragedy; it’s also a personal one. To be severed from your inheritance and forced to preserve someone else’s, or risk being beaten, is to establish, in one of the rawest ways possible, a clear hierarchy between whose history, whose culture, whose knowledge deserves to be passed down and whose is so insignificant it deserves to be erased.

大型语言模型加速了语言的消亡。即使是像 GPT-2 这样几代之前的模型，世界上也只有少数几种语言被足够多的人使用，并且有足够规模的在线记录，以满足这些模型的数据需求。在现存的七千多种语言中，根据联合国教科文组织的数据，近一半濒临灭绝；约三分之一的语言在网络上存在；只有不到2%的语言得到了谷歌翻译的支持；而根据OpenAI自己的测试，只有15种（0.2%）的语言得到了GPT-4超过80%准确率的支持。随着这些模型成为数字基础设施，互联网对不同语言群体的可及性——以及它所提供的经济机会的可及性——将持续萎缩，从而激励越来越多的群体优先学习和使用英语等主流语言，而不是自己的母语。

Large language models accelerate language loss. Even for models several generations earlier like GPT-2, there are only a few languages in the world that are spoken by enough people and documented online at sufficient scale to fulfill the data imperative of these models. Among the over seven thousand languages that still exist today, almost half are endangered according to UNESCO; about a third have some online presence; less than 2 percent are supported by Google Translate; and according to OpenAI’s own testing, only fifteen, or 0.2 percent, are supported by GPT-4 above an 80 percent accuracy. As these models become digital infrastructure, the internet’s accessibility to different language communities—and the accessibility of the economic opportunities it provides—will continue to shrink, incentivizing more and more of those communities to prioritize learning and speaking a dominant language like English over their own.

正是面对这种迫在眉睫的生存威胁——一种对生存的根本性不同理解——一对原住民夫妇，彼得-卢卡斯·琼斯 (Peter-Lucas Jones) 和基奥尼·马赫洛纳 (Keoni Mahelona)，首次将人工智能视为一种可能的工具，帮助新一代毛利语使用者重现其活力。琼斯是毛利人，而马赫洛纳是夏威夷原住民，他们是工作和生活中的伴侣。马赫洛纳说，两人相识并坠入爱河，是因为他在梦中看到了一个景象：如果他搬到新西兰，他会遇到一个毛利男孩，他会与他共度一生。

It was up against this impending existential threat—a fundamentally different conception of what is existential—that an Indigenous couple, Peter-Lucas Jones and Keoni Mahelona, first turned to AI as a possible tool for helping a new generation of speakers return te reo to its vibrancy. Jones, who is Māori, and Mahelona, who is native Hawaiian, are partners in work and in life. The two men met and fell in love, Mahelona says, after a vision came to him in a dream: If he moved to New Zealand, he would meet a Māori boy with whom he’d share his life.

2012 年，两人从惠灵顿搬回了琼斯出生于新西兰北部的凯塔亚。琼斯成为 Te Hiku Media 的首席执行官，这是一家用毛利语广播的公共广播电台，是致力于振兴毛利语的媒体和其他组织网络的一部分。在新的岗位上，琼斯发现了一个机会。在二十多年的广播中，Te Hiku 积累了大量讲毛利语者的音频档案，其中包括他祖母 Raiha Moeroa 的录音。她出生于十九世纪末，口音尚未受到殖民者英语的影响。琼斯还希望录制更多对毛利长者的采访，记录他们在去世前的口述历史和本土毛利语。在琼斯看来，这些录音可以成为宝贵的语言学习资源，是新一代毛利语使用者回到过去的门户，让他们听到自己语言的原始声音，并与祖先的智慧联系起来。

In 2012, the two moved from Wellington back to the town where Jones was born, Kaitāia, in Aotearoa’s northern reaches. Jones became CEO of Te Hiku Media, a public radio station that broadcasts in te reo, part of a broader network of media and other organizations engaged in te reo’s revitalization. In his new role, Jones identified an opportunity. Over its twenty-odd years of broadcasting, Te Hiku had amassed a wealth of archival audio of people speaking te reo, including a recording of his own grandmother Raiha Moeroa, born in the late nineteenth century, whose accent had yet to be distorted by the influences of the colonizers’ English. Jones also had an ambition to record many more interviews with Māori elders to document their oral histories and native te reo before they passed away. These recordings, as Jones saw it, could be a precious language-learning resource, a portal back in time for newer generations of te reo speakers to hear the original sounds of their language and connect with the wisdom of their ancestors.

由于流利的毛利语使用者稀缺，挑战在于如何将音频转录成文字，帮助学习者跟上。因此，在2016年，OpenAI刚刚起步之际，琼斯向正在改进Te Hiku网站的马赫罗纳寻求解决方案。马赫罗纳博学多识，曾在奥林学院学习机械工程，第一个硕士学位是工商管理，第二个硕士学位是作为富布赖特学者在新西兰学习物理和计算纳米技术。他很快想到了使用人工智能的点子：借助一个经过精心训练的毛利语语音识别模型，Te Hiku只需几个说话者就能转录其音频库。

The challenge was transcribing the audio to help learners follow along, given the dearth of fluent te reo speakers. So in 2016, just as OpenAI was getting started, Jones turned to Mahelona, who was revamping Te Hiku’s website, to figure out a solution. A polymath, Mahelona had studied mechanical engineering at Olin College, business management for his first master’s, and physics and computational nanotechnology for his second as a Fulbright scholar in New Zealand. He quickly came up with the idea of using AI: With a carefully trained te reo speech-recognition model, Te Hiku would be able to transcribe its audio repository with only a few speakers.

Te Hiku 的故事与 OpenAI 和硅谷的人工智能开发模式截然不同。Jones 和 Mahelona 深知殖民掠夺带来的毁灭性影响，他们决心只有在能够保证三个条件——同意、互惠和毛利人民的主权——的情况下，才会开展这个项目。这意味着，即使在启动项目之前，他们也要获得毛利社区及其长老的许可，询问他们是否真的想要这个项目；在收集训练数据时，他们只会寻求那些完全了解数据用途的人的贡献；愿意参与；为了最大限度地发挥模型的优势，他们会听取社区的意见，了解哪些语言学习资源最有帮助；一旦他们有了资源，他们还会购买自己的现场 Nvidia GPU 和服务器来训练他们的模型，而无需依赖任何科技巨头的云。

This is where Te Hiku’s story diverges completely from OpenAI’s and Silicon Valley’s model of AI development. Intimately familiar with the devastating effects of colonial dispossession, Jones and Mahelona were determined to carry out the project only if they could guarantee three things—consent, reciprocity, and the Māori people’s sovereignty—at every stage of development. This meant that even before embarking on the project, they would get permission from the Māori community and their elders, asking them if the endeavor was even something they wanted; to collect the training data, they would seek contributions only from people who fully understood what the data would be used for and were willing to participate; to maximize the model’s benefit, they would listen to the community for what kinds of language-learning resources would be most helpful; and once they had the resources, they would also buy their own on-site Nvidia GPUs and servers to train their models without a dependency on any tech giant’s cloud.

最重要的是，Te Hiku 将创建一个流程，使其收集的数据能够持续作为未来福祉的资源，但绝不会被用于未经社区同意、可能剥削和伤害社区、或以其他方式侵犯社区权利的项目。根据毛利人的“kaitiakitanga”（监护）原则，这些数据将由 Te Hiku 管理，而不是免费发布到网上；Te Hiku 只会将数据授权给那些尊重毛利价值观、并计划将其用于社区同意且认为有益的项目的组织。

Most crucially, Te Hiku would create a process by which the data it collected would continue to be a resource for future benefit but never be co-opted for projects that the community didn’t consent to, that could exploit and harm them, or otherwise infringe on their rights. Based on the Māori principle of kaitiakitanga, or guardianship, the data would stay under Te Hiku’s stewardship rather than be posted freely online; Te Hiku would then license it only to organizations that respected Māori values and intended to use it for projects that the community agreed to and found helpful.

““数据是殖民的最后边疆，”马赫洛纳告诉我：“昔日的帝国从原住民社区手中夺取土地，然后强迫他们买回来，并附加新的限制性条款和服务，如果他们想重新获得所有权的话。人工智能只不过是土地掠夺的翻版。大型科技公司喜欢或多或少免费地收集你的数据——用来构建他们想要的任何东西，无论他们的最终目的是什么——然后把它们转手，作为服务卖给你。”

“Data is the last frontier of colonization,” Mahelona told me: The empires of old seized land from Indigenous communities and then forced them to buy it back, with new restrictive terms and services, if they wanted to regain ownership. “AI is just a land grab all over again. Big Tech likes to collect your data more or less for free—to build whatever they want to, whatever their endgame is—and then turn it around and sell it back to you as a service.”

从始至终，Jones 和 Mahelona 毫不妥协地完成了这个项目。他们一度发起了一项教育活动，旨在让更多毛利人了解人工智能，并发起了一场社区竞赛，以众包方式捐赠和注释数据。在十天内，Te Hiku 收集了约 2500 人录制的约 20 万条录音，总时长 310 小时，为高质量转录音频。这种参与程度在众多人工智能研究人员中前所未有，这充分证明了 Te Hiku 的方案在社区中赢得了多么大的信任和热情。一旦人们了解并同意该项目，并且完全信任 Te Hiku 会继续妥善管理这些数据，他们就非常乐意捐赠自己的数据。

From beginning to end, Jones and Mahelona pulled off the project without compromise. At one point, they kicked off an education campaign to teach more Māori people about AI and a community competition to crowdsource data donations and annotations. Within ten days, Te Hiku gathered three hundred ten hours of high-quality transcribed audio from some two hundred thousand recordings made by roughly twenty-five hundred people. The level of engagement was unheard of among many AI researchers—one that is a testament to the level of trust and excitement Te Hiku’s approach engendered within its community. People were more than willing to donate their data once they understood and consented to the project, and with full trust that Te Hiku would continue to steward that data appropriately.

与六百八十个数据相比，这个数据池显得黯然失色OpenAI 从网络上抓取了 1000 个小时的音频，用于训练其语音识别工具 Whisper。但 Te Hiku 的经验告诉我们，这 310 个小时仍然足以开发出首个准确率高达 86% 的te reo语音识别模型。OpenAI 致力于开发能够处理所有任务的单一海量 AI 模型，这一目标必然会尽可能多地收集数据，而 Te Hiku 则专注于创建一个小型、专用的模型，专注于某一领域。此外，Te Hiku 还受益于跨境开源 AI 社区：作为起点，它利用Mozilla 基金会推出了一个名为 DeepSpeech 的免费语音识别模型，它本身就是另一种人工智能发展愿景的产物。与 Te Hiku 一样，Mozilla 仅使用完全同意捐赠的数据来训练该模型，并使用由中国公司百度位于湾区的研究实验室开发的神经网络架构构建该模型。总的来说，Te Hiku 只使用了两块 GPU。

That data pool paled in comparison to the six hundred eighty thousand hours of audio that OpenAI ripped from around the web to train its speech-recognition tool, Whisper. But it is yet another lesson to be drawn from Te Hiku’s experience that the three hundred ten hours still proved sufficient for developing the very first te reo speech-recognition model with 86 percent accuracy. Where OpenAI seeks to develop singular massive AI models that will do anything, a quest that necessarily hoovers up as much data as possible, Te Hiku simply sought to create a small, specialized model that excels at one thing. In addition, Te Hiku benefited from the cross-border, open-source AI community: As its starting point, it used a free speech-recognition model from the Mozilla Foundation called DeepSpeech, which itself is an artifact of a different vision of AI development. Like Te Hiku, Mozilla trained the model only on data donated with full consent and built it using a neural network architecture developed by the Bay Area–based research lab of the Chinese company Baidu. In all, Te Hiku used only two GPUs.

—

—

在 ChatGPT 迅速占领主流人工智能开发范式，几乎将同意、互惠和主权抛诸脑后之前，我就撰写了关于 Te Hiku 工作的文章。但此后的几年里，我逐渐意识到 Te Hiku 的激进方法更加重要且具有现实意义。我在本书中对 OpenAI 和硅谷更广阔愿景的批判，绝不是要彻底否定人工智能。我反对的是一种危险的观点，即人工智能的广泛利益只能源于——事实上，也永远不会源于——这样一种技术愿景：这项技术需要我们完全放弃隐私、自主权和价值，包括我们的劳动和艺术的价值，最终走向帝国式的集权化。

I wrote about Te Hiku’s work before ChatGPT swiftly seized the dominant AI development paradigm, all but tossing consent, reciprocity, and sovereignty out the window. But in the years since, I’ve come to see Te Hiku’s radical approach as even more relevant and vital. The critiques that I lay out in this book of OpenAI’s and Silicon Valley’s broader vision are not by any means meant to dismiss AI in its entirety. What I reject is the dangerous notion that broad benefit from AI can only be derived from—indeed, will ever emerge from—a vision for the technology that requires the complete capitulation of our privacy, our agency, and our worth, including the value of our labor and art, toward an ultimately imperial centralization project.

Te Hiku 向我们展示了另一种方式。它设想了人工智能及其发展可以完全相反。模型可以很小，任务特定，其训练数据可以保存且可知，从而消除普遍存在的剥削性和心理伤害性劳动行为的诱因，以及生产和运行大型超级计算机所带来的无尽的资源掠夺。人工智能的创造可以由社区驱动，由各方共识，并尊重当地环境和历史；其应用可以提升和加强边缘化社区；其治理可以具有包容性和民主性。

Te Hiku shows us another way. It imagines how AI and its development could be exactly the opposite. Models can be small and task specific, their training data contained and knowable, ridding the incentives for widespread exploitative and psychologically harmful labor practices and the all-consuming extractivism of producing and running massive supercomputers. The creation of AI can be community driven, consensual, respectful of local context and history; its application can uplift and strengthen marginalized communities; its governance can be inclusive and democratic.

Te Hiku 并非唯一一个探索人工智能发展新路径的组织。在我撰写本书的报道过程中，世界各地涌现出许多组织和运动，它们不断激励着我，抵抗人工智能帝国，维护自身的自主权，并展望新的发展方向。

Te Hiku isn’t the only organization pursuing new paths for AI development. Through the course of my reporting for this book, I was repeatedly inspired by the many organizations and movements around the world that have blossomed to resist the empires of AI, assert their rights to self-determination, and envision a new way forward.

在 Timnit Gebru 被谷歌解雇后，她于2021年12月创立了一家非营利组织，继续她的研究。她将其命名为DAIR，即分布式人工智能研究所——“分布式”一词旨在挑战中心化。“这是我首先想到的词，”格布鲁说道。她设想组建一支来自世界各地的研究人员团队，他们将扎根于各自的社区，将丰富的经验和本土视角带入研究所的工作，同时也利用这些成果造福这些社区。“科技正在通过硅谷影响整个世界，但整个世界却没有机会影响科技，”她说道。

After Timnit Gebru was ousted from Google, she founded a nonprofit in December 2021 to continue her research. She named it DAIR, the Distributed AI Research Institute—“distributed” to defy centralization. “That was the first word that came to my mind,” Gebru says. She imagined building a team of researchers from around the world who would stay embedded in their communities to bring the rich experiences and perspectives of their local contexts to the institute’s work, while also using that work to benefit those communities. “Tech is impacting the whole world out of Silicon Valley, but the whole world is not getting a chance to impact tech,” she says.

社会学家亚历克斯·汉纳 (Alex Hanna) 是谷歌“随机鹦鹉”论文的合著者之一，他率先加入格布鲁，担任 DAIR 的研究主任。汉纳的首要任务是撰写一份研究理念，以进一步阐述该组织的工作精神。为此，格布鲁和汉纳聘请了 DAIR 的第三人米拉格罗斯·米切利 (Milagros Miceli)，他也是社会学家和计算机科学家，一直在研究人工智能行业的剥削性劳工行为。他们共同撰写了他们的理念：“我们的研究旨在使那些通常无法享受人工智能服务的社区受益，并共同创建拒绝、质疑和重塑人工智能系统的途径。”

Alex Hanna, a sociologist and one of the Google coauthors on the “Stochastic Parrots” paper, became the first to join Gebru as DAIR’s director of research. Hanna’s first order of business was to write a research philosophy to further elaborate the ethos of the organization’s work. To do so, Gebru and Hanna hired DAIR’s third person, Milagros Miceli, another sociologist and computer scientist who had been conducting research into the AI industry’s exploitative labor practices. Together they wrote their philosophy: “Our research is intended to benefit communities which are typically not served by AI and create pathways to refuse, interrogate, and reshape AI systems together.”

他们为这一理念的实施创建了七大支柱，包括：以受人工智能研究影响但尚未在研究中得到典型体现的群体为中心，并与他们建立有意义的关系；将他们视为追求知识生产的真正合作伙伴；公平地补偿参与研究和技术创造的任何形式的劳动；质疑人工智能发展背后的体系，这些体系将那些在历史上一直被边缘化的人边缘化；并与这些社区合作，共同构想替代方案，逐步将世界重塑为他们想要居住的世界。

They created seven pillars for the philosophy’s implementation, including centering and forging meaningful relationships with communities affected by but not yet typically represented in AI research, treating them as true partners in the pursuit of knowledge production, fairly compensating any forms of labor involved in the creation of research and technologies, questioning the systems underpinning AI development that marginalize those who’ve always been historically marginalized, and working with those communities to dream up alternatives that could bit by bit remold the world toward one they wanted to inhabit.

从那时起，米切利开始了一项新的研究项目，将他们的哲学付诸实践。她创建了“数据工作者调查”（Data Workers' Inquiry），邀请世界各地的数据工作者提出关于数据标注行业及其改进方法的研究问题。无论他们身在何处，她都会支付给他们相当于她所在城市德国研究人员的标准工资：每小时25欧元，以反映他们工作的价值。

From there Miceli embarked on a new research project to put their philosophy into practice. She created the Data Workers’ Inquiry and invited data workers from around the world to formulate their own research questions about the data-annotation industry and how to make it better. Regardless of where they lived, she paid them a standard researcher’s salary in Germany, where she is based, to reflect the value of the work they did: twenty-five euros an hour.

“数据工作总是存在这样一种错误的逻辑：我们能给这些人的最低工资是多少？这源于一种殖民主义逻辑：你选择一个能用最低预算做最多事情的地方，在那里你可以真正地从人们那里窃取资源，以低成本窃取资源，”米切利说。“问题是，如果这项工作能为这些公司带来数十亿甚至数万亿美元的收入，为什么他们只支付每小时两美元的工资？我们为什么不看看这些公司能支付多少钱，而要看看这些员工能少拿多少钱？”

“There’s always this false logic around data work: What is the minimum that we can pay these people? That comes from a colonialist logic: You choose a place that allows you to do the most with the cheapest budget and where you can really steal from people, steal resources at low cost,” Miceli says. “The question is why are these companies paying two dollars an hour if the work is making them billions or trillions in revenue? Why don’t we look at how much these companies can pay instead of how much less these workers can take?”

参加第一轮调查的 15 名工人包括来自委内瑞拉的 Oskarina Veronica Fuentes Anaya 和来自肯尼亚的 Mophat Okinyi。为了完成她的项目，Fuentes 与一位动画艺术家合作，制作了一段关于她经历的视频，并与其他数据工作者合作，强调他们共同面临的挑战：平台上任务的稀缺、工作时间的不可预测和控制，以及极低的薪酬。如今，Fuentes 同时在五个数据注释平台上工作，月薪略高于哥伦比亚的最低工资标准 335 美元左右。每项任务的平均报酬在 1 到 5 美分之间；她仍然强迫自己在半夜接到任务时醒来。“我们是社会的幽灵，我敢说，对于我们服务多年的公司来说，我们是廉价的、可随意支配的劳动力，没有任何保障或保护，”她在自己的项目中写道。自“数据工作者调查”以来，她一直在线上讲座和网络研讨会上讲述这些经历，希望向公司和政策制定者施加压力，以改善员工待遇。

Among the fifteen workers who participated in the first round of the inquiry were Oskarina Veronica Fuentes Anaya from Venezuela and Mophat Okinyi from Kenya. For her project, Fuentes partnered with an animation artist to create a video about her experiences, and collaborated with other data workers to highlight their shared challenges: the scarcity of the tasks on the platform, the unpredictable and uncontrollable working hours, and the abysmal pay. These days Fuentes works on five data-annotation platforms at the same time to make a little more than the minimum wage in Colombia, around $335 a month. Each task pays on average between one and five pennies; she still forces herself to wake up when tasks arrive in the middle of the night. “We are ghosts to society, and I dare say we are cheap, disposable labor for the companies we have served for years without guarantees or protection,” she wrote for her project. Since the Data Workers’ Inquiry, she has continued to speak about these experiences in online talks and webinars in the hopes of applying pressure on companies and policymakers to enforce better worker treatment.

在另一个大陆，奥金伊也在组织。2023年5月，OpenAI 与 Sama 的合同突然终止一年后，他成为了总部位于肯尼亚的非洲内容版主联盟的组织者，该联盟致力于为从事互联网领域最恶劣劳动的非洲工人争取更高的工资和更好的待遇。半年后，他通过我在《华尔街日报》上发表的文章公开了自己在 OpenAI 的经历。他还与前 Sama 同事 Richard Mathenge 一起创办了一个名为 Techworker Community Africa（TCA）的非营利组织。

A continent away, Okinyi is also organizing. In May 2023, a little over a year after OpenAI’s contract with Sama abruptly ended, he became an organizer of the Kenya-based African Content Moderators Union, which seeks to fight for better wages and better treatment of African workers who perform the internet’s worst labor. Half a year later, after going public about his OpenAI experience through my article in The Wall Street Journal, he also started a nonprofit of his own called Techworker Community Africa, TCA, with one of his former Sama colleagues Richard Mathenge.

2024年8月，当我们再次见面时，Okinyi 设想将 TCA 打造成一个资源库，不仅服务于非洲人工智能数据工作者群体，也服务于寻求支持他们的国际组织和政策制定者。他一直在组织线上会议和校内集会，向工作者和学生，尤其是女性，讲授他们的劳动和数据隐私权利，以及人工智能行业的内部运作。他正在寻求资金，以开设一个培训中心，提升技能。他曾会见了前往内罗毕的美国代表，这些代表旨在更好地了解在美国科技公司工作的工作者的经历。他还负责处理来自全球组织的各种请求，包括致力于支持全球南方国家工人的人权和劳工权利组织 Equidem，以及牛津互联网研究所的 Fairwork 项目。

In August 2024, as we caught up, Okinyi envisioned building TCA into a resource both for the African AI data worker community and for international groups and policymakers seeking to support them. He had been organizing online conferences and in-school assemblies to teach workers and students, especially women, about their labor and data privacy rights and the inner workings of the AI industry. He was seeking funding to open a training center for upskilling people. He had met with US representatives who came to visit Nairobi to better understand the experience of workers serving American tech companies. He was fielding various requests from global organizations, including Equidem, a human and labor rights organization focused on supporting workers in the Global South, and the Oxford Internet Institute’s Fairwork project.

在“数据工作者调查”中，他采访了肯尼亚的 Remotasks 员工。Scale 公司曾一度禁止他们访问其平台，导致他们从未兑现的最后一笔收入消失。他利用 TCA 筹集的部分捐款，帮助他们度过了这场财务困境。“随着这一章尘埃落定，有一件事依然清晰：不受约束的权力和肆无忌惮的贪婪给人类带来了巨大的损失，”他写道。“这些工人的声音呼应了人们对更光明、更公平未来的期盼……这是一次行动的号召，确保世界各地的工人都能得到应有的尊严和尊重。”

For the Data Workers’ Inquiry, he interviewed Remotasks workers in Kenya whom Scale had summarily blocked from accessing its platform, disappearing the last of their earnings that they had never cashed out. He used part of the donations that TCA collected to support them through the financial nightmare. “As the dust settles on this chapter, one thing remains clear: the human toll of unchecked power and unbridled greed,” he wrote. “These workers’ voices echo the hope for a brighter and more equitable future…it’s a call to action to ensure that workers everywhere are treated with the dignity and respect they deserve.”

奥金伊表示，在自己的生活中，他通过倡导活动获得的尊严和尊重，让他重燃希望，并极大地改善了他的心理健康。在我们打电话之前不久，他收到了消息：他将被列入《时代》杂志年度百位最具影响力的人工智能人物名单。“我觉得我的工作正在“我很感激，”他说道。但这并不意味着工作没有挑战。2024 年 3 月，他辞去了 Sama 之后就职的外包公司的全职工作。他说公司领导层并不欣赏他的组织活动。“他们认为我会影响员工成为积极分子。”随着工会和 TCA 的声音越来越大，该公司将一些项目转移到了加纳。他听说肯尼亚政府官员抱怨说，工人的抗议活动吓跑了投资，导致更多肯尼亚人失业。

In his own life, the dignity and respect that Okinyi has received from his advocacy has reinvigorated him with new hope and greatly improved his mental health, he says. Not long before our call, he had received news that he would be named in Time magazine’s annual list of the one hundred most influential people in AI. “I feel like my work is being appreciated,” he says. That isn’t to say the work has come without challenges. In March 2024, he resigned from his full-time job at the outsourcing company he worked for after Sama. He says the company’s leadership didn’t appreciate his organizing. “They thought I would influence the employees to be activists.” That same company shifted some of its projects to Ghana as the union and TCA grew more vocal. He’s heard that Kenyan government officials have complained that the worker agitation is scaring away investments and leaving more Kenyans jobless.

该行业的全球性使得奥金伊更加致力于让国际社会关注非洲数据工作者。即使肯尼亚政府支持，仅靠肯尼亚法律也难以限制人工智能公司的行为。他表示，这些公司大多来自美国，尤其是旧金山。国际社会需要齐心协力，追究他们的责任。

The global nature of the industry has made Okinyi even more committed to bringing international attention to African data workers. Even if the Kenyan government were supportive, Kenyan law alone would do little to restrict the behavior of AI companies. Most of these companies come from the US and San Francisco specifically, he says. There needs to be a concerted international effort to hold them accountable.

在乌拉圭，丹尼尔·佩纳得出了同样的结论。人工智能行业的供应链错综复杂，规模庞大。“他们从这里获取能源，将数据输送到那里，从某个地方开采矿产，从其他地方引进工人，”他说道。面对这些蔓延的影响以及背后庞大而强大的公司，每个在当地抗争的社区都会感到孤立无援，无力自拔，尤其是在受到本国政府“需要这些公司来维持表面上的经济稳定”的束缚时。我见到他后不久，他得知，他的政府无视了他那份有四百多人签名的请愿书，该请愿书旨在更广泛地研究谷歌数据中心在乌拉圭的社会和环境影响。环境部反而悄悄批准了该项目，直到30天的公开竞标期结束后才公布了这一决定，他说。佩纳并没有放弃。他一直在与智利的MOSACAT沟通，并尽可能多地联系其他同样抵制科技行业剥削和开采的社区。通过跨境联结他们的行动，通过彼此分享信息和抵抗策略，他看到了一条构建更强大集体力量的道路，这种力量能够对这个行业施加压力，并促使其朝着更好的方向发展。“我们需要在全球范围内抗争，”他说。

In Uruguay, Daniel Pena draws the same conclusions. The AI industry’s supply chain is convoluted and expansive. “They take energy from here, the data goes there, they extract minerals from somewhere, they bring workers from somewhere else,” he says. Against these sprawling impacts and the massive, powerful companies behind them, each community fighting their local struggle can feel isolated and disempowered, especially when hamstrung by their own governments that “need the companies to maintain an appearance of a stable economy.” Shortly after I met him, he learned that his own government ignored his petition with over four hundred signatories to more extensively study the social and environmental impacts of the Google data center in their country. The environmental ministry instead quietly approved the project, revealing the decision only after the thirty-day public contestation window was over, he says. Pena isn’t giving up. He’s been speaking with MOSACAT in Chile and reaching out to as many other communities as possible that are also resisting the tech industry’s exploitation and extractivism. By connecting their movements across borders, by sharing information and resistance strategies with one another, he sees a path to building more collective power that can pressure and evolve the industry toward something better. “We need to fight on a global level,” he says.

—

—

如果OpenAI的使命是建立帝国的公式，那么瓦解它的公式又是什么呢？在我撰写本书之际，我们无法知晓这家公司以及快速发展的人工智能行业将如何继续发展的细节。或许OpenAI众多竞争对手中的某个会取代它的领先地位；这些人工智能帝国的策略很可能会在开发模型、利用劳动力和扩展计算基础设施方面发生演变。但无论两年或十年后情况如何，有些事情我们应该坚持，不应该改变。

If OpenAI’s mission is a formula for constructing empire, what is the formula for dissolving it? As I write this book, it’s impossible to know the fine-grain details of how this company and the fast-paced AI industry will continue to unfold. Perhaps one of OpenAI’s many competitors will supersede its leading position; very likely the tactics of these empires of AI will evolve in how they develop models, exploit labor, and expand computing infrastructure. But regardless of how things play out in two years or ten years, there are things we should do that shouldn’t change.

2019年，斯坦福大学人工智能研究员里亚·卡鲁里在NeurIPS的“人工智能中的酷儿”研讨会上发表演讲，就如何确保人工智能“行善”这一问题提出了一个深刻的替代方案。善、造福人类——这些词的含义永远取决于观察者。相反，我们应该问，人工智能是如何转移权力的：它是在巩固权力，还是在重新分配权力？用本书的框架来概括，它是在继续巩固帝国，还是在开始将我们拉回民主？

In her 2019 talk at NeurIPS, during the Queer in AI workshop, Ria Kalluri, an AI researcher at Stanford, proposed an incisive alternative to the question of how to ensure AI does “good.” Goodness, benefit to humanity—these terms will always be in the eye of the beholder. Rather, we should ask how AI shifts power: Does it consolidate or redistribute that power? To put it in the frame of this book, does it continue to fortify the empire, or does it begin to wrest us back toward democracy?

卡鲁里在面向技术听众的演讲中重点探讨了人工智能的基础研究——科学家如何利用这个问题来评估应该构建哪种形式的人工智能，以及应该朝哪个方向推进该领域。她提出的问题对人工智能的所有其他方面都同样至关重要。我们应该如何开发人工智能应用程序？我们应该如何使用它们？最终，正如我在本书开篇所问，我们应该如何治理这项技术，将权力交还给人民？

Speaking to a technical audience, Kalluri focused her talk on fundamental AI research—how scientists could use this question to evaluate which forms of AI to build and which directions to advance the field. Her question is just as critical to all other aspects of AI. How should we develop AI applications; how should we use them; and, ultimately, as I asked at the start of this book, how do we govern this technology to shift power back to people?

Te Hiku、DAIR、Okinyi、Fuentes 和 Pena 的工作，都体现了重新分配权力可以且必须开展的工作。但治理的问题在于如何创造条件，让更多此类工作得以蓬勃发展。

The work of Te Hiku, of DAIR, of Okinyi, Fuentes, and Pena are each examples of the work that can and needs to be done to redistribute power. But the governance question is about how to create the conditions under which more of this work can proliferate and flourish.

卡鲁里在演讲中提出了不同权力轴的概念。本书涉及三个方面：知识、资源和影响力。目前，OpenAI 及其竞争对手帝国控制着这三个方面：通过集中人才、侵蚀开放科学以及封闭模型使其免受公众监督，他们控制着知识生产；通过囤积资金、数据、劳动力、计算能力、能源和土地，他们控制并削弱他人的资源；通过创造和强化它们推崇意识形态，并发起引发全球瞩目的、广受欢迎的示威游行，从而拥有深远的影响力。这些因素相互促进。控制知识生产可以增强影响力；不断增长的影响力可以积累资源；积累资源可以保障知识生产。

In her talk, Kalluri raised the idea of different axes of power. This book touches on three: knowledge, resources, and influence. As it stands now, OpenAI and its competitor empires have control of each of them: through centralizing talent, eroding open science, and sealing their models from public scrutiny, they control knowledge production; through hoarding funding, data, labor, compute, energy, and land, they control and diminish other people’s resources; through creating and reinforcing ideologies and producing wildly popular demonstrations that captivate global imagination, they command far-reaching influence. Each of these reinforces the other. Controlling knowledge production fuels influence; growing influence accumulates resources; amassing resources secures knowledge production.

因此，瓦解帝国的方案需要沿着每个轴线重新分配权力。我在此提出的建议和建议具有示范意义，但绝非面面俱到。首先，为了重新分配知识，我们需要更多资金来支持帝国之外的知识生产。这包括支持能够对企业模型进行独立评估的研究人员，这样我们就不会仅仅依赖企业来了解其能力。这包括支持像DAIR这样的组织，它们可以探索全新的研究方向，例如超越大型语言模型、数据和能源效率更高的新型人工智能。这包括支持像Te Hiku这样的组织，它们可以开发针对特定任务、由社区驱动的人工智能应用，从而增强边缘化社区的力量。独立的知识生产还包括记者和民间社会团体的工作，他们可以深入社区，实地考察，帮助我们理解这些技术影响的现实，而不仅仅是猜测。

The formula for dissolving empire thus requires the redistribution of power along each axis. The suggestions and recommendations I lay out here are exemplary but by no means comprehensive. First, to redistribute knowledge, we need greater funding to support its production outside the empire. That involves supporting researchers who can conduct independent evaluations of corporate models so we are not solely reliant on companies to understand their capabilities. It involves supporting organizations like DAIR that can pursue completely new directions of research, such as new forms of AI beyond large language models that are more efficient with data and energy. It involves supporting organizations like Te Hiku that can pursue task-specific, community-driven AI applications that strengthen marginalized communities. Independent knowledge production also includes the work of journalists and civil society groups who can embed within communities and be on the ground to help us understand, rather than merely speculate about, the textured realities of the impact of these technologies.

重新分配知识还需要制定政策，要求公司交出其模型和超级计算机的训练数据和技术规格的关键细节。只有这样，独立的企业模型评估人员才能开展工作。加州大学伯克利分校研究员黛博拉·拉吉在舒默论坛后继续与全球政策制定者保持沟通，她表示，这也是保障企业系统在现实世界中安全的最低标准。这里指的并非末日论中那种理论上的人工智能危害，而是现实世界中现有的危害，从歧视到虚假信息，再到工作自动化，如果广泛部署的模型未经适当测试，消费者和社区就可能面临这些危害。“我们有消费者金融保护局（CFPB）来监管消费金融产品。我们有美国食品药品监督管理局（FDA）来监管医疗器械。但不知何故，在人工智能产品方面，却完全没有监管，”拉吉说道。人工智能模型事实上，应该比普通产品要求更高的透明度。“这些是数据定义的系统。它们不是确定性的。所以我们需要更多地了解这些系统，才能理解它们在做什么。”

Redistributing knowledge will also need policies that require companies to relinquish key details about the training data and technical specifications of their models and supercomputers. Only then could independent corporate model evaluators do their work. UC Berkeley researcher Deborah Raji, who has continued to engage with global policymakers after the Schumer forums, says this is also a bare minimum for guaranteeing the real-world safety of corporate systems. That is, not the theoretical rogue AI harms of Doomerism, but the existing real-world harms, from discrimination to misinformation to job automation, that consumers and communities can already face if widely deployed models aren’t properly tested. “We have the CFPB that monitors consumer finance products. We have the FDA that monitors medical devices. But for some reason when it comes to AI products, there’s just no oversight,” Raji says. AI models should in fact require more transparency than the average product. “These are data-defined systems. They’re not deterministic. So we need to know more about these systems to understand what they’re doing.”

这种透明度对于衡量人工智能对环境的影响也至关重要。在这方面，其他产品已经接受了人工智能产品无需接受的评估。“如果你使用汽车，或者购买电器，你都会获得能源之星评级，”Hugging Face 的 Sasha Luccioni 说道。“但人工智能已经深深融入我们的社会，广泛应用于各种产品中，而我们却对这些系统的可持续性一无所知。”

Such transparency is additionally crucial for measuring the impact of AI on the environment. In this regard other products once again already submit to evaluations that AI products do not. “If you’re using a car, if you are buying an appliance, you have an Energy Star rating,” says Sasha Luccioni at Hugging Face. “But AI is so integrated into our society, so widely used in products, and we don’t have any information about the sustainability of these systems.”

有了这种透明度，我们还将开始沿着第二个轴线——资源——重新分配权力。通过将其模型的组成部分隐藏为知识产权，人工智能帝国迄今为止能够逍遥法外，无需获得任何荣誉、同意或补偿即可攫取他人的知识产权。公司训练数据的可视性将使这种攫取和剥削行为更加困难。公司供应链的可视性也将如此，包括他们在哪里签订劳务合同，以及他们在哪里谈判新的土地租赁以建造更多的发电厂和数据中心，而这些情况经常发生在空壳实体之下。

With this transparency, we would also begin to redistribute power along our second axis: resources. By hiding the ingredients of their models as their intellectual property, the empires of AI have thus far been able to get away with seizing other people’s IP without credit, consent, or compensation. Visibility into company training data would make such extractive and exploitative behavior far more difficult. So, too, would visibility into company supply chains, including where they contract their labor and where they’re negotiating new leases of land to build more power plants and data centers, which so often happens under shell entities.

重新分配资源还需要全面加强劳动保护，这不仅针对行业直接签约的数据工作者，也针对所有面临其产出被纳入训练数据或工作被自动化取代风险的工作者。好莱坞罢工成功地保障了编剧和演员免受某些人工智能用途的侵害，这凸显了工会在抵制人类劳动力贬值、工资压低以及人工智能公司将工人的财富从工人手中夺走方面将发挥的关键作用。

Redistributing resources also requires stronger labor protections across the board, not just for the data workers directly contracted by the industry but for all workers at risk of having their outputs co-opted into training data or their jobs being automated away. The Hollywood strikes, which successfully secured writers and actors protections against certain uses of AI, illustrated the critical role that unions will play in resisting the devaluing of human labor, the depression of wages, and the consolidation of money away from workers in the hands of AI companies.

最后，为了沿着我们的第三条轴线——影响力——重新分配权力，我们需要广泛的教育。要打破人工智能炒作带来的神秘感和幻想，关键在于让人们了解人工智能的工作原理、它的优势和劣势、塑造其发展的体系，以及开发这些技术的人员和公司的世界观及其易犯的错误。正如麻省理工学院教授、ELIZA 聊天机器人发明者 Joseph Weizenbaum 在 20 世纪 60 年代所说，“一旦某个程序揭开其神秘面纱，一旦其内在运作方式用足够浅显易懂的语言解释清楚，其魔力便会瓦解。我希望这本书能帮助人们理解。它建立在我之前众多致力于公共教育的学者、记者、活动家和教育工作者的成果之上。愿它成为一片新的基石，让更多后人能够奋起，建造。

Finally, to redistribute power along our third axis, influence, we need broad-based education. The antidote to the mysticism and mirage of AI hype is to teach people about how AI works, about its strengths and shortcomings, about the systems that shape its development, about the worldviews and fallibility of the people and companies developing these technologies. As Joseph Weizenbaum, MIT professor and inventor of the ELIZA chatbot, said in the 1960s, “Once a particular program is unmasked, once its inner workings are explained in language sufficiently plain to induce understanding, its magic crumbles away.” I hope this book is just one offering to help induce understanding. It builds on the work of the many scholars, journalists, activists, and educators before me who have dedicated themselves to public education. May it be a new ground upon which many more after will rise up and build.

致谢

Acknowledgments

本书的核心主题是信念。对深度学习的信念。对通用人工智能的信念。以及自信。信念如何动员和激励他人。谁值得相信，谁不值得相信。信念是一种强大而令人陶醉的东西。在我的职业生涯中，许多人对我和我的工作的信任，一直是我最大的动力。

A core theme of this book is belief. Belief in deep learning. Belief in AGI. Self-belief. How belief mobilizes and incites. Who is and isn’t to be believed. Belief is a powerful and intoxicating thing. And in my own career, it has been the belief of so many people in me and my work that has been my greatest enabler.

首先，我要感谢所有相信本书项目的人们。我尤其要感谢我所有的消息来源。许多人不顾法律或其他风险与我沟通，因为他们相信真相、透明和问责。许多人也非常慷慨地奉献自己的时间——邀请我到他们家做客，带我参观他们的社区，或者接受我长达十个小时、分阶段的采访。我永远不会将人们向记者敞开心扉的勇气视为理所当然。能够讲述你们的故事是我的荣幸。谢谢你们。没有你们，这本书根本不会存在。

Thank you first and foremost to the people who believed in this book project. I especially owe so much to all my sources. Many spoke to me despite legal or other risks because they believed in truth, transparency, and accountability. Many were also extremely generous with their time—inviting me to their homes, showing me around their communities, or sitting for upward of ten hours of interviews across multiple sessions. I will never take for granted the leap of faith someone makes to open up their heart and mind to a journalist. It is an absolute honor to tell your stories. Thank you. Without you, this book simply wouldn’t exist.

我由衷感谢我的优秀经纪人大卫·多勒 (David Doerrer)。在我有任何值得向他展示的作品之前，他首先投入时间和支持，帮助我发展本书的构思。正是凭借他的耐心、他探索性的问题，以及最重要的，他善意而坚定地指出我遇到的问题，我才开始明白，我零散的想法是如何构成一本书的基础的。

My sincere gratitude to David Doerrer, my wonderful agent, who was first to commit his time and support to me to develop my ideas for this book before I had anything worthy to show him. It was through his patience, his probing questions, and, most importantly, his ability to kindly and firmly tell me when something just wasn’t working that I began to see how my scattered collection of thoughts could form the basis of a book.

致企鹅出版社的斯科特·莫耶斯，他是所有作家都梦想的编辑，他能立即理解我的愿景，并始终如一地支持我。让我得以以最雄心勃勃的方式追求它。斯科特和安不仅在我的报道和写作过程中，充当着道德指南针和啦啦队员的角色，提供深刻而富有启发性的反馈意见，他还和安·戈多夫承诺企鹅出版社的资金和法律资源将用于支持本书的创作。报道和撰写这样一本书既昂贵又敏感，而且耗时。除了其他事项外，它还需要聘请研究人员和事实核查人员；支付机票、住宿、当地合作者、翻译和司机的费用，以便深入社区。斯科特和安让我能够完成所有这些工作，并全身心投入到这本书的创作中。

To Scott Moyers at Penguin Press, any writer’s dream of an editor, who immediately understood my vision and whose unfailing support ever since allowed me to pursue it in its most ambitious form. Not only was he a moral compass and cheerleader throughout my reporting and writing process, providing incisive and illuminating feedback, he and Ann Godoff also committed Penguin Press’s financial and legal resources to support the book’s creation. Reporting and writing a book like this is expensive, sensitive, and time-consuming. Among many other things, it requires hiring researchers and fact-checkers; paying for flights, accommodations, local collaborators, translators, and drivers to spend time on the ground embedded within communities. Scott and Ann made it possible for me to do all of that and to work on this book full time.

感谢企鹅出版社的米娅·康瑟尔 (Mia Council)，她犀利而富有同情心的编辑给了我所需的动力和安全感，让我敢于冒险，将我的写作提升到一个新的高度。她在幕后精湛的协调能力使整个编辑和制作过程感觉如此天衣无缝。我敢肯定，米娅如此巧妙地控制了后勤混乱，而我甚至没有看到其中一半。还要感谢企鹅出版社和企鹅兰登书屋美国和英国团队的其他杰出成员，包括广濑由纪 (Yuki Hirose)、盖尔·布鲁塞尔 (Gail Brussel)、朱莉·基扬 (Juli Kiyan)、丹妮尔·普拉夫斯基 (Danielle Plafsky)、劳拉·斯蒂克尼 (Laura Stickney)、金·沃克 (Kim Walker)、罗西·布朗 (Rosie Brown)、洛特·霍尔 (Lotte Hall)、凯伦·德齐孔斯基 (Karen Dziekonski)，以及其他许多我没有直接接触但对整个过程至关重要的人员。

To Mia Council at Penguin Press, whose sharp and compassionate edits gave me the prompting and security I needed to take risks in and push my writing to the next level. Her masterful coordination behind the scenes made the entire editing and production process feel so seamless. I am sure I didn’t even see half of the logistical chaos that Mia so expertly contained. Thank you also to the rest of the stellar Penguin Press and Penguin Random House US and UK teams, including Yuki Hirose, Gail Brussel, Juli Kiyan, Danielle Plafsky, Laura Stickney, Kim Walker, Rosie Brown, Lotte Hall, Karen Dziekonski, and the many others with whom I didn’t interface directly but were critical to the process.

感谢我杰出的事实核查团队：Lindsay Muscato、Matt Mahoney、Rima Parikh 和 Muriel Alarcón。他们四人都一丝不苟地审阅了草稿，将错综复杂的细节与文献和资料来源进行交叉核对，并对我的措辞进行压力测试。Matt 也支持了我书的早期研究，Lindsay 接听了我的许多电话，耐心地倾听我的意见，而 Rima 则不知何故将她的事实核查笔记变成了一出脱口秀。他们都是我的救星。

To my incredible fact-checking team: Lindsay Muscato, Matt Mahoney, Rima Parikh, and Muriel Alarcón. All four of them fastidiously combed through the draft, cross-checking the labyrinth of details against documents and sources, and stress-testing my word choices. Matt also supported early research in my book, and Lindsay fielded many calls from me to serve as the most patient sounding board, while Rima somehow turned her fact-checking notes into standup comedy. They are all lifesavers.

穆里尔也是我在智利和乌拉圭的出色报道搭档。她简直就是个奇迹：在两周不间断的报道中，她负责研究、协调采访、寻找消息来源，还兼任翻译和司机，一切都充满了美好而愉悦的活力。我们一起经历了许多欢笑和冒险。

Muriel was also my reporting partner extraordinaire in Chile and Uruguay. She is a one-woman wonder: She conducted research, coordinated interviews, chased down sources, and played both translator and driver across two weeks of nonstop reporting, all with the most beautiful, joyous energy. We had so many great laughs and adventures.

感谢所有在我报道之旅中给予我支持的人，特别是 Stephen Thuo Kiguru，他是我在内罗毕的勇敢向导，他总是在我需要的时候出现，他的幽默和不懈的乐观精神让我始终保持镇定，即使在有人报警后，他依然保持镇定。由于严重的沟通失误，我们的旅行全部泡汤了。那是另一个故事了。

Thank you to everyone else who supported me in my reporting trips, especially Stephen Thuo Kiguru, my intrepid guide through Nairobi who was there for anything I needed and whose humor and relentless optimism remained unflappable even when someone called the cops on him after one of our excursions due to a gross miscommunication. That is a story for another time.

感谢我亲爱的朋友和导师：Angela Chen、Gideon Lichfield、Roger McNamee、Brenda Guadalupe López Alatorre、Jose Manuel Rodriguez Moreno、Bina Venkataraman 和 Tate Ryan-Mosley，他们慷慨地阅读了本书的初稿或各种节选，并给予我明智而宝贵的反馈。感谢 Oren Etzioni，他慷慨地审阅了我对人工智能历史的叙述以及我对人工智能研究的所有技术解释，以确保其正确无误且细致入微。感谢 Ria Kalluri，早在我们开始研究人工智能发展的殖民性质之前，她的友谊就是我的力量和快乐的源泉，她在这个问题上的智慧和道德清晰一直是我的指路明灯。

To my dear friends and mentors: Angela Chen, Gideon Lichfield, Roger McNamee, Brenda Guadalupe López Alatorre, Jose Manuel Rodriguez Moreno, Bina Venkataraman, and Tate Ryan-Mosley, who generously read early drafts of the book or various excerpts and gave me wise and invaluable feedback. To Oren Etzioni, who graciously reviewed my recounting of AI history and all of my technical explanations of AI research to ensure they were correct and appropriately nuanced. To Ria Kalluri, whose friendship was a source of strength and joy long before we both began investigating the colonial nature of AI development, and whose intellectual and moral clarity on the subject has been a guiding light.

本书还借鉴了我整个新闻职业生涯中所做的报道和工作。如果不感谢一路上支持我的所有人，那将是多么的失责。我非常感谢我在Quartz的编辑 Janet Guyon，她是第一个明白自己在说什么的人，她告诉我，她相信我能成为一名伟大的记者。我还要感谢当时担任《麻省理工科技评论》主编的 Gideon，他打了个疯狂的赌，给了我第一份全职新闻工作，而且是报道人工智能，这让我踏上了一段我从未想象过的长达数年的旅程。我还要感谢我在《科技评论》的编辑 Niall Firth，有一天他对我说，你为什么不报道一下 OpenAI？当时我从来没有报道过任何公司。无论出于什么原因，Niall 相信我能做到。而我更加努力，不断鞭策自己，以证明他是对的。

This book also draws upon reporting and work I did throughout my journalism career. I would be remiss not to thank all of the people who supported me along the way. All my gratitude to Janet Guyon, my editor at Quartz, who was the first person who knew what she was talking about to tell me she believed I could make a great journalist. To Gideon, then the editor in chief of MIT Technology Review, who made a crazy bet to give me my first full-time job in journalism, to cover artificial intelligence, no less, putting me on a yearslong journey I could have never imagined. To Niall Firth, my editor at Tech Review, who said to me one day, Why don’t you profile OpenAI? when I had never profiled a company before. For whatever reason, Niall believed I could do it. And I worked harder and pushed myself further to prove him right.

当我开始意识到人工智能正在加剧的全球巨大不平等时，尼尔（Niall）也对我新的研究方向提供了重要的支持。我在第四章中提到的同事安吉拉（Angela）也给予了我很大的帮助。她从现有的学术研究中发现了“数据殖民主义”这个术语，并帮助我找到了正确的方向。接替吉迪恩担任主编的马特·霍南（Mat Honan）很快就理解了我研究的重要性，并全心全意地支持我继续深入研究。

When I started realizing and turning my attention to the vast global inequality that AI was perpetuating, Niall was also instrumental in supporting my new line of inquiry, as was Angela, the colleague I referenced in chapter 4 who identified the phrase “data colonialism” in existing scholarship and helped point me in the right direction. Mat Honan, who took over from Gideon as chief editor, quickly understood the importance of my investigations and wholeheartedly supported me in pursuing them further.

2021年末，我离开《科技评论》杂志，在麻省理工学院奈特科学新闻奖学金和普利策中心人工智能问责基金的大力支持下，开展了一项为期六个月的关于“人工智能殖民主义”的报道项目。我非常感谢黛博拉·布鲁姆和阿什利·斯马特麻省理工学院KSJ以及普利策中心的Marina Walker Guevara和Boyoung Lim为我提供资金，让我在疫情期间开展如此浩大的计划。最终成果是一系列四集的系列报道，涵盖了南非、委内瑞拉、印度尼西亚和新西兰的报道，这为我的论文奠定了基础，并最终成为了本书的标题。感谢我在这些报道中杰出的合作者：Heidi Swart、Andrea Paola Hernández和Nadine Freischlad，她们的报道专业知识、语言能力以及深厚的本土文化背景，使这些报道更加丰富，远超我独自完成的成果。正是在Marina富有远见的全球新闻合作领导下，我才与Heidi、Andrea和Nadine建立了联系，并学习到了一种处理全球报道项目的新方法。普利策中心的人工智能问责网络汇集了来自世界各地的记者，共同推进人工智能问责报道，如今已成为我最重要的职业社群之一。

In late 2021, I went on leave from Tech Review to pursue a six-month reporting project about “AI colonialism” with the wonderful support of MIT’s Knight Science Journalism fellowship and a Pulitzer Center AI Accountability grant. I am indebted to Deborah Blum and Ashley Smart at MIT KSJ and Marina Walker Guevara and Boyoung Lim at the Pulitzer Center for giving me the funding to pursue such an expansive project in the middle of the pandemic. The result, a four-part series with stories from South Africa, Venezuela, Indonesia, and New Zealand, laid the groundwork for the thesis and, ultimately, the title of this book. Thank you to my incredible collaborators on those stories: Heidi Swart, Andrea Paola Hernández, and Nadine Freischlad, whose reporting expertise, language skills, and deep local and cultural context made those stories richer than I ever could have alone. It was under Marina’s visionary leadership in global journalistic collaborations that I connected with Heidi, Andrea, and Nadine in the first place, and learned a new approach for tackling globe-spanning reporting projects. The Pulitzer Center’s AI Accountability Network, which brings together journalists from around the world to advance AI accountability reporting, has since become one of my most important professional communities.

在《华尔街日报》工作时，是我的编辑 Josh Chin 首先鼓励我撰写一篇最终成为头版新闻的文章，文章内容是关于 Mophat Okinyi 和与 OpenAI 签约的肯尼亚工人；Drew Dowell 和 Jason Dean 帮助我确保了我的报道之旅，使之成为现实。在《大西洋月刊》工作时，当我向我的编辑 Damon Beres 撰写一篇关于人工智能背后的计算基础设施对环境影响的古怪故事时，他无需任何说服；Paul Bisceglio 和 Adrienne LaFrance 也无需任何说服，他们就批准了我另一次前往亚利桑那州的报道之旅。还要感谢 Bradley Olson、Deepa Seetharaman、Daniel Engber 和 Matteo Wong 帮助我将这些故事变成现实。与两家出版物中我独一无二的同事一起工作，让我对以最高水平报道和撰写故事的意义有了全新的理解。

At The Wall Street Journal, it was my editor Josh Chin who first encouraged me to pitch what ultimately became a front-page story about Mophat Okinyi and the Kenyan workers who contracted for OpenAI; Drew Dowell and Jason Dean helped secure my reporting trip to make it happen. At The Atlantic, my editor Damon Beres needed no convincing when I pitched him a wonky story about the environmental impacts of the computing infrastructure behind AI, nor did Paul Bisceglio or Adrienne LaFrance, who green-lit another reporting trip to Arizona. Thank you also to Bradley Olson, Deepa Seetharaman, Daniel Engber, and Matteo Wong for helping me bring those stories to fruition. Working alongside my inimitable colleagues at both publications gave me a whole new understanding of what it means to report and write stories at the highest levels of mastery.

最后，我要向我的家人表达我最深切的爱与感激。我的妈妈，她在我小时候就看到了我对写作的热爱，并倾尽所有帮助我实现梦想。我的爸爸，他从未犹豫过，竭尽所能地支持我。我的奶奶，我取之不尽的灵感源泉。我的公婆，他们明智地提醒我要珍惜过程，庆祝胜利。我的丈夫：我最好的朋友、人生伴侣、道德指南针、啦啦队员、头号粉丝、早期读者、倾听者、建议者、无尽的浪漫主义者。爱你和被你爱是我一切的基石。

Finally, my deepest love and gratitude to my family. To my mom, who saw my love of writing as a little girl and poured everything she ever had into helping me achieve my dreams. To my dad, who never once questioned doing whatever he could to support me. To my 奶奶, my unending source of inspiration. To my in-laws, who wisely remind me to savor the process and celebrate the wins. To my husband: best friend, life partner, moral compass, cheerleader, number one fan, early reader, sounding board, advice giver, endless romantic. Loving you and being loved by you is my foundation for everything.

笔记

第一章 君权神授

Chapter 1: Divine Right

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

就好像，马斯克：马斯克对奥特曼的看法、马斯克共同创立OpenAI的经历以及马斯克对人工智能看法的演变，很大程度上基于马斯克于2024年2月29日对奥特曼、布罗克曼和OpenAI提起的诉讼，并于2024年8月5日再次提起诉讼：Musk v. Altman, No. 4:24-cv-04722, CourtListener (ND Cal. August 5, 2024)。其他内容主要来自Maureen Dowd的“埃隆·马斯克的未来冲击”，《名利场》 ，2017年4月，archive.vanityfair.com /article/2017/4/elon-musks-future-shock ；以及Walter Isaacson的《埃隆·马斯克》（西蒙与舒斯特出版社，2023年），第239–44页，Kindle。

It was as if, Musk: Musk’s views on Altman, Musk’s experience cofounding OpenAI, and the evolution of Musk’s views on AI are largely based on a lawsuit Musk filed against Altman, Brockman, and OpenAI on February 29, 2024, and refiled on August 5, 2024: Musk v. Altman, No. 4:24-cv-04722, CourtListener (N.D. Cal. August 5, 2024). Additional color comes primarily from Maureen Dowd, “Elon Musk’s Future Shock,” Vanity Fair, April 2017, archive.vanityfair.com/article/2017/4/elon-musks-future-shock; and Walter Isaacson, Elon Musk (Simon & Schuster, 2023), 239–44, Kindle.

Selbst 的论文《大数据的不同影响》对理解人工智能如何导致歧视做出了早期的开创性贡献，该论文发表于《加州法律评论》 104，第3期（2016年）：671–732，ssrn.com/abstract= 2477899。此外，还有一篇报道深入探讨了这种歧视在实践中是如何体现的：Karen Hao 的论文《即将到来的针对使人们陷入贫困的隐藏算法的战争》，发表于《麻省理工学院技术评论》 ，2020 年 12 月 4 日，technologyreview.com/ 2020/12/04/1013068/algorithms-create-a-poverty-trap-lawyers-fight-back 。

Selbst, “Big Data’s Disparate Impact,” California Law Review 104, no. 3 (2016): 671–732, ssrn.com/abstract=2477899. Here’s also a story that dives more into how this discrimination plays out in practice: Karen Hao, “The Coming War on the Hidden Algorithms that Trap People in Poverty,” MIT Technology Review, December 4, 2020, technologyreview.com/2020/12/04/1013068/algorithms-create-a-poverty-trap-lawyers-fight-back.

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

Altman 负责监督 Mayo 办公室的工作：我用谷歌图片反向搜索办公室照片估算了家具的价格。当我试图联系负责 OpenAI Mayo 办公室的建筑公司，询问确切价格，并确认我的描述（“办公室里的螺旋楼梯是用木头和石头做的，准确吗？”）时，有人回复说，该公司签署了保密协议，无法谈论这个项目。

Altman would oversee Mayo’s: I estimated the price of the furniture by reverse image searching photos of the office with Google Images. When I tried to get the exact price from the architecture firm that worked on OpenAI’s Mayo office as well as confirmation of my descriptions (“Is it accurate to say the spiral staircase in the office is made of wood and stone?”), a person replied that the firm is under an NDA and cannot speak about the project.

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

“能够解决问题的技术”：最初的白皮书写于2019年，并于2022年发表在同行评议期刊上。引用的段落在2022年版本中被编辑为：“许多应对气候变化的技术工具已经问世多年，但尚未被社会大规模采用。虽然我们希望机器学习能够加速制定有效的气候行动战略，但人类也必须决定采取行动。” David Rolnick、Priya L. Donti、Lynn H. “Technologies that would address”: The original white paper was written in 2019; it was published in a peer-reviewed journal in 2022. The quoted passage was edited in the 2022 version to: “Many technological tools useful in addressing climate change have been available for years but have yet to be adopted at scale by society. While we hope that ML will be useful in accelerating effective strategies for climate action, humanity also must decide to act.” David Rolnick, Priya L. Donti, Lynn H. Kaack, Kelly Kochanski, Alexandre Lacoste, Kris Sankaran et al., “Tackling Climate Change with Machine Learning,” ACM Computing Surveys (CSUR) 55, no. 2 (February 2022): 1–96, doi.org/10.1145/3485128.

第四章：现代性的梦想

Chapter 4: Dreams of Modernity

作者指出： Daron Acemoglu 和 Simon Johnson，权力与进步：我们对技术与繁荣的千年斗争(PublicAffairs，2023 年)，129–33。

The authors point to: Daron Acemoglu and Simon Johnson, Power and Progress: Our Thousand-Year Struggle over Technology and Prosperity (PublicAffairs, 2023), 129–33.

转至正文注释参考

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

1956 年，六年后：他们在夏季研讨会上计划做的事情的简介：John McCarthy、Marvin L. Minsky、Nathaniel Rochester 和 Claude E. Shannon，《达特茅斯人工智能夏季研究项目提案》，斯坦福大学，1955 年 8 月 31 日，jmc.stanford.edu/ articles/dartmouth/dartmouth.pdf 。

In 1956, six years after: The brief of what they planned to do at the summer workshop: John McCarthy, Marvin L. Minsky, Nathaniel Rochester, and Claude E. Shannon, “A Proposal for the Dartmouth Summer Research Project on Artificial Intelligence,” Stanford University, August 31, 1955, jmc.stanford.edu/articles/dartmouth/dartmouth.pdf.

转至正文注释参考

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

达特茅斯教授约翰·麦卡锡：起初，约翰·麦卡锡、克劳德·香农等人将研究论文汇编成一本关于同一组后来被称为人工智能的理念的文集，名为《自动机研究》，并于1956年出版。麦卡锡对人们提交的论文及其缺乏雄心壮志感到失望。他说，正是这种失望促使他开始使用“人工智能”一词。

John McCarthy, the Dartmouth professor: At first, John McCarthy, Claude Shannon, and others collected research papers into a compendium on the same set of ideas that would be called AI and titled it “Automata Studies,” which was published in 1956. McCarthy was disappointed by the papers that people submitted and their lack of ambition. He said it was that disappointment that led him to begin using the term artificial intelligence.

转至正文注释参考

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

19 世纪初：凯特·克劳福德，《人工智能地图集：权力、政治和人工智能的全球成本》（耶鲁大学出版社，2021 年），第 123 页。

In the early 1800s: Kate Crawford, Atlas of AI: Power, Politics, and the Planetary Costs of Artificial Intelligence (Yale University Press, 2021), 123.

转至正文注释参考

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

2007 年修订版： John McCarthy，“什么是人工智能？”，John McCarthy 主页，形式推理小组，2007 年 11 月 12 日，www-formal.stanford.edu/ jmc/whatisai.pdf 。

A 2007 revision: John McCarthy, “What Is Artificial Intelligence?,” John McCarthy’s Home Page, Formal Reasoning Group, November 12, 2007, www-formal.stanford.edu/jmc/whatisai.pdf.

转至正文注释参考

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

人工智能发展的目标：詹娜·伯雷尔 (Jenna Burrell)，“人工智能和不断“未来的后退地平线”，科技政策出版社，2023 年 6 月 6 日，techpolicy.press/ artificial-intelligence-and-the-ever-receding-horizon-of-the-future 。

The goalposts for AI development: Jenna Burrell, “Artificial Intelligence and the Ever-Receding Horizon of the Future,” Tech Policy Press, June 6, 2023, techpolicy.press/artificial-intelligence-and-the-ever-receding-horizon-of-the-future.

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

1969年，他与人合著了一本书：《Marvin Minsky 和 Seymour A. Papert，感知器：计算几何导论》（麻省理工学院出版社，1969年）。

In 1969, he coauthored a book: Marvin Minsky and Seymour A. Papert, Perceptrons: An Introduction to Computational Geometry (MIT Press, 1969).

GO TO NOTE REFERENCE IN TEXT

然而，在底层： Joseph Weizenbaum，《ELIZA——一个用于研究人机自然语言交流的计算机程序》，《ACM 通讯》 9，第 1 期（1966 年 1 月）：36–45，doi.org/ 10.1145/365153.365168 。
